column2: Censorship and other barriers to the free flow of news across international boundaries gained ground in 1969 in the Middle East, but they lessened in Portugal.

OBERSTAUFEN, West Germany, Jan. 3 (AP) Berni Rauter, a 20-year-old Austrian blonde, mastered an icy second run that knocked out 13 topseeded racers and won the special slalom today in the World Cup ski meet. Only 18 of the 91 starters completed both runs.
The days of the meter reader may be numbered.

OTTAWA, Jan. 3 Jean Le- sage, father of Quebec's "quiet revolution" in the early nineteen-sixties and one of Canada's most influential politicians for a decade, is quietly ending his career as leader of the Quebec Liberal party.

BEIRUT, Jan. 3 A Government communique reported today that the Lebanese Army killed three Israeli soldiers during the raid on an outpost at Tal Nahas, near the Israeli border. The communique added that the Israelis blew up several buildings before withdrawing.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 3 Vice President Agnew said today that the United States' allies in Asia understood, the Nixon doctrine of regional self- reliance, but wanted to hear it again because they are "frightened" of Communist China.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 3 (Reuters) An Indonesian Government spokesman said today that high-ranking Indonesian Army officers were being arrested because they opposed and wanted to change the present administration.

A smart little red-and-white cocker spaniel named Upsan Down's Colleen, owned by Mrs. Robert E. Grimshaw of Norwich, Conn., became dogdom's New Year's baby yesterday when she emerged as winner of the Futurity that always is an opening-day highlight of the American Spaniel Club's national speciality.

THE National Theater of Andorra, headed by Joachim Gotthelfen, has just arrived for its first series of performances in the United States. Gotthelfen, a slim, intense man in his late thirties, immediately made short shrift of just about every contemporary theatrical hero.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 3 (AP) Tommy Bell, the referee, headed the list of officials named today by Commissioner Pete Rozelle for the National Football League title game tomorrow.
MIAMI, Jan. 3 (AP) Bart Starr, quarterback for the Green Bay Packers, was presented with the first annual Gladiator of the Year Award today during half-time ceremonies of the Playoff Bowl.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 (UPI) Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, United States commander in Vietnam, was discharged from a military hospital today, "fully recovered" from pneumonia, a military spokesman said.

PARIS There are many indications that a dark horse may soon join the struggle for leadership of the Democratic party when Sargent Shriver, U.S. Ambassador to France, departs in order to seek his party's nomination and election as Governor of Maryland. Nothing is definite but if Shriver decides to enter the race he must announce his intention before this spring's primary.

MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Jan. 3 (UPI) Larry Mowry, a sixyear competitor on the Professional Golfers' Association tour, added a 69 today to his opening-round 70 for a three-underpar 139 and a two-stroke lead after 36 holes of the $52,000 Southern California open golf tournament.

Militant young Puerto Ricans who seized a Methodist church in East Harlem last Sunday vowed yesterday to continue their occupation until the police forcefully removed them or until church officials agreed to let them run a breakfast proggram for children there.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 3 The radar station airlifted last week by Israeli commandos from the Red Sea coast of Egypt was described here tonight as the Soviet P-12 type designed to detect low-flying aircraft.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 3 With lustrous drivers like Jackie Stewart, Graham Hill, Bruce McLaren, Chris Amon and the late Jim Clark, the Tasman Series has always enjoyed a glamorous perch in motor racing. In the last few years, though, this program of seven races in New Zealand and Australia has not been a great financial success.
THERE is a most notaable trend in the house plant hobby toward miniatures. These are plants that "grow small in comparison to the average type of the same genera."

CHARLESTON, W.Va., Jan. 3 Miss Christine Llewellyn Jones was married here this afternoon to Joel Cook Huber 3d, son of Mrs. Thomas Willing Huber of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Mr. Huber Jr. of Haverford, Pa. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Erskine Jones Jr. of Charleston.
Miss Helen Ann Bloom, a public relations consultant in London, plans to be married to Richard M. Lewis, who is with the International Publishing Corporation, Ltd., there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird indicated today that he would not rule out expansion of the controversial Safeguard antiballistic missile system from the two sites now approved.
A reputed Mafia leader, indicted as a result of a letter sent by a man who died the day after he wrote it, will go on trial with three other men in Federal Court in Newark tomorrow.

MIAMI, Jan. 3 (AP) Although George Allen and his Los Angeles Rams received only $1,200 apiece for defeating Dallas today in the National Football League Playoff Bowl the personable coach said the victory was priceless.
Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein, Talmudic scholar, teacher and author, died on Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 229 West 78th Street.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3 Lester F. Avnet, honorary chairman of Avnet, Inc., one of the country's major electronics corporations, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital after having suffered a heart attack. He was 57 years old and maintained residences here and in Kings Point, L.I.
ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 3 Lake Apopka, which covers 50 square miles, will be drained and its bottom exposed to sunlight for several weeks in an attempt to rid the lake of pollution.

BIEL, Switzerland There is a basic difference between Europeans and Americans when they sit down to plan a holiday trip. The expansive, outgoing American is likely to embrace two or three or more countries, covering as much terrain as he can physically encompass in his vacation weeks. The European, on the contrary, is more likely to carve out a small section of a country, possibly even his own country, and concentrate his holiday time therein.
The number of apartment dwellers complaining of lack of heat soared to 300 an hour during certain periods yesterday, a spokesman for the city said.

Every America's Cup year the story is repeated that when the United States finally loses a defense series, the head of the losing skipper will replace the famous sailing prixe on a stand at the New York Yacht Club. This could be the decade. There will he four chances for somebody to get his head on display before 1980 if the three-year interval between cup matches is maintained.

TOKYO This nation of one hundred million people has entered the decade of the 1970's with a new political map. There is general agreement that the Dec. 27 election for the House of Representatives, which saw a great victory for the conservative Liberal-Democrats and a smashing defeat for the Socialists marks the end of an era.

The inside lane position in track is usually a desirable spot for a runner. But when Denis Fikes drew that position yesterday before the mile run in the ninth annual Iona College Spike Shoe Club schoolboy meet he was most unhappy.

When he died suddenly of a heart attack in 1963, Mac Hyman was 40, distressingly restless, and the author of a novel, "No Time for Sergeants" (which was also a successful play and film), three short stories and an article. A second novel, "Take Now Thy Son," on which he had worked for most of his adult life, was published a few years after his death, but received little attention.
LIMA, Peru, Jan. 3 (AP) The Peruvian Government applied a provision of its strongly protested new "freedom of the press" law today, fining almost every newspaper in Lima.
WILTON, Conn., Jan. 3 Miss Whitney Ann Beekman Burnett and Robert Irving Stevens 2d, were married here today in St. Mathew's Episcopate Church. The Rev. Roger O. Douglas performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 It was not until early December that one sensed he might be seeing something historic. It was Dec. 14, in fact, and Junius Loftlubber, fabled interior lineman for the McKeesport Duckbill Platypuses had just been assisted from the field by his colleagues.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 3 A cold-shooting Princeton squad relied on tight defense and 26 points from co-captain Jeff Petrie to gain a 75-50 victory over Rutgers today.
The basic ingredients of a corporate merger include products, profits and money. But the most important ingredient is people.
The National Conference of Black Students in Medicine announced last week the establishment of a national clearinghouse "to effectively channel medical school applications of black students."
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 3 An off-duty Negro policeman shot and killed a Puerto Rican youth in downtown Jersey City today following a street argument, the police said.
NEW models of decorative plants are of as much value to man's welfare and economy as any other agricultural and horticultural plants.
LAUREL, Md., Jan. 3 (AP) Laurel race course felt the effects of competition from Philadelphia's new Liberty Bell track during the 49-day meeting that ended today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) Nearly $27-billion in Social Security benefits were paid out last year, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today. The checks reached one of every eight Americans.

The Scientists Institute for Public Information, a New York City organization, is preparing a series of workbooks on major environmental problems for concerned citizens, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Margaret Mead, the newly elected president of the institute.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 3 (UPI) Gladys Aylward, a British missionary whose life story was depicted in the motion picture, "Inn of the Sixth Happiness," died today here of pneumonia. She was 67 years old.

As he told it to an Israeli court, Denis Michael Rohan believed he had been chosen by God to build a temple to Jesus in Jerusalem at the site of the Hebrew temple that was destroyed in 70 A.D. That was why, he said, he had tried to burn down the Al Aksa Mosque, which stands on the same site.

Randall Jarrell once wrote that his heart, confronted by the supermarket offerings of public media, was sad; but that same sad heart, offered a good book, reacted with an almost disorderly passion of gratitude, and these posthumous essays and reviews (all previously published) breathe on every page the pleasure of suspended deprivation, as if the child with his nose pressed to the sweetshop window (Yeats's phrase about Keats) had suddenly been given a cake.
NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 President Nixon, dressed in golf clothes, took a couple of stiff practice swings today, felt the small of his back and turned away from his ball in mock agony.

WHEN the American Association for the Advancement of Science decided to hold its 1969 annual meeting in Boston, Agnes Mongan, director of Harvard's Fogg Art Museum, was given the nudge to come through with a hospitable gesture of a cultural nature. Like a good housewife after a successful inventory of the freezer in a comparable emergency, the Fogg has turned out an art-and-science exhibition drawn from Harvard's historical collections in both fields.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Jan. 3 St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Direxa Virginia Dick to Christopher Farrell Dearie, a lawyer with the New York firm of Carter, Ledyard Milburn.

PLAINVIEW, L.I., Jan. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Graham R. Freer have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet G. Freer, to Midshipman Michael D. Malone, a first clansman at the United States Naval Academy. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Malone of Farmingdale.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 3 (AP) Gov. Marvin Mandel today banned the use of DDT and several other pesticides in Maryland except when public health is endangered by a threat of epidemic.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market advanced last week in active trading.

RUMSON, N.J., Jan. 3 The marriage of Miss Lezlie Feiring, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce C. Feiring of Fair Haven, to Robert Dominic Migliara of Nutley took place here this afternoon in St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church. The Rev. George Willis performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfonse C. Migliara of Margate, Fla.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 3 Performing in a snowstorm that made visibility poor and the landing area sticky, Karl Bohler of nearby Peekskill topped a small field in the 25th annual Torger Tokle Memorial ski jumping tournament today.
BLOOMINGTON; Minn., Jan. 3 Much as they did not want to, the New York Rangers had to settle for a tie with the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

WHEN a very funny idea is too broad an idea for the play it's in, some- one's been napping somewhere. The idea I'm thinking about this wintry Sunday is one that turns up in the third act (or third play, since each act is a law unto itself) of Neil Simon's "Last of the Red Hot Lovers."
MADRID Much of Spain's attenuated political life consists of the struggle of factions within the regime to assure, themselves of jobs now and an inside track for the future, postFranco era.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 3 (Agence France-Presse) Interior Minister Nanlo Bamba disclosed this week that a secessionist movement among the Agni tribesmen in the southeast of this West African nation had flared recently, long after it was thought to be dead.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 3 Out on Kraus's Kastle, a 10-foot-square raft bobbing gently in frigid Manhasset Bay, Frostbite Yacht Club officials worked to keep warm. Breathing smoke and drinking fire water, they took turns chipping ice in preparation for the 39th annual regatta that began last Thursday and ends today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The Treasury Department announced today that its antinarcotics forces, reinforced by 685 new agents, were being thrown into a New York-centered drive against heroin smuggling.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 3 (UPI) Mickey Thompson, a race-car builder, informed his sister, Mrs. Coleen Thompson,Campbell, by telephone tonight that he had suffered four broken ribs and a broken arm when a snowmobile in which he was ridine overturned.
"What's been going on in Times Square is now spreading out into the neighborhoods," a City Councilman said yesterday in proposing legislation to penalize movie theaters that show obscene films.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 The 1970 session of the New York Legislature will convene Wednesday to find the problems of the decade just past have spilled over into the new one.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 The new year is bringing an old problem crime to the forefront as a major issue of the 1970 Congressional campaign.

Too many yacht races have been spoiled because wind shifts have destroyed planned windward legs that test helmsmen's skills most, leaving reaching and running the only points of sailing. The Royal Canadian
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 The 1965 apportionment plan for Congressional districts in Illinois was declared unconstitutional this week.
SALEM, Ore., Jan. 3 Wayne Morse is returning to Oregon early next week with an answer, his friends and enemies hope, to two persistent questions:

Two Nigerian Army divisions linking up on the road from Aba to Umuahia apparently have reduced what was left of Biafra by a third. If federal forces also have finally secured the road between Awka and Onitsha, they have accomplished a step essential for an effective drive on the Uli airstrip, Biafra's only major link with the outside world.

WASHINGTON The possibility of an end to the draft, with the armed forces moving into the marketplace to compete for young men like the rest of the nation's employers, seemed one step closer last week. There were reports that a prestigious Presidential commission was about to declare such a move entirely feasible and not outrageously expensive.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 3 Miss Janet Stephens Buehler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Stephens Buehler, was married today to Lieut. (jg.) Christian Emil Kaefer, U.S.N., executive officer of the minesweeper Fidelity, based in Baltimore.

On a blackboard during the philosophers' convention in New York last week appeared this message: "When critical philosophers point their finger to reality, orthodox philosophers study the finger. Power to the People."

DEMAREST, N.J., Jan. 3 The marriage of Miss Constance Thayer Cory, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Cory of Demarest and Amagansett, L.I., to Roger Clark Williams took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. William Nye, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

NANTUCKET ISLAND, Mass., Jan. 3 Miss Wendy Elizabeth Spinney Wise and John Cambron Mathis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mathis of Webster Groves, Mo., were married here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary, Our Lady of the Isle.
Demands for funds in the international bond market are likely to keep interest rates high for the next several months.

THE growth of Interstate highways and the advent of automobiles that need servicing less frequently are having a profound effect on the design of gasoline stations, especially those situated near superhighway exit and entrance ramps.

IN the face of the rising awareness that the future happiness of most of us will turn upon our ability to solve the problem of the cities, it would appear that everyone must now become concerned with the proper role of "local participation" in the scheme of government. Especially must we be concerned as to the impact of local participation on the planning of our physical urban environment.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP) Jerry Meyer, a trainer, and Hugo Dittfach, a jockey, accounted for their second stakes victory in three days at Liberty Bell Park today when Herbert E. Wilson's Arrolane won the $28,175 Allegheny Stakes by a length and a quarter.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 3 (UPI) Homicide investigators have color movies of the fatal stabbing of an 18-year-old youth at last month's Rolling Stones rock festival at the Altamount race track but have been unable to make an arrest.

A study of the state of freedom around the world has concluded that 1969 was a year of net losses for Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America. The report, by Freedom House, found net gains in freedom only in Western Europe and the United States and no real change in Eastern Europe.

The weather shelter on Grover Danford's pony farm in Wolverton, Tenn. shelters more than ponies. A lot of courtin' goes on under it too. Here Grower has trysted with his beautiful mistress, Kathlee, whom the local color bar prevented him from marrying. Here the farm's foreman, Jim Whittaker, had courted his wife. And here, Jeff Bazemore,

COPENHAGEN, Denmark Nearly horizontal Copenhagen is not a city that comes to mind when one thinks of climbing. Yet Copen hagen, Denmark's capital and Scandinavia's largest city, offers an urbanized variety of climbing (up towers) that is especially appealing to those who retain the childhood urge to explore the "secret" parts of old buildings.

PARIS, Jan. 3 (UPI) French dockers loaded a cargo of 200 tons of French munitions aboard an Iraqi freighter today near the moorings from which five French-made Israeli gunboats slipped out of Cherbourg on Christmas to go to Haifa.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 3 The Brazilian Foreign Ministry has announced it will be totally installed in Brasilia next April, completing a move that will force international recognition of Brazil's inland capital.
BONN, Jan. 3 The 1,310 miles of hastily built autobahns that the Hitler era left West Germany will be virtually replaced by 1985.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 3 Full political activity is resuming in Pakistan after a period of more than nine months in which it had been restricted.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 3 The 1970 session of the Pennsylvania legislature will convene at noon Tuesday with an unsolved tax problem involving more than $200-million left on its doorstep by the still linger- ing 1969 session.
MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (UPI) Jacques Lemaire scored twice tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens out of a four-game slump with a 5-1 victory over the Oakland Seals in a National Hockey League game.

SEATTLE, Jan. 3 (UPI) A group of businessmen said today they must raise $3.5-million "right now" or possibly give up plans to purchase the Seattle Pilots and keep the American League baseball team here.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 3 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Barkhouse Jr. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Barkhouse, to Alan B. Daroff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell A. Daroff of Philadelphia.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 (AP) A television newscaster on the American Forces Vietnam Network charged over the air today that a broadcast on the network "is not free to tell the truth."

WASHINGTON If 1969 was hardly a year of good news on most fronts, it closed with the most satisfactory situation in years in an area that had produced its share of troubles the international monetary system.

VIENTIANE, Laos. IF the Congressional subcommittee looking into United States in volvement in Laos had paid a visit to this capital city in the guise of ordinary tourists, its members might have come away with at least two unexpected impressions. First of
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 3 (AP) Ron Gutkowski of Michigan State grabbed a rebound and scored as the game ended today to give the Spartans an 85-84 victory over Indiana in a Big Ten basketball opener.

Bob Beamon, the world long jump record-holder, wore Adelphi's colors for the first time yesterday and won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's senior long jump championship with a leap of 24 feet 4 inches. Beamon had transferred to Adelphi after attending colleges in North Carolina and Texas.

MIAMI, Jan, 3 Roman Ga-briel hurled scoring passes of 35 arid 67 yards the first two times Los Angeles had the ball today, then he added two touchdown aerials in the second Half as the Rams trounced the Dallas Cowboys, 31-0, in the National Football League Playoff Bowl.

SPORTS races into the seventies with every expectation that the dizzying expansion of the last decade will continue, that top athletes will get richer than ever, that ticket sales and television revenues will continue to rise and that all sorts of things will have happened before the final forward pass of the decade is flung in 1979.

TRENTON, Jan. 3 Some companies that sell auto insurance in New Jersey may make a new attempt to get rate increases following a decision granting a 26 per cent rise to Travelers Indemnity Company of Hartford, according to Horace J. Bryant Jr., State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance.
A number of supermarket chains are following the lead of food processors by entering the growing fast-food restaurant business.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 3 This city has become the newest battleground in a national drive to organize hospital workers that has already reached New York, Baltimore, Charleston, S.C. Memphis, Tenn., and other cities.

Dr. George deStevens has been named executive vice president of the CIBA Pharmaceutical Company, Summit, N.J. He formerly was vice president-research and a member of the management committee for the company and will continue to direct research activities. He will also have responsibility for the development and control department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Achievements ranging from miniaturization of electronic circuits to the understanding of the role of viruses in cancer have been noted with the presentation of the 1970 National Medal of Science Awards.

Not all the houses in Harry Devlin's book are homes. A fireman might live in a firehouse, but whoever lived in an icehouse, or would take up residence in a gazebo or a necessary even one designed by Thomas Jefferson? Some of the Devlin houses are not even houses: he gives us a school, a church, a barn, a railroad station, a water mill. Yet this author-artist knows exactly what he's doing. He's showing

THE 1970's are here, and the problems that plagued the past decade in the cultural field do not look is if they are going to vanish. The recent differences between management and performers at the Metropolitan Opera and with various orchestras around the country may have been resolved for the immediate future, but the sources of those differences are still very much present.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 3 While Vice President Agnew conferred with Chinese Nationalist officials during his one-day stay here, his wife, Judy, weathered her first experience in keeping her own schedule of official appearances on their Asian tour, her first trip abroad.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 3 The stock and the pillory have long since disappeared as methods of punishing the sinful. But tomorrow, at a religious ceremony before the National Football League championship game, a repentant sinner could very well slip into the hockey penalty box.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 3 The Johannesburg newspaper, The Sunday Times, in its early editions today, accused the United States Central Intelligence Agency and the American consul general in Rhodesia of complicity in recent economic spy cases in Rhodesia.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3 North Vietnamese troops made a third concentrated assault in six days on American soldiers in a field camp last night, killing seven Americans and seriously wounding 11, the United States military command reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 President Nixon struck an appropriate note, which he recognized, in making his first official act of the decade the signing of a bill that will strengthen efforts to make American air and water fit again for human consumption. That must be a "major goal" of the seventies, the President said: "It is literally now or never."
AUSTIN, Jan. 3 "The Republican party of Texas is prepared to accept the responsibility for the management of this Government when the voters entrust this responsibilty to us."
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 3 (AP) Tipton's Nursing Home in Charlotte became yesterday the first private North Carolina nursing home to begin eviction of Medicaid patients.

LONDON, Jan. 3 Britain's first dial-a-poem service is starting in Wales a new medium for the poetic talent of the land of song. From Feb. 1 the dialing of 29017 in Cardiff will guarantee at least two minutes of telecommunicated verse.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 The words used to sound odd coming from so neatly trimmed a young man and spoken in such quiet tones, with only an occasional lift of an eyebrow for punctuation.
BURU, Indonesia Josephus Subiandi is one of 2,500 political prisoners recently shipped to Burn island by the Indonesian Government in a resettlement project.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) The Post Office Department is now charging higher rates for newspapers, magazines and other second class mail and expects $15-million additional a year from them.
WASHINGTON On an average day four convicts in prison across the country consider their lot, find it unnecessarily unpleasant, and sue the warden. Until recently, they almost never won.
When Premier Castro of Cuba talks about sugar, sugar experts listen with a knowing smile and discount about 50 per cent of what is said.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) Wildlife enthusiasts today criticized Gina Lollobrigida, the actress, because of her tiger skin maxicoat.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 3 Miss Sandra Baker Crow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Crow, was married at Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon, to Edward Stanley Luneburg. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wendell Phillips.

Power Memorial, with the rebounding skills and strength most college teams lack, overwhelmed Boys High, 69-53, yesterday at Madison Square Garden to enhance a national scholastic basketball reputation born with Lew Alcindor in the early nineteen-sixties.
One of the newer bits of business folklore concerns the rapid development of the highly efficient and relatively cheap electric furnace for making steel.

OPENING night of Neil Simon's "Last of the Red Hot Lovers" at the Eugene O'Neill. The star of the show, James Coco, had tears in his eyes when he took his solo bow. And when the audience stood up and shouted "Bravo!" at him, he smiled and reached out his hands.

A Federal judge yesterday doubled the $50,000 bail of a man accused of conspiring to bomb Government buildings when friends and acquaintances of the defendant appeared in court prepared to post bond for his release.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 3 As his teen-age widow clutched a tightly folded flag and his mother wept softly into a handkerchief, the silver gray coffin slid slowly and silently into the frozen earth and Bill Henry Terry was granted his wish.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 The participants in a convivial cookout party that ended in tragedy on Chappaquiddick Island last July 18 will gather at the Dukes County Court House at Edgartown, Mass., on Monday for the opening of an inquest in the death of Mary Jo Kopechne.

WASHINGTON The millions of refrigerators, medicine cabinets and night tables in the United States are filled with products that have theoretically been approved by the Federal Government for use by Americans. Yet 18,000 Americans die and 20 million are injured by pesticides, flammable fabrics, electric appliances and other common but hazardous products, and at least 2 million people become ill from eating contaminated food.

President Nixon's characterization of the battle against the pollution of the environment as a "nowor-never" fight offers new hope that this survival issue will be given top priority, not in discussion panels but in action.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 3 Mrs. M. Grielle Thomas Wright and Daniel John Reiber of Portsmouth were married here this afternoon in Emmanuel Episcopal Church. The Rev. Daniel Quimby Williams performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Sidney Lovett, chaplain emeritus of Yale University.

DURING the last five to 10 years, so many new plants have been introduced that in the rush to try them, gardeners forget many older reliables. In some genera, new types and hybrids have been an improvement and in some cases they have provided wider plant usage.
Traffic lanes closed during rush hours to all vehicles except buses will be set up on the midtown Manhattan stretches of First and Second Avenues starting tomorrow.

In the first move of what is taking shape as a highly organized campaign, the state's "Big Six" Mayors challenged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to restore money to the cities before claiming credit for new programs.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 3 Three prominent spokesmen for "middle America" President Nixon, the Rev. Billy Graham and Vice President Agnew have won the top three positions on the Gallup Poll's "Most Admired Man" list for 1969.

Four members of the New York Mets Tom Seaver, Cleon Jones, Tommie Agee and Art Shamsky will be honored by Sports Lodge of B'nai B'rith at the organization's 19th annual Bill Corum Memorial Awards Dinner on Saturday, Jan. 24 in the Hotel Roosevelt. The quartet will be cited by Sports Lodge for "high principle and achievement in sports in 1969."
Isaac Rosenberg of 71-40 112th Street, Forest Hills, Queens, manufacturer of decorative ribbons, died yesterday morning of cancer at the Polyclinic Hospital. He was 68 years old.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 3 Gov. John Bell Williiams, on the eve of next week's scheduled court-ordered total school desegregation in many areas of the state, told Mississippians tonight that he would work to erect a private school system as a "workable alternative" for thousands of white children.
VIENNA, Jan. 3 The Hungarian Government announced today a new draft law on passports that is expected to make it easier for Hungarians to travel to Western countries.

A glance at a portrait of Hermann Hesse austere, unpretentiously barricaded behind steel-rimmed glasses, yet sensitively open-reveals the inner contradictions of the man, his reputation, his work. And each time we meet with a new critical appraisal or another translation, these contradictions impress themselves upon us anew.
HONG KONG, Jan. 3 (Reuters) A Vietnam peace delegation, including two Americans, has arrived in Hanoi, the official North Vietnamese press agency said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 Mayor Richard J. Daley was so angry recently at Chicago's Better Government Association that he aimed his roughest epithet at it. He accused it of being an arm of the Republican party.
One day last week the list of new yearly lows on the New York Stock Exchange ran all the way from A (for Admiral) to Z (for Zenith Radio). The list also contained RCA.
"We're a glut on the market," said a new Ph.D. in English last week during the frantic jobseeking forays that are typical of the annual meetings of scholars.
New York's state divorce rate, for years the lowest in the nation, has soared in the first two years of a liberalized matrimonial law.
Bob Lancer of St. Bonaventure and Rick Mount of Purdue were unanimous choices on the coaches E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival all-tournament team announced yesterday.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 3 Oregon's gross product, hit by a lagging lumber industry, had its third lowest real rate of growth during the last decade in 1969.

In a classroom at the University of California this week about 200 students, many of them college football players, will begin the first serious socio-psychological evaluation of intercollegiate athletics.
Miss Carole Ruth Hoffman and Stan Edward Mawson, who met as Peace Corps volunteers in Colombia, are planning an early spring wedding.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 3 (UPI) Bill Battle, an assistant the last four years, was named Tennessee's head football coach today. He succeeded Doug Dickey, who resigned Wednesday to become head coach at Florida.

The auction season is starting again, albeit slowly, after the rash of pre-holiday sales and the lull that followed. The Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, will offer, on Wednesday at 2 P.M., a wide variety of 17th century to 19th century English and European paintings and drawings and 20th century paintings and sculpture, including American works.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Miss Ellen Muskie, daughter of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine and Mrs. Muskie, was married here this afternoon to Ernest Michael Allen, a 23-year-old veteran who served with the Army in Vietnam.

The new 30-cent subway and bus fare will still leave the Transit Authority facing $84million in debts to the city for the last six months. It would produce an operating balance only by optimistic projections this year and next.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 If you've seen one Agnew, you've apparently seen them all.

ELATH, Israel, Jan. 3 Just outside Ramle, on the main Tel Aviv-Jerusalem highway, a motorist passes two huge storage yards. One contains hundreds of Egyptian military vehicles captured in the six-day war of June, 1967. The other is filled with 42-inch-diameter pipes.

TORONTO, Jan. 5 Finance Minister Edgar J. Benson, pledging the Government "to take all necessary steps in order to win the battle against inflation in this country," warned today that "the next several months are crucial."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 It's just as well that all the preliminaries ended yesterday for next Sunday's climac- tic Super Bowl. If the boisterous brutalities of the two championship games had been permitted to continue over an even more extended period of time, there might not have been sufficient survivors to man the platoons.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 5 (UPI) Mike Phipps, Purdue's allAmerica quarterback, and 32 other senior football players were awarded $1,000 postgraduate scholarships today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 (AP) Jarrett Durham poured in 32 points as Duquesne made a shambles of American University's early full-court press to defeat the Eagles, 103-64, tonight.
Working control of the Curtis Publishing Company is being offered for sale by the trustees of the estate of the late Cyrus H.K. Curtis.

VIENNA, Jan. 5 Dr. Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak Communist leader, today attacked ultraconservatives in the party who he said wanted to turn the clock back to the harsher period before the 1968 democratization.

ROME, Jan. 5 Efforts to achieve a strong majority national government to deal with continuing strikes and unrest throughout Italy inched forward today with a meeting of leaders of four center-left potential coalition partners.
The 1970 corporate bond market got under way yesterday with interest rates well below the peak levels they reached early in December.
BONN, Jan. 5 Dr. Max Born, the German physicist and pioneer of modern nuclear physics, died today in the Gottingen University Medical Clinic. He was 87 years old.

ALBUQERQUE, N.M., Jan. 5 (AP) Reies Lopez Tiperina was sentenced today to concurrent state prison terms of 1 to 5 years and 2 to 10 years on convictions stemming from the raid on the courthouse at Tierra Amarilla June 5, 1967.

Today is the 12th day of Christmas and in many parts of the world it is the day for giving presents. According to the New Testament it was on the 12th night that the Magi the Three Wise Men from the East arrived in Bethlehem bearing gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh for the Christ child.

The New York Knickerbockers begin their longest journey of the National Basketball Association season tonight, the type of trip the cliche-mongers like to call an odyssey, by playing the Bullets in Baltimore. The fans at home can see the game on Channel 9 at 9 P.M.

ROME, Jan. 5 Special sanitation crews removed the most visible heaps of garbage from the rutted mud streets of Rome's Borghetto Prenestino slum just before Pope Paul VI went there Christmas morning to say mass. The street cleaners have not been back since.
PARIS, Jan. 5 France is believed to have officially informed the United States and Britain that she is negotiating with Libya the sale of arms and capital goods for Libya's economic development.
In the hope of prolonging his career as a quarterback by avoiding a fourth knee operation, Joe Namath will not compete in the American Football League All-Star Game on Jan. 17 in Houston.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 (AP) Coin flips necessary to break ties in order of selection for the 1970 pro football draft will be held here Friday at the site of the Super Bowl game, Commissioner Pete Rozelle announced today.
"I tell you, the only differences that success has made for me are that I work more and that I don't have this fear, which I had for many years, that I will starve."
Adoption of self-policing rules by a group of private car-forhire owners banded together since last April as the public Livery Association was announced yesterday by Willie Clowers, president.

"Z," the French film drama dealing with a Greek political assassination, was voted the best movie of 1969 in the fourth annual poll of the National Society of Film Critics. The group, which cast its ballots at the Algonquin Hotel Sunday, cited the winners at a reception at the hotel yesterday.
NEWARK, Jan. 5 Newark's deputy mayor began what he called a "grass roots" movement today to draft Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio as a candidate for re-election this spring.
HONG KONG, Jan. 5 Communist China has, in the last year, steadily reduced the flow of information to the outside world through its official press.
"Nous avons deja vendu plus de 1,000 exemplaires et nous les avons recommandes une fois de plus," Leon Amiel, the portly managing director of Librairie Larousse, told a customer the other day.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 5 (Agence France-Presse) Hanoi residents fled from their homes before dawn today as light tremors from the severe earthquake that shook southern China were felt here.

With compassion and an occasional wince, the referee-inchief of the National Hockey League asked yesterday for understanding for his men, "who are washed" up when they're 42 years old, in the prime of life."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The Bureau of the Census released new figures today that documented earlier estimates that both whites and Negroes had been fleeing the poverty areas of cities.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 5 Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson called today for expansion of the county's programs to combat drug abuse and pollution of the air and water, which he said "are reaching disaster proportions."

HAMBURG, West Germany, Jan. 5 (AP) The magazine Spiegal reported today that the commander of the West German Army had called for a reemphasis on "German soldierly traditions" to counteract "paci fistic, uptopian" tendencies menacing the armed forces.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Jan. 6 The United States command said that enemy soldiers attacked a Marine night camp south of Danang early this morning, killing 11 marines and wounding 59.
DETROIT, Jan. 5 New car sales were still falling as the year ended, the General Motors Corporation reported today.
Smith, Barney Co., Inc., announced yesterday the election to new posts of several senior executives of the large investment banking and brokerage concern.

Although earnings of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company in the third fiscal quarter were only 2.5 per cent ahead of the level in the preceding year, the gain for the nine-month period was 11.9 per cent over profits for the corresponding three-quarters of fiscal 1968, the report disclosed yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 5 The South Vietnaese Senate adopted a resolution tonight describing the alleged massacre of Vietnamese civilians at Songmy as "an isolated act by an American unit and not the policy of the United States armed forces."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) The United States has paid $6,100 to the families of 11 Cambodians who were killed in two border incidents and to 13 Cambodians who were wounded at the same time, the State Department said today.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist reluctantly ruled today that 21 colleges with religious affiliations were not eligible under the State Constitution to participate in a $24-million program designed to aid private colleges and universities.
Miss Sharon Susan Penkower, and Joseph Charles Kaplan, will be married here on March 29.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 5 Stephen May finally moved into the Mayor's third-floor suite in City Hall today, but the political atmosphere in the city was as chilly as the weather.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service has agreed to investigate whether the Shell Oil Company is trying to deduct from taxes the cost of mandatory lectures for its employes in which the company presented its views against cutting the oil depletion allowance.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 5 Westchester's new 17-member County Legislature met for the first time today, but few people expect it to differ significantly from the 45-member Board of Supervisors it replaced.

BALTIMORE William Roy Bentley, who was a Bal timore school teacher, worked days, and his wife, Helen Delich Bentley, who was a newspaper reporter, worked nights. So in 1968 they opened an antique shop in order to have something in common.
TEL AVIV, Tuesday, Jan. 6 Egyptian commandos landed on the East Bank of the Suez Canal last night but Israel said it had quickly repulsed them.
NOBODY goes to a hat show any more just to look at the hats. Sometimes there aren't any a headband, a flower, a scarf tied under the chin is enough to keep the millinery franchise.

TRENTON, Jan. 5 (AP) Four large industrial concerns in Hudson County and two in Bergen were directed by the state Health Department today to halt what it called the unlawful pollution of the Hudson River.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 5 Mississippi school officials, who have been ordered to desegregate their schools completely, played a waiting game with the Federal courts today.

Columbia University's American Press Institute announced yesterday that Samuel G. Blackman, who recently retired as general news editor of The Associated Press, had joined the institute on a temporary assignment.
The Board of Education has told leaders in the Legislature that it has "no objection" to retaining six school districts in Manhattan under decentralization if the state law is changed.

ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 5 (UPI)-Karl Schranz of Austria, the World Cup champion, scored his first victory of the new Alpine skiing season today, when Gustavo Thoeni of Italy admitted at the finish line that he missed a gate in the second giant slalom heat.
Arrests for all types of violations of law increased 28 percent in November, compared with the same period in 1968, the Police Department reported yesterday. The totals were 19,406 and 15,160.

HILLSBOROUGH TOWNSHIP, N.J., Jan. 5 Nearly 1,000 policemen, state troopers, National Guardsmen and civilian volunteers searched over snow-covered expanses of more than two square miles here today but failed to uncover a clue to the fate of missing 2 year-old Gregory Scott Lowe.

Members of the Young Lords organization and their supporters who have been occupying a red brick church in East Harlem for the last eight days were ordered yesterday to appear in court this morning and state why they should not be held in contempt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Myrl E. Alexander, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, who is a strong advocate of prison reform, will retire Jan. 31, Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) A boom in the construction of general cargo freighters, despite the present trend toward container ships, was predicted today in a confidential report to the British shipbuilding industry.

Al Fatah, the Palestinian guerrilla organization, celebrates its fifth anniversary this week, riding a wave of undiscriminating Arab enthusiasm. From a rag-tag band of 82 men with $1,000 worth of second-hand weapons, Fatah has expanded to more than 20,000 men, equipped with the latest Russian and Chinese arms and supported by a budget this year estimated at $5.6 million.
Sidney L. Solomon, chief executive officer of Abraham Straus since 1960 and its chairman since 1963, is relinquishing those posts on Jan. 19.

NORTHFIELD, Ill, Jan. 5 Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hobart have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ballard Hobart, a senior at Skidmore, to Jonathan Petke, a second lieutenant in the Marine Corps, who is in helicopter pilot training at Hunter Stewart Army Airfield in Savannah, Ga.
The American Stock Exchange scored its fourth consecutive advance yesterday in stepped-up trading.
PANAMA, Jan. 5 (AP) A Cabinet reshuffle in the Government of President Demetrio B. Lukas was announced today.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 5 (AP) A 25-year-old graduate student was formally charged with murder today in the fatal stabbing last Saturday of Robert B. Sinclair, a retired theatrical director.
The stock market, bolstered by seasonal factors at the start of a new year, maintained yesterday its unblemished record for 1970. The market has gone up in two out of two sessions.
Merger activity rose to a record in 1969 although the number of tender offers was down sharply, according to the annual merger survey and analysis made by W.T. Grimm Co. that was released yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok Zimbalist, founder of the Curtis Institute of Music and wife of Efrem Zimbalist Sr., the violinist, died yesterday at her home here. She was 93 years old.

The three major television networks have protested to Herbert Klein, Director of Communications of the Nixon Administration, that their camera crews were excluded from covering parts of Vice President Agnew's stopover in Saigon.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 The two teachers' unions in Los Angeles, with a school district second in size only to New York's, announced today an agreement to merge.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 5 While officially there is no Government censorship of the Brazilian press, this week's edition of the weekly newsmagazine Veja was reviewed by two army commands and the Brazilian Federal Police before it was allowed onto newsstands across the country today.

Mayor Lindsay has given dramatic recognition to the nonpartisan nature of his election victory by choosing an outstanding Democrat as one of his three Deputy Mayors. In drawing Robert M. Morgenthau into his administration, Mr. Lindsay has not only honored a pledge to "develop a true coalition government for the city" but has made an imaginative and thoroughly admirable appointment.
A group of 15 to 30 demonstrators occupied Soloam Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section yesterday, demanding space to set up a rehabilitation center for narcotics addicts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The director of the Small Business Administration said today that two loans totaling $560,000 had been granted by the agency to "firms suspected of having underworld connections."

NEWARK, Jan. 5 A jury was selected today in the extortion trial of a reputed Mafia figure and was immediately sent to a hotel to remain "insulated" from any information except what was produced in the courtroom.
The Union Pacific Corporation announced yesterday that it has completed the acquisition of Champlin Petroleum Company and Pontiac Refining Corporation in a transaction valued at $240-million.

HINDELANG, Germany, Jan. 5 (UPI) Bernhard Russi of Switzerland won both heats of the giant slalom today with an aggregate time of 2 minutes 21.99 seconds. He covered the first run in 1:08.38 and the second in 1:13.61.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 5 Israel has given the United Nations a letter from a Jewish couple complaining that they have been prevented from emigrating from the Soviet Union to join their son in Israel.
RICHMOND, Jan. 5 (AP) Frank Lavarre, a 20-year-old college student, walked out of the Virginia Penitentiary today with a conditional pardon from a 20-year sentence for possession of marijuana.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 5 (UPI) Walter Johnson, Cleveland Browns' defensive tackle, rested in Shaker Medical Center today after a scare over the possibility of losing part of one or more fingers on his right hand through frostbite.
PARIS, Jan. 5 General of the Army Jean-Etienne Valluy, a former commander-in-chief of the North Atlantic Central European Forces, died here yesterday at the age of 70.

The first Monday of the thirty-cent transit fare was torture for subway riders. From now on the pain will subside to a dull ache, another burden to add to the many that oppress New Yorkers in these days of inflation and possible recession.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The Federa Reserve's open-market committee voted to keep its monetary policy unchanged at its Oct. 7 meeting although projections showed an unchanged policy would mean a significant decline in total bank deposits, it was disclosed today.

ROME, Jan. 5 (UPI) Pope Paul VI assured the wives of seven United States servicemen today he was doing everything he could to try to help them learn whether their husbands were alive or dead in North Vietnam.
HOUSTON, Jan. 5 There's a trace of gold on the moon's Sea of Tranquility and an unfamiliar yellowish mineral, too.
The Anaconda Company raised the price of primary copper yesterday by 4 cents a pound to 56 cents.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Jan. 5 Whenever the court docket permits, Judge James A. Boyle, the presiding justice of the Dukes County District Court and holder of two holes-in-one, likes to get away from the red brick courthouse by 1:30 in the afternoon and head for the first tee at the Mink Meadows...
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 5 State Senator Norman F. Lent was virtually assured today that he will be the Republican candidate this year in the Fifth Congressional District.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 Governor Rockefeller will ask the Legislature to create a new Board of Consumer Protection in the executive department and to broaden the powers of the Attorney General to act on behalf of consumers.
The Amati Ensemble of Berlin, is conductorless, stand-up group of 11 string players, made its local debut at Tully Hall last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (UPI) Roy M. Cohn, New York financier and onetime aide to the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, was indicted today with three other men on charges of violating Illinois banking laws.

A Bronx grand jury, finding that voting machines had been tampered with in an attempt to change the outcome of an election, called yesterday for the "immediate dismissal" of the deputy chief clerk of the Bronx office of the Board of Elections.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 5 A press report that two men jailed in Rhodesia last month for "economic espionage" were in the pay of the United States Government was described today as "pure fantasy" by the American consul-in-charge in Salisbury, W. Paul O'Neill Jr.

Among the Christmas presents that Tiffany's had for under $10 always a rather fabulous collection one of its best sellers was a sterling silver token holder for $9.75. But whatever joy a recipient got out of one was short-lived; the holders were for 20-cent tokens.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 5 (AP) The farmer kneeling before the body of his wife looked up at the old wall clock, which he had set 15 minutes fast to give him an earlier start on the day. "Last night she was alive," he said to himself.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 5 (Reuters) At least 36 bodies were taken to a hosiptal and police stations throughout the city of Mendoza today after a dam broke and sent a six-foot wall of water and mud roaring into the city.
Representatives of smallbusinessmen in the garment industry and the dry-cleaning trade complained yesterday that rent increases of 100 per cent and more were threatening to drive them from the city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Manufacturers' inventories rose $450-million in November, somewhat less than in most other recent months, the Commerce Department reported today.
Numerous delays plagued rail commuters here yesterday as metropolitan area residents sought to return to work following the four-day New Year's holiday.

Almost $2-billion, the most money ever asked by a city agency, was requested by the Human Resources Administration yesterday for a year that officials said would start with 1.1 million New Yorkers on welfare.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 5 Eight Lehigh wrestlers remained undefeated in dual competition tonight as the Engineers defeated visiting Maryland, 31-3, before 2,500 spectators.
WASHINGTON, Jan, 5 (UPI) The Defense Department announced today that it would cut its civilian payroll by 5 per cent, or 76,700 employes, by next June 30.

The Office of Economic Opportunity's Legal Services branch stands at the cutting-edge of the fight to give the poor a middle-class weapon against enforced poverty. Because its 1,800 attorneys Have shifted their focus recently to test cases that challenge established legal practices and community traditions, some local and state officials have resisted the Federal program.

ANNA MARIE BARLOW'S "Cruising Speed 600 M.P.H." and Kenneth Pressman's "Mrs. Snow," the two plays that opened last night as part of the ANTA Matinee Series at the Theater de Lys, have at least one thing in common: They are object lessons in how not to write one-act plays.

CLARKSVILLE, Pa., Jan. 5 Joseph A. Yablonski, whose unsuccessful challenge last year for the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America touched off the bitterest election campaign in the union's 79-year history, was found shot to death today, with his wife and daughter, in their home here.
In a new "get tough" policy toward postal employes who steal from the mails, Federal Judge Edward C. McLean imposed prison sentences yesterday on two former post office workers.
AMERICA'S young people are playing an important role in the growing reaction against environmental pollution.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 Jim Marsalis, a rookie quarterback with the Kansas City Chiefs, had a bruised kidney and did not accompany the American Football League champions on their chartered flight here today for the Super Bowl game on Sunday.

Dr. Harrison Lloyd McLaughlin, professor of clinical orthopedic surgery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died Sunday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived at 64 Standish Avenue, Tuckahoe, N.Y.

The Army information officer who described his job as being essentially to make "the military look good" posed the dilemma confronting both the armed forces and the journalists-in-uniform broadcasting and writing in Vietnam.

ROME, Jan. 5 Mrs. Frances Trammel Lister, a long-time resident of New York and a former kindergarten teacher in Manhattan's Washington Heights section, died in a hospital here on Dec. 16 at the age of 89.

The New York Times will make a contribution to the Neediest Cases Fund beginning in the 1970-71 fund drive. The contribution will be in lieu of the publication of the names of donors to the Neediest Cases Fund.

IT so happens I have suffered much in the cause of art. Last night I think I may have contracted pneumonia. The occasion was the opening of Merce Cunningham's new season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the world premiere of his latest piece, "Tread."

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 4 The American tuna fleet has put to sea for the start of a new season that seems bound to reopen the United States dispute with South American countries over fishing rights on the high seas in the eastern Pacific.
A recent study calling for the elimination of the stock certificate on Wall Street was challenged yesterday by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 5 Charles Sadek, who was born on New York's Lower East Side and rose to success in business, died Saturday of cancer in his home here, 29 Disbrow Lane. He was 76 years old on New Year's Day.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 5 Two young Negro men were fatally shot last night during what the police called an arson attempt. Today, the police and a local civil rights leader disputed the circumstances of the shootings.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 The defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial announced plans today to "indict" Mayor Richard J. Daley when he appears as a witness tomorrow.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., Jan. 5 Following is a statement today by Judge James A. Boyle, presiding over the inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne:

After an absence of almost 10 years, Shirley Booth is returning to Broadway as the star of "Look to the Lilies," the new musical based on the successful movie and novel, "Lilies of the Field." It opens March 23 at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.
RACINE, Wis., Jan. 5 (UPI) The Selective Service headquarters in Racine was vandalized late yesterday, less than 24 hours after the latest in a series of similar occurrences in Madison.

On the first weekday test of the new 30-cent transit fare, thousands of persons got to their jobs late because of long waits to buy the new tokens, disorderly protests were mounted aganist the increased cost and 11 persons were arrested on charges of trying to evade paying any fare at all or trying to encourage others to avoid paying fares.
A beaming Mayor Lindsay yesterday appointed Robert M. Morgenthau, the deposed United States Attorney, who is a leading Democrat, to the newly created post of a third Deputy Mayor.
Two of the major television networks have increased the commercial time on a number of major programs to offset higher line charges by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

BEFORE we've even had a chance to analyze and classify the fiction of Colin MacInnes, he confounds us with another book. Only a year ago, Mr. MacInnes's "London novels" "Absolute Beginners," "City of Spades," "Mr. Love and Justice" were published in this country for the first time, eliciting critical huzzahs...

DETROIT, Jan. 5 Jerome (Dizzy) Dean, the former baseball pitching star, is "furnishing information" to Federal authorities attacking a gambling syndicate with wide connections in the sports world, a United States Attorney in Detroit said today.
A confidence man who swindled four Manhattan jewelers out of $476,200 in diamonds and diamond jewelry was sentenced yesterday to seven to eight years in prison.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 5 In his first act of executive clemency, President Nixon commuted the six-month prison sentence of Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, a Negro neurosurgeon who heads the National Economic Growth and Reconstruction Organization in New York City.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan 5 (AP) More than 30 city buses were hijacked by students of Ankara University today in protest against a cancellation of reduced-fare permits.

SUMMERVILLE, S.C., Jan. 5 The engagement of Miss Phyllis Corson Walker to James Gillespie Blaine Ewing 3d has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Adams Walker. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Marjorie Ewing of Aiken and J.G. Blaine Ewing Jr. of Bedford, N.Y.
Steel production last week was 6.1 per cent higher than that of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The world is not full of young pianists who want to make their New York debuts by playing Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit," so Garrick Ohlsson's recital last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium had a certain built-in fascination. The "Scarbo" finale of the Ravel is only for the upper ranks of virtuosos to practice, let alone perform in public, let alone in a debut.
Seeking a more meaningful voice in the administration of the sport in this country, top track and field athletes have recommended sweeping organizational changes to the Amateur Athletic Union.

BUFFALO, Jan. 5 Workmen unloading a refrigerated truck here today found an unconscious and unclothed boy among crates of tomatoes that had been sealed inside the vehicle a week ago in Nogales, Ariz, 2,000 miles away.
Miss Diane Tietjen and Gerard Henry Dericks Jr. were married last Wednesday in the Methodist Church in St. Maarten, the Netherlands Antilles. The Rev. R.J. Willingham performed the ceremony.
Daytime parking of passenger cars at all 1,000 metered spots in mid-Manhattan will be banned by next Thanksgiving at the latest, Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff said yesterday.
ATLANTA, Jan. 5 This city's first Jewish Mayor, Sam Massell Jr., was inaugurated tonight and pledged to pay Negroes "a debt dating back over 100 years."
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 5 With winter racing now a fact of life on the thoroughbred scene, the Bowie Race Course opened its 52-day season today under excellent conditions.
THE best record of any mutual fund in 1969 was made by New York Venture Fund, Inc., and Jeremy H. Biggs, one of its three portfolio managers, says to chalk it up to the fund's relatively small size.

HOUSTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) The Apollo 13 moon flight may be delayed a month to April and the launching of Apollo 14 will be set back three or four months this year, the head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 5 Dr. Walter F. Cogswell has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss. Heather Frances Cogswell, to Pvt. William Albert Palmer, U.S.A. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Palmer of Manchester, Vt., formerly of New York. A wedding next August is planned.

The City Center Joffrey Ballet will present new productions of "Petrouchka" and "Pineapple Poll" as well as two premieres by Gerald Arpino in its season at the City Center from Feb. 25 through April 5.

The State Supreme Court has issued an injunction against a landlord for using "a calculated program of harassment" to force tenants out so their space could be rented to commercial enterprises at far higher rates.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., Jan. 5 For the first time under oath, Senator Edward M. Kennedy answered questions today about his movements before and after the drowning of Mary Jo Kopechne nearly six months ago.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 5 A year ago Bud Grant was so engrossed in the last week of the pheasant season in Nebraska that he didn't have time to watch the Super Bowl on television.

Dr. Hilary Holmes, assistant attending physician and Presbyterian Hospital, died Saturday in a shooting accident while duck hunting on Little Nob Island near Larchmont, N.Y. He was 51 years old and lived at 5445 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale, The Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) A group of associates and former campaign workers of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Hubert H. Humphrey and the late Robert F. Kennedy announced today a campaign to make the 1970 Congressional elections a referendum on the Vietnam war.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 5 (Reuters) Rhodesian security forces said today that African nationalist guerrillas crossed the Zambezi River from Zambia last Saturday and attacked a Rhodesian patrol launch, wounding one policeman.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 5 (Agence France-Presse) President Felix Houphouet-Boigny reorganized his Ivory Coast Government today, naming nine new ministers all of them under 40 years of age.
The city charged yesterday that some yogurt being sold here was even more slimming for dieters than its labelling would indicate.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 5 As 15,379 fans attended the second night of harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway, George Morton Levy Sr., track president, announced he had sent a letter of protest to the State Harness Commission chairman, Robert A. Glasser, against the "no-whipping rule" that went into effect last Saturday night.
The First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, Philadelphia's largest bank, offered yesterday to pay 7 per cent to savers with as little as $100 to invest.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were higher yesterday as buyers returned to all sectors of the market.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 5 The Oakland Raiders aren't the Dallas Cowboys, Tom Keating says, but they're not the Kansas City Chiefs either and that's why Keating will be in the stands instead of on the field in New Orleans Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Is it not splendid that college students have begun to behave with maturity again? Their rude shouting has abated. They are less impulsive about seizing the dean's office. They are Beginning to shut up about the war. If the boys would get crewcuts and the girls would put on bobby socks and saddles, our college problems would be over.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 5 (Reuters) Vice President Agnew arrived in this Himalayan kingdom bordering on Tibet today on a 22-hour visit that included brief political talks.

CAIRO, Jan. 5 A leading Cairo editor reported today that President Gamal Abdel Nasser brought tears of gratitude to the eyes of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian commando leader, during the recent Arab conference in Rabat, Morocco, with an offer to turn over to the Palestinians $60-million in funds intended for Egypt's armed forces.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5--Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Dec. 27 was above the corresponding week of last year, while intercity truck tonnage was below the 1968 figure.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 Bernard Shea Horne, retired board chairman of the Joseph Horne Company department store and an authority on Izaak Walton, died yesterday in the Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis, Mass. He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage on Wednesday. Mr. Horne was 64 years old and had moved to Hyannis Port after his retirement in 1964.
ATHENS, Jan. 5 Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the giant Swiss-based mutual fund organization, was accused today by the Government of engaging in "illegal transactions" in Greece.
Deep under Pennsylvania Station in a chilly, drafty tunnel yesterday, Spring Mills, which is very big in textiles in the sunny South, unveiled its four-car public-relations supertrain.

The 100th birthday of Franz Lehar, who wrote "The Merry Widow," will be the theme of the 15th annual Viennese Opera Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 23. The dinner dance will benefit the Margit Bokor-Norman Scott Memorial Fund for Cancer Research at Columbia University.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 5 About 1,200 of the 4,000 nonuniformed employes of this city of 500,000 went on strike today in defiance of a temporary injunction.

In the closest betting spread of the four Super Bowl games, the Minnesota Vikings were installed yesterday as a 13-point favorite over the Kansas City Chiefs by Jimmy (The Greek) Snyder, the Las Vegas oddsmaker.

Silver futures prices began the New Year yesterday with strength. Brokers could cite no specific reason, but talked of influences such as higher prices in London, the more hopeful aspect of the stock market, which has been rising recently, and the end of tax selling.

WOODVILLE, Miss., Jan. 5 Annette Brown stood in the rain with her little brother, Tommy, biting her lips and waiting for a bus to take them home from their first day as the only white students in a sprawling, onestory public school that has 1,391 black students.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan. 5 More than 23,000 Kenya teachers did not turn up for work at the start of the 1970 term today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 5 Mr. and Mrs. William Shannon Eakins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Reid Eakins, to Albert Louis Nelson 3d of Los Angeles. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Jr. of St. Louis. An early spring wedding is planned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended a Philadelphia mutual fund management company, a brokerage house and two individuals. The S.E.C. accused them of having split commissions with other firms that bought and sold stock for the fund.

HOUSTON, Jan. 5 After a detailed study of the first lunar samples brought back to earth, it has been concluded that, if the moon was torn from the earth, it must have occurred either during the earth's formation or immediately afterward.
TROY, Jan. 5 This city, which has not had a City Hall building for 31 years, completed its fifth day today without a mayor.
Willem de Kooning, the artist, is suing a Queens dentist to recover three paintings that the abstract expressionist claims are his "sole property and never offered for sale."

TRENTON, Jan. 5 (AP) The State Banking and Insurance Commissioner, Horace J. Bryant Jr., announced today that he was revoking an average 26 per cent increase in the auto insurance rate he had granted to the Travelers Indemnity Company.
Bob Beamon, the world record holder in the long jump, will ask the Eastern College Athletic Conference to clarify his college athletic eligibility, Ron Bazil said yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 5 Greenwich High School was closed today because of extensive vandalism in which every floor of the three-story building was flooded, two computers were broken, laboratory equipment was destroyed and furniture tossed about.

DICK GREGORY, the humorist and champion of the human rights of blacks, now passes nearly 98 per cent of his time at colleges lecturing on the evils of racism and the shortcomings of democracy as he sees them. Last night National Educational Television, with the financial support of the Corporation of Public Broadcasting, gave an illustrated version of his talk on noncommercial TV (Channel 13).

EVEN in these free-wheeling days a young woman who goes job hunting at one of the big companies had better be fairly conservative in appearance hair not too long, skirt not too short, blouse not too sheer, legs not bare.
The Police Department said early this morning that it would issue orders today permitting its men to wear American flags.

PISTOL Pete Maravich, who led the nation's college basketball players in scoring the last two seasons, is leading again and is only 168 points short of breaking the major college career scoring mark of 2,973 points, set by Oscar Robertson at the University of Cincinnati from 1957 to 1960.
New accounting procedures now required of commercial banks acted to reduce substantially their earnings gains, according to year-end statements of several banks reporting yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 5--Dr. George A. Buckley, professor and chairman of the department of removable prosthodontics at the New York University School of Dentistry, died yesterday at his home, 194 Nassau Boulevard. He was 61 years old.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 5 (UPI) Gov. Preston Smith today ordered 24-year-old Charles D. Watson of Copeville, Tex., extradited to California to stand trial in the murder of Sharon Tate and six others.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 5 Mayor Peter F. Flaherty pledged today to appoint "a fresh new team" of city officials in a housecleaning intended to reform the government of this industrial city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board has ruled against an aircraft leasing plan that would have enabled Trans Caribbean Airways and American Airlines jointly to provide direct service between the Caribbean area and a number of cities.
The Union Oil Company of California plans a sharp reduction in its capital expenditures this year, Fred L. Hartley, president, announced yesterday.
Milton A. Gordon, a financier who delights in turning small investments into big ones, became president and chief executive of Halle Stieglitz, Inc., yesterday.

The Cities Service Company announced yesterday a realignment of its activities into six operating groups. Charles S. Mitchell, chairman and chief executive, said the changes would expand marketing opportunities, eliminate duplicate functions, and effect greater flexibility and cost savings.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 5 The California Legislature opened it 1970 session today amid scrambling between party leaderships for the pre-eminent role in environmental protection.

Miss Karen Ann Thorn, a master's degree candidate in psychiatric nursing at New York University, and Lester S. Penner, director of engineering for the General Instrument Corporation in Hicksville, L.I., plan to be married in June.

NORWOOD, N.J., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Carnevale have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Carnevale, to David Christopher Taylor. He is the son of Paul E. Taylor of Overbrook, Philadelphia, and the late Mrs. Taylor. A wedding in May is planned.

Ion Buzea, a Rumanian who made his Metropolitan Opera debut last night as Rodolfo in "La Boh me," is that rare specimen, a tall tenor. Since he also is romantically dark and handsome, and actor enough to walk across the stage without arousing anxiety over whether he will fall into the promoter's box, he made an unusually credible figure of Puccini's dashing poet.

NEWARK, Jan. 6 In a heavily guarded courtroom, which no one was permitted to enter without passing through an electronic firearms detector, the Government opened its conspiracy and extortion case against a reputed Mafia figure, Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, and three other men today.

Claudio Abbado was the guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra in its concert in Philharmonic Hall last night. A winner of the Mitropoulos contest seven years ago, he has appeared here since with the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera. Now in his mid-30's, he is permanent conductor at La Scala, and a sign of his increasing success is the frequency with which he turns up on the international orchestral circuit.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 6 Prescription for a New York Knickerbocker basketball team ailing and in a slump: Go to Baltimore.

Albert A. Walsh, the city's new Housing and Development Administrator, said yesterday that he would pursue a policy aimed at attracting substantial numbers of middle-class residents white and black to the impoverished slums within a generation.

HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 6 (AP) The American yawl Salty Tiger, owned and skippered by Jack Powell of St. Petersburg, Fla., shared the lead today with Fidelis of New Zealand in the Hobart to Auckland, New Zealand, yacht race.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, Jan. 6 The ruling National Liberation Front party has decided to expel the former President of Southern Yemen, Qahtan alShaabi, and the former Premier, Faisal Abdul-Latif, from membership.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 6 Milford James Baker, who retired in 1961 as a vice president and manager of the contact department of Young Rubicam, Inc., the advertising agency, died Monday at Stamford Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 2 Maywood Road here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Inauguration of a new, coordinated attack on violations of the antitrust laws through illegally restrictive patent agreements was announced today by the Justice Department. A new Patent Unit has been formed within the Antitrust Division to handle all cases involving illegally restrictive practices in the licensing of patents and technology.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6 Just as Joe Namath had the leading role in last year's Super Bowl build-up, Joe Kapp is center stage this time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The rise in the interest rate ceiling on Government-backed mortgages to 8 per cent produced a record-breaking flood of offers to sell mortgages at the auction of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the assiciation disclosed today.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) Fran Tarkenton of the New York Giants was named today as a quarterback for the East in the annual National Football League Pro Bowl game Jan. 18.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 6 Eight municipalities in the Hackensack Meadows charged today that they would lose millions of dollars in revenue if the Hackensack Meadows Development Commission's proposal for a two-year freeze on commercial development went into effect.
Jumbo jet service with Boeing 747's will be inaugurated on Jan. 21 by Pan American World Airways, the airline announced yesterday.

CAPETOWN, Jan. 6 The South African Parliament will be presented with a bill redefining the moment of death to remove uncertainty from heart transplants when it reassembles at the end of this month, it was disclosed today.
Gulf Western Industries, Inc., has purchased almost 10 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Cone Mills Corporation, a major textile producer, over the last 12 months.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 6 Gov. Ronald Reagan added his voice today to the chorus warning that damage to air and water and the land may soon make life difficult if not intolerable in some sections of California.
A court-appointed trustee recommended yesterday that R. Hoe Co. sell its printingpress business.

Lew Alcindor of the Milwaukee Bucks was the only rookie on the eight-man Eastern Division squad selected yesterday to meet the West in the National Basketball Association's All-Star game Jan. 20 in Philadelphia.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 7 (Reuters) Vietcong gunners shot down three American helicopters yesterday in a new outbreak of fighting near Danang. There were no casualties.

PARIS The greatest success of the Nixon Administration as it closed out 1969 may conceivably have been defusing the Vietnamese war. Past predictions on this intricate problem have been proven wrong by future events but present auguries seem modestly hopeful.
"I make the decisions about how material will be released. You asked for this material, and you've got it."

The women from Boston are active crusaders advocating drastic changes in the concepts of children's programing by commercial television. They wrote letters to the three networks asking that they be allowed to present their ideas.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 6 Mr. and Mrs. William K. Barry of Stamford, formerly of Darien, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Ann Barry, to John Gano Prentice, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Prentice of Tenafy and Mantoloking, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) The Treasury reported today that redemptions of United States savings bonds in 1969 exceeded purchases by $724million as rising interest rates prompted Americans to shift their savings to other investments.
