The Canadian Women's Club of New York will hold its 50th anniversary Maple Leaf dinner dance at the Plaza on Jan. 23.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 8-- Interior Minister Kamal Jumblatt announced today that a new agreement had been reached with Palestinian guerrillas operating in Lebanon in which the guerrillas promised to refrain from shooting across the border into Israel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8--A steady rain that diluted the pleasures oP a day off amid the beauties of this colorful city was falling as Coach Red Holzman oaf the New York Knickerbockers spoke about one of his favorite basketball players.

BERLIN, Jan. 8--Twentyeight professors of the Free University of West Berlin went on strike today in protest against what they described as 'student terror". They called a one-week halt to all lectures and other university work.
Samuel E. Manchester, a cantor, died Tuesday evening at a hospital in New London, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 88 years old and lived at 28 Charming Street in New London.
There were all kinds of enjoyment at the Musica Aeterna concert led by Frederic Waldman at Tully Hall last night. There was also something to quibble about.
An alleged drug addict who reportedly spends more than $150 a day on heroin was arrested yesterday and accused of holding up more than 200 taxi-cab drivers during the last three months.
John Prinz, one of the New York City Ballet's younger principals, has left the company to join the Munich Ballet.

HOBART, Tasmania, Jan. 8 (AP)--Bob Carmichael, an Australian who now lives in France, upset top-seeded Arthur Ashe of Richmond, 4-6, 6-3, 6-2. today and well on to join two Americans, Bob Lutz and Jim McManus, in the semifinals of the Tasmanian tennis championships.
TRENTON, Jan. 8--Gov. Richard J. Hughes denounced today the public release of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's transcripts of recorded Mafia conversations.

The Mafia's tribulations-- and enormous expenses--outweighed its profits in trying to establish police--protected dice games in New York City during 1961 and 1962, according to a transcript made by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The Union Carbide Corporation reduced prices yesterday on its major glycol ethers, widely used as industrial solvents, by amounts ranging from about 12 per cent to more than a third.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Jan. 8 --The closed inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne, who drowned when Senator Edward M. Kennedy's automobile plunged from a bridge on Chappaquiddick Island the night of July 18, ended today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP0--The Chicago Bulls compiled the biggest point total in their fouryear National Basketball Association history tonight by routing the Phoenix Suns, 152-123.
WHEN Howard Butcher 3d --that anomaly of anomalies, an outspoken Philadelphia financier--rattles off a story about the Penn Central Company, even Wall Street listens.
DETROIT, Jan. 8--The Chrysler Corporation, pressed by sales and profit problem the last year, realigned its management today.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 8 --Mr. and Mrs. Sanford E. Kesselman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marsha Kesselman, to Jeffrey Alan Silverman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Silverman of Somerville. A wedding in September is planned.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8--Paul Niven, for 20 years a leading broadcast newsman, died today after a fire swept through his Georgetown home here early this morning. His age was 45.
The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday the first actual production test results of oil drilling on the North Slope of Alaska and said the results indicated that the wells.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8-- Arnold Palmer came within a stroke of catching the three who shared the first-round lead today in the $100,000 Los Angeles Open, as a new year began on the pro golf circuit.
HONG KONG, Friday, Jan. 9 (Reuters)--The Chinese Communists confirmed today that a severe earthquake rocked the southern province of Yunnan Monday.
David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said yesterday that the United States "must do all it can to safeguard the security and sovereign existence of Israel."

HARTFORD, Jan. 8--Edward L. Marcus of New Haven, Democratic majority leader of the State Senate, said today he would seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate. He is the third announced candidate for the nomination.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8--Although his team is favored by 13 points, Coach Bud Grant of the Minnesota Vikings predicted today that Sunday's Super Bowl game here between the Minnesota club and the Kansas City Chiefs would be close.
By the end of this month, John Carlos will learn what the professional football scouts really think of him as a 6-foot-3-inch, 205-pound prospect.
THE AMERICAN Littoral Society has asked Wil- liam T. Cahill, New Jersey's new governor, to renew, and then honor, the moratorium, begun June 21, 1969, intended to halt sale of state-owned tidelands.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 8--Three months after the upward revaluation of the mark, West Germany is facing mounting pressure on prices in a period of unparalleled prosperity. Consumer prices are up by 3 per cent a modest rate by most other countries' standards, but excessive for Germans, who after a history of currency problems regard price stability almost as a religion.
THE television controversy between the United States Ski Association and the American Broadcasting Company, which erupted last month at the World Cup races at Val d'Isere, France, has been settled.

Frank Beard, the leading money-winner on the pro tour last year, and five other players not otherwise eligible have been declared exempt from local and sectional qualifying for the 1970 United States Open championship through a new point system adopted by the United States Golf Association.
Mitchell I. Ginsberg, head of the often embattled Human Resources Administration, will leave the city government at the end of this year, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 8-- The Rev. Rush Richard Sloane, rector emeritus of St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church, Locust Valley, died today in Community Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 5 Circle Drive.

Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz thinks it is time to ease the Government's "stranglehold" on interest rates. As former dean of a graduate school of business, Dr. Shultz undoubtedly has credentials to advise on monetary policy--even though little in the present runaway state of inflation seems to justify this particular bit of advice.

The board of trustees of the Museum of Modern Art yesterday elected John Hightower, executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, as director. The appointment ends a search that began last May, when the board ousted Bates Lowry, director for less than 10 months.
The Federal Government's top mediator made a second effort yesterday to bring the General Electric Company and its striking union employes together in "fruitful negotiations."

ALBANY, Friday, Jan. 9--A sharply critical audit report of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's administration of the Long Island Rail Road, with findings of revenue losses and lax supervision of maintenance and train crews, was released yesterday by Controller Arthur Levitt.

THERE was paint everywhere: all over the vinyl- coated tarpaulin on the floor; streaked up and down the walls, and joyously slathered on sheets of paper that hung from clothespins on a drying line. And on the smocks of the 3-year-olds who had come to the art class that morning.
PARIS, Jan. 8--The United States today revived a proposal to begin "restricted" sessions of the Vietnam peace talks as "a way of ending sterile debate."

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 8 (AP)--Karen Moras, Australia's 15-year-old swimming star, beat Debbie Meyer, the Olympic champion and world record-holder, in the 800meter free-style final of the New South Wales championships tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) --The House Ethics Committee has concluded it cannot censure Representative Seymour Halpern, New York Republican who accepted unsecured loans from banks that were interested in bills before the House Banking Committee, of which he is a member.
Chuck Estrada, the rookie star of the Baltimore Orioles' pitching staff a decade ago, was named the minor league pitching coach of the New York Mets yesterday.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Jan. 8-- Ralph Watkins, chairman of the Suffolk Human Relations Commission, said today that the executive director of the commission was illegally removed from his office last month by County Executive H. Lee Dennison.

"We have resolved this year to express our thoughts in deeds.

Mayor Lindsay strongly denied yesterday that he or his aides had engaged in any discussions with top Democratic leaders about his possible conversion to the Democratic party, but Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio acknowledged that informal talks had taken place.

AARHUS, Denmark, Jan. 8 (AP)--Julius Katz-Suchy, former Polish representative to the United Nations, has been granted political asylum in Denmark and has accepted an offer of an assistant professorship at the University of Aarhus.

The Lindsay administration has made no move to carry out a 15-day jail sentence imposed on Albert Shanker, president of the teachers' union, because he led three illegal school strikes in the fall of 1968.

HONG KONG, Friday, Jan. 9 --A Communist newspaper that maintains close ties with Peking reported today that two months of negotiations between China and the Soviet Union on border questions had "failed to produce any results" and said that the Soviet Union was to blame.

David Merrick, Broadway's most successful producer, who sold the movie rights to "Hello Dolly" to Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, may be planning to take a much more active interest in the affairs of the movie company.
ALBANY, Jan. 8--The state's highest court today upheld the right of Ralph Nader, a leading auto safety advocate, to sue the General Motors Corporation for invasion of privacy.

Dr. Alfred A. Burgeni, a physical chemist, who held basic patents on absorbent fiber structures widely used in sanitary napkins, died Tuesday at, St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived at 10 Park Road, Short Hills, N.J.

James D. Griffin, executive director of the state's Conservative party, said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's message to the Legislature on Wednesday was "a political blueprint for election-year spending paid for by tax increases the year after election."

Hints of a subtle easing in the Federal Reserve System's program of monetary restraint were all around last week, but it would take a brave analyst to predict that credit policy had, in fact, changed.
The American Museum of Natural History opened a $25million centennial fund-raising drive yesterday, seeking to enlarge and improve its overcrowded facilities as it moved into its second century.

Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, head of NEGRO, the National Economic Growth and Reconstruction Organization, said yesterday that his black selfhelp program would ask President Nixon for the use of Ellis and Alcatraz Islands.
The election of Roger F. Murray as president of the Fund for Mutual Depositors, Inc., was announced by the mutual fund. He is a director of the fund and chairman of its investment committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8-- The nation's unemployment rate continued low in December, at or near the 3.4 per cent rate of November, it was reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8-- Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz ordered today a "fullscale investigation" of the United Mine Workers of America election in which Joseph A. Yablonski was defeated by the incumbent union president, W.A. (Tony) Boyle.

AS Bob Newhart readily acknowledged, last night's special was something of an impossible mission, taking "A Last Laugh at the GO's." Trying to summarize 10 years of comedy in 60 minutes would seem the quickest route to madness for any editor, and the chronicle over the American Broadcasting Company network never aspired to anything like completeness. But even within the time limitations the show had some fleeting funny moments.

ORELAND, Pa., Jan. 8-- The engagement of Miss Karen Lynne Kredo to Mitchell N. Daroff has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Albert H. Kredo. Her fiance is the son of Michael Daroff, president and board chairman of Botany Industries, Inc., and Mrs. Daroff of Philadelphia and Bal Harbor, Fla.
A novel method of minimizing aircraft noise in homes near airports was outlined here yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Tri-State Transportation Commission.

NOORDWIJKERHOUT, the Netherlands, Jan. 8 (UPI)--A group of liberal Dutch priests said today that they would place married Roman Catholic priests in communities willing to accept them without waiting on a new policy ruling from the Dutch Episcopate.
LONDON, fan. 8 (Reuters)-- Gold was offered for sale here today at its lowest price in more than 12 years, but nobody wanted to buy it.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 9--President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that it would be "impossible and impractical" to withdraw all American combat troops from South Vietnam in 1970.

TEL AVIV, Jan. 8--Israel reported today that her pilots had shot down three Syrian MIG-21 jets, bombed Egyptian military installations for more than two hours and strafed guerrilla bases in Lebanon for an hour and a half.
WELLFLEET, Mass., Jan 8 --Miss Margaret E. Smith, an insurance underwriter with Chubb Son, Inc., in New York, and Ens. Lawrence L. Hale, U.S.C.G.R., will be married here on June 28.

The price pep was out of the grain and soybean markets yesterday following their rise earlier in the week because of the bad weather. Yesterday, at the close of trading, soybeans had edged forward by about a cent a bushel in some contracts, corn was up by a fraction of a cent a bushel, and wheat dropped by a fraction of a cent.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. James Mak of Sao Paulo, Brazil, of the enbagement of their daughter, Miss Theresa Linda Mak, a student at the Newton (Mass.) College of the Sacred Heart, to Thomas K. Hsu of Cambridge, Mass.

The head of the American Can Company called yesterday for a national body to set policy and make regulations for the orderly use of the country's environment. He suggested the establishment of an agency setup like the Federal Reserve System.

MANY famous personalities in bridge could claim to have contributed mare than anyone else to the promotion of the game. One of the strongest candidates would certainly be Richard L. Frey of Greenwich. Conn., who retires today after 12 years as director of public relations for the American Contract Bridge League.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (AP)-- Jean Beliveau scored one goal and assisted on Bobby Rousseau's tie-breaker tonight to help give the Montreal Canadiens a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh penguins in the National Hockey League's East Division.
MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., Jan. 8 (AP)--Former Gov. Ransome J. Williams, who served as chief executive in 1945 and 1946, died here last night. He was 78 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18--The Army broadcaster who accused the United States command of censorship last weekend took issue today with courtmartial charges that have been lodged against him in connection with a previous incident.
The Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra laughed when it sat down to play yesterday afternoon in Philharmonic Hall. Somebody had neglected to bring the instruments.

NEWARK, Jan. 8--Defense attorneys tried again today and failed to get Federal Judge Robert Shaw to disqualify himself from continuing to conduct the conspiracy-extortion trial of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, a reputed Mafia figure, and three others.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 8-- Douglas R. Gray of 407 Walton Avenue, former lawyer, retired legal writer, and editor of Corpus Juris, a case reference volume for lawyers, died yesterday at his home. He was 77 years old and lived at 407 Walton Avenue.
SKOWHEGAN, Me., Jan. 8-- Recollections were the order of the day in theatrical circles in Maine yesterday.

Aa the Federal court deadline approaches for adoption of constitutionally valid boundaries for the state's 41 Congressional districts, the Republican legislative leaders charged with preparing the new maps say they are not yet ready. DETROIT, Jan. 8--Walter P. Reuther, the president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that the Nixon Administration was "obsessed" with fighting inflation and predicted a recession in three to four months unless national economic policy was changed.

ROME, Jan. 8--The Vatican announced today that Archbishop Giovanni Benelli, one of Pope Paul's most influential advisers, would discuss world peace and economic development with President Nixon and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada during a 10day visit to North America beginning Monday.

PARIS, Jan. 9 European central bankers are considering reviving the gold pool to prevent prices in London and Zurich from falling below the official $35-an-ounce level. The market closed today, at $34.90, after touching $34.85. Gold has never sold so low in a decade.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company plans to spend more than $1-billion over the next three years for additions and improvements to its New Jersey service area. Edwin H. SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 The New York Knickerbockers rested and in top form crushed the San Francisco Warriors, 123-93, tonight in the second game in three nights between the clubs at Civic Auditorium. Two nights ago, the Knicks were extended to the fullest to top the Warriors, 9994.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The growth in the total number of jobs in the United States continued last month to show a sluggishness that belied the apparent strength of the low unemployment rate, which remained at the November level of 3.4 per cent. Both figures were reported today by the Labor Department.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 9 (UPI) Freddie Lewis and Roger Brown led the Indiana Pacers to a 111-104 victory over the New York Nets tonight in an American Basketball Association game at the Island Garden.

CHICAGO, Jan, 9 (UPI) Defiance Industries, Inc., an Ohio corporation, once controlled by Roy M. Cohn and Victor Muscat, the New York financiers, was fined $60,000 today after its officers pleaded guilty to violating Illinois banking laws.

BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 9 A Gulf Coast official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today told a United States Senate subcommittee investigating Hurricane Camille relief operations that the "American Red Cross history of discrimination against black people" manifested itself during recovery from last August's storm.

NEWARK, Jan. 9 The conspiracy-extortion trial of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, a 67-yearold reputed Mafia figure, was enlivened today with a dazzling tale by a 32-year-old witness of how he made a $1-million in five years and paid no income taxes on it.

BOMBAY, India, Dec. 31-- Socialism has reared its head over Bombay's highrise skyline, and the business community in this shrine of free enterprise--India's commercial center, banking hub and busiest port--is worried and angry.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 When histories of the Chicago conspiracy trial are written, today's proceedings will probably go down as "The Great Bathroom Debate."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9 Eight of the passengers of a Trans World Airlines jetliner hijacked near Paris and flown here during the night departed for Rome today. The ninth a 26-year-old Frenchman identified as the hijacker was jailed and faced three possible charges.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 9 (AP) Pathet Lao and North Vietnamese forces were reported to have fired 15 rockets today into Pakse, Laos's second largest city. It was said to be the first time in the Laotian conflict that they had fired rockets at a major city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The Treasury disclosed today a purchase of $500-million of gold from West Germany probably the biggest single United States gold acquisition since World War II.
A New Jersey distributor of fishing tackle and ski equipment and a Tennessee guardservice concern stood out in an otherwise spotty new-issue market this week.

NEWARK, Jan. 9 (AP) Superior Court Judge Nelson Mintz issued a temporary injunction today enjoining Aetna Casualty and Surety Company from sending out notices of nonrenewal of policies to its New Jersey customers.

Dr. Arthur J. Kraus has been wandering about the world for 37 years trying to convince people that he was wronged when he was dismissed from the City College faculty in 1933 after conducting a hunger strike to protest fascism in Europe and isolationism at home.
RICHMOND, Jan. 9 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reversed today the convictions of two persons arrested during antiwar demonstrations at the Pentagon two years ago.

AGAINST the day when present feature-length films prove unacceptable to general family television audiences the networks one way or another are making a few films of their own. The National Broadcasting Company and the American Broadcasting Company have had partnership deals for some time but last night the Columbia Broadcasting System unveiled the first product of its wholly owned subsidiary, Cinema Center 100.
MILAN, Italy, Jan. 9 Shirley Verrett scored both a public and a critical success in her opera debut here last night, singing Delilah in La Scala's new production of SaintSaens's "Samson and Delilah."
The Florida weather experts squeezed the juice out of orange juice futures recent price rises with their estimate yesterday that recent freezing temperatures probably had not caused crop damage.

The first hat is in the ring. It will not be the last. The chief races in New York's election this year will be those for Governor and United States Senator, and in this generally capricious season for both politics and weather, announcement of candidacies can soon be expected to fall as thickly as winter's snows.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) A spot check found that Army Reserve units selected for high combat readiness had neither the training nor the equipment to mobilize fast in an emergency, Congressional investigators reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) House Democrats moved eagerly into battle today against President Nixon's announced intention to veto an appropriations bill because he feels that it contains more money for education than should be spent now.
MOSCOW, Jan, 9 (Reuters) The United Arab Republic and the Soviet Union will increase mutual trade under a protocol for 1970 signed here today.

JACKSON, Miss. Jan. 9 (UPI) School integration was peacefully carried out today in Leake and North Pike Counties. They were the latest to integrate under an order handed down by the United States Supreme Court in October calling for the complete and immediate desegregation of 30 Mississippi districts.

VIENNA, Jan. 9 Eastern European diplomatic sources said today that the foreign affairs chiefs of the Soviet bloc might soon meet again to evaluate the forthcoming talks between the United States and Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The Coast Guard will put a weather ship and a large automated buoy in the Atlantic to help improve forecasts for the East Coast, Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe announced today.
PANAMA, Jan. 9 A military officer shot and killed a Panamanian today who had been trying to hijack an airliner to Cuba.

The paintings of Pat Adams, currently on view at the Zabriskie Gallery, 699 Madison Avenue, are distinctly of the latter persuasion.

The Administration has scored a notable advance in winning Peking's agreement to resume the longinterrupted talks between American and Chinese ambassadors in Warsaw. Reopening of a direct communications channel between the leaders of the United States and of the Chinese People's Republic could pave the way toward the still-distant goal of full normalization of United States-Chinese relations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) The nation's retail stores did $352.08-billion worth of business last year, up 4 per cent over 1968's total of $339.32billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

ATLANTA, Jan. 9 About 1,500 students walked out of Atlanta schools this morning and marched a mile in 12-degree temperatures from Atlanta Stadium to the Federal Building to protest the impending transfer of 1,800 Atlanta teachers.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 9 Mrs. Gertrude H. DuBois Campbell, the widow of Allan R. Campbell, a New York City and Westchester County lawyer, died yesterday in her home here at 22 Sagamore Road. She was 91 years old.
ATHENS, Jan. 9 Henry J. Tasca, the new United States Ambassador to Greece, arrived in Athens today.
PARIS, Jan. 9 After much hesitation, French officials acknowledged tonight that about 50 Mirage jet fighter planes would be sold to Libya.

TENAFLY, N.J., Jan. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Campbell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sallie Hedren Campbell, to John Codman Ruhnka, who is associated with the New York law firm of Lord, Day Lord. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Ruhnka of Chestertown, Md.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 9 (AP) Two military newscasters who accused the United States command of censorship were transferred today from the American radio and television network to other duties within the command in Saigon.

THE film star Omar Sharif ends a strenuous week in London today under the glare of television cameras. He has been acting out in real life his movie role in "Funny Girl" as a big gambler, playing a rubber bridge match against top international experts for the highest stakes ever known in the game.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 9 President Chung Hee Park urged today that the United States go slow with its new Asian policy in order to give time for the Asian nations to build up their own defense capacities.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 9 Trailing by 10 yards starting the final lap, Marty Liquori resumed his place as America's premier miler tonight with a victory in the National invitation indoor track meet at Cole Field House.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 Realignment of the 13 teams that will be in the National Conference next season, which has provoked an impasse for six months, will be discussed tomorrow when those club owners interrupt their Super Bowl festivities to assemble for a National Football League meeting.

PESCARA, Italy, Jan. 9 (AP) Thieves using poles, iron bars and pickaxes broke into a church here today and made off with gold and art objects valued at $800,000.

ZURICH, Jan. 9 South Africa was today thought to have been depressing the freemarket gold price so as to take advantage of the recent agreement under which it might sell gold to the International Monetary Fund as soon as the freemarket price dropped to $35 an ounce.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 9 (AP) Don Smith's two-handed stuff shot with 31 seconds remaining gave the Milwaukee Bucks a 120-116 National Basketball Association victory today over the Phoenix Suns.
The vanguard of an expected 50,000 potential entrepreneurs filed into the New York Coliseum yesterday afternoon as the annual Start Your Own Business Exposition opened for a five-day run.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Jan. 9 Miss Amy Beth Jacobson, a junior at Brandeis University, plans to be married in June to Eric Howard Yoffie, a magna cum laude graduate of Brandeis. The wedding is to take place at Temple Emanuel in Newton.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 9 The Mahopac (N.Y.) Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Lon Keller, eliminated the Brae Burn No. 1 rink of West Newton, Mass., 10-3, today in the second round of the 35th annual Douglas Medal bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club. Brae Burn, skipped by Howard (Bud) Chandler, was the defending champion.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 When a 1921 silver dollar thudded into a conference table and came up "tails" after being tossed today by Commissioner Pete Rozelle, the Pittsburgh Steelers were awarded the first choice of college talent in the Jan. 27 by the 26 pro football teams.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 8 Demands by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to rezone residential land in Nassau County to permit the development of low-and middle-income housing received the support of County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson today.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 Arthur H. Thornhill, chairman of the board of Little, Brown Co., one of the oldest book publishers in the country, died here today. He was 74 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) The nation's citrus fruit crop this season will be up 3 per cent from last year but slightly less than indicated, the Agriculture Department announced today.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 9 Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison told the 10 members of the Suffolk Human Relations Commission today that they should drop their opposition to his removal of the commission's executive director or submit their resignations immediately.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 9 The convenience of jet travel and the prerogatives of the Presidency made possible a Nixon family reunion tonight in a small apartment near the Smith College campus. The occasion was the President's 57th birthday.

Metromedia Radio has ordered its 12 stations in seven cities around the country to broadcast weather information only as reported by the Weather Bureau, since "elaborte warnings and repeated suggestions of impending doom scare listeners and hurt businesses in the community."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Margaret Josephine Corcoran, a daughter of Thomas G. Corcoran, the Washington lawyer and former adviser to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died today at her home at the age of 28. The cause of death was not immediately determined.
New York's Islamic community, numbering 30,000 families, will begin soon to build a $19-million cultural center on the Upper East Side.
The mystery of six Chinese seamen from Hong Kong who jumped ship continued last night after the Coast Guard suspended its search for them at the entrance to New York Harbor.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 9 (Reuters) The British Army, which tools over security duties here following bloody religious riots in the summer, will soon hand back full responsibility to the police, it was announced here tonight.
LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) Shell Petroleum, the BritishNetherlands oil group, said today it had called an international conference of tanker owners to discuss fire hazards on giant tankers.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan 9 Russell H. Hughes, a retired vice president of the New York Telephone Company, died yesterday at the Phelps Memorial Hospital here after a long illness. Mr. Hughes, who lived at Strawberry Hill, Irvingtonon-Hudson, and Cape Haze, Fla., was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Chairman Dean Burch of the Federal Communications Commission told the cable television industry today that it could expect that "most of the rules governing broadcast stations will eventually" also be applied to cablecasting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 The United States blamed the Soviet Union today for the continued deadlock in the Middle East peace negotiations and charged that Moscow had, in effect, gone back on an earlier agreement on a settlement.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 9 Mrs. Arthur E. Cooney has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eileen Regina Cooney, to Timothy A. Hogan Jr. He is the son of the late Chief Warrant Officer Hogan, U.S.A., and the late Mrs. Hogan of Washington.
The Long Island Rail Road told the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday that the line needed a fare increase to meet a rising deficit.

CAIRO, Jan. 9 A Cairo editor, Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, disclosed today that an airliner carrying President Gamal Abdel Nasser to Benghazi, Libya, from Tripoli 12 days ago, was involved in an emergency when the front landing gear jammed. A crash landing was averted, the editor said, when the crew succeeded in lowering the gear manually.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 9 (AP) The Central Bank today ordered another mini-devaluation of 20 to 23 points depending on the rate of the Chilean escudo.

LEONIA, N.J., Jan. 9 Dr. William W. Cumming, professor of psychology at Columbia University, died yesterday of a hemorrhage at his home, 402 Allaire Avenue. His age was 42.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 9 Britain received from five of the six members of the European Common Market today a promise that no binding political decisions would be made before negotiations for Britain's admission began.

LONDON--No one in Britain seems to be holding their breath waiting to find out what will happen now that the age of full legal capacity has dropped from 21 to 18. They can now vote, marry without their parents' consent, buy on the installment plan, take out mortgages or get mail from their bookmakers but this sudden power does not seem to matter much.

Late last week the McDonald's Corporation, the Chicagobased hamburger-stand czars, invited five hometown agencies to pitch for its $5-million account. Then over the weekend two New York shops were added to the list of competitors Doyle Dane Bernbach and Wells, Rich, Greene.

The Columbia Broadcasting System will inaugurate a prime time evening newscast on Sunday evenings beginning Jan. 25. The C.B.S. televised football season will end the Sunday before, averting a broadcast conflict, but only temporarily.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12 A spokesman for the United Nations, William Powell, answered with a curt "yes" this morning when he was asked whether the headquarters of the world organization had been surprised by the rush of events in Nigeria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 A study group of the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence has recommended the creation of an independent national center for media study that would judge the performance of the press and broadcast journalism.
A thin, wet snow drizzled on the slushy streets yesterday, permeated the air with a nasty chill and inconvenienced New Yorkers who were already inconvenienced by the normal discomforts of winter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12(AP) A.F.L.-C.I.O. President George Meany charged today that the Nixon Administration's Philadelphia Plan for opening construction jobs to minority workers was nothing more than a political tool and would prove of little value.
Juanita Jane Saddler, a leader in the integration movement in the Young Women's Christian Association and other organizations, died Sunday at her home, 80 La Salle Street. She was 78 years old.

HARTFORD, Jan. 12 The Federal Bureau of Investigation joined the state and local police today in the search for a paroled convict, Louis Cofone Jr., who is accused of murdering one Wilton housewife and kidnapping another and of attempting to rape a woman in Stamford.
PARIS, Jan. 12--The French Defense Ministry denied today that negotiations were under way to sell Iraq Mirage jet fighter planes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide if law graduates may be required to show that they are loyal to the Government and are of good moral character before they may be licensed to practice law.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 12 The United States military command announced here today that the First Infantry Division would be the major combat element to leave South Vietnam in the third phase of President Nixon's withdrawal program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Last April, a small group of militant students at Hampton Institute in Virginia demanded the resignation of the college's president, Dr. Jerome Heartwell Holland.

The producers of "Gantry" have rescinded their invitations to 12 out-of-town critics to attend previews of the show here for the purpose of comment while excluding New York reviewers from these performances.

The five-month-long attempt of the Mite Corporation to acquire the Heli-Coil Corporation ended successfully yesterday with the announcement that an agreement in principle had been reached between the two companies.
The city announced yesterday the award of a $222,593,477 contract for a 13.7mile water tunnel, the largest addition to the water distribution system in 35 years.

Conspiracy and perjury indictments handed up against Nathan Voloshen and Dr. Martin Sweig, former administrative assistant to House Speaker John W. McCormack, outlined an alleged influence-peddling operation that reached from coast to coast.
The versatility of the credit card was broadened yesterday with the disclosure that taxpayers in at least nine states would be able to pay their Federal income taxes by credit card.

The guessing game ended yesterday as Stan Smith was ranked No. 1 by the United States Lawn Tennis Association. The 23-year-old Pasadena, Calif., power hitter supplanted Arthur Ashe at the top of the men's list. Ashe, who did not have a good season, dropped to No. 3 behind Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex:
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 12 For the fisrt time in more than 150 years, two scholars were elected today to the highest governing board of Harvard University.

The Nixon Administration's first year was "a mixed bag" with "more negative than positive aspects" for black Americans, the assistant executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday.
Another skyscraper office building will soon begin to rise at Times Square, bringing to six the number that have been completed or begun along Broadway in the last few years.
VIENNA, Jan. 12 .The Czechoslovak Government said today it had uncovered a Trotskyite plot aimed at "overthrowing the existing political system."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Secretary of the Air Force said today that the primary cause of an F-111 airplane crash on Dec. 22 was a manufacturing defect that caused the swingwing jet fighter to lose its left wing.

SOMEWHERE IN BIAFRA, Jan. 12 (Agence France-Presse) The situation was chaotic today in many parts of Biafra, with roads packed with refugees. Thousands of others have been cut off behind the lines of the advancing Nigerian troops.

Robert W. Stock a staff member of The New York Times Magazine, has been appointed editor of The Times Sunday travel section, replacing Paul Friedlander, it was announced yesterday by Daniel Schwarz, Sunday editor.
It costs the Long Island Rail Road about $169 to handle a freight car in its short-haul, but intricate, operations, according to the line's figures.

ROME, Jan. 12 A judicial police inquiry has been unable to fix responsibility for the wartime reprisal killing of 17 Italian villagers nor to determine the exact role of the Most Rev. Matthais Defregger, Auxiliary Bishop of Munich, who, as a Nazi officer, passed on the order for the shootings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 John W. McCormack, the Speaker of the House, said today, "I have no comment to make" on the indictment of his friend and administrative assistant of 24 years, Dr. Martin Sweig.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) Wayne Hardin, who left as Navy coach in 1965 amid controversy, signed a three-year contract today to coach Temple University's football team. He succeeds George Makris, who resigned last month after 10 years as Owl coach.

Doyle Dane Bernbach has hired a Wall Street specialist in venture capital investments and put him in charge of its own acquisitions. That probably makes this publicly held company the first agency to have a full-time man with this kind of assignment.

The Defense Department's pledge to comply with new Congressional rules prohibiting it from sponsoring any university research that is not directly "mission oriented". could go a long way toward eliminating overdependence of educational institutions on military grants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) The police today charged the 14-year-old adopted daughter of a local official with beating him to death with a crowbar. Also charged with murder were two young men who had been living with the girl in a hippie colony apartment on Du Pont Circle.

HOUSE OF GOLD. By Elizabeth Cullinan. 32C pages. Houghton Mifflin. $5.95. THERE is no sex in "House of Gold," although there are children. There is no violence, although there are deaths: by cancer, cardiac arrest, drowning, tropical fever. There are no politics,

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 12 (AP) The Buick Division of General Motors announced today the recall of 4,000 new-model La Sabres, Wildcats, Electras and Rivieras for replacement of wheels "which might have improper welds that could cause a failure."
LONDON, Jan. 12 Governments and relief agencies in Europe formulated plans today for aid to Biafran refugees but found themselves unable to move pending word from the Nigerian Government.

ATLANTA, Jan. 12--Judge Frank Hooper of United States District Court announced today that he would delay for a month, from Feb. 1 until March 5, implementation of the city's school system's newest integration plan.

WESTBURY, L.L., Jan. 12 Cesare Gennari, the 41-year-old track superintendent at Roosevelt Raceway, started work at 7:15 this morning to get the track into shape for the nighttime nine-race operation. And he and his crew came through with a most satisfactory accomplishment, as indicated by the times turned in by the contestants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The United States took economic and diplomatic steps today to help avert mass starvation in Biafra and the possibility of reprisals against the Biafrans following their surrender to the Nigerian forces.
A Biafran in New York yesterday deplored the Nigerian victory in the civil war and expressed fear that it would be followed by widespread killing of Biafrans.

TRENTON, Jan. 12 Governor-elect William T. Cahill warned today that New Jersey faced a "major state fiscal crisis" and said that the existing 3 per cent state sales tax must be increased to 5 per cent.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 The police sergeant who led a predawn raid in which two Black Panthers were killed changed today the police account of who had fired the first shot.

A witness who expressed fear for his life testified behind locked doors yesterday in the trial of a former official charged with the theft of more than $500,000 in payroll checks from the city's Neighborhood Youth Corps.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Jan. 11 Driving into Uganda from Kenya, the visitor is stopped five times at roadblocks over the 120 miles to Kampala. Soldiers with machine guns or rifles ask the purpose of the trip, look over the luggage and wave the car on.

"My boy," said Pablo Picasso to Luisito Rey when he sought out the then 19-yearold singer and guitarist backstage after hearing him at the Olympia Theater in Paris, "you are like a chill that can be heard."

A 5 per cent state sales tax in New Jersey, as proposed yesterday by Gov.-elect William T. Cahill, would still make purchases a litle cheaper in that state than in New York City, where buyers pay a total of 6 per cent in sales taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Breaking with its tradition of wanting annual drastic changes in football rules, the American Football Coaches Association expressed nearly complete satisfaction today with the way the college game is being played and conducted.
On a wall in the Capitol office of Dr. Martin Sweig, tacked up among the standard autographed portraits of politicians, there is a framed homily from Elbert Hubbard on "loyalty."
Settlements of more than $700,000 were reached yesterday in Manhattan Supreme Court in cases involving the deaths of two passengers in an American Airlines crash near Cincinnati, Ohio, Nov. 8, 1965.

Dave DeBusschere of the New York Knicks was one of the eight players named yesterday to complete the East-West squads for the 20th annual National Basketball Association All-Star Game next Tuesday night in Philadelphia.
INDIO, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) Hortense Odlum, former president of Bonwit Teller, the specialty store, died here today. She was 78 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to consider whether a Greek sailor injured aboard a Greek ship in a United States harbor could seek damages in United States courts.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 12 The American Football League commenced operations 10 years ago and it was a joke. It ceased its existence as an entity in the Super Bowl yesterday and made its exit laughing. The Kansas City Chiefs administered a shocking upset to the highly favored Minnesota Vikings, 23-7, and they did it with a decisiveness that could not have been more convincing.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 12 In the wake of yesterday's Kennedy Memorial ski jumping tournament here, four athletes today were named to the National Nordic combined team that will represent the United States in the Federation Internationale de Ski world championships at Vsoke-Tatry, Czechoslovakia starting Feb. 14
A pipe bomb exploded yesterday morning, before the start of classes, in the deans' office at James Madison High School in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 12 The Lebanese Government decided tonight on a new defense policy to counter Israeli attacks on the southern border.
Gerald Duncan, who was the chief editorial writer of the former World Journal Tribune, died yesterday in his home at 401 East 74th Street. He was 66 years old.
American copper producers indicated yesterday that they were not only willing but also eager to explain to a White House committee why copper prices had been rising sharply in the last few years.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 12 A 26-year-old mother of two who had been searched, handcuffed and fingerprinted before being released in $500 bail for having flown the American flag upside down in an antiwar protest was freed from bail today and will stand trial on March 17.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, set the stage today for an early Confrontation with the Administration. He scheduled as the first order of business, when Congress returns next Monday, an appropriations bill that President Nixon has threatened to veto.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 An experiment here in unit pricing listing the price per pound or pint of packaged foods and detergents has produced strong evidence that pinching pennies in supermarkets is more appealing to the affluent than to the needy.

The Crocker National Corporation, San Francisco, reported yesterday that net income in 1969 amounted to $31.54-million, or $3.03 a common share, 21.7 per cent higher than the $25.92-million, or $2.49, earned the year before.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 12 (UPI) A dozen more Mississippi school districts complied today with the Supreme Court's total desegregation ruling, and the result was thorough integration in some areas and white abandonment of public schools in others.
DENVER, Jan. 12 An attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union charged today that the safety standards of the Atomic Energy Commission "grossly underestimate" possible damage from radiation.
A gray-haired and grimly silent gunman strode into a hiring hall in the heart of the garment district yesterday and opened fire on a crowd of unemployed cutters, wounding four, two of them seriously.

The election of Gerhard D. Bleicken as chairman and chief executive officer of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company and Frank B. Maher as president and chief operations officer, was announced yesterday following a directors' meeting.
MEMPHIS, Jan. 12 (UPI) The Detroit Pistons, led by Dave Bing's 22 points, defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 113-100, tonight.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 The sobering-up station at 1 Petrovsky Boulevard was operating normally. In a 30-minute period, policemen firmly led in four men ranging in age from about 25 to 50, none shabbily dressed.

It will take the acquittal of Nathan Voloshen and Martin Sweig to lift the shadow that has fallen on the office of the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The indictment of the lobbyist and of the former administrative assistant to Speaker John W. McCormack alleges that serious crimes were committed in that office and perjury was used to conceal them.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 Mayor Joseph Alioto, regarded for many months as an unannounced candidate for Governor, removed himself abruptly from the race today.
Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange eased yesterday on liquidations and other selling following renewed fears that United States portfolio investments in Japanese stocks might be tightened.
American Raceways, Inc., and the Sports Car Club of America, which sanctions three professional series of road races, parted company yesterday after an association of only one season.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. Jan. 12 (UPI) A three-car team of new 512-S sports racers signals Ferrari's return to international road racing in the 24 Hours of Daytona, the auto company announced today. The race will be run over the Daytona Speedway's high-banked, twisting 3.81-mile road course Jan. 31Feb. 1.
MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (Reuters) The Moscow radio tonight hailed Nigeria's victory over secessionist Biafra as "the victory of progressive forces of the whole African continent over imperialism."
Fellow-countrymen, as you know I was asked to be the officer administering the government of this republic on Jan. 10, 1970.
PARIS, Jan. 12 (Reuters) Senator Eugene McCarthy, who led an election-year political revolt against American policy in Vietnam, conferred today with Vietcong and American peace negoti- ators.

ATHENS, Ga., Jan. 12 (AP) Mike Pratt scored 7 points in the final 4 minutes tonight, to spark second-ranked Kentucky to a 72-71 victory over Georgia giving the Wildcats the Southeastern Conference basketball lead.

HERE'S a dinner menu (recipes for the starred dishes) with seafood in skillet-fried cakes and the poultry crisp beneath a seasoned orange sauce. For a luncheon, the shrimp cakes could be the entree, served with a melange of stir-fried vegetables and the bean sprout salad.

OFFICERS CHANGED BY COMMONWEALTH There has been another shift in top management of the Commonwealth United Corporation, the Beverly Hillsbased conglomerate that has been so dependent in the past for financing from subsidiaries of Bernard Cornfeld's Investors Overseas Services of Geneva.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 12The New York Knicks outscored the Phoenix Suns in every quarter tonight tallying 30 or more points in each as they romped to a 130-114 victory in a National Basketball Association game before l2,384 fans at the Salt Palace.
A majority of more than 1,000 of New York credit and financial executives see 1970 as a year with a number of unfavorable prosects.

The Harsco Corporation realized a 15 per cent increase in earnings in 1969 on a sales gain of 4 per cent, both setting new annual records, J.T. Simpson, chairman, reported in a preliminary statement issued yesterday.

Dr. Martin Sweig, suspended administrative assistant to Speaker of the House John W. McCormack, and Nathan M. Voloshen, a lobbyist accused of posing as a member of the Speaker's staff, were indicted yesterday on charges of defrauding agencies of the Federal Government.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 12--In an East-West competition, Americans have outbid Russians in the sale of passenger planes to the Indian Government for its domestic airline.
Spartans Industries, Inc., has been offered and has purchased 275,000 shares of its common stock, Charles C. Bassine, chairman, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) Roy Petersen, a reserve, sank four free throws in the final minute tonight to lift the Chicago Bulls to a 117-113 victory over the Philadelphia, 76ers in the National Basketball Association.
When Carlos Marks talks, you can almost hear calypso music.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI)--The Securities Exchange Commission today suspended over-the-counter trading through Jan. 21 in the securities of Carbon, Inc., and Naturizer, Inc.
LONDON, Jan. 12 A Boeing 747, the world's largest passenger airliner, landed here today. The trans-Atlantic crossing was the first such flight of the 747 by Pan American World Airways.

A homicide suspect waiting in an East Harlem service station to meet his lawyer and surrender to the police became a witness in another murder yesterday when a robber walked in with a rifle and fatally shot the station manager.
An elderly woman, her daughter and grandson were killed in a predawn fire yesterday while they were asleep in their second-floor apartment in the Richmond Hill section of Queens.
LONDON Mallett Son, the Bond Street antique firm whose name has a very old and lovely glow for Britons is coming to Bergdorf Goodman in April.

Lou Rossini, seeking a panacea for future New York University basketball teams, spent the weekend recruiting in Texas. The Violet coach and Harry Kotcher, a lawyer and N.Y.U. alumnus, flew there to watch the powerful Wheatley High School team and its star, Dwight Jones. They also viewed the talent at Kilgore Junior College. They came away with high praise and hopes.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that its net earnings rose last year to $788.43-million from $648.42-million in 1968.

The collapse of Biafra by no means marks the final solution of the Ibo problem. That problem, whose intensity was vividly demonstrated by the massacres in northern Nigeria in 1966, will only be solved when the Ibo tribe believes that it is safe. The massacres, in which as many as 40,000 Ibos were...

NASHVILLE, Jan. 12 (UPI) James Earl Ray, who complained that his isolated imprisonment was cruel and asked for some work to do, has been assigned to paint the interior of the state prison's maximum security building by himself.

DENPASAR, Indonesia, Jan. 12 The "moon rocks" that Vice President Agnew present- ed here yesterday to Adam Malik, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, were almost identical with those he has passed out in eight other countries on his current trip on behalf of President Nixon and the American people. They are chips from a rock brought back from the lunar surface by the crew of Apollo 11.

MOSCOW, Jan. 12 In the department-store section of Moscow's central market, a man waits 10 minutes in line to order three small foamrubber crocodiles for his young son. The crocodiles cost $3.30, but the price is not the buyer's principal pain.
Mrs. Alice Peyton Brown, who was born into slavery near Lexington, Va., eight years before the Civil War began, died Friday in Knickerbocker Hospital. She was 116 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) The Supreme Court's refusal to intervene in a court case involving White Consolidated Industries' unsuccessful attempts to take over Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing company was one of several decisions today affecting business.
Steel production declined 2.4 per cent last week, compared with that of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

TIME was when a woman comedian had to make herself ugly, cross her eyes, or fall down in order to get laughs. Her hair stuck straight up in the air or else it resembled a ragmop. And it didn't hurt any if she was a few dozen pounds overweight.

President Nixon's threat that he will veto the $20-billion appropriations bill for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare goes to the heart of the matter of national priorities. The amount at issue is $1.1 billion, most of it earmarked for education, in excess of the Administration's recommendations.

A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that because of "the present circumstances of rampant crime," a tenant might keep a dog in her Lower East Side cooperative apartment despite a ban against animals in her lease.

The mound-makers at Peter Paul, Inc., have decided to slip some of their candy products over to Benton Bowles. All of the products of the Naugatuck, Conn., sweets folk are now handled by Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, which has been its agency for 13 years. It is understood that the annual Peter Paul advertising outlay is over $4million.

VIENNA, Jan. 13 Czechoslovak police investigators who are tracing the ramifications of a clandestine Maoist faction have found that it comprised old-time members of the Communist party as well as young intellectuals and students, according to information reaching here.

An accountant who represented foreign opera stars and conductors was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of having paid more than $2,500 in bribes to three former Internal Revenue Service auditors.

The Nigerian Government's insistence on maintaining Federal supervision over all foreign relief operations in war-devastated Biafra is perfectly understandable. But Nigeria's demand that all foreign aid be channeled through officials in Lagos, if this is to be taken literally, is tragically unreasonable. And if General Gowon's statement yesterday means that he rejects all help from agencies that have participated in Biafran relief, his position is nothing short of unconscionable.

While one Brooklyn housewife refrained recently from buying an electric cutting knife made by the General Electric Company, a Manhattan woman, went cut of her way to several stores just so she could buy a General Electric frying pan.

Frank M. Folsom, former president of the Radio Corporation of America, an aggressive merchandiser whose bold selling concepts played a major part in the commercial expansion of television, died Monday night after a brief illness.

Two members of the Black Panther party from Oakland, Calif., were arrested here shortly after midnight last night by three policemen who said the Panthers had scuffled with them. The Panthers denied the police version of the incident.

THE birth of the automobile, contributing to a social revolution that has yet to reach its conclusion, was presented last night by John Secondari and his wife, Helen Jean Rogers, in a documentary over the American Broadcasting Company's network. It was an hour of assured pleasure for antique car buffs, but rather abrupt in dealing with the modern problems posed by the internal combustion engine.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) The Government moved today to speed up school desegregation in three southern Alabama counties.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 14 (Reuters) Premier Eisaku Sato's Cabinet resigned today to enable the formation of a new Government following general elections last month.

PARIS, Jan. 13 An American and a French authority on multinational companies agreed today on the need for some form of international supervision of the giant enterprises to avoid conflicts with national administrations.
ATLANTA, Jan. 13 On they came, marching along the chilled, rain-glistened streets, crying out for justice and fairness in the schools of the city.
A midtown dentist was arrested yesterday on charges that he submitted insurance claims totaling almost $4,000 for dental work he never performed.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 13 (AP) Debbie Meyer, a 17-year-old schoolgirl from Sacramento, Calif., who won three swimming gold medals in the Mexico City Olympics, was selected today as The Associated Press female athlete of the year for 1969. She almost won the award in 1968, but she was narrowly beaten in the poll by the ice skater, Peggy Fleming.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The United States stood by its support of the so-called Rhodes formula for future Arab-Israeli negotiations today despite the Soviet Union's rejection of the procedure.

Canadian copper producers said yesterday they had agreed to suspend their recent 16 per cent price increase for two months at the request of the Dominion Government. The action was voluntary, but it was taken, in the words of one company president, "with extreme reluctance." Finance Minister Edgar J. Benson announced yesterday afternoon ...
A state mediator, Meyer Drucker, reported yesterday that no progress had been made toward ending a strike of 1,700 gravediggers at 44 metropolitan Roman Catholic, Jewish and nonsectarian cemeteries.
The issue of women's rights weighed heavily yesterday in a decision by Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff ordering a new election of county leaders by the Bronx Republican organization.
QUEBEC, Jan. 13 The provincial government asserted today that the Quebec economy performed about as well as did the national economy in 1969 and will keep pace in 1970.
Two prominent black artists have signed contracts to star in Broadway and Off Broadway productions this season.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday as the trading pace quickened.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 TUBE, a new student organization at the George Washington University Law School, filed today a petition with the Federal Communications Commission.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 13 (AP) Stan Smith, the topranked United States tennis ace, led an American charge into the second round today at the Victorian open championships.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 13 (Reuters) President Nguyen Van Thieu today again strongly criticized advocates of coalition or neutralism in South Vietnam, calling them political witches and racketeers.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 13 Gov. John Bell Williams asked the Mississippi Legislature today to give financial assistance to private, racially segregated schools by providing state tax relief to their patrons.
DETROIT, Jan. 13 It's the coldest January in a decade and that report doesn't come from the weather man it comes from Detroit.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13 Easily containing a Penn State squad that hit only 21 per cent from the floor, Princeton needed only Jeff Petrie's 22 points and John Hummer's 17 to down the Nittany Lions tonight. The Tigers won, 77-38, after leading at half-time, 36-21.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 13 (AP) The Los Angeles Rams placed five players on the first Pro Football Hall of Fame all-pro team and Kansas City's Super Bowl winners grabbed four places as the National Football League dominated the first team.

"It would appear that the God of Africa has specially created the Ibo nation to lead the children of Africa from the bondage of the ages," Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe, an Ibo who was the father of Nigerian nationalism and chief architect of Nigeria's independence, wrote in 1949.

The Norwegian tanker Condo and the three-masted schooner Tina Maria Doncine of unknown registry were both reported to have called off rescue efforts by the Coast Guard yesterday after catching fire in the Atlantic Ocean.
Tomorrow has been proclaimed "Martin Luther King Day" by both Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 13 Stanford University has agreed to give up control over the Stanford Research Institute, target of campus demonstrations, for payments of more than $25million spread over a period of years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 A large part of the policy-making layer of government is purposely insulated from sudden shifts of Presidential power in the so-called "independent" regulatory agencies. But Richard M. Nixon, like other Presidents before him, is finding the take-over process even in these protected corners of Washington power quicker and easier than it looks in the textbooks.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 A resolution was introduced in the Assembly today to prohibit anyone who owns stock in a bank or serves as an employe, officer or director of a bank from sitting on the Assembly Banks Committee.

The Most Rev. Antulio Parilla Bonilla, a Roman Catholic Bishop from Puerto Rico who has visited what he called "political prisoners" in 19 civil and military jails over the last four weeks, called yesterday for the abolition of the military chaplaincy.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 13 (AP) Four nude models two male, two female postured before the coeducational sociology class of 250 persons.

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Jan. 13 There was perhaps a slight hint of regret in Jean Ratelle's voice as he spoke of the thrill of being selected today to the National Hockey League's All-Star team for the first time.

Foremost-McKesson, Inc., whose McKesson Robbins Drug Company is the nation's largest prescription-drug wholesaler, yesterday announced its entry into the comparatively new field of servicing thirdparty prescription plans.
MOSCOW, Jan. 13 When the Soviet Union decides, as it rarely does, to speak directly to foreign correspondents, the voice it uses is that of Leonid Mitrofanovich Zamyatin.
MOSCOW, Jan. 13 The Soviet Union has taken "a favorable attitude" toward United States participation in the proposed all-European security conference, a Soviet Government spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 President Nixon today named Murray M. Chotiner, one of his earliest, closest and most controversial political advisers, to a post on the White House staff.

SYOSSET, L.I., Jan. 13 Mr. and Mrs. Bern Budd Jr. of Laurel Hollow have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Beckman Budd, to Michael Beh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Beh of Lloyd Neck, Huntington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Army announced today that it was going to transfer to Fort McPherson, Ga., or nearby bases most of the active-duty servicemen connected with the investigation into alleged atrocities at Songmy, South Vietnam.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday its entry into the income tax preparation field with a computerized service called Tax Pak designed to process Federal, state and city returns.

Reading the program notes to Newell Jenkins's Clarion Concerts year after year, one gets the general impression that most of the early works to which he regularly gives local premieres were discovered just the other day in a Spanish monastery.
When Norton Garfinkle was teaching economics and economic history at Amherst students would occasionally ask as they are wont to do "if you're so smart, why aren't you rich?"

In a move to help curb creditcard frauds and losses, the Diners Club announced here yesterday that it was planning to introduce a new credit-authorization system for its two million credit card holders in cooperation with the Audac Corporation, Burlington, Mass., manufacturer of a touch-tone telephone device.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Labor Department was urged today to vacate the election in which the late Joseph A. Yablonski was defeated for the United Mine Workers presidency last month and direct a broad Federal inquiry into all of the union's affairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) An offcial of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers said today that the union would go on strike against Trans World Airlines at 3 A.M. Thursday if negotiators had not reached an agreement on a new contract before then.

The buyers are in town again, in greater force than they were last year. But their faces are a bit more sober and contemplative as they troop around in the slush with their open notebooks and full briefcases and crowd into the showroom buildings.

Chancellor Willy Brandt clearly runs the risk of being whipsawed by heading into separate but simultaneous negotiations with three Communist countries the Soviet Union, Poland and East Germany. But he is doing so in the belief that a working relationship with a reluctant East Germany, his chief objective, can only be achieved with the help of Moscow and Warsaw. The question now is whether that gamble will pay off.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 (AP) Jon McGlocklin scored 10 points and Lew Alcindor 9 in the third quarter tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks pulled away from the Cincinnati Royals for a 112-92 National Basketball Association victory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) Researchers who suspect birth control pills of causing sterility, genetic damage and cancer will lead off testimony this week as Congress takes its first look into the safety of oral contraceptives.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 13 Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, Nigeria's head of state, today condemned foreign relief agencies that had aided Biafra. He charged that they had interfered with the conduct of the Nigerian civil war and with Nigeria's attempts to handle the problems of hunger and the distribution of food and medical supplies.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) British banks have announced agreement in principle with the Government and the Bank of England on granting cheap credit to British shipbuilding concerns.
