Willie Mays, who first excited New Yorkers in 1951, makes his first gala New York City appearance of 1970 today, in honor of his 600th home run. Just to describe his itinerary involves a longer list of commercial announcements than a prime-time movie on television.

PARIS, Jan. 13 Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann told Gaullist Deputies today that France's policy in the Mediterranean area had helped her regain her influence in the Arab world. He defended the Government's approval of a sale of 50 Mirage-III fighter planes to Libya by saying that the conditions and dates of delivery would not compromise efforts by the Big Four powers to agree on a solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13 Donald Strachan, a retired sales executive who was a threetime national squash champion, died today in Princeton hospital after a short illness. He was 60 years old and lived on Rosedale Lane here.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Jan. 13 (Agence France-Presse) The final meetings of Gen. Odumegwu Ojukwu, the Biarfran leader, with his cabinet and military advisers were long, sad affairs, according to those who were present.

LONDON, Jan. 13 The Duchess of Windsor said that she would like to be the head of an advertising agency. The Duke of Windsor said that his doctor had told him it was better to smoke marijuana than ordinary tobacco but that he did not intend to try it.

"I am a Yiddish poet and as such I am utterly superfluous in the Soviet Union. Surely no one can any longer deny that because of certain historical developments, there is absolutely no future for Yiddish culture here."
SEATTLE, Jan. 13 The Boeing Company announced here tnday that it plans to reduce its local work force in 1970 by 18,000, to 62,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The first complete study of student protests last year at colleges and universities shows that most were nonviolent and did not interrupt routine, that new left groups were a minor factor, and that the protesters were less concerned with the Vietnam war and related issues than with conditions on the campuses.
The New York Times has announced that it is expanding its editorial services to other newspapers and to magazines with the formation of The New York Times Special Features, a new syndicate.
Besides Hank Stram's imaginative game plan, Len Dawson had one other bit of advice to follow in the Super Bowl.

The General Services Administration sold 1,662,000 ounces of silver of 1,737,000 ounces offered yesterday at prices ranging from a high of $1.8240 to a low of $1.8061 an ounce. This was slightly lower than last week's prices.
MOSCOW, Jan. 13 The Soviet Union and Communist China have resumed negotiations in Peking, a Soviet Government spokesman announced today.

ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., Jan. 13 Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson and Mrs. Nickerson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stephanie Westcote Nickerson, to Stephen Baldwin Bromley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bromley of Upper Nyack. N.Y.
Andrew Wyeth, the belaureled painter whose painstakingly realist work is adored by conservative art critics and scorned by the avant-garde, has a friend at the White House.

TRENTON, Jan. 13 Gov. Richard J. Hughes urged the Republican-dominated Legislature today to approve a state income tax in a final legislative message that recalled what he regarded as the greatest achievements of his eight years in office.
Coy D. Smith interrupted his trial yesterday to plead guilty to the theft of almost $400,000 in pay checks when he was the chief fiscal officer of the city's Neighborhood Youth Corps.

NEWARK, Jan. 13 (AP) An East Orange truck driver who pleaded guilty last June to two charges of attempting to influence jurors in a conspiracy trial of Ruggiero (Richie the Boot) Boiardo and 18 others received a suspended sentence today.

About 20 members of two organizations invaded the Community Psychiatry Unit of St. Lukes Hospital yesterday to demand that the hospital provide immediate bed space to detoxify heroin addicts under 18 years old.

PEOPLE just stop inside the door and stare," said Martin Noren, who, with his brother, David, runs the Gem Monogram and Cut Glass Corporation. "Then they say, 'I thought this was just going to be some little repair shop.'"

LONDON, Jan. 13 (Reuters) The Rev. Ian Paisley, extremist leader of Northern Ireland's Protestants, was involved in a bizarre incident today that left two fellow clergymen chained to the railings of Buckingham Palace. The Rev. Ian Foster, 26 years old, a Free Presbyterian, and the Rev. ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 A three-judge Federal District Court here ordered the Internal Revenue Service today to stop granting tax-exempt status to segregated private schools in Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 An odd thing is now happening in world politics. The small and middle nations, which used to be afraid that the United States and the Soviet Union would blow up the world, now seem to be afraid that Washington and Moscow will get together and organize the world in their own national interests and against the interest of many other nations.

Protests against the 30cent fare continued yesterday in the Rockaways, where users of the Independent subway have to pay a double fare. In the morning, some riders jammed the three turnstiles at the Beach 60th Street station with slugs, putting them out of use during the rush hour.

ATLANTA, Jan. 13 The body of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has been transferred to a site adjacent to his former church, his family announced today. The move was the first step in the creation of a memorial center for the slain civil rights leader.

LONDON, Jan. 13 Hundreds of Biafrans, emotions etched on many faces, crowded together today in a red brick Victorian building that has been the headquarters here for representatives of the government of Maj. Gen. Odumegwu Ojukwu.
LONDON, Jan. 13 Games of chance will not be permitted at Crockford's, London's most renowned gambling club, after July 1.

CAIRO, Jan. 13 The United Arab Republic, the Sudan and Libya moved a step closer today to a regional alliance, agreeing to organize a series of ministerial commissions to study coordination of economic, cultural, military and political affairs.

Leonard Boudin, counsel for the National Emergency Civil Liberties Committee, announced here yesterday that he would represent Specialist 5 Robert Lawrence, the Army newscaster who was removed from his television assignment in Saigon after he had charged the military authorities with censoring of news broadcasts.

An organization of American and Arab-American supporters of the Arab position in the Middle East suggested yesterday that meetings between American Zionists and Arab sympathizers might help toward lasting peace in the Middle East.
Some subway riders are beating the new 30-cent fare by using any of at least seven cheaper foreign coins that are accepted by subway turnstiles.

A study group of the Citizens Committee for Children urged a major shift of authority in the city's public high schools yesterday, saying that this would help restore a climate for learning that was "dangerously polluted by an increasing estrangement between students and faculty."
CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 13 Vice President Agnew greeted Australians today with a pledge of partnership in the Pacific and a friendly wave to antiwar demonstrators.

LONDON, Jan. 13 Britain broke even in her merchandise trade with the rest of the world in December, Government figures showed today. After deductions for freight and insurance, the value of imports was balanced by the value of exports.
Alvin V. Shoemaker has been elected a vice president of the First Boston Corporation. He is a member of the company's municipal department.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 13 The representatives of the Big Four powers discussed the Middle East conflict for four hours today.

SAO TOME, Jan. 13 The only plane known to have left Biafra since the secessionist state's surrender evaded panicky mobs of Biafrans and flew through machinegun fire as it took off last night. It arrived Only 15 minutes behind schedule at this equatorial island, which has served as the base for the Biafran relief airlift since 1968.
Two city attacks on high commercial rent increases were pressed yesterday.

NEWARK, Jan. 13 Seven black and one Puerto Rican candidate, nominated in November by a "community convention" in Newark as candidates for Mayor and City Council announced a national fund-raising campaign at a news conference here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The likelihood of a recession this year appeared lessened today after the Government issued a report on a sensitive sector of the economy business inventories.
RICHMOND, Jan. 13 Virginia's Republican Governorelect, Linwood Holton, announced today that he had appointed a Negro as a key member of his executive staff.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 The Legislature approved a series of changes in New York City's school decentralization law today, but the Senate rejected a proposal that would have permitted the city's Board of Education to deviate from the basic plan and establish the Spanishspeaking community of East Harlem as a separate school district.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) Calling pollution an international problem, Secretary of State William P. Rogers today announced the creation of an Office of Environmental Affairs.

The First Chicago Corporation, whose only component is the $5.4-billion First National Bank of Chicago, reported yesterday that net income rose 44.5 per cent last year to $58,594,000, or $5.84 a common share. This compares with $40,544,000, or $4.05 a share, in 1968.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 13 A military spokesman said that Israeli jets attacked Cairo's suburbs today in the second raid in a week in the Nile Delta. One of the two targets was an army base south of El Khanka, a suburb about nine miles northeast of central Cairo.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 13 Manuel Ulloa, founder and former publisher of the Lima newspaper Expreso, said today that the new Peruvian press law was designed to "gag criticism of the inept military Government" in Peru.

"Most black Americans responded to the war in Biafra like most whites," said Franklin H. Williams, a former Ambassador to Ghana. He noted that a "lack of knowledge" about the war had promoted a general confusion "so that many people did not know what to say or do."

TRENTON, Jan. 13 The Sate Supreme Court warned the municipal officials of Long Branch today that their local court would be abolished if they did not put an end to "local and public controversy" involving the court.

Governor-elect William T. Cahill's effusive shock over New Jersey's deep fiscal plight only reflects a previously shallow understanding of that state's obligations and needs. His proposed solution, increasing the sales tax from 3 per cent to 5 per cent and perhaps including some items now excluded from taxation, represents a shortsighted response to this plight.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Keith of New York and Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Louise Keith, to Lieut. F. David Kemp-Potter of the British Navy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Richard Kemp-Potter Hillside of Findon, Sussex, England.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 Dr. Alfred G. Buehler, one of the nation's leading tax authorities, died yesterday in Bryn Mawr Hospital. His age was 69.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (Reuters) Anticigarette campaigners today began Washington's first No Smoking Week and said the United States led the world in the number of people who have quit smoking cigarettes.

A book to help children expand their capacity to use the English language, called "Language Through Play," has been published here. It is specifically designed so children can cut it up, as part of the learning process.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 13 (AP) John R. Gaines of Lexington paid $56,000 today for the broodmare Victoria Cross II, in foal to Dr. Fager, at the Keeneland winter sale of thoroughbred horses of all ages.

Regine, the "locomotive" who leads "le tout Paris" (as the Seine-based chapter of the jet set calls itself) hasn't quite met everybody who's anybody in New York since she arrived Sunday for a week's visit. Just enough to fill the economy section of one of the new jumbo jets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Mortgages prices declined sharply on continued heavy volume at this week's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association disclosed today. The prices indicated that discount "points" are already increasing on Government-Backed Mortgages, despite the recent increase in the interest rate to 8 per cent.

Teresa Zylis-Gara was the fetching new Pamina in the Metropolitan Opera's performance of "The Magic Flue" last night. In addition to a naturally feminine warmth and charm, Miss Zylis-Gara interjected a pleasant note of humor into her early scenes and a genuine tragic pathos later on in Act 2 effectively staving off the danger of goody-goody insipidity that can so easily affect this character.
A call for greater cooperation between merchants and manufacturers of boys' wear was made here yesterday by Philip M. Hawley, president of the Broadway Department Stores in Los Angeles.

The New York Chief of Detectives, long the independent head of a powerful fiefdom within the Police Department, has been shorn of an important part of his personal power: the exclusive right to decide which detectives will be promoted.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) President Nixon announced today he had freed two Federal prisoners because they were suffering terminal illnesses.
OFFICE furniture that would be so nice to come home to was shown yesterday by Marble/Imperial, a division of the Dictaphone Corporation.
The Defense Department has slashed plans for purchase of the F-111 attack plane by $1billion or more over the next two fiscal years, official sources disclosed yesterday.
The city will try to have its cake and eat it too on January 28 when it will put the five-story Commercial High School Annex on East 46th Street between Second and Third Avenues on the auction block.
The National Broadcasting Company named George A. Heinemann yesterday to the new post of vice president for children's TV programs.

LET'S see, now, where were we? Ah, yes: Dan Gurney's opening the switch season by leaving Ford to drive Plymouth Super Birds in stock-car road races and Barracudas in the TransAmerican series. As drivers and team managers have moved around, Plymouth has ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Six rare hereditary diseases have each been forced to give up their crucial secret, and scientists have begun experiments to translate that victory into methods of treatment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) The Nixon Administration today dropped as inadequate its mild approach to welfare reform and turned instead to public castigation of what it termed the intent of Congress to scuttle the plan.

VIENNA, Jan. 13 Czechoslovak Jews are increasingly worried by what they consider to be a surge of anti-Semitism in the Communist party apparatus, according to reliable private information reaching here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that it would cut 50,000 jobs from its programs in the next 18 months to save money.

NEWARK, Jan. 13 United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey disclosed today a six-point program that he plans to present to New Jersey legislators in an effort "to win the battle against organized crime." "Regardless of how forcefully the Federal Government prosecutes organized crime," he said at a news conference in his office at the Federal Building here, "it cannot be wiped out until there is vigorous enforcement on state and local levels."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Yale University was placed on athletic probation for 17 months by the Eastern College Athletic Conference's executive council today, but within three hours after announcing the penalty, the council withdrew it "for further study."

A state loan to the Long Island Rail Road in anticipation really, in hope of a favorable Federal ruling on division of freight rates was being explored in Albany yesterday as a way to avert or hold down a new passenger fare increase. The parent Metropolitan Transportation Authority, meanwhile, reported it had promised commuters a delay in a hearing ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) Congress has been given a chilling account of potential disaster from air and water pollution if conventional methods are used to satisfy the nation's growing desire for electrical power.
A BELIEVER in the old maxim, J.P.K. Fontaine says, if you don't succeed, try, try again."
International
A vehicle surveillance system that can tell a dispatcher one of his trucks is being hijacked was demonstrated here yesterday by the Hazeltine Corporation.

The appointment of Harry P. Barrand Jr. to the newly created office of executive vice president of the Franklin National Bank in charge of international banking, was announced yesterday by Harold V. Gleason, president.
Applicants for teaching posts here will be eligible for draft deferments only if they go to one of the 450 schools in poverty areas.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 (AP) A team of Justice Department lawyers operating under sealed orders from Attorney General John N. Mitchell is aiding a Federal grand jury here in a broad-scale investigation of the national Black Panther party.

The Soviet reply to United States proposals for a negotiated settlement in the Middle East is a disappointing exercise in diplomatic cowardice. Retreating from positions that American diplomats say the Russians had advanced in private conversations, the Soviet note seems designed to appease the most intransigent Arabs, as though dictated in Cairo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Paul W. Cherington, Assistant Secretary of Transportation for policy and international affairs, confirmed today that he would leave the Government next month to return to the Harvard Business School faculty and to consulting work for private industry.

In the first major triple-A taxexempt financing this year, New Jersey sold $25-million of bonds yesterday, and underwriters priced them to yield at least half a percentage point less than similar securities marketed when interest rates were at their peak in mid-December.

Forecasters who shout down any possibility of recession in 1970 base their judgment on two important premises that consumers will spend a major part of the $13-billion they will receive because the surtax has been halved and because Social Security benefits have been increased and that businessmen will not slash radically their plans to ...
PAGOPAGO, American Samoa, Jan. 13 (AP) A twinengine airliner crashed into a lagoon today after takeoff during a heavy rain at Faleolo Airport in Western Samoa, killing all 30 persons aboard.

In the corporate reorganization of the Commonwealth United Corporation, in which Louis J. Nicastro became president and chief executive officer, the company has agreed to transfer the assets of its real estate division to a new venture, which the Exeter International Corporation and Commonwealth will jointly own.

Operations of the American Enka Corporation in 1969 resulted in record sales and earnings, reflecting demand for fine denier textile nylon yarns and some other textiles, Claude Ramsey, president, reported yesterday.
Select glamour stocks soared to record prices yesterday, while the general market, dawdled along on low volume as the average investor wrapped a cocoon of caution around himself.

Among the thousands of letters received in answer to the 58th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund there is an increasing number of letters from youngsters who are learning the art of giving from their parents.
SOLEDAD, Calif., Jan. 13 (UPI) Three prisoners were shot to death today when a guard opened fire with a carbine on a group of convicts brawling in a prison exercise yard.
MIAMI, Jan. 13 (AP) John L. Rotz, who was injured in a three-horse spill yesterday at Tropical Park, was released from a hospital today.

LONDON, Jan. 13 "If it was anyone else, they'd lock him up," the London matron sniffed, as she peered through the plate glass window on Bond Street to see John Lennon's lithographs of his sex life with Yoko Ono, his wife.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 13 (AP) Unheralded Ingrid Lafforgue led the French to another Alpine skiing victory today when she won the Silver Jug slalom, considered one of the most important events before next month's world cham- pionships. Three American women placed among the top 10.
The head of a company that provided services for lawyers was charged yesterday with forging the names of State Supreme Court justices and City Court judges to subpoenas.

The chairman of the City Planning Commission charged yesterday that a New York Times news story Dec. 29 on the commission's preparation of the capital budget for 197071 contained "unsupported and erroneous allegations."
OMAHA, Jan. 13 (UPI) Treasury Under Secretary Charls E. Walker said today it appeared there would be a continued lack of a "real growth" in the American economy well into 1970.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 13 Representative Donald E. Lukens, the former president of the Young Republican National Federation, announced here today that he would seek the Republican nomination for Governor of Ohio.

ROME, Jan. 13 Arthur Wiesenberger, a New York financier, died of a heart attack here yesterday at his nearby villa. He was 73 years old. He is survived by his widow, the former Frances Glenning Bayes; a son, Arthur F., and a sister, Mrs. Helen Trotsky of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Under Secretary of State, Elliot L. Richardson; said today that "we have every reason to be encouraged" that there would be no indiscriminate killing of Biafrans by the victorious forces of the Nigerian Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 Gene Scott, a former Davis Cup player from New York, surprised by gaining the quarterfinal round of the United States open court tennis championship with a 4-8, 8-1, 8-5 victory over James L. Van Alen 2d of Philadelphia today at the Racquet Club.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 13 The Swedish Government, introducing its budget for the 1970-71 fiscal year today, outlined a tax reform program that will mean increases for persons in higherincome groups.
Valery Klimov, the Soviet violinist, was soloist with the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra last night in a concert given at Philharmonic Hall under the direction of Kiril Kondrashin.

Beginning tomorrow night, a comet discovered last October almost simultaneously by three Japanese should be visible to persons living in the latitude of New York if the southwestern skies are clear after sunset.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 13 (UPI) Rowe S. Steel, former controller of the Rockefeller Foundation, died here yesterday. He was 70 years old.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange turned firmer over a broad front yesterday, indicating that investors were satisfied with Britain's trade performance in December.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 13 Gov. Ronald Reagan, responding to a State Assembly, Committee's report that California's welfare grants were insufficient to feed children properly, asked today for an emergency appropriation of $6-million to provide free meals for needy schoolchildren.

MAERDY, Wales, Jan. 13 Engineers and firemen were racing against time and rain tonight to pump hundreds of tons of water from the reservoir at the head of this mining valley in Glamorgan County. Officials are concerned about the condition of the 70-year-old dam, and 2,000 people have left their homes in areas threatened with flooding.
THE Circus led by Omar Sharif began a sevenweek North American tour in Chicago last night fresh from its rubber bridge victory over an English partnership.

PUTNEY, Vt., Jan. 13 Mike Gallagher, a hungry-looking skier from upstate Killington, and Mike Elliott, a graduate student at Colorado State, clinched berths today on the United States cross-country squad that will compete in the world championships Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 South Africa's right to sell gold to the International Monetary Fund will be determined daily by prices on the London gold market and the amount will be about one-fifth of a week's gold production, it was disclosed today.

The Mesa Petroleum Company announced yesterday it had filed suit in the Court of Chancery in Wilmington, Del., in an attempt to force the Southland Royalty Company to provide Mesa with a list of its shareholders.

In his firm but quiet manner, Len Dawson, the quarterback of the world champion Kansas City Chiefs, indicated here yesterday that he would spurn surgery for his damaged left knee and also spurn his wife's plea that he retire from pro football.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 A Federal judge refused today to set aside a subpoena ordering three doctors who performed an independent autopsy of Fred Hampton, the slain Black Panther leader, to appear before a Cook County grand jury.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 This state's proud centuryold tradition of tuition-free higher education will be broken if Regents of the University of California adopt a proposal to be submitted reluctantly to them later this week by Charles J. Hitch, the university's president.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 13 Lee Benson spent a small fortune last year keeping his 2year-old trotters and pacers eligible for stake events. None of the youngsters ever got to compete in those events.
Manhattan's eight Councilmen yesterday chose a prominent cancer specialist to serve on the 16-member board that will govern the city's 18 public hospitals starting July 1.

PARIS, Jan. 13, (AP) Senator Eugene McCarthy spent four and a half hours in "cordial and informative conversation" today with Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief delegate to the Paris peace talks, a spokesman for Mr. CcCarthy said.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 13 (AP) Red Robbins and Jack Moreland led a third-period outburst that enabled the New Orleans. Buccaneers to break open a close game and go on to a 126-106 victory over the New York Nets tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

"NOT many people realize," said a smiling Billy Sullivan, the president of the Boston Patriots, "the extra measure of satisfaction that all American Football League owners got when one of our teams beat the Minnesota Vikings in the Super Bowl. It was great for us a year ago, of course, when the Jets beat the Colts, but there wasn't the same undercurrent that was running against the Vikings, the same deep feelings.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (UPI) Pan American World Airways today canceled the remainder of a scheduled European tour by the line's first Boeing 747 jumbo jet airliner. The plane headed back to New York.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 13 Analysts here say they do not expect enemy forces to mount a major military offensive during the three-day Tet, or Lunar New Year, holiday next month.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 13 (AP) United States troops, pursuing a North Vietnamese force in foothills west of Tamky, captured a freshly built base camp today in an area where enemy troop concentrations have been reported.

In December, 1956, Carmen Capalbo, the producer of "The Threepenny Opera," announced that the following fall he would present the United States premiere of the neglected Kurt WeillBertolt Brecht classic "Mahagonny." This week, 13 long years later, "Mahagonny" finally is in rehearsal.
Miss Myrna Wien Katz, a graduate student in education at New York University, plans to be married in May to Stephen D. Greenberg, a Yale senior she met at a Briarcliff mixer three years ago.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 Governor Rockefeller today sent to the Legislature a $93.7-million deficiency budget that included a request for $6-million more for the controversial Harlem State Office Building.
A belated invitation helped squeeze Adelphi University into one of the secondary relay races at the Wanamaker Millrose games last year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 Julian Bond, the black state legislator from Georgia, said today that Tom Hayden told him several months before the 1968 Democratic National Convention that he feared "police violence" here during the convention.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 13 United States Representative George Bush, Republican of Houston, announced his candidacy today for the Senate seat held by Ralph W. Yarborough, Democrat of Austin.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 Two teams of scientists have reported that they found that United States defoliation efforts in the Vietnam war had damaged rubber production in adjacent Cambodia.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 13 (AP) Sixteen terrorists were reported to have attacked the Ubol air base early today. Six of them were killed and an American airman was wounded.
Losses outnumbered advances on the American Stock Exchange yesterday by a wide margin as the trading pact slackened.
The nation's electric power production rose 9.6 per cent in the week ended Jan. 10, from the level in the corresponding 1969 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute.

The head of the Metropolitan Housing Council of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday that the council was negotiating to turn several large apartment buildings into co-ops for low- and moderate-income families.
THERE is only one thing wrong with a satire of soap operas. Nothing can be more outrageously improbable than the originals.
Interest rates on new issues of corporate bonds were raised slightly yesterday, interrupting the downward trend that began in early December.
Joseph Colombo, reputed to be a powerful leader of the Mafia in Brooklyn, invoked the Fifth Amendment 50 times yesterday on questions about the underworld.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Supreme Court ruled today that desegregation of pupils in the public schools of six Deep South states could not be put off until next fall.
The seven crewmen of the three-masted schooner Tina Maria Doncie were transferred safely to an American freighter yesterday in the midst of gale force winds in the mid-Atlantic.

THE first major tournament for New York enthusi asts in this decade begins today at Grossinger's in the Catskills. It is the Tri-State Regionals, offering a chance for those on the life master trail to win red points and gold points.

HE was sitting in a coffee shop booth, slightly angled so his legs would not be clamped under the table, and he had received a question Are you having fun? without blink or smile. He seemed to examine it for catches or flaws in the fine, cool chambers of his mind, and then he spoke slowly, carefully, in a deep and even voice.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 14 The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court and the State Attorney General were asked by the Nassau County Executive today to investigate the treatment received in court by a 26-year-old mother of two who was arrested for flying the American flag upside down as an antiwar protest.

Two Japanese propaganda films that have never been shown in the Western hemisphere have been acquired by the Museum of Modern Art film archives. They were directed by Tomotako Tasaka in 1939, during the Sino-Japanese War.
BRUSSELS, Jan. 14 Belgium is investigating reports that United States weapons and military equipment are being shipped to Israel through the port of Zeebrugge, the Foreign Ministry disclosed today.

TORONTO, Jan. 14 The New York Rangers trampled Toronto tonight, 7-1, spoiling the last-place Leafs' six-straight skein without a loss and rudely welcoming back to big-time hockey Gerry McNamara, lately of the Orillia Terriers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Jan. 15 The Saigon police broke up a meeting this morning at the An Quang Pagoda in which militant Buddhist students had called on the people to rise up in a national campaign for peace.

LISBON, Jan. 14 (Reuters) Premier Marcello Caetano reshuffled his l5-month old Cabinet tonight and reorganized the governmental structure. He eliminated a ministerial portifolio and merged several others.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 President Nixon's habit of appearing in winning teams' locker rooms, in person or by telephone, became a familiar part of the American football ritual this winter, as did the President's incisive sports commentary.

NO one who loves the dance can afford to knock "The Nutcracker." Apart from that of the Ford Foundation, it is the greatest subsidy dance the United States has ever known. We are humiliatingly grateful for what it does for us however, there is a kind of song in our hearts when it is all over until next Christmas. Even the greatest "Nutcracker" palls with time.

The particular strength of Aldo Parisot's concert last night at Alice Tully Hall proved to be the way the Brazilian-born cellist directed attention toward the music he played without letting one lose sight or sound of the fact that he was performing extraordinarily difficult works extraordinarily well.
Joseph J. Sisco, the State Department's negotiator on the Middle East, met privately with Jewish leaders yesterday in an effort to allay their concern about United States policy toward Israel.
The end of the war in Nigeria is expected to result in a prompt revival of the nation's oil industry, which had been one of the country's brightest hopes for economic development.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Jan. 14 John Marren scored 28 points for Manhattan tonight for a career total of 1,007 points, but Marshall University defeated the Jaspers, 87-79, at Memorial Coliseum before 5,900 hometown fans. Marren, the No. 7 rebounder in the nation, picked up 20 tonight. Joe Taylor led Marshall scores with 25.
The Rev. James D. Watson, a minister from Queens who calls himself a radical, has been elected moderator of the New York Presbytery of the United Presbyterian Church.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 14 Miss Linda Jeanne Gibson and John Frederick Preston 3d plan to be married this June.
The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday it planned to increase the price of Methocel methylcellulose products by 5 cents a pound in truckload quantities, effective Feb. 1.
Elisabeth Ward Krautter and Alexander Ferguson Treadwell, reporters for Sports Illustrated magazine, plan to be married in March.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 Hobeau Farm's The Purple Kid, a 4-year-old Florida-bred gelding, scored his first victory today, outlasting Hustlin' Raymond to take the $5,500 feature race by a nose at Liberty Bell Race Track.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Texas and Penn State, who finished one, two in last season's football rankings, will meet Sept. 12 in the opening game of the 1970 season at University Park, Pa. The arrangements were made by the coaches, Joe Paterno of Penn State and Darrell Royal of Texas, tonight during the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention.

OVIEDO, Spain, Jan. 11 The Nalon River, which winds like a black thread through the steep green hills near here on the way to the Bay of Biscay, runs paler these days. The mines of Asturias, whose coal is washed in the Nalon and its tributaries, were paralyzed by strikes all last week.
The Board of Education yesterday approved a record operating budget request of $1,640,946,293 for the fiscal year beginning next July 11.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14 Where symphonic music is concerned, American cities with a population of 300,000 might well look at what is happening in Ottawa, a city of comparable size. The Canadian capital, with its new National Arts Center, has established an enlightened and very satisfactory situation, exemplified by the mid-season concert given by the center's orchestra last night.
The annual convention of the American Horse Shows Association begins today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with a meeting of the board of directors. The convention will run through Saturday.
NEWARK, Jan. 14 A municipal employe was indicted by a Federal grand jury today and charged with 18 counts of assisting in the preparation of false income tax returns for his clients.

In anticipation of a loan of $8.5-million from the state to help cover its losses from freight haulage, the Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that it would seek a passenger fare rise of $4.60 a month instead of the $9.20 monthly increase it had requested on Saturday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 14 Considering that Otto Schniebs will be celebrating his 75th year as a skier next winter, the old skiemeister came schussing down the slopes of Whiteface Mountain with surprising speed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) Excited scientists were studying today a 21.6pound meteorite that fell in Oklahoma 11 days ago, for clues to the creation of planets and perhaps of the universe itself. The meteorite was the first to be found by a network set up in 1964 to quickly trace such objects.
Have you noticed that your take-home pay unless you got a raise at New Year's is lower than it was only a few weeks ago?
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 14 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals announced today the signing of Bob Gibson for a salary reported to be $125,000, second highest in the major leagues.
Stewart L. Udall, the former Secretary of the Interior, said last night that limits would have to put on this country's growth in the next decade to avoid destroying the environment.
When Graham Grove looks at a church, he sees more than its steeple or facade. He sees an art gallery, not in use. When he surveys the whole church scene, he sees a potential 300,000 art galleries.
BONN, Jan. 14 Chancellor Willy Brandt proposed today that West Germany and East Germany begin talks soon with an open agenda, aimed at achieving a "regulated relationship."

Consolidated Edison paid $795,000 for an efficiency survey of the company by an outside firm of management consultants but when the consultants reported that the utility was top-heavy with executives nothing was done about it, according to testimony before the Public Service Commission yesterday.

Mrs. Dorothy George Stone and Geoffrey Carpenter Doyle were married in Kingston, Jamaica, last Thursday. The ceremony at the home of Vincent de Roulet, United States Ambassador to Jamaica, was performed by the Rev. David Lapsley of the Webster Memorial Presbyterian Church.

CAT CAY, Bahamas A cold gale came out of the northwest during the night gusting to 50 knots and moaning through the coconut palms. Windrows of seaweed piled on the white beach, spray burst over the coral headland and 15-foot waves rolled in the Gulf Stream between Cat Cay and the Florida mainland 50 miles away.
The Republic of Niger has awarded petroleum exploration concessions covering 71,630,600 acres to the Continental Oil Company, the company announced yesterday.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP) On the sixth attempt, the first rocket ever insured against failure hurled a commercial communications satellite into a successful preliminary orbit tonight.
Commemorative services will be held in the city and throughout the nation today on the 41st anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. the assassinated civil rights leader.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 14 European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are taking a more skeptical attitude toward the Soviet Union's proposal for a European security conference, United States officials said today.

Consumer confidence in the state of the economy has eroded further since early fall and has adversely affected consumer buying plans for durable goods, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.
UNDERWEIGHT dogs in the winter and over weight ones in the summer needed close watching by owners, particularly those...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The first widescale results of the experimental use of the controversial drug L-DOPA were reported today, showing that it had dramatically reversed the course of Parkinson's disease in almost 5 per cent of those who had been treated with the chemical.

Faced with the prospect of smoke-free airwaves, the A.B.C. television network has created a new-business team and a road show that next Monday begins a six-city tour aimed at bringing non-television advertisers into the medium.
The BankAmerica Corporation and the Chemical New York Corporation, one-bank holding companies that rank among the nation's largest banking institutions, reported yesterday increases in 1969 earnings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 E. Russell Lutz, retired steamship executive, maritime lawyer and former State Department legal adviser, died Monday of heart failure at George Washington University Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived here at 1427 34th Street, N.W.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 There is an imperative need for more research on the possibility that dangerous genetic damage may be done by some drugs, food additives and other chemicals, a scientist said today.
TRENTON, Jan. 21 Governor-elect William T. Cahill, who takes office next Tuesday, as New Jersey's first Republican Governor in 16 years, announced four more Cabinet appointments today.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were very firm yesterday.
Dr. Nell Eurich resigned as dean of the faculty at Vassar College yesterday at the request of the college's president, Dr. Alan Simpson.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 14 Theos J. Thompson, commission of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, said today that excessive concern by environmentalists over radiation hazards had been carried to an almost ridiculous extreme.
The Security Pacific National Bank, Los Angeles, announced yesterday the establishment of New York headquarters for its Security Pacific International Bank subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Republican leaders in New York are considering the unuusual step of endorsing the reelection of Representative Emanuel Celler, the 81-year-old Brooklyn Democrat who will be seeking his 25th consecutive term in the House next fall.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 A college student said today that his arm had been broken by Chicago policemen as they pulled him from a statue in Grant Park during demonstrations at the 1968 Democratic National Convention here.

Continued bitter cold weather in the Middle West caused considerable buying of commodity futures on the Chicago Board of Trade early yesterday. However, profit taking later in the day almost wiped out early advances.
WASHINGTON, Thursday Jan. 15 (UPI) A Federal mediator reported progress last night in contract talks between Trans World Airlines and representatives of 15,000 ground service personnel.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 14 (AP) Ray York came within one victory today of tying a national thoroughbred racing record for jockeys when he rode seven winners on the 10-race program at Turf Paradise.

FOR a good part of the New Jersey Symphony program last night in Carnegie Hall, the large audience waited patiently for one thing to hear Marilyn Horne unleash her full powers in the Rossinian fioritura.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The National Collegiate Athletic Association refused today to give its Council explicit power to sanction the basketball competition in the Maccabiah Games.

MONTREAL, Jan. 14 (UPI) The Montreal Canadiens overcame a two-goal deficit tonight with three power-play goals, two of them by Jacques Lemaire, and recorded their fifth straight victory with a 4-2 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings.
Governor Rockefeller told the Governor's Club last night that President Nixon had personally promised him full support in his bid for re-election this year.
The president of the trade association of the investor-owned electric utilities described yesterday as "sheer nonsense" reports that the nation is threatened with blackouts and power shortages.

GUATEMALA CITY, Jan. 14 The chief detective of the Guatemalan National Police was killed by machine-gun fire here late yesterday. Justo Lopez Castanaza was shot to death by three young men in a car. A detective, Demetrio Enriquez, who was with Mr. Lopez, was gravely wounded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 In the arms control deliberations within the Administration, the proposal for a moratorium by the United States and the Soviet Union on the testing of multiple missile warheads is gaining the technical support of Dr. Lee DuBridge, the President's science adviser.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Bernard G. Segal, president of the American Bar Association, announced today plans to establish the first comprehensive program to train court administrators.
Seventy-five youngsters gathered in the chilled morning air yesterday to help save an 85-year-old magnolia tree in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

The Nixon Administration took office a year ago with the commendable goal of halting inflation without causing a recession. It sought to do this by gradually tightening fiscal and monetary policy but without resorting to wage-price guideposts or Presidential "jaw-boning."
CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 14 (UPI) The pro football Hall of Fame announced today its "alltime" American Football League All-Star team.

Seven industrial concerns were accused in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday of polluting New York City waterways or creating navigational hazards. It was the first concerted effort of the Federal Government to crack down on alleged polluters in the area following a call for such action several months ago by Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel.
DR. OREST POPOVYCH of Brooklyn, an experi- enced competitor outscored 105 players for first place during the recent 16th North Central Open in Milwaukee.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 14 (UPI) Bob Verga scored 40 points tonight to pace the Carolina Cougars to a 112-107 victory over the New York Nets in an American Basketball Association game.
BANMETHUOT, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (Reuters) President Nguyen Van Thieu said today he expected to announce a reorganization of South Vietnam's armed forces later this year.
The four-day Sporting Goods Fair closed yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel, with manufacturers and retailers convinced that their industry's upward movement will continue this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee plans to open its public hearings on the Vietnam war on Feb. 2, committee sources said today.

The former first vice president of Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., stockbrokers, and a Swiss bank and its general manager were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in an alleged conspiracy to use secret Swiss bank accounts to evade margin requirements in the purchase of securities.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 The Democratic minority leaders in the Legislature today presented a program for the 1970-71 school year that calls for adding $720million to the anticipated school-aid budget of more than $2-billion.

Mass transportation delays are costing businesses here thousands of dollars a day in time lost, and are becoming a factor in whether businesses stay in the city or move to suburban headquarters, according to Ralph C. Gross, president of the Commerce and Industry Association.

Leonard Bernstein and a Black Panther leader argued the merits of the Black Panther party's philosophy before nearly 90 guests at a cocktail party last night in the Bernsteins' elegant Park Avenue duplex.
DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 14 The Izaak Walton League began legal proceedings here today to block all mineral exploration by private companies in the vast Boundary Waters Canoe Area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Among the most attentive listeners to a speech today by a Deputy Under Secretary of State on modernization of the State Department was Charles William Bray 3d, a career Foreign Service officer.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 14 Israel appeared today to have finally written off France as an arms supplier and to have decided to depend on the United States.

WASHINGTON Jan. 14 The Army's investigation of the alleged massacre at Songmy has been widened to include 13 soldiers and 18 former soldiers, five more men than were previously known to be under scrutiny.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 The Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company announced today more production cutbacks in the wake of falling car sales. The company also disclosed its 1970 capital spending budget would be down to $300-million from $376-million spent in 1969.

The Cobble Hill area of Brooklyn, which in the words of the Landmarks Preservation Commission "retains almost untouched its 19th-century residential atmosphere," was designated by the commission yesterday as a historic district.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14 (Canadian Press) Brig. Gen. John Drewry, a Canadian military obserber in Nigeria, has reported that the physical condition of Biafran refugees "is much better than was feared." The substance of the report was given the House of Commons today by the External Affairs Minister, Mitchell Sharp.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The National League of Cities and the United States Conference of Mayors urged President Nixon today "to make an immediate commitment" to spend the whole $800-million that Congress appropriated last December for water pollution control this fiscal year.
ATHENS, Jan. 14 A military tribunal in Athens today sentenced five Greeks who are living abroad to prison terms and fines "for antinational activities."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (AP) Field reports said today the crew of a United States Navy river patrol boat and Army helicopter gunships en- gaged 10 to 15 North Vietnamese soldiers trying to cross the Saigon River about 18 miles north of the capital and killed eight of the enemy with machine-gun fire.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 14 (UPI) Government payments to farmers will be needed to bring farm incomes to the level of other American groups, a top Government official said today.

Revlon, Inc., announced yesterday it had signed an agreement in principle to acquire the net assets and business of the Mitchum Company, a maker of anti-perspirants, medicated face and body creams and related products.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 14 (UPI) Four students were arrested today at Long Beach State College during a protest over the suspension of two assistant professors who had used nude models to teach a class in sociology.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 14 Dave Bell's 32 points and 20 rebounds paced Hofstra to an 86-82 victory over Kings Point tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The United States Census Bureau is preparing in some unusual ways to conduct the national headcount beginning April 1.
The discovery of a 435carat rough diamond, 2 inches long and 2 inches wide, in West Africa last year was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The wife of Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, and seven co-defendants went on trial today for breaking Federal building violations by attempting to hold an ecumenical mass for peace inside the Pentagon last Nov. 13.
A 23-count superseding indictment was returned yesterday by a Federal grand jury charging two men and two women with conspiracy in the bombing of Federal properties in Manhattan.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 The 197071 state budget, which Governor Rockefeller will present to the Legislature next week, is virtually completed, but the mayors of the state's six largest cities have only begun a new kind of struggle for political leverage they hope will change that budget.
A Queens chemist was awarded $315,000 in Queens Supreme Court Tuesday following a six-day trial concerning the death of his wife, who was suffering from arthritis.

MOSCOW, Jan. 14 Probably the only evil of metropolitan public transportation the Muscovite does not worry about is a fare increase. According to the Communist party program for transport of the masses in Moscow, the already relatively low fares will, like the state, eventually wither away.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Jan. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Volney William Foster have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Adair Foster, to James Paulman Stirling, a vice president of Kidder, Peabody Co., the investment bankers in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The State Department reported today that Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, Nigeria's head of state, had told an American representative of his "warm appreciation" of American offers of aid.
A State Supreme Court justice ordered striking gravediggers yesterday to permit burials of Jews in metropolitan cemeteries in accordance with Orthodox religious law.

IN ballet circles, she has emerged as somewhat of a prodigy. She has been likened to a young princess. But when Gelsey Kirkland is not at New York State Theater, where she danced leading roles at the age of 16 with the New York City Ballet this season, what is she like?
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 14 King Hussein of Jordan has reasserted his intention to arm Jordan with weapons, including aircraft, from the West, despite pressures on him to take arms from the East.

Studies reported here yesterday indicate that chronic exposure to low levels of carbon monoxide, a common air pollutant, may produce damage to the arteries and heart muscle and hinder the development of the unborn child.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 14 The Nigerian Government announced today that it would accept no assistance for the relief of the victims of its civil war from France, Portugal, South Africa, Rhodesia or any other country or agency that had been "studiously hostile" toward Nigeria through the long conflict.

NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 14 Gen. Leonard F. Chapman Jr., commandant of the United States Marine Corps, said here today that the Marine troop strength in Okinawa would remain at the present level of 19,000, even after the island reverts to Japanese administration in 1972.
HARTFORD, Jan. 14 "I believe we've got to admit we've made a mistake," said J. Bernard Gates. "I couldn't feel worse if it had happened to my wife."

MINEOLA, Jan. 14 (UPI) A Plainview, L.I., mother of four was sentenced today in Nassau County Court to a one-to-nine war prison term for the slaying of her husband, an insurance executive, on Aug. 4, 1968.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Finding a proper relationship between the poor inner city and the prosperous outer ring of suburbs is a genuine American dilemma.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 The Federal Government will soon tell the automobile industry to come up with virtually pollution-free engines by 1980, Edward N. Cole, president of the General Motors Corporation, said today.
Some of the high-flying glamour stocks trimmed their recent gains yesterday as the general market closed with modest losses.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 14 (UPI) The United States Steel Corporation backed down today from its ban on parking foreign-made automobiles on the grounds of its Fairfield plant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The State Department unveiled a wide-ranging plan today to reassert its leadership in foreign policy, to revitalize the nation's diplomatic service and to make better use of its personnel.

The disclosure that the Nixon Administration plans to ask Congress for new laws to deal with national emergency strikes would be more encouraging if it were not accompanied by a Labor Department study minimizing the effect of such strikes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Federal Reserve Board postponed today for the third time the effective date of its new regulation aimed at limiting the sale of commercial paper by subsidiaries of banks.

The Bell Howell Company introduced yesterday a new system for showing and storing color slides. The showing at Lincoln Center came after a Dow-Jones interview with Peter G. Peterson, chairman and chief executive officer, in which he...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Holley Mims, a former middleweight boxing contender, died in Providence Hospital last night of a kidney ailment. He was 40 years old.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (Reuters) The International Tin Coun cil decided today to continue another six weeks a suspension of its buffer stockpile manager's obligation to offer tin at the ceiling price of 1,605 ($3,852) a metric ton when the price is above or at that level.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan 14 (AP) A rising tide of young stars is ready to give a sea of trouble to the old pros Billy Casper and Gene Littler for the favorite's role in the $100,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 14 (Canadian Press) The ocean liner Oronsay was held in quarantine for four hours here today while health authorities checked the crew and passengers for typhoid.

The head of the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it was not satisfied with the emergency evacuation system of the new Boeing 747 and raised the possibility that the jumbo jet would not be allowed to begin commercial service on schedule next week.

The final days in the 30month life of the Biafran nation saw thousands of frightened, starving refugees hurrying in all directions to escape the advancing Nigerian troops while the rumble of artillery and the fire of small arms could be heard in the distance, according to an Irish priest and an American author.

Curt Flood's impending suit against baseball's reserve clause has stirred so much interest within the legal profession that the New York Law Journal began yesterday a three-part series, displayed prominently on its first page, analyzing some of the underlying issues.
The police may have foiled an attempted hijacking early yesterday morning when they called back to Kennedy International Airport an Eastern Airlines jet on its way to Puerto Rico.
HOUSTON, Jan. 14 College administrators seem to have developed a new sense of confidence is dealing with student upheaval.

Genesco, Inc, manufacturer and retailer of apparel, announced the resignations of three top officers of Berkshire Apparel Corporation, a major unit that manufactures women's dresses with headquarters at Malden, Mass. They are Sidney S. Stogel, president; David A. Wise, executive vice president, and Donald I. Spund, treasurer.
TYLER, Tex., Jan. 14 (AP) United States Attorney Richard B. Hardee of Texas' eastern district resigned today under pressure from the Department of Justice.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) Federal agents are investigating indications of sabotage at an Atomic Energy Commission plant, Government sources disclosed today.
The next time you leave the house in your sweatsuit and sneakers for that weekend workout, don't jog, says Payton Jordan, run.

Legislators of Maine, meeting in special session this month, have a unique opportunity to help preserve for their constituents and for millions of envious fellow Americans the natural splendor of one of the nation's least-spoiled states.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 President Nixon has ordered further "substantial" cuts in the budget for the fiscal year 1971 to combat inflation, the White House said today.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 The Bostwick brothers, Jimmy and Pete, of New York, won their first matches in the United States open court tennis singles championship today at the Racquet Club.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 The Court of Appeals ruled today that the present "weighted voting" plan of the Nassau County Supervisors was unconstitutional but that a new plan was not necessary until after the 1970 Federal census.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 14 The wonder at Roosevelt Raceway tonight was that a total of 13,076 persons turned out for the program. The temperature was 17 degrees, but the wind velocity made the chill factor high enough to make ski costumes de rigueur.
Johnny Murphy, general manager of the New York Mets during the team's miraculous climb from the depths of baseball to its heights, died last night. He was 61 years old.

Retailers have not done enough, either to raise the Negro's employment potential in their stores, or to improve his lot in the community, despite many pioneering efforts along these lines by individual merchants, a new national spokesman for retailers said here yesterday.

GENEVA, Jan. 14 The Nigerian Red Cross said today that it expected to be the sole source of food for 1.5 million people in the "liberated areas" of Biafra. It submitted an urgent request to the League of Red Cross Societies for heavy trucks, Land-Rovers and a vessel to help distribute the food, but said it did not need any aircraft.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) The Boston Celtics, behind the play of Henry Finkel, the unheralded Bill Russell replacement, rallied in the fourth period tonight for a 123-118 victory over the Detroit Pistons at the Boston Garden.
A 17-year-old paroled narcotics addict, who the police said had held up at least 10 taxi drivers here in the last three weeks, was critically wounded by detectives last night.
The owners of the 13 teams in the new National Conference of the National Football League went through five more hours of meetings here yesterday without reaching a solution for realignment.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 A half million census takers begin the nationwide task tomorrow morning of recording the populaton changes that have taken place in the Soviet Union since the last census in 1959.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Fish protein concentrate, once heralded as the big weapon in the war on hunger, remains an illusive dream despite the best efforts of Government and private business to produce it commercially.

VIENNA, Jan. 14 The main newspaper of the Czechoslovak Communist party today strongly criticized Alexander Dubcek and some of the former party chief's associates who, the newspaper alleged, had organized "a rightist center."
CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 14 Vice President Agnew appeased one set of Australian critics today but avoided a confrontation with another.
Mayor Lindsay went to Queens last night, starting a new series of visits to talk directly with neighborhood civic leaders.
While most of the contributions and letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund come from persons in the metropolitan area, donations have come in from all over the world.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 14 Secretary General Thant is almost certain to fly to Lagos Sunday for talks with Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon and other Nigerian leaders, informed sources said today.

IT isn't mere happenstance that Maurice Shroder's West Side apartment has a Gallic amblance. On a clear day the sun pours into the place as if it were Provence; there are bottles of Chateau Ausone, 1942, stashed away here and there, and it smells like stale Gauloise. Mr. Shroder is a professor of French at Barnard College and a corking good cook.

The 79th running of the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior championships in the 102d Engineers Armory last night was a time for overcoming adversity and Brian Kivlan and Barry Brown both responded to the challenge.
Tom Seaver, whose pitching arm helped make the New York Mets world champions, was named male athlete of the year yesterday in The Associated Press's annual poll.
CAIRO, Jan. 14 The United Arab Republic today scorned Israeli air strikes in the vicinity of Cairo as futile efforts to achieve "political and psychological effects."
Consolidated net earnings of Corning Glass Works were up seven per cent to $50,029,547, or $7.26 a share in 1969, from $46,766,679 or $6.79 a share earned the year before.

Having completed a talk entitled "Selling Cigarettes Worldwide... Ground Rules and Exceptions" without giving away any trade secrets or saying anything controversial, Fred A. Goldstein, director of marketing research for Liggett Myers, accepted questions from the luncheon guests.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 14 Dartmouth scored 18 straight points in the final 5 minutes tonight to overcome a 15-point deficit and hand Harvard an 83-80 defeat in an Ivy League basketball game.

A 20-year-old Air Force private from East Harlem who, the police said, had been absent without leave for a month from a Puerto Rican airfield, shot and killed himself early yesterday while sitting in the waiting room at Grand Central Terminal.

THE story in this column relating a brokerage house's glowing opinion of Penn Central stock came at the wrong time for W.S. Wurzburger, a principal in a small Wall Street brokerage house and a daily commuter on the Central's Harlem division.
NEWARK, Jan. 14 The prosecution asked Judge Robert Shaw today to jail Angelo De Carlo, reputed Mafia figure, and three men on trial with him in Federal District Court until the trial is over.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 14 Miss Patricia Beth Grant, a speech pathologist, and Dr. Howard Roy Cohen, a resident in radiology at the New York University Medical Center, plan to be married here next month.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) Three young women members of the Peace Corps were killed in Eldoret, Kenya, yesterday when their car was struck by a train, a corps spokesman said today.

A REVIEW of the timeless appeal and relevance of "Hamlet" was presented last night by National Educational Television, Channel 13, with Sir John Gielgud acting as guide to visits with the troubled Dane in many different countries and among successive generations of actors and directors.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 14 (AP) Harry MacGregor Woods, composer of "When the Moon Comes Over the Mountain," "I'm Looking Over a Four-Leaf Clover" and "Side by Side," was struck and killed by a car last night. He was 73 years old.

TOKYO, Jan. 14 Eisaku Sato, re-elected Premier of Japan by the parliament today, named a Cabinet emphasizing continuity in pro-American foreign policies and moderately conservative domestic programs, but with interesting nuances in both fields.

The president of a bottling concern was arrested yesterday on charges that he committed perjury at a State Investigation Commission hearing seeking to determine the extent of organized crime's infiltration into legitimate business.

JON HAGGINS chose the red plush lounge of the Ziegfeld Theater to show off his super-contemporary summer clothes. As the models danced lightly around the circular ottoman in the center, just grazing the candy counter, it proved to be a good idea. The clothes, very spare and free as usual, looked very comfortable in the Victorian surroundings.

Choreographers are not French restaurants. But if anyone is handing out four stars, Merce Cunningham's "Place" could go to the top of the list. Last night, the Cunningham Dance Company performed the piece, probably Mr. Cunningham's finest, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

PARIS, Jan. 14 With a system of short-term credit support worked out by its central bankers, the European Economic Community is moving ahead with deliberate speed in strengthening monetary cooperation.

LONDON, Jan. 14 Anxiety mounted today in Europe over the fate of the fleeing Biafrans as relief agencies and governments continued to be puzzled by the attitude of the Nigerian Government.

A one-hour Canadian-produced documentary on present day China will be broadcast next Monday evening by National Educational Television over the 165 stations of the country's public television network. Until yesterday it was not at all certain that the program would be shown.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 14 A group of major Latin-American newspapers are founding a news agency that will report on hemispheric and world affairs from a Latin-American point of view.
The Midwest Stock Exchange in Chicago announced yesterday that it had submitted rules changes to the Securities and Exchange Commission covering public ownership of member firms.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 The United Federation of Teachers was accused by Democratic legislators today of lobbying against new decentralization lines in Manhattan to promote union-supported candidates in the local school elections in March.
SAO TOME, Jan. 14 International relief organizations have 14 planes here loaded with medicine, food, clothing and vehicles ready to take off at five minutes' notice, when word comes from Lagos.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. yesterday at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church, 315 East 47th Street.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 14 (AP) Stan Smith, who has replaced Arthur Ashe as America's No. 1 player, was forced to the limit by 18-year-old John Alexander of Australia today as he advanced to the third round of the $14,000 Victoria open tennis championship.
DETROIT, Jan. 15 Detroit has discovered a word: "Environment." Today that word is bigger in the motor city than such old standbys as "horsepower" or "all new" or "profits."
CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 14 Australia is strengthening defenses on her Indian Ocean coast at a time when a growing Soviet naval presence is reported in those strategic waters.
GENEVA The fast-moving Swiss economy is picking up speed at a rate that is causing the Government to groan with concern over the specter of inflation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon From Europe and the United States the Arab Middle East may look like an unpromising area for investment, but as 1970 begins, a surprising amount of Arab capital is being repatriated from those two regions.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 Jimmy Bostwick of New York reached the semifinals in the defense of his United States open court tennis championship today by defeating Jimmy Dunn, local professional, 8-3, 8-2, at the Racquet Club.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 A bipartisan legislative committee urged today that leaders of illegal strikes by public employes no longer be jailed under the Taylor Law because confinement "tends to make martyrs of them" and may increase union militancy.

ALBANY, Jan, 15 A legislative committee on education made up of both Republicans and Democrats is considering a package of bills that would provide as much as $395-million more in state aid to local school districts in the 1970-71 budget.
