BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Bobby Orr set a National Hockey League record for defensemen with his 50th and 51st assists of the season tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 6-3.
GENEVA, Jan. 15 Gen. Odumegwu Ojukwu appealed to the world today to help save the people of Biafra from "complete annihilation" by the Nigerians.

NEWARK, Jan. 15 United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey said today that organized crime had moved into the garbage collection and disposal industry in New Jersey and urged the Legislature to pass laws making the industry "a public trust" regulated by the state.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Ralph Nader chided fellow consumer advocates today for holding what he depicted as an exaggerated notion of their accomplishments.

BONN, Jan. 15 "A period of frost is coming in our relations with West Germany after the thaw of the last two months," a well-informed East European Communist official remarked here today, commenting on yesterday's state-of-thenation speech by Chancellor Willy Brandt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 A former Army intelligence officer said in a magazine article today that nearly 1,000 plainclothes Army investigators keep track of civilian political activity across the country and submit regular reports to a collection headquarters at Fort Holabird in Baltimore.
KANSAS CITY, Jan, 15 (AP) John B. Gage, mayor of Kansas City for three terms in the turbulent days after the smashing of the Tom Pendergast Democratic organization, died today. He was 82 years old.

AT all times, not only in the 12 years of my tenure of office as president of the Bundesbank [West Germany's central bank], my motto has been the call for a maximum of monetary discipline, that is to say, for a policy which protects the value of money against depreciation by keeping the supply, of money tight.
ATHENS The persisting scarcity of sizable foreign investments in Greece may force the country's militarybacked regime to turn this year into a year of belttightening for the Greeks.

Higher and stronger prices of primary and fabricated aluminum products, among other factors, enabled the Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation to post the highest earnings for the quarter and the year ended Dec. 31, it was reported yesterday by T. J. Ready Jr., president.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 16 Senator Tran Van Don and 14 other members of the South Vietnamese Senate announced today the formation of a political bloc that they said would become the nucleus of a wider opposition front.

VIENNA Austria, a nation of just over seven million people, spent $800-million on Christmas shopping last month. This means that every one of the 2.5 million salaried citizens spent about threequarters of his monthly income on the average $200 in addition to Christmas bonuses.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 15 (UPI) Postmaster General Winton M. Blount said today that "outrageous" wage settlements in the construction industry were having "a devastating effect" on the economy and were crippling the Nixon Administration's battle against inflation.

AT a luncheon in Brussels last month, six experts agreed that new efforts were needed to accelerate progress toward free trade among the world's principal industrial powers, Special attention was given to the revival of protectionist sentiment in the United States.
Dr. Leah Goldberg, a leading Hebrew author, poet and trans- lator, died Wednesday night at the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem after a brief illness, She was 58 years old.
GENEVA, Jan. 15 (Reuters) Following is the text of a statement issued here today by Gen. Odumegwu Ojukwu through Markpress, a public-relations concern:
PARIS In the efforts of rich countries to reduce their budgets to combat inflation, the poor countries stand to pay a disproportionate share of the burden. The situation in France is no exception.

LONDON In the years since the end of World War II, the British vacationer has been almost continually restricted as to the number of pounds he could spend abroad. Urgent balance of payments problems forced limits on sterling outflows.
Stewart L. Udall, the former Secretary of the Interior, said Wednesday night that limits would have to be put on this country's growth in the next decade to avoid destroying the environment.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) The Chicago Bulls breezed to a 130-120 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight to equal the club's longest National Basketball Association winning streak five games.

Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay joined thousands of New Yorkers yesterday in memorial services and meetings honoring the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the slain civil rights leader.

An 8-year-old Brooklyn boy and his younger sister were killed yesterday in a fire in their first-floor apartment in the Crown Heights section while their baby sitter, an adopted brother and another sister managed to escape safely.
George Wehner, a composer, actor, and writer, died Monday at Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 79 years old and lived at 69 Cranberry Street, Brooklyn.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15 (AP) A paroled rapist Louis Cofone Jr. of Bridgeport, Conn. was seized without a struggle here today on charges that he fled Connecticut eight days ago after robbing one woman, strangling another and Kidnapping a third.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Senator Thomas J. McIntyre proposed today a law limiting to five the number of newspapers a company could own and a ban on newspaper ownership of a television or radio station in the same metropolitan area.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15 George W. Ball, former United States Under Secretary of State, urged Canadians today to avoid neutralism of the Scandinavian type, and said that the mutual interests of the United States and Canada called for an expanding free market of trade.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 Dr. S.I. Hayakawa, president of San Francisco State College, chose today to remain at the troubled school rather than embark on a new career in politics.

TRENTON, Jan. 15 Governor-elect William T. Cahill announced today that he had achieved "full support" from Republican legislative leaders for his $300-million tax package, which is based on increasing the state sales tax from 3 to 5 per cent.

DUBLIN A sharp rise in the Republic's international payments deficit and a diminution in tourist earnings because of troubles in Northern Ireland were the two matters of major concern here during 1969.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 15 Nassau County sought an injunction in State's Supreme Court here today to prohibit the use of the waterway under its Atlantic Beach Bridge by the owners of a barge that reportedly has hit the bridge 16 times in the last 21 months.
Somebody at the Child Study Association, which is devoted to the mental health of children, has been sneaking in a bit of adult psychology in dealings with the charity's supporters.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 15 (AP) Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., the No. 1 ranked player in the United States, lost in five sets today to Tony Roche of Australia in the third round of the Victorian open tennis championships.
Joe Namath is wearing a red sports jacket these days, out of love and respect for his second favorite football team.

LONDON Once a week, an Italian freight car drops off Lambretta scooters in Surrey and picks up AustinMorris engines, transmission body pressings and other hardware from the British Leyland Motor Corporation's plants in the industrial midlands.
Mayor Lindsay called on both sides in the gravediggers strike yesterday to intensify their efforts to achieve a quick settlement.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 (UPI) Willie McCovey, the National League's most valuable player of 1969, signed a two-year contract with the San Francisco Giants today that put him in the $100,000 class.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today against American General Insurance Company, two organizations in the Channing group of mutual funds and the Variable Annuitw Life Insurance Company, charging violations of longstanding legal restrictions on advertising that offers securities for sale.

Three Long Island Rail Road commuters, angry over having to wait nearly an hour in freezing weather for a train in Jamaica, Queens, were arrested last night on their homewardbound train after they refused to show their tickets to a conductor.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 William A. Buzick Jr., chairman of the Consolidated Foods Corporation, disputed today the accuracy of published reports that gave William Howlett's version of events leading to Mr. Howlett's dismissal as chairman of the company late last year.

Dealers and private buyers shared yesterday in gathering up riches in jewelry at an auction that yielded $420,165 for outstanding rubies, sapphires and other gems. The consigner to the sale at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, was Harvard University, which had received the collection as a bequest from Mildred Barnes Bliss, widow of Robert Woods Bliss.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 15 (Reuters) A total of 220 cars will set out from eight points tomorrow on the first and easiest leg of the Monte Carlo Rally. The crews representing 25 countries will leave from Dover, England; Rheims, France; Warsaw; Monte Carlo, Athens, Oslo, Norway; Frankfurt, West Germany, and Lisbon on 2,000-mile routes that will bring them here on Monday.

BRUSSELS After the most severe strains of its 12year history, the European Economic Community was infused with fresh vitality last month and moved into what may be its most exciting phase of development.
The 41st anniversary of the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was celebrated quietly across the nation yesterday.

Two high officials in the City Controller's office were arrested yesterday on first-degree perjury charges accusing them of lying to a grand jury in connection with an application for city mortgage money.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished slightly lower yesterday in stepped-up trading.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 President Nixon is preparing to announce a new nominee to the Supreme Court, amid secrecy that has revealed only that the nominee's name will probably not be a household word.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Friday, Jan. 16 Vice President Agnew said here today that Senator J. William Fulbright "apparently has blown his cool again."
ALBANY, Jan. 15 The cost of welfare throughout the state for 1969 was estimated today at $2.2-billion, reflecting a drastic drop in the growth rate of Medicaid for the first time since its inception.

Mr. and Mrs. William Morris walked a mile in the cold yesterday morning to stand shivering on the corner of Bedford and Willoughby Avenues during the dedication of the Martin Luther King Jr. Building.

INVESTMENT clubs groups of people with small recurring surpluses of money who pool those resources and buy stocks came into vogue in the United States in the early fifties. This June, when the World Federation of Investment Clubs meets in Brussels, delegates will be on hand from 11 countries: Australia, Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Ireland, the Netherlands, Nigeria, New Zealand and the United States.
HONG KONG, Jan. 15 (Reuters) A retired United States Marine general predicted today that Communist China would test an intercontinental ballistic missile in the Pacific this year or early in 1971.
CAT CAY, Bahamas When the third day of our stay at Cat Cay dawned cold with the northerly gale of the previous 24 hours scarcely diminished, it became clear that we would do no fishing.
An alleged robber was shot and killed early yesterday by a customer in a Brooklyn tavern who then disappeared and is being sought, the police said.

JOHN CAGE strikes me as more of a mistake than a musician and, at his very urbane, charming best, more of a joke than either. Last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, with a, wistful arrogance that was engaging in its aspirations, presented something it called "Theater Event." It was neither theater nor an event. It was, however, something of a salutary occasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Republicans looked today to a record campaign budget and talked hopefully of a drive to reverse political history and capture control of the House from the Democrats in this year's elections.

IN 1966, at the age of 32, Kakubu Dan Yumma Gowon, the fifth son of a Gonwa tribesman, emerged at the center of a turbulent vortex of coups d'etat and assassination. The then six-yearold independent nation of Nigeria was being torn apart by regional conflict and tribal.

MADRID The two dozen young economists who write Spain's development plans work in a warren of offices in the basement of the venerable, totally inefficient Palace of the Presidency on the Avenida de la Castellana here.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 15 (UPI) A spokesman for the strikebound Santa Anita race track and the Federation of California Racing Associations said a new offer had been made today to the striking service employes unions.

Emergence of the Black Panthers as the romanticized darlings of the politico-cultural jet set is an affront to the majority of black Americans. This so-called party, with its confusion of Mao-Marxist ideology and Fascist para-militarism, is fully entitled to protection of its members' constitutional rights. It was to make sure that those rights are not abridged by persecution masquerading as law-enforcement that a committee of distinguished citizens has recently been formed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 A prominent scientist cautioned today that all doctors prescribing birth-control pills should treat each patient as though she were part of a research project.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) A peace fellowship group, including two clergymen now on trial for an earlier incident, conducted a mass without interference today on the steps of the Pentagon.

The New York Times received last night the 1969 award of the American Medical Writers Association for "excellence inwriting about medical subjects for the lay public." The award, a citation, was presented during ceremonies at a dinner of the metropolitan chapter of the association.
ONE of the last "men-only" bastions United Air Lines' 5 P.M. Executive Flight between Newark and Chicago died Wednesday amid cheers from women's rights groups. The Executive was 17 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 In an effort to reassure the bulk of the nation's broadcasters, the Federal Communications Commission said today that it would not entertain license challenges against radio and television stations that "substantially" met the programing needs of their communities.

SKIERS who have found the cold weather and high winds in recent weeks uncomfortable may be able to enjoy a change of pace this weekend. The forecast by the weatherman yesterday called for moderating temperatures, even high in the north country.

BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan. 15 (UPI) Isabelle Mir, Florence Steurer, Michele Jacot and Francoise Macchi gave France a sweep today in the Silver Jug races last major downhill event before next month's world championships.

MOSCOW, Jan 15 The Soviet Union announced today plans for a massive development program in western Siberia to take advantage of enormous oil and natural gas reserves in that sparsely inhabited part of the country.
LAS VEGAS, Jan. l5 Dr. Edward L. Teller, a leader in the development of the hydrogen bomb, today celebrated his 62d birthday with a defense of the programs of the Atomic Energy Commission.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15 Christian Belon, the 26-year-old Frenchman who hijacked a Trans World Airlines' jet to Beirut last Friday, was released from jail today on $8 bail on the order of Minister of the Interior. However, he could not make up his mind where to go.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 President Nixon has all but decided against asking Congress to increase excise taxes on liquor, cigarettes and gasoline as a means of insuring a budget surplus next year, officials disclosed today.

LISBON Portugal is starting to build her fruit, vegetable and flower industry, with an eye to foreign markets. Up to now, this garden country of Western Europe has barely produced enough farm products to cover her own needs.

LONDON, Jan. 15 Vaguely Anglicized by Ruth Goetz and Bart Howard, with one eye on the West End and the other on Broadway (David Merrick is the London co-producer), Francoise Dorin's "Play on Love" transmits Gallic smugness of a kind that sets one's teeth on edge.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan 15 Dr. and Mrs. James Nixon Trousdell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Allen Trousdell, to Jose Inacio Gonzaga Franceschini, son of Magistrate and Mrs. Jose Luiz Franceschini of Sao Paulo, Brazil.

PHILADELHIA, Jan. 15 (UPI) A Philadelphia banker predicted today there would be no recession in 1970, but that there would be an "abrupt change" in the economic policy of President Nixon's Administration.

The shaping of American positions for the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) with the Soviet Union has shown some alarming signs of excessive military influence and conservative Pentagon technical advice. But recently there have been encouraging indications that a countervailing force may be in the making in the Senate and in the President's Science Advisory Committee (PSAC).

TEL AVIV, Jan. 15 (Reuters) The widow of Dr. James Pike, the former Episcopal Bishop of California, who died in September in the Judean Desert, returned to Israel tonight to continue her husband's research into the origins of Christianity.
Walter N. Rothschild Jr., president of Abraham Straus, was named yesterday to succeed Andrew Heiskell as chairman of the New York Urban Coalition.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 15 Enemy gunners are reported to have fired about 100 mortar rounds into an allied artillery base near Cambodia and then launched a ground attack that died out after an hour of intense fighting. Allied soldiers killed 29 of the enemy, while suffering light casualties, military spokesmen reported here.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Plans to spend $540-million in a massive investment program in the northwest of England were announced by the giant Shell group today.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 15 An Israeli archeologist uncovered today in the Jewish Quarter of Old Jerusalem the ruins of a building that was destroyed in A.D. 70 along with the rest of the city.

Ever since the ships of Columbus first became entangled in its weeds, the Sargasso Sea has been known for its drifting plants, but today its coating of tar and oil is more extensive than its famous seaweed.

The Metroliner the Penn Central's silver-skinned, highspeed passenger train is a year old today, and still a big hit with travelers. But it is so hounded by mechanical bugs that the men who planned it say they wish they could go back and design it over again.
VIENNA, Jan. 15 Strong police forces were securing the center of Prague tonight, the eve of the first anniversary of Jan Palach's self-immolation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon christened the nation's first operational 747 jet the "Clipper Young America" at Dulles International Airport today.

"COMES the revolution there will be Hilton and Intercontinental hotels in every major city, Diners Club and American Express cards in every pocket, Hertz and Avis cars in every garage and Coke and Pepsi in every, bottle."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 About 1,250,000 Americans will lose their jobs as a result of reductions in military manpower and spending either already made or planned in the next defense budget, Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today.

TRENTON, Jan. 15 An increase in Blue Cross costs to New Jersey subscribers of 22 per cent, effective next May 1, has been recommended to the State Banking and Insurance Department by T. Girard Wharton, special counsel to the commissioner of the department.

Ammon Hennacy, author and former associate editor of The Catholic Worker, a monthly edited here by Dorothy Day and dedicated to the application of radical Christian principles to social problems, died Wednesday in Salt Lake City. He was 77 years old.

PARIS, Jan. 15 Ha Van Lau, North Vietnam's representative at the Paris peace talks, said at the 50th session of the talks today that President Nixon's three criteria for the withdrawal of United States forces "in fact can never be met."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The growth of the United States economy came to a halt in the fourth quarter of 1969 which is about what the Government had sought with its policy of restraint.

MOSCOW The Soviet Union is entering the 1970's with its economy continuing to react sluggishly to the efforts of Soviet leaders to instill a new sense of dynamism into both the industrial and agricultural sectors.

Yancy (Yank) Durham, the trainer of Joe Frazier, world heavyweight champion in six states, and Murray Goodman, a former sports writer and boxing publicity man for Madison Square Garden, were named yesterday to receive major awards by the Boxing Writers Association at the group's 45th annual dinner this spring. The site and date will be announced.

John W. Macy Jr., president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, suggested yesterday that public broadcasting could be a "positive, upbeat alternative" to the "veritable Grand Canyon of disbelief" existing in the United States.
City agencies are requesting a total far in excess of $8-billion to carry on their operations in the fiscal year beginning July 1, an unofficial tally showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 15 (AP) Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, said today he would investigate reports that Robert M. Morgenthau had been removed as United States Attorney in New York because of his investigation of the illegal use of secret foreign bank accounts.
ROME The healthy glow that has suffused the face of Italy for the last four years began to take on something of a hectic flush at year's end, threatening a bout of inflation fever for 1970.

SEATTLE, Jan. 15 (AP) The Seattle Pilots obtained three Oakland Athletic players today Lew Krausse, pitcher; Phil Roof, catcher, and Mike Hershberger, outfielder in exchange for Don Mincher, first baseman; Ron Clark, infielder, and Ken Sanders, pitcher.

The National Gypsum Company has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has increased its holdings in the H.H. Robertson Company to strengthen its in- vestment and to facilitate an acquisition of control or a merger or other combination with Robertson. Consolidated Edison's management has proposed to its trustees that its five-year construction program be increased by nearly a third to a total of nearly $2-billion.
BONN, Jan. 15 (Reuters) Opposition leaders depicted East Germany today as a satellite of the Soviet Union unable and unwilling to negotiate Independently with Bonn.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul. Pacific Railroad said yesterday that its preliminary estimates indicated it would report a $6-million deficit for 1969. In 1968, the road had earnings of $6,036,171 before various fund charges.

Lloyd E. Varden, professor of photographic science and engineering at Columbia University and a leading consultant to the photographic industry in this country and abroad, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 58 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Legislation to expand the availability of credit in poverty areas won the general endorsement of officials of several leading banks taday at a Senate subcommitte hearing.
LONDON A recent announcement that the Cunard Line's passenger fleet would make a profit this year for the first time in a decade mildly surprised even the man who made it, Sir Basil Smallpeice.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 15 This city's 430 public-school teachers have voted to walk out of the system's 10 schools tomorrow in a dispute that could set a statewide pattern in teacher-community relations.

The conclusion of a Presidential commission that an all-volunteer military force can and should replace the draft raises questions that go beyond the proposal's feasibility in terms of the manpower supply. The impact of the military establishment on a democratic nation's way of life is too serious to allow fundamental policies to be guided primarliy by technical concerns. The potential effect on the relationships of civilian and military sectors requires careful assessment.

LONDON, Jan. 15 William J. Owen, a 68-year-old Labor party Member of Parliament, was charged here today with offenses under the Official Secrets Act. He will appear at Bow Street Magistrates' Court tomorrow.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia The Yugoslav economy is still undergoing the difficult phases of the economic reform started in 1965.

PARIS, Jan. 15 In an experiment to bridge the gap between labor and capital in France, President Pompidou wants to give newly created shares of stock to the workers of the big state-owned Renault auto works. But the workers themselves are indifferent, if not downright opposed, to the idea.

SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill., Jan. 15 Gen. Jack J. Catton, U.S.A.F., commander of the Military Airlift Command, and Mrs. Catton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cheryl Lee Catton, to Capt. Francis Edward King, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. George King of Pinetta, Fla. A spring wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Secretary of State William P. Rogers decided today to withhold publication of the United States draft proposals for a Middle East settlement.

BONN As everyone knows, the "beetle" is German from tip to toe. It may surprise the ordinary West German, therefore, to discover that the bag of tools he received with his new Volkswagen came from Poland.
FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 15 A Roman Catholic Bishop from Puerto Rico, the Most. Rev. Antulio Parilla Bonilla, was prevented for the second time today from seeing prisoners in the post stockade here.
National Football League club owners failed once more to come up with a realignment plan for the 1970 season during a meeting yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina accused the Administration today of deceiving Congress with new orders setting racial quotas for Federal contractors.
The Yankees and the Mets mourned John Murphy yesterday the Yankees for losing another link to their glorious past, the Mets for losing a central link to their unpredictable future.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland Emerging from the stress and strains of 18months of civil unrest, Northern Ireland is, to quote the words of Commerce Minister Roy Bradford, "attempting to convince industrialists they will find a forward-looking, stable society."

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 15 (AP) Bert Greene still seeking his first tour victory, carded a seven-under-par 64 today despite an out-of-bounds ball and surged into a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $10,000 Phoenix golf tournament.
SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 15 The South Korean Defense Ministry denied today as "unfounded" and "deplorable" the charges that South Korean troops had murdered hundreds of South Vietnamese civilians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The chairman of the Senate Labor subcommittee called on Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz today to report on the depatment's progress in investigating the United Mine Workers of America. There were indications that the subcommittee was dissatisfied.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Bo Schembechler of Michigan, who suffered a heart attack the day before his Wolverines played Southern California in the Rose Bowl last Jan. 1, was named major college coach of the year today by the American Football Coaches Association.

BERLIN, Jan. 15 The East Germans reflected dissatisfaction today with Chancellor Willy Brandt's report to the Bonn Parliament yesterday, but they did not reject his offer of talks to renounce the use of Force.

METAMORA, Ill., Jan. 15 Don Bestor, a composer, conductor and pianist who had been music director for Jack Benny's radio programs, died on Tuesday. His age was 80.

WASHINGTON The United States will be host to a diplomatic conference here from May 25 to June 19 to negotiate a patent cooperation treaty.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 15 (UPI) Several fist fights broke out today among about 2,000 University of Tennessee students who gathered in front of the administration building to express their differences over selection of a new school president.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 15 (AP) The Cincinnati Reds sent Jack Fisher, one-time New York Met pitcher, to the California Angels today for two minor-leaguers Bill Harrelson, pitcher, and Don Loomer, shortstop who were assigned to the Reds' Indianapolis team in the American Association.

David Black has modified his original intention of not inviting the New York drama critics to review his latest production, "Paris Is Out," scheduled' to give its first public performance Monday at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

The New York Public Library's board of trustees has elected new members to replace four who are retiring.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 An attorney for the Black Panthers was ordered today to produce for two official groups a missing door panel from the apartment in which two Panthers died in a pre-dawn raid. The demand was made in behalf of a Cook County grand jury and a coroner's panel.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it was reorganizing the management of its Stock Clearing Corporation, which processes about $1-billion in securities transactions daily. Richard B. Howland, a senior vice president of the American Express Company, was elected president of the Clearing Corporation. He will be the first full-time president of the organization.

Renata Tebaldi, Colette Boky, William Walker, Cesare Siepi and Gene Boucher entered the cast of Puccini's "La Boheme" for the first time this season in the performance given last night by the Metropolitan Opera.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) Britain's mercy airlift to Biafra will begin tomorrow night when a chartered plane takes off for Lagos with 11 tons of supplies, the Foreign Office said today.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 15 The use of the American flag with the peace symbol displayed across its face was declared to be a violation of state law today by Nassau County District Attorney, William Cahn.
Officials of St. Luke's Hospital, replying to the demands of a dozen sit-in demonstrators, offered a three-point plan yesterday to expand the hospital's narcotics addiction treatment facilities.
"I WOULDN'T take normal people," Mrs. Julia Bolk said firmly. "They wouldn't interest me. And you don't know who you're getting."
Miss Alice Fenvessy and James Bruce Healy, who are studying for doctorates at Rockefeller University, plan to be married in May.

Frank Chapot, a member of the United States Equestrian Team for the past 15 years, and Jolie Richardson, a leading saddle horse exhibitor from Atlanta, were named Horsemen and Horsewoman of the Year for 1969 yesterday.

American Selling Price: The Tariff Act of 1930 defines the dutiable value of imports as market value in the exporting country before import duties; for certain chemicals, the value is put at the American selling price, which may multiply the duty that must be paid.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 15 (UPI) A new international communications satellite, insured against failure, was ready today for a switch into its final stationary orbit above the Atlantic Ocean.
NEWARK, Jan, 15 Criminal charges against 13 companies accused of polluting the tributary waters of New York Harbor were filed here today by United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 15 (AP) Gen. Charles de Gaulle picked President Nixon as a "man with a great future" when the American's political fortunes were at a low ebb, Foreign Minister, Maurice Schumann of France said today. He told the story to a Brussels lecture audience.

Governor Rockefeller promised yesterday that he would "personally oversee" the implementation of stronger, more effective antidiscrimination laws, especially in the crucial field of public and private housing.
LAGOS, Jan. 15 (Agence France-Presse) General Gowon announced tonight that all former civil servants and officials of public corporations in what was known as Biafra would be reinstated.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 15 (UPI) Ab McDonald's 20th goal of the season and Ernie Wakely's third shutout gave the St. Louis Blues a 2-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Under Secretary of State Elliot L. Richardson said today that the United States policy on Nigerian relief was "guided by purely practical considerations aimed at delivering the largest amounts of food, medical supplies and other required materials to the people who need them."

PARIS It was one of those frenzied years that seem to mark the turning points of history. Americans walked on the moon, and Europeans drew closer together economically. Governments changed, and new openings were made East and West. Out of currency chaos came the beginnings of a new monetary order.

In an effort to make its facilities "available to more members of the community," the Museum of Modern Art will suspend its $1.50 admission fee, the highest of any museum in the country, one day a week. Starting Feb. 9, the museum will be open free every Monday from 2 P.M. until 9 P.M.

JERUSALEM Pinhas Sapir returned to an old post, Minister of Finance, late last year and was staggered when he opened the books. Within days he had called for "drastic measures" to bridge Israel's growing trade imbalance.
PARIS, Jan. 15 Communistled unions sought today to nullify a key element in a longterm Government effort to end the traditional antagonisms between capital and labor.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 15 Billy Myer was wondering tonight what he would have to do for a victory in 1970 at Roosevelt Raceway. He finally found the answer in the feature Family Night Pace as he drove Black On to a two-length triumph in the mile race.

The Chase Manhattan Corporation reported yesterday that its profits, computed in conformity with the new accounting methods, registered a 6.3 per cent decline last year to $93.36-million, or $2.93 a common share, from $99.61million, or $3.12 a share.
Harold C. Halsted, a yachtsman and a retired textile manufacturer, died Wednesday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived there and in Bellport, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The Administration announced today an agreement with the state and local authorities in Florida forbidding the construction of a major international. jetport near the Everglades National Park. President Nixon hailed the agreement as "an outstanding victory for conservation."

DEERFIELD BEACH, Fla., Jan. 15 Mr. and Mrs. William Malcolm Tait have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Erelene Tait, to Peter Winthrop Burns-Meyer, U.S.N., an aviation electronics apprentice. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Burris-Meyer of Boca Raton, formerly of Arlington, Va.

THE HAGUE In the westernmost part of the Hague, a wet wind blows in from the North Sea over modest brick houses with red tile roofs and tulips in the windows. Children are playing quietly on the sidewalk. A matronly woman is walking slowly, laden with groceries.
Aaron Weinstein, a printing executive, died yesterday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 66 years old and lived at 65 Ocean Court, Brooklyn.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN'S return to the podium of the New York Philharmonic saw him in the latest phase of his career an opera conductor. Last night he presented a concert version of Beethoven's "Fidelio," the opera he is going to conduct this may in Vienna as part of the Beethoven bicentennial. Thus he killed two birds with one stone, giving the public a "Fidelio," of sorts, and himself a rehearsal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 That incorrigible football buff, Richard M. Nixon, has come to the end of the first quarter with his "game plan" intact. Like his friend Vince Lombardi of the Washington Redskins, he is sticking to fundamentals and controlling the ball.
GENEVA The eight member nations of the European Free Trade Association are about to welcome a ninth into their ranks although the dissolution of the group now seems imminent.
FOUR teams survive unbeaten in the New York Knockout Championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy as a result of matches played this week. The original entry was 59 teams.
A patrol boat called Sentry, which belongs to the Army's Corps of Engineers, struggled through deep ice floes in New York harbor yesterday as it made its rounds to check on potential water polluters.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 15 (AP) Jean Peters, the former actress, will seek a divorce from Howard Hughes, the mystery billionaire, a spokesman said today.

They turned out nearly 1,800 strong last night Governor Rockefeller, Mayor Lindsay and a host of other elected officials, judges and leaders of industry, labor and politics and their wives to salute a lean little man from the Lower East Side who made it big Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
SAO TOME, Jan. 15 Biafra began to fall apart on Christmas Eve.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI) A strike of Trans World Airlines was averted tonight when union and management representatives reached tentative agreement on a new contract only seven hours before a strike deadline.

THE HAGUE Curbing wage and price inflation is the central objective of the Netherlands' coalition Cabinet headed by Premier Piet DeJong, but its critics as well as some of its admirers feel that conflicts over wages and prices may kill the Government prematurely.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Yale University was placed on a two-year probation in all sports today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 15 A report charging that 10 per cent of the $590-million in California welfare grants paid annually to familities with dependent children are obtained fraudulently was released today to Gov. Ronald Reagan's administration.
The Pepsi Cola Metropolitan Bottling Company yesterday announced a novel advertising campaign designed to promote small businesses operated by blacks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The Government disclosed today that it had electronically monitored a conversation in 1966 in which one of the parties was the Rev. Daniel Berrigan, the 48-year-old Jesuit priest involved in the antiwar movement.
James T. Aubrey Jr. faced the stockholders of MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, Inc., for the first time yesterday and in almost three hours of questioning, much of it hostile, did not once lose his cool.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15 The Government today ordered commando representatives out of Hasbeya and Nabatiye, two southern towns, after demonstrations in which a commando office had been set afire by angry townspeople.

THOSE traffic jams inside the tunnel Macy's has devised on the northwest end of the ninth floor are not likely to end today when the store opens its newly designed modern furniture area. And there is a good reason. The tunnel is lined with settings displaying some of the ...
The Federal Reserve System's banking statistics continued yesterday to provide tantalizing indications that the central bank may have begun to modify its 13-month program of severe credit restraint.

Morris S. Goller, chairman of the accounting department of Grover Celevland High School, Ridgewood, Queens, died yesterday in La Guardia Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 58 years old and lived at 94-15 69th Avenue, Forest Hills.

DENVER, Jan. 15 (AP) Larry Jones scored 23 points for Denver tonight to become the first player in American Basketball Association history to go over the 5,000-point mark as the Rockets downed Dallas, 126-123, to take over second place in the Western Division.

Fifty years ago today national Prohibition closed all the saloons. The New York Times, reporting the reaction of the city, said in a headline the next morning that John Barleycorn had "died peacefully."
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 14 (AP) Following is the text of the surrender document signed here today by Lieut. Col. Philip Effiong, who was a major general and is acting as leader of the Biafrans:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 Twenty years to the day after he turned in his first National Hockey League shutout, Terry Sawchuk perhaps discovered tonight that at the age of 40 it's enough to survive when you're a goalie.

A Brooklyn jewelry concern accused of using "sewer service" to sue thousands of customers, a year for not paying their bills was sued by the Government yesterday in an attempt to force it to give back most of the money, it recovered through the courts.

New York City Ballet's Kay Mazzo made her debut as Terpsichore in "Apollo" last summer in Monte Carlo, the birthplace of the work, and last night she showed her interpretation to New York for the first time at State Theater. It was a characterization that pleasingly combined a sober reserve with suave lyricism.
Francis I. duPont Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage concerns, announced yesterday that it either had closed or would close a total of nine of its branch offices here and abroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Senator Edmund S. Muskie said today that the Nixon Administration's antipollution effort had been "slogan-rich and action-poor."

When Marty Liquori of Villanova lines up for the Wanamaker Mile on Jan. 30 at Madison Square Garden, many observers will be expecting him to provide the 63d Millrose Games with the first under-four-minute mile in its history. The Wildcat star filed his entry for the Wanamaker yesterday.

NEWARK, Jan, 15 Federal Judge Robert Shaw granted a severance and postponement of trial today to two co-defendants of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, a reputed Mafia figure, on charges of conspiracy and extortion.

The Brick Church Fair's 26th annual dinner dance will be held next Friday in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom. Mrs. James H. Terry Jr. is chairman of the evening, whose proceeds will be added to funds raised at the fair's annual November bazaar in behalf of charities supported by the women's association of the church.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 15 (AP) The Kentucky Colonels, tied 4-4 after the first two minutes of play, broke in front and stayed there tonight to defeat the New York Nets, 132-124, in an American Basketball Association game.

Tom (The Bomb) Bethea of New York signed yesterday to replace Juarez de Lima of Brazil in the 10-round middleweight fight against Carlos Marks of Trinidad, B.W.I., tonight at the Felt Forum. De Lima failed to obtain a visa and was detained by Brazilian immigration authorities.
LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Jan. 15 (AP) One of the last planes out of Biafra had 40 passengers and "a waiting list" of millions. The man who decided who got on board enforced his choices with a rifle.

In the second of his concerto concerts in Carnegie Hall, last night, Artur Rubinstein played something of a novelty. This was Chopin's Fantasy on Polish Airs, a work that is hardly ever heard nowadays.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 14 Lieut, Col. Philip Effiong, who was the leader of secessionist Biafra in the final hours before it fell last weekend, came to Lagos today and made a formal declaration of surrender.

Rising costs, competition from professional football, television appeal and confidence in a current success formula are some of the reasons back of the decision to allow college teams to schedule an 11th game next fall.

Max Hickman, vice presidentsales for Cook-Waite Laboratories, a subsidiary of Sterling Drug, Inc., died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Toronto, where he was attending a sales conference. He was 51 years old and lived at 87 Old Farm Road, Pleasantville, N.Y.

The president of a cooperative apartment house project on the Lower East Side has announced that he plans to "press for a speedy trial" following a judge's refusal to enjoin a tenant from keeping a dog in her apartment despite a ban against animals in her lease.

The Ford Foundation has contributed more than $195million to the arts since 1957, but on the basis of urgent appeals that it feels deserve attention it would need to distribute a much larger sum in 1970 alone.

DETROIT, Jan. 15 A threeday rest hopefully will have the New York Knickerbockers in top form as they resume action tomorrow night against the Detroit. Pistons at Cobo Arena. The game will be the seventh of an eight-game swing around the National Basketball Association before the Knicks return to Madison Square Garden on Jan, 24.

OAKLYN, N.J., Jan. 15 Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Palmer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Joyce Palmer, to Mark Fulton Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robinson Miller of Garden City, L.I., and Buck Hill Falls, Pa.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 15 The Texas Railroad commission decided today to hold the February allowable for Texas crude oil at the January market demand factor of 68 per cent, a record high since 1953. This is calculated to yield actual production of some 3,250,500 barrels per calendar day.
DARTMOUTH, Nova Scotia, Jan. 15 (AP) William James Roue, designer of the championship racing schooner Bluenose, died here yesterday. He was 90 years old.
With the European Common Market now beckoning to Norway and Denmark, plans for a customs union of these two countries with Sweden and Finland appear to have been sidetracked.

BONN Many West German industries stayed open over the Christmas holidays, churning out goods to meet the extraordinary demands of foreign and domestic consumers in what continued to be called the country's super boom.

The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday it had gains in consolidated gross income and net income for all 1969, despite declines in both categories during the fourth quarter. Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman, described last year's operations as showing "relatively modest rates of growth."

DALLAS, Jan. 16--Jesse E. Curry, retired police chief of Dallas, has suggested in a book just published that the entire circumstances surrounding the assassination of President Kennedy may not have been told.
ONCE upon a time, Kenneth J. Lane was a small time dreamer. He wanted to be a designer of "something."
OTTAWA--The Agriculture Department had some umpromising news last week for Canada's 189,000 grain farmers and for the Administration of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 16-- The Joint Legislative Committee on Education was told today that property owners cannot pay any higher realty taxes to support education and that the state should restore cuts in its aid program.

A Masked Ball at the Winter Palace is to be evoked Friday in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre. The event, the sixth annual Petroushka Ball, will aid the Russian Children's Welfare Society, Inc., an organization founded 44 years ago by Princess Alexis Obolensky and other emigres from Imperial Russia to assist children of refugees from the Soviet Union.

NAIROBI, Kenya--Arthur Ichoya is a twenty-year-old Kenyan, a Kikuyu, who has a certificate showing that he finished three years of secondary school. That is more education than the vast majority of his countrymen have had.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 16--The release on bail of three leaders of the Municipal Employes Union today was followed a few hours later by an announcement that negotiations aimed at ending the 12-day strike of 1,500 nonuniformed city workers would be resumed tomorrow afternoon.

STANFORD, Calif. The fundamental flaw in the Administration's program for Vietnamizing the war is that it does not facilitate the very compromise settlement that President Nixon has announced as his objective.
OTTAWA, Jan. 16 (AP)--The Government announced today its endorsement of Canada's eventual conversion of weights and measures to the metric system.

In the five and a half years that Richard M. Nixon lived in New York--from June, 1963, to January, 1969--he had a small group of intimate friends, men with whom he dined, shared his deepest thoughts, played golf or otherwise relaxed. These friends are high in the metropolitan area's banking, busness, publishing, legal and political communities.

PARIS, Jan. 16 (UPI)--The Monetary Committee of the European Common Market met today to put finishing touches on an interim report on arrangements for mutual medium-term financial aid among the six member nations.

LONDON, Jan. 16--London's theater critics were clearly baffled and generally disappointed with Edward Albee's play, "Tiny Alice," which opened last night in repertory at the Aldych Theater. However, they agreed that an Albee failure was more interesting than many playwrights' successes.

TIJUANA, Mexico--A United States airplane flown to Mexico to pick up half a ton of marijuana returned to California the other day carrying a load of alfalfa that had been "planted" in place of the drug.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16--A proposal to raise tuition at the University of California failed today to gain the necessary support at a meeting of the Board of Regents and was put over for consideration at their next meeting Feb. 19 and 20 in San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI)--Mrs. Philip A. Hart, whose husband is not only Michigan's senior Senator but also a ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, testified in a suburban Virginia Federal magistrate court today as a co-defendant with seven other persons arrested for participating in an unauthorized eucharistic mass in the concourse of the Pentagon last November.
Conversations monitored by the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the home of an alleged Mafia leader, John (Sonny) Franzese, were ordered withheld from the public yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 14--In this city where temperatures never stray far from zero in the winter and where spring is often very late, a secretary can now leave her coat in her office closet and do her employer's errands over a seven-block area, or go 11 buildings away for lunch, or stop off eight buildings away to shop without ever straying into the cruel air or defying the automobiles.

The six-man board of the Levin-Townsend Computer Corporation removed its largest stockholder yesterday as president and chief executive officer and turned over the two posts to the company's second-largest stockholder.

NEWARK, Jan. 16--The widow of the late Louis B. Saperstein was put on the stand as a Government witness today in the Federal conspiracy-extortion trial of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, an alleged Mafia figure.

Whitney North Seymour Jr. took over yesterday as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and said he would put particular emphasis on prosecution of business crimes and narcotics trafficking.
"DARLING! How marvelous to see you! Wasn't he wonderful?"

ONITSHA, Nigeria, Jan. 15-- Some 200 Biafran soldiers sat disconsolately in the dust here this morning or stood in interminable lines to register with the Nigerian forces and to receive medical attention.
BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 16 (AP)--Debbie Meyer, the Olympic champion and world record-holder, easily won the 400-meter free-style title in the Queensland swimming championships today.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday in active trading.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16-- The Bostwick brothers, Jimmy, the defending champion, and Pete, the world open champion, gained the final of the United States open court tennis tournament at the Racquet Club today.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 16 (AP)--Mrs. Ann Jones of Britain, the Wimbledon champion, and Jane (Peaches) Bartkowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., gained the final today of the women's singles in the Western Province tennis championships.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 16 (AP)-- The University of Texas is trying to recruit 14 black football players, Bill Ellington, assistant athletic director, said today.

Bach sonatas for violin and harpsichord were played in Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum last night by James Oliver Buswell IV and Fernando Valenti in performances that were genteel and pretty but not very Bachian.

DETROIT, Jan. 16--The New York Knickerbockers were expecting a tough game from the Detroit Pistons tonight at Cobo Arena and their expectations were completely fulfilled. The Knicks, sluggish after a threeday rest, had a battle all the way in downing the Pistons, 104-102, before a screaming crowd of 7,753.

Soybean meal and potato futures continued to dominate the commodities market yesterday. On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybean meal futures jumped more than $4 a ton and influenced an advance of more than 1 cent a bushel in soybeans. Soybean oil futures closed with a loss, however.
Stephen E. Smith, the guardian of the Kennedy family's political interests in New York, is expected to be the next prominent Democrat to become part of Mayor Lindsay's administration.
CAIRO, Jan. 16--Three Israeli aircraft were shot down today during attacks on Egyptian positions in the Gulf of Suez area, according to Cairo's military spokesman.

CHADDS FORD, Pa., Jan. 16--Miss Elizabeth Hannum Dean has become the fiancee of Alain Raunay Singer Jr., a descendant of Isaac Merritt Singer, who invented a sewing machine and organized the Singer Company.
"THEOREM" paintings are a form of early-l9th century American endeavor that can be seen currently in the new primitive art department of the Kennedy Galleries, 20 East 56th Street.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 16 --A new kind of $155-million hydro-electric project, unusual for the Tennessee Valley Authority, is to be built six miles west of Chattanooga, the T.V.A. announced today. Construction will begin in mid1970.

INDIANAPOLIS--John K. Snyder, the treasurer of the State of Indiana, is roundfaced, mild-mannered, conservative in dress and viewpoint-- a typical product of the small town, southern Indiana Republican organization that sent men like William E. Jenner and Homer E. Capehart to the Senate in Washington.
MIAMI, Jan. 16--Hialeah Park opened a 40-day meeting today apparently caught in the downward spiral that hit Tropical Park 10 days ago. Attendance and mutuel play were both off.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 16 (AP)--Vice President Agnew, winding up his Asian tour, declared tonight that the United States and its allies must stand firm in Vietnam and not be swayed by antiwar factions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) --A top Justice Department official has charged some federally paid lawyers with filing "politically motivated" lawsuits aimed at embarrassing the Nixon Administration.
The Bristol-Myers Company agreed in principle yesterday to acquire the Simplicity Pattern Company, Inc., through an exchange of common stock valued at approximately $450-million.
The Connecticut Commissioner of Transportation asked the Penn Central yesterday to take immediate action to solve problems that have led to a "growing list of complaints" about passenger service:

Thomas E. McInerney, 28 years old, was named yesterday vice president of the American Stock Exchange in charge of a new operations planning division responsible for the controls and planning of Amex automation and systems projects. Formerly an assistant vice president in charge of the market operations division of the exchange, he becomes the youngest vice president ever appointed by the Amex.
Eight of 13 Puerto Ricans who are accused of disrupting a church service in East Harlem last Dec. 7 were ordered yesterday to be held for trial next April 13 in Manhattan Criminal Court.
LONDON, Jan. 16 (Reuters)-- Another 5 cents an ounce was clipped off the price of gold here today, bringing it down to its lowest price in 16 years.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 16 (AP)--Arthur Ashe completed a rout of the Australian Davis Cup team and went into the semifinals of the Victorian open tennis championships today with two Australians and a Briton, all pros.

Wililam O. Robertson, a partner in the law firm of Howie Robertson, died Thursday after a short illness at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived at 5 Stonehouse Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.
The Hilton Hotels Corporation plans to construct a 45-story tower adjoining the New York Hilton that will make the hotel the largest in the world.
A suit charging baseball with violation of the antitrust laws was filed yesterday in Federal Court here on behalf of Curt Flood, St. Louis Cardinal outfielder for the last 12 years.
Zim Israel Navigation Company, Ltd., Israel's largest shipping company, has gone out of the passenger-liner business.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 16--The head of the Black Panther chapter here pleaded guilty today to shooting a fellow Black Panther who, the police said, was tortured and killed as a turncoat.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday scoffed at Governor Rockefeller's contention that the $24-million subsidy from the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority's surplus funds to the city's transit system constituted a grant by the state.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16--The director of information for the armed forces denied today that military officials censor the radio and television stations that broadcast news to United States servicemen overseas.

IT would be easy to give the back of the hand to this long, long-winded and sometimes incoherent exercise in per sonal panegyric. The unending stream of self-praise begins to sound like a caricature of itself.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 16--A student at Saigon University said today that in 1966 he interviewed at least 100 refugees who told him stories or gave eyewitness accounts of indiscriminate killings and destruction by South Korean soldiers in Phuyen Province.

A STREET vendor, using a 19th-century French roaster, will be cooking chestnuts over charcoal. A doughnut machine will turn out chili-flavored doughnuts at the rate of 12 a minute. Brass-banded English window-washers' pails will hold an unusual assortment of crudites.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- Three servicemen listed as missing in North Vietnam may be prisoners of war, according to new information received by the Defense Department.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16--Richard N. Goodwin, an aide to President Kennedy and President Johnson, testified today that he knew of "no plan for violence" by demonstrators at the Democratic Convention here in 1968.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- Scientists at the Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory were granted a patent this week for a method of producing power by controlled nuclear ...
Carbon monoxide fumes from a coal furnace killed a building superintendent and injured 17 other persons, including 14 children, in a six-story South Bronx tenement yesterday.
The Columbia University Senate adopted regulations yesterday that will prevent the university from participating in classified research projects for either the Government or private industry.
VIENNA, Jan. 16--The Czechoslovak Government announced tonight that members of an espionage ring had been arrested in Slovakia.

R gine, the popular French chanteuse and leader of the Parisian jet set, made her American debut at Carnegie Hall last night. She danced a little, sang a lot, and captivated a houseful of her high-fashion admirers, a fair number of whom had flown to New York especially for the occasion.
GENEVA, Jan. 16 (AP)-- The International Red Cross Committee said today it had received permission from the Nigerian Government to fly 21 tons of medical supplies to Lagos early next week.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 16 (UPI)--American Legion members here began today a national fund-raising drive to collect $200,000 for a legal defense fund for Army Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., accused of murdering 110 Vietnamese civilians.

Joe Frazier of Philadelphia, in training at Miami to defend his share of boxing's world heavyweight championship here against Jimmy Ellis of Louisville, Ky., Feb. 16, was named 1969 Fighter of the Year by the Boxing Writers Association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16-- The new gold agreement with South Africa provides no assured "floor price" in the free market for gold speculators, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs said today. Paul A. Volcker said the accord also denied speculators the "ability to 'unload' promptly without driving the price down."

The Ivy League colleges criticized the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday for its action earlier this week that placed Yale on a two-year probation and tabled future basketball participation by American students in the Maccabiah Games.

PUTNEY, Vt., Jan. 16--Competing on one of the warmest afternoons in this southern Vermont country in more than a month, Mike Gallagher, the slim overland racer from upstate Killington, rounded out a sweep of three national crosscountry trials today.

A significant factor in the low return in human betterment from the $1.5 billion a year the city spends on welfare is the time wasted on bookkeeping by skilled caseworkers. That situation may change for the better before the end of this year as a result of revisions planned by Mitchell I. Ginsberg, retiring head of the Human Resources Administration.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 16 (AP)--Vietcong guerillas invaded a hamlet near Songmy early today and hurled dynamite charges into houses, killing 16 persons and wounding 21, an American spokesman said.

Nine young conductors from seven countries were chosen as semifinalists in the 1970 Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition yesterday after quarter-final auditions were held at Carnegie Hall. They will compete in semifinals to be held Tuesday and Wednesday.
NEWARK, Jan. 16--The state police said today that they had broken up an Essex County gambling operation that was under the control of organized crime and was doing a $50,000-a-day business.
A lower fourth-quarter earnings report by I.B.M. caught Wall Street by surprise yesterday and sent glamour stocks tumbling in the heaviest trading of 1970.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) --A small rocket motor that ignited on a radio signal from Washington sent the newest communications satellite out of an elliptical orbit today into a circular orbit 22,300 miles high.

Tapes of a nine-year-old telephone conversation that were disclosed yesterday indicate th a reputed Mafia operator had dealings with Kirk Kerkorian, now the controlling stockholder of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and a major stockholder in Western Airlines.

OTTAWA, Jan. 16 (Canadian Press)--Canadian farmers could save nearly $15-million a year if they could buy tractors at prices close to those paid by their British counterparts, the royal commission on farm machinery reported today.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 16--An international team of observers just back from the territory that was Biafra reported today that they had found neither widespread starvation nor mistreatment of inhabitants in the part of Biafra that they visited.

International efforts to control aerial hijacking suffered a shocking setback the other day when Lebanon released on $8 bail a young Frenchman who hijacked and shot up a Trans World Airliner. The hijacker apparently is free to leave the country; it is not expected he will ever be brought to trial.

Carlos Marks of Trinidad made his first appearance in the Felt Forum last night. Billed as a future Sugar Ray Robinson, Marks, in stopping Tom Bethea in six rounds, proved only that he has a long way to go before he even remotely approaches the fabled Sugar Ray in talent.
The London Stock Exchange turned slightly firmer yesterday as selective buying pushed prices forward.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) National banks are authorized to buy stock and limited partnership interests in the new National Corporation for Housing Partnership, William B. Camp, Controller of the Currency, said today.

OSAKA, Japan, Jan. 14--A wine-colored shawl pulled tightly over her gray kimono to guard against the chill draft Mrs. Fusea Nakagawa hurried through the vast underground shopping center beneath Osaka's main railroad station.

The American Horse Shows Association licensed 871 shows last year compared with 824 in 1968, Albert E. Hart, the group's president, said in his annual report to the membership during the 53d annual convention yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 (AP) --Fifteen points by Wally Jones in the second period tonight sparked a 127-105 victory for the Philadelphia 76ers over the San Francisco Warriors in a National Basketball Association game.
Winter has brought the calm of snow and cold and empty beaches to the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, but it is a deceptive quiet.

The Corporation for Public Broadcasting is giving $500,000 to enable the Peabody Awardwinning children's series, "Misterogers' Neighborhood," to be seen on virtually all the public television stations throughout the country.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 16-- The young military officers who seized control of Libya on Sept. 1 in a bloodless coup d'etat took the first step today toward direct control of the country's administrative affairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP)--United States air travelers apparently had a merrier Christmas and a happier new year this past holiday season--they didn't have to spend as much time waiting in terminals and planes as in the past.
AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 16 (AP) --The Maine Supreme Court, in an advisory opinion, ruled today that legislation proposing state aid for parochial schools was unconstitutional. The vote was 4 to 2.
NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 16-- Dave Breger, the cartoonist, died today in Nyack Hospital after a long illness. He was 61 years old and lived at 26 Smith Avenue, South Nyack.

WOODSTOCK, Vt.--This beautiful central Vermont village, with its colonial charm and neat business section, is again throbbing with skiing activity. A City College economist predicts Manhattan's nonwhite population will begin to decrease after this year. The percentage in Manhattan's over all populatiion, however, he estimates will increase as whites thin out even faster.

THE first 1970 stamps from the United Nations will be issued March 13. Both stamps were designed by Ole Hamann.

COWRA, New South Wales, Australia--For those who do not consider a trip to Australia as getting far away from it all, there is now a way to go even farther afield: Visit an out-of-the-way sheep station here in New South Wales.

KENT, Conn., Jan. 17--Mr. and Mrs. William Howard Culbertson of Kent and Jamaica, W.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Cosgrave Culbertson, to Lieut. Sean Crombie Connor. U.S.A. He is the son of Col. John Powers Cannor, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Connor of Fair Haven, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

Gareth Martinis, the judge's son who won acquittal in 1963 on chargee of drunken driving and leaving an accident in which five persons were killed, was freed in $5,000 bail yesterday on similar charges in a new accident that occurred at almost the same place.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 17 (AP)-Charlie Davis, Wake Forest guard, paced a second-half rally that gave the Deacons a 91-90 victory over the seventhranked North Carolina Tar Heels today.

OTTAWA, Jan. 17--The light against inflation, which Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has made his paramount concern for 1970, took important steps ahead this week. ATHENS, Jan. 17--Extremism and violence within the Greek community of Cyprus drew a denunciation today from the leaders of the Greek and the Greek Cypriote Governments. In the past, both leaders have been viewed as stanch partisans of the Greek Cypriote community on the ethnically divided island.

RECALLING the 20th anniversary of the 1949 "Operation Magic Carpet," which brought Yemenite Jews to Israel by aircraft (rather than the "eagles' wings" of their prayers) Israel has issued a 30-agorot multicolored stamp, designed by Amram Prath. It shows a jewel-like plane in flight. A tab on the bottom row contains this quotation in Hebrew and English: "I bore you on eagles' wings and brought you to myself," from Exodus 19:4.

SAMSON, Old Testament hero, and Theodora, Christian martyr, are the subjects of two oratorios produced by Handel during his mature years. Aside from the great beauty of their music, the two works could not be more different, and they are a tribute to the composer's enormous expressive range. Excellent recordings of both were issued last year. They deserve anyone's attention, preferably in tandem, since they set each other off so superbly.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y.--Winter sport has come full circle in this busy Adirondack Mountain resort country. PARIS. ODD, one begins to think, that art should ever be otherwise. Women, flowers, the sky, mem ories of childhood, adult joys and hopes, color, excitement. Why paint at all, if not about the life that surges through you, the things that are you and are worth celebrating?

Novelists are rarely snobs; any life can be a matter of particular concern. Thus fictions affirm, among other things, possibility. But they are just as apt to search for it in the ordinary as elsewhere. The dust that settles over a household during one day in a given lifetime can suffice as atmosphere for the truly perceptive writer--whereas even the flares of a Gehenna would fail to illuminate the imagination of the run-of-the-mill faker.

A significant event in the expansion of rehabilitation services for the physically handicapped in Africa will take place tomorrow in Kampala, Uganda, with the beginning of the first international training course for the manufacture and fitting of artificial limbs and braces to be held in Africa.

ROSEAU, Dominica, W.L.--This West Indian island offers perhaps the best of Caribbean enchantments, if only in small quantities. Throughout Europe and other widely scattered areas, epidemic Hong Kong influenza is sending millions of aching people to bed with fever and respiratory symptoms and causing thousands of deaths.

ALTA, Utah--Easterners will find Western skiing considerably easi er this season if they trek to the deep-snow country of the Western Rockies. A majority of the new lifts added at older resorts or installed at new areas are rated "beginner" or "intermediate."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) --Twenty-four Senators and 95 Representatives scored 100 per cent this week in the A.F.L.C.I.O.'s record of Congressional voting on issues important to labor. All of the Senators and all but three of the Representatives were Democrats.

THE OPPOSITES COMPANY, described by it self as "an acting company that believes the esthetic realism of Eli Siegel has something to say to the theater," has been operating on this fond possibility for some nears off off Broadway. On Friday night, it brought its production of "Hedda Gabler" th an Off Broadway Theater, the Actors Playhouse.

Tom Gorman, a National League umpire since 1951, will receive the W.J. Slocum Award "for long and meritorious service to baseball" at the annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association on Feb. 1 at the Americana Hotel.
MY MY, perhaps the greatest five-gaited saddle horse of all time, showed practically no potential as a 3-year-old.

BUDAPFST--This Communist capital city is not exactly swinging yet, but the idea is no longer preposterous. Budapest is moving astonishingly fast to reclaim its pre-World War I status as the Queen of the Danube, as spritely and day as Vienna.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 17 (Reuters)--Four Londonbased journalists were expelled from Nigeria this morning for visiting the former secessionist territory of Biafra.
The Eastern Lawn Tennis Association endorsed yesterday a proposal that would sanction fees to a section holding an open tournament.

TAKING the low road is celebrated Tin song as the most effective road to Scotland, and in bridge books as the soundest policy for a defender in second position. Consequently players tend to play low automatically when a suit is led from the hand to their right.

The Plains, was married here today to Louis Philip Thebault Jr. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Edward L. Melton, assisted by the Rev. Neal Morgan.
Somewhere among the books and the filing cabinets in Carl William Ackerman's large West Side apartment, there is a wheelchair. It has never been used.
Curt Flood, whose Federal suit against baseball's reserve clause was filed Friday, was attacked yesterday by the presidents of the two major leagues for having failed to honor his contract.

MANY gardeners rely on seed and nursery catalogues to decide on the plants they will grow this year. Everything needed to plant and tend a garden can be purchased from catalogues. Although most sell the same kinds of seeds or plants, it is a rare gardener who is satisfied with only one.

AMIENS, France--In this age of lunar exploration, when moon dust, capsules, modules and gigantic rockets are becoming almost commonplace, it is not surprising that Jules Verne's house here in Amiens is becoming a popular place to visit. After all, Verne almost drew the Apollo 8 flight plan in 1865.
Orthodox Jews from various parts of the country paid tribute last night to Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson on his 20th anniversary as spiritual leader of one of the world's largest Hassidic groups.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Call of Fresh Meadows, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cathy Marie Call, to Lieut. (jg.) John Walter Newcomb, U.S.N. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Newcomb of Bayside, Queens.

Few of our social institutions are more oriented to the future than business. It knows that adaption to change is the measure of survival in a competitive world. The preoccupation of managers with the future has been redoubled by the furious pace of technological innovation. Perhaps the one volume that has contributed most to "business futurism" is The Year 2000 by Herman Kahn and Anthony J. Wiener (Macmillan, $9.95). It presents in

In most parts of the country, an American has to be near middle age to remember when the coal man came to the house. Looking like a fugitive from a minstrel show in his veneer of black dust, he used to back his truck to a cellar window. Then he would empty burlap bags of coal or coke down a chute into a bin near the furnace.

CLIFTON, Ariz.--Travelers who have driven the Coronado Trail (U.S. 666) from here to Springerville will be happy to learn that those rugged first 20 miles of the northsouth route are about to be relocated off to the east, out of the deep and gloomy canyon that the highway now follows.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17-- The telephones have been ringing steadily in recent days at the office of Representative William T. Cahill with calls from aides of other House members asking when his office will be closing here.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H.-- Well aware of the yearly increase in the theft of skis and ski poles, the New Hampshire Ski Area Operators Association has embarked on a pioneering plan of ski-equipment registration.

VIENNA, Jan. 17--Small delegations from institutes of higher learning in Prague started taking turns this afternoon laying wreath at the tomb of Jan Palach, the 20-year-old student who set himself on fire a year ago yesterday in protest against the Soviet--led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 17 (Reuters)--Pakistan plans to build a national mosque that will be in keeping with the modern grand scale of her new capital here. It has been planned to rank with Islam's most splendid places of worship.
By exercising some improvised whale psychology, Florida marine patrolmen have managed to save 22 of nearly 200 black pilot whales that beached themselves a week ago.

PITTSFIELD, Mass.-- Paul Bousquet, whose father founded Bousquet's ski area here 'in the Berkshires in 1932, is back at his childhood home with the aim of giving Bousquet's "some of the character it enjoyed back in the days when the rope tow was considered a luxury."

Columbia's track team built a 33-11 lead in the five field events, then held on to defeat Lafayette, 56-52, yesterday at Baker Field. The victory broke a 20-meet losing streak.
Roger S. Berlind is a 39year-old frustrated song writer who is doing much better on Wall Street than he might have done on Tin Pan Alley.

OYSTER, BAY, L.I., Jan. 17--Miss Sybil Kent Kane Baker, daughter of Mrs. Ross W. Baker, was married here this afternoon to Maurice Roger Carton 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Henri Carton of Ville Laval, Quebec.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.--Unusually heavy early winter snows promise a longer season than ordinary for the ski slopes of Sandia Peak, the high est point in the Sandia Mountains. The mountains overlook Albuquerque, from where the longest aerial tramway on the continent whisks winter sports devotees and sightseers alike up the 10,695-foothigh peak in a matter of minutes.

THE stock market and the economy were as chilled as the weather in many parts of the country last week. Temperatures were reduced by the frigid winds of uncertainty-over business conditions, corporate profits, inflation, monetary policy and the Government's fiscal plans.

GENEVA, Jan. 17--The Nigerian Government has denied permission for a Danish Red Cross plane with 10 tons of medical supplies to land at Lagos, the International Committee of the Red Cross said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) --President Nixon returned to the White House today after three days of solitary work at his Camp David, Md., mountain retreat.
SINCE the seasonal bills are already upon us or well on their way, this might be a good time for the jazz record buyer to turn to the cut-price reissue labels.

Books, broadsides and maps that deal with various phases of early American history will he auctioned on Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. The collection, from the Library Company of Philadelphia and the Pennsylvania Historical Society, will be offered in two sessions, at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (UPI) -A pair of Olympic champions, Kipchoge Keino and Willie Davenport, were beaten in their favorite events tonight at the Sunkist Invitation indoor track meet.

IN the musical world, at least, 1970 is the Beethoven year, because it is the 200th anniversary of his birth. But what year isn't a Beethoven year, judging by the amount of the composer's music that is played? And what year isn't a Bach year, with annual festivals at Bethlehem, Pa.; Cranbrook, Mich.; Berea, Ohio; Carmel, Calif.; Winter Park, Fla., and still other places?
CAN the truth prevail against a false idea whose time has come?
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 17 (AP)--Undefeated Kentucky got its fast break in gear early in the second half today and defeated Tennessee, 68-52, in a Southeastern Conference basketball game.
Although the Tokyo stock market has taken a tumble from its record highs, Japanese investment specialists continue to display a bullish attitude.
