The engagement of Miss Fern Patricia Sklover to Donald Prosnitz has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. I.T. Sklover of Queens Village, Queens. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Prosnitz of East Hills, L.I.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 17--The engagement of Miss Susan Wolins to Arthur Schaefer has been announced by her parents, Mr. andMrs. Lester Wolins. The future bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Sidney Schaefer of New York and the late Mr. Schaefer. A summer wedding is planned.

WANTAGH, L.I., Jan. 17 --The engagement of Miss Patricia Ann Landman to Larry R. Witlen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Witlen of Valley Stream, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herman Landman.

Miss Madeleine Fontein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pieter M. Fontein of Oradell, N.J., was married here yesterday afternoon to Wayne de Vries, son of Mrs. Raymond Drum of Zeeland, Mich., and the late Raymond de Vries.
MONTICELLO, N.Y.-- Sullivan County is rolling out an icefringed welcome mat for an ever-increasing band of cold-weather followers of Izaak Walton--the ice fisherman.

MERCE CUNNINGHAM is concerned with movement the way a composer is con cerned with sound, or a banker with money. To Cunningham movement is complete in itself--he has no desire to translate it into literature, to tell stories, draw pictures or paint characters. He is not above suggesting the occasional joke, but even these jokes are really about movement itself, rather than banana skins.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP) --Ed Bourdase of Fresno, Calif., rolled a 201 in the final round today and won the $50,000 Greater Los Angeles open bowling tournament. The 41-yearold bowler scored his first victory since joining the pro tour in 1961.

Anybody who races a Grand Banks dory on the East River these days must have something in mind other than sport, so the six men who will do it tomorrow morning were suspected of seeking more than the 4 British gold sovereigns (about $54) that were at stake.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 17--Last Thursday in Philadelphia; Ed Giacomin got a night off in the New York Ranger goal. Tonight, in the Metropolitan Sports Center, Giacomin gave the Minnesota North Stars an almost complete evening of frustration in leading his teammates to a 3-1 National Hockey League victory.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 18 (AP)--The Sunday Times of London said today that Gen. Odumegwi Ojukwu the former Biafran leader, was overthrown by military colleagues who had decided the civil war with Nigeria was lost. They forced General Ojukwu to leave the country.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 17 (AP)--Reports that four defendants in a narcotics case drew straws to determine who would plead guilty has prompted a City Court judge to reopen the case.
MIAMI, Jan. 17--This has been a fortuitous week for John L. Rotz. Last Monday the jockey was lucky to escape with his life in a dreadful spill at Tropical Park.

THE usual summer home of the American Wind Symphony is a red barge anchored off the north side of a park in Pittsburgh located where the Alleghany and Monongahela Rivers join to form the Ohio. When the weather is right, the symphony weighs anchor and sets out down the Ohio, serenading along the way.

WALL-mounted shelving systems, which have become increasingly popular in recent years, are now more versatile than ever. In addition to providing the homeowner with a factory finished wall shelving system that enables him to install shelves on any wall, and in almost any conceivable arrangement, homeowners can now also purchase wallmounted "furniture" units that can be hung from the same wall standards--with or without the matching prefinished shelves that are part of the system.

The small bomb that exploded in the office of the dean of boys at James Madison High School early last Monday startled and puzzled officials and students at what has long been among the most stable and peaceful of the city's high schools.
HARTFORD, Jan. 17--Four men were killed today when two private planes collided in the air near Brainard Field, a small private airport on the outskirts of Hartford.
DETROIT, Jan. 17 (UPI)Alex Delvecchio scored one goal and set up two by Frank Mahovlich today as the Detroit Red Wings snapped the Philadelphia Flyers' six-game unbeaten streak with a 5-3 victory.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 17. -Manhattan dominated the distance-running events, but gave away too much in the field events today as the Army trackmen registered a 58-51 victory. The cadets won seven of the 13 events while scoring 37 of a possible 45 points in the five field events.

PALMDALE, Fla.--Cecil Clemons wants to raise alligators commerciaily the way a farmer raises chickcas. As owner of Gatorama, a scenic 16-acre alligator farm three miles east of this central Florida town on U.S. 27, Mr. Clemons believes that, if he could operate a commercial farm on which gators were sold for their hides or for breeding, it would help stop alligator poaching, an act that is causing the creature's alarming, depletion.

LEESBURG, Fla.--Increasing numbers of motoring tourists tooling along busy Interstate 95 en route to Palm Beach, Miami and other Gold Coast points have been breaking out of the traffic pattern and heading into central Florida and its fresh-water fishing grounds. In 1968, the last year for which figures are available, fresh-water fishing licenses were issued to more than 175,000 outof-state residents as inland fishing blossomed into a multimillion-dollar business.

Hundreds of people, most of them poor, began lining up in midtown before daybreak yesterday, waiting in vain for the arrival of Michael Jamos Brody Jr., the 21-year-old who says he is a multimillionaire and who has promised to give away millions of dollars to those in need.

AGUSTA, Me.--No one knows the exact number of snowmobiles that are cruising about Maine this winter because, while no snow treaded vehicle can be operated in the state unless registered (at a fee of $10), no registration is required for those snow scooters operated by an owner on his own land. What is known is that there are now 43 snowmobile clubs in the state with a combined membership of about 6,000.

This could be the year the tank suit gives the bikini competition. The one-piece swimsuit began to get attention last summer at European beaches, and indications are that it is coming on strong at America's favorite resorts this winter. In either Mack Sennett stripes or offbeat geometries, the tank suit adds up to--1970.

MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, Jan. 17--Annemarie Proel, a pretty farmer's daughter from Kleinarl, Austria, surprised the world's top women skiers today by winning the giant slalom race in an international competition counting toward the World Cup championship.

MONTREAL, Jan. 17--Yves Pratte, the chairman of Air Canada, has been running the airline for only a year, but he has gotten off to a fast start by purchasing aircraft and equipment worth about a billion dollars, by challenging the airline industry to simplify its complex fare structure and by expanding routes.
The major leagues drafted 357 college and high school players yesterday, a record number for baseball's midwinter search for amateur talent.

A medium-sized Ohio bank widely known for its innovations, the City National Bank and Trust Company of Columbus, introduced last week what may be the ultimate in credit card services.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17-- Joanne Darakjy, a dark-haired beauty costumed in white, came through with a magnificent free skating performance to win the Eastern senior ladies' figure skating championship before a standing-room-only crowd of 1,100 at the Wissahickon Skating Club tonight.
KITZBUEHEL; Austria. Jan. 17--Dumeng Giovanoli of Switzerland won the men's giant slalom race in driving snow and mist today, establishing himself as the favorite to capture the Hahnenkamm Trophy.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17 (AP)-- The paternal grandparents of Mr. Brody live on a $200-amonth steelworker's pension, but they said today that they were not asking for any of the money their grandson said he was giving away.
QUEBEC, Jan. 17--Delegates to a Quebec Liberal party convention chose Robert A. Bourassa, a 36-year-old Harvardtrained economist, today to be their new leader.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 17--Tony Roche overcame an erratic Arthur Ashe in a stirring, four-set semifinal of the Victorian open tennis championships today.
GENEVA, Jan. 17--Smallpox has receded by almost 60 per cent since the launching of a worldwide campaign against the disease three years ago, the World Health Organization said today.

THE Terra Magics series of travel books, under the general editorship of Hanns Reich, are among the most handsomely reproduced in this fied. All adhere to the same format of a short introduction to a volume consisting mostly of photographs, selcted by Mr. Reich from the work of various photographers. This provides a cross-section of impressions and observations of the country treated.

President Nixon rightly calls abandonment of the projected jetport near the Everglades National Park "an outstanding victory for conservation." It is, in fact, a victory that goes beyond even the saving of that priceless natural haven. It is a hopeful indication of what can be done to save the remains of a magnificent national heritage when groups of private citizens are wise enough and determined enough to work together to that end.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Jan. 17 (Agency France-Presse)-- President Mobutu of the Congo today accepted a suggestion by President Bokassa of the Central African Republic that General Mobutu meet President Ngouabi of the Congo Republic on Jan. 22.
LAS VEGAS, Jan. 17--As a three-day symposium on Project Plowshare ended today, the nuclear program's problems seemed as impressive as its accomplishments.

CONSTRUCTION on the Keio Plaza Hotel in the shinjuku district of downtown Tokyo has begun. When completed in June, 1971, as part of an urban development project, the 51-story building will be the world's tallest hotel.
NAHA, Okinawa--ABout 50,000 workers of Okinawa's employed population of 422,000 have jobs on the United States military base here.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP) -A burst of 11 straight points midway through the second quarter today keyed a 141-116 victory for the Philadelphia 76ers over the Cincinnati Royals.

HONG KONG--Last year was a boom year for Hong Kong that brought big profits to the colony's basic manufacturing industries and an increased interest from abroad in its investment potential. But fears were expressed that the boom was generating side effects that could dampen future investment in this British Crown Colony.
BOULDER, Colo., Jan. 18 -- A Czech-born associate professor of modern Russian history has disappeared from the University of Colorado campus.
The Doors, the Los Angeles rock group, fought off repeated assaults by young members of their audience Saturday evening as it played its first New York concert in a year.
QUEBEC, Jan. 18-The Liberal party of Quebec Province aligned itself solidly behind its national leader, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, in the leadership convention here this weekend.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 18-- The two-day indoor GermanAmerican Soccer League tournament got under way at the County Center today before 1,100 fans with all the Major Division teams, except Hellenic, playing a total of 14 games.

A new city Children's Center for 250 neglected or abandoned children is a project that Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administrator, said yesterday that he hoped to see "before I die."

It was a potpourri of pieces designed for an open space unhindered by the restrictions of the proscenium arch.

CHATHAM, N.J., Jan. 18 --Mr. and Mrs. Arthur V.C. Marshall have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Beth Marshall, to William Edward O'Connell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Timothy O'Connell of Florham Park. A June wedding is planned.

Miss Sarah Ann Stark and David Arthur Ross, students at Wesleyan University, plan to be married in June.

Peter Martins, who has dropped in for the final weeks of the New York City Ballet season, made his formal reentry into the repertory yesterday at the State Theater with "Symphony in C" in the afternoon and "Ballet Imperial" last niQht_

VENICE, Italy, San. 18 UPI) - About 50 barges, motorboats and fishing craft -but no gondolas-cruised through the canals of Venice today in a demonstration against pollution.

The Moscow Philharmonic closed out its concentrated, eight-concert New York miniseason last night at Carnegie Hall. Kiril Kondrashin, conductor, and Van Cliburn, pianist, who have been heard with each other, off and on, since Mr. Cliburn became famous by winning the Tchaikovsky Prize in Moscow in 1958, were featured in the Liszt Piano Concerto No. 1.

THE radio news depart ment of the National Broadcasting Company took the unusual step last night of pre-empting three hours of "Monitor" for an exhaustive analysis of the subject of disunity in the United States. Scores of individuals, prominent experts and unsung laymen, were heard giving diverse opinions on the Vietnamese war, the attitude of the younger generation, race relations and a discussion of priorities for healing national divisions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Congress will begin work tomorrow on one of the most farreaching domestic proposals since the New Deal-President Nixon's plan to provide income assistance for 10 million of the working poor-and the political interests concerned are nervously maneuvering and probing each other's positions like armies on the eve of battle.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 18, --James L. Bruton, former superintendent of Tucker State Prison Farm, has drawn a $1,000 fine and a suspended one-year prison sentence on a charge of brutality against inmates. Federal Judge J. Smith Henley said he refused to send the defendant to prison because it was likely that Mr. Bruton would be murdered there.
ROME; Jan. 18-Pope Paul VI said today that he had "good news" from Nigeria where "responsible Government authorities" have indicated there would be no "violence or vendettas."

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 18 Secretary General Thant of they United Nations arrived in Lagos this afternoon to talk with Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the Nigerian head of state, about the immediate relief needs in the war-shattered territory of Eastern Nigeria and what is being done to meet them.

WHEN the Rev. Mannie Lee Wilson told his congrega- tion at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem that he was going to be the first Negro Protestant to preach in St. Patrick's Cathedral, he got a fast feedback.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 B'nai B'rith, in a documented analysis of textbooks used in Soviet schools, accused Moscow today of "systematically excising history" in an attempt to make the Jew a "nonperson."

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 18--Gordon Gray and Jesse Sammis 3d captured the final in the New Canaan Field Club's platform tennis invitation tournament today with a 6-0, 6-2, 6-2 victory over Chuck Baird and Roger Lankenau, the fifthseeded team and winners of the tournament in 1966.

CAIRO, Jan. 18-Passengers and employes at Almaza, Cairo's international airport, rushed to shelters today as, anti-aircraft guns fired at two or three diving Israeli planes. Concussion waves from the! guns, rattled windows in the terminal.

In the rhetorical style reserved by Congressional leaders for great occasions, Senator Hugh Scott concluded his annual report as minority leader with the perceptive observation that "Omnia mutantur, et nos mutamur in illis"--which he translated, "all things are changing, and we are changing with them."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-- President Nixon's State of the Union Message Thursday is eagerly awaited in Washington, but it is not likely to be as revealing or profoundly important--to him, to his staff, perhaps even to the country--as his speech to the nation on Vietnam last Nov. 3.

Beleaguered commuters on the New Haven Railroad, who have been promised a bright future as a result of a plan to put the railroad under state control, are almost daily struggling to cope with a nightmare of ancient, crowded cars, frequent delays, confusion and breakdowns.

INDIA'S central problem for the next several decades is to improve the ratio of food to people. In greater or lesser degree, this applies to almost all the countries of South and Southeast Asia. In size, and perhaps in severity, India's problem is the most difficult and the most significant.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 18--Mrs. Helen Cummings Cook of Wendling Farm, Williamstown, and William H. Vanderbilt of Williamstown, former Governor of Rhode Island, were married here this noon at the bride's home.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18, (AP) --The West, waking up after its defense scored a safety, rallied today and defeated the East, 16-13, in the 20th annual National Football League Pro Bowl game.
Robert D. Thomas, 60 years old, has been elected president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, succeeding Earl B. Hathaway, 66, who retired.

THE Asian region is big. The problems facing the region are big. They are many faceted. Half of the world's population lives here-hundreds of millions of people, eager to enjoy and to get, but who have to contend with hunger and with the lack of opportunity to substantially better their lives.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, Jan. 18-- Two Lake Placid high school seniors, Eddy Schissler, 17 years old, and Matt Bimonte, 18, went all out today to defeat each other but when the competition was over, each had emerged with victories in the Mount Beacon ski jumping tournament.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 18 (AP) --The United States Auto Club's board of directors voted today to continue dirt-track races as part of its championship car series.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)--Representative Richard Bolling, Democrat of Missouri, the first House member to say that John W. McCormack, Speaker of the House, ought to stand aside for a younger replacement, called on fellow Democrats today to start getting their names in the pot.

BANGKOK, Thailand--The sound of pile drivers preparing for new high-rise apartment houses, office buildings and hotels mixed with the blare of automobile horns in 1969 as Bangkok continued to buzz at a frantic pace.

BANGKOK, Thailand--The development of road transport in Asia, an absolute essential for economic progress over the vast expanse of the continent, is proceeding in a slow tempo of patchwork and paradox.

Virgil Fox so evidently enjoys giving organ recital-lectures, and his admiring audience, seated in the semidark, so obviously takes pleasure from luxuriating in the floods of sound that he sends forth that it seems churlish to point out that the sort of playing that went on last night at Philharmonic Hall would be hard to surpass for naivete and vulgarity.

DETROIT, Jan. 18, (AP)-- Al Karlander and Pete Stemkowski scored 59 seconds apart late in the second period today to break up Gerry Desjardins's great goal-tending effort and lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-1 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--An intense prebudget struggle has been taking place within the Government over the financing devices to be used for several important programs, notably the attack on water pollution.

SINGAPORE--By now it should be no secret that this city state of two million people is one of the economic marvels of the developing world. A recent book on the third world referred to the growth of "broken-backed states"--countries with good infrastructures from their colonial governments, but which were slowly grinding to a halt economically.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (Reuters)--Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States was pleased wish the attitude of the Nigerian Government now that the civil war with Biafra is over.

About 50 people picketed near Gracie Mansion yesterday afternoon to protest a money freeze that has prevented many physicians from getting paid for treating Medicaid patients. The demonstrators said numerous medical centers in poor, Spanish-speaking communities were about to close as a result.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18-- Dean Hiltzik of New York gave a crisp free-skating exhibition today in winning the junior men's singles title of the Eastern figure-skating championships at the Wissahickon Skating Club.

NEW DELHI--A foreign economist--Wolf Ladejinsky of the World Bank--recently warned the Indian Government that if the widening gap between the incomes of rich and poor farmers was not reduced, the poor farmers would start "raising hell instead of crops."

KARACHI, Pakistan--Last year saw the installation of a national administration pledged to a more equitable distribution of the fruits of this country's notable industrial and economic progress. This year finds the country looking forward to implementation of several specific promises:

KABUL, Afghanistan--Any smart Afghan who wants a loan to start a business or who wants to buy or sell some foreign currency would not dream of going to Kabul's big commercial banks. These banks are cumbersome, conservative institutions designed primarily to serve the whims of the waelthy men who founded them.

American Airlines. Inc., the nation's second-largest air carrier, and Trans-Caribbean Airways have reached an agreement to merge, it was announced here yesterday by George A. Spater, chairman of American, and O. Roy Chalk, chairman of Trans-Caribbean.

A Stanford University anes thesiologist, saying that there is a disproportionate number of surgeons in the United States, has raised the question of whether there might also be an excessive number of surgical operations performed.
COLOMBO, Ceylon--Government programs aimed at encouraging foreign investment here have resulted in a substantial expansion of tourist facilities.

TOKYO, Jan. 18-Brilliant with multicolored banners and helmets, some 5,000 students and young workers of the socalled new left gathered in a Tokyo park today to commemorate the battle of Yasuda Hall and to pledge new efforts to bring their version of a revolution to Japan this year.

SAIGON, South Vietnam-- Like a patient undergoing a harsh cure, the South Vietnamese economy was still gasping at the end of 1969 from a dose of bitter medicine administered in the fall by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-The Congressional controversy over proposals to grant a squadron of Phantom jet fighter-bombers to the Chinese Nationalists on Taiwan is expected to be resolved early this week after blocking for a month the approval of foreign-aid legislation.
The first Negro Protestant to preach in St. Patrick's Cathedral opened a nationwide observance of the annual Week of Prayer for Christian Unity yesterday.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 18--The Indiana Pacers have the best won-lost record in professional basketball, but their coach says they're not quite ready to dominate every team in the business.
A gala benefit for the University of the Streets will be held Thursday night at the organization's five-story building at 130 East Seventh Street, at Avenue A near Tompkins Square Park.
MANILA--The Asian Development Bank, a stripling among the major international development financing institutions, showed signs of developing a distinctive personality during 1969.
Hector's bustling cafeteria in Times Square, where one helping of strawberry shortcake could make an instant disaster out of a calorie-limited diet, closed at 12:30 A.M. today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 18-- Puerto Rico, known for its Casals Festival each June, has made a serious bid for another place on the world's cultural map with the first San Juan Biennial, presenting 700 graphic works by 180 artists from Latin America and the Caribbean. The exhibition opened Friday and will continue through March 15.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 18-- Since the war of secession began, two and one-half years ago, the street lights have been turned off in Lagos. The few people who venture out in the dark of the steamy nights feel their way to avoid drainage ditches around most buildings.
The Zlowe Company, made up of a nice group of people, really, will be introducing nudity to New York television advertising later this week. It's only infant nudity, however.

Playbill, the program that thinks of itself as the "national magazine for theatergoers," and Bravo, the program that thinks of itself as "the national magazine for concertgoers," are both products of the publishing division of Metromedia.
The money and capital markets are heading into a crucial three-week period that will largely determine the course of interest notes this year.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28--Steel mills are searching hard for an order improvement.

BOSTON, Jan. 18-The New. York Knickerbockers, with the exception of Willis Reed, suffered a disastrous shooting drought in the third quarter that brought about a 109-102 defeat at the hands of the Boston Celtics, the National Basketball Association's defending champions, in a nationally. televised game today at Boston Garden.

Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. of the State Assembly said yesterday that he had urged Governor Rockefeller to give Dr. William J. Ronan more help in running the Long Island Rail Road and that the Governor had found it "a stimulating idea."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-- (AP)--The Government will tell the nation's 43 commercial airlines Tuesday they must end pollution of the skies with jetengine smoke by 1972 or face punitive legislation from Congress.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Zeeman Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Zeeman's daughter, Miss Laurie Jane Lees, to James Richard Bottomley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bottomley of Geneva. A June wedding is planned.

DENVER, Jan. 18 (AP)--The Denver Rockets whirled to their 13th straight victory in the American Basketball Association today with a 135-112 decision over the Carolina Cougars before a standing room crowd of 7,014.
New York City's position as the only remaining legal jurisdiction in the nation that denies a jury trial to a defendant facing up to a year in jail has sharply divided the city's chief prosecutors.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 18- A dynamite explosion in a Jewish school early today! shattered hundreds of windows! and injured several patients at a nearhy Arab hospital.
HOUSTON--A close look at aggravated pollution in south Texas waterways has stiffened the determination of Federal officials to press for quick Congressional revision of national water quality laws.
TAIPEI, Taiwan--Taiwan is entering the decade of the seventies with a drawing board full of economic plans, after passing the $2-billion mark in foreign trade for the first time since 1969.
SEOUL, South Korea--The South Korean economy faced problems of everheating in 1970, and the Government has lowered the growth goal to 11 per cent in an attempt to cool things off.

SAIGON, South Vietnam-- A middle-aged man with mud-stained ankles plods behind a water buffalo in a landlord's flooded rice field, while hoping that the combatants on both sides of the war will leave him alone. That has been the picture of the South Vietnamese farmer for the past five years.
BOMBAY, India, Jan. 18An Israeli fighter bomber dropped two bombs in the vicinity of the Cairo airport this afternoon, setting a fire that was still burning nearly two hours after the strike.
HONG KONG--United States cigarette manufacturers have found an expanding market in Hong Kong, where smokers have developed a taste for American brands.
OSAKA, Japan--Visiting the headquarters of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Ltd., is a bit like attending a Moral Rearmament meeting.

MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, Jan. 18 (AUPI)--Barbara Cochran of the United States captured the slalom event today and took top honors in the twoday competition counting toward the women's World Cup championship in Alpine skiing.
Claude Robinson, an employe of The New York Times since 1933, died of a heart attack Saturday at Parkchester General Hospital in the Bronx. He had marked his 64th birthday the day before.
New York City's weekend death tall from fires stood at eight last night and fire fatalities since Jan. 1 climbed to 26 yesterday with the deaths of two women in Qucens and a man in the Bronx.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Jan. 18- One of the loudest, if not the largest, protest marches ever held in this city took place without incident today over the closing of the LIFO, one.of the nation's first antiwar coffeehouses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-The General Accounting Office has recommendcd to Congress that uniform accounting standards be established as a check on the price of defense contracts and to prevent contractors from charging the Government twice for certain costs.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18--A young Belgian disrupted the intermission of the Russian production of "My Fair Lady" tonight by shouting support for Soviet political dissidents and throwing hundreds of leaflets to the theater audience.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 18 (AP)--A.J. Foyt of Houston, Tex., won a crash-marred Riverside-Motor Trend 500-mile stock car race today by about three seconds in his 1970 Ford Torino.

After all the planning and controversy, the success of the decentralization of the city's schools depends in large measure on the citizens' concern and participation. MILWAUKEE, Jan. 18 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks took a 20-19 first-period lead today and went on to crush the San Francisco Warriors, 123-107, in a National Basketball Association game.
Stormdrill VI, the new mobile oil drilling platform recently completed for the Storm Drilling Company of Houston by the Bethelehem Steel Corporation, boasts a wrinkle--limited propulsion.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 18-- Alfred Noroton Phillips, threetime Mayor of Stamford during the nineteen-twenties and thirties, and a former United States Representative, died at Stamford Hospital this afternoon of a heart attack. He was 75 years old and lived at 29 Middlesex Road, Darien.

COLOMBO, Ceylon--The Government of Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake, after leading Ceylon to a 6 per cent economic growth during 1969 is girding for an even greater growth during the election year of 1970.
The young men's division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University will hold its Winter Wonderball Jan. 31, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia--The May 13 riots in the capital, Malaysia's worst racial disturbances since independence, inflicted, apart from lost productivity for a few days and decreased consumer spending for a few months, little short-term damage to the country's economy. They did, however, put a damper on Malaysia's industrialization program.

TOKYO--Japanese companies, encouraged by the Government, will be helping underdeveloped countries to increase their food production. And they hope to help themselves to the big consumer markets in these nations once they develop self-sufficiency in food.

WILIMAR, Minn., Jan. 18 (AP)--President Nixon's threat to veto the health, education and welfare appropriations bill is an attempt to "repeal the nineteen sixties," former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said last night.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 18-David O. McKay. president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, died today at the age of 96. Physicians said the Mormon leader died of acute congestion of the heart at 6 A.M. after having been in a coma for six hours.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 18 (Reuters)--A recurring elbow injury forced Tony Roche of Australia, the world's No. 2ranked tennis player, to withdraw today from the men's singles final in the Victoria State open championships.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP)-- Bobby Orr broke his season scoring record for defensemen and his Boston Bruins teammates staged a four-goal rally in the final period tonight for a 6-3 National Hockey League victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

The Torch of Learning Award, a bronze statuette sculptured by the New York artist Chaim Gross, has been created by the American Friends of Hebrew University to honor leaders of American-Jewish communities who have advanced the cause of higher education in this country and Israel.

TRADE and capital liberalization were major issues in relations between the United States and Japan during 1969. HOUSTON, Jan. 18--Prospects for the housing industry in 1970 were described today as "dismal--and getting worse" by the leadership of the 51,000member National Association of Home Builders.

AUCKLAND, N.Z.--Trade figures last year first gratified officials with the speed at which the economy bounded back from the recession of 1967-68, then puzzled them. The continuing dynamism of the economy is now even causing some misgivings as to whether such an upsurge will bring difficulties.

Dr. Benjamin J. Pressman, a dentist who became a professional magician, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 345 Eighth Avenue.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18, (AP)--The indoor track and field scene shifts eastward this week and at least one 1968 Olympic champion, Kipchoge Keino of Kenya, will be seeking to reverse his first loss of the winter season.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP)-Two explosions damaged Karl Marx's tomb and memorial in north London during the night, Scotland Yard reported today.
NEW DELHI--A simple red triangle, the symbol of India's birth control program, is seen everywhere these days-- from the lapels of public officials to the sides of locomotives.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 18-- Leroy D. Downs, a former United States Representative and newspaperman, died today at Norwalk Hospital. His age was 70 and he lived at 29 Elmwood Avenue.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 18 (UPI)--Dale Douglass shot a 66 in the final round to pull away from the pack and win the $100,000 Phoenix open golf tournament today with a 72-hole total of 271, two strokes under par. The first prize was $20,000.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 18--A plan for de luxe bus service between four places in Nassau County and the East Side of Manhattan during the morning and evening rush hours has been announced by County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18--(AP) Dave Lundmark of Duluth, Minn., defeated six members of the United States national team today to win the Class A division of the 65th Norge Ski Jump and the Central Division championship of the United States Ski Association.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Jan. 18 --Maj. Gen. Wallace C. Philoon, U.S.A., retired, who commanded the Army's center at Fort McClellan, Ala., from 1942 to 1944, when 200,000 infantry replacement troops were trained for World War II, died on Friday in a hospital in Portland. He was 86 years old.

The Committee of Liaison With Families of Servicemen Detained in North Vietnam, organized by antiwar activists to facilitate the exchange of mail between American prisoners held in North Vietnam and their families, opens its office today at 365 West 42d Street, according to the chairman of the group.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Jan. 19 MacDonald Smith, a partner in the New York law firm of Holtzmann, Wise Shepard, 30 Broad Street, died today of a heart attack at his home on Mendham Road. He was 40 years old.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 Governor Rockefeller called today for an election-year budget of nearly $7.3-billion that he described as a "socially responsive" and "fiscally responsible" program that could be financed without increasing state taxes.

Even the most gifted linguists usually speak their native tongues more fluently than others, but it was still a gratifying surprise last night at Carnegie Recital Hall to hear Donald Weilerstein and Susan Halligan give so idiomatic a performance of the Ives Sonata No. 2 in G.
Thirteen striking gravediggers were arrested yesterday when they tried to prevent hearses from entering the Roman Catholic Calvery Cemetary in Long Island City, Queens.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 19 A Suffolk grand jury recommended in a report made public today that the dean of students and an assistant dean at the State University Center at Stony Brook be dismissed for neglecting to enforce university rules governing the use of drugs on the campus.

BRIDGEWATER, N.J., Jan. 19 Miss Barbara R. Marinelli and Douglas Chipman Dobson plan to be married in April. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Frank Marinelli, corporate controller of the Fedders Corporation in Edison, and Mrs. Marinelli. Mr. Dobson is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman S. Dobson of North Windham, Me.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) Three of the nation's largest airlines American, Trans World and United asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to approve a two-drink limit for passengers on domestic flights.
Steel production last week was 0.3 per cent higher than output the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
WHEN I.B.M. set a record at 387 on Friday, traders must have had a rather heady notion of the kind of earnings the giant computer company was going to show for 1969.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 19 About 100 representatives of peace groups picketed the offices of Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn today to protest his ruling that the use of an American flag with symbols displayed across its face was a violation of state law.
Barry Gottehrer, who developed the Mayor's Urban Action Task Force during the first Lindsay administration, was given a new title by the Mayor yesterday along with praise for past performances.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 19 (AP) The Massachusetts Institute of Technology applied today for court complaints charging 31 individuals with trespassing in the invasion of the top administrative offices at the institute last week.

ATHENS, Jan. 19 The Greek Government reached preliminary agreement today with Aristotle Onassis, under which the shipping magnate will invest $600-million in industrial projects, including a planned oil refinery. At the same time, the Government pressed similar negotiations with another millionaire, Stavros Niarchos, for a $200-million contract.

A team of researchers says that it has detected a new strain of a common intestinal bacteria and that this strain caused diarrhea in a group of British soldiers flown from Britain to Aden, in the Middle East.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 19 Larry Mallar, the racing secretary for Roosevelt Raceway, announced today an eight-horse field for the $25,000 Early Bird Pacing series final Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 An increasing number of senior American military planners are coming to believe that enemy commanders in Vietnam are building toward a major countrywide offensive this summer, rather than next month as previously thought.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 19 (UPI) Jody Finney scored 30 points tonight in leading Ohio State to an 84-70 victory over West Virginia.

PANAMA, Jan. 19 The Panamanian Government signed today an agreement with the British-German-Italian consortium to build a wholly Panamanianowned oil pipeline across the Isthmus of Panama which, according to its promoters, will compete with the Panama Canal.
The mass beaching of whales at Fort Pierce, Fla., on Jan. 10 may have come about because the echo-ranging equipment of the animals could not detect a shelving shore.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 19 (AP) Most West German banking institututes announced today an increase of the basic interest rate for saving accounts to 4.5 per cent from 4 per cent, effective Feb. 1.

Ten of the world's best women tennis players, who have graced courts all over the world, are going to compete at one of the strangest places they've ever been for a tournament the third floor of the Grand Central Terminal building here.

But Mrs. Gladys Fitchett, the school's lunch manager, spends three and onehalf hours every day warming soup for 300 children on three small, antiquated gas burners while the heating unit remains unused.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 19 Paul Fenimore Cooper, great-grandson of James Fenimore Cooper, died in his home here yesterday after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 19(Reuters) Swedish and Italian drivers said today their cars had been sabotaged during the first stage of the Monte Carlo Rally.

HOUSTON, Jan. 19 Two Cabinet members used the rostrum of the troubled homebuilding industry today to defend the Administration's tough prescription for curing inflation, arguing that the bitter medicine would be good for housing over the long pull.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Soviet Union said today that it would broadcast statements attributed to American prisoners in North Vietnam, and the State Department responded with a formal diplomatic complaint.
CONNECTICUT'S Board of Fisheries and Game is reminding anglers that many of the state's lakes and ponds are open to the taking of all species of fish through ice until Feb. 22.

TRENTON, Jan. 19 As one of the final acts of his administration, Gov. Richard J. Hughes today averted a crisis that threatened hundreds of thousands of the state's automobile liability insurance policy holders.

NEWARK, Jan. 19 A letter written by a man the day before he died was heard by a jury in Federal court here today where Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, reputed Mafia figure, and Daniel (Red) Cecere are on trial.

The engagement of Miss Myrna Debra Margulies to William Arthur Breitbart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Breitbart of New Rochelle, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Margulies of New York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 President Nguyen Van Thieu was reported today to have ordered the shifting of three more South Vietnamese commanding generals in what informed sources said was a major shake-up brought about, at least in part, by American pressure to improve the performance of the army.

BERLIN, Jan. 19 West Germany and East Germany indicated in separate statements today that political talks between them could be opened for the first time since the two states were established 20 years ago.

Ann Corio, last of the coterie of runway queens that included Gypsy Rose Lee, Margie Hart and Georgia Sothern, is bringing back "This Was Burlesque." The 1970 edition of the show, a musical satire based on Miss Corio's recollections, opens at the new Hudson West Cabaret, 57th Street and Ninth Avenue, on Feb. 11 for an indefinite run.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 With the disclosure of plans for New York's new Congressional districts today, the Democrats picked up one new candidate for the United States Senate and lost another.
KEARNY, N.J., Jan. 19 A rolling-mill furnace exploded here early today forcing tons of steel through a 40-foot-high roof and blowing out the factory's steel window frames.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 The Republican leadership of the Legislature made public a Congressional reapportionment plan today that many politicians expect to help the election of two or more new G.O.P. Congressmen this year.

IF ANITA LOOS was right about gentlemen and blondes, the black-tied men who dined and danced at the Fanci-full party in the Plaza's Terrace Room last night never had it so good. Most of their partners were blondes. There were silver blondes and golden blondes, blondes who were born that way or who elected to be. There were even some blondes who usually prefer to be brunettes.

THE Canadian Broadcasting Corporation sent a report er and camera crew to Communist China during last fall's trade fair in Canton. They brought home the familiar propaganda film, as Chinese guides decided what could be photographed. In the documentary, seen last night on Channel 13, Bill Cunningham acknowledged he had been in China for less than two weeks, and always stressed that he was under censorship wraps.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI) Jim Cook remained in extremely critical condition today following his spectacular accident yesterday in the Motor Trend 500 at the Riverside International Raceway.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 19 The ultra-right fing Reconstituted Nationalist party, led by a former Cabinet minister, Dr. Albert Hertzog, is now considered a bigger threat to Prime Minister John Vorster than his ruling National party had believed.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 19 (Reuters) Two hundred steel-helmeted troops armed with submachine guns occupied the campus of National University today and tore down placards attacking a proposed university reform bill.
Bob Scheffing, one-time catcher and manager in the major leagues, was named vice president and general manager of the world champion New York Mets yesterday.
ENCINO, Calif., Jan. 19 Simon Kovar, second bassoonist with the New York Philharmonic from 1923 to 1949, died at his home here on Saturday of a heart attack. He was 79 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Supreme Court declined today to strike down vaguely worded jury selection laws that Negroes contended had been used in Alabama and Georgia to keep many blacks off jury rolls.

The Bureau of the Budget was reported yesterday to be opposing approval of a plan by Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe for creation of a quasi-public corporation to run the nation's railroad passenger system.
Burglars and persons who commit felonious assaults fall into a pattern and usually repeat their crimes, according to a police study disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Securities and Exchange Commission has apparently closed the door against the type of self-regulation of mutual fund fees that was recently proposed to Congress by the fund industry's trade organization, the Investment Company Institute.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 David D. Thomas announced his resignation and retirement today as deputy administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, effective Feb. 15.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Food and Drug Administration urged the nation's doctors today to pay close attention to the risks involved in the use of birth control pills and to explain to their patients the potential hazards of the pills.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Sounds of the sky, overheard when the jets were getting bigger than ever:
Y.J. Johnson Jr. has been appointed senior vice president of the Bank of America-New York. He has been with the bank for 23 years and since 1950 has been vice president of international banking.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Two Presidential committees called today for training of the mentally retarded in more fields such as electronics and data processing.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 19 Army limited Fairleigh Dickinson to two field goals and 13 points in the second half and registered a 44-38 victory today in a battle of defensive standouts. The cadets lead the nation in team defense and Fairleigh is ranked eighth.

The Colonial Commercial Corporation announced yesterday it had held preliminary discussions with some of the directors of the Coburn Corporation of America regarding the acquisition by Colonial of about 51 per cent of the outstanding shares of Coburn.
Going from one good thing to another is the way supporters of the America-Israel Cultural Foundation will spend the evening of Feb. 1.

Make-believe boxing makes its debut on the movie screen tonight when approximately 1,500 theaters in the United States and Canada show a staged color film of a fight between two former world heavyweight champions, Rocky Marciano and Cassius Clay. A computer will determine the outcome.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19 Richard M. Kleindienst, United States Deputy Attorney General, joined-Mexican officials today in the burning of several tons of marijuana, as a symbol of international cooperation to reduce traffic in narcotics and dangerous drugs.
About 120 Lower East Side residents demonstrated in Beth Israel Hospital at noon yesterday to protest the dismissal of a physician who had publicly supported their demand for reforms.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 19 Appeals Court Judge G. Harrold Carswell said today that he had no financial interest that could cause the Senate any difficulty in deciding whether to confirm him as a Supreme Court Justice.
Three senior corporate executives moved to get new jobs for themselves yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Student harassment of Peace Corps teachers in Ethiopia has caused the corps to cut back its educational programs there and to recall some volunteers to the United States.

THE Swiss Team tournament that closed the Tri State Regional Championships at Grossinger, N.Y., Sunday was won by a fiveman team headed by Murray Schnee of New York. Teamed with Sol Seidman and Jim Becker of New York, Jim Bennett of Hartford and Tannah Hirsch of Stamford, Conn., he won eight matches out of a possible nine to head a field of 128 teams.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 "There is no philosophy in this budget," a high administration source said of Governor Rockefeller's $7,257,000,000 spending plan for this election year. "We didn't begin with any philosophy this is built from the bottom up, not from the top down with any philosophical consid erations."

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 19 ?This city was in semi-official mourning today as Mormons and gentiles alike marked the death of 96-year-old David O. McKay, ninth president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Influenced by the weather, trading on the Chicago Board of Trade opened on a mixed and active note yesterday, slowed down for a while and then quickened in the closing minutes of the session.
PARIS, Jan. 19 Virtually all the industrially advanced countries expect a surplus in their trade in goods and services with the rest of the world next year.

A long-pending complaint by a Brooklyn dock worker that he was once asked to join a socalled Cosa Nostra family and lost his job after he wouldn't do so was reported yesterday to be close to a decision by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

The head of an organization representing 1,500 Eastern Nigerians living in the United States charged yesterday that the Government in Lagos was waging "planned and systematic genocide" on the people of defeated Biafra.
Concerned about their inability to increase their profit margins on foods, supermarket chains are planning to turn more and more to higher-profitratio nonfood products.
The Caterpillar Tractor Company achieved a 17 per cent increase in sales and earnings last year, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 19 First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with killing 109 Vietnamese men, women and children at Songmy, declined to testify today at a hearing on an additional charge that he murdered a Vietnamese civilian about six weeks prior to the alleged Songmy action.
The fifth plenary assembly of the Dutch Pastoral Council has expressed the opinion of a substantial part of the church community in the Netherlands as to the junction of celibacy and priesthood.

Syntex Laboratories announced yesterday that it was suspending clinical tests of its "minidose" oral contraceptive pending further analysis of unusual changes in the breast tissue of dogs treated with the drug.

Jack Curran tossed aside his draft of the opening paragraph of the introduction of his book Saturday night on a desk cluttered with papers. It was now game time and Curran, the Archbishop Molloy High basketball coach, stepped into a packed gymnasium where his unbeaten Stanners were to defeat Bishop Reilly, 70-61, for their 12th victory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) After a week of painful economizing. President Nixon has come up with a budget for the 1971 fiscal year that will provide at least some surplus and require no new excise taxes, the White House reported today.
A private Bronx treatment center for adolescent heroin addicts has received a summons for violation of the new Building Code.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 18 The trial of Julius Klein Jr., who has been convicted of murder, and two others on robbery and kidnapping charges, resulted in a mistrial today.
MARSEILLES, France, Jan. 13 Called by radio to an interview, Chief Commissaire Maurice (the Beard) Hug left his men staked out near a suspect bar and returned to his office a little out of sorts.

AT his most succinct, Bernard Shaw is a wordy and tendentious playwright, and few, if any, of his plays are more wordy and tendentious than "Getting Married," which has just been revived by the Equity Library Theater.
PARIS, Jan. 20 Defenders of French scenery are undertaking an 11th-hour effort to save the Gare d'Orsay, which dominates the Left Bank of the Seine opposite the Louvre.

Dr. James Britt Donovan, the lawyer and educator who arranged the trade of a Soviet spy for the U-2 pilot Francis Gary Powers and negotiated the ransom of prisoners taken by Cuba in the Bay of Pigs invasion, died early yesterday. He was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, accused the Nixon Administration today of polarizing nationalpolitics and said that the Pentagon's budget should be cut by $50-billion in the next three years.
WHILE hemlines are grimly tumbling down in Europe, summer started with a lighthearted bounce on Seventh Avenue yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 19 (AP) Roger Brown hit a 17foot jump shot from the side with one second left tonight to give the Indiana Pacers a 108106 American Basketball Association victory over the Kentucky Colonels.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 19 Secretary General Thant of the United Nations left Lagos for Paris today, apparently satisfied after a day in Nigeria that the human distress in the territory that had been Biafra was not so serious as it had some times been painted.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 South Vietnamese military spokesmen said that 18 persons, including 16 South Vietnamese officer cadets and their instructor, were killed today when two Claymore mines that they say were planted by the Vietcong exploded in their training area about 12 miles northeast of Saigon this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The House Ways and Means Committee began consideration of President Nixon's proposed welfare reforms today in an atmosphere chilled by the Administration's criticism of Congress.

Eleven Soviet editors, headed by Lev N. Tolkunov of Izvestia, the Government newspaper, arrived here yesterday for a threeweek tour of the United States. They are returning a visit to the Soviet Union by 10 members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today that it had rejected all bids at today's mortgage auction and would resume the auction next week under new rules aimed at combating speculation.

NAPLES, Italy, Jan. 19 (AP) The Soviet missile-helicopter cruiser Moskva has left the Mediterranean and is sailing in the Atlantic for the first time, a United States Sixth Fleet spokesman said today.

JOHN DEMOS has not written a strident book. He seeks in the past neither sanctions for what we do now, nor symptoms of a cultural terminal disease about which to attitudinize. But "The Little Commonwealth" is nonetheless provocative, and Mr. Demos, assistant professor of history at Brandeis University, is more convincing ...

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 Anthony Haswell boarded the Broadway Limited here this afternoon and headed for New York via overnight sleeper. This was nothing unusual for him in a few days he will be off to the West Coast on the Superchief but this particular trip gave him a certain symbolic satisfaction.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive session as the trading volume dropped sharply.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 A former high-ranking Justice Department official testified today that the department made unsuccessful efforts to get Chicago officials to negotiate with demonstrators prior to the 1968 Democratic National Convention here.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19 An American Marine captain was acquitted tonight by a general court-martial of the premeditated murder of a North Vietnamese prisoner of war.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 On the eve of the National Basketball Association's 20th annual All-Star game, the conversation among the arriving players, coaches and front office officials was predominantly about a man who will not play.
Grace Line started its second half-century of passenger-ship operations to Latin America yesterday under a new name and a new chief executive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court decision that George M. Bunker was acting as a representative of Martin Marietta Corporation when he served on the board of directors of the Sperry Rand Corporation.
ROME, Jan. 19 The newest feud, or polemica, simmering backstage at the spring and summer couture shows this week is between the Italian and foreign models.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 19 Interior Minister Kamal Jumblatt indicated today that Lebanese forces would return to refugee camps to maintain law and order there.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 19 "What I saw with my own eyes was easy meetings between federal soldiers and the people walking along the roads, some of them still in Biafran uniforms. I think it is going to be all right."

ALBANY, Jan. 19 Following are the boundaries of the proposed new Congressional districts in Nassau, New York City and Westchester. Where changes are not noted the changes are not expected to have significant political effect.

Starting with Apollo 14 this fall, astronauts who go to the moon are expected to leave wheel tracks among their footprints. They will be using a two-wheel, rickshaw-like cart when they are on the lunar surface, collecting moon rocks and soil.
LONDON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) Mocatta Goldsmid, London bullion brokers, in their annual bullion market review, said the long-term silver price trend should continue upward.
The Southern Company and operating subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $94-million, or $1.82 a share, for 1969. This compared with $80.4-million, or $1.63 a share, in 1968.
Bryce S. Durant has been named a senior vice president in charge of operations and planning at American-Standard, Inc.
A four-alarm fire swept through a two-story commercial building on 23d Street, near Seventh Avenue, yesterday, causing considerable damage. One fireman was slightly injured.

In San Diego, Mrs. Carmen Gilman regularly drives 15 miles south of the city to cross the Mexican border and do her shopping in Tijuana. Like a growing number of other San Diego housewives, she makes the trip to take advantage of lower Mexican food prices. Husbands occasionally go along to get a less expensive haircut.

Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., denied yesterday that it was making "handsome profits" from the sale of farm machinery in Canada and added that it would welcome discussions with the Canadian Government about pricing policies.
David Merrick, the Broadway producer who has on occasion evinced a strong dislike of theater critics, turned critic yesterday to denounce the Off Broadway play "Che!"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The American Council on Education, representing the nation's major institutions of higher learning, recommended today that no further 2S draft deferments be granted for college students.

The Government of Lebanon faces a nearly hopeless choice as it tries to placate militant Palestinian guerrillas and their followers while maintaining sufficient control over its vulnerable borders to avert a disastrous clash with Israel. The prospects are dim for the continuing success of this desperate balancing act, at which the Lebanese have been adept in the past.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (AP) Air West, Inc., a financially troubled airline seeking to complete its sale to Howard Hughes, announced today its directors would meet Wednesday.
For years, Peck Peck has been a certain kind of store, the kind that used an ad agency instead of having its own ad department. That's unusual in retail.

Six days after one judge permitted a woman to keep a dog in her Lower East Side apartment despite a ban against animals in her lease, another judge yesterday ordered another tenant five blocks away to get rid of his dog for violating a similar lease.
Rollin Crampton, an abstract artist whose paintings are in the collections of many leading museums, died Saturday in Woodstock, N.Y. He had moved there recently from New York.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 (UPI) Wilt Chamberlain will rejoin the Los Angeles Lakers before the regular season ends, Dick White, a spokesman for the National Basketball Association Club, said today.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved lower over a broad front yesterday.
The Fred Benjamin Dance Company has a slick performling panache, at least three first-rate dancers, including Mr. Benjamin and an almost insupportable load of soap-opera choreography.
DALLAS, Jan. 19 (AP) Odie R. Seagraves, one of the last of the early Texas oilmen, plunged to his death today from the eight floor of a Dallas hotel. He was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 "Thirty dollars or thirty days," a type of sentence as old as American law, will come under constitutional challenge before the Supreme Court later this year.

The cleanest place in town will be the municipal treasury by the time John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, gets through with it. Mr. DeLury has threatened a no-overtime strike and other forms of harassment if the city does not reopen its contract with the sanitation union to grant an 8.7 per cent cost-of-living pay increase.

GARY, Ind., Jan. 19 The Gary School Board asked a Superior Court today for a restraining order to halt a twoweek-old strike by 2,000 teachers' union members. The request followed a 12-hour meeting yesterday that failed to produce a settlement.
A fire that the Fire Department said was of suspicious origin caused extensive damage late last night to the Congregation Ahavath Torah Synagogue at 170 East Mount Eden Avenue, The Bronx.

Robert O. Anderson, a petroleum executive, rancher and civic leader, was elected last night chairman of the Business Committee of the Arts at its third annual meeting at the Museum of Modern Art. He succeeds C. Douglas Dillon, who has been chairman since the committee, an organization of prominent business leaders set up to stimulate corporate involvement in the arts, was formed in 1967.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Air Force estimated today that it would cost $6.48million to strengthen the C-5A cargo plane against potential wing cracks that turned up in one of the planes last week.

Miss Jean Katherine O'Con nor, who is on the financial relations staff of Ruder Finn, Inc., public relations concern, and La Rue Applegate, vice president in charge of press relations and publications for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., plan to be married at the Unitarian Church of All Souls here on Feb. 14.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 Angelo Bruno, a reputed Mafia leader here, was ordered today to testify before a New York City grand jury investigating organized crime.

BRUSSELS, Tuesday, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The European Common Market Executive Commission directly challenged today the United States Government's view that an international accord is needed to limit certain textile exports to the United States.
Three National Boat Show oarsmen braved yesterday's cold in the hope of racing against a British team, but took a dip in the drink instead.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 19 Albert H. (Bert) Reinauer, marine oil transportation executive, died in Valley Hospital here yesterday afernnoon of pneumonia. He was 74 years old and lived at 154 Park Avenue, Midland Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr., of Florida told the Supreme Court today that his state was "financially and physically unable" to meet the terms of the Court's order for immediate school desegregation.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 19 (Reuters) The Indian Government today warned Burmah Shell Refineries, the Esso Standard Refining Company and Caltex Oil Refining to reduce the price of imported crude oil for their refineries.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19(AP) A rescue helicopter has located three American helicopter crewmen who had evaded the enemy for three days and lifted them to safety only 50 feet from a North Vietnamese patrol, the United States Army announced today.

Discovery of bloodstains in a storefront social club in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn an area long known as a dumping ground for victims of underworld executions has set off investigations by the police, the Brooklyn District Attorney and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
State officials said yesterday that Governor Rockefeller's new budget, exclusive of support for public schools, contained an increase of $138-million in aid for the city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The high point of the 37,000mile odyssey that Vice President Agnew ended here tonight may have occurred at a hole in the ground 37 miles north of Saigon on New Year's Day.
PARIS, Jan. 19 French racing inspectors are investigating the strange case of a suspected "reverse ringer" in a trotting race at Vincennes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Congress came back to the Capitol today with the state of the nation's economy as its chief concern.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 19 (AP) A 14-year-old boy was taken into custody by a United States marshal today after a Federal judge's order that he not attend his neighborhood school was defied.

I.B.M. held center stage in Wall Street yesterday as its stock tumbled 19 points to 350 in response to the latest earnings report and sent tremors into both the glamour and blue-chip sectors of the market.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The 91st Congress began an election-year session on a contentious note today as Senate Democrats squared off with the Administration for a "battle of national priorities."
Two giant New York bankholding companies reported yesterday sharp increases in net income last year.

The Federal Government is expected to sell today $350million of notes at yields approaching 9 per cent. At the same time, the Ford Motor Company will sell $200-million. at yields of 8.20 per cent or less.
The dispute over baseball's "reserve clause" grew more clamorous yesterday on the eve of the first hearing in Federal Court here.
The Armco Steel Corporation announced increases of about 3 per cent yesterday on basic prices of sheet products used in automobiles, appliances and other consumer durables.
SEATTLE, Jan. 19 Despite around-the-clock escape-slide tests, Pan American World Airways was still unable to get final approval today to put its new 747 jet into commercial service.

The election of two teacher-scholars to Harvard's seven-man governing corporation is a constructive act of institutional renewal. Harvard, incorporated 320 years ago, is the nation's oldest corporation; its decision is bound to influence the trend and tone of the trusteeship of all higher education.

Five new executive vice presidents have been appointed by Frederick Atkins, Inc., in a program to strengthen the concern's merchandising structure. Atkins, which is operated by 40 leading department and specialty stores, is a merchandising research organization based in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The B'nai B'rith Board of Governors, the policy-making body of the 500,000-member Jewish organization, charged today that American prestige and credibility had been poorly served by the State Department's policy of proposing "concessions" while seeking a peace formula for the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission held hearings today on whether the press should continue to pay a special low rate for leasing telegraph wires to carry the news.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19(AP) Frankie Narvaez, a New York lightweight, piled up a lead in the early rounds tonight and gained a split decision over Roger Evans of Philadelphia. The 10-round bout was a cofeature at the Philadelphia Arena.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 The Supreme Court ruled today that the Selective Service System lacks the legal power to accelerate the induction of young men who turn in their draft cards to protest the Vietnam war.

JERSEY CITY, Tuesday, Jan. 20 (UPI) Members of the Black Panther party here said 10 shots were fired into their storefront headquarters at 384 Pacific Avenue early today. Seven persons were inside, but no one was hurt, they said.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 Consumer prices rose six-tenths of 1 per cent in December, bringing the increase for 1969 to 6.1 per cent, the Labor Department reported today.
The cost of consumer goods and services rose 1 per cent in December in the metropolitan area, making price increases here in 1969 greater than in any year since 1951.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (Reuters) A Vietcong sharpshooter killed a United States Army colonel while he was flying in an observation helicopter, the United States command announced today.

Bruno Sammartino took 18 minutes and 10 seconds of a single fall match to pin Ivan Koloff last night at Madison Square Garden before a record crowd of 16,858 fans. He retained the World Wide Wrestling Federation championship belt, using a double-reverse back flip body hold.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 19(AP) Hal March, who was master of ceremonies of the popular television quiz show "The $64,000 Question" in the 1950's died today at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center at the age of 49.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Unexpected thousands of sickened coal miners are claiming millions of dollars in newly won disability benefits for black lung disease.

Herbert B. Leonard, the producer who made his movie debut last year with the comedy-drama, "Popi," starring Alan Arkin, will film three additional features and two movies for television, at a cost of about $7-million. The first two films, Mr. Leonard said, will be made for United Artists, which sponsored "Popi."

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 19 This city's 11 public schools were closed today for the second day as the Passaic Education Association continued its strike in defiance of a temporary injunction ordering its 431 teachers back to their classrooms.
LONDON, Jan. 19 (Reuters) Today was ladies' day in English soccer as the Football Association, governing body of the game here, officially recognized women players for the first time.

Willis Reed and his fans can stop worrying.

NAHA, Okinawa, Jan. 19 (AP) More than 7,000 Okinawan workers began a scheduled five-day strike at United States military bases today, and five Americans and 14 Okinawans were reported injured in picket line incidents.

SEATTLE, Jan. 19(UPI) Robert B. Colwell, first vice president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, said tonight that, at the request of the International Lawn Tennis Federation, the association had called a meeting of Davis Cup nations to discuss the status of South Africa and Rhodesia in the draw for this year's competition.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 Two views of what constitutes priority clashed today at the National Basketball Association's business meeting, and the result was a strong statement against accommodation with the American Basketball Association and a delay in adding teams to the N.B.A.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 19 (UPI) East meets West tomorrow night for the first time in an expansion city in the National Hockey League's 23d annual All-Star game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) President Nixon named Allan Oakley Hunter, former Republican Congressman from Fresno, Calif., today as president of the Federal National Mortgage Association.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 Gov. John J. McKeithen called tonight upon Americans to speak out against the busing of schoolchildren.

A Westchester couple who fear their two foster children will be returned to their natural parents a man and woman previously convicted in the starvation death of a third child went to the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday in an effort to retain custody.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 19 Miss Jo Woodley, owner of the Improvisation Boutique here, a woman's apparel shop, and Dr. John William Benoit, a research engineer at Princeton University, plan to be married here Jan. 27.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) Representative Adam Clayton Powell, the Harlem Democrat, told colleagues today that he had been battling cancer for the better part of a year and that he believed he had won.

Shortly after 9:30 A.M. on a recent Tuesday, the dozen or so aides of Staten Island's Borough President, Robert T. Connor, entered his paneled office and gathered around a thick table.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 Miss Nancy Chickering, a senior at Berkeley, plans to be married on March 22 to John Carl Warnecke Jr., a newspaper reporter who used to make a daily detour by the Chickering residence when she was a grade school pupil at the Katherine Delmar Burke School and he was a smitten school boy at the Town School four blocks away.

BELLPORT, L.I., Jan. 19 Jim Strano, one of the leaders of a group of white students in the school district here, stood next to Clyde Gamble, a leader of a group of black students, today, and said: "If we can get together, the whole school can come together."

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, Tuesday, Jan. 20 The eight Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church in the Netherlands said last night that there should be room in the church for both married priests and celibate priests.

KARLSRUHE, West Germany, Jan. 19 (AP) The civil branch of the West German Supreme Court began hearings today in the case of the 69-year-old woman who for almost 40 years has claimed to be the Grand Duchess Anastasia, youngest daughter of Czar Nicholas II of Russia.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 19 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi dedicated today India's first nuclear power plant the largest in Asia.

Mayor Lindsay appointed a three-man panel yesterday to recommend election reforms. He called the existing procedures "a bureaucratic nightmare" that seemed designed to discourage voters.

The names of Frank Sinatra it was not clear whether Sr. or Jr. was meant and Jackie Gleason were brought up yesterday at the start of the Federal Court trial of the business manager of Frank Sinatra Jr. on charges of conspiring to use stolen credit cards.
Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday announced the appointment of six banking and insurance executives to advise the city on investment policy and debt management.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today that the first year in the White House had been "interesting and rewarding" and that the President thought it had been "a great year."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Federal Reserve Board announced today sizable increases in the interest rates the commercial banks can pay to savers both "consumer type" savers and large corporate depositors. Several hours later the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced similar increases in the ceiling affecting savings banks.

I do not think it would be an exaggeration for me to say that never before in the history of New Jersey has an incoming Governor been confronted with the enormity of problems, both in variety and degree, which now face this administration.
The State Board of Regents has proposed the establishment of an educational center in Latin America as part of a broadened approach to international understanding by teachers and students.
Silver futures prices dipped yesterday in moderate trading, with the nearby January contract dropping to $1.88 an ounce from $1.90 the day before.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 20 Elbert C. Isom, a former petroleum engineer and Civil Air Patrol officer, who once survived the disintegration of his plane in the Atlantic, died at Stamford Hospital here yesterday of cancer. He was 73 years old and lived on Bowery Road in New Canaan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Judge G. Harrold Carswell, President Nixon's new nominee to the Supreme Court, has a virtually unblemished record as the type of "strict constructionist" that Mr. Nixon promised to appoint when he campaigned for the Presidency.

A Fordham University Conference on Equal Opportunities in Broadcasting has concluded, as have similar conferences before, that television and radio as industries discriminate against blacks and Puerto Ricans.

Richard A. Tewkesbury, who in 1939-40 walked from the Panama Canal to the border of Colombia to demonstrate that the Darien Isthmus was not a barrier to plans for a Pan American Highway, died in New York City on Dec. 19. Mr. Tewkesbury, who was born in Iowa in 1907, had been a mathematics teacher at the Garden City (L.I.) Junior High School for 14 years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) A Presidential commission recommended today that construction workers give up ratification votes and, instead, elect union negotiators with binding power to negotiate labor contracts.
