R. Inslee Clark Jr., the 34year-old dean of admissions at Yale, has been named headmaster of Horace Mann School, a leading private institution here.

DUBLIN, Jan. 20 Eleven years ago, when Ireland's plan for economic development was started, agriculture was the prime source of export earnings. Today, industrial exports account for more than one-half of the Republic's external trade, with manufacturers the largest employers.
YARDLEY, Pa., Jan. 20 Miss Lesley Ann Loser, a senior at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., and Todd Douglas Johnston, a student at Boston University Law School, plan to be married in June.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) President Nixon plans to ask Congress for higher Social Security taxes next year by raising the taxable wage base from $7,800 to $9,000, Administration sources said today. One of every five workers would be affected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 As an undergraduate at Stanford 30 years ago, Walter John Stoessel Jr. had to make what seemed to be a crucial decision about his future; to pursue his interest in international affairs by going into the Foreign Service or to accept a tempting offer...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 President Nixon announced today that he would submit to Congress a "State of the World" message about two weeks after the traditional State of the Union address that he will deliver on Thurs day. In a relaxed and talkative mood on the first anniversary of his inauguration as President, Mr. Nixon informed newsmen of the unusual special message during a picture-taking session with VicePresident Agnew,...

Governor Rockefeller's proposed $7.3-billion budget for New York State is both too large and too small too large in its reliance on bonded debt and too small in its provision for the desperate needs of urban areas. It is at once an underfunded and recklessly expensive document that deprives cities and feeds the fires of inflation. It is a no-tax budget, a spend-big budget, an election-year budget.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey, said today that complacency was sweeping over the ecumenical movement.
IT seems incredible to some thoughtful Wall Streeters that a few stocks are drawing hordes of investors and are selling at soaring priceearnings multiples when the market generally is in a malaise.

ELIOT'S Prufrock, a sagacious if boring man, measured out his life in coffee spoons which is great if you have a special thing going for coffee. Drama critics, less sagacious if no less boring, measure out their lives with hit shows. Tomorrow "Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris" will have been alive, well and living in New York for two years. And it seems but yesterday . . . however.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 20 A report that President Nixon, Commander in Chief of American armed forces, had personally urged a murder trial for First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was submitted today by defense counsel as an argument that the lieutenant could never receive a fair trial in a military court.
During his active baseball career, Lou Boudreau gained fame as the boy wonder of managing. In more recent years, however, he has become better known as Denny McLain's father-in-law.
Eight private bus companies operating in the city will seek approval of a 30-cent fare in place of their current 20-cent rate at a hearing tomorrow before the Board of Estimate at City Hall.

BUFFALO, Jan. 20 (AP) Police and Treasury Department agents arrested two young men tonight and seized 40 cases of dynamite, which they said was apparently destined for Cuban exile terrorists in New York City.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 A Federal District Court judge ordered the Pasadena school district today to submit a plan for desegregation of its public schools by Feb. 16. The plan, covering all schools in the district in suburban Los Angeles, would go into effect next September.
WHITTIER, Calif., Jan. 20 (AP) Dr. Frederick M. Binder, Associate Commissioner for the New York State Education Department, was named today as president of Whittier College.
Almost like a meeting of the United Nations Security Council and almost as well covered by the press was a news conference mounted yesterday by Benton Bowles.
A fresh cover of snow and frigid temperatures combined to make walking and driving hazardous in the New York metropolitan area last night and early this morning. At 2 A.M. at was 18 degrees.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., which already is engaged in a variety of enterprises, yesterday further broadened its operations by entering the art reproduction business.
GREAT NECK, L.I., Jan. 20 In this affluent suburban community, a man's home may be his castle but apparently not his farm.
Frank Wille, New York State Superintendent of Banks, approved yesterday-with certain conditions the merger of the City Savings and Loan Associations into the Emigrant Savings Bank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Government moved today to setle a five-year antitrust case by requiring the American Pipe and Construction Company of Monterey Park, Calif., to sell a competing pipe-manufacturing plant that it acquired in 1963 from U.S. Industries, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Selective Service System issued instructions to draft boards today not to order for induction next month men whose lottery number is above 60.
The city school system has reminded teachers that contro-, versial subjects such as the issues in the current strike against General Electric should be treated in a scholarly and objective manner.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 More than a month before the 1968 Democratic National Convention here, a United States Assistant Attorney General warned there might be a "national disaster" in Chicago's streets unless city officials and demonstrators developed a "working relationship."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, announced today that A.E. Fitzgerald, the Pentagon cost expert dismissed by the Air Force, had been hired as a consultant to the Senate-House Economic Commitee.

WHEN Bob Scheffing was only 24 years old he was appointed playermanager of a minor league team in the St. Louis Cardinal chain. The man who picked him was Branch Rickey and it is doubtful whether baseball ever had a more perceptive judge of men and talent than the now legendary Mahatma. That early endorsement by the Top Branch has to be recognized as a high testimonial to Scheffing's abilities.
A reputed Mafia figure, John A. Masiello, and his 23-year-old son, John Jr., both of Yonkers, were convicted last night of bribing postal officials who supervised mail trucking contracts in New York.

A lawyer's motion that contended the District Attorney's office "handpicked" a judge to hear almost all Black Panther cases led yesterday to an order directing State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh to show cause why he should not be removed from the trial of 16 Black Panthers on bomb conspiracy charges.

City Council members made a line-by-line study of 20 typed pages of suggested new proceedural rules yesterday to come up with some changes that will increase the power of individual councilmen to press for legislation they have sponsored.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 State Democratic leaders met here today to discuss legal action to try to block a Republican plan that would reapportion New York's 41 Congressional districts along lines that would favor G.O.P. candidates in many areas.

A standard topic of economic debate for many years has been whether the Federal Reserve is too independent of the Administration. With the accession of Dr. Arthur F. Burns to the chairmanship of the nation's central bank, the question may well be whether the Administration is sufficiently independent of the Fed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Nixon Administration declared today that any reduction of United States troop strength in Europe would be militarily unwise, politically unsettling and financially insignificant.

A group of ranking New York-based business executives sat down to a school lunch yesterday with representatives of the Bank Street College of Education and learned, among other things, of a role their companies might play in the field of providing day-care facilities.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) An association of Chicago suburban real estate brokers, accused in a Government suit of practicing racial discrimination, agreed today to sell or rent homes to prospective buyers regardless of race.

A new comedy-mystery by Jules Feiffer called "The Whitehouse Murder Case" will be presented at the Circle in the Square on Feb. 19 by the producing team of Theodore Mann, Paul Libin, Harold Leventhal and Orin Lehman.
VIENNA, Jan. 20 Albania announced today the signing of a new trade and financial accord with Communist China that would establish event closer ties between the two countries.

NEWARK, Jan. 20 A group of local black and Puerto Rican leaders, seeking broader employment for minority group members in publicly supported construction projects here, has called on the United States Labor Department to investigate alleged discrimination in the building trades in Essex County.
Undefeated by the living, Cassius Clay lost his heavyweight "title" to a dead man last night.

Three months ago, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales announced his retirement from competitive tennis, but tonight he will return to Madison Square Garden, one of his favorite stages, for its sixth annual invitation tournament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate approved today a bill appropriating $19.7billion for the Department of Labor and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare:

In naming Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court, President Nixon has displayed more glaringly than ever a talent for seeking out undistinguished candidates for the high bench.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The United States expressed conern today over the rising level of fighting in Laos. A State Department spokesman said it appeared that North Vietnam might be preparing to launch a "dry season offensive" there.

NEWARK, Jan. 20 United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey appealed today for more judicial manpower to ease a large backlog of criminal cases that has arisen partly because of the Federal investigation of municipal crime and corruption.
A hearing in the new drunken driving case against Gareth Martinis was postponed yesterday in Bronx Criminal Court until Feb. 10.

The New York State Department of Mental Hygiene began an investigation yesterday of charges by a Queens mother that her 7-year-old son might have been beaten while a patient at Queens Children's Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Democratic-controlled Senate laid down a political challenge to the White House today by endorsing, 74 to 17, a $19.7 billion health and education appropriations bill that President Nixon has threatened to veto as inflationary.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 20 Miss Leslie Ann Ayvazian and Pvt. David Graham Webster of the Army plan to be married here in August.
NHATRANG, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (UPI) The defense won a six-week delay today in the court-martial of a 20-year-old American solider charged with murdering a South Vietnamese man last September.
Senator George S. McGovern proposed last night that the Federal Government give parents an allowance of $50 to $65 a month for each child in an attempt to eliminate poverty.

Seven persons pleaded guilty in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday to the illegal occupation of a student center on the City College campus early on Nov: 7, 1968, and were sentenced to pay $25 fines or to serve five days in jail.

Walter E. Spahr, chairman of the department of economics of New York University from 1927 to 1956, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack. Dr. Spahr, who was 78 years old, was stricken on the 28th Street station of the BMT.

H. Barclay Morley, 40 years old, has been named executive vice president of the Stauffer Chemical Company. He will assist Roger W. Gunder, president and chief executive officer and have primary responsibility for the future growth of the company.

CHANDIGARH, India, Jan. 10 Smoking is being discouraged in the Punjab half of the massive government building here the ashtrays have been removed from Punjab offices and cigarettes are not sold in the Punjab canteen. All the smoke-filled rooms are in the Haryana section of the nine-story structure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 A big change is taking place in the language of politics. Officials are not only talking about home affairs rather than foreign affairs these days and tossing around a new vocabulary of environment, pollution and ecology, but they are talking about "control of the growth of population."

MONTREAL, Jan. 20 (AP) Daniel Cohn-Bendit, leader of student demonstrations in Paris in 1968, was among the demonstrators ejected from Superior Court here yesterday during the sentencing of an accused terrorist for contempt of court.

THE Dallas Aces, designated representatives of the United States in this year's world team championship in Stockholm in June, built up a substantial lead in the first stage of a marathon match against Omar Sharif's Circus, a group of European stars.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20 Nigeria's Ambassador said today that Soviet aid to his country was the most important factor in the defeat of the Biafran secessionists.

VIENNA, Jan. 20 A hardline member of the present Communist leadership in Czechoslovakia, Alois Indra, denounced Alexander Dubcek today as "unstable ideologically with marked inclination toward petit bourgeois ideas."

Judge Dudley B. Bonsal of the United States District Court refused yesterday to delay for more than a day a hearing on a request for a preliminary injunction against John P. Bauer and Bauer International, importers, for issuing certain statements about the purchase and shipment of about 425,000 cases of Spanish eggs.

CAIRO, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram said today that Egyptian defense forces killed at least 10 Israeli frogmen who tried to swim across the Suez Canal near Ismailia Sunday night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Archbishop Giovanni Benelli, the Deputy Secretary of State at the Vatican, said today that he hoped that war-torn Nigeria would accept relief aid from the Vatican.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon had only two major instructions for her interior decorator at the Western White House make it light and airy with lots of yellow, and don't make it too expensive.

Last minute preflight grooming was under way here yesterday on a huge Pan American World Airways Boeing 747 jet that is scheduled to start a new era in aviation today by flying from New York to London with all its 362 seats filled.
Dave Hill and Bob Lunn are tied at 144.9 points for the lead in the new system established by the Professional Golfers' Association of America Tournament Players Division.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 21 United States forces killed 54 enemy troops in three sharp jungle clashes north and northwest of Saigon yesterday, the United States command reported today.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 Mayor Lindsay contended today that Governor Rockefeller's new $7.3-billion budget would add to rather than ease the city's financial problems.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 20 (AP) Ralph Simpson's 35 points led Michigan State to an upset 85-82 basketball victory over Notre Dame tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) The Supreme Court ruled today that minority stockholders can bring damage suits based on illegal proxy solicitation material promoting a merger without first proving that the proxy statement induced the merger.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The man whose report to the Government resulted in the partial banning of DDT said today that the local elimination of such long-lasting pesticides would endanger the world's food production system.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (UPI) Military investigators studying charges that the American Forces Vietnam Network censors news broadcast to servicemen in the war zone agreed today that the network had not violated Defense Department policies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 When President Nixon moved into the White House a year ago this week, he saw this city as an illusion grand but also forbidding.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange were down yesterday in line with Monday's decline on Wall Street. However, late buying reduced some of the initial losses.

David Westheimer's play and novel on a pregnant Southern white girl and an educated young Negro lawyer from New York was adapted and produced by Richard Levenson and William Link for the National Broadcasting Company's "Tuesday Night at the Movies."

ROME, Jan. 20 Serious fears of split between the Roman Catholic church of the Netherlands and the Holy See are being expressed in responsible Vatican circles in the wake of what they consider repeated acts of indiscipline by the Dutch hierarchy and clergy.
SAO TOME, Jan. 20 (Agence France-Presse) A new hangar at the airport here, packed from floor to roof, holds enough food to feed five million people for 20 days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The General Motors Corporation told Chevrolet dealers last month that they should ignore defects covered by warranty unless the defects were to safety or were discovered by the customer, Senate investigators were told today.

SEATTLE, Jan. 20 Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco and two former Washington state officials were sued today by the state and 12 municipalities and utilities for $2,32l,308.05 that the plaintiffs said the three men conspired to share illegally.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 20 The Algiers Motel incident was reopened here today as three Detroit policemen and a private guard went on trial in Federal court in connection with the beating of eight Negro youths and two young white women in the motel annex during the Detroit riots of 1967.

LONDON, Jan. 20 The Government was urged today by the Greater London Council to protect London from possible river flooding by financing a $120million moveable tide-control barrier across the Thames.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 20 (AP) Frank Sedgman, Australian tennis star of 20 years ago, carried his countryman, Bill Bowrey, a current Davis Cup player, to five sets today before succumbing in the Australian open championship.

Having survived the Depression, the temptation to go big time and the demise of its charitable beneficiary, the annual Blue Ridge Ball will be held for the 61st time here next week with all the enthusiastic congeniality of a Southern family reunion, which it almost is.

TOKYO, Jan. 20 (AP) Japan had a balance-of-payments surplus in December equivalent to about $260-million, compared with a surplus of $161-million in December of 1968, the Finance Ministry estimated today.

Diebold. The appointment was announced by Earl W. Brydges, State Senate majority leader. The salary is $30,000 a year.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Herman Fialkov have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Fran Fialkov, to Richard Eric Kopelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Kopelman of Roslyn Heights.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (AP) George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury in the Eisenhower Administration from 1953 to 1957, died tonight in University Hospital. He was 79 years old.

The "average" Broadway theatergoer is white. He is an educated man or woman about 37 years old with a family income of $18,000 a year, a home or apartment owner with at least one car (bought new). He prefers Scotch, dines out frequently and owns stocks, bonds or mutual funds.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 20 The Lebanese Interior Minister, Kamal Jumblatt, assured the Jewish community here today of Government protection and of his regret over an explosion at a Jewish school last Sunday.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange plunged 2,945,102 shares in the month ended Jan. 15, in one of the sharpest month-to-month fluctuations in stock exchange history, the Big Board announced yesterday.

The election of John F. McGillicuddy as a director and a vice chairman of the board of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company was announced yesterday. He will succeed Eugene S. Northrop, vice chairman, upon his retirement June 1.

"Serenade," given last night by the New York City Ballet with two new principals, Karin von Aroldingen and Peter Martins, was the first ballet choreographed by George Balanchine in this country.

PARIS, Jan. 20 (AP) Secretary General Thant of the United Nations said today that South Vietnam's top priority was a "broad-based government." He was immediately accused by Saigon's peace-talk team of meddling.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 20 (AP) The Minnesota Vikings will keep Gary Cuozzo, their backup quarterback, General Manager Jim Finks said today.
The American Heart Association announced yesterday that Rudolph A. Peterson, a San Francisco banker, would head the association's 1970 fund-raising campaign.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (AP) Gordie Howe and Bobby Hull scored a goal apiece and the East Division routed the West, 4-1, tonight in the National Hockey League All-Star game.

The city had to pay 7.31 per cent interest its highest ever in selling $176,860,000 worth of bonds yesterday for public improvements. STONEWALL, Tex., Jan. 20 The easy life he never had before holds continued satisfaction for former President Lyndon B. Johnson at his beloved LBJ Ranch on the Pedernales River.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 20 Two men were found slain today in an apartment they shared in the rear of the Villa Sorrento, a restaurant at 198 Glen Cove Avenue here.

TRENTON, Jan. 20 Pledging his new administration to search out and destroy organized crime and corruption in New Jersey, William Thomas Cahill was inaugurated today as the state's 46th Governor and the first Republican one in 16 years.

TRENTON, Jan. 20 The power of the State Commission of Investigation to seek the indefinite imprisonment of witnesses who refuse to testify after being granted immunity from prosecution was unanimously upheld today by the New Jersey Supreme Court.
A fire that swept the interior of a Bronx synagogue Monday night and destroyed five Torah scrolls and other religious objects was called arson yesterday by the City Fire Marshal's office.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 20 Miss Deborah Perine, a teacher at the Easterly Parkway Elementary School in State College, Pa., and Jacob John Kleinschuster, a doctoral candidate at the chemistry department of Pennsylvania State University, will be married in June.

NEWARK, Jan. 20 The defense counsel in the extortion trial of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo and Daniel (Red) Cecere made a variety of attempts in Federal Court today to find a way to discredit the testimony of the prosecution's chief witness.
LAREDO, Tex., Jan. 20 (UPI) A Federal Court jury found Dr. Timothy Leary guilty today of helping import three ounces of marijuana into Texas four years ago in his teen-age daughter's underwear.
"When George speaks," President Eisenhower said of Mr. Humphrey, "all the rest of us listen."
The possibility that two rebellious gang members were murdered recently by fellow "soldiers" in the Mafia family of Joseph Colombo is being investigated by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Jackie Robinson praised the franchise business today as a potential solution to the problems of black capitalism, but he severely criticized President Nixon's efforts in the field.

A heavily annotated second draft of the Constitution of the United States, printed on Sept., 12, 1787, was auctioned yesterday for $160,000. It was the second-highest price recorded for an American historical document.
A STYLISH new form of passive resistance, spon taneously christened a pantsin, took place yesterday at noon at the C.B.S. Broadcast Center, 524 West 57th Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The Supreme Court upheld today a 61-year-old Federal law that makes possession of heroin sufficient evidence of illegal importation of the drug.
For what is believed to be only the second time in the history of astronomical observations, it has been possible, from a quick succession of photographs, to determine the orbit of a meteorite.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (Canadian Press) The players want an equal voice with club owners in any decisions regarding proposed international tournaments, the National Hockey League Players' Association said today.
With a massive volume of Federal, municipal and corporate financing taking place yesterday, the credit markets tested a wide range of interest rates levels.
Lou Boudreau, the former "boy manager" of the Cleveland Indians, became the 114th member of baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 20 (AP) The National Hockey League's All-Star organ debate was settled amicably today. The host, St. Louis, allowed its home organist, Norm Kramer, to share the keyboard with Al Melnar of Chicago, who was imported by the Black Hawks for the occasion.

Another major Wall Street brokerage house, DempseyTegeler Co., Inc., has been forced by operational difficulties to go beyond the financial community for a major infusion of capital. It was disclosed...

The Concert Artists Guild distinguished itself last night by presenting Sandra Darling, a gifted young soprano in her New York recital debut at Carnegie Hall. Miss Darling is not unknown, having sung with the New York City Opera, the Metropolitan Opera Studio and other companies of quality, but her ability to carry off a recital with the aplomb and skill of a veteran came as a pleasant surprise.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 20 (AP) The Bundesbank disclosed today that it has prematurely recalled a billion marks of United States Treasury bonds purchased in 1968 to offset the dollar drain caused by the stationing of American troops in West Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 The National Basketball Association reaffirmed by a 12-2 vote today its desire to expand next season. It saw the possible addition of four teams, but said a final decision would be made at another meeting within two weeks.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 The President's Water Pollution Control Advisory Board has formally recommended the disbursement of the entire $800-million voted by Congress to help cities build sewage treatment plants.
Thomas Harrington McKittrick, who was president of the Bank for International Settlements during World War II, died yesterday at the Newton (N.J.) Nursing Home. He was 81 years old.
The Lily-Tulip division of Owens-Illinois, Inc., announced yesterday it would transfer its headquarters from New York to Toledo this spring.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Jan. 21 An amphibious Navy cargo ship broke loose from her anchorage early today and smashed a gap in the Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel, the 17.6-mile crossing between Virginia's mainland and the Eastern Shore.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 We went to see Congress. It appeared to be dead.
James Baldwin, the novelist, essayist and playwright, and LeRoi Jones, poet-playwright, will join in an evening of readings of their most recent works on Feb. 4 at Town Hall, 113 West 43d Street.

The American Electric Power Company's net income topped the $100-million level for the the first time in 1969, Donald C. Cook, president, told yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (UPI) A 1968 campaign aide to Senator Eugene J. McCarthy told a Federal court jury today that the Senator's staff antiwar protest leaders had an informal working agreement before and during the turbulent Democratic National Convention.

Dr. Konrad Lorenz, author of the widely read book "On Aggression" and a founder of the young science of ethology (the study of animal behavior in the wild) argued yesterday that large and stable family groupings were essential to the survival of human society.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 21 The Baghdad radio announced that 16 persons were executed today after an attempt to overthrow the Iraqi Government failed.

ROCKY MARCIANO did not like Muhammad Ali. Some years ago, Marciano said that Ali's conduct in and out of the ring reflected unfavorably on all boxers, and in retrospect chipped away at his own formidable reputation.
JACKSON, Mich., Jan. 21 (UPI) The Consumers Power Company today announced plans to spend $232-million on capital expansion in 1970, up from $198-million in 1969.
CHICAGO, Jan. 21 A special coroner's jury ruled today that the deaths of two Black Panthers slain in a pre-dawn police raid were "justifiable."
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 21 (Reuters) Rain washed out all matches today in the $14,000 Australian open tennis championships and plunged the tournament into a crisis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21(AP) The Pentagon announced today that its chief research office was being trimmed in a move to give the individual armed services more responsibility over their defense research projects.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) The Nixon Administration endorsed today a crackdown on supermarket "bait" advertising under present law rather than under a proposed new Federal Trade Commission rule.
CEDARHURST, L.I. In the homes of America, catered affairs notwithstanding, there is probably no table more sumptuous, elaborate and exotic than that of the Raphael Elmalehs in this suburban village.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has charged that state and city education authorities were lax in their handling of millions of dollars of Federal funds given to education projects here.

HOUSTON, Jan. 21 The 51,000-member National Association of Home Builders today applauded President Nixon's statement, but the organization's officers were unable to list any specific commitments they had received from the White House.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, widely regarded as the most conservative member of the American Catholic hierarchy, resigned today as Archbishop of Los Angeles. He was immediately succeeded by Coadjutor Archbishop Timothy J. Manning, who was designated the Cardinal's successor last June.

Following are excerpts from a speech by G. Harrold Carswell that appeared in The Irwinton Bulletin on Aug. 13, 1948; Judge Carswell's statement to the Columbia Broadcasting System last night, and a statement by Attorney General John N. Mitchell:
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm yesterday, helped by selective buying.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Harwood Rogers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Howell Rogers, to Lieut. E. Bloxom Baker, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Marjorie Credo Baker of Princeton, N.J. and Nantucket, Mass., and Elias B. Baker of New York aad Little Silver, N.J.

Renewal of formal Sino-American diplomatic contacts has been accompanied by the usual deep secrecy that has surrounded the Warsaw talks in the past. Nevertheless, Washington-Peking relations are so important that every major world capital is subjecting the little that is known about this week's meeting to microscopic analysis.

The election of B. William Kostecke as president of the Miller Brewing Company, Milwaukee, was announced yesterday. He succeeds Charles W. Miller, who becomes chairman of both the board of directors and the company's executive committee. Mr. Kostecke had been treasurer and chief financial officer.

Armed white civilians were more widely involved in civil disorders during the last decade than is commonly believed, according to a study prepared by two scholars under a grant from the National Institute of Mental Health.

HONG KONG, Jan. 21 Articles in the Chinese Communist press about the activities of the Nixon Administration at home and abroad have underlined the difficulties facing the American officials who resumed talks with representatives of Communist China in Warsaw yesterday.
THE most recent competitor in the international arena to attain the status of grandmaster was Jesus Diez Del Corral of Spain. He earned this accolade during the 18-man round-robin in Majorca, Spain.
MIAMI, Jan. 21 It was "no comment" time once again at Hialeah today as Bill Hartack returned to Florida in triumph winning the $32,400 Hibiscus Stakes with the California colt, George Lewis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced here tonight the arrest of three men in Cleveland in connection with the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter three weeks ago.
DICKINSON, W. Va., Jan. 21 (UPI) Nine persons were hospitalized tonight, and the area around the Dickinson Railroad Yards was sealed off when a tanker car began leaking lethal ammonia-type gas fumes.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 The Soviet Defense Ministry newspaper warned today against underrating Communist China's potential military threat to the security of the Soviet Union and other neighbors of the Chinese.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board moved "reluctantly" today to authorize the nation's savings and loan associations to pay higher interest rates on a wide variety of savings instruments.

Throughout the day and into the night the vans that shuttle people between freedom and confinement roll up to the Baxter Street entrance of the Criminal Courts building, pouring their manacled cargoes into the funnel of the city's overcrowded correctional system.

The Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's No. 2 aluminum producer, second only to Alcoa, increased fourth-quarter earnings by 90.4 per cent and annual profits by 85.8 per cent, according to the 1969 statement issued yesterday in Richmond, Va.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 Enemy gunners fired rockets and mortars into 55 military and civilian targets in South Vietnam last night in the most extensive shellings in seven weeks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The Senate opened debate today on a tough crime control program amid suggestions that the Republicans may seek to revive the issue for their Congressional campaign this year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 An air of unreality hangs over the trial of the so-called "Chicago Seven," and not merely because it keeps turning up such witnesses as Country Joe, the leader of the rock group known as Country Joe and the Fish.

THE Playwrights Unit has moved to Broadway. Well, not quite, but this organization, founded in 1961 and now directed by Richard Barr, Edward Albee and Charles Woodward, has opened a two-week engagement at the ANTA Theater with a double bill of plays by Philip Magdalany.

The phrase "grand slam" has become almost a part of Rod Laver's name. It's on his new aluminum racquet. And when he was awarded the Martini Rossi Gold Racquet yesterday as the tennis player of 1969, he was applauded for having registered a grand slam of the world's four major championships United States, Wimbledon, Australia and France.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 David A. Wallace, who joined the Chrysler Corporation as a master mechanic and rose to be president of the corporation's Chrysler Division, died at his home here today. He was 81 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Mushrooming discontent with the administration of Medicare has led hundreds of nursing homes to quit the Federal health care program, a nationwide study disclosed today.

The newly proposed Congressional district embracing parts of the Bronx, Manhattan and Queens has become known as the Puerto Rican 21st, but Puerto Ricans and some politicians agree that the descriptive title is half truth at best.
GENEVA, Jan. 21 The International Monetary Fund cautiously approved today Britain's continued penalizing of importers to strengthen her balance of payments.

ROME, Jan. 21 The least forgettable number in the Italian spring-summer couture shows, which end today, might just be the long white evening dress splattered with fried eggs. If it is not that one, the runner-up could be the long dress whose print is raw chicken parts, or the ankle-length black party dress with the pasta print. Actually, the pasta is rigatoni, which Americans know as elbow macaroni.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 Dogs that are snagged and impounded by dogcatchers and the price their forlorn young masters might have to pay for their release were the major subject of debate in the Assembly today.
PARIS, Jan 21 International interest rates for the dollar receded today, following the move taken yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.

ROME, Jan. 21 The Pontifical Commission on Justice and Peace can make no judgment on alleged political torture in Brazil, the head of the organization said in a letter released here today, but the commission has transmitted to Pope Paul VI a dossier documenting such charges.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 21 Miss Betty Clarice Blanchard and Lyle William Johnson, who is serving in the Marine Corps, will be married here Aug. 29 in the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Some South Vietnamese refugees told American researchers in Saigon in 1968 of "excessive and misdirected" allied bombing and shelling that made many of them hostile to the South Vietnamese Government.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21 Citizens in key countries of the Western world predict that the United States will have the leading position in science and the strongest military forces in the years ahead, the Gallup organization reported today.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called yesterday upon the Senate to reject President Nixon's nomination of Judge G. Harold Carswell to the Supreme Court because of his "pro segregation record."

A group of 30 churchmen and laymen have begun an attempt to raise bail in some cases by putting their church buildings up as collateral for 16 Black Panthers who have been in jail since April 2 awaiting trial on bombing conspiracy charges.

DINHQUAN, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 (AP) The Vietcong delayed the Tour de Vietnam bicycle race for three hours today by attacking South Vietnamese troops clearing the highway. One Government soldier was reported killed.
OWERRI, Nigeria, Jan. 19 The hard-pressed people of Biafra finally have peace but little else.
OSCAR started the day and Donald ended it. This put fashion enthusiasts roughly in the same state that the rock crowd would be in if it faced the Beatles and the Rolling Stones on the same bill.

THE National Basketball Association's 20th annual All-Star game passed into history in snowy Philadelphia Tuesday night, but all the really interesting aspects of the two-day gathering concerned the future.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation set a ceiling today of 5 per cent on regular deposits that mutual savings banks may pay in Massachusetts.

At the National Collegiate outdoor championships last year, Lee Evans and Larry James spent so much time worrying about each other in the 440-yard dash that Curtis Mills, a Texas A. and M. sophomore, won the race and set a world record.

PARIS, San. 21 Francois Tanguy-Prigent, a Resistance hero and member of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's first postwar Cabinet, died last night at his home in Morlaix in Britanny after a long illness: He was 61 years old.

Bache Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, will pay no yearend bonuses to its employes and all of its officers have accepted salary reductions as part of an over-all policy to cut costs and improve profitability.

A concept for using nuclear energy to convert junk cars, beer cans and other solid wastes into their basic, reusable elements is stirring wide interest among scientists as a means of alleviating man's mounting waste-disposal and pollution problem.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 21 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit upheld today dismissal of two damage suits filed by Dr. Sam Sheppard, who was imprisoned for 10 years on charges that he murdered his wife but was acquitted at a second trial.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 The Court of Appeals ruled today that separation decrees and agreements obtained before the 1967 reform of the state divorce law could be considered grounds for divorce.
VIENNA, Jan. 21 (Reuters) The Austrian National Bank raised the discount rate today to 5 per cent from 4.75 per cent, effective tomorrow.
Miss Valerie Anne Kent and James Hopkins Taylor plan to be married on March 21 in Nairobi, Kenya, where the future bride's father, a retired British Army officer, operates a safari business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 UPI) A State Department official said today that there had been some progress toward getting the Soviet Union to reconsider its rejection of United States peace proposals for the Middle East.
James J. Weldon, a former deputy chief inspector of the Police Department, died in his car at the entrance to the queens Midtown Tunnel Tuesday afternoon, apparently of a heart attack.

THE PRESIDENT Humphrey. President Nixon issued a statement mourning the death of George M. Humphrey, former Treasury Secretary. Mr. Humphrey was praised as "a man of firm purpose, unremitting effort and high dedication." Activities. The President met all day with his top advisers as he worked on the final draft of his State of the Union Address.
Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany said yesterday, in a videotaped interview broadcast here, that Germany would never again become a major power.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 21 Red Kap, a fidgety 5-yearold bay gelding, and his groom, Roy Raulins, were in agreement at Roosevelt Raceway tonight neither wanted to work.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor was created in 1953 to combat half a century of crime and corruption on the waterfront, of kickbacks, usury and labor racketeering, of bloodied heads and murder.
THE American Broadcasting Company is overhauling its evening television schedule this week after most of its Monday night programing had proved a costly disaster.

LONDON, Jan. 21 The Wilson Government rebuffed George Brown today following the former Foreign Secretary's return from a private trip to the Middle East that was marred by reports of ill-tempered remarks.
GLEAN, N.Y., Jan. 21 (UPI) Led by Bob Lanier's 28 points and 22 rebounds, fourth-ranked St. Bonaventure won its 11th in a row tonight by beating De Paul, 83-59.
After Art Buchwald writes a newspaper column, he never retypes it. But he has already rewritten his first play, "Sheep on the Runway," about 15 times.
Fourteen Fordham students, charged with criminal trespass in campus disorders last Nov. 12, accepted six months' supervision by the city's Youth Counsel Bureau yesterday in lieu of trial.

IRWINTON, Ga., Jan. 21 G. Harrold Carswell, President Nixon's Supreme Court nominee, during a campaign for the Georgia Legislature in 1948, made a speech in which he said that he would always be governed by the "principles of white supremacy."

ALBANY, Jan. 21 Members of the Council of Commuter Organizations, which says it represents more than 200,000 frustrated commuters, have demanded that the Public Service Commission be totally revamped and then be given jurisdiction over the autonomous Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

THE dowager queen of the investment world, Ameri can Telephone and Telegraph, surprised and titillated Wall Street yesterday in announcing an offering to shareholders of an intriguing new package of securities.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 There was a guard stationed outside a fourth-floor room of the Capitol today as Republicans made last-minute changes in their plan to reapportion the state's 41 Congressional districts. At 2:30 P.M., the guard was sent downstairs to get precinct-byprecinct vote totals for the

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Jan. 21 Vincent C. Berberich, supervisor of highway engineers and chief of the Bureau of Urban Development for the New Jersey Department of Transportation, died here yesterday at his home. He was 60 years old and lived at 3716 Liberty Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 With a newfound unity, House and Senate Democratic leaders staged a pre-emptive political attack on the Administration today, seeking to put a Democratic stamp on the crime, pollution, education and health issues before President Nixon delivers his State of the Union Message tomorrow.

The Bank of America the biggest bank in the world apparently bowed yesterday to criticism from two California legislators and sharply reduced the interest it would charge its three million credit-card holders who elect to pay income taxes as part of the bank's loan program.

It's nice to go traveling, but there's no place like home. Fordham, which hadn't played basketball in its Rose Hill gym for more than a month, came home last night to score a 62-61 victory over the University of Massachusetts.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 21 (Agence France-Presse)--The charge d'affaires of North Vietnam here said today that Hanoi would not publish the list of American pilots it holds prisoner.
The Shelton Towers Hotel (selected for its steam bath and swimming pool) is the temporary office of a new agency called Jack Byrne Advertising.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 24 (AP) The National Hockey League's West Division, loser to the East by 4-1 in last night's All-Star game, will have a little extra going for it in next year's game at Boston.

Blanche Yurka, who has had a long, varied and notable career on Broadway, is returning to the local stage but, this time, off Broadway. She will star in "The Madwoman of Chaillot," Maurice Valency's adaptation of Jean Giraudoux's play, opening March 22, in Sokol Hall, the Czechoslovak cultural center at 420 East 71st Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) President Nixon has asked his chief science adviser to explore possibilities for making "other governmental use" of a space agency electronics research center at Cambridge, Mass., which is to be closed because of budgetary restraints.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Anthony J. De Andrade, president of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistant's Union of North America, died yesterday, apparently of a heatr attack. He was 73 years old.

The Northeast continued yesterday to suffer from the bitter Arctic cold that brought temperatures close to or below zero in parts of 30 states and caused major delays in transit and interruption of some fuel service.

ELKHART, Ind., Jan. 21 Mr. and Mrs. Vincent B. Terlep have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ward Terlep, to Kevin Michael O'Connell, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. O'Connell of Ridgewood, N.J. The wedding is planned for June 27.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 State Department officials told impatient Senators today that Nigerian insistence on control over internal affairs was the main roadblock to United States and church aid for the ill and starving in the former rebel enclave of Biafra.
DETROIT, Jan. 21 Car production schedules were trimmed again today by the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation.

Crown Prince Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Deva of Nepal and Crown Princess Aishwarya Rajya Laxmi Devi Rana will be married on Feb. 27 in Katmandu, capital of the mountain kingdom. The festivities in connection with the Hindu ceremony will last for two days.
Hungarian refugees, particularly students in Europe, will benefit on Jan. 31 when the Hungarian Catholic League of America holds the 16th annual Hungarian Charity Ball at the Pierre.
American Telephone, which unveiled the largest corporate financing in history, did not trade yesterday as the general market posted a modest advance.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 21. (Reuters) The West German Porsche of Sweden's So Waldegaard roared onto the dockside here today well ahead of the field after the first two stages of the Monte Carlo rally.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Penguins scored three goals tonight in the last 26 minutes to salvage a 3-3 tie with Oakland in a National Hockey League West Division game.

The next big push of the Business Committee for the Arts should be to establish a clearing house of information and guidance for corporations ready to involve themselves in the arts but not yet certain about what direction to take.

If there is no such thing as a Peter Martins critic, he will have to be invented. Last night at the State Theater for the third time since he swung back into repertory Sunday as guest artist with the New York City Ballet Mr. Martins glided smoothly into a new role. This time it was in Jerome Robbins's "Dances at a Gathering."

YONKERS, Jan. 21 Dr. Raymond L. Garman, vice president, technology, for the Singer Company, died at St. John's Riverside Hospital here yester day. He was 62 years old and lived at 50 Summit Drive in Hastings-on-Hudson.
Nathan Dretzin, a founder of World-Wide Volkswagen Corporation, died yesterday in his home at 101 Central Park West. He was 68 years old.

LONDON, Jan, 21 The Port of London Authority which manages 2,700 acres of docks and warehouses along the Thames River, today announced a five-year development plan that would close half of its 108 general-cargo berths. The anticipated growth of container traffic was the reason given for the move.

George S. Dively, chairman of the Harris-Intertype Corporation, of Cleveland, testified in Federal Court here yesterday about his company's offer to take over printing operations of R. Hoe Co. in proceedings for reorganization of the New York-based maker of printing presses.

The Bell System's mammoth $1.57-billion debenture issue announced yesterday afternoon weighed heavily upon the bond market, depressing prices of most outstanding corporate bonds and slowing the sales of some new issues.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 21 (AP) The top command of the Venezuelan armed forces was reshuffled today on orders of President Rafael Caldera and his Defense Minister, Brig. Gen. Martin Garcia Villasmil.

Lieut. Benjamin Franklin Pinkerton is, of course, a cad and a clod, and it's hard to understand what dear little CioCio-San sees in him. But, if that happens to be the average tenor's interpretation of his part in "Madama Butterfly," there are nonetheless subtler ways to delineate the character than Ion Buzea discovered last night in his first Pinkerton for the Metropolitan Opera.
The Allied Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings in 1969 would amount to about $2.44 ...
Union dressmakers and the dress industry in the metropolitan market area reached agree-ment yesterday on a new contract that will give 80,000 workers 20 per cent wage increases over three years.
KRANJSKA GORA, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20 (UPI) Dumeng Giovanoli of Switzerland won giant slalom honors in the Vitranc Cup men's Alpine ski tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The niceties of judicial ethics forced the cancellation of a Supreme Court hearing in midargument today, as one Justice disqualified himself from the case. There were not enough Justices left to hear it.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 21 The Country Club rink of Brookline, Mass., skipped by Mrs. Henry Jackson, led the way through the quarterfinal round tonight in the 16th annual Empire State women's bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21 Alan S. Downer, professor of English at Princeton University and author of books on the theater, died yesterday at Princeton Hospital after a short illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 294 Nassau Street here.

In 1968, one month before he won the election, Richard M. Nixon said: "When we talk about cutting the expense of government ... the one area we can't short-change is education." What was true then is even more pertinent today. The threatened veto of the $19.7-billion appropriations bill for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare is contrary both to the national interest and to the President's own promise.

Call it redistricting or call it gerrymandering, the new Congressional lines designed by the Republican leadership in Albany are highly partisan, yet supposedly drawn in the name of one-man, one-vote. The plan to railroad new districts through the State Legislature at the last moment allowed by a Federal court order has much to do with gaining Republican seats and little to do with giving fair representation to the voters of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 (AP) Two weeks after the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company put its $20-million issue of low denomination, highinterest notes on sale, they were sold out. The new notes were designed to attract the dollars of the small saver.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) State Department officials said today that Aleksa Kapicic, a consul in the office of the Yugoslav Consulate General in New York, had asked for permanent residence in the United States.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 21 Israeli officials spoke bitterly tonight of reports from Paris that France had agreed to increase her order of Mirage jet fighters to Libya.
Knocked out by a National Cash Register 315 computer in his "Super Fight" with Rocky, Marciano, Cassius Clay emerged yesterday as a big cash winner.
Discoveries of natural gas in the North Sea off Britain and in northern California were announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Women who use birth control pills should have their blood pressure tested every three months, a specialist said today at a Senate subcommittee hearing.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that no new city taxes including a rise in the income tax were likely this year despite a projected budget gap of $1.5billion.

OCRACOKE ISLAND, N.C. A skim of ice twice the thickness of a window pane held the big skiff and its load of decoys in cold embrace at Quork's Hammock Creek, and our guides, Earle Gaskins and Paul Teeter, were not happy.

An interconference swap of two experienced quarterbacks Charlie Johnson of the St. Louis Cardinals for Pete Beathard of the Houston Oilers provided the highlight of four trades among pro football clubs yesterday.

ATLANTA, Jan. 21 The son of the man who defeated Judge G. Harrold Carswell in his first political venture 22 years ago said tonight that he thought Judge Carswell's racist remarks in that campaign were inspired more by political expediency than by personal conviction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Reuters The Senate Mapority Leader, Mike Mansfield of Montanto, said today that he would continue to press for reduction of United States troop strength in Europe, despite a counterattack yesterday by the Nixon Administration.

IF sufficient interest develops, a meeting to discuss the formation of an informal national federation of clubs devoted to ring stewarding at dog shows will be held in New York during the West minster Kennel Club Show in Madison Square Garden Feb. 9 and 10.
ROME, Jan. 21 (UPI) Pope Paul VI said today Roman Catholics must stop fighting among themselves before they cold hope to overcome the divisions with Protestant or Orthodox churches.

BERLIN, Jan. 21 The East Germans blocked access routes to West Berlin today in a sporadic sequence, apparently to protest against West German parliamentary committee sessions scheduled to open here tomorrow.
Montgomery Ward Co., Chicago, following the lead of Sears, Roebuck Co., is making a substantial commitment to aid black capitalism.

Most of the nation's large commercial banks and thrift institutions moved swiftly yesterday though with varying degrees of enthusiasm to put into effect the higher interest rates they are permitted to pay depositors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Despite gestures by the Government of Chad aimed at soothing tensions with Arab rebels, the Central African nation remains beset by internal strife between Arab and black Chadians.

AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 21 The Jordanian Army along with a Saudi Arabian battalion and Palestinian guerrillas, fought a 24-hour running battle with an Israeli armored column of more than 60 tanks and other armored vehicles in the rugged mountains southeast of the Dead Sea, the Jordanian Army and Palestinian guerrillas announced tonight.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company called on its giant stockholder family yesterday to help raise a record $3.1-billion for its expansion needs.
Increased petroleum production and higher prices for domestic crude oil enabled the Getty Oil Company to lift earnings in the fourth quarter and the year 1969, the report disclosed yesterday.

James A. Greene Jr., a former vice president of the 195 Broadway Corporation, a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died yesterday at a hospital in Opelika, Ala. He was 64 years old and lived at 49 Rockledge Road in Yonkers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, conceded today that the housing industry was suffering a "recession" but said of the economy generally:
GENEVA, Jan. 21 The Executive Board of the World Health Organization adopted a resolution today calling on persons attending its meetings to refrain from smoking.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 Record sales and earnings for 1969 were reported here today by the Koppers Company a diversified producer of chemicals, plastics and forest products, which also engineers and builds heavy equipment for the steel industry.
City Controller Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had "stalled" the Second Avenue subway project.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks since 1964, is a leading contender to head the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Republican sources disclosed today.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 21 Israeli armored units this evening completed their most extensive ground operation since the six-day war of June, 1967, a 23-hour attack against Arab guerrillas in Jordan south of the Dead Sea.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling shareholders of listed companies.

NEWARK, Jan. 21 The Essex County Sheriff was ordered by a judge today to halt the issuing of honorary badges following a recent disclosure that two alleged gamblers were carrying them at the time of their arrest.

LARCENY at ski centers continues to be a major problem plaguing area operators. Thieves are still taking advantage of careless skiers who leave a pair of $200 skis unguarded outdoors while having a snack or coffee break indoors.

Serving consistently and volleying sharply, Fred Stolle of Australia defeated one of his countrymen, Ken Rosewall, 6-3, 7-5, for the $2,000 singles prize in last night's opening program of the sixth Madison Square Garden invitation tennis tournament.
The beginnings of the American Civil Liberties Union were hardly auspicious. It was the winter of 1920, with much of America already engulfed by Red scares.

The two members of the bistate Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor split yesterday over a dock worker's charge that Brooklyn longshore leaders, including Anthony Scotto, wanted him to join a so-called Mafia family led by Carlo Gambino. The split meant commission dismissal of that charge.

The City Planning Commission yesterday narrowly ap proved the controversial plan to build a $300-million glassenclosed office and public building complex across First Avenue from the United Nations headquarters.

A first time novelist who used to teach history and now raises sheep in Connecticut, William Steig, the cartoonist, and E.B. White, the author, were named winners yesterday of the nation's leading awards for children's books.
Citing higher costs, the Carrier Corporation announced yesterday that its air-conditioning divisions would increase prices by 3 per cent to 5 per cent on a wide range of air-conditioning products.

The 1970 Southern Ocean Racing Conference circuit, starting next Friday with the St. Petersburg-Venice race, will match for the first time the two sailing yachts generally considered to be the world's fastest.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 (AP) A Federal appeals court upheld today a decision dashing "fantastic" plans to set up a sovereign nation on two coral reefs four miles off Florida's coast.
WASHINGTON, Pa., Jan. 22 A bizarre account of events preceding the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter began to unfold here today.
Consolidated Edison was directed yesterday to give the Public Service Commission the names of it executives who approved construction contracts involved in bid-rigging exposed by a grand jury.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company expects to report earnings of about $1.50 a share for 1969, David D. Scott, president and chairman, said at the company's annual meeting in Milwaukee yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday appointed a Family Court judge, Joseph B. Williams, to the newly created post of Administrator of the city's Model Cities Program.
Two well-known passenger ships now flying the American flag may soon switch emblems.
Mayor Lindsay declared last night that a "heating crisis" existed in the city and directed the Housing and Development Administration to use emergency powers to help tenants in unheated buildings.
Sunfish, the bright little boats that sparkle in harbors around the world, have graduated to new honors: their first world championship and recognition by name on a foreign postage stamp.
John and Warren Luhrs, heirs to an honored boatbuilding legacy, are branching out on their own.

NEWARK, Jan. 22 The defense reluctantly rested today in the Federal conspiracy and extortion trial of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, reputed Mafia figure, after complaining that it had been unable to find witnesses it wanted to subpoena.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 22 Eleven more men were executed today in Baghdad eight army officers and three civilians the Iraqi radio said, bringing to 27 the number of persons who have been shot or hanged for their part in an alleged right-wing conspiracy Tuesday night to overthrow the Baathist Government of Iraq.
Time is running out on negotiations to limit textile imports, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, warned yesterday.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 22 (Reuters) the liner Oronsay, quarantined Jan. 14 after a typhoid outbreak, will stay in Vancouver until at least Wednesday, it was announced today.

In reflecting on more than two decades of quality tennis, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales chose Lew Hoad, one of his many Australian rivals, as "probably the best and toughest player when he wanted to be" of all his famous opponents.

CHESTER SPRINGS, Pa., Jan. 22 Miss Mary Stewart Heathcote, a student at the Royal Ballet School in London, and Norman Bruce Pinto, who is studying English and theater at Yankton (S.D.) College, plan to be married.

Airline and industry engineers worked yesterday to solve a perplexing mystery: Why did one engine of a Boeing 747 jetliner "run out of breath" just before its scheduled maiden commercial flight Wednesday night?

Any resemblance between the role of Pearson Yachts in this year's Boat Show and that of its appearance at the 1959 marine showcase is absolutely monumental.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 22 Several thousand high school children today resumed demonstrations in the streets of Jakarta ostensibly protesting against recent Government increases in prices of gasoline and kerosene used as fuel for cooking.

OCRACOKE ISLAND, N.C. Ducks and geese, or "fowl" as they are called locally, were plentiful all along Ocracoke Island and northward up the Cape Hatteras National Seashore, but were either out of range or not legal game.

The Giants and the Jets will play a preseason game again this summer in the Yale Bowl at New Haven, The date is not set, but likely it will be Sunday afternoon, Aug. 23, with tickets again priced at $7 each for the 70,874 seats.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 22 Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the head of Nigeria's military Government, declared today that his country could solve the "gigantic problem" of emergency relief for the territory that was Biafra.

THE ballots had been printed and the envelopes had been addressed. All was in readiness last month or so it seemed to poll the tribunal of 1,000 sportsmen in the annual voting for the Sullivan Award, the highest honor for an amateur performer in this country. The list of candidates had been drawn up by the Amateur Athletic Union some time previously and the goof therein was monumental.
Delta Air Lines, Inc., named W.T. Beebe yesterday as the carrier's president. He had been senior vice president-administration.
Mayor Lindsay and a West Side movie studio, where a campaign fund-raising party was held for him last October, were both cleared of any impropriety by the Board of Ethics yesterday.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where indicated.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 22 The Rev. Robert Allen Perry, pastor of the First Dutch Reformed Church here, died today at the Middlesex General Hospital, New Brunswick, N.J. after a brief illness. He was 31 years old.

The Real Beautiful Society picked its way through the garbage-dappled snow on East Seventh Street last night to the home base of the Real Great Society or, as it is now called, the University of the Streets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff accused the Agriculture Department today of secretly undermining its order limiting the fat content of hot dogs. He produced the text of a departmental memorandum as evidence.

THE TELEVISION networks engaged yesterday in instant and careful analysis of President Nixon's State of the Union Message continuing a tradition that preceded Vice President Agnew's outburst over immediate commentary on a Presidential address.
A 9-foot fiberglass fun boat called the Hydro-Cycle is attempting to prove that you can go waterskiing on a shoestring.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 22 From big-city wards to backcountry Assembly Districts, Connecticut is in the grip of political fever.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann of France said today that France along with the five other members wanted Britain to join the Common Market.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 Songs and movements have no place in the Chicago conspiracy trial, Judge Julius J. Hoffman ruled today.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Friday, Jan. 23 (AP) Bjorn Waldegaard and Lars Helmer roared to a predawn finish of the Monte Carlo auto rally in their West German Porsche today to be declared the unofficial winners.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) Excerpts from a secret Senate debate on Laos were published today, but heavy censorship kept from the record the extent of United States involvement in aerial combat there and the number of American casualties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 President Nixon committed himself and challenged the country today to rescue the American environment from years of human indifference and to display, in the decade ahead, a deeper concern for the quality of American life.

In the climax of the most active week of tax-exempt financing in more than a year, half a dozen major state and city bond issues came to market yesterday. Interest rates were higher, but investor acceptance of the bonds followed no pattern.
"Keeping Pleasure Boating Pleasant," a 24-page booklet of advice and suggestions about small craft, is being offered to the public at no charge by State Farm Fire and Casualty Company.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it planned to go to court to force the Penn Central Company to comply with on-time performance standards on the railroad's Hudson and Harlem divisions.

Next season in Britain promises to be as busy as ever for powerboats. A full racing program has been planned, including the 213-mile CowesTorquay and the 180-mile Wills Trophy race, the two British events that count for the world offshore championship title.

THE London Symphony Orchestra is in town for three consecutive Carnegie Hall concerts, each one with Vladimir Ashkenazy sharing the program. Last night he played the Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 4. Tonight and tomorrow he will turn his attention to Nos. 3 and 5, respectively. Andr Previn, in addition, placed the Beethoven Seventh Symphony on the program, though his other two concerts will avoid the other Beethoven symphonies.

Sales of new cars produced in this country continued to lag behind last year's pace during the middle of January, the four major United States manufacturers reported yester- day. Retail deliveries in the period from Jan. 11 to 20 were 152,618 units, a drop of 17 per cent from 184,148 sales in the comparable period of 1969. The two periods had the same number of selling days.

By the end of 1970, the production of marine diesel engines is expected to reach 21,000 units a year, more than double the 1967 output, according to H.O. Bedsole, marine division manager of Perkins Engines, Inc. The figure attests to the increasing demand for marine diesels but not to the reasons why more people are buying them.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 The State Senate and Assembly approved a Republican Congressional redistricting plan today after seven hours of interparty wrangling that ended when a convalescent Senator was rushed to the Capitol to cast the deciding vote.

Herbert W.J. Hargrave, one of the prosecutors at the war crimes trial at Dachau, Germany, died yesterday at his home after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 24 Beech Road, Islip, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 President Nixon said today he would propose a $10-billion program to clean up America's waters over five years. Informed officials said later that, under the President's plan, the Federal Government would pay 40 per cent of the cost and the states and cities 60 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 President Nixon's State of the Union Message was widely regarded on Capitol Hill today as a skillful political speech that seized the political high ground and took election-year issues away from a Democratic Congress.

EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 22 Teachers struck this city's 15 public schools today in a dispute similar to the one that led last week to a walkout by Passaic teachers.

Dr. Marie Smith Murray, a dentist and a founder of Christ United Methodist Church in Brooklyn, died Wednesday at the Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. She was 82 years old, the widow of Dr. Daniel Murray. Dr. Marie Murray lived at 336 86th Street, Brooklyn.
AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 22 (AP) Paul Eggers, general counsel for the United States Treasury Department, announced today his candidacy for Governor.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 About a year ago, amid great fanfare, high hopes and some skepticism, the Philadelphia school system initiated one of the nation's boldest experiments in public education, the Parkway Program, in which high school students choose their own subjects of study and use the city's institutions and businesses as classrooms.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 23 Mrs. Lynn Kelly and Thomas Michael Hamm were married here this afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Werner Hamm.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 The director of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts disavowed today, in an enigmatically worded statement, knowledge of an investigation by the Italian Government into the museum's acquisition of a Raphael painting.

Harold A. Kahn, 74-yearold American Bank Trust Company minority shareholder who has been selling women's ready-to-wear apparel in the Bronx for 51 years, came to Fifth Avenue yesterday morning and tried unsuccessfully to block the bank from establishing a one-bank holding comnany.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 23 Byegone, the 5-year-old son of Bye Bye Byrd, who is owned, trained and driven by John Patterson Sr., is the 3-1 choice to win the $25,000 Early Bird pacing series final at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

The Controller of the Currency has approved the merger of the Rockland National Bank and the County National Bank, according to a joint statement yesterday by John H. Payne Jr. and Richard H. Stover, presidents of the banks. The merger, which will become effective on Feb. 27, will create the Empire National Bank.
A Pan American World Airways Boeing 747, on its second westbound trans-Atlantic flight, arrived at Kennedy International Airport at 4:51 P.M. yesterday 4 hours 11 minutes behind schedule.
A selling squall buffeted the stock market yesterday afternoon, sending the Dow-Jones industrial average down 10.56 points and erasing, the combined gains of the three preceding sessions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The board of directors of the Export-Import Bank has approved a new system of guarantees for American exports generated as a result of leasing, as distinct from outright sale.
A little bird flew into the garden of the Fukiage Palace as the Emperor and Empress of Japan were talking after lunch.

The Penn Central said yesterday that it had not taken any action to comply with a sevenmonth-old order of the State Public Service Commission caliing for "immediate" steps to purchase or lease 80 new cars and 24 new engines for the line's Harlem and Hudson commuter divisions.

A hearing examiner for the Federal Maritime Administration has called for an investigation of fees, aggregating $939,500, paid by the United States Lines to a marine engineering company owned by the ship company's president.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 23 (AP) The deadlock at strikebound Santa Anita and Bay Meadows race tracks continued through its 21st racing day today and the secretary of the Federation of California Racing Associations expressed extreme pessimism on a possible settlement.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 23 (AP) Christian Belon was rearrested here today on a charge of having restricted the freedom of the passengers and crew of the Trans World Airlines plane he hijacked to Beirut Jan. 9. [United Press International said Belon was taken to prison at Baabda.]

BONN, Jan. 23 The East German press agency, A.D.N., issued a short commentary today mildly criticizing the letter sent yesterday by the West Germany Chancellor, Willy Brandt, to the East German Premier, Willi Stoph, proposing negotiations between the two states.

A group of black leaders announced plans yesterday for the marking of Black Liberation Week next month to make the community aware of the "grave peril facing us and to organize, new common strategies for our protection."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The White House said today that domestic communications satellites should be developed and operated on a competitive basis by private interests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today the removal of limitations on the amount of sugar that foreign suppliers can ship into the United States in the first quarter of this year.

Dr. Joseph A, von Bradish, author and professor emeritus of German at City College, died Wednesday at Staten Island Hospital in Hopkinsville. He was 86 years old and lived at 350 Richmond Terrace there.

Mrs. Elizabeth Doyle Hogan, assistant to the administrator of the Morrisania Hospital and the wife of Francis L. Hogan, a chartered life underwriter for the John Hancock Insurance Company, died Thursday at the Montefiore Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 2515 University Avenue, the Bronx.

How could the Viennese Opera Ball in New York be more genuine Viennese than it usually is. By celebrating, as it did last night, the 100th birthday of Franz Lehar, the operetta king. For if there is one thing the Viennese love more than whipped cream, it is whipped cream music.

Indicated earnings in the Fourth quarter of 1969 by Imperial Oil, Ltd., Canada's largest integrated oil company, fell to $26-million, or 20 cents a share, from $30-million, or 24 cents, in the year-ago period. Indicated sales for the quarter, however, rose to $433-million from $413-million in the corresponding period of 1968.
