SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 24 (Reuters) Dennis Ralston, the American professional beat John Newcombe of Australia today in the longest major tennis match played in Australia at the Australian open championships.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) Cliff Richey, second-ranked player in the United States, reached the semifinals of the Austin Smith tennis tournament today with a 6-2, 6-0 rout of Bill Higgins, the top ranked teaching pro in the country.
Dr. Frank Hamilton Hankins, professor emeritus of sociology at Smith College, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 92 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, today challenged the Administration's contention that political, military and financial considerations justified the maintenance of American troops in Western Europe at their present level.

ATLANTA, Jan. 23 (AP) The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy said he sent a telegram today to Senate leaders urging them to oppose the nomination of Judge G. Harold Carswell to the United States Supreme Court.

PARIS, Jan. 23 Marcel Dassault, the French aircraft builder whose Mirages may be tipping the balance of power in the Middle East, indicated today that he had nothing to do with policy regarding the sale of French military planes.

BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N.J., Jan. 23 William Mills Emery, president and chairman of the Better Sleep Manufacturing Company here, makers of sleeping aids and comfort devices, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 72 years old and lived at 44 Pittsford Way, New Providence.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 23 Harold J. Pryor, head of the United Transportation Union, which represents union members working for the Long Island Rail Road, said today that his union had withdrawn from the Long Island Federation of Labor.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 23 (UPI) Student protests against Government-ordered increases in the price of gasoline and kerosene spread today from Jakarta to Jogjakarta in Central Java. The army warned that troops were ready to enforce a ban on demonstrations.
MIAMI, Jan. 23 (UPI) J.M. Olin's 4-year-old bay filly Gunite, making her first start of the season, captured the $10, 000 Gainsborough Girl Purse at Hialeah Park today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Federal investigation of the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski was reported today to be focusing on what was described by Government officials as "a sizable sum of money" promised the killers by a person or group in the Kentucky-Tennesseee coal fields.

COURT BARS PAPER ON NONVIOLENCE CHICAGO, Jan. 23 An unequivocal stand against violent demonstrations at the 1968 Democratic National Convention here was read into the record at the Chicago conspiracy trial today.
SEATTLE, Jan. 23 (AP) Mayor Wes Uhlman, in a lastditch move to keep the Seattle Pilots in this city, asked a state court today for a restraining order prohibiting the removal of the franchise.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 23 As gale winds of 34 mile an hour swept along the Monterey Peninsula today. Bert Yancey played the Spyglass Hill course, the most sheltered of the three sites used in the Bing Crosby pro-amateur golf tourney, today and led with a 36-hole aggregate of 137.

Richard A. Shafter, a press agent with the Cooperative for American Relief Everywhere and a former newspaperman, died Thursday in Belleville, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived at 131 Bremond Street there.
NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J. Jan. 23 A strike by the Teachers Association today close this community's five public schools.
MOSCOW, Jan. 23 A Soviet foreign affairs weekly said today that the United States hoped to use its talks with Communist China in Warsaw to worsen Peking's relations with Moscow.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 23 (Reuters) Gen. Odumegwu Ojukwu, who was the leader of secessionist Biafra, is in the Ivory Coast and has been granted asylum, the Government here announced today.
BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Jimmy Hayes scored 30 points and Steve Gladstone added 23 tonight as Boston University earned a 79-74 basketball victory over Dartmouth.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 23 (AP) Henry R. Hecht's Francis X. scored a three-length victory in the Caroline Purse at Bowie race course today to return $5.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 23 Although the honor was a long time coming, it may have seemed inevitable that Joseph Fielding Smith Jr. was elected today as president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to succeed the late David O. McKay.

A threatened impasse between the building inspectors union and the city over Mayor Lindsay's directive to assist tenants in unheated apartments was ended last night after negotiators reached a general agreement.
Trading on the Chicago Board of Trade was active at the opening, following the issuance of a government report on stocks of grains in all positions, but it slowed down later.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 Luis Echeverria Alvarez, the presidential candidate of Mexico's ruling party, said today that it was in Mexico's best interest to intensify efforts to reduce international narcotics smuggling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Officials of the State Department said today that North Vietnam had recently massed more troops and military supplies on the edge of the Plaine des Jarres in Laos than ever before.

LAS VEGAS, Jan. 23 (AP) John Glover, a left-handed bowler from Bakersfield, Calif., won eight of nine matches today to lead after the semifinal round of the $77,777.77 Showboat invitation professional tournament.

MEGEVE, France, Jan. 23 (UPI) Karl Schranz of Austria returned to championship form today with a victory in the 26th Grand Prix of Megeve downhill ski races, an event marred by the death of Michel Bozon, a French skier, and injuries to 15-year-old Werner Grissmann of Austria.

Congressmen who have doubts about a pending measure to lighten Federal penalties for possessing marijuana should study the case of a young student recently pardoned in Virginia. No action taken by Congress would directly affect penalties imposed by the states, but the incident should serve to point up the savagery with which American society has been approaching the subtle and difficult problem of drugs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 The Chicago Bulls clawed tenaciously at the New York Knickerbockers tonight, displaying one of their best performances of the National Basketball Association season, but to the disappointment of a cheering crowd of 14,505 at Chicago Stadium emerged only with their fifth straight loss of the season to New York, 120-117.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) J. Frazier Moore of Detroit has been elected acting president of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union of North America. The union said Mr. Moore was elected by its executive board to succeed Anthony J. DeAndrade, who died Tuesday.

Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Binion Cahn of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Binion Cahn, to Thomas Richard McIntosh. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas John McIntosh of South Weymouth, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

Two stocks held the spotlight in the new-issue market this week-one quadrupled in price and the other nearly tripled. Otherwise, there was little to hearten investors and traders in this often speculative segment of the stock market.

The Collegiate Chorale has wasted no time in getting its celebration of the bicentennial of Beethoven's birth under way. At Philharmonic Hall last night, this biggest and best of our amateur choruses performed Beethoven's Missa Solemnis, and that is celebration enough for any group of singers.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 23 (AP) The Bolivian Government said today that it had uncovered a downtown office here run by the United States Central Intelligence Agency and that it will ask for the removal from Bolivia of any Americans involved in the "center of operations."

JERUSALEM, Jan. 23 The Israeli High Court decided today, by a vote of 5 to 4, that an Israeli could register his children as Jewish by nationality rather than by religion even though their mother was not a Jew.
SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 23 Joseph Fielding Smith Jr., the 93-year-old grandson of one of the early Mormon martyrs, was designated today as president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

It hardly speaks well for the thoroughness or the quality of the Justice Department's research that the "white supremacy" speech delivered by Judge G. Harrold Carswell in 1948 was only uncovered by a television reporter following Judge Carswell's nomination to the Supreme Court.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 23 "We have spent four days tinkering with the machinery," Roger Burgess said this afternoon, "but I think now we are ready to go."
OTTAWA, Jan. 23 Daniel Cohn-Bendit, the European student revolutionary whose oneweek visitor's permit expired last night, was granted today an extension until Feb. 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Following are recommendations contained in a memorandum on Federal policy on domestic satellite communications sent today by Peter Flanigan, assistant to the President, to Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission:

The American Civil Liberties Union, which this week celebrated its fiftieth anniversary and the coincidental eighty-sixth birthday of its founder, Roger N. Baldwin, started out as a watchdog of constitutional liberties at a moment in history when another Attorney General was cracking down on those who disagreed with the prevailing notion of what was patriotic thought and conduct.
Leaders of American Orthodox Judaism denounced the ruling of Israel's highest court yesterday that one may hold Jewish nationality despite a rejection of Judaism and a declaration of atheism.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) An Interstate Commerce Commission hearing examiner recommended approval today of the merger of the Louisville Nashville and Monon Railroads.
BONN, Jan. 23 West German newspapers are looking forward to continued growth in advertising revenues this year, thanks to new techniques and ideas.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 23 The American Basketball Association, in a quick about-face, tonight declared all-out war on the National Basketball Association.
FREDERICKTOWN, Pa., Jan. 23 Seaching for clues in the slaying of Joseph A. Yablonskl, scuba divers recovered today a bag of material from the ice-clogged Monongahela River.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 23 An American relief airlift for the former Biafran territory began today with the arrival in Lagos of 26 jeeps, one 200-bed portable hospital and two C-97 transport aircraft.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The new Commissioner of Food and Drugs hinted today that his agency might take a look at the safety and efficacy of drugs that have been on the market for many years.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Jan. 23 (UPI) The Atomic Energy Commission triggered the first underground nuclear test of the year today. The nuclear weapon, with a force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT, was detonated at a depth of 800 feet. No radiation leaked into the atmosphere.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 (AP) Justice George Tilzer of the Bronx was designated today as an associate justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, First Department. Justice Tilzer, who was named to a two-year term by Governor Rockefeller, was an appellate justice from 1966 until his retirement Jan. 1.
LONDON, Jan. 23 The International Publishing Corporation, the largest publishing company in the world, is to be taken over by the Reed Paper Group.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 23 (UPI) Hirsch Jacobs, noted trainer of thoroughbred race horses, was reported in satisfactory condition at the Miami Heart Institute today after having been hospitalized for treatment of a heart condition.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 The Massachusetts Commission on Christian Unity issued 10 guidelines today signaling major changes in hieratical attitudes toward marriages between couples of differing denominations.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (UPI) Floyd Clymer, automobile and motorcycle dealer and publisher of automotive books, died last night apparently of a heart ailment. He was 74 years old.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 The Jap anese Government, never un duly rash in changing trade police, is waiting cautiously for talks on a trade pact with the European Economic Community scheduled to start next month
The major television and radio networks applauded yesterday the Administration's policy of "open entry and rate competition" for a domestic communications satellite system.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Arthur J. Phelan, retired partner of the Washington law firm of Hogan and Hartson, died today at the Georgetown University Hospital. He was 69 years old.
Seven years ago, Patricia Stonewall left high school in Erie, Pa., to go to work with the thought that some day she would resume her education and "finish in style."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Concerned at the rapid increase in pulmonary disease, a Philadelphia physician has invented a portable therapeutic face-mask, named Breath-Aid. A patient can treat himself with it in home, train or office.
Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Bernstein's gathering on behalf of the New York Panther 21 Legal Defense Fund is rapidly becoming the most talked-about party since Truman Capote's masked ball.

William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that he would present to the Board of Estimate next week an alternative plan for the proposed Second Avenue subway that would serve the needs of residents of both the Lower East Side and of Brooklyn.

DESPITE the air of national celebration and self-congratulation that now presides over the historiography of American art in the 20th century, we are still remarkably ignorant about the careers and achievements that give this period its distinctive character.
An 11-year-old Brooklyn boy, has been arrested on a charge of selling heroin through a mail slot in the door of his home, the police said yesterday.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1969.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Congressional Democrats decided today to present their own state of the union message to the country by turning to the man in the street to discuss the problems confronting the nation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Senator Edmund S. Muskie said today that President Nixon's "rhetoric of concern" about the environment in his State of the Union Message yesterday was "excellent" but that any final judgment of the extent of the President's commitment to environmental quality would depend on the programs he proposed and the money he requested.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 (AP) The South Vietnamese Government demonstrated today that it could conduct a bicycle race along 290 miles of its roads so long as several thousand soldiers were available to protect the cyclists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Preliminary findings of a Government-backed study indicate that women who decide to use birth control pills may be more prone to cancer than women who do not, Congress was told today.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (P) The foreign ministers of Britain an France agreed today to restore cooperation between their two countries in as many fields as possible, including foreign affairs.

GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ballet "Bugaku," given by New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater last night, is an Oriental epithalamium, a careful marriage ritual suggesting Japanese connubial ceremonies in a happily familiar European translation.

The diagnosis of typhoid fever has been confirmed in 36 and is suspected in 30 additional crewmen and passengers from the British liner Oronsay, now in the harbor of Vancouver, B.C. About 1,600 persons remain in voluntary quarantine aboard the cruise ship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee recommended to the Senate today a huge $35-billion education bill going far beyond President Nixon's recommendations.

An assistant Queens district attorney investigating charges of child abuse toured the center for disturbed children at Creedmoor State Hospital yesterday and said that "everything about it reminded me of a prison."

The state will take over 1,500 more of the city's 6,000 prisoners under an agreement announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller. The pact brings to 2,500 the number the state will accent in its institutions.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 23 A planeload of arms from Iraq for the Palestinian guerrillas is due here tomorrow, the Iraqui Defense Minister, Lieut. Gen. Hardan Takriti, said today.

The Government accused eight reputed Mafia members yesterday of conspiring to bribe Internal Revenue Service agents. Seven of the eight were arrested along with a tax consultant who was a former tax agent and an I.R.S. agent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board's enforcement bureau asked today for the suspension of two American supplemental airlines and two foreign lines for alleged illegal trans-Atlantic charter flight operations.

A series of books of computer printouts, ledger size and two inches thick, were offered yesterday to prove a charge that a conspiracy by contractors to rig bids had inflated the Consolidated Edison Company construction costs by nearly 10 per cent.
TOKYO, Jan. 23 (Reuters) A five-day strike by Okinawan workers on United States military bases on Okinawa ended tonight without settlement of the issue of almost 1,200 dismissed workers.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The Detroit Pistons dissipated a 13point lead in regulation time but rallied behind Jimmy Walker and Dave Bing in an overtime period to score a 109-105 victory tonight over the Boston Celtics.

It's January and the New York Rangers and Boston Bruins are battling for first place. That never happened during the 1960's, but it is a new decade and a new era for the two Eastern teams that the National Hockey League had forgotten about for nearly 30 years.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 23 Mrs. Lucy Sevier Jones McDannel, the widow of Thomas H. McDannel, a tax consultant with an office in New York City, died yesterday in the Beechwood Manor Convalescent Home here of pneumonia. She wac 88 years old.
MOLLIE PARNIS really started a trend. Since she denounced longer hemlines at the start of her summer show earlier this week, any number of designers have felt compelled to do likewise.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The Arab negotiating team that concluded France's controversial arms deal with Libya included key military experts from the United Arab Republic posing as Libyan officials, according to diplomatic intelligence reports.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 23 Auguste G. Pratt, former chairman of the board of the Babcock Wilcox Company, a New York engineering concern, died apparently of a heart attack at his home here last night, at 345 Walnut Street. He was 88 years old.
As could be expected in the wake of a long and bitter civil conflict, reports from the defeated Nigerian secessionist state of Biafra are confused and not altogether reassuring.

GENEVA, Jan. 23 Joint Church Aid, the interdenominational agency that flew more than 60,000 metric tons of food and medical supplies into the former Biafran region, announced today that its mission was ended.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 23 (Reuters) A United States spokesman said today that B-52's struck targets around a Mekong Delta province today and in a province near Saigon.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Jan. 23 This old ski jumping stronghold is about to play host to its first national tournament since 1909. Nearly 100 skiriders have come here to display their prowess on the city's year-old 73-meter Silver Mine Hill.
The John's Bargain Stores Corporation plans to acquire Sprayregen Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange. Terms of the transaction were announced yesterday by both concerns.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 23--An Israeli task force withdrew today from the Egyptian island of Shadwan after a 30-hour operation in which that Red Sea outpost was completely neutralized as a military base.
ROME, Jan. 23 (AP) The world junior middleweight boxing champion, Freddy Little of Las Vegas, Nev., was disqualified tonight for not fighting during a nontitle bout with Eddie Pace of Los Angeles.

The Department of Transportation's plan to create a semipublic corporation Railpax to revitalize and run the nation's disintegrating intercity passenger rail service merits support it has not so far received from the Bureau of the Budget and the White House.
Familiar too is the Auden cadence: "happy is he who hopes for better, /what awaits Her may well be worse," the pronouns as usual without antecedents.

What makes Marty Liquori run? "My grandparents," the 20-year-old Villanova junior from Cedar Grove, N.J., said recently. "They follow all my races, and one of my grandmothers lights candles and prays for me every time I run."
The cast of LeRoi Jones's "Slave Ship" walked off the stage last night after complaining to the audience that conditions at the theater were too similar to a real slave ship.

SOME friends of mine with children of kindergarten age reported to me recently that their 5-year-old son, Play School class of '69, was graduated last June in full academic regalia. The idea behind the ceremony seems to have been that with things going the way they are in the universities, this might be the last chance the boy would have to wear a cap and gown.

George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said here yesterday that $20-billion more a year in private investment in housing was needed to meet the goal fixed by Congress of 26 million new housing units by 1978.

Respondong to 14,761 spectators who provided a bullfight atmosphere, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales gored the matador, Rod Laver, at Madison Square Garden last night in the opening match of the Tennis Champions, Inc., $200,00 Classic.

WALTER BYERS, sometimes known as "That powermad Walter Byers," is the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, sometimes referred to as "That Kansas City Mob." Byers and the N.C.A.A. are probably American sports' most available target for criticism. Some of that criticism is reflexive: Authoritarian, Midwest-oriented, politically conservative, the N.C.A.A. is frequently attacked by liberals, Easterners and partisans of the Amateur Athletic Union, with whom the N.C.A.A. wars like gangs for a turf.

A fire broke out yesterday on the first floor of Junior High School 64, at Atkins and Belmont Avenues in the East New York section of Brooklyn, causing the building to be evacuated and classes to be canceled until Monday.

Andre Backar, a former first vice president of Shearson Hammill Co., New York stockbrokers, pleaded not guilty here yesterday in Federal curt to charges of arranging unlawful extension of credit on stock purchases through a Swiss bank.

METUCHEN, N.J., Jan. 23 (AP) The Ford Motor Company plant here announced today that it would be closed for the next three weeks, rather than for one week, in the second temporary layoff since production of 1970 cars began.
The omnipresent figure of Beethoven (200 years old this year in case anyone is still unaware of the fact) hovered once again over the London Symphony Orchestra's concert at Carnegie Hall last night.
THE first tournament of this decade to be played in New York City begins today at the McAlpin Hotel, 34th Street and Broadway.

AKRON, Jan. 23 (UPI) The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced today it had settled a five-year old trademark infringement suit against the Weather-Rite Sportswear Company of Brooklyn. Weather-Rite agreed to refrain from using trademark similar to those of Goodyear.
The chairman of the governing board of the Intermediate School 201 complex in East Harlem urged parents yesterday to boycott the community school board elections scheduled for March 19.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 23 Soviet officials say the two most important points preventing progress here in the Big Four talks about the Middle East are United States insistence on Arab-Israeli negotiations and on demands that the Arab Governments accept a compromise to prevent guerrilla activities against Israel.

WARREN, N.J. Howard and Dorothy Leichter escaped the madness of the city about 18 months ago by settling into a sparsely furnished multilevel ranch house nestled in the hills of Somerset County. Snow, space and silence surround them in the winter, a screen of full-leafed trees in summer.
New York drama critics were informed yesterday that they may attend any performance of "Paris Is Out" from next Wednesday through Saturday and then print their comments on Feb. 3.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Officials of four Southern states asked today that all 50 states be brought under uniform rules of public school desegregation.
ROSE VALLEY, Pa., Jan. 23 Miss Lindsey Paige Latimer and Bruno La Rocca, who are with the Bankers Trust Company in New York, plan to be married in May.
MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Jan. 23 The Winchester, Mass., Country Club rink, skipped by Mrs. Walter L. Wilcox, retained the Empire State women's curling championship and the Clarke Trophy today.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) George Brown, a former foreign Secretary, conferred with Prime Minister Wilson today to report on his recent private visit to the Middle East.
Thirty telephone operators struggled yesterday at the Department of Buildings emergency complaint bureau to answer the thousands of complaints of no heat in the cold city.
CLEMSON, S.C., Jan. 23 (AP) George M. MacIntyre, an assistant for two years at Temple University, joined the Clemson football coaching staff today.

The city's latest industrialpark project, a 100-acre site in the Bronx, is expected to provide 3,000 new jobs when construction is completed in about four years. But the city's intention to acquire 37 acres of land in assembling the site has caused protests by businesses that apparently will have to relocate.
The arrest of three men on charges of conspiring to kill Joseph A. Yablonski offers the first glimmer of hope that the perpetrators of this brutal crime will be brought to justice.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 23 The United Arab Republic, under intensifying pressure from Israeli attacks, is taking steps to tighten discipline in the armed forces and to sustain civilian morale, according to information reaching here from Cairo.

Studebaker-Worthington, Inc., announced yesterday that about 1,433,000 shares of its common stock had been tendered in response to its offer to its shareholders to exchange shares of the STP Corporation for shares of StudebakerWorthington.
Three operas will be given their first performances of the season by the Metropolitan Opera during the week of Feb. 9, the seventh week of the company's season.
WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Jan. 23 Engineers will use a propeller-driven airliner to create artificial winds tomorrow in an effort to solve an on-the-ground engine problem in the Boeing 747.

Seven months before Joseph M. Valachi, the defector from the Mafia, disclosed its secrets at public hearings in Washington, members of the criminal brotherhood were overheard discussing evidence that the Government was preparing supposedly in secret against them.
Charles Feinstein has been elected president of the International Leather Goods, Plastics and Novelty Workers Union, a spokesman announced yesterday.

The disclosure that American Export Isbrandtsen Lines had entered into an agreement with a Greek shipowner to sell the passenger liner Constitution produced protest demonstrations aboard five of the line's cargo ships yesterday.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved lower yesterday on news that the British Government was planning to abandon most of its price and wage restraint powers this summer.
NEWI, Nigeria, Jan. 22 In the northern part of the former Biafra region, the Nigerian Army is behaving with discipline, but relief efforts are pathetically slow and appear to be inadequate.

ROME, Jan. 23 Italy's motor giant, Fiat, announced today that it had done very well in 1969 but could have done even better had not a plague of strikes hampered production during Italy's "hot autumn" of labor unrest.

THE program known as "On Stage," which has made some important dramatic contributions to television, settled last night for a very light comedy of suspense. Robert Culp's performance was all that held together the thin handiwork of John Mortimer's "Married Alive" on the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) The National Coal Association, from incomplete carloading reports from the railroads, estimates last week's bituminous coal production in the United States at 10.88 million tons. Production in the year's earlier period was 10.9 million tons. Production reported by the Bureau of Mines for the week ended Jan. 10 was 8,676,000 tons.

Dr. Albert Reissner, a psychotherapist who had been on the staff of the Alfred Adler Consultation Center here for a decade, died yesterday in the Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 86 years old and lived at 93 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn.
NORWICH, Conn., Jan. 23 Louis Darling, an author and illustrator of books on natural history, died in a hospital here Wednesday of cancer. He was 53 years old and lived in Old Lyme.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference Council postponed action on the Yale-Jack Langer eligibility case yesterday in a move that may put the issue before the entire 190-member E.C.A.C. at its annual meeting, Feb. 25.

Anthony A. Cantalupo, president of a Brooklyn realty company in which Joseph Columbo, a reputed Mafia boss, is a salesman, denied yesterday that he knew of his employe's alleged underworld connections and said that he had been "harassed" by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Edelstahlwerke Buderus, A.G., a leading West German specialty stel and alloy producer, said yesterday it had established a North American marketing subsidiary to be known as the Buderus Steel Corporation. The new unit, with offices in South Hackensack. N.J., and will be headed by O.A. Kaletsch.
Alfred J. Phillips and Virgil N. Woolfolk have been elected vice presidents of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

DEAL, N.J., Jan. 23 Stephen A. Argeris, a senior partner in the law firm of Hanlon, Argeris Amdur of Asbury Park, died today in Monmouth County Medical Center. He was 48 years old and lived at 2 Queen Avenue Drive.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23 (UPI) The Union Oil Company has signed a contract to build an $80-million electric power plant in South Korea as a joint venture with the Korea Explosives Company.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) The nation's new-car production was scheduled at 161,477 this week, higher than the 138,517 last week, but still below the 193,380 for the corresponding period a year ago.

A former Internal Revenue Service agent was found guilty by a Federal Court jury in Brooklyn late Wednesday night of receiving a $3,000 bribe to refrain from further tax examination of several related Long Island corporations.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) Barbara McIntire and Mrs. Carolyn Cudone were eliminated today as four youngsters emerged as semifinalists in the 38th annual Doherty Challenge Cup golf tournament.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, Jan. 23 (AP) Bjorn Waldegaard of Sweden, in a Porsche, was officially confirmed today as the winner of the Monte Carlo auto rally, an event that proved to be little more than a road race in the Alps this year.
THURMONT, Md., Jan. 23 (UPI) President Nixon flew to Camp David today for the start of a weekend of relaxation with his wife and their daughter Julie, and her husband, David Eisenhower.
VERY few collectors will be looking for the pricetags on objects in the Metropolitan Museum loan to this year's Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory, 67th Street and Park Avenue.

Schubert's "Die Winterreise," the greatest of song cycles, poses the greatest test for a lieder singer. Its 24 songs have to be sung without interruption, spanning approximately an hour and a quarter.
TOKYO, Jan. 23 The Private Investment Company for Asia, S.A., (PICA) S.A., a capitalist venture in development assistance, announced today its first major financing projects.

John Clyde McCarroll, a lawyet, formerly associated with Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons Gates, 320 Park Avenue, and since 1966 a graduate fellow at Harvard Law School in Islamic law, died Thursday of leukemia in Memorial Hospital. He was 34 years old and lived at 135 East 17th Street.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 23 John E. Riordan St., engineer and superintendent of the First District Water Department, died today at Norwalk Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 37 France Street.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 23 (AP) Jerry Proctor of Redlands (Calif.) University soared to a long-jump meet record on his next-to-last leap in winning the only final event in tonight's opening of the fifth annual National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics indoor track championships.

WHITE BEAR LAKE, Minn., Jan. 23--Miss Josephine Bremer Benz was married here this afternoon to Thomas Kimberly Carpenter, who is president of the REMSA Corporation, real estate management consultants of Detroit and Minneapolis.

DONCASTER, England, Jan. 23 (UPI) Last year's Grand National steeplechase winner, Highland Wedding, has been retired, his trainer, Toby Balding, said today. Balding said the horse was injured six weeks ago, "but is now sound."
MIAMI, Jan. 23 An officer of the Gulf Oil Corporation said today that he had been informed that the Spanish Government was negotiating for control of Gulf property nationalized by Bolivia.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 23 The New Year began with celebrations on the beaches here as it has for years.

Eighty-four elected executives of several national Protestant denominations and the National Council of Churches asked yesterday that charges against the Young Lords for disrupting services and occupying the First Spanish Methodist Church in East Harlem be dropped.

Rock Hudson, the actor, and Rod McKuen, the poet and song writer, have formed an independent movie company, R and R Productions. The first film to be made under the new partnership will be "Chuck," from a novel by Carl Sterland published last year by Doubleday Co., which Mr. Mckuen recently acquired for filming.

Tino Barzie, the former manager of Frank Sinatra Jr., Jackie Gleason and Tommy Dorsey, and two co-defendants were found guilty by a Federal jury here last night of conspiracy to use stolen credit cards to purchase thousands of dollars worth of airline tickets.
The New York Mets started paying the price of success yesterday almost $80,000 worth when they signed Jerry Koosman and Ron Taylor to their 1970 contracts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 The nation's manufacturing industries were operating on the average at only 81.8 per cent of capacity in the fourth quarter of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Robert Willoughby is professor of flute at the Oberlin College Conservatory of Music, and he knows his instrument inside out. Tackling a demanding program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, he met every technical challenge with fluent and confident ease.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (Reuters) The average rate of discount at today's tender of British Treasury 91-day bills fell to 7.524 per cent from 7.550 per cent last week. Mr. and Mrs. John B. Babcock of New York and Sharon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanne Scheerer Babcock, to Gerard Peter Hallock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Hallock of Islip, L.I.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP) The Philadelphia 76ers got 54 points from their starting forwards, Billy Cunningham, and Jim Washington, tonight as they scored an easy 133-118 victory over the Baltimore Bullets in a National Basketball Association game.
WARRENTON, Va., Jan. 23 Harry Fitzhugh Gray, former, general agent for the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company in New York, died yesterday. He was 85 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 Martin Fromin, who had been in somewhat of a slump since losing his apprentice allowance of Jan. 14, broke out of it by booting home three winners at Liberty Bell race track today.

Miss Wesley Ann Vazquez and Howard Thomas Hogan Jr. were married yesterday morning at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Vincent Hart performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Donald McPhail, an Episcopal minister. A reception was held at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

WASHINGTON--Richard M. Nixon was making fresh, penciled changes in his State of the Union Message until 30 minutes before he appeared in the House of Representatives to deliver it last Thursday. But well before then, in the solitude of San Clemente and Camp David, he had fashioned an address that was conspicuously different in style and substance from any so far unveiled in his brief and relatively uneventful Presidency.

Jazz and laughter were blended in a vesper service yesterday afternoon by Clark Terry's big band and the comedian Hank Garrett. The service was one of a weekly series of jazz vespers at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 54th Street at Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 With Gen. Earle G. Wheel- er's term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff expiring on July 3, President Nixon will have an opportunity to make some major changes in the United States military command.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 "Nobody ever wonders about Pat Nixon," said a man the other day who has seen first ladies come and go and who spends much time crisscrossing America on the speech circuit. "Nobody asks you: 'What is she really like?'"

BONN, Jan. 25 A stockpile of surplus butter so large that the Germans call it Butterberg looms as a symbol of the problems facing agriculture in Western Europe. The imaginary mountain of butter weighs 400,000 tons about as much as the weight of all the people living in New York City or in Austria.
PANAMA The economy of this buoyant little country at the maritime crossroads of the Americas recovered smartly last year from the political instability and growth depression of 1968.

LIMA, Peru It is time to bring into truer focus the widely accepted image of the generals who rule Peru as something strikingly new under the Latin-American sun.

ASHCROFT, British Columbia Few vehicles roll on the unnumbered road that winds through the Highland Valley a good thing considering its unannounced dips and curves. One of these days, however, a survey crew will be along, figuring out how to make the road safe for hundreds of commuting miners.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 Senator Jacob K. Javits left Saigon today after a four-day visit that he said had served to confirm his view that the United States should withdraw its troops from South Vietnam "at the earliest possible date."

The multibillion-dollar construction industry is not keeping pace, economically, with the rest of the United States private economy, according to a report published yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

VIENNA, Jan. 25 Alexander Dubcek, the former head of the Czechoslovak Communist Party, flew to Turkey tonight to take up his new post as ambassador. He left Prague amid speculation that he would soon lose his last party position, his seat on the Central Committee.

NORTH SALEM, N.Y., Jan. 25 A van carrying Barney Ward's Spaced Out crashed into a bridge abutmeni while traveling from Harrisburg to the Washington horse show slightly more than three months ago. The 8-year-old brown gelding was thrown from the van and was injured.

MIAMI The sugar-dominated Cuban economy, following what was perhaps its poorest annual performance since the 1959 revolution, day stage a moderate advance this year.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 (UPI) Jacques Lemaire scored twice within 59 seconds in the first period tonight and started the Montreal Canadiens on their way to a 4-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings. Lemaire, who leads the National Hockey League in goals, now has 28.

The Clark Center for the Performing Arts of the West Side Young Women's Christian Association has for years unselfishly provided established and aspiring talents with a midtown showplace. Yesterday evening some of the better-known performers repaid the kindness with a benefit performance at the Clark Auditorium.

Rosalind Rees, soprano, appeared in a program of vocal chamber music presented at Town Hall Saturday afternoon under the direction of Stanley Hoffman. Miss Rees, who is studying here with Adele Addison after having graduated from the Cleveland Institute of Music, showed that her pleasing and well-poised voice adapts smoothly to music of various periods and styles.
The New York Stock Exchange announced over the weekend that John J. Alexander Jr., 34, had been named vice president in charge of the exchange's Electronic Systems Center.

An important factor in the unity of the Jewish people over the centuries has been the close link between Jewish religion and culture, even in times of widespread nonobservance of religious law.

The marriage of Miss Susan Marie Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard James Allen of New York, to Arthur Stern 3d took place at the Carlyle yesterday afternoon. Five hundred and thirty million Indians one-sixth of mankind celebrate one of the most remarkable political achievements of all time today: Their completion of twenty years of federal union under the democratic Constitution India adopted on Jan. 26, 1950, two and one-half years after gaining independence from Britain.

DENVER, Jan. 25 (AP) The Denver Rockets scored their 15th straight American Basketball Association victory today, defeating the Dallas Chaparrals, 127-118. The Rockets have won 17 of their last 19 games and pulled to within 1 games of New Orleans, top team in the Western Division.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 24 The delicate sounds of the yang-chin, the heng-hsiao, the erh-hu and the pi-pa filled the smah crowded room as a quartet of musicians played at a musicale at the Chinese Center on Long Island here recently.

TO my knowledge Robert Altman's "M*A*S*H" is the first major American movie openly to ridicule belief in God not phony belief; real belief. It is also one of the few (though by no means the first) American screen comedies openly to admit the cruelty of its humor. And it is at pains to blend that humor with more operating room gore than I have ever seen in any movie from any place.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Jan. 25 Bill Bakke, the stylish red-headed sky rider, served notice early today that he was doing to make an all-out effort to win his first national ski jumping championship. In his first outing this afternoon, he tied the hill record he had set last year with a mighty flight of 251 feet.

The tempo of labor negotiations in the port's commercial tug and barge industry will be quickening this week. The current three-year agreement between the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association and Local 333, United Marine Division, National Maritime Union, expires at midnight Saturday.

Miss Susan Jane Levin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Levin, of New York, was married here yesterday to Martin Bruce Tepper, a lawyer with Schrieber Lancaster, Newark. The ceremony was performed at the Pierre by Rabbi Irwin Fishbein of Temple Beth El, Elizabeth, N.J.

Awards for screen achievement in 1969 were presented yesterday afternoon by the New York Film Critics at a reception held at Sardi's West Restaurant, 234 West 44th Street. The award-winners and the 22 movie reviewers who chose them were joined by from the entertainment field.

As the voter registration for local school board elections moved into its second and final week today, officials expressed keen disappointment at the low turnout so far. They expressed hope that the trend would improve radically as the Saturday deadline approached.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Businesses that pollute the air and water will bear much of the cost of President Nixon's campaign to clean up the en- vironment, Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 President Nixon sent a message to an emergency conference of Jewish leaders today reiterating Administration assurances that the United States believed peace in the Middle East could come only after a negotiated agreement between Israel and the Arab states.

A duo recital by Ma Si-Hon, violinist, and his wife, Tung Kwong-Kwong, pianist, was given at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night to assist in the establishment of a New York Chinese School Music Program Scholar- ship and Expansion Fund.

ARCTIC BAY, Northwest Territories Arctic Bay is an Eskimo settlement strung along the shore of Baffin Island, backed by sentinel stone mountains and ice rivers guarding the eastern entrance to the Northwest Passage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) A seven-judge ethics committee appointed by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has advised Federal judges that it is all right for them to teach at law schools or serve as a paid trustee under a relative's will.
Sniper fire injured two policemen who were responding to a report of disorderly conduct by a group of youths on a Harlem street last night.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 (AP) Tom Van Arsdale led a firstquarter spurt as Cincinnati rolled up a 21-point lead and Oscar Robertson netted 17 fourth-quarter points to spark the Royals to a 129-122 National Basketball Association victory today over the Baltimore Bullets.
SANTO DOMINGO Four years of relative political stability and the end of a prolonged drought produced an upturn of the Dominican economy last year.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 25 (UPI) A racquetwaving ruckus broke out today as Cliff Richey, the No. 2 ranked player in the United States, conquered Clark Graebner, the No. 4 man, 6-3, 7-5, in the final round of the Austin Smith tennis tournament.
A $50-million cellulose plant is expected to be built soon in Chile, the Bank of London and South America says.
The new president of Hunter College, Mrs. Jacqueline Grennan Wexler, presided yesterday at commencement exercises at which 450 baccalaureate and 350 master of art degrees were awarded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said today that President Nixon's Supreme Court nominee, G. Harrold Carswell, should be judbed on his record and not be punished for an old speech endorsing white supremacy.
ROME, Jan. 25 (Reuters) The Vatican has refused to grant accreditation to a West German diplomat because she is a woman, a Vatican spokesman said today.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 25 The National Religious party declared tonight that it would resign from the Government coalition unless a law was introduced in Parliament reversing the High Court decision of Friday on the question of who is a Jew.

BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Fred Stanfield's power-play goal early in the third period tonight snapped a 1-1 tie and helped the Boston Bruins score a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 25 (AP) Mike Laughton scored three times today and Gary Smith, the goalie, turned back 42 Minnesota shots as the Oakland Seals beat the North Stars, 4-1.

OSLO, Norway "We're not part of the jet set, the Norwegian shipowner said with a smile. "You mustn't confuse us with the Greeks. Norway is very democratic. If anyone in Oslo drove a Rolls-Royce, he'd be hounded out of society if there is any society."

ROME, Jan. 25 Pope Paul VI, what he called a "moment of great consolation" in this "hour of trubulation for the church and bitterness for us," today proclaimed as a saint a Spanish sister who helped found a religious order.

Miss Ruby Klappholz, a doctoral candidate in comparative literature at the University of Wisconsin, was married yesterday at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn to Dr. Alvin Newman, a research fellow in medicine at the Johns Hopkins University. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, Rabbi Kurt Klappholz of Congregation Tifereth Israel. The bride's parents make their home in Brooklyn.

MEXICO CITY Mexico's economic momentum is reflected in the campaign slogan, "Onward and Upward," coined by Luis Echeverria Alvarez, the virtually unchallenged presidential candidate of the governing Institutional Revolutionary party.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (Reuters) Yevgeny F. Loginov, the Minister of Civil Aviation, said today that Russia is planning to build its own jumbo jets, which would seat from 300 to 500 passengers. He told newsmen that the planes would go into service "in the coming years," but gave no further details.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) Louis E. Wolfson, whose family built a scrap iron business into a multimillion dollar empire, is scheduled to leave jail tomorrow and says "Americans are entitled to know of inequities in our disgraceful penal system."

Former Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo said yesterday that he would not decide whether to run for Congress until the Federal courts had reviewed the Congressional redistricting plan passed last Thursday by the State Legislature.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 (UPI) A brilliant performance by Bernie Parent, the goalie, and scores by Reggie Fleming and Bobby Clarke carried the Philadelphia Flyers to a 2-0 victory today over the St. Louis Blues.

A committee of the American Bar Association made "substantial progress" yesterday toward deciding whether to approve the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court. There were strong indications that the committee would approve President Nixon's choice.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 The first armed policeman at the scene of trouble in the City of Brotherly Love later this year may be a teen-ager.
MORENHOVEN, West Germany Sigurd Krause, a farmer in this small village near Bonn, tossed his head back and snapped: "Farming in West Germany today? It's one hell of a gamble!"
The National Association of Securities Dealers has announced disciplinary actions against two securities firms and four securities salesmen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Have American economists, including many in the Government, become complacent about the once-burning question of the United States balance of international payments? The issue has been raised forcefully by Kenneth N. Davis Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Domestic and International Business. He believes there is a new complacency and
The machine-tool industry, the builders of the machinery that becomes the country's production lines, is in excellent shape, according to an analysis of figures released yesterday in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 Robert Conquest, a leading British authority on Soviet affairs, has warned a Senate subcommittee that the present Soviet leaders are "intellectually third-rate." He cautioned Western policymakers against assuming that the Kremlin would always react in a rational or coherent fashion.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana Guyana, the only Englishspeaking country on the South American mainland, maintained political stability and continued her economic advance in 1969.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation and subsidiaries reported over the weekend gains in sales and net income for both the fourth quarter and the calendar year, with net for the year reaching a record high of more than $165-million. This compared with the previous high of $143-million reported in 1956.

Dr. William J. Ronan, the head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said last night that mass transit should receive public subsidies, but he did not say whether the subsidies should come from state, local or Federal government.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) President Nixon will hold his first formal news conference of the year in the East Room of the White House at 6:30 P.M. Friday, the White House announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Westchester County Board of Legislators voted unanimously today to approve a $50-million contract with New York Medical College as a means to improve county health facilities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The National Committee on Product Safety listed 122 models of color television sets today as extraordinary fire hazards.
NASHVILLE, Jan. 23 For the voters of Tennessee, a coonskin cap symbolized the late Senator Estes Kefauver, and a piece of fried chicken symbolizes John Jay Hooker Jr.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (Reuters) The wives of four United States airmen shot down over North Vietnam visited a military hospital here where wounded North Vietnamese prisoners are treated.

ROME, Jan. 26 A Brazilian Archbishop, noted for his support of social reform and his opposition to his country's military rulers, said today that an audience with Pope Paul VI had given him renewed courage.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Department of Defense expressed satisfaction today with the performance of 246,000 "new standards" men who have entered the armed forces since October, 1966.

A so-called "middle" contract designed to spur Broadway theater production, stem rising operating costs and cut ticket prices has been suggested by the League of New York Theaters to theatrical craft and performer unions as well as guilds.
Interest rates moved higher yesterday as corporations continued to announce new bond issues and investors displayed little enthusiasm for yields already available in the capital markets.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The Supreme Court ruled today that students who lose their draft deferments after turning in their draft cards may challenge their reclassification in court before induction.
SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26 The opposition New Democratic party elected Yoo Chin San as its president today. He succeeds Dr. Yu Chin O, who resigned recently for health reasons.

VIENNA, Jan. 26 Reliable sources in Prague said today that Alexander Dubcek had resigned from the Central Committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party before he left for his new assignment as Ambassador to Turkey yesterday.
Fillmore Hyde, author and editor, who was a former national amateur squash tennis champion, died Sunday at Funchal, Madeira, where he lived. He was 73 years old.
The four-page ad that is part of the cover of Modern Bride magazine is all about a sterling silver flatware brand and starts off with this headline, "From Oneida with love." Rather romantic.

A bank economist who was one of the first to use the term recession in connection with the present business downturn said yesterday that he was worried lest "those who made errors" in overestimating the effects of the passage of the income tax surcharge a year and a half ago make the same kind of mistake again.

MIAMI, Jan. 26 (AP) J.L. Smallman's Laughing Bill won the feature race, a $10,000 seven-furlong event, at Hialeah today, holding off Pilot Knob to score by a neck. Mile's Fancy was third, a length and a half behind the top pair and half a length in front of Tanrackin.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 26 (UPI)--Wally Jones, Bill Cunningham and Jim Washington combined for 78 points tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers defeated the Milwaukee Bucks, 122-103, in a National Basketball Association game.

MANILA, Jan. 26--Angry youths shouting "Marcos puppet" and demanding reforms attacked President Ferdinand E. Marcos with stones and bottles this evening as he emerged from the Congress building with Mrs. Marcos. Both escaped injury.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 26 (AP)--Louis Cofone Jr., who was brought back from New Orleans over the weekend, was presented in Superior Court today and formally arrested on a charge of murder in the strangling of a Wilton housewife.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26--A new research and diagnostic technique in which a bedside atom smasher is used to generate short-life radioactive substances was described here today.
PEKING, Jan. 26 (Agence France-Presse) The elementary school reopened at the Soviet Embassy today.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 26 (AP) At least three persons were killed tonight and scores injured when five cars of a Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad passenger train derailed south of here.

Book publishing, once a stately ocean liner of industry, has been transformed into a jet of corporate flightiness, moving executives and authors from one house to another faster than they ever moved before.
An evaluation handbook being distributed this week at City College lists 37 faculty members as "not recommended," based on class ratings of their performance by students.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 The City of Philadelphia joined the Department of Justice today in defending the Nixon Administration's controversial Philadelphia Plan to increase minority employment in construction projects.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 26 Led by Jeff Petrie's career high of 39 points, Princeton scored a 69-54 victory tonight over Fordham.
The London Stock Exchange was quiet yesterday.
A majority of Americans now support the concept of an allvolunteer army, according to a poll by Louis Harris published in yesterday's New York Post.
AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 26 (Reuters)--Colored mosaic floors dating from the Byzantine era have been discovered in the suburbs of Amman, the Jordanian Directorate of Antiquities has announced.

Representatives of 1,700 striking gravediggers and the operators of 44 metropolitan area cemeteries met with state mediators for four hours yesterday, but made no progress toward ending a strike that has suspended nearly all burials here since Jan. 12.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 26 Prince Butler, 4-year-old son of Adios Butler and Lady Scotland, made his 1970 pacing record 3-for-3 by winning tonight's $5,250, Class A-3 featured mile in 2:03 3/5 at Roosevelt Raceway.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26 (AP) The United States Command reported today increased battle action by both allied and enemy forces in all four military zones of South Vietnam.

BERLIN, Jan. 26--Chancellor Willy Brandt conferred today with the three Western allied commanders of Berlin as East Germany continued for the sixth day its on-again-off-again tactics of harassment on the city's access routes. Mr. Brandt also met with Mayor Klaus Schutz of West Berlin.

Owners of some American League clubs held private strategy talks in San Francisco yesterday, in preparation for today's league meeting at which the fate of the Seattle Pilots should be decided. There are widely divergent views within the league on what ought to be done, and the exchange of ideas before the actual meeting takes place may have a decisive influence on the decision.

The suicide of one prisoner and the attempted suicide of another during the weekend at the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island were under investigation yesterday by City Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath.
Thirty-three witnesses at a public hearing here yesterday, urged the Metropolitan Transportation Authority not to grant new fare raises requested by the managers of the Long Island Rail Road.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP) The judge who presided at tthe Clay Shaw conspiracy trial was acquitted tonight on charges of providing women and sex movies for a stag party.

EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 26 The 530 teachers and 247 staff and maintenance workers of the East Brunswick Township public school system were ordered today by Superior Court Judge David Furman to end their three-day "work-action" walkout and return to their classrooms.

IN any gathering of state legislators, Jerome Kretch met looked somehow out of place, both because of his 6-foot-4-inch height and because of his dress, which never conformed to the apparent tradition that legislators must dress as conservatively as possible, whatever their politics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) William Lambert's article in Life magazine that led to the resignation of Justice Abe Fortas from the Supreme Court has won the American Newspaper Guild's Heywood Broun Award of 1969.

PLAYERS from New York City captured almost all the titles in the American Bridge Association tournament played Saturday and Sunday at the McAlpin Hotel under the auspices of the Henry C. Parker Jr. Club and the Bronx-Westchester Associates.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 26 (AP) President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia tonight accused West Germany, France, Britain and the United States of arming South Africa "to its teeth" to enable it to attack black liberation movements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Supreme Court ruled today that a park established in a segregationist's will in 1911 for the exclusive use of the white citizens of Macon, Ga., could be returned to the donor's heirs in the face of a court order to admit Negroes.

THE STOCK of Walter Kidde Co., Inc., skid- ded to a new low for 19691970 yesterday at 33 and closed at 33 7/8, off 3 1/8. The selling represented a continuation of a toboggan run for the stock on Friday when the shares plunged 6 3/8.

The Metropolitan Opera, besieged by patrons demanding refunds or issuance of tickets for performances lost or rescheduled as a result of the curtailed season, has added an emergency force of 35 workers to its subscription department to handle the crush.
An increasing number of taxi riders, particularly women, are complaining daily to the Police Department's Hack Bureau about abusive and obscene language used by some cab drivers.

Records were set in every phase of operations of the Union Oil Company of California last year, "but acrossthe-board higher costs and unrealistic price competition prevented a comparable rise in earnings," Fred L. Hartley, president, reported from Los Angeles yesterday.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 26--The British liner Oronsay, which sailed into Vancouver Harbor 13 days ago with her colorful cruise banners flying, lay silent alongside Pier B today, yellow quarantine flags telling a grim tale of frustrated medical detectives.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 26 El Salvador and Honduras began peace negotiations here today in an effort to restore normal relations broken since the two countries fought a fiveday war last July.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)--The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended today a Florida brokerage firm and its president for violations of the registration and anti-fraud provisions of the Federal Securities laws.

Professional football achieved yesterday a degree of distinction reserved for Presidential messages to the nation, national conventions, elections and moonshots. Beginning this year, its games will be seen on all three major television networks, American, Columbia and National.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 26 Jordan is studying the possibility of purchasing some arms, particularly antiaircraft guns, from Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said today that his organization would oppose the confirmation of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (UPI) Nate Thurmond, one of the top centers in pro basketball, announced his retirement today at the hospital where he is recuperating from a knee operation.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 26 Some of the best young tennis players in the East went into action today at the Concord Hotel's annual intercollegiate indoor tournament.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 Judge Julius J. Hoffman said today that, as far as he was concerned, Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago was "a good Mayor."

Michael F. Glynn, a lawyer who had served with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and with the New York District Attorney's office, died Sunday night in New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 35-43 84th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Mrs. Virginia H. Knauer, President Nixon's special assistant for consumer affairs, said today that she would meet with officials of the Department of Agriculture to discuss a recommended change in poultry inspection standards.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan.26 A Government science official says that widespread fears of a shortage of jobs for scientists and engineers over the next decade may not be founded, but that many may have to do work they really do not want to do.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Supreme Court denied today a request by Ralph Ginzburg, the publisher, for a review of a $75,000 libel judgment won by Senator Barry Goldwater.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26 Twenty-five students at the Berkeley Divinity School here occupied the seminary chapel today to protest a decision of the board of trustees to merge with a larger theological school.
VIENNA, Jan. 26 A Soviet delegation arrived here tonight for trade talks with neutral Austria.
A number of new executive appointments were announced yesterday in Chicago by Marshall Field Co., that city's largest department-store chain. Field's also owns stores in Seattle and Spokane.
Steel production declined by 1.1 per cent last week, compared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 (AP) Paul Warfield, the Cleveland Browns' star receiver, was traded today to the Miami Dolphins for their top choice in tomorrow's pro football draft.
BEACH HAVEN, N.J., Jan. 26 (AP) John P. Cahill, 19-yearold son of Gov. William T. Cahill, who was arrested on a marijuana charge in Philadelphia on Saturday, also was arrested here last June 26.

At a time when the drug problem among the very young is reaching critical proportions, New York City officials have incredibly demanded the closing of the one facility devoted solely to the rehabilitation of teen-age drug-users.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26--President Nguyen Van Thieu, who was elected in 1967 with only 37 per cent of the vote, proposed tonight that run-off elections be held if no presidential candidate won a majority on the first ballot in future elections.
A suit to compel the Board of Education to redraw the five decentralized school districts proposed for Manhattan was argued yesterday in State Supreme Court.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 26 Premier Golda Meir said tonight that President Nixon's message yesterday on American-Israeli relations was a clear expression of concern for Israel's security and integrity.

BOWIE, Md., Jan. 26--Entete made the first start of her career an auspicious one today as she raced to victory as a 103-1 shot at Bowie Race Course. Ridden by Bill Passmore, the 3-year-old filly won the sixth race on the program, a $4,500 claiming event and returned $208, $88.40 and $25.60 for $2 across the board wager.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 26 (Agence France-Presse) An African member of the Rhodesian Security Forces and three African guerrilla infiltrators have been killed in a new battle in the remote Zambezi Valley, the Government announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The American Medical Association and some of its old adversaries met secretly here three weeks ago to explore proposals for a national health insurance system, it was learned today.

More than 150 men, women and children took over the offices a of the Social Services Department's division of day care, 80 Lafayette Street, for three and a half hours yesterday. They were protesting the lack of progress in talks with the city concerning changes in the guidelines for the operation of day-care centers.

A recent unanimous decision by the Oregon Supreme Court ruled that all dry sand areas of the Pacific seashore in that state are reserved for public use. Thus, some 300 miles of wild and dramatically scenic beach are, in effect, to be preserved in their natural condition forever.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 26 Miss Emily Rutgers Fuller, who is with the department of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, plans to be married on May 16 to John Kingston, who is with Coenen Co., Inc., investment bankers in New York.

NEWARK, Jan. 26 Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio abruptly dismissed Newark's Fire Director, John P. Caufield, today after Mr. Caufield refused to step aside as a potential rival in the city's next mayoral contest.
Squads of policemen pressed a house-to-house search yesterday for the snipers who lured two patrolmen into an ambush in Harlem Sunday night and seriously wounded them.

The Board of Higher Education, in preparation for the open admissions program that goes into effect next September, approved last night the rental of 259,000 square feet of space for City, Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 26 The army was called out today in Hyderabad, 120 miles north of here, after clashes between student groups accompanied by burning and looting in several sections of the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The Army acknowledged today that its Intelligence Command had about 1,000 "agents" across the country who conduct security checks of Army and Government personnel, but it denied that any widespread monitoring of civilian political activity took place.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 Miss Dianne Elizabeth Mullane, who is associated with the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, and James Allan Magee, who is associated with the New York law firm of Donovan, Leisure, Newton Irvine, plan to be married March 21 in New York at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More. Both are graduates of the University of Michigan Law School.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--House and Senate conferees agreed today on a $1.8-billion foreign-aid appropriation for the current fiscal year and set the stage for a vote on the measure before the end of the week.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 26 (AP) Adolph Rupp coached his 1,000th basketball game tonight, and his team gave him an 86-71 victory over Alabama, but it was a tarnished gift.
Two of the country's biggest steel companies reported yesterday that their sales rose to records last year but their earnings advanced only slightly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The House ethics committee proposed today that House members and employes publicly disclose any large indebtedness and sources of sizable fees for speeches.
CHEROKEE, N.C. Jan. 26 The tribal council of the Eastern band of Cherokee Indians has asked the Cherokee chief to resign as leader of the 6,500-member tribe and he has steadfastly refused.

TRENTON, Jan. 26--The new Republican administration of Gov. William T. Cahill and the leaders of the overwhelmingly Republican legislative majorities announced their agreement today on a proposed law that would give the State Attorney General the power to supersede county prosecutors in fighting organized crime and corruption in New Jersey.
WHEN Allen Funt, television's Peeping Tom, bought his $165,000 duplex apartment five years ago, he decided then and there that it wasn't going to be like anybody else's.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 William P. Ellenburg, a retired Detroit police inspector, was appointed Cleveland's police chief today, was sworn in and took office immediately.
About 100 passengers on a New York-to-Stamford train that was stuck for more than an hour in the tunnel under Park Avenue last night refused for a time to surrender their tickets to the conductor.

VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, Jan. 25 Hunched low over their small motorbikes, four Americans in plastic helmets and motorcycle jackets roared down this afternoon from the hill overlooking this beach resort and bounced over the sand to the edge of the sea.

It is still too early for any let-up in the Government's antiinflation campaign, despite evidence that the economy has begun to slow and the contention in some quarters that a recession is already assured, Alfred Hayes, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.

MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 26 Tribesmen in the remote misty mountains here received instructions dropped from planes today on how to vote in the general election tomorrow. The leaflets emphasized the secrecy of the ballot. The election will be the first since Lesotho's independence from Britain in 1966.

TOKYO, Jan. 26--After a heated two-hour discussion, leaders of the ruling Liberal Democratic party today gave the Government their agreement on early signing of the treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons.
Mayor Lindsay, confirming reports that circulated over the weekend, named Assemblyman Jerome Kretchmer yesterday as the new head of the city's Environmental Protection Administration.
B.H. WRAGGE'S clothes are generally destined for sober suburbanites who live in station wagons during the day and dress up for country club evenings. But there are whimsical touches for summer:
In a foreign take-over bid, the Burmah Oil Company announced yesterday that it was offering to acquire LaPorte Intries (Holdings), Inc., for stock valued at about $156-million.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Congress was warned today that a growing imbalance of science teaching and research in relation to the humanities was dividing the nation, de stroying its values and making it impossible to solve society's most serious problems.

MANHASSET, L.I., Jan. 26 The engagement of Miss Diane Carol Kleine, daughter of Mrs. Edwin D. Kleine and the late Mr. Kleine, to Edward John Kuebert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Kuebert of Wantagh, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 New orders received by manufacturers of durable goods one of the key economic indicators declined substantially in December for the third straight month, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Liberal party leadership yesterday scored the new state redistricting law on Congressional districts as of "partisan gerrymandering character designed to give special advantages to the Republican party."

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 26 Streetwalkers have not yet disappeared from Dayton but police enforcement of a threemonth-old unlawful-assembly ordinance has made life so difficult for prostitutes that many have left town.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 President Nguyen Van Thieu said in Saigon a couple of weeks ago that he was compiling a list of arms, materials and funds that he expected to get from the United States as American troops are withdrawn and South Vietnamese forces take over more of the fighting.

Ralph S.Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, suggested yesterday that financial institutions had become the primary audience for some corporate managers, replacing the traditional role of the individual stockholder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 State Department officials said today that France's projected sale of supersonic aircraft to Libya had injected a new sense of urgency into the Nixon Administration's consideration of four-month-old requests from Israel for aid.

President Nixon's veto of the health and education appropriations bill could force a reduction in the city's Head Start and other programs for disadvantaged children, Dr. Nathan Brown, Acting Superintendent of Schools, said last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 "I am afraid," said a Democratic head-counter recently, "that we have enough votes to override."

ALAMOGORDO, N.M., Jan. 26 (UPI)--Gov. David F. Cargo called today for a moratorium on the distribution in the state of mercury-treated grain, which has resulted in the poisoning of three children here.
The Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday plans for the largescale importation of liquefied natural gas from overseas sources into the United States.
Sloppy weather conditions, which have bogged motor and pedestrian traffic all winter, are clogging training schedules for track and field athletes along the east coast.
Schienman, Hochstin Trotta, Inc., the brokerage concern, announced yesterday that it had acquired from McDonnell Co. the management and distributing companies for the McDonnell Fund.

George N. Spitz, former consultant to the Joint Legislative Committee on the Election Law, has proposed that Democrats in Manhattan's 26th Senatorial District join forces in an experiment to demonstrate to the state that campaign costs can be cut.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 27 (UPI) Arthur Ashe of Richmond, Va., became the first Negro to win the Australian open tennis championship today by defeating Dick Crealy of Australia, 6-4, 9-7, 6-2, at White City.

The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that it would comply with a Government subpoena for the news film of the complete program, including portions not shown to the public, on the Black Panther party. The program was seen on Jan. 6 in the series called "60 Minutes."
The men who run the country's public television stations agree that protection of the environment should be the primary subject of educational television programing.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange tumbled sharply yesterday. Losses outnumbered advances by almost a four-toone margin in comparatively quiet trading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (Reuters)--Financial sources said today South Africa has already sold about $40-million worth of newly mined gold to the International Monetary Fund as a result of the continued failure of the free market price to rise above $35 an ounce.

LOOKING back he could see the Temple burning below, burning six million of its priests, he could see them climbing an immense blazing ladder: Jacob was having a bad dream." A dream from which Elie Wiesel has been trying to awake...into what? Into our historical ennui; into a reality paved with political platitudes? "He who says 'I' says everything.

State Senator Roy M. Goodman said yesterday he was introducing a bill in the Legislature that would eliminate the concept of the "guilty party" from the state divorce law and cut the waiting time for divorce in cases of separation from two years to one.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 26 Two crewmen were lost and presumed dead and the captain and two others rescued today after their clam-dredging rig broke loose from its mooring and the 80-foot vessel, the Sewanhaka, capsized in the Atlantic.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 26 A United Nations spokesman today said that Secretary General Thant had "made no assessment of the relief situation whatsoever" during his visit to Nigeria.

Milton Thomas, violist, offered a program of considerable variety last night at Tully Hall. It ranged from 14th-century Italian dances (played unaccompanied) all the way to Henri Lazarof's "Cadence II" for Viola and Tape (1969), a first performance.

What's in a name? If the promoters of the newly formed Stutz Motor Car of America, Inc., are correct, there is enough nostalgia left to attract buyers for their new Blackhawk. The original Blackhawk was a contemporary of the more famour Bearcat model that was part of automotive folklore in the early nineteen-twenties.

Almost exactly 90 per cent of the contracts let by the Department of Defense are non-bid, negotiated contracts which guarantee the contractor a profit over and above costs. The various contractors follow various methods of calculating their costs and, since there is no uniform accounting procedure, there is no effective governmental audit of these contracts.

WIESBADEN, West Germany, Jan. 26 (AP) Preliminary figures show the West German trade surplus in 1969 totaled 15.6 million marks, down from 18.37 million marks in 1968, the Federal Statistics Office reported today.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 26 The European Common Market governments, acting to prevent new outbreaks of the currency turmoil that has plagued them over the last two years, took the first cautious steps today toward a monetary union.
Dr. Peter Lantos has been promoted to vice president of research and development for the Sun Chemical Corporation.

The Norfolk Western Railway the nation's most profitable carrier in transportation operations reported yesterday preliminary consolidated earnings of $87.5-million for 1969. In 1968, net income restated to reflect a rate divisions settlement with other lines, was $76.3-million.
VIENNA, Jan. 26--The existence of a New Left among young intellectuals in Hungary has been brought into the open by a controversy over Ernesto Che Guevara, the revolutionary slain in Bolivia in 1967.

Dr. David Rittenberg, professor of biochemistry at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and chairman of the department from 1958 to 1969, died at his home Saturday. He was 63 years old and lived at 560 Riverside Drive.
