President Nixon's message of reassurance on the Middle East to American Jewish leaders is, like Secretary of State Rogers's December speech, a simple restatement of long-standing American policy. The two statements are perfectly compatible with each other and with the position taken by the previous Administration following the 1967 Arab-Israel war.
Howard J. Samuels, who began putting together a campaign organization 10 months ago, made it official yesterday, by announcing that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Esther Eng, proprietor of Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, who had produced and directed motion pictures in Hong Kong and brought Chinese opera companies to the United States, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 55 years old and lived at 50 Bayard Street.

TOKYO, Jan. 26 Senator Jacob K. Javits warned today that the Japanese faced a possible trade war with the United States and called on their country "to live up to the responsibilities of its economic power and its new political maturity."
Blue-chip and glamour stocks weakened along a broad front yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrial average slipped to its lowest closing since October, 1966.

Norman Singer, general administrator of the City Center of Music and Drama, was named last night by the Board of Higher Education to the newly created post of dean of administration of the City University's Graduate Division. The appointment becomes effective Sept. 1.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 26 A United Nations observer who recently returned from the former Biafran region reported today that the current relief program for refugees there was "obviously not enough."
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico; Jan. 26 Plans for a world championship for harness racing drivers were announced today by the Harness Tracks of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Before a nationwide television audience, President Nixon, with a flourish of his pen, vetoed tonight a $19.7-billion measure containing funds for health, education and antipoverty programs.

CROOKSTON, Minn., Jan. 25 Luverne Hagen of Roseville, Minn., took the first lap today of the 587-mile St. Paul Winter Carnival 500 snowmobile marathon. Of the 221 starters who left Winnipeg, Canada, at 8 A.M. today, 150 finished in the unusually mild temperature which hovered just above zero.

The city asked the United States Supreme Court yesterday to review a recent Department of Justice settlement of an antitrust case that charged the country's automobile industry with suppressing development and installation of devices to reduce exhaust pollution.
President Nixon's expected veto of funds for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare drew minimum immediate reaction from the television networks last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Reuben Mills, winner of the Loser of the Year Award for 1969-70, was in town over the weekend. He had hoped to cash in on his award by making some guest appearances on television, but naturally none of the local TV hosts or hostesses wanted him.

A group of Hunter College students met with the Transit Authority yesterday and persuaded it to give them permission to decorate the 68th Street-Lexington Avenue IRT station in honor of the college's 100th birthday, which is coming in two weeks.

Prime Minister Wilson, on the eve of his first visit to Washington in nearly two years, proposed in a speech here last night "a new special relationship for the nineteen-seventies" between Britain and the United States.
A 34-year-old writer told a Federal court hearing yesterday that she had three abortions between 1960 and 1967 because having an illegitimate child "would have been the end of my life."
Dave DeBusschere raced up and down the gymnasium floor at Garden City, L.I., High School yesterday doing wind sprints. Then he shot baskets with a teammate, Bill Hosket.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26--The New Jersey branch of the American Civil Liberties Union moved today to join Frank Sinatra in his fight against testifying before the state's investigation commission.
A high-ranking official of the Nixon Administration asserted here yesterday that there is no stigma attached to dealings by American businessmen with Communist nations.
World sugar futures, which had been slightly lower last (week, rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
Service on the West Side IRT was disrupted for an hour and a half last night after the cars of a Brooklyn-bound express separated as the train was approaching 14th Street station in Manhattan.

In this period of skyrocketing prices, consumers need all the assistance they can get to make sure they receive maximum value for their shrinking dollar. An ambitious effort of New York City to help in this direction has now been challenged in the courts by a major group of food retailers.

A youth who is the son of a banker and a psychiatrist was ordered held in $100,000 bail here yesterday on charges of impersonating a Federal officer and smuggling hashish into the United States from Puerto Rico.
Paul Tierney's resignation as a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission was accepted yesterday with "particular reluctance" by President Nixon. His resignation become effective Feb. 28.
FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 26 Color the center of Florence blue and the faces of its downtown merchants an angry red.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 Dr. Arthur J. Kraus, who was discharged from the City College faculty in New York 37 years ago and who spent those years in penury while relentlessly seeking exoneration, came to the Capitol today in quest of a pension.
The Boeing Company's directors cut the quarterly dividend yesterday to 10 cents a share from the 30 cents that the company had been paying quarterly.
What does a world-famed sailboat designer want most to see at the National Boat Show? It's not sailboats.

MOVIE audiences have a Ford in their future. If she doesn't end up as another face on the cutting room floor, Henry Ford 2d's elder daughter, Charlotte Ford Niarchos, will appear briefly as an admissions clerk at Mount Sinai Hospital in the Paramount Pictures film, "Love Story."

PARIS, Jan. 26 The scope of the French-Libyan arms deal was widened a bit more today. The fleet of Mirage aircraft that France will deliver to Libya will number "closer to 110 than 100," an official spokesman said in an interview.
The boxer, the slugger and the bleeder emerged as the winners on last nights card at Madison Square Garden.
Senator Charles E. Goodell told the Women's City Club yesterday that the time for rhetoric was past and the need now was for "money muscle" from Washington to meet the nation's urgent domestic needs.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 26 The two sons of Joseph A. Yablonski, murdered leader of an insurgent faction in the United Mine Workers of America, were reported today to be among more than 20 witnesses summoned to appear before a United States grand jury that convenes here tomorrow. The grand jury is to open a new phase of the broadening investigation into the "contract" slaying of the union official and his wife and daughter.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 26 Leopold A Chambliss, a former Newark bank and hospital official, died at Doctors Hospital here Saturday of a heart ailment. He was 73 years old and had lived at 550 Ocean Drive, Key Biscayne, since retiring in 1958.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y. For 13 weeks, 13,000 workers at the huge General Electric plant here have been on strike. For 20 days this month the temperature here has been below freezing. But at Matt's bar and at Angelo's, where the blue-collar workers drink boilermakers, the mood is more relaxed than despairing.
ATLANTA, Jan. 26 (AP) The Georgia Supreme Court unanimously upheld today a provision of the state Constitution that prohibits a Governor from succeeding himself in office.

PARIS, Jan. 26 A public protest has saved the century-old mansions that form a base for the ChampsElysees. Marcel Dassault, the aircraft designer, has scrapped plans for a big concrete office building on his corner of the Rond-Point, a plaza midway along the avenue.

The dancer James Cunningham is like a piece of Silly Putty that can shatter, stretch, bounce or do a variety of other, and at times, contradictory things with movement. He is a superb performer but also indiscriminately intoxicated with theater and theatrical effects, a condition that tends to diffuse his choreographic focus. Last night at the Cubiculo he presented three of his pieces under the collective title "Lions and Roaring Tigers."
Robert A. Morse, an assistant United States Attorney during the Eisenhower Administration, was sworn in yesterday as chief assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York.
SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 26 Daniel Burke, a lawyer and former president of the America Bible Society, died today at his home, 66 Fernwood Road, after a long illness. He was 96 years old.
Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it would provide a smoke-free refuge for nonsmokers in its new 362-passenger Boeing 747 jetliners.

WITH a well-groomed impudence and a cheerful antic wit, a new musical, "The Last Sweet Days of Isaac," arrived at the East Side Playhouse last night for what should be a long stay. It is one of the most preposterous shows in New York and yet also one of the happiest.

A LIKING for salt pork, whether lean or fat, and salt fish, is common among the older residents of seacoast New England. Although their grandchildren seem to prefer frozen pizzas and TV dinners, it gave me, as a middle-aged New Englander, a twinge of nostalgic pleasure to discover on a recent hunting trip to North Carolina's Outer Banks that salt pork figures prominently in many of the old-time recipes there.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 Home mortgages with variable interest rates might be a way to funnel funds into housing, bankers suggested here today.
Scientists in Ohio have identified two chemicals that make the elm tree a tasty treat for the European elm bark beetle, the main spreader of Dutch elm disease.
The members of the Board of Education met yesterday to consider the appointment of an Acting Superintendent of Schools but did not reach a decision.

John H. Young, who was defeated by Representative Adam Clayton Powell by a 3-2 margin in a primary election two years ago, announced yesterday that he would try again in June to win the Democratic nomination for Mr. Powell's Congressional seat.

BONN, Jan. 26 Chemie Grunenthal, the West German pharmaceutical company that developed and sold thalidomide, offered today to pay $27.3-million (100 million marks) in an out-of-court settlement to West German children born with birth defects caused, it is alleged, by their mothers' use of the tranquilizer during pregnancy.
The Giants called Homer Jones's signal for a long gainer yesterday all the way to Cleveland.

BONN, Jan. 26 Chemie Grunenthal, the West German pharmaceutical company that developed and sold thalidomide, offered today to pay $27.3-million (100 million marks) in an out-of-court settlement to West German children born with birth defects caused, it is alleged, by their mothers' use of the tranquilizer during pregnancy.
The Giants called Homer Jones's signal for a long gainer yesterday all the way to Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Some guests couldn't help but have an uneasy feeling that any minute a blue-coated guard was going to tap them on the shoulder and say sternly: "No food allowed in the exhibition rooms of the National Gallery."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) George Romney said today that he had no plans to run for Senator this year. But he declined to rule out the possibility that he or his wife might become a candidate if Michigan Republicans cannot agree on someone else.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Following are excerpts from a statement made today by Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, at a joint Senate-House subcommittee hearing on the Arts and Humanities Act of 1965:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The Supreme Court rejected today without comment a plea by Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida that it reconsider a decision that orders 14 Southern school districts to desegregate by Feb. 1.
Talks aimed at settling the 13-week-old General Electric strike were reported to be approaching a crucial stage yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The new rules for the mortgage auction of the Federal National Mortgage Association apparently had the effect of stabilizing prices, the Association disclosed tonight.

Dr. Edwin H. Colbert, curator of vertebrate paleontology at the American Museum of Natural History, last night received the museum's gold medal for his research in the Antarctic. He was the sixth person to receive the award.

TOKYO, Jan. 27?The Japanese Government has decided to sign the treaty barring the spread of nuclear weapons next Tuesday, Government sources reported today. The Japanese Ambassadors in Washington, London and Moscow are to be instructed to sign the treaty on that day.

William R. Dill, an executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, has been appointed dean of New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration, it was announced yesterday.
For some reason, perhaps to whet the appetites of its true loyalists, the New York City Ballet saves George Balanchine's lovely Mozart ballet, "Divertimento No. 15," for the end of each season.

The New York Knicks stepped back two months last night and recaptured for 48 thrilling minutes the near-perfect form that marked their early 18-game winning streak that set a National Basketball Association record.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 27 The executive vice president of the United States Trotting Association and the chairman of the department of veterinary medicine at Ohio State University reported today the virtual infallibility of pre-race blood tests conducted at two Ohio harness race tracks in 1969 to the delegates to the 16th annual convention of the Harness Tracks of America.

"I STILL occasionally wear white shirts," Milton Musicus said yesterday. "I see from looking around City Hall I better start changing the color of my shirts and widening my ties unless I still want to maintain the aura of Albany."

Terry Bradshaw, a big, blond quarterback from Louisiana Polytechnic Institute, was the first of 442 college football players drafted by the 26 National Football League teams yesterday. The Pittsburgh Steelers chose Bradshaw as the two-day draft began yesterday morning at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.
National Educational Television will launch an eight-part cycle of dramas next month, about a generation questioning its-legacy.

Jim Files is still 26 credits short of a marketing degree at Oklahoma but he is about to venture into the marketplace anyway. His first project is to promote a bonus for a 6-foot-4 -inch, 235-pound linebacker named Jim Files.

BETHPAGE, L.I. Jan. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wilson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Marie Wilson, to Kevin M. McNamee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert McNamee. Both families live here.

CLEVELAND, Jan, 27 The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been aided by a "fourth man" who backed out of a reported murder "contract" in its investigation of the slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter, a source close to the case said today.
The two New York City patrolmen wounded by sniper fire in Harlem on Sunday night were reported to have made "some improvement" yesterday after surgery.
Price increases continued to spread yesterday for important categories of steel products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 In what has become an almost annual rite of British-American friendship, Prime Minister Wilson arrived here amid pomp and ceremony for a round of talks with President Nixon and other Senior United States officials.
PARIS, Jan. 27 Delegates from 26 countries appealed to world opinion today to save the handful of Jews remaining in Iraq, Syria and the United Arab Republic.
ALBANY, Jan. 27 Hoping for a lively debate, if not approval, 26 Assembly Democrats introduced a resolution today urging immediate withdrawal from Vietnam by United States troops.

A major accomplishment of the National Boat Show has been the bringing together of two individuals whose worlds would probably never have crossed so dissimilar are their ideas, their backgrounds and their deeds.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (AP) The surging Los Angeles Lakers, behind Jerry West's 41 points and 13 assists, routed the San Diego Rockets, 124-109, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 27 While Canadian health authorities pursued eforts to track down the carrier of typhoid aboard the liner Oronsay, plans were being made today to disembark between 20 and 30 American passengers aboard. They want to abandon their delayed cruise on the British liner that has been in quarantine here for 14 days.

MANILA, Jan. 27 President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who narrowly escaped injury in last night's riot outside Congress, summoned the chiefs of police and the metropolitan military command to a meeting at the presidential palace this afternoon. He expressed displeasure with police handling of the students in the riot and directed the Police Commissioner to prepare guidelines for preventing violence at future demonstrations.

HONG KONG, Jan. 27 The Chinese Communist authorities have launched a new austerity drive in the country in conjunction with programs for stockpiling food and strategic materials and developing regional self-sufficiency.
Companies that sell merchandise door-to-door had a good year in 1969 and are anticipating even better business in 1970, despite the current economic slowdown.
PARIS, Jan. 27 So many women are grinding their teeth over the new, longer hems in the spring-summer couture collections here that you hear the critics carrying on everywhere.

Four men who competed in a recent National and American Football League championship series are among 15 players named yesterday to tour United States military bases, hospitals and outposts in the far east, including the war zones of South Vietnam.

In what could set a precedent for commercial television broadcasters, the National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it had contracted with the state of Idaho to design, construct and operate an educational television production center. It will be located in Boise, the capital.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 Warning that 250 children between the ages of 14 and 16 years old might die this year from the use of heroin or other drugs, Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea said today he would propose a special program of treatment for teen-age addicts.

"SOMEBODY'S got to take her dancing when she looks like this or else she can milk the cows." Tom Nasarre, the designer for Junior Sophisticates, was talking about the mannequin in the short, bouncy blue plaid dress with the white lace apron and the kerchief on her head.
NEWARK, Jan. 27?A reputed Mafia gambler invoked the Fifth Amendment today in refusing to answer questions asked by a Federal grand jury investigating organized crime.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 28 Six men allegedly associated with Mafia families were indicted today by a Nassau County grand jury investigating organized crime, and District Attorney William Cahn said that six other men being sought as material witnesses had disappeared.
The General Electric Company and its striking unions were reported yesterday to be close to an agreement that could end the 93-day-old strike.
A group calling itself the Emergency Committee for Jewish Burial appealed yesterday for an immediate end to a strike of gravediggers that began Jan. 12.
MIAMI, Jan. 27 (UPI) In a miniskirt Barbara Jo Rubin's legs look just fine, but on a horse her knees give her trouble. Today they forced her into early retirement.

About 700 installers, repairmen and plant workers staged a one-day strike yesterday at the New York Telephone Company's central exchange building, 228 East 56th Street, to protest the suspension of a shop steward. The building serves the midtown area.

Mrs. Suzanne Lipskin Weiss, an active horsewoman and joint district commissioner with Whitelaw Reid of the Purchase Pony Club, died while sleeping Monday afternoon at her home in Purchase, N.Y. She was 34 years old. The cause of death was not known.

St. John's University was cleared by an arbitration panel yesterday of charges of anti-union activity and violations of academic freedom in the first decision in a dispute stemming from the dismissal of 33 faculty members in 1965.
Negotiations for a new contract for the port's commercial towboat and barge industry came to a standstill yesterday following union rejection of a management offer.

President Nixon's dramatic attempt on television to justify his veto of the health, education, welfare and labor appropriations bill failed to make a persuasive case. His over-simplified political appeal served only to obscure the situation with broad generalities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Presidential police force sheepishly saluted Prime Minister Wilson of Britain today in dazzling new operetta-like uniforms ordered by President Nixon and designed by a Washington tailor, Jimmie Muscatello, and the Secret Service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Nixon renewed today his case against the $19.7-billion health, education and antipoverty appropriations bill, citing fresh economic statistics to bolster his arguments and offering a possible compromise.
PARIS The French Government reckons it can court the Arabs with arms as most recently Libya because the very idea of an existing Middle Eastern power balance is outmoded.

Omar Sharif's Circus of European stars and the Dal las Aces, the designated representatives of the United States in the 1970 world championship, resumed play in Los Angeles last night with the Aces holding a slender advantage.

Another chance to keep the Pilots in Seattle for the 1970 baseball season and beyond was put forth by the American League late last night at Berkley, Calif., where owners of the league's 12 clubs kept wrestling with the problem.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 27 (UPI) Bill Keller's two free throws with 8 seconds to play gave the Indiana Pacers an 88-87 American Basketball Association victory over the New Orleans Bucs tonight.
The Citizens Budget Commission elected seven members to its board of trustees yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 27 When a colony of large Norway rats invaded his neighborhood in Arlington, Va., a couple of summers ago, Larry Whitehead and his buddies rooted the rats out of their burrows with sticks, BB guns and smoke.
Prices ended mostly lower in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

BONN, Jan. 27 Foreign Minister Walter Scheel announced today that West Germany was sending State Secretary Egon Bahr, one of its highest officials, to Moscow tomorrow in an attempt to accelerate negotiations on a pact renouncing the use of force.
A controversy over whether the city should provide 200 or 300 new subway cars for the transit system developed yesterday between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and Mayor Lindsay.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The proliferation and popularity of franchise businesses have led to increased fraudulent practices in the field, a Senate subcomittee was told today.
Two cars of a Penn Central passenger train bound for Boston were derailed last night shortly after leaving Penn Station.

Interest rates once again climbed higher yesterday, pushed upward largely by the prospect of still more bonds for sale. The Chrysler Corporation announced plans yester day to sell $150-million of debt securities during the week of March 9. The maturity of the securities was not ...

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 The Soviet Union today urged accept ance of its Middle East peace proposals to prevent what it described as a new and possibly more dangerous war from breaking out between the Israelis and the Arabs.
Former Criminal Court Judge Benjamin H. Schor set a $3,500 price tag on obtaining a liquor license for a Queens tavern, a witness testified at his trial on a perjury charge.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 27 Mr. and Mrs. A. Hamilton Emery 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Emery, to Thomas Francis Darcey of Washington, D.C. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. S.R. Darcey of Bethesda, Md., and Burnt Cabins, Pa.
The New York Mets continued to divide the treasure yesterday. They signed Cleon Jones, the No. 1 batter in their eight-year history, for $50,000 twice what he made last season.
Two medical teams report, after preliminary research, that one injection of a new drug apparently can safely produce abortions in women as late as five months after they become pregnant.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of Milton Musicus, a career civil servant and currently head of the state's billion-dollar health services improvement plan, as Administrator of Municipal Service.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 27 The largest Orthodox rabbinic body in the United States condemned today the decision of Israel's highest court last week that persons who were non-Jews under Jewish religious law could be registered as Jews by nationality.

THE grind of magazine and newspaper journalism takes its toll on the sensitive observer. Renata Adler who came to the profession by the unlikely route of Bryn Mawr, the Sorbonne and Harvard would be the first to say so. Indeed, she does say so in the valedictory, bittersweet essays that serve as introductions to ...

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 27 Mr, and Mrs. Corwith Davis have announced the engagement of Mrs. Davis's daughter, Miss Robin Rosborough, to George Spencer Berger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer M. Berger of Guilford, Conn. The prospective bride is the daughter also of the late Angus Baker Rosborough, who was Florida general agent for the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

GREENPORT, L.I., Jan. 27 Senator Ford, the vaudeville comedian who starred on the "Can You Top This?" radio program in the 1940's, died of cancer of the lung and throat at the Eastern Long Island Hospital here tonight. He was 82.

The director of gynecology and obstetrics at Georgetown University Hospital told a Federal Court hearing yesterday that an abortion, other than to save a mother's life, was "poor biology" and "poor science."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27? Roger S. Firestone, fifth son of the founder of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, died last night after collapsing at his home in nearby Bryn Mawr. He was 57 years old. The cause of death was acute lung congestion.

A chamber orchestra-sized group of lively guests from Argentina made its local debut last night at Tully Hall. The Ensamble Musical de Buenos Aires, formed in 1966, is on the way to becoming a fixture in its home city, and is now venturing on its first United States tour.
George Poplis, a 41-year-old drug addict, was sentenced yesterday to 20 years to life in prison for the fatal beating last March of his 3-year-old stepdaughter, Roxanne Felumero.
LONDON, Jan. 27 Gypsies won their long fight today for the right to official sites on which to station their caravans.
Two of Eddie Cantor's daughters will figure prominently in an Off Broadway musical, "Lyle," opening March 4 at the new McAlpin Rooftop Theater in the McAlpin Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended the registration statement filed in 1968 by the Scientific Research Development Company of Salt Lake City after finding that it contained false statements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 President Nixon has clearly decided to use the power of the Presidency, plus the power of network television, to combat his opponents in the Democrat-controlled Congress and presumably to establish a Republican Congress in November.
Francis H. Schott has been elected vice president and economist for the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the U.S. He succeeds Reynolds J. Nowell, who has retired.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were mostly firm yesterday.

Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has announced the establishment of a new bus service to the upper East and West Sides of Manhattan for the convenience of patrons going home after evening performances at Lincoln Center.

The program at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum last night, entitled "An Evening of New Music from the University of Connecticut," featured resident musicians and composers of the school and offered a couple of lively and welcome surprises, along with long stretches of dry scholasticism.

Combustion Engineering, Inc., took the lead yesterday in 1970 nuclear power-plant orders with the announcement that the Southern California Edison Company had chosen it to supply two 1.1-million kilowatt nuclear steam supply systems.
President Nixon and former Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson and Harry S. Truman were honorary chairmen in absentia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Senate approved today a modified "no knock" statute under which Federal agents could break into a home without warning or identification if they feared narcotics were about to be destroyed inside.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 27 President Nixon's message to American Jewish leaders on Sunday has raised the question among Arab political leaders and some Western diplomats here whether the "evenhanded" Middle Eastern policy laid down by Secretary of State William P. Rogers has now been reversed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The United States Air Force, reluctantly yielding to Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird and the Government of Nigeria, has removed its insignia from heavy cargo aircraft for a relief airlift to Lagos, Pentagon sources said today.
Earnings of the Southern Railway slipped in the fourth quarter of last year to $12.5-million, or $1.73 a share, from the $14.4-million, or $2.03 a share, of the same period of 1968.

The cooking classes have shifted from petit-fours to casseroles and the sewing lessons have abandoned the tucks and folds of the bustle for the mini, but in 100 years the Young Women's Christian Association has never changed as much as it is trying to do today.

Of four major oil companies reporting yesterday for 1969, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Gulf Oil Corporation showed lower earnings while the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Cit ies Service Company made moderately more money than the year before.
A number of factors com bined yesterday to send grain futures tumbling on the Chicago Board of Trade.

ATLANTA, Jan. 22 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission will not have a decision ready on whether to revise the structure for minimum stock brokerage rates for several more months, Commissioner James J. Needham said today.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Jan. 27 (AP) The Army must spell out whether it will try to prove that First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. personally killed Vietnamese civilians. Ordered others to do it, or both, a military judge ruled today.

Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, charged yesterday that his organization and its "case for racial integration" had been ignored in a decision by a Massachusetts church body to grant $1-million to a new organization of black clergymen.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) A high police official testified today that a Cleveland professor hit him and threw a traffic barrier toward a sergeant in street disorders the week of the Democratic National Convention in 1968.

Having added some new people to the staff, the Al Paul Lefton Company of Philadelphia and New York is going out for new business armed with a bold idea. The company is ready to refund up to 20 per cent of its income to a client if agreed-upon sales goals of a campaign are not reached.

The boxing promoters at Madison Square Garden have begun negotiations to import Marcel Cerdan Jr., the son of the middleweight champion who died in an Azores plane crash in 1949, from France for a welterweight bout in May with Donato Paduano of Montreal.
Julius Rudel has been engaged as music director of the Cincinnati May Festival Association for the festivals of 1971 and 1972.
The American-Scottish Foundation won't dine on real Scottish haggis after all the Department of Agriculture turned it back.
MERRICK, L.I. Jan. 27 (UPI) A 20-year-old animal trainer was arrested early today when his male lion cub bit two patrons at a Long Island bar.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 27 (UPI) Arthur Ashe, the first American to capture the Australian tennis championship since 1959, headed for a skiing vacation at Sun Valley, Idaho, today and a well deserved rest.
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, known as 3M, achieved record sales and earnings last year, with fourth-quarter results contributing to the improvement.
Two store divisions of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., anounced yesterday the election of new directors and the realignment of executive committee responsibilities.

As a training orchestra, the National Orchestral Association is not expected to spend its time learning nonrepertory pieces, but at least once a season it tackles a novelty. Last night in Carnegie Hall it tackled two, in one of the more interesting programs of its season.
LONDON, Jan. 27 Frenzied buying broke out today on the London Stock Exchange as unconfirmed reports quickly spread of another huge West Australian nickel strike.

DETROIT, Jan. 27 A National Labor Relations Board examiner denied today a motion by three brokerage firms to dismiss proceedings prompted by a group of rebel stock salesmen, who are seeking to establish a legally constituted bargaining unit.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 27 Latin America is experiencing a boom in subway building likely to cost the nations of the area at least $1-billion during the next decade.
With only four days remaining for voter registration for the community school board election, every effort must be made to reverse the appallingly apathetic showing to date.

The Gouverneur health center, target of increasing demands for community control by Lower East Side residents, operated under heavy police guard yesterday after another in a series of disturbances there.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 27 Israeli police authorities said today that Dick Scott, an American immigrant to Israel who is wanted in California on a drug charge, jumped bail last Thursday and probably had left the country.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 27 Dr. David Djaparidze, a specialist in Slavic philology, and a member of the Prinston University faculty since 1960, died today in his New York City home, 340 Riverside Drive.

LAGOS, Nigerian Jan. 27 The Nigerian Red Cross said today that it was sending more men and equipment into the former Biafran territory to bring a "greater urgency and vigor" to the relief effort there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The House of Representatives approved a $1.8-billion foreign aid appropriation today without debate and sent the measure to the Senate for final legislative action, which is expected tomorrow.
Thousands of subway riders were delayed last evening because of substation power failures on the IRT's Broadway-Seventh Avenue line and the BMT's Broadway line.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, which collects art as well as money, is spreading a little of both around this week. It is sponsoring an art show and sale for the benefit of the fledgling Studio Museum, Harlem's only public art facility.

Citing "the epidemic proliferation of teen-age heroin addicts" here, a subcommittee of the Medical Society of the County of New York last night passed a resolution calling for emergency funds for "separate and adequate treatment facilities" for teen-age addicts.
The ocean container shipping industry was urged yesterday by one of its leaders to put its own house in order.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 Democratic legislative leaders said today that they hoped with the aid of Nassau County Republicans to hold Long Island Rail Road Fares at current levels and eliminate double fares on New York City's transit system.

NEWARK, Jan. 27 Both prosecution and defense lawyers summed up today in Federal Court in the case of Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, reputed Mafia figure, and Daniel (Red) Cecere, who are on trial on conpiracy and extortion charges.
CHICAGO, Jan. 27 "Wow!" said Norman Mailer when he first heard the Yippie strategy for the 1968 Democratic National Convention here.
The New Democratic Coalition has slated 10 regional meetings across the state to hear candidates seeking Democratic nominations for statewide office this year.

PAESTUM, Italy, Jan. 15 When the Lucanians, a tribe of barbarians whom historians have tended to treat as rather pushy hillbillies, took over this busy port city from its Greek founders about 400 B.C., they changed its name from Poseidonia to Paestum.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 (UPI) The San Francisco Warriors dismissed Coach George Lee today and named AI Attles, a guard, as interim playercoach for the remainder of the season.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Dr. Wernher von Braun, a key figure in developing the giant Saturn 5 rocket, which sent men to the moon, will head the United States' planning effort for future space exploration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Gov. Harold LeVander of Minnesota and two members of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy clashed today over Minnesota's asserted, but not established, rights to set more rigid limits on radioactive discharges from nuclear power plants than the Atomic Energy Commission requires.

In selecting Steve Tannen of Florida in the first round of the draft yesterday, the Jets acquired a guitar-playing, clothes-conscious cornerback who loves the idea of playing in New York with Joe Namath.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

TRENTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Three reputed Cosa Nostra figures who were sentenced to jail until they answered the State Commision of Investigation's questions were ordered by the Commission today to begin serving their sentences.

Democrats and Republicans have named candidates for the special election Feb. 17 to fill two vacant Assembly seats one in Queens and the other in the Bronx but the Liberal party is refusing to participate in either.

Profit of the United States Steel Corporation, the world's biggest steel producer, declined 13 per cent last year, although sales and other revenues were the highest in history, the company said yesterday.
GREENVILLE, S.C., Jan. 27 Gov. Robert E. McNair, contrasting sharply with other Governors from the Deep South, said today that he would comply with court orders to desegregate schools.

The Bohack Corporation, a New York supermarket chain, announced yesterday a twoway corporate move involving an investment of $1-million by Eugene Ferkauf, founder of the Korvette discount stores and the purchase by Bohack of a chain of small discount stores in which Mr. Ferkauf has a substantial interest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The gradual inprovement in the nation's trade position continued in December, the Commerce Department reported today.
GENEVA, Jan. 27 The Swiss announced today that a shipment of aircraft parts found aboard an El Al airliner during a stopover in Geneva on Saturday had been seized as "war materiel."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Commerce Department announced today that it would guarantee loans of more than $82-million for the two largest tankers in the American flag fleet, to be built by Seatrain Lines, Inc., at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.
Since last summer a leading economist, a monetarist, has been forecasting a recession this year. Recently he addressed a Detroit civic group.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The United Association of Plumbers and Pipefitters agreed today to place 500 minority members in line for high-paying journeymen jobs in areas where there is a labor shortage.
Sig Rosner pointed to his 17year-old daughter, Hela, who was sitting on the floor of the crowded living room of his Canarsie home, and asked her in front of Mayor Lindsay and 50 civic leaders:
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 27 The National Electoral Tribunal banned all further political rallies in this national capital today, to avoid violence before next Sunday's national elections.
A two-week extension in the voter registration period for the city's local school board elections a period now scheduled to end Saturday was recommended to Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday raised the quarterly dividend to $1.20 a share, payable March 10 to holders of record Feb. 11. It was the third cash increase since the stock was split two-for-one in May, 1968.
Sharp differences were expressed yesterday over whether the city should regulate commercial and business rents.

"I believe the two sexes are not going to get along well to the degree that men become passive and women become more competitive with men," he said in an interview at his home here. "That's what's wrong with unisex, even if it is becoming more fashionable."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The Commerce Department, in a special economic forecast of its own which may or may not prove different from the Nixon Administration's predicted today that the year 1970 "will not be a comfortable one."

Jesse Gray, the Harlem rent strike leader, announced yesterday that he would enter the Democratic primary against Adam Clayton Powell, who has held the seat in Manhattan's 18th Congressional District since 1944.

William Styron, author of the 1967 Pulitzer Prize novel, "The Confessions of Nat Turner," yesterday charged that the filming of the book, which has been temporarily postponed, was being influenced by "black pressure groups" who opposed his treatment of the historic leader of a slave rebellion.

I return herewith, without my approval, H.R. 13111, an act, "making appropriations for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare and related agencies for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1970, and for other purposes."

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that starting Feb. 2 its stock price index will be reported in numbers rather than in dollars and cents. It said that the continuity of the system would not be affected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The United States used a Cambodian sect dedicated to the overthrow of the legitimate government of Cambodia on covert missions into that country in 1967, according to testimony at the trial of a Green Beret captain convicted in 1968 of killing one of the members of the sect.
WATSONVILLE, Calif., Jan. 27 Miss Sharon Sachiko Yagi, a social worker with the Stanislaus County Welfare Department in Modesto, ...
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 27 Pat Iovine was not at Roosevelt Raceway this morning. Nor was he there tonight.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 27 The Suffolk County Legislature authorized the County Executive today to acquire Suffolk Air Force Base and to seek enabling legislation in Albany for the county to set up an agency to run the field.

"Sesame Street" a brisk, rib-tickling television program that is designed to improve the the language, numerical and reasoning skills of preschool children, particularly those fro poor families appears to be achieving many of its goals.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 27 (AP) A high-speed train rounding a curve just outside Alexandria overturned its last five cars over a steep, muddy embankment early today, killing three women and injuring 41 other passengers.

WHAT a nice drama critic like me was doing at a show like "Joy" at first mildly puzzled me. The show, or whatever you want to call it, opened last night at the New Theater. It is only fair to say who needs to cliff-hang? that at last "Joy" won me over. But not at first.
Opponents of air pollution picketed a department store yesterday to protest a toy plastic truck, about a foot long, that emits smoke from its exhaust pipe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 Mayor Joseph L. Alioto won an important procedural victory today in his $12.5-million libel suit against Look magazine; which said in an article published last September that the Mayor was "enmeshed in a web of alliances with at least six leaders of la Cosa Nostra."

The city housing official most directly responsible for carrying out Mayor Lindsay's emergency procedures to restore heat to freezing apartments quit his post quietly the day after the Mayor declared the state of emergency.
Lester B. Pearson, chairman of a special World Bank study committee, warned last year that the faltering performance of foreign assistance donors was creating a "crisis" in international development.
Lacy Kux, a limited partner of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Hirsch Co., died of a heart attack Monday at his home, 54 Washington Mews. He was 73 years old.
Once in the 1920's Dr. Lewis Perry picked up three hitchhikers on his way from Exeter to Boston and the riders took turns guessing his occupation.
FOR more than half of his 37-year tenure as director of the Millrose Games, the always enthusiastic Fred Schmertz has dreamed of producing a Wanamaker Mile with a clocking under four minutes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 27 (AP) President Nixon, Vice President Agnew and five Cabinet members will meet here Feb. 5 with a bipartisan group of about 10 Mayors to discuss city problems, Mayor Richard G. Lugar announced today.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation announced today major cutbacks in automobile production for February.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn said yesterday he would seek the convening of a three-judge constitutional court to rule on the use of peace symbols in conjunction with the American Flag.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 27 Dr. Lewis Perry, who built Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire into a major preparatory school in 32 years as its principal, died here yesterday in a nursing home. He was 93 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 Judge G. Harrold Carswell denied today allegations that his participation in the formation of a private golf club in Tallahassee in 1956 was part of an effort to prevent desegregation of the municipal facilities that the private club took over.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 27 Senator Ralph W. Yarborough, Democrat of Texas, announced for re-election today. He pledged that, before doing any campaigning, he would do what he could to get Congress to override President Nixon's veto of the health and education appropriation bill.

LONDON, Jan. 27 Active purchases by Communist China in world metal markets have contributed to heavy volume and soaring prices on the London metal exchange. But dealers are divided in their interpretation of the buying spree.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Overseas National Airways asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to dismiss a petition for an enforcement action filed against it by the board's enforcement bureau last Friday.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reported yesterday lower quarterly and 12-month earnings despite record sales in 1969. The company attributed the earnings decline to higher costs, lower selling prices, particularly in textile fibers, and the cooling off of the country's economy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 A collection of 19th and 20th century art objects to be housed in the M.H. de Young memorial museum here has been presented to this city by Tullah Hanley, a Hungarianborn former dancer whose husband, the late Thomas Edward Hanley, was a Pennsylvania oil and gas heir.
Joe Paterno of Penn State received the New York Football Writers Association coach-of-the-year award yesterday for the second straight time in ceremonies at the New York University Club.

A foul odor in the air caused hundreds of residents of Manhattan, the Bronx and western Queens to phone the police, Consolidated Edison and city and state agencies last night in an attempt to learn what the smell was.
Stock prices continued to slide yesterday, again carrying leading market indicators to their lowest levels since October, 1966, when the bear market of 1966 bottomed out.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (AP) The withdrawal of 50,000 more American troops will begin tomorrow with 3,000 marines from 19 units leaving over a five-day period, the United States Command announced today.
A New York University chemist has found that a common air pollutant and food additive is capable of changing the chemicals that comprise hereditary material.

PARIS, Jan. 27 Premier Jacques Chaban-Delmas declared today that the Mirage aircraft sold to Libya had been meant solely to defend that country's territory and that if any of the jets appeared on the Arab-Israeli fighting front, remaining deliveries would be embargoed.
Frank Murphy, who has an eye for pretty Irish lasses, has never met Bernadette Devlin. But before Murphy departs Dublin later this week, he may wish he had.

MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP) Herbert Allen's Distinctive, unable to win a race last year, scored his second straight victory of 1970 at Hialeah Park today as he outran Outspan, a 21-to-1 shot, to win by 1 lengths. Outspan was 1 lengths in front of Spiral Staircase. In his previous start here, Distinctive won by 13 lengths.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 Howard J. Samuels, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, suggested today that the state impose a surtax similar to the one the Federal Government is abandoning, but limit it to corporation profits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27(AP) In a two-year period, while the United States committed extensive sums for the war in Vietnam, South Vietnam collected $28-million to $34-million in taxes from the United States Government.
MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 27 Pony trains stood by tonight to deliver the vote in Lesotho's first general election since independence from Britain in 1966.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 27 Army lost to Providence in hockey, 3-2, today in a suddendeath overtime as the cadets could not get a shot on goal in the extra period.

HONG KONG, Jan. 27 (Reuters) Anna Louise Strong, the American author who has lived in China for almost 12 years, says she will soon stop putting out her Peking newsletter because she is 84 and "the writing grows ever harder."
A perennial City Hall revenue proposal legalized off-track betting in New York City made a new appearance in the political paddock yesterday under the approving eye of Mayor Lindsay.

IT was Thomas Scherman's idea to present two English one-act operas closely associated in time and place, and so last night in Philharmonic Hall he and his Little Orchestra Society put on Ralph Vaughan Williams's "Riders to the Sea" and Gustav Holst's "At the Boar's Head."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) A. Ernest Fitzgerald, the Pentagon efficiency expert who lost his job after telling Congress about pyramiding costs of the C-5A cargo jet, was hired today by a businessman's organization to crusade against wasteful military spending.

Patrolman Patrick Dolan has received a letter of congratulations from President Nixon for his successful fight to continue wearing an American flag pin on his police uniform, just above his row of five citations for heroism.

YONKERS, Jan. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Einhorn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie K. Einhorn, to Frank M. Werner. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules H. Werner of Malverne, L.I.A wedding in the spring is planned.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., showed a decline in net income for 1969 despite the fact that operating revenues topped the $1billion level for the first time in any calendar year. The giant utility first reported $1-billion or more in revenues for the 12 months ended last June 30.

A Federal judge denied a motion yesterday by Jane L. Alpert, one of three persons facing trial on charges of bombing office buildings here last year, to suppress as evidence package of tear gas cartridges, a box of bullets and three passports seized in her apartment last Nov. 14.
JOHN M. HARTWELL, whose mutual funds took a beating with the rest of the performance funds in the 1969 bear market, is about to reverse himself again.
ALSDORF, West Germany, Jan. 27 (AP) A criminal court today held open the possibility of ending the thalidomide trial through a $27.3-million settlement out of court.
William Howard Schuman, looking too contented to be confused with Napoleon on Elba or Lyndon Johnson on the LBJ Ranch, sounded a bit smug about his new life.
The professional football draft, a grab bag of potential talent, is usually accompanied by brisk trading.

EVERY morning during the icy spells the parkways and expressways are cluttered with cars that have skidded into other cars, light poles and retaining walls. No fun there. But there are any number of cheerful maniacs who enjoy driving on ice indeed, racing on ice.

The R.C.A. Corporation and the Magnavox Company, two of the major television set makers accused of making color models with "extraordinary fire hazards," took measures yesterday to correct such problems.

A new committee structure more closely attuned to the organization of the city administration was approved yesterday for the City Council. It included a new Public Safety Committee responsible for crime and narcotics legislation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 The dramatic story of one of the greatest struggles in the long career of William McChesney Martin Jr. as Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board has been placed on the public record a few days before Mr. Martin is to retire and be replaced by Arthur F. Burns.

No one knows how many thousands of New York families have been broken up because the husband earned so little that he decided his wife and children would be better off on welfare. The one thing experts do agree on is that the number is large. They also agree that New York's experience is not unique. Every other large city has seen its welfare rolls grow through what is wryly called "fiscal abandonment."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 More than 1,000 Federal vehicles will be converted this year to burn natural gas in a system that cuts noxious exhaust emissions by about 80 per cent, Government officials told Congress today.
Pan American World Airways will start its second Boeing 747 route on Feb. 7 with daily flights between Kennedy International Airport and San Juan, P.R., except Tuesdays and Wednesdays.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 27 The United States has assured Arab governments that President Nixon's message to American Jewish leaders Sunday did not in any way invalidate the American proposals for a Middle Eastern settlement that had been advanced during recent Big Four and Big Two talks, diplomatic sources here said today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 Through a many-faceted program to involve the black community in construction and operation of the world's largest atom smasher, leaders of the project believe they are demonstrating that an enterprise devoted to basic research can also serve as a social force.
Leading chain stores and catalogue houses staged a moderate recovery in their lagging sales last month. Volume improved sufficiently for them to achieve a 12.2 per cent rise over December of 1968.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors, and officers of listed companies. The reports include the following:
ANNAPOLIS, Md. Jan. 28 (UPI) Charlie Yelverton scored 19 points and John Zanzelari added 16 tonight as Fordham handed Navy its 13th loss in 15 games this season with a 75-63 victory.
Howard J. Samuels interrupted his campaigning for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday to be with his 17-year-old son, who has been charged with possessing marijuana.

THE world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot Tigran Petrosian, the grandmaster from whom he wrested the crown last year, matched skills again during the last days of 1969.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 G. Harrold Carswell completed his testimony today before the Senate Judiciary Committee, having apparently satisfied a majority of its members that his nomination to the Supreme Court should be approved.
ALBANY, Jan. 28 Man was declared the victor over the machine today, two years and thousands of votes after electronic voting boards were installed in the Legislature to flash out each member's vote.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Jan. 28 (Agence France-Presse) A three-day meeting of leaders of East and Central African states ended here today with a call for increased aid to black liberation movements.
Last December French spokesmen both here and in Paris indignantly denied a New York Times report that France was selling 50 Mirage fighter planes to Libya.

SAO TOME, Jan. 25 Proud red and green Portuguese banners have been planted on the main square by the sea to mark the fifth centennial of the discovery of this palm-strewn equatorial island by Portuguese navigators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Mayor Lindsay, who put together a new political coalition to win re-election last November, urged House members from New York City today to form new alliances with Congressmen from other areas to expand Federal programs for the cities.

PRINCETON continues to list its best tall basket ball player this way: John Hummer, senior, forward, 6 feet 7 inches, from Arlington, Va. The name, the class, the position and the hometown are correct. But don't bet that Hummer is only 6-7. Pete Carril, his coach, said.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP) American officials said today that two United States Government agents were infiltrated into the Saigon press corps but were withdrawn after their identity had been exposed.
Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan announced yesterday that he would make a preliminary proposal for reorganization of R. Hoe Co., makers of printing presses and saws, next Thursday.
"All budgets are political documents," Mayor Lindsay told newsmen last week, and his observation offers an insight into the anguished, recrimination-filled annual recurrence of the city's budget gap.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The State Department formed 13 task forces today to revitalize the diplomatic service and to reassert leadership in the formation of foreign policy, which has become diffused among many departments since World War II.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 28 A new Congressional proposal to ban further oil development in the slick-plagued Santa Barbara Channel was advanced today as citizens ceremonially observed the first anniversary of their great oil well blowout.

Secretary John A. Volpe of the Department of Transportation said yesterday that his staff was drafting preliminary ideas for a "national transportation trust fund" potentially a multibillion-dollar pool of Federal aid to assist virtually all modes of public transportation.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 Seventeen years and nine months after a bloody clash between policemen and a rampaging May Day mob among the wide lawns and gnarled pine trees of the Imperial Palace Plaza, the Tokyo District Court today handed down a verdict partly upholding the prosecution's main charge rioting.

The Extrudo Film Corporation, an affiliate of the Enjay Chemical Company, announced yesterday it would raise prices by one to two cents a pound across the board for polyethylene film, effective Jan. 30.
Rabbi Samuel D. Soskin, who two decades ago came from Fort Worth, Tex., to become spiritual leader of Temple Beth Emeth of Flatbush died Tuesday night at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. His age was 63.

Futures prices of Maine potatoes, which had risen on Tuesday after dropping for some time, held firm yesterday. This was true particularly in the May contract, the most active month, with 1,624 contracts traded out of the day's total of 1,875.
For City Hall's "invisible man," Thomas J. Cuite; who uses the power levers ever so quietly, today's mood is one of "here we go again."

LONDON, Jan. 28 British (women won a long-sought victory today when the Government introduced legislation requiring equal pay for equal work by the end of 1975. Employers protested that their wage bill would increase by 5 per cent, or $2.4-billion.
THE play of a hand often focuses on the potential of a particular suit. A case in point is the spade suit on the diagramed deal, reported by Wellington Sun from a team game in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
Three reputed underworld figures were questioned yesterday by a special Federal grand jury investigating organized criminal activities in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Executive Committee of the United States Conference of Mayors accused the Nixon Administration tonight of departing from the "moral commitments of two decades" in its recent cutback of ongoing urban renewal projects.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 28 Leaders of Orthodox Judaism called on the New York Legislature today to repeal the socalled Blaine Amendment in the State Consitution, which prohibits aid to religiously sponsored schools.

PARIS, Jan. 28 An unconfirmed French News Agency report from Moscow said today the Soviet Union has introduced a transferable ruble, a reform long sought by Eastern European countries to restructure trade in the Comecon bloc.
Lipa M. Rutenberg, a former Russian Jewish revolutionary and Soviet trade representative here, died last Thursday in Moscow, according to Soviet press reports. He was 76 years old.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Treasury offered today a choice of three securities with interest rates ranging from 8 to 8 per cent to holders of $5.6-billion of bonds maturing in February and March.
