Blyth Co., one of the nation's leading investment banking houses, was acquired yesterday by the I.N.A. Corporation, an insurance holding concern, for $55-million in I.N.A. convertible preferred stock. The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that it was moving to dispose of its long-standing 36 per cent interest in the General Cable Corporation.

Paul H. Smart of Noroton, Conn., a 79-year-old Star Class luminary who still races and only Tuesday was reelected chairman of the United States Olympic Yachting Committee, was the principal figure of the principal event associated with, but not part of, the National Boat Show yesterday.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 (AP) Japan's Nissan Motor Company, the Toyo Kogyo Company and the Ford Motor Company today established a joint venture to manufacture and market automatic transmissions for cars in Japan, informed sources said.

THE Danny Thomas special, "Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow," was an expensive if traditional vaudeville show with the accent largely on yesterday. Bob Hope and Juliet Prowse appeared in an old chestnut about a romance that had gone on for 16 years, and the inevitable sketch about the generation gap, with the Thomas TV family, suffered from the same antiquity.

CAIRO, Jan. 28 Israeli fighter-bombers attacked targets as close as six miles from the center of Cairo today. The United Arab Republic Government asserted that three civilians were killed and 12 wounded.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved yesterday the fare increases requested by the state-owned Long Island Rail Road.
If the quality of the Jets' new rookies is anything like the caliber of their college majors, the team's defensive backfield problems may be ended.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 28 (AP) Four American players were ousted today in the Benson and Hedges open tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Nixon Administration's long search for a new director of Selective Service appeared today to be at an end.

Negotiators for the General Electric Company and its striking unions sought yesterday to reach a consensus of contract language and conclude an agreement that would settle the 94-day-old walkout of 133,000 workers.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 28 The Government refused today to give a visa to Arthur Ashe, the American Negro tennis player, to play in the South African open championships.
The Seaboard Coast Line Railroad reported yesterday that its earnings climbed last year by 185 per cent to $38,485,000, or $4.25 a share, from $13,464,000, or $1.49 a share in 1968.

IXTEPEC, Mexico, Jan. 28 (UPI) Twenty escaped convicts and four law enforcement officials were killed today during a five-hour gun battle in the badlands 310 miles southeast of Mexico City, the Defense Department announced. Another 20 convicts survived and fled.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The State Department said today there was "urgent need for scrupulous restoration" of the United Nations cease-fire in the Middle East by both Israel and the Arab states.

WASHINGTON, Jan 28 (AP) "President Nixon's State of the Union Message is fuzzy, misleading and in some instances patently inaccurate," a co-chairman of the Democratic Policy Council's Committee on National Priorities declared today.
Former Brooklyn Criminal Court Judge Benjamin Schor took the stand in his own defense yesterday to repeat, under a new oath, the testimony on which perjury charges against him were based.

The recital given by Elly Ameling at Alice Tully Hall last night was her first in New York, but it will surely not be the last, for she proved that when her voice and temperament are put to the service of a song that suits both equally well the results can be captivating.

ROME, Jan. 28 The Italian Chamber of Deputies, its members weary and red-eyed after a 66-hour parliamentary session, completed action this morning on a controversial bill to give broad legislative and administrative powers to 14 new regional parliaments and governments at least two of them with Communist majorities.
MONTREAL, Jan. 28 (UPI) Two goals by Bobby Rousseau led the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-4 National Hockey League victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

FRANKFURT, Jan. 28 (Reuters) The West German central bank said today that West Germany's liquid monetary reserves rose by 872 million marks (approximately $235.44-million) to 21.49 billion marks (approximately $5.80-billion) in the week to Jan. 23. (The mark was quoted at 27.13 today).

Two major bodies of Reform Judaism in the United States asked the Israeli Government yesterday to resist attempts by a "vocal minority" to overturn last week's decision by Israel's high court permitting citizens to register as Jewish by nationality rather than by religion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Plans to double the combat strength of the South Vietnamese Air Force in less than two years were disclosed today by Robert S. Seamans Jr., the United States Secretary of the Air Force.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 Two federally subsidized shipping companies were indicted here today for violations of the Federal Corrupt Practices Act in contributing money to political campaigns of House and Senate members.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Book publishers claimed complete license under Supreme Court standards, and the United States Catholic Conference called for a halt to the "smut flood" in testimony this morning before a House subcommittee considering antiobscenity legislation. But the highlight of the hearing was Jack Valenti explaining the Motion Picture Association code.
"Everybodys trying to fish for the bottom of this market," a Wall Street broker declared yesterday as both blue-chip and glamour stocks displayed weakness.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP) The United States command today denied charges that unfavorable news reports were censored by the Armed Forces Vietnam Network.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 A report of intense gravity waves apparently coming from the core of the Milky Way is so contrary to physical theory and present knowledge of the universe that theorists have found it hard to believe.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 28 A 24-day strike of city employes took a militant turn today as more than 1,000 strikers and sympathizers marched on City Hall and demanded a settlement.
Martin Meyerson, president of the State University of New York at Buffalo, was appointed president of the University of Pennsylvania yesterday.
Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, the brokerage concern, announced yesterday that it had completed arrangements to acquire the investment advisory business of Moody's Investors Services.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 28 Golf professionals who discovered there were no funds available to pay them when they finished the $100,000 Michigan Classic last September have now been fully reimbursed by their own organization.
The police were seeking clues yesterday in the holdup slaying of the Rev. Franklin Diggs, who was found dead in his apartment Tuesday at 191 Willoughby Street in Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 Judge Julius J. Hoffman barred Ramsey Clark, the former United States Attorney General, from testifying today as a witness for the defense in the Chicago conspiracy trial.

No one would say exactly how many there were, but about one out of every 10 men at last night's Diamond Ball at the Plaza was there for reasons totally unrelated to dining, dancing or worthy causes, in this case the Institute of International Education.
COCONUT GROVE, Fla. In 1963, when Zev Bufman, an Israeli-born producer, leased the Coconut Grove Playhouse in this Miami suburb, he was the inheritor of failure.
TOKYO, Jan. 28 (AP) The General Electric Company has asked for additional components and parts from Hitachi, Ltd., and the Tokyo Shibaura Electric Company, Toshiba, the Japanese companies said today.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 28 Westchester commuters are turning to politics in their continued fight against deteriorating service on Penn Central trains.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation achieved new highs in sales and earnings in 1969, Donald C. Burnham, chairman, reported yesterday. Sales and revenues for the final quarter of 1969 also topped 1968 levels.
Three big steel companies reported yesterday that their earnings declined last year, but, like most of the steel industry, they also reported record sales and other revenues for 1969.
ATHENS, Jan. 28?Sources in the military-backed government vigorously denied today that the drive to increase trade with Communist nations implied any political alienation from the West.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Several Egyptian soldiers were executed the other day because they had performed badly in combat against Israeli raiders. News dispatches said the purpose was to make an example of them.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 28 (AP) At a news conference today prior to competing in exhibition matches with the United States Davis Cup team here, Mr. Ashe said he was surprised at South Africa's refusal of the visa.
Bishop Odd Hagen, president of the World Methodist Council since 1966, died yesterday after a short illness, according to word received from Stockholm. He was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Senate approved unanimously today a bill designed to produce an intensified Federal attack on illicit narcotics traffic and use, while also reducing penalties for lesser drug violations.

WASHINGTON Jan. 28 It is a good thing that neither the Bill of Rights nor the Magna Carta is the pending business of the Senate these days. If either were to be presented to the world's greatest deliberative body, in its present mood of political panic and myopia, it would undoubtedly be voted down as a needless restraint in the war on crime.

TORONTO, Jan. 28 (Canadian Press) Humberto Trottman, a Panama-born boxer who lives in New York, was disqualified and his purse was suspended here last night after he had struck the referee, Sammy Luftspring, during a match with a Toronto fighter, Clyde Gray.
DUBLIN, Jan. 28 (AP) Gerald Sweetman, Finance Minister of Ireland in the nineteen-forties and nineteen-fifties, was killed today in an automobile accident. He was 61 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, said today that the American arts picture was brighter under President Nixon than it had ever been, with the Chief Executive, the national legislature and the average citizen displaying a surge of enthusiasm for culture.

ISLE, Minn., Jan. 28 The St. Paul winter carnival's 587-mile international snowmobile race lost its chance for a foreign winner today as Dan Oberg of Sweden and Talevi Vekhonen of Finland both blew their Ski-Doo engines.

MARTIN MEYERSON is fond of recalling the facetious comment of a Yale president that Harvard is "so outstanding because it is in a miserable metropolitan area and thus has more delinquency for its sociologists to study, more crime for its lawyers, more disease for its medical...

ALBANY, Jan. 28 Republicans in both houses of the Legislature defeated today a Democratic attempt to eliminate double fares on the city's transit system and to head off a fare increase on the Long Island Rail Road.

The 12-year-old daughter of a wealthy East Side psychiatrist was found yesterday morning in an Upper West Side apartment building, still drugged from a narcotics binge that began when she ran away from home Monday.
Three men were convicted of murder yesterday in the holdup-slaying in November, 1967, of two brothers in their Bronx real estate office.

There were three first-prizewinning conductors on the podium during last night's Gala Concert that wound up the Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition. That is usual in this prestigious contest. They had been chosen from a field of 30 contenders in trials held here this month. Each carried off a gold medal, $5,000 in cash and an appointment as an assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic for next season.

PRAGUE, Jan. 28--Oldrich Cernik, one of the leaders of the 1968 liberal reform movement in Czechoslovakia, was ousted as Premier today and replaced by Lubomir Strougal, a conservative. Dr. Strougal, a 45-year-old party official, has been a driving force in the purge of liberals. He is regarded as a rival to Dr. Gustav Husak, the party leader.

PAULINE TRIGERE, the fashion designer, collects turtles. Eleanor Perry, the screen writer, collects ladybugs. Charles Croft, the proprietor of Leah's Antiques, collects frogs. None of these animals are real, of course, although some of them are remarkably lifelike.

LONDON, Jan. 28 Several derelict buildings in a rundown part of London are being converted to create what is described as Britain's first Black House for black cultural and business activities. The $600,000 project is being financed in large part by a rich young white man.

THERE are times when I think I can stand any- thing in the theater except toothache and pretensions. In fact--without wishing to tempt fate--I think I might be able to withstand toothache. But pretensions, such as those shown with such bland effrontery by Dore Schary's play "Brightower" at the John Golden Theater last night, these are difficult to accept.
A nun was robbed of $40 yesterday by a narcotics addict who lunged at her with an 11inch knife in a Bronx church while a mass was being celebrated.
The American Stock Exchange ended lower yesterday, in moderate trading as increased selling pressure in the afternoon erased most of the earlier gains.
The Rockefeller administration sought court action yesterday to expedite the installation of jet-engine devices that would eliminate the bulk of smoke pollution caused by jet airliners.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (UPI) A two-engine TAG Airlines plane to Detroit with nine persons aboard crashed into icecovered Lake Erie today. The Coast Guard said there were no survivors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Government reported today a 2 per cent rise in the wholesale prices of processed foods this month, indicating further inflation for American consumers.
The Department of Health has sent instructions to all city elementary and secondary schools on what to do if a pregnant student goes into labor or gives birth while in school.

NEWARK, Jan. 28 Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, a reputed Mafia chieftain, and Daniel (Red) Cecere were found guilty tonight of trying to collect payment of extortionate loans from the late Louis B. Saperstein.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 28 (UPI) The 53-year-old chairman of the Rockland County Liberal party yesterday admitted that he had used marijuana "some 10 to 12 times" in the last 10 years and called for its legalization.

The Treasury'a three new note issues, offered yesterday in the Government's refinancing of $6.66-billion of maturing bonds, quickly rose to a slight premium. Dealers generally described the notes as highly attractive, and most predicted that relatively few of the two maturing bond issues would be turned in for cash instead of the new notes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 One way to get invited to the White House as a member of Congress is to side with President Nixon on a roll-call vote on a major issue.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (AP) Emile Griffith, a five-time world champion, hammered out a unanimous 10-round decision tonight over Doyle Baird in a middleweight fight at the Cleveland Arena.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 There was more ceremony than tension in President Nixon's first veto contest with Congress, and he prevailed today by an even larger margin than his aides had expected.
The nation's electric power production rose 12.5 per cent in the week ended Jan. 24 from the level in the corresponding 1969 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 28 The United States accelerated its relief airlift for Biafran refugees today with the arrival here of two huge cargo planes carrying trucks, blankets and generators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 By an unexpectedly large margin, the House of Representatives upheld today President Nixon's veto of a $19.7-billion appropriations bill for health, education and antipoverty programs.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 28 (UPI) Lou Dampier sank one of three free throws with two seconds remaining tonight to give the Kentucky Colonels a 108-107 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets before 5,228 fans at Island Garden.
The automobile industry has told the oil industry that lead will have to be eliminated as an additive to gasoline to reduce air pollution, the chairman of a major oil company said here yesterday.

The family of Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav author imprisoned on charges of insulting the Soviet Union and deriding his government, reported yesterday that he had been told he would be released on March 4, almost a year before his sentence expires.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, Jan. 29 (Reuters) British troops were on a full alert here early today after a fifth night of demonstrations by Protestant extremists.
Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials signed a contract yesterday to buy 240 airconditioned, high-speed subway cars.
Two policemen shot and killed a Bronx man last night after he allegedly shot at them, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration is considering a requirement that drug manufacturers furnish warnings of possible health hazards directly to women using oral contraceptives, an F.D.A. official said today.
After playing a half of slowdown, St. Francis decided to play a half of regular ball against Manhattan last night, but the Jaspers won, 82-43, on St. Francis's home court, the 69th Regiment Armory.
With all the talk about higher commission rates for the small investor, the M.I. Pers have virtually been ignored. Yet their numbers are at record levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 A House District subcommittee approved today anticrime legislation that would create a new Superior Court in Washington and give it jurisdiction over all local cases, both civil and criminal.

TRENTON, Jan. 28 Two of New Jersey's reputed Mafia racketeers and an alleged enforcer for the mob were jailed for indefinite terms today for refusing to testify before the State Commission of Investigation, and one of them said he had changed his mind and now was willing to give testimony.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) Here is the 226-191 vote by which the House sustained today President Nixon's veto of the $19.7-billion Health, Education and Welfare and Labor Departments appropriations bill. The vote was 52 short of the twothirds needed to override.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Democratic Senators on a committee investigating smog-free cars accused the Nixon Administration today of dawdling on antipollution efforts.
WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 28 Good Chase developed a cough this morning and the pacer was withdrawn from Saturday night's $12,500 junior free-forall one-mile handicap event at Roosevelt Raceway.

UNION CITY, N.J., Jan. 28 Bernard Korn, a retired Union City fire chief who was known for his long-distance swims, died yesterday in Englewood Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 809 New York Avenue here.
The High School Principals Association, in urging their members to suspend the daily Pledge of Allegiance and flag salute, has done little to bring reason to bear on a confused issue.
Up on the 18th floor of the New York Coliseum, the walls are covered by pictures of giants. Young Roosevelt Brown Young Frank Gifford, Old Y.A. Tittle.

MILAN, Italy, Jan. 28 (Reuters Philip Blaiberg, the South African heart transplant patient, led a double life with his new heart, appearing officially in excellent health but spending much of his time in bed or in the hospital fighting for survival, his widow was quoted as saying in an interview published here.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 28 A rail-crossing crash about 25 miles from here today killed 30 schoolchildren and injured 30, three seriously.

An Internal Revenue Service special agent attached to the Intelligence Division in White Plains was arrested yesterday on charges of having accepted $4,000 in bribes from three reputed Mafia figures in Westchester.

A leading economist predicted yesterday that the Federal Reserve will "soon" start to relax its tight rein on credit and that higher stock prices and some lower interest rates will be among the results.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Mr. and Mrs. Scott George of Washington and Tokyo, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Margaret George, to Dr. Paul Leon Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. B.I. Kaufman of New York. An April wedding is planned.
VANCOUVER, Jan. 28 One hundred and fifty-four Australians and New Zealanders from the cruise ship Oronsay left Vanecuver by charter flight tonight for their homelands.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP) Villanova lost all but 2 points of an 11-point lead in the final six minutes, but the Wildcats handed third-ranked St. Bonaventure its first defeat of the season, 64-62, tonight at the Villanova fieldhouse.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28- Prime Minister Wilson of Britain participated in an extraordinary session of President Nixon's National Security Council today, exchanging views on the roles of London

Despite improved earnings in the final quarter, the General Dynamics Corporation and subsidiaries ended 1969 with a net income of $2,531,000, or 24 cents a common share, down from the $29,756,000, or $2.83, earned the year before, it was reported yesterday. The 1968 net was before an extraordinary gain of $8,927,000, or 85 cents a common share.

PARIS, Jan. 28 The newest looking accessories turning up at the Paris spring-summer haute couture collections this week are not on the models but down in the audience on the wrist of a New Yorker. They are the rope bracelets being worn by a young fashion editor who has already been asked half a dozen times where she found them. The answer is at Bonniers on Madison Avenue.
DETROIT, Jan. 28 The Ford Motor Company will cut its February car production by 20 per cent with a series of plant closings it was announced today.
HARTFORD, Jan. 28 The 18year-old son of Elisha C. Freedman, City Manager here, was arrested at his home yesterday for selling what was believed to be LSD to an undercover police agent.
THE International Gamefisherman, a monthly newsletter for those interested in big game angling and fishing tournaments, was born a few months ago in Miami.
The long-expected, muchawaited news came out yesterday SSC is acquiring 49 per cent of Lintas, the international advertising agency network, from Unilever.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (UPI) Gary Dornhoeffer's goal six minutes into the last period gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 2-2 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 A young former Tennessean who has been identified as a key police informer in a plot to kill Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter testified today before a Federal grand jury.

The net result of two days of deliberation in Berkeley, Calif., about the future of the American League's l2th franchise was another nine-day extension to enable Seattle interests to raise the money needed to keep the Pilots there.

DETROIT, Jan. 28 Herman L. Weckler, a leading figure in the automobile industry for nearly half a century, who rose to be second in command of Chrysler Corporation died yesterday in Detroit's Grace Hospital. Mr. Weckler, who entered the hospital Sunday was 81 years old.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I, Jan. 28 Dr. John A. McCabe, a surgeon who was formerly director of surgery at the St. Catherine's and Greenpoint Hospitals in Brooklyn, died today at Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre. He was 74 years old and lived here.
BERLIN, Jan. 28 The East Germans ended their slowdown of border controls on the highway to Berlin early this morning.

The smashing of a Mafiadominated, interstate ring that stole more than $5-million worth of Cadillacs. Lincolns and other luxury cars in three years was announced yesterday by the Brooklyn District Attorney, Eugene Gold. He said 21 persons, including three, women, have been arrested.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 28 A panel of three Federal judges sought to determine today whether the Black Muslim organization constituted a religion or a foreign nation.
Long Island Rail Road commuters singing at the station while waiting for late trains in the morning?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Savings withdrawals at savings and loan associations in December exceeded receipts by $383-million, contrasted with an excess of receipts of $178million in the 1968 month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 Paul M. Cuenin, executive vice president of International Operations for the Gillette Company, died of a heart attack Monday in Frankfurt, Germany, a spokesman for the company said here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Supreme Court flatly rejected today a plea by Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. of Florida that it set national standards for school desegregation.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm yesterday Australian nickel issues again were the most active sector.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 28 Miss Caroline Walker Metcalf and Peter Martin Saylor plan to be married in April.
Dr. Bernard Lewis Grossman, a specialist in neuroradiology, died of a heart attack Tuesday in his home at 275 Hoym Street, Fort Lee, N.J. He was 38 years old.

Two top rent-control lawyers at the Housing and Development Administration have stepped down from their posts because they were making lower salaries than some of their subordinates, sources within the agency said yesterday.

The slowdown in trading in the stock market has cost New York City more than $14million so far this fiscal year a year in which the city figured to be hard-pressed even if its income forecasts held up.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 28 Support for President Nixon's Vietnam policies is holding firm, the Gallup Poll reported today.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Jan. 28 Miss Barbara Stewart Sanderson and Martin Alexander Kruming will be married here April 25.
LONDON, Jan. 28 (UPI) The Stock Exchange Council warned investors today against excessive speculation in various Australian nickel shares.
The City Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday mailed its final guidelines for regulation of unit pricing to food retailer associations and some large chains.
A capacity crowd of 21,000 was at Madison Square Garden last night to see performers ranging in style from East Harlem to Las Vegas in a benefit for the Vietnam Moratorium Committee.

Ralph Blomeley, president of Blomeley Engineering Corporation, died yesterday at Richmond Memorial Hospital, Princess Bay, S. I. He was 73 years old and lived at 4927 Arthur Kill Road, Richmond Valley, S.I.

Some of the sounds that fill El Avram, the Israeli nightclub on Sheridan Square, are, as might be expected, the old, traditional sounds of the eastern Mediterranean the lively, sparkling rhythms of the bouzouki or the keening cry of the oud. But the source of those sounds is not at all what might be expected.

"Inquest," a new version of the play by Donald Freed about the Rosenberg trial in the nineteen-fifties, when the couple were charged with conspiracy to commit espionage, found guilty and executed, will be brought to Broadway on April 16.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 28 (UPI) Don Smith scored 7 of Milwaukee's first 10 points in the fourth quarter to break open a close National Basketball Association game and lead the Bucks to a 126-114 victory tonight over the Cincinnati Royals.

BELLPORT, L.I., Jan. 28 The Bellport School Board has suspended eight black students for being involved in fights with students and teachers at the high school here, which was reopened today after being closed for a week and a half because of racial disorders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 President Nixon's new budget is expected to trim the Administration's earlier spending plans for the supersonic transport plane and force another, possibly critical delay in production of two prototype aircraft.

John Carlos and Willie Davenport, Olympic track medal ists with sketchy football backgrounds, were included in the dragnet, yesterday as professional football concluded its annual draft of 442 college players.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 (AP) United States troops searching through a huge enemy arms cache in the jungles northwest of Saigon uncovered, two and a half tons of arms and nearly 250,000 rounds of ammunition American headquarters said today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 In a wild finish that precipitated a 15-minute debate over the validity of a goal by the Los Angeles Kings as the final buzzer sounded, the New York Rangers incurred a hectic 5-4 loss tonight before 7,762 confused spectators.
CURRAN W. HARVEY, a stocky, brown-eyed 41year-old with a piercing gaze, runs one of the most unusual mutual funds in the industry.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 Israeli Government leaders decided tonight to introduce legislation reversing a recent Supreme Court ruling on the question of "who is a Jew."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) A consultant for the Justice Department says the current pattern of electric utility mergers, if left unchecked, will result in power industry giants impossible to regulate.
In a 4-to-0 decision, the Appellate Division refused yesterday to remove State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh as the presiding judge at the, conspiracy trial of 16 Black Panthers.
SIX GIRLS have been named to represent the United States in the Federation Internationale de Ski world championships at Val Gardena, Italy, starting on Feb. 7.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Senate today sent to President Nixon a $1.8billion foreign aid appropriations bill containing one of the lowest allotments ever for the program.
Six swastikas were painted on walls and doors of a Bronx synagogue early yesterday and a tablet was set afire before the vandals escaped.

McLEAN, Va., Jan. 28 Mrs. Joanne Field Langdon, a greatgreat-granddaughter of Marshall Field, founder of the Chicago department store, was married here last Friday to John Pirovano, who attended Harvard with her brother, Marshall Field 5th, publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times and The Chicago Daily News.
COS COB, Conn. The next time your baby sitter gives you advice take it. Mrs. Scott Bartlett did, and now she has a flourishing catering establishment in this Greenwich suburb with the peculiar name.
OMAHA, Jan. 28 State Senator Edward F. Danner, the only Negro member of the Nebraska Legislature collapsed Monday on a downtown street here and died shortly afterward. He was 69 years old.

EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 28 In the face of threatened contempt of Superior Court charges, the 530 public school teachers and 247 other school system employes here decided to return to their jobs tomorrow.
Kevin P. McGovern, a Brooklyn lawyer, announced his candidacy yesterday for the Conservative party nomination for the Senate seat held now by Charles E. Goodell.

MIAMI, Jan. 28 (AP) Stephen A. Calder's Office queen, a strong favorite in a 16-horse field of 3-year old fillies, ran away with the $35,400 Mimosa Stakes at Hialeah today, scoring by eight lengths over the Briardale Farm's Devilish Angel, a 36-to-1 shot, before a crowd of 17,096.

BROOKVILLE, L.I, Jan. 28 The engagement of Miss Marilyn Hayes to Ronald C. Barr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Barr of Delray Beach, Fla., and Brookville, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Clifford Hayes.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (UPI) A Superior Court judge entered a plea of not guilty today on behalf of Charles Manson in the murder of Sharon Tate and six others. His trial was set for Feb. 9.

The Federal Reserve, despite a growing body of opinion that it ought to modify somewhat its severe tight-credit policy, has not yet taken any substantial steps to do so, according to the weekly banking data published yesterday.
SWANTON, Vt., Jan. 29 (UPI) Flames spurred by high winds destroyed 12 buildings on five blocks of the business district today in this town on the Canadian border.
Earnings reports issued yesterday by large oil companies continued to follow the mixed trend indicated in reports previously issued by other companies.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 29 A student demonstration forced a shutdown of the five-story administration building at the University of California campus here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Red Skelton played the White House tonight, and President and Mrs. Nixon were "at home." The occasion was the first in a series of "Evenings at the White House," in which, every month or six weeks, the Nixons will invite famous entertainers to perform for an audience of invited guests.
RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 29 Greg Hill scored 24 points to lead American International College to a 58-52 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson tonight.

DETROIT, Jan. 29 The General Motors Corporation's fourth-quarter profits, $510-million, or $1.78 a share, fell 14 per cent from the $596-million, or $2.06 a share the year before, and were the lowest fourth-quarter G.M. profits since 1964.
Big corporations continued to announce major financing programs, and bond prices continued to skid yesterday.
Steady pressure on blue-chip stocks drove the Dow-Jones industrial average down 10.49 points yesterday to a final reading of 748.35.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped to their lowest level in six months yesterday as the list continued to decline in comparatively quiet trading.

BUFFALO, Jan. 29 (AP) A husband and wife filed a $1million suit in Federal court today against a drug manufacturer, contending the company's oral contraceptive pill caused various ailments, including a blood clot on a lung, to the wife.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 29 (UPI) The nuclear submarine Nathanael Greene, inching through Charleston Harbor in a dense fog, ran aground on a sandbar today under the lee of Fort Sumter, and it took tugboats seven hours to get her afloat again.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Is the idea of an individual's having a single, lifelong career outmoded?
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone This small West African country is hoping that it is over the worst of its newnation growing pains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The first public accounting of the Justice Department's wiretap activities against organized crime, made public today, shows that electronic eavesdropping under the Nixon Administration's law-and-order regime has been limited and restrained.
COTONOU, Dahomey After another 12 months of political instability and social unrest, Dahomey's serious economic problems are no nearer a solution.
ALGIERS Political stability at home has enabled President Houari Boumedienne's regime to continue laying the foundations of a modern economy, with the emphasis on oil and other industries.
J. Curtis Counts, Federal mediation chief, announced last night that a basis for agreement had been reached between the General Electric Company and the striking electrical unions.

THE chain reaction really started last week when the Chicago Bears made a move that totally surprised the professional football folks. The experts had figured the upcoming draft of collegians with their usual unerring accuracy. The Pittsburgh Steelers would exercise their first choice by picking Terry Bradshaw, the marvelous Louisiana Tech quarterback. The Bears, selecting second, were a cinch to go for Mike Phipps, the Purdue quarterback, to solve their manifold problems in that position.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe rode through snarled rush-hour traffic today in a car equipped with radarcontrolled brakes that are applied automatically to prevent collisions.
IN the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

Leopards never change their spots and the species from Lafayette ran true to form by losing, 75-72, to New York University last night at the University Heights gym for their 10th setback in 15 games this season.

The engagement of Miss Joya Utermohlen to Lieut. Robert Darrah Jenks, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Meylan Jenks of Wilton, Conn., and the late Edward North Jenks, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Theodoor Utermohlen of New York.
SOME 10 years have gone by since the wind of independence swept Africa and focused world attention on the problems of the continent's development.

LONDON, Jan. 29 Capt. Sir Basil Liddell Hart, one of the world's leading military writers and thinkers, whose basic ideas on tank warfare were adopted by the German Army in its 1940 blitzkrieg through France, died today at his home in Marlow, Buckinghamshire. He was 74 years old.

PARIS, Jan. 29 France's Radical Socialist party, once a powerful force on the left but now decrepit and conservative, sought today to revitalize itself and to revolutionize the French political scene with an audacious program of economic and social reform.

Perry B. Duryea Jr., Speaker of the Assembly, and Assemblyman Stephen C. Hansen of Manhattan, both Republicans, announced yesterday they would introduce a bill requiring the screening of all candidates for the State Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 A premature release of President Nixon's Economic Report to Congress disclosed tonight that his new budget would total $200.8-billion.
CHAPPELL, Neb., Jan. 29 (UPI) Duane Earl Pope was sentenced today to die in Nebraska's electric chair for the murders of three persons in a bank robbery in Big Springs in 1965.
BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Militants stormed a building at Northeastern University, where S.I. Hayakawa, San Francisco State College president, was speaking tonight, broke windows and shouted obscenities.
PEKING There are signs that the mass sports movement may be on its way back in Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 William McChesney Martin Jr. will preside tomorrow over his last meeting of the Federal Reserve Board after almost 19 years as Chairman of the body that governs the nation's central bank and makes the nation's monetary policy.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 29 Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, the Nigerian leader, promised today that his Government would conduct "nothing like Nuremberg trials" of the leaders of the Biafran secession.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 29 Jack Nicklaus made it look easy today by carding a 7-under-par 65 that gave him the first-round lead by a stroke in the $150,000 Andy Williams-San Diego open tourney. The 30-year-old Ohioan laughed when asked if he might repeat his victory of a year ago with spectacular golf during the next three days.
KAMPALA, Uganda Although political matters are uncertain, economic prospects for this East African country have been brightened for the 1970's by a strong recovery last year in production and trade.
TUNIS Two major events affected the economy of Tunisia and indeed the lives of her 4.7 million people in 1969: The SeptemberOctober floods and a major shift in agricultural policy.

Jean-Louis Barrault, an outstanding figure in the Frenchtheater, is bringing his production, "Rabelais," to the City Center Theater for an engagement of 16 performances beginning May 19 and ending May 31.
PARIS, Jan. 29 Viscountess do Noailles, one of Paris's most celebrated hostesses and a patron of the avant-garde arts since the nineteen-twenties, died here today of an embolism. Her age was 67.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 29 President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic flew secretly to Moscow last week for four days of talks with the Soviet leaders, according to information reaching here from diplomatic sources in Cairo.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 A Syrian MIG-21 swept low over Haifa today, shattering dozens of windows in the Mediterranean port city.
The Bethelehem Steel Corporation announced seven appointments in steel operations and sales yesterday.
BRAZZAVILLE, the Congo Unsettled political conditions continue to hamper economic development in the Congo.
ACCRA, Ghana "Kafu dide" is an expression in Twi, one of Ghana's languages, that means "the debtor still must eat."
Dr. Andrew A. Eggston, a pathologist and hematologist, died Monday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived at 120 Elmsmere Road, Mount Vernon, N.Y.

The Public Service Commission is less far advanced in its consideration of other utility rate cases of extreme importance to millions of New Yorkers, chief among them Consolidated Edison's plea for a rise of $117 million in electricity bills.

PARIS, Jan. 29 Coco Chanel, who let the nineteensixties slide by without changing her style one whit, strode right back into fashion today. The elderly couturiere probably did not even know she was ever out of it. After all, for Chanel there is only Chanel.

Mayor Lindsay plans to allocate $3-million in the 1970-71 capital budget to "neighborhood stabilization" programs in six areas with a total population of about 600,000, according to reliable City Hall reports.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia Efforts to speed development in this still largely feudalistic land were encouraged last year by good harvests that have increased prospects for a needed rise in exports in 1970.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the Hartford Fire Insurance Company and three of Hartford Fire's stockholders have filed suit in Superior Court in Hartford, Conn., to set aside the recent order of the Connecticut Insurance Commissioner barring the $15-billion acquisition of Hartford Fire by I.T.T.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 Bobby G. Seale returned to the Chicago conspiracy trial today and finally got a chance to speak out at length.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 29 (AP) Henry Ransom posted a two-under par 70 on the 6,800-yard National Country Club course today to take a one-stroke lead in the 72-hole $40,000 Ford Professional Golfers' Association seniors championship.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia Africa is entering the seventies with the kind of hope that follows a long siege of disaster the conviction that since things have gone so badly they are bound to get better.

Mrs. John H. Pyle of Pasadena, Calif., and Fred W. Fairman Jr. of New York have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frederica Fairman, to John Irwin Marshall 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill. The wedding will take place in August.

TRIPOLI, Libya Brisk and efficient plans for economic and social development of this underdeveloped country, which struck it rich with oil in the 1960's, came to an abrupt halt last September 1, when a group of army officers in their 20's deposed the government of King Idris.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 29 A Federal court jury concluded here today that the United Mine Workers of America had conspired to "unreasonably restrain trade" in the coal industry.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 29 Bill Dawkins rolled the money through his fingers this morning at Roosevelt Raceway. He had scored with a 100-to-1 shot, named Efficient. He drove the pacer to a $215.60 payoff last night in the ninth race to set up the largest exacta in metropolitan harness racing history $1,282,60.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 29 (AP) A series of snow avalanches swept down on the Amoz Maraz highway in the Elburz Mountains 50 miles northeast of here yesterday, burying about 100 vehicles, Iranian officials said.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan.29 A group of 15 Americans, the first cleared by Canadian health authorities, disembarked from the typhoidquarantined cruise liner Oronsay today, generally cheerful after their 14-day confinement in Vancouver harbor. Some, however, criticized Canadian authorities for delaying their release so long.
NEWARK, Jan. 29 Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, who is under Federal indictment on charges of extortion and income tax evasion, formally declared himself a candidate for re-election today.

Miss Laurie Marie Bullot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Bullot of Rye, N.Y., was married here yesterday to David Kittredge Levington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham J. Levington of New York and Beverly Hills, Calif. Criminal Court Judge Frederick L. Strong performed the ceremony in his chambers.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Jan. 29, (Reuters) Mrs. Philip Blaiberg, widow of the heart transplant patient, denied today that her husband had lived a double lift after his operation.
Teachers walkouts and threatened boycott of classrooms continued yesterday to plague plague the public school systems of a number of New Jersey communities.

Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Mendelson of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Florence Mendelson, to Dr. Michael Charles Gelfand. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Harold Gelfand of New York. A wedding in the spring is planned.

Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and Julie Heldman of New York remained 1, 2 in the recommended national rankings announced yesterday by the United States Lawn Tennis Association Women's Ranking Committee.

MONROVIA, Liberia Reduced debt burdens and higher output of iron ore and rubber in 1969 have made prospects for this West African republic the brightest, relatively, that they have been in many years.
Sandy Koufax was named "Baseball Athlete of the Decade" yesterday in a poll of sports writers and broadcasters taken by The Associated Press.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 29 Princeton's basketball co-captains, John Hummer and Jeff Petrie, scored a total of 42 points tonight to lead the Tigers to a 79-58 Ivy League victory over Cornell. The triumph was the Tigers' 10th against six losses, while Cornell lost for the 10th time in 14 contests.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 29 William Judson Holloway Sr., eighth governor of Oklahoma, died yesterday after being stricken in downtown Oklahoma City near his law office. He was 81 years old.

The much-abused riders on all the mass transit lines in the metropolitan area are on the verge of open rebellion. The latest affront is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's order for higher fares on the Long Island Rail Road, effective tomorrow an order so certain to stir additional outrage that the Long Island trainmen are threatening to strike unless they get police protection.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 29 Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Brown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Brown, to James David McNitt 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McNitt of Greenwich, Conn. A wedding in June is planned.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Nixon has set a political ceiling of 5.3 per cent on the national unemployment rate this year, Senator Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, said today.
A dozen Mets, led by Casey Stengel, attended a premiere of the team's annual film yesterday. And for the first time in eight years, it had a happy ending.
Despite a fourth-quarter drop of 58.4 per cent, earnings of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation last year increased 24.1 per cent over 1968.
For 12 years Ernest H. Nelson nursed a grudge against his employer, the REA Express, and according to the police yesterday, he worked it off stealing from shipments entrusted to the company.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 29 Two hundred students blocked access to this city's main pier overnight in a sitdown demonstration protesting oil operations in the Santa Barbara channel.
LOME, Togo In this small West African country, women run most of the businesses, while for men the chief form of steady employment is government jobs that pay more in prestige than money.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 29 Mr. and Mrs. William A. Boeger Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Benton Boeger, to William Neville Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Lyle Smith of Oklahoma City.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia Rhodesia has gone from a very bad agricultural season to a very good one and seems likely to have increased its gross national product by at least 7 per cent over the last year.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29 (UPI) George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that busing was not the correct method for overcoming the problems of segregation in schools.

A man suspected of being a Fagin who employed boys from 11 to 15 years of age who were arrested Tuesday for selling heroin in Coney Island, was taken into custody yesterday and charged with criminal possession of dangerous drugs for sale.
LAGOS, Nigeria Put to the test of a brutal and destructive civil war, the economic structure and promise of the Nigerian nation appear to have emerged almost unscathed.
NAIROBI, Kenya For the 10.8 million Kenyans enumerated in a population census last August, 1969 was, economically, a year of truth.
LISBON A major hydroelectric project now under construction in western Mozambique is expected to provide enough cheap electric power for the development of much of southern Africa during the 1970's.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 29 (UPI) Roger Brown scored 34 points tonight and led the Indiana Pacers to a 127-123 American Basketball Association victory over Los Angeles.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Jan. 30 United States fighter-bombers attacked an antiaircraft missile base 90 miles inside North Vietnam on Wednesday after an unarmed American reconnaissance plane was fired upon by missiles, the American command announced here early today.
YAOUNDE, Cameroon One of Africa's "quiet countries," the Federal Republic of Cameroon completed a decade of independence last year with two major achievements to its credit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Intercity truck tonnage and freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Jan. 24 were both below the corresponding week last year.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 29 Francis Wadsworth James Sr., who retired in 1967 from his management consulting firm at 267 Fifth Avenue, New York, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 135 Leroy Avenue here.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 Still smoldering over the disputed last-second goal that provided the Los Angeles Kings with a 5-4 victory last night, Emile Francis, the general manager and coach of the New York Rangers, contended today that an improper red goal-light system existed in The Forum.
Ralph Doubell can't take a copy of Lawrence Durrell's "Justine" back to Australia with him, but the customs officials have nothing against track trophies.
Richard E. Landau, a young lawyer in a Manhattan firm, was selected yesterday as winner of the $250,000 superprize in the New York State Lottery.

New York, N.Y. (Special) Today, grateful thousands are hailing TONEL, the unique laxative pill that helps make elimination more regular, thorough, comfortable! And without undue strain, irritation, or weakening after-effects.
The New York Stock Exchange has renewed its opposition to any form of public ownership of member firms that would preclude their close supervision by the exchange.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) Bobby Orr, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, registered a goal and three assists tonight and Phil Esposito added two goals as the Boston Bruins posted a 6-5 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.
BOSTON, Jan. 29 Harvard University is under a legislative threat of having its stadium taken by eminent domain for the Boston Patriots.

John W. Gardner, chairman of the National Urban Coalition, announced yesterday the expansion to 22 cities of a broadcast-oriented project designed to make the institutions of government more responsive to citizens' complaints.

Although they took a decisive lead early in the second period, the New York Knickerbockers rode to victory over the Detroit Pistons last night in Madison Square Garden on the strength of a 40-point third quarter that led to a 127-106 triumph.

To be able to take home after the game a printed record of the deals with an expert commentary on them is an attraction to most club duplicate players. This service is sometimes provided by the organizers of special events, such as the NassauSuffolk Bridge Association's charity game tonight in aid of the American Contract Bridge League's Charity Foundation.

LONDON, Jan. 29 The renewal of sectarian strife in Northern Ireland evoked deep pessimism in London today and prompted restrictive measures in Belfast.
STANLEY HERMAN sent hemlines tumbling down at Mr. Mort yesterday, and the world didn't come to an end. In fact, the long dresses looked pretty. The short dresses looked pretty, too.
Happiness to a National Boat Show exhibitor is keeping the great location he had last year and the year before that and the year before that. It's security and prestige rolled into one.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) The Soviet Union has sent a collection of 162 icons to London for sale at auction Feb. 25.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) A hitherto little-known experimental drug called BCNU is proving to be "one of the most promising" of the new anticancer weapons developed by a Government testing program, the National Cancer Institute said today.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 The Israeli Cabinet today reversed the intent of the recent highcourt ruling that would allow a person to register himself as a Jew without meeting Orthodox Jewish criteria for acceptance as one.

DENVER, Jan. 29 The wife of a Colorado legislator was recovering today from a concussion and more than 100 knife wounds from an unknown attacker who was apparently reacting to her husband's role in a racial controversy.

PARIS The successive visits to Washington of Prime Minister Wilson, President Pompidou and Chancellor Brandt reflect renewed U.S. interest in Europe and the growing concern of Europe with itself. Almost unobtrusively a change has come about in both goals and methods of superpowers and powers. This change is bound to be reflected in President Nixon's conversations.
Marion Harper Jr., founder and deposed head of the world's largest ad agency combine, is back in the busi ness.

To gain an insight into the complexities of economic development as they appear to Africans, a panel of four experts on Africa was brought together last month for a tape-recorded discussion in Accra, Ghana.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Negotiators for the nation's railroads and four shopcraft unions broke off a series of contract talks today. A nationwide rail shutdown by Monday appeared possible.
THE hardy, ubiquitous crow, beloved by few, is the target of many shotgunners in winter when the hunting season is closed in most areas on all game birds.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended Wednesday in thousands of pounds follows:

PHOENIX Ariz., Jan. 29 (AP) Connie Hawkins scored 15 of his 24 points in the fourth period to lead the Phoenix Suns to a 111-102 National Basketball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

Perjury charges against former Brooklyn Criminal Court Judge Benjamin Schor went to the jury yesterday after three days of testimony before Justice Thomas S. Agresta in the criminal section of the Queens Supreme Court.

A man who the police said had been loud and boisterous was charged yesterday with setting a fire in his apartment that forced 16 families to flee from their homes and resulted in the treatment of three firemen for smoke inhalation.

Trading in soybeans and wheat futures settled into a relatively tight range and most dealings were on a local or commercial basis on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Except for soybean oil, public participation was light in most commodities.
CAIRO Despite the strains and costs of sharpening warfare with Israel, the economy of the United Arab Republic showed resilience and achievement in 1969.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI) Phil Goyette, the Western Division's leading scorer, tallied two goals tonight, including the decider with 10:47 remaining to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 3-2 triumph over the Los Angeles Kings. Goyette now has 20 goals for the season and 55 points, fourth best over all in the National Hockey League.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 29 Robert P. Casey, the state auditor general, was endorsed today for the governorship by the Pennsylvania Democratic organization.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 29 The Indian Government, in an effort to avert the self-immolation of a Sikh leader, awarded the city of Chandigarh to Punjab State today, but sought to appease the rival claimant, Haryana State, by giving it a fertile and prosperous piece of Punjab territory.
IT IS A SAD BUT incontrovertible fact that one cannot buy mutual funds mindlessly and expect to profit over the short term.
LUSAKA, Zambia "The way we have been going in the past five years shows clearly that the majority of us have decided to make Zambia a nation of paupers or beggers."

TRENTON, Jan. 29 Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that New Jersey's legislative leaders had reached bipartisan agreement on a proposed state antitrust law to prevent the infiltration of legitimate businesses by organized crime.
The Consumers Power Company reported yesterday record sales of electricity and gas for 1969. Net income was above the 1968 level.
President Nixon's White House news conference scheduled for 6:30 P.M. today will be carried live on television and radio.

An art ehhibition that will amount to a quick survey course of the trends of the last one hundred years will open at M. Knoedler Co. on Feb. 9 with a champagne reception to benefit Dartmouth College's Hopkins Center Art Galleries.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner filed a separation suit yesterday against his wife, the former Barbara Cavanagh. They were married July 26, 1965.

THE polished machinery of Iris Murdoch's 13th novel spins around a wager. Four world record-holders with different running styles, backgrounds and personalities will enter the same race tonight and the 600-yard run finally may shed its role as track and field's orphan event.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 29 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith hinted today at reprisals against Zambia if she continued to "harbor and assist" terrorists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) The House approved today a revision of the Internal Security Act to keep subversives out of sensitive defense plants.
The New York State Bar Association has approved a plan requiring every automobile owner to carry insurance covering medical payments and income loss for passengers in his own car.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania Helped by a recovery in trade and a large inflow of foreign aid from both West and East, Tanzanian development gained a momentum last year that promised to continue through 1970.

Long Island Rail Road train crews, saying they were afraid of "physical assault by commuters" angered by the new fare increase, threatened yesterday to refuse to operate trains on Monday unless they were given police protection on every run.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (UPI) Duquesne scored 12 straight points midway in the second half tonight and then coasted to an 83-67 victory over Kentucky Wesleyan. Jarrett Durham was high scorer for Duquesne with 24 points. Larry Morris tallied 22 for Wesleyan. It was only the third loss in 16 starts for Wesleyan.

IN 1947, the United Nations Trusteeship Council re ceived a petition which vividly described what used to happen to some young girls of the Elkum tribe in the Bamenda Province of what was then the Britishadministered Cameroons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Attorney General John N. Mitchell urged the House today to act quickly on a major drug control bill that cleared the Senate 82 to 0 yesterday.
KHARTOUM, The Sudan The new revolutionary Government in the Sudan faces a stiff battle to restore the economy in the year ahead.
Governor Rockefeller contended here yesterday that the $10-billion program proposed by President Nixon to clean up the nation's water would be far from adequate.

Record fourth-quarter and annual sales and earnings were posted by the American Home Products Corporation whose six major operating divisions contributed with peak sales last year. William F. Laporte, chairman, also announced yesterday an increase in quarterly dividend to 37 cents a share.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 29 President Kenneth Kaunda took virtual control of Zambia's mining, industry and commerce today.
TOLEDO, Jan. 29 (AP) Toledo rallied late in the first half and then outscored Colgate in the second half tonight to post a 99-76 victory.

Officials of the Westinghouse Electric International Corporation said yesterday that an American consortium including Westinghouse and the Budd Corporation had signed a contract to supply 198 subway cars for the new transit system of Sao Paulo, Brazil.
A public hearing last night on transportation problems in Queens was almost unanimous in accusing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of failing to provide adequate subway and bus service.
A $40-million, 50-story office building will soon begin to rise on 57th Street west of Fifth Avenue the largest postwar office tower yet built on the crosstown thoroughfare.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird suggested today that creating an all-volunteer armed force might require a slash of about one-third in the size of the nation's active duty armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Nixon has decided to seek an expansion of the Safeguard missile defense system and of the funds to be requested for it from Congress in the next budget, Administration officials say.
Donald E. Williams has been elected president of the Baer Securities Corporation, an affiliate of the private banking firm of Julius Baer Co., Zurich, Switzerland.

A man who served two years as president of the city's Tax Commission was indicted on a perjury charge yesterday, accused of having falsely denied to a grand jury that he paid former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus at least $1,300 in an effort to influence a decision of the City Planning Commission.

In a double-barreled mixture of good and bad news, the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced yesterday the most successful test results yet reported from an oil well on Alaska's North Slope and a sharp decline in 1969 earnings as a result of its merger with the B.P. Oil Company, American subsidiary of British Petroleum, Ltd.

KINSHASA, the Congo Helped by record copper earnings, new high levels of trade and an upsurge in foreign investor interest, the Congolese economy is showing signs of moving from rapid recovery into vigorous health.

In the second massive corporate financing project in two weeks, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday that it plans to raise between $400-million and $450-million through an offering of additional capital stock.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 28 (AP) Mrs. Ann Jones of England, the Wimbledon champion, defeated Robyn Leggs of New Zealand 6-0, 6-0 today in the quarterfinal round of the Benson and Hedges open tennis tournament.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa "Business," says 33year-old David Abramson understatedly, "is a most pleasant way of occupying the day."

CAIRO The mammoth Aswan High Dam, a billiondollar venture that some skeptics thought could not be built and others said should not be built, will be put into full operation this year and become a pillar of the Egyptian economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Senator Henry M. Jackson introduced a bill today that would provide incentives to the states to adopt land-use plans to protect the environment and also provide penalties for failure to adopt plans acceptable to the Federal Government.

Two manuscript Haggadahs were among the stellar items auctioned yesterday in the sale of part of the Hebraica collection of the late Michael Zagayski of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. The sale, held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, realized $161,035.

PARIS, Jan. 29 The United States affirmed today that it sends reconnaissance planes over North Vietnam with fighter escorts, but denied that this violated the 1968 understanding that halted the bombing raids.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa After nearly two years with its economic head buried firmly in the gold-mine dumps of the Witwatersrand, South Africa has pulled out and acknowledged the dollar is king.

RABAT, Morocco Since disaster to Morocco's agricultural economy is always possible because of drought, attempts to insure against the vagaries of climate will continue to get top priority in the Government's planning. This will focus especially on the construction of dams and irrigation networks.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (Reuters) Cassius Clay defeated Rocky Marciano tonight in a revised version of their filmed and computerized "fight."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 After drafting millions of men into the military during three wars and the periods of peace in between, Gen. Lewis Blaine Hershey will retire next month, convinced that the values he learned as an Indiana farm boy at the turn of the century and the structure he created for the Selective Service System three decades ago are still sound.
DETROIT, Jan, 29 Robert F. Williams, the black militant leader, lost a minor point today in his battle against extradition to North Carolina on a kidnapping charge.

TWO days to go and all is well," Jim Kelly, the operator of Brodie Mountain at New Ashford, Mass., made that comment yesterday after spending the morning wondering whether the usual January thaw had waited until the month's final days to melt snow covers.

MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Jan. 29 (AP) Gustavo Thoeni of Italy won the giant slalom of the men's ski meet today after a jury disqualified him for missing a gate and then overruled itself following the testimony of Austrian skiers.

Almost exactly two years after Alexander Dubcek became First Secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist party, he has "resigned" from that party's Central Committee. Symbolically, his departure from his last party position marks the end of the remarkable period in Czechoslovak history that began when Mr. Dubcek replaced Antonin Novotny.
The Transamerica Corporation announced yesterday that Edward L. Scarff, president, had resigned to head a new subsidiary of Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., the New York brokerage concern.
SAIGON, Jan. 29 (AP) Four United States Government investigators not two were infiltrated into the Saigon press corps to spy on the newsmen, official sources conceded today.
BATHURST, Gambia Gambia once again managed to balance its books for the fiscal year 1969, but the tiny West African country is not resting on its laurels.

The president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York indicated yesterday that there was a narcoticsaddiction problem in business offices, too. He compared industry's recently acquired awareness of it to the discovery in the nineteen-fifties that alcoholism "wasn't limited to bums on the Bowery."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal of Queens has decided to enter the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York as an active but undeclared candidate.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 29 The United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, today described 1969 as a year of meaningful progress in South Vietnam, but conceded that the enemy "is still a military force to be reckoned with."

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 29 Dr. Robert Morse Woodbury, economist and author, who retired in 1953 as chief statistician of the International Labor Office in Geneva, died Jan. 17 at his home here. His age was 80.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Senate refused today to postpone consideration of legislation that would immunize from antitrust prosecution all existing and many prospective joint operations of a separately owned newspapers.
PARIS, Jan. 29 (Reuters) The Bank of France said today France's gold and convertible currency reserves rose by 57million francs in the week to Jan. 22.
Dr. Alfred T. Corvin, a psychoanalyst, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home, 300 Central Park West. He was 60 years old. His office was at 360 East 65th Street.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 The Federal grand jury investigating the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski returned an indictment today naming the three suspects arrested here eight days ago as the killers, hired by "persons unknown" for fees of up to $1,700.
