CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 29 A pool of $100-million has been created by 11 top United States banks this week to finance non-traditional Latin-American exports in an effort to unshackle the region's dependence on customary sales to world markets.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 Analysis of a meteorite recently found in France has led to a suggestion that a great stellar explosion may have accompanied, or immediately preceded, the formation of the solar system. This has been calculated by Dr. Gerald J. Wasserburg of the California Institute of Technology.

The United States Steel Corporation and the Kaiser Steel Corporation said yesterday that they would match the price increases of about 3 per cent on flat-rolled sheets already announced by most of the steel industry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 A Government study shows that a surprisingly large number of heart attacks occur without the victims' being aware of them.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 The Republican majority in the Legislature is preparing to compromise in the first major test of antipollution sentiment in a year of increasing political rhetoric about environmental protection.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Civil Aeronautics Board threatened the major airlines today with a $1-million-a-day fare cut unless they came up with a more equitable plan for sharing revenues with local airlines on through-fare tickets that involve two or more carriers.

Paperboard production rose 3.7 per cent with 526.6 tons in the week ended Jan. 24, from 508,000 tons in the corresponding 1969 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

Congress is now grappling with the sordid consequences of the compromises which the Administration used as bait to persuade the House to sustain President Nixon's veto of the education appropriations bill.
Dr. Brian D. Josephson, 30year-old theoretical physicist from Cambridge University, received the 1969 Research Corporation Award last night at a dinner at the Plaza Hotel here.

Governor Rockefeller announced last night a long-range capital improvement plan for the Harlem and Hudson divisions of the Penn Central, onequarter of which is to be paid for by the railroad and the remainder by the $2.5-billion mass transportation bond issue of 1967.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Col. Frank Borman, the astronaut who commanded Apollo 8 on man's first circumnavigation of the moon, announced plans today to leave the space program and join a Texas billionaire in starting a foundation to promote public debate on pressing national issues.

DETROIT, Jan. 29 (UPI) Gordie Howe scored one goal and assisted on two others tonight as the Detroit Red Wings fought off a determined thirdperiod attack and scored a 4-3 National Hockey League victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The major automobile manufacturers were attacked today by William P. Lear, the inventor, for failing to develop vehicles that emitted lower levels of pollutants than standard models do.

A 34-year-old Bronx pharmacy owner was indicted yesterday on charges of grand larceny in connection with the alleged embezzlement of -67,000 from a travel agency for which he acted as an agent in his store at 850 East 169th Street.

JEROME ROBBINS offered us and the New York City Ballet another Chopin ballet at the New York State Theater last night, and nothing would be easier to suggest than that it is a simple spinoff from last season's Chopin masterpiece, "Dances at a Gathering." But great choreographers repeat themselves but rarely, and then only by mistake.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The first official White House music library for this and future Presidents and their families, "perhaps the finest ever assembled," was announced today.

Mayor Lindsay got a look at another city's troubles yesterday as he and the mayors of the state's six largest cities toured the inner core of Yonkers while its Mayor, Alfred B. DelBello, ticked off the catalogue of woes arising from the city's being taxed to its limits and still short of vital services.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Justice Department's antitrust division expects to be bringing more cases in the near future involving pricefixing on services, rather than products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 "The Silent Majority," a controversial film produced by the United States Information Agency to show that President Nixon has ample public support for his policies in Vietnam, has been less than a smash hit abroad.
The union representing 9,000 employes at six Macy's department stores in the metropolitan area announced yesterday that members had authorized their leaders to call a strike.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 29 Maxwell E. Kaps, a commissioner of the North Jersey Water Supply District for the last six years and previously a legal counsel to the New Jersey State Assembly, died yesterday at the Jersey City Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived at 82 Tonnelle Avenue here.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 The Soviet Union's labor organization called today for a nationwide crackdown on workers accused of shirking on the job.
New York State's orchestras, operas, dance companies, museums and other cultural organizations face a combined deficit this year of $70-million.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 President Nixon announced today the membership of the new Council on Environmental Quality amid stern demands from Capitol Hill that he use the council as its architects in Congress intended.
The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that a plan to acquire United States Leasing, International, Inc., had been discontinued by mutual agreement.
BANGUI, Central African Republic The Central African Republic suffers considerably from its geographical location.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, whose husband died in 1969 after several heart attacks, was honored at the White House today as "the nation's foremost heart volunteer."
MIAMI, Jan. 29 (AP) The Hobeau Farm's Knight Of The Road charged from last place to score an impressive victory today in the feature at Hialeah Park before a crowd of 14,691.

The normally sold-out Metropolitan Opera, which opened its belated and shortened 85th season a month ago yesterday, has suffered a severe falling off in ticket sales. Company officials blame confusion resulting from the three-and-a-half-month postponement for the empty seats and say attendance is now picking up rapidly.

The election of Leonard Sloane as president of the New York Financial Writers' Association, Inc., was announced yesterday. Mr. Sloane, a financial and business reporter for The New York Times, succeeds Ted Ward, financial editor of The New York Post.
Scripps-Howard Newspapers announced yesterday that Mark Ferree, who has been executive vice president in the New York offices since 1952, would retire Sunday.
The International Paper Company realized a 15.6 per cent increase in earnings last year on a sales gain of 12.9 per cent, both setting new records for the year.
Two of the city's Democratic county leaders were accused yesterday of "instrusion" into the affairs of the City Council.

Morley Safer, a correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, left Nigeria yesterday on orders from Government authorities in Lagos, who had refused to renew his expired visa, according to C.B.S. News. The authorities in Lagos gave no reason for the expulsion.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 29 Rosalind Oppenheim a freelance photographer and teacher of photography, died at Community Hospital here yesterday after a brief illness. Miss Oppenheim, who was 56 years old, lived in Woodbury.
The Consolidated Edison Company and the Van Iderstein Company, renderers of animal fats, pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to charges of polluting New York City waterways.

Lady Furness, the former Thelma Morgan and twin of the late Mrs. Reginald Vanderbilt, collapsed and died yesterday in Manhattan while on the way to a doctor's office. She was 65 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

Earnings reports from the metals industry were mixed yesterday. While several producers and fabricators of nonferrous metals set records in 1969, the nation's seventh largest steel company suffered a 20 per cent drop in net income for the year and a loss for the fourth quarter.
JEFF WANSHEL is 21 years old. He is a writer. He has a gift for words big, fat, colorful ones like pluvial monsoon and he may have a long future in the theater.
A panel of civic, government, labor and educational leaders gas named yesterday to make a comprehensive study of the State University's plans.

CONAKRY, Guinea Life is still very hard for most of Guinea's 3.5 million people. The last 12 months saw little, if any, improvement in their standard of living, and the country continues to exist in what is virtually a wartime economy almost everything is in short supply.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa The three mini-states of southern Africa Botwana, Lesotho and Swaziland enter the year with a solid cash position through an important new deal with the country that influences their economic destinies, South Africa.
Four of the country's largest retail companies reported yesterday substantial sales gains for January over the year-ago month.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) A student antiwar group announced today a conference, open to the entire antiwar movement, in Cleveland Feb. 14-15 to plan a spring action campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, advocated today legislation curbing takeovers of banks, utilities, insurance companies and other regulated companies.

Miss Patricia Gail Hundemann, who is with the BoyleMidway division of American Home Products, Inc., here, plans to be married to David Curtis Neldner, who is attending the Army's noncommissioned officers school at Fort Benning, Ga.

Pollution. President Nixon anounced the members of his new Council on Environmental Quality. Russell E. Train, Under Secretary of the Interior Department, is chairman, and Robert Cahn and Gordon J.F. MacDonald are the two other members.
Zdzislaw Czermanski, a painter and political cartoonist, died Tuesday at FlowerFifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 70 years old and lived at 436 East 77th Street.
NIAMEY, Niger Improvement in this semi-Saharan land is a matter of whether the struggle to survive is easier in one year than another. On this basis, 1969 was better than most for Niger.
COCCOLIA, Italy, Jan. 23 Last fall the 600 furious inhabitants of this tiny agricultural town 15 miles southwest of Ravenna renamed their home "Puzzolia," freely translatable as "Stinkville."
ALBANY, Jan. 29 Governor Rockefeller proposed today a highway safety program "to cope with the shameful record of automobile accidents," with special emphasis on curbing drunken drivers.

The Public Service Commission, long a dumping ground for broken-down Republican politicians, is finally being reorganized to make it an effective protector of the public interest. Unfortunately, at the very start of that shake-up, the commission finds itself obliged to rush out a decision on the New York Telephone Company's application for $175 million in rate increases.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 G. Harrold Carswell was accused today of harboring not only racist beliefs but also "sexist" views in opposition to equal rights for women.
BATON ROUGE, Jan. 30 (AP) The petroleum industry was not responsible for the oil spill that coated Grand Isle beaches last Sunday, the Louisiana Stream Control Commission said yesterday.

I am the last one to deny the utility of cliches to public officials. But a cliche cannot be substituted for a policy. I fear that this may be happening with respect to the Administration's inflation policy.

Francis Donaldson, vice president and a director of Mason Hanger-Silas Mason Co., Inc., engineers and contractors of 500 Fifth Avenue, died Wednesday at his home, 7 Tanglewylde Avenue, Bronxville, N. Y. His age was 88.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) An American was named today to direct Pergamon Press, Ltd., a publishing group formerly headed by a British millionaire, Robert Maxwell.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 30 New inducements for the expansion of the mining industry were announced by Zambia's Minister of Finance, Elijah Mudenda, in his budget speech here today. But details of new mineral taxation, which will replace the present royalty and export tax system, were note, disclosed by the Minister, who said legislation soon would be introduced to give effect to them.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange fell yesterday to their lowest levels in more than six years.

MANILA, Saturday, Jan. 31 Some 2,000 students and young people, hoisting revolutionary placards and upsidedown Philippine flags, tried last night to storm into the grounds of Malacanang, the presidential palace, and battled with policemen into the morning.

MADISON, N. J., Jan. 30Henry Stark Ferriss of 133 Green Village Road, a lawyer for 14 years for the Title Guaranty Trust Company in New York City, died yesterday at his home after a short illness. His age was 72.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 A presidential commission charged with "a thorough examination of needed changes in our financial institutions and regulatory structure" will be appointed shortly, the Administration said today.

Bargaining committee of the two striking electrical unions gave their approval yesterday to new agreements with General Electric that will cost nearly $1-billion and will provide $1.05 an hour in higher wages and improved benefits.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 30 Allnight talks aimed at ending a four-week strike of city employes collapsed early today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 30 A Circuit Court judge who once ordered the arrest of a group of Connecticut parents for serving liquor to teen-agers at parties in their homes watched today as his own son pleaded guilty to a heroin charge.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 After breezing into the final 10 minutes of play with a seemingly insurmountable 18-point lead, the New York Knickerbockers almost dissipated all assets and had to battle to subdue the Philadelphia 76ers, 104-100, tonight before 13,191 fans, the Spectrum's largest National Basketball Association crowd of the season.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 "We need a rip-roaring campaign," said Sander Levin, a 38-yearold Democratic State Senator who is today's best bet to challenge Michigan's Governor in November.
Oppenheimer Co., amember firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that it had admitted as general partners Anthony Bruan, 26 years old; Donald Kramer, 32, and Stephen Robert, 29.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 The defense in the Chicago conspiracy trial neared the end of its case today in a session marked by the appearance of several prominent witnesses.

The stock market plummeted yesterday to its lowest point in more than six years. With trading active on the New York Stock Exchange, the downward movement that has characterized the market for almost a year continued for most of the day. At the bell, the key Dow-Jones industrial average had sunk to 744.06, down 4.29 points, to the lowest

The strike begun early today by the railroad shopcraft unions represents an outrageous abuse of power by a minority of a minority in rail labor. The tragedy is that all labor is likely to pay a heavy price in public indignation if the shopcrafts persist in their arbitrary rejection of Secretary of Labor Shultz's plea for a week-long truce to explore new peace avenues.
THE Canadian Broadcasting 3 Corporation contributed a poignant and all-too-true play last night to the National Educational Television Playhouse on Channel 13.
Not many concerts are selling out these days, but the combination of Bach, Starker and Ruzickova turned the trick last night at the Metropolitan Museum.

Almost 10 years ago, when the Banco de Ponce became the first Puerto Rican bank to open a branch in New York City, the banking establishment here watched with interest as the newcomer moved in where other banks had feared to tread.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The White House, unhappy about the premature publication of details from President Nixon's annual Economic Report in The Washington Post today, will reconsider whether to continue the practice of giving economic writers an advance look at such comlpicated documents.

The choreographers Rosalind Pierson, Margaret Beals and, Carla de Sola are quite dissimilar temperamentally, but they shared a program and a highly similar approach to choreography last night at Cooper Union Great Hall. Each decided to mirror closely in movement the musical or spoken accompaniment to her dances. The results generally lacked imaginative subtlety.

Aetna Life and Casualty, which found itself without a president earlier this month with the surprise resignation of John A. Hill, filled the vacancy yesterday by electing its chairman and chief executive Officer, Olcott D. Smith, to the additional post.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that construction of new nuclear plants for peaceful uses did not fare very well in 1969 and said one major reason was public fear of such installations.
PARIS, Jan. 30 The Givenchy collection today may be the dark horse of the spring-summer haute couture collections, which wind up tomorrow, and what a horse it is, too.

John Carlos is not talking about professional football because he is an amateur runner, and amateur runners are not supposed to stalk about money. But if he were talking about money, "well, we'd start at a million dollars and maybe work downtoward $600,000."

WHEN you have just produced LeRoi Jones's "Slave Ship" what do you do for an encore? This was the problem facing the Chelsea Theater Center at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and last night they came up with an adroit, even urbane answer.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 30--The Government's award of the disputed city of Chandigarh to Punjab State induced a Sikh Punjabi leader today to call off his threat to burn himself to death, but it touched off widespread arson and violence in Haryana State, the rival claimant for the city. The army was brought in tonight to restore order.
DENVER, Jan. 30 Gov John A. Love said today he was "horrified" at the attack on the wife of the Democratic leader of the Colorado House of Representatives.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 The Chrysler Corporation today reported a loss for its fourth quarter of $4.4-million, or 10 cents a share, dropping net income in all 1969 to $88.8million, or $1.87 a share.

Miss Ellen Judith Rubinstein, a reference librarian with McGraw-Hill, Inc., here, and Allison Franklin Butts plan to be married next month in Paris, where the future bridegroom is a lawyer with the New York firm of Hughes, Hubbard Reed.
PRAGUE, Jan. 30 Dr. Gustav Husak, the Communist party chief, assured Czechoslovaks today that the party would not "degrade itself" by staging show trials of progressives.

Phyllis Curtin will make her first appearance as Violetta this season in the Metropolitan Opera's production of "La Traviata" on Feb. 16, and Richard Tucker will sing the title role in "Don Carlo" for the first time this season on Feb. 20.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 The United States Mission said in a statement issued here today that four agents fraudulently accredited as newsmen had been on a mission "completely unrelated to the local Vietnamese and foreign press corps or their activities."

WASHINGTON, dan. 30 In hopeful phrases that recalled one of the earliest news conferences of his Presidency. President Nixon expressed the belief tonight that, in time, he could win the respect and allegiance of the black community.
RICHMOND, Jan. 30 Miss Ernestina Sylvia Palumbo and G.E. Kidder Smith Jr. of San Francisco plan to marry in France in March at Marly-le-Roi, near Paris.
Mrs. Afeni Shakur, who is one of 16 Black Panther party members who have been in jail since last April on bombing conspiracy charegs, was released last inght in $100,000 bail.
ATLANTA, Jan. 30 (UPI) Outbreaks of influenza and influenza-like illnesses in the East Coast states of Connecticut Georgia and Florida were reported today by the National Communicable Disease Center.

THE simplest hands to bid are often the hardest to play, and vice versa. Bidding to a grand slam requires good partnership undertanding and judgment, but the play is generally straightforward. Conversely, a one-level contract is easy to reach but can offer many varations in the play.
PASSENGERS on Penn Central commuter cars con tinue to fume over a Butcher Sherrerd recommendation of the railroad's stock mentioned in this column on Jan. 9.

THERE is something arresting about publishing that is absent from the manufacturing of seamless hose or even from the exploits of the herring fleet. That is true, I think, because publishing is a waterway that drains from so many streams, some bright, some muddy. Technological development in press work and composition, the economics of cost and distribution,

To report on any exhibition at the New York Cultural Center, Formerly Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art, involves a preliminary embarrassment, because the new name suggests that this problem child of architecture and philanthropy has changed character to become a City institution where the arts flourish as one great constellation.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 A 62-1 shot and a 28-1 shot ran 1, 2 in the third race at Liberty Bell race track today to form the largest exacta payoff of the winter meeting, $1,109,40.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Senate today passed a bill directing the Federal National Mortgage Association to pay $68-million to the Treasury.
Miss Constance Meyer, a fashion coordinator with Allied Graphic Arts, Inc., here, plans to be married in June to Alan H. Buerger, a student at Columbia.

Five persons were arrested by transit police at the height of the rush hour last night on a charge of holding open the gates to the IND subway station at 53d Street and Madison Avenue and urging patrons to ride free.
WALDOBORO, Me., Jan. 30 Howard A. Marple, retired head of the public relations department of the Monsanto Company of St. Louis died in a hospital yesterday at the age of 70.

Twenty-three people protesting further building expansion in Central Park last night picketed a private reception held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in honor of Arthur A. Houghton Jr., chairman of the board, and C. Douglas Dillon, the president.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Jan. 130 (AP)--El Salvador and Hondruas agreed today to an immediate pullback of troops along their border.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) Frank V. Brach, a founder and chairman of E. J. Brach Sons, one of the largest candy companies in the country, died here Yesterday at the age of 80.

A group of prominent black officeholders and artists endorsed efforts today to elect Kenneth A. Gibson as the first black mayor of Newark, along with a slate of black and Puerto Rican council candidates.
Plans to expand Jewish studies at the City University of New York were announced yesterday by the Rev. Timothy S. Healy, vice chancellor for academic affairs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 (UPI) The Rolling Stones and their promoters today filed an $11-million suit against owners of the originally scheduled site of their Dec. 6 free concert, which drew 200,000 fans and was marred by a fatal onstage stabbing.
PARIS, Jan. 30 According to an opinion poll just published here, 55 per cent of the Frenchmen interrogated said that France should not sell arms to any country in the Middle East.
AFTER a day on the ski slopes, an Iowa scalloped chicken casserole prepared in advance to pop in the oven and served with a broccoli dish and caramel nut cake the cook, to relax by the fire.

MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP) Al Hattab, an odds-on favorite, was beaten again today, tiring in the final strides to finish third as Ghost Train nosed out Futura bold at Hialeah. Entered against lesser company, the crowd of 14,254 made Al Hattab the 3-5 choice and he looked like a winner when he turned for home with a clear lead.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, Jan. 31 A strike against Union Pacific Railroad started at midnight last night and industry spokesmen said they would move to shut down the nation's entire rail network.
PITTSBURGH. Jan. 30 An agreement to employ 1,250 Negroes as journeymen in the construction industry in Allegheny County over the next four years was announced here today.
GENEVA, Jan. 30 A United Nations commission approved a draft treaty today to place hallucinogenic drugs under strict international controls.
Hugo Heuermann of the trust investment department of the Chemical Bank has been promoted to vice president.
Cotton futures closed mixed yesterday in a steady market. Early in the day there was commission house buying, but prices eased later as liquidation increased.
Wilbur L. Arthur, Eastern advertising manager of The Chicago Daily News from 1937 to 1960, died yesterday at Yale New Haven Hospital. He lived at 200 Drum Hill Road, Wilton, Conn.

Mrs. Ruth Kony Lanes, a member of the board of visitors to Creedmoor State Hospital, died Thursday of a heart attack in Flushing Hospital. She was the wife of Paul Lanes, a factoring executive, and lived at 36-20 Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens.

Sergei J. Denham, director of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo from 1938 until the midnineteen-sixties, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital. Mr. Denham was injured Thursday night when he was struck by a bus at Madison Avenue and 57th Street. He was 73 years old and lived at 1200 Fifth Avenue.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 The Soviet Union today ordered the expulsion of Ennio Carretto, the Moscow correspondent for La Stampa of Milan, Italy, for what it termed "violation of the norms of foreign journalists in the Soviet Union."

A special survey by the city's Transportation Administration reported yesterday that the sub ways were "intolerably' dirty, sometimes unsafe and often so late that fewer and fewer people were using the system.

KANO, Nigeria When he sets off shortly on his African trip, Secretary of State Rogers will quickly observe a fundamental truth, obvious enough but nevertheless impressive when seen for oneself: Black Africa is not a homogeneous place but a collection of territories that vary enormously in their qualities and their problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The Senate approved a bill today that would exempt from antitrust prosecution all existing and many prospective joint operations of two separately owned newspapers. The vote was 63 to 14.

Lee C. Webb, manager of the Port of New York Authority's bus station at the George Washington Bridge, retired this week after 22 years with the bistate agency. He has held his present job for seven years, and before that he was the first manager of the bus terminal at Eighth Avenue and 41st Street.
The new decentralized schooldistrict lines drawn for Manhattan were voided yesterday by a state judge who said that they failed "to create integration and maximum heterogeneity" as required by law.
The American Electric Power System committed itself yesterday to the largest single generating unit in the history of the electric power industry.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 30 (UPI) A Taiwanese law professor, who defected in protest against the Chinese Nationalist regime of Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek, was granted political asylum here today.

Art works by well-known women artists will be exhibited Monday through Sunday, Feb. 8, at the National Arts Club, 5 Gramercy Park South. A number of the artists are expected to attend the opening of the show, which is sponsored by the Skidmore College art department and the Skidmore Arts Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The Council of Economic Advisers gave cautious and conditional support today to ideas for small and frequent changes in currency exchange rates but emphasized that "the United States cannot move its own, parity with respect to other currencies."

The first major crackdown by the Federal anticrime strike force in Brooklyn has brought about the seizure of $175,000 worth of illegal cocaine and the breaching of an international cocaine-smuggling ring, Federal authorities announced yesterday.
OLD LYME, Conn., Jan. 30 (UPI)-Denton Butt, a radio and television announcer and actor, died Wednesday. He was 68 years old.

DARIFN, Conn., Jan. 30 Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Van Dusen Kilbourn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Tucker Kilbourn, to George Rice Munson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Townsend Munson of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

Industry's quest for employes continues to lag, according to the National Industrial Conference Board. The board's helpwanted advertising index in December dropped for the third consecutive month to 216 per cent of the 1957-1959 average, a decline of 6 points from the November figure and 9 points under the level of December, 1968.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 President Nixon projected today a growth of the national economy by about $50-billion this year, with both less inflation and less "real" growth than in 1969.

The Secretary of the Air Force, Robert C. Seamans Jr., went to St. Louis yesterday to seek assurance from the McDonnell-Douglas Corporation, the recent winner of a $1.1billion plane contract, that it would comply with Federal nondiscriminatory employment policies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 President Nixon said tonight that he would still have nominated G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court if he had known that he had espoused white supremacy in a 1948 political speech .[Question 7, Page 14.]
President Pompidou of France will not be accorded an official welcome by the city when he comes here on March 2, Mayor Lindsay's office said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The Labor Department described as "premature" today a report that it was considering invalidating the re-election of W.A. Boyle to the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America.

Miss Amy Suzzanne Kessler, a doctoral student in the history of art at Cornell University, plans to be married to Elliott Stephen Lewitt, a senior in the honors program at Hobart College in Geneva, N.Y.

MINEOLA, L.I. Jan. 30 A 14-year-old boy and his father were awarded $280,000 by a State Supreme Court jury today for injuries suffered by the boy when he was shot in the head by another youth six years ago.

BONN, Jan. 30 Chancellor Willy Brandt has marked his hundredth day in office with a significant domestic-policy decision by his Cabinet to liberalize West Germany's laws against political demonstrators.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 GovernorRockefeller asked the Legislature today to extend for two weeks the period of voter registration for the New York City local school board elections. They are scheduled to end tomorrow night.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) Sam Snead took a three-stroke lead after 36 holes in the Professional Golfers Association's senior championship today with his second 71 for a 142 as rain and the flu bug cut the field to 90.
The first vessel in a small and still active United States fleet of troop ships sailed into oblivion yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 31 (AP)--Officers said today that reports yesterday of a major battle between United States soldiers and enemy battalions near Tayninh had been made by a unit commander and that "we are not convinced" of the accuracy of the reports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 An attempt by the Government to create a more scientifically exact framework for deciding what the nation can afford and what it cannot afford was disclosed by President Nixon today in his Economic Report to Congress.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jn. 30 (AP) Gov. Claude Kirk Jr. issued executitve orders today prohibiting busing by two Florida counties to implement Federal court-ordered school desegregation plans.
Tiffany Co., which carries sterling silver but not silver plate, yesterday gave its nod to a bit of plastic.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 (AP) The nation's auto makers reported today their smallest new car production for a January since 1961.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 30 Two old, old pros, Ron Stewart and Terry Sawchuk, collaborted tonight in a 2-1 victory over the Oakland Seals that preserved the New York Rangers' distinction of not having lost two consecutive games in this National Hockey League season.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange declined yesterday. The losses reflected an almost complete absence of buyers and not selling pressure.
CHICAGO, Jan, 30 The seven Black Panthers who survived a predawn police raid here were indicted today on charges of attempted murder.
More than 400 of the 669 pupils at Public School, 226 23d Avenue and 60th Street in Brooklyn, were absent yesterday because of a parentorganized boycott protesting a reduction in the teaching staff.

MIAMI, Saturday, Jan. 31 (AP)-About 3,500 ground employes of National Airlines went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today, grounding the line's 53 jets. The strikers are members of the Air Line Employes Association, which has been working without a contract since last spring.

THREE-FOURTHS of Anton Kuerti's recital in Alice Tully Hall last night was spent on large-scale works. The other fourth was devoted to the 12 etudes that make up Chopin's Op. 25, and it was in these relatively short pieces that the pianist was in his element.

The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered a 6.35 per cent rollback in most domestic air fares yesterday after the nation's largest domestic airlines rejected a new fare-splitting plan proposed by the C.A.B.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) Prices that farmers received for their products rose onethird of one per cent during the month ended Jan. 15 and put further pressure on the Administration's attempt to curb the cost of living.

Dr. Maurice S. Calman, a retired oral surgeon and a memher of the Board of Aldermen in 1917, died Tuesday at the home of his son, Dr. Clarence M. Calman in Glen Rock, N. J. He was 83 years old and lived at 658 West 188th Street.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 30 "It is indeed a wonderful thing that the war has ended," a taxicab driver said the other day as he careened perilously around corners in this vibrant capital, horn honking constantly, "but now Nigeria needs better highways."
The chairman of the Franklin Society Federal Savings and Loan Association, one of the largest in New York State, proposed yesterday that Congress stimulate housing by giving savers a tax break.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The chairman and two members of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, whose report on the economy will accompany Mr. Nixon's message to Congress Monday, collectively represent several decades of economic study for government, business and academia.
Long Island Rail Road commuters heaped abuse on ticket sellers yesterday as the railroad put its fare increase into effect one day early on some tickets.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) James R. MacAnally, senior vice president of the Union Pacific Railroad, Omaha, died yesterday while on a business trip here shortly after suffering a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced a new plan yesterday for the projected Second Avenue subway route to Lower Manhattan that included both a direct line and a loop through the Lower East Side bulge.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Jan. 27:
Prices continued to drop yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in slow trading.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I. Jan. 30 Unable to generate the momentum for the fast-breaking game that had given them 15 straight victories, the Denver Rockets bowed tonight, 115-98, to the New York Nets, a club they expected to rout.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) Jacksonville's 7-foot-2inch Artis Gilmore raked in 30 rebounds and scored a career high of 46 points tonight as the sixth-ranked Dolphins downed St. Peter's of Jersey City, 124-101, in a fast-breaking basketball game.

YOU want me to sign something?" asked Casey Stengel. "I work here," said the hotel maintenance man; tentatively offering a pen and a scratch pad. "Cost you four ... teen ... thou ... sand dollars," said Stengel.
TIN, painted and plain, is the subject of the current exhibition, "The Tinker and His Dam," at the Museum of American Folk Art.

Vandals made a predawn foray on the home of Queens district Attorney Thomas J. Mackell yesterday, breaking a window and spray-painting two slogans "Off Pig Mackell" and "Free the Panther 21 or There Will Be White Riots."

ATHENS, Jan. 30 Richard C. Scott, an American who jumped bail on marijuana charges two years ago in California, asked American consular authorities in Athens, where he was arrested Wednesday, to send him "back home."
PARIS, Jan. 30 An icy wind has whistled over many security markets of the world this month, influenced to some extent by the frigid temperatures in Wall Street.
Dr. Kurt Rosenberg, a gynecologist, died Wednesday in Boulevard Hospital, Long Island City, Queens. He was 55 years old and lived at 14 Greenway South, Forest Hills, Queens.

THE reigning school of color abstraction in con temporary American painting has developed, in recent years, into a curious amalgam of hedonistic visual sensation and dispassionate (not to say cold) intellectual analysis. Color in the most delicious combinations fills the spectator's field of vision,
NEWARK, Jan. 30 Two of 13 companies accused of polluting the tributary waters of New York Harbor pleaded guilty in Federal Court here today and were fined $750 each.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 While insisting that he was not partial to either side in the continuing conflict in the Middle East, President Nixon said this evening that he would decide within a month how many more weapons the United States would sell to Israel.
COPPFR is too fragile, aluminum too light, gold too symbolic, silver too weak, bronze is out of fashion and platinum inaccessible, said Maria Pergay, a 39-year-old French sculptordesigner.
Michael Freyberg, a former president of the city Tax Commission, denied yesterday that he had attempted to influence a City Planning Commission decision by bribery.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Jan. 30 -Lawren Harris, a member of the Group of Seven, Canadian painters who joined in the 1920's in an effort to develop a distinct Canadian style, died yesterday at his home here. He was 85 years old.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 School administrators throughout the state were instructed by the Department of Education today to continue the daily salute to the flag by students and let the courts decide how to deal with dissenters.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 Factory cars from Ferrari of Italy, Porsche of West Germany and Matra of France swept the first eight qualifying positions today for the 24 Hours of Daytona, presaging one of the hardest-fought endurance races of recent years.

"The way they say it, it's as if there is liberty and justice, but there isn't." Twelve-year-old Mary Frain, sitting pensively on a wooden rocker in her Jamaica, Queens, home, gave this explanation yesterday as one of her reasons for objecting to the daily Pledge of Allegiance to the flag in school.

The Moog synthesizer may well become the musical instrument of the Seventies. If so, it will have to come up with something better than what was offered by Gershon Kingsley's First Moog Quartet last night in Cargenie Hall.
ROME, Jan. 30 Italian filmmakers, many of whom believe their industry has been crippled by the abrupt withdrawal of American financing, got some bad news today.

WESTBURY, L.I. Jan. 30 Although Billy Haughton will be less than 15 miles away from Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night, he will not appear at the track to drive either Meadow Elva in the featured $12,500 fourth race or Mizelle Smokey in the $3,000 fifth. Both pacers are among the 24 standardbreds in the Haughton barns here.

ROME, Jan. 30 A French cardinal charged today that the attack on clerical celibacy, led by the Dutch branch of the Roman Catholic church, had as its real aim the undermining of Papal authority and reduction of the church to decadence.
Negotiations for a new contract for the port's commercial towing industry took a turn for the worse yesterday.

Texas Instruments, Inc., had the second highest annual earnings in its history in 1969 on record sales, with fourthquarter results making a major contribution to last year's performance of the leading producer of semiconductor products and other electronics.

The illusion that the Middle East could go on indefinitely in a more or less tolerable state of no-war, no-peace has been shattered this week along with the windows of Haifa and Damascus where Israeli and Syrian jets exchanged ominous feints.
Allegra Kent, back at the New York City Ballet after an absence of some months, danced her first Terpsichore of the season in Balanchine's "Apollo" at the State Theater last night.

The tentative settlement of the fourteen-week strike of nearly 150,000 General Electric workers represents a triumph for mediation. The company and the twelve unions that had formed a coalition to battle it on the picket line might, if left to their own devices, have staggered on for many more weeks without any real attempt at collective bargaining.

GARMISH PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, Jan. 30 (AP) Francoise Macchi led the French women on another victorious ski run in the Kandahar-World Cup downhill today, but their performance failed to detract from the best United States' showing of the season.

MOORESTOWN, N. J., Jan. 30 Mrs. Millicent Evison McEntee, a former Shakespearean actress, died yesterday in the Greenleaf Extension, a Quaker nursing home here, at the age of 93. She lived at Mount Rose, in Hopewell, and was the widow of Francis D. McEntee, an actor and a producer.
MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (Reuters) Egon Bahr, a close adviser of Chancellor Willy Brandt, spent six hours with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today discussing the prospects for a nonaggression treaty.

MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Jan. 30 (AP) Gustavo Thoeni, Italy's 18-year-old Alpine skiing expert, closed in on Patrick Russel of France, the World Cup leader by winning the giant slalom today for his second consecutive victory.
Temperatures during January were more than 10 degrees below normal, the Weather Bureau said yesterday in a summary for the month.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery's son married the daughter of Daphne Du Maurier, the author, today in a Kensington registry office.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 The United States command acknowledged today that there had been periodic air-toground engagements in North Vietnam since the bombing halt 15 months ago that had not been made public because they were considered to be "insignificant."
GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 30 (AP) Bob Verga scored the first 10 points of the game tonight and paced the Carolina Cougars over the Pittsburgh Pipers, 117-98, in an American Basketball Association game.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 30 Herbert A. Bell, an important figure in the infant radio industry of the 1920's, died of a heart attack at St. John's Hospital here today. He was 79 years old.

The Senate has passed overwhelmingly the Newspaper Preservation Act. But, even before the bill goes to the House, the need for any such measure has been rendered extremely dubious by Federal Court approval in Tucson of a joint publishing arrangement for the separately owned morning and afternoon papers in that Arizona city.

Lincoln Hospital, which serves 350,000 people in a predominantly Puerto Rican and Negro neighborhood in the South Bronx, was threatened yesterday with a take-over Monday morning by its community advisory board.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 30 A resolution condemning South Africa's "illegal" presence in South-West Africa was adopted today by the Security Council after a heated debate in which the Soviet Union and the United States accused each other of slander.
TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES: For many years the American people have been seeking, through their Government, the road to full employment with stable prices.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (UPI) Lew Alcindor tallied 27 points as the Milwaukee Bucks breezed to a 121-105 victory over the Chicago Bulls in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

THIRTY years ago a University of Southern Cali fornia law student and a young Duke University law school graduate, whose girl friends were roommates, became acquainted at a party following the U.S.C.-Duke Rose Bowl game.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30 Tony Jacklin, who is going to London to see the Queen next month, moved into a tie with Jack Nicklaus today for the lead in the $150,000 Andy Williams-San Diego open golf tournament.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Jan. 30 -Virgil M. Graham, former technical relations director for Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., who was a leader in standardizing electronic tubes, died yesterday. His age was 68.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 30 -Kenneth I. Wood, research consultant for the United Community Funds and Councils of America, died yesterday at the Stamford Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 232 Seaton Road.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 30 Harry Edwards, who as a Negro militant tried to organize an Olympics boycott in 1968, was appointed today as an untenured member of the sociology faculty at the University of California.
TOKYO, Jan. 30 Japan registered a record suplus of $2.28-billion in its international payments balance in 1969, the Government reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended Butcher Sherrerd, a Philadelphia broker-dealer, and censured a partner after finding violations of the registration provisions of Federal securities laws.

The Master Virtuosi of New York opened a special truncated season at Philharmonic Hall last night a few months after having announced there would be none at all. At the end of last season, this chamber or chestra conducted by Gene Forrell found itself with a loyal audience of subscribers but no Maecenas to pay the inevitable concert deficits for 1969-70.
Benjamin H. Schor former Criminal Court judge in Brooklyn, was acquitted yesterday morning of charges that he lied to a grand jury investigating irregularities in the State Liquor Authority in 1966.

A snug, bay-windowed brownstone half a block west of Central Park has become the battleground for a fierce struggle between a group of tenants and their landlord. The weapons: fists, threats, vagrants, broken locks, intermittent heat, mysterious phone calls in the middle of the night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The Federal Communications Commission announced today that telephone companies may not sell cable-television service directly to consumers in areas where they provide phone service.

Joseph Louis Searles 3d resigned yesterday as a member of the Lindsay administration and was then proposed for membership on the New York Stock Exchange. If he is approved, as is expected, he will become the first Negro to hold a seat on the nation's leading securities market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had filed a complaint in United States District Court in Los Angeles against the Enterprise Fund, Inc., a Los Angeles-based mutual fund, and the Shareholders Management Company, its principal underwriter.

The White Cross Stores, Inc., said yesterday that in view of an apparently unfavorable tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service, it appeared clear that its board of directors would have to cancel the proposed merger with the Zale Corporation.
OLYMPIA, Wash., Jan. 30 (AP) The Washington State Senate passed today a bill legalizing abortion after adding amendments that might run into opposition in the House.
The quarter-mile may be too short for Marty McGrady and the half-mile too long, but the 600 is just right.

MASERU, Lesotho, Jan. 30 The Prime Minister of Lesotho declared a state of emergency today and arrested his leading political opponent, who had just claimed victory in the first general election since independence in 1966.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) Billie Sol Estes lost today his first bid for parole from a 15year Federal prison term.
VIENNA Jan. 31 Is the celebrated Viennese charm nothing but schmaltzy complacency?
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 A Connecticut family of eight was granted a patent this week for a barbecue at which all eight car sit down to cook and eat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, insisted today that his nation's recent air strikes on the outskirts of Cairo were aimed principally at persuading the United Arab Republic to curtail its artillery and commando raids across the Suez Canal and at convincing the Egyptian people that their country was not capable of launching large-scale military operations against Israel.

Howard J. Samuels Jr., 17year-old son of a contender for Governor, went to Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday morning to face the same kind of charges brought each month against hundreds of other New York youths.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Jan. 30--Newton Dyckman Rich, former president and board chairman of the L. E. Myers Company, a Chicago contracting company, died of a heart attack at his home, 400 Lakewood Drive here, yesterday morning. He was 78 years old.

A judge of the state's highest court said last night that decisions of the United States Supreme Court and other Federal courts that reversed convictions in the state courts had created a "serious imbalance" in the administration of criminal justice.

Two years ago Community Planning Board 7, which covers Manhattan's West Side from Lincoln Center to Columbia University, put forth the idea that Broadway and 96th Street would be an ideal site for a major department store. No one objected.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 30 (UPI) Sea Castle, the 9-10 favorite of 7,914 fans, romped to a 13length victory in the Glendale Purse at the Bowie race course today.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP) George Frenn, a 28-yearold schoolteacher, broke the listed world record for the 35pound weight throw today with a heave of 71 feet 3 inches.

Predicted-log competitors, fearing their sport may be getting too stodgy, are doing something about it. With their annual seminar scheduled to start at 10:30 this morning in the South America Room of the Coliseum, they have asked an attractive 23-year-old girl to be the principal speaker.

Paul Jennings, president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, which is on strike against the General Electric Company, received last night the first Norman Thomas Award presented by the Socialist Party, U.S.A.

The 1970 new-issue market may be one in which investors show a strong reluctance to buy purely speculative stocksexcept at very low prices and one in which underwriters will be forced to resort to imaginative techniques to bring companies successfully to market.
Xerox Data Systems, a subsidiary of the Xerox Corporation, announced yesterday it was cutting 20 per cent from its prices for computer system interface units.

MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP) Army Engineers spent $342,358 to build a 150-foot square helicopter landing pad just off President Nixon's waterfront Key Biscayne compound, an official of the company that built it said today.

Media General, Inc., a rapidly expanding Southern communications corporation, has agreed to acquire The Evening News of Newark and two of the New Jersey newspaper's other properties, a newsprint processing company and an engraving plant.

CORNING, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP) State police arrested Allen Smith of Hinsdale today on a charge of "contemptuous display of the American flag" because his small foreign car was painted with stars and stripes.

CAIRO, Jan. 31--Cairo's military spokesman said tonight that an Egyptian infantry company crossed the Suez Canal early today and ambushed an Israeli armored patrol, destroying the vehicles and killing all the occupants.

IF you think you have troubles, turn on Channel 13 at 10:30 tomorrow night and see "Hospital," Frederick Wiseman's new 90minute documentary. It may make you feel lucky just to be alive. NEWTON, N. J., Jan. 31-- Miss Marjorie Priscilla Cummings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benton Pierce Cummings, was married here today to Thor Fredrik Wilcox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Wilcox of Cambridge, Mass., where his father is dean of general education at Harvard.
A new "baby boom" has begun in New York City, the Health Department reported yesterday, with expectations that it may reach record levels despite expanded efforts to provide family planning.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 31--In the week since the Government discovered that Prof. Peng Ming-min, a leading advocate of Taiwanese independence from Chinese Nationalist rule, had escaped from Taiwan, the security police have been conducting an intensive investigation to learn how he managed it.
They've stopped asking, "What's John Lindsay really like?" This year they're asking, "Is there real a 'New Lindsay'?"

THERE was a pervasive spirit of gloom--but no panic --in Wall Street last week as the stock market con tinued its winter plunge to the lowest levels in more than six years. Despondency was rampant as the leading stock "averages sustained their worst weekly losses in six months and the bond market suffered another period of turmoil, with interest rates soaring and prices slipping.

SUMMIT, N. J., Jan. 31-- Mr. and Mrs. Sturgis S. Wilson have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Bowes Wilson of Brookline, Mass., to Morris Randall Brooke. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Clymer Brooke of Key Largo, Fla.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 31-Miss Christy Bogart Latham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lindsay Latham of Morristown, was married this afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church to Paul Denman Fowler, son of Mrs. Willis Fowler of St. James, L. I., and Benjamin Prince Fowler of New York.

THE First National City Bank has come to the rescue of the stalled 225acre Blue Hill office development in Rockland County, N. Y., which had left the Uris Buildings Corporation abashed because of the lack of adequate initial construction financing.
ST. CLAIR, Mich., Jan. 31-- Michigan's Republican leaders chose 25 potential candidates today for the Senate race this fall, with George and Lenore Romney heading the list.
A ground-breaking ceremony was held last week for a new $61-million campus for Bronx Community College to be constructed over the subway storage yards at Bedford Park Boulevard and Paul Avenue.
GLEN HEAD, L. I., Jan. 31 --Miss Barbara Hussennetter and Lieut. Ivan G. Larsh of the Marine Corps were married here today in Our Savior's Lutheran Church by the Rev. Maury Drum, the pastor.

Hoffman to let Ramsey Clark, the former United States Attorney General, testify before the jury in the trial of the "Chicago Seven" constitutes the ultimate outrage in a trial that has become the shame of American justice. FOR years, whenever "the three B's" were mentioned, music lovers knew automatical ly that Bach, Beethoven and Brahms were what was meant. Now, on a new Angel release, those old masters are getting a little competition for their proprietorship of the initial.
Army and Long Island University justified their listing among the nation's best defensive teams yesterday, but unfortunately both also lived up to their other reputations--they couldn't score.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 31 --Army's track team won 10 of 13 events today against Penn State and rolled to its fifth victory in six meets this season. The score was 81-28.
DALLAS, Jan. 31 (AP)--New York's slow brand of play kept Dallas off balance as the Nets scored a 113-108 American Basketball Association victory over the Chaparrals tonight.

QUOGUE, L. I., Jan. 31-- Miss Wendy Margaret Afton was married in the Presbyterian church here today to Richard Ernest Rieder, a lawyer with Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside Wolff in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. R. Dewitt, Mallery of All Saints Episcopal Church in New York.

A leading biologist expressed fear yesterday that a planned nationwide campus teach-in on pollution of the environment could turn into a "glamorous event and a stupendous failure" unless it was backed up with long-range philosophy.

Australia's hope to become its America's Cup challenger next September has been named Gretel II. She is expected to be launched this week and shipped to the United States in May or early June.

If the late 1950's and early 1960's were not a golden age in the generally gloomy history of American cities, they are at least beginning to appear, in retrospect, as a brief sunlit hour, a time when hope and energy and confidence flourished. In city after city, there was renewed belief that although the problems were formidable, they could be overcome. Under the leadership of an astonishing variety of mayors, genuine headway was being made.

Donna Caponi, winner of the United States women's open golf tournament last year and the third leading money winner on the women's tour, will be honored at the annual awards dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers' Association on Feb. 23.
GARMISCH, Germany, Jan. 31--The world's leading men ski racers went on strike today and forced postponement of the Arlberg Kandahar downhill because of poor visibility.

TOM GORMAN, a local boy from the Fordham Road section of the Bronx, made good in the big leagues--as an umpire. The New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association will rule him safe at home tonight at the Hotel Americana during their annual eating-and-drinking talkathon. He will be honored when he is presented the Bill Slocum Award for "long and distinguished service to baseball."
HONG KONG, Jan. 31 Reuters)--Foreign newsmen got a rare closeup look at Mao Tse-tong in a film show here this week.
An assortment of modern paintings, drawings and sculpture--mostly French--will be auctioned on Wednesday at 2 P.M. in the first of three sales at the Park-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
Joseph Rivera, a physicist with the environmental studies division of the Atomic Energy Commission here, died yesterday following a heart attack at his home in Old Bridge, N. J. He was 37 years old.

HOUSTON, Jan. 31--(AP) --The Apollo 13 moonwalkers will be able to take drinks of water while exploring the lunar surface in April.

The world champion New York Mets counted 18 players set for the 1970 season yesterday, with the announcement that three of their younger members had signed contracts. JERUSALEM--The Middle East reverberated last week to the relatively routine thunder of a sonic boom. This one was made by a Syrian MIG-21 over Haifa, however. It was the first such Arab aerial incursion since the 1967 war.

HEERENVEEN, the Netherlands, Jan. 31 (AP)--Nina Statkevich of the Soviet Union finished second in the 500-meter sprint, won the 1,500 and took the half-way lead today in the European women's speed skating championships. Her time for the 1,500-meter race was 2 minutes 24.92 seconds.

The Rutgers track and field team beat Columbia, 57-52, in a dual meet at the Baker Field Airdome yesterday. The Scarlet Knights now have a 1-1 wonlost record for the indoor track season, while Columbia is 1-1-1.

Two packages of diamonds valued at $82,874 were stolen yesterday by hijackers near Kennedy International Airport half an hour before the gems were to be placed aboard a Japan Airlines flight to Tokyo.

KING CITY, Calif.-I first saw Mission San Antonio de Padua 37 years ago as a member of a touring party stuck in the mud for three days and nights. We managed to summon a tow car from King City, on U.S. 101 some 23 miles to the northeast, but it, too, mired down in the gumbo of the flooded road, and a second truck had to be sent out to rescue it-and us.

Naturally, when the piece appeared quite a few letters came flying in, some from those very play wrights I was being nosy about.

AIBANY, Feb. 1--State Senator John J. Marchi has ruled out a race for the House of Representatives this fall, but says he still wakes up each morning with "my Hamlet thing" about the United States Senate.
WASHINGTON, Feb.2 The nation's long-haul airlines were preparing today for the second round in a battle over a Civil Aeronautics Board air fare plan.
Steel production last week was 1 per cent higher than in week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Future prices of frozen orange juice concentrate which had been dropping for some time, rose yesterday on no particularly bullish news.

MASILI, the Philippines, Feb. 1-"If change can be peaceful, that would be best," old Raimundo Guevara said. "But if things go on like this, I'm afraid the only way to get change is going to be by revolution."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed today that a regional Middle East peace conference be convened, including Moslem states such as Turkey and Iran alongside the militant Arab governments and Israel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Two friends who met while touring Everglades National Park a few years ago and who now explore the park together each February filed suit today to stop use of a training airstrip in South Florida, which they contend will destroy the Everglades.
A projected textile trade deficit of $1.4-billion last year, up sharply from the $1.1-billion deficit in 1968, helps explain why there is pressure in the United States to curb textile imports.
The New York State Banking Board has raised the percentage of time deposits that savings banks and savings and loan associations may hold relative to total deposits to 40 per cent, from 15.

WASHINGTON Suddenly, the new American concern for the environment is evidenced everywhere from student activists' teach-ins to the speeches of the big industrialists. This concern even got official recognition in President Nixon's State of the Union Message. The Everglades have been saved, against all odds, and Mr. Nixon says he will now spend all the money Congress has appropriated to clean up the waters.

David Merrick, the theatrical producer, apparently is stepping up his war at least his war of nerves against the management of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation.

OSSINING, N. Y., Feb. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Walter Archibald Stanley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marnie Isabelle Stanley, to Andrew Wallace Heck, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Cameron Heck of Cliffside Park, N.J.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 Joseph C. Swidler was sworn in today as chairman of the much-criticized Public Service Commission and quickly pledged an effort to assure that consumers would have a voice in the regulation of the state's utilities.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2 (AP) The police arrested a signalman today in the crash last night of a cross-country express and a stalled commuter train in which 160 were said to have been killed and 250 injured.

Birny Mason Jr., chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, said in a preliminary report yesterday that the company's net income in 1969 increased 19 per cent to $186.2-million, or $3.08 a share, from a net of $157.0million, or $2.60 a share, the year before.

FORMAL announcement of the election by the special old-timers' committee of three new members to the Hall of Fame was made the other night during the 47th annual midwinter bash of the Baseball Writers Association's New York Chapter. Those voted enshrinement at Cooperstown, N. Y., were Earle Combs, Yankee center fielder during the Murderers Row era; Jesse Haines, Cardinal pitcher, and Ford Frick, former commissioner.
The American Stock Exchange ended in the plus column for the first time in seven sessions yesterday on slightly stepped-up trading.

The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in sales of natural gas, revenues and net income for 1969. W. K. Sanders, chairman and chief executive officer, pointed out that natural gas sales topped the trillion level for the first timer reaching 1.33-trillion cubic feet-or 6 per cent over the 1968 level of gas sales.

Rastelli, head of open heart surgical research at the Mayo Clinic and twice a winner of American Medical Association gold medals, died in a Rochester hospital today of Hodgkin's disease a progressive deterioration of the kidneys and spleen. He was 36 years old.

IT USED to be a flowered hat or a navy blue suit that a woman would rush out to buy when the snow was on the ground and she hoped to hasten spring. But these are more prosaic times. Today she's more likely to rush the season with a raincoat, according to Abbe Rabiner.

The Boston Patriots, pro foot ball's orphans, remain without shelter. LATE last month in his State of the Union ad dress, President Nixon made a stirring appeal for an environmental cleanup, directing the nation's already awakened concern to what may be the major domestic effort of the 1970's.

A 21-year-old prisoner who had pleaded guilty to two holdup murder charges and faced a life sentence raced past his guards yesterday and escaped from the basement of the State Supreme Court Building in the Brooklyn Civic Center.

MIAMI, Feb.2 (AP) Jim (Ding) Schoonmakar conquered 20-knot winds today and won the first race in the Bacardi Cup sailing series.

Two boys, 16 and 15 years old, brandished harmonicas as simulated guns in a Queens bank yesterday and were given $8,000 by a frightened teller moments before two passing patrolmen entered and captured the boys.

President Nixon has produced a budget for fiscal 1971 that does not measure up to the needs of the nation on either economic or social grounds. It might be said of Beethoven's Diabelli Variations that never have so many notes been owed to so few. This hourlong work, which grows out of a harmless little waltz by Diabelli like an oak tree out of an acorn, is one of the great piano pieces.

The Continental Can Company realized an 8.3 per cent increase in annual earnings and 4.3 per cent in the fourth quarter, Ellison L. Hazard, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday. He said sales and earnings in 1969 were the highest in its history for the sixth successive year.
The stock market, bolstered somewhat by hopes of lower interest rates, rallied yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrial average posted its first advance in seven sessions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) Negotiators seeking to avoid a nationwide rail shutdown next week met for two hours today, and the chief Government mediator expressed hope that some progress might now be possible in the stalemate.

Five days a week, people try to get Frank Tomeo to buy commercial time on television. Yesterday, Tomeo sold instead of bought. The product he sold was himself, talking his way into the Casey 600 Friday night in the 51st annual Knights of Columbus indoor track meet at Madison Square Garden.
TRENTON, Feb. 2 The overwhelming Republican majority in the Assembly tonight approved Gov. William T. Cahill's request to increase New Jersey's 3 per cent sales tax to 5 per cent.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) A High Court judge who is a physician ruled today that surgery could not change a person's sex.
GENEVA, Feb. 2 (Reuters) Bank Hentsch et Cie. said today five Swiss banks had set up the Samurai Fund to invest in Japanese stocks.

With a Korean tenor, Jae Woo Lee, as the Duke of Mantua and a fetching young woman, Eve Queler, on the podium, last night's concert version of "Rigoletto" at Alice Tully Hall possessed a great deal of curiosity value. And the performance, by the Opera Orchestra of New York, did present a recognizable, economy-sized picture of Verdi's family-circle tale of malediction, rape and murder.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Sixty-five members of the antiwar movement filed suit against the Dow Chemical Company in district court today, charging that Dow supplies the United States Government "with the instrumentalities to violate international law" and should be made to stop.
A study now circulating among top officials of the Board of Education shows that absenteeism among the city's 60,000 public school teachers has risen 50 per cent in the last three school years.

The Waterman-Bic Pen Corporation has written off Ted Bates after nine years and gone to one-year-old Kurtz, Kambanis, Symon, Inc., founded by three former Tinker men. Bic bills $4-million, just about enough to double the size of the agency.
PARIS, Feb. 2 Jean Anouilh's latest play, "Les Poissons Rouges" (The Goldfish) is receiving an enthusiastic welcome from the critics.

Stanley Kubrick, who has not made a film since the release nearly two years ago of his highly successful futuristic adventure, "2001: A Space Odyssey," has been signed to write, direct and produce "A Clockwork Orange" for Warner Brothers release. The film will be an adaptation of Anthony Burgess's novel published here in 1963 by W.W. Norton.
AUBURN, Ala., Feb. 2 (AP)Terry Mills's 25-foot field goal with 11 seconds remaining tonight gave second-ranked Kentucky an 84-83 victory over Auburn in a Southeastern Conference basketball game.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Acting on a plea by Gov. Edgar D. Whitcomb, the Supreme Court today temporarily blocked the reapportionment of all state legislative districts in Indiana.

HONG KONG, Feb. 2 (UPI) Two United States banks have joined with two other banks to help provide financing for enterprises in Australia, New Zealand and elsewhere in the Pacific, it was announced today.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 2Capt. Robert E. Lindquist, former master of the luxury liner Constitution, died today at his home here. He was 59 years old.

The appointment of Dr. William J. McGill as president of Columbia University brings to a successful conclusion a search in which trustees, faculty and students joined in effective cooperation. Their painstaking task was complicated by the need for overcoming the apprehensions that linger after months of campus confrontation and hostilities in 1968.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 The Soviet Union was reported tonight to have advised the United States of its intention to increase substantially and immediately its shipments of weapons, including advanced jet aircraft, to the United Arab Republic.

AFTER a Mets-like mistake in the expansion draft that threatened to bury the Pittsburgh Penguins for years, the club with one of the sorriest nicknames in sports has made it as a playoff contender in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The Labor Department said today that workers' output per manhour in the private economy rose moderately in the last quarter of 1969, but the year's gain of nine-tenths of 1 per cent was the smallest since 1956.

Calling the case "the tip of an iceberg, Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts announced yesterday the indictment of four men on charges of filing an inflated claim of loss with a fire insurance company after a fire in a Bronx butcher shop.

Harold LeVine; founder and former president of the National Brick Company in Long Island City, Queens, which was sold in 1953 to the United States Plywood Corporation,died Thursday in Hollywood, Fla. He was 78 years old.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 2 Gimbels opened a department store here today that virtually completed the State Street Urban Renewal Project, a 50-acre Federally aided downtown redevelopment program begun almost 10 years ago.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 The authority to limit imports must rest in the hands of the President and not Congress, Senator John D. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) The state of Mississippi asked the Supreme Court today to block the Federal Government's school desegregation directives. Attorney General John N. Mitchell and Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, were named defendants.
The President's Budget Message and the innate appeal of an 8 per cent interest rate on Treasury notes gave the government bond market a substantial lift yesterday afternoon.

In a three-pronged move to prod more activity into the loan program for minorityoperated businesses, Senator Jacob K. Javits, representatives of New York area commercial banks and officials of the Small Business Administration met yesterday to announce plans for some changes.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 2 Jose Figueres Ferrer, a leader for democratic social reform in Latin America, has won the Presidency of Costa Rica by an impressive margin, according to official returns from yesterday's election.
William J. McGill, chancellor of the University of California at San Diego, was named president of Columbia University yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Angelo Dundee, the manager and trainer, is the author of one of the ultimate maxims of boxing: "In the life of every fighter, there comes a time when you've got to put him in with somebody that can fight. "
Miss JoAnn Veronica Giffuni, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Giffuni of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married in Paris yesterday to Michael Sher, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Sher of New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 When the Democrats left office a year ago, their plans called for close to $1-billion a year to be spent for Model Cities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Judge G. Harrold Carswell was said by a Senate witness today to have been so "insulting and hostile" to Negro lawyers that young civil rights attorneys who were to appear before him were previously drilled in making their arguments while being harassed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Negroes have made substantial gains in education, income and housing in recent years but still lag behind whites, two Federal agencies reported today.

Lord Taylor, the largest store division of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, announced yesterday the appointments of a new executive vice president,four senior vice presidents and three vice presidents.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 Franklin D. Roosevelt, usually described by Soviet writers as a friend of the Soviet Union, is portrayed in a new play here as having ordered development of an atomic bomb to give the United States domination over the Soviet Union and the rest of the world.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 2 (AP) A lawyer who helped organize an agency offering a package deal for abortions in England pleaded not guilty in Springfield District Court today to charges brought against him and his agency by the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Nixon's pledge to take "a new and searching look at American education" is not spelled out but it is hinted in his budget for the fiscal year 1971.

MASERU, Lesotho, Feb. 2 (Reuters) Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan rounded up more political opponents today while tightening his grip on this country, an enclave in South Africa, where he has ruled by decree since last week.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 2--William P. Ellenburg, Cleveland's police chief for one week, denied today reports published here and in Detroit over the weekend that he had accepted payoffs to shield a Detroit abortion operation.
GAINESVILLE, Fla. Before his second birthday, Ivan Lucius James Mitchell Jr., nicknamed "Peco" by his father because the little boy was so pink at birth, was withdrawn and very shy.

NEWARK, Feb. 2-Howard Samuels, New York industrialist who is running for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York, presided tonight at a meeting called to improve communication between Newark's black and white communities.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 Earl Caldwell, correspondent for The New York Times in the newspaper's bureau here, was served today with a subpoena requiring his testimony before a Federal grand jury that has been investigating the Black Panther party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 The disarmament subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee laid down a new challenge to the Administration today by questioning President Nixon's decision to expand the Safeguard missile defense system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 President Nixon's proposed budget seeks funds to start the construction of a Federal corrections center in New York City and to expand customs facilities at Kennedy International Airport to service the new jumbo jets.

The Consolidated Edison Company closed its Indian Point One nuclear plant at Buchanan, N.Y., for three days last month because "a very substantial number" of fish were killed when they were drawn from the Hudson River into conduits that supply water to the plant.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art and city representatives will meet this week with Local 1503 of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes in an effort to avert a strike by the museum's guards, attendants and maintenance men.

The strike of gravediggers is now in its fourth grisly week. Several thousand unburied bodies lie in vaults, garages, tents and other storage places at cemeteries in the metropolitan area. For anguished families the pain of this humiliation to the dead grows daily more insupportable.
