WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 4 Skiing continues to be a big item at the United States Military Academy. Every afternoon after classes, when conditions are favorable, hundreds of cadets can be found whizzing down the reservation's modest-sized slopes.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz disclosed yesterday that his office had uncovered 361 Wall Street workers with criminal records including 14 principals and partners of Wall Street firms.
Carnegie Hall wasn't quite an armed camp last night for the program by David Oistrakh, violinist, and Sviatoslav Richter, pianist, but it almost looked it.

LITTLE SILVER, N.J., Feb. 4 David W. Marshall Sr., a senior management consultant for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in New York, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, after a long illness. He was 49 years old.

TRENTON, Feb. 4 A special investigator for the State Commission of Investigation presented evidence today that John Gawler, the Monmouth County chief of detectives who committed suicide last October, was an embezzler. He indicated that Chief Gawler had taken nearly $58,000 from a revolving fund earmarked for underworld informants.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 Within hours after a $25,000-a-year state official's name was published in a list of registered lobbyists here today, he notified the Governor's office that he would resign the lobbying job "immediately."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, told Congress today that the age of triumphant science and technology was forcing man into a new philosophical era based on the "why" of living.
Arthur J. Rooney, the longtime president of the Pittsburgh Steelers, received and gave an award yesterday at two ceremonies honoring professional football figures.

STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 4 Raymond Barre, vice president of the executive commission of the European Economic Community, said today that the group had a trade deficit of about $100-million in 1969 compared with a surplus of $1.75-billion in 1968.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 A South Vietnamese policeman has won a medal of honor and national recognition for his actions the night of Jan. 15, when he refused a $10 bribe.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed higher yesterday, although many issues finished below the day's high. Sentiment .was influenced by Tuesday's rally on Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The same group of advertising industry people that has been hearing the call for selfregulation heard today from a panel of experts that it can't be done.

The brief market rally powered by the remarks of David M. Kennedy, Secretary of the Treasury, ran out of fuel yesterday. Leading stock-market indicators, after showing token strength in the first hour and a half, staged a mild reversal for the rest of the session.

It is hard to believe that the New York City Ballet has waited 20 years for Melissa Hayden's local debut in the ballerina role of "Ballet Imperial," but that was apparently what took place at the State Theater last night.
The Tappan Company, a large appliance manufacturer, announced yesterday it planned to increase prices on all dealer products by about 3 per cent, effective Feb. 16.

Along Brooklyn's sprawling waterfront where a few years ago the Mafia "button men," or common soldiers, of the Gallo Brothers gang waged a murderous but unsuccessful revolt against their bosses in the organized-crime family of the late Joseph Profaci a new kind of button man is making the scene.

LIGHTHOUSE POINT, Fla., Feb. 4 Harold Kraus, a former hotel executive in New York City, died here yesterday of cancer. He was 61 years old, and owned and operated the Edgewater Motor Inn in Fort Lauderdale.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 4 Cesare Gennari, the track su perintendent at Roosevelt Raceway, does not carry a thermometer, or an anemometer. Therefore, he cold only guess upon his arrival at the raceway at 6:20 A.M. that the temperature was 6 degrees and the wind velocity 45 miles an hour.
Soybean and grain prices, which had been rising recently, dropped back yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade because of profit taking.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 4 Mrs. G. Leonard Johnson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Amy Johnson, to Dr. John Archibald Wood, also of Englewood. The prospective bride is a daughter also of the late Dr. G. Leonard Johnson and her flance is the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Archibald O. M. Wood of Far Rockaway, Queens, New York.
They have a very funny railroad here in New York. It is called the Long Island.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4--The son of Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey was released on $200 bail today, charged with ilegal possession of marijuana.
The two-day advance on the American Stock Exchange ended abruptly yesterday as the list mostly declined in quiet trading.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Americans who flee to Canada to escape the draft or to desert from the armed forces remain a relatively minor but annoying problem for Government and military officials here but there is not much they can do about it.

The New York City police and two Federal agencies have joined in a search for the source of a number of blank Navy discharge papers and drivers' license forms that's turned up recently in a raid on an East Side apartment.

In a part of the world where democracy is in short supply, tiny Costa Rica perseveres along freedom's road. Doing what comes naturally, a half-million voters have brought off the country's fifth peaceful presidential election in twenty years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) Negotiations supervised by the National Mediation Board continued today between National Airlines and the striking Air Lines Employes Association.
Operations of American Brands, Inc., in 1969 resulted in record sales and earnings for the fall year and for the fourth quarter, Robert B. Walker, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday.

WEBERN's Five Pieces for orchestra had been scheduled, but Franco Donatoni's "Puppenspiel" No. 2 instead turned up. Claudio Abbado, guest conductor of the Boston Symphony last night in Philharmonic Hall, made the last-minute substitution.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 4 A spokesman for the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation confirmed here today that its Pittsburgh Works, which account for nearly a third of the company's total output, lost money last year.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 5 (AP) North Vietnamese infantrymen assaulted a remote United States fire base north of Saigon yesterday, then regrouped and attacked an American patrol sweeping the perimeter.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Two prominent Republicans, John W. Gardner and Milton S. Eisenhower, made it known today that they considered President Nixon's new budget inadequate for domestic needs.

A last-minute wage offer to mechanics of the Inter-City Transportation Company averted a strike against the New Jersey bus company yesterday. The offer, an ,increase of 60 cents over two years, was made after the mechanics had already voted to strike. A vote on the new offer was set for 10 A.M today and the strike deadline postponed until midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Three Democratic Senators urged tonight that Judge G. Harrold Carswell, President Nixon's nominee for the Supreme Court, be encouraged to answer a broad range of questions before the Judiciary Committee votes on his nomination.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4 Mrs. Edward L. Katzenbach, Sr., a prominent New Jersey educator and the mother of former Attorney General Nicholas deB, Katzenbach, died here today at her home. She was 87 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Another meeting between the United States and Communist China has been scheduled in Warsaw for Feb. 20, only one month after the first formal contact between the two governments in over two years.

The Curtis Publishing Company said yesterday it has a study under way to determine whether it would be in the best interest of its shareholders to sell all or part of the assets of the magazine owned by the Saturday Evening Post Company.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 The American Motors Corporation reported today a $15,663,000 loss for its first fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31. The loss equaled 64 cents a share and was blamed on a fall strike. It contrasted with a profit of $4.54million, or 24 cents a share, the year before.

The Zero Manufacturing Company announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Rossmoor Corporation and its subsidiaries and affiliates for 2.7-million shares of Zero common stock valued at about $25million.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4--William P. Ellenburg, Cleveland's chief of police, resigned after 10 days in office today, continuing to deny charges that he took money from a Mafia attorney while a member of the Detroit police force.

John M. Hopkins, secretarytreasurer of the Parsons-Jurden Corporation, and a specialist in engineering law, died Monday at the Beekman-Downtown Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 151 Heritage Hill Road in New Canaan, Conn.
One bright spot in President Nixon's otherwise disappointing proposals for foreign aid in his 1971 budget message is the President's plan to shift more foreign assistance to multilateral agencies.
BERLIN, Feb. 4 The United States Ambassador to West Germany, Kenneth Rush, today challenged Communist assertions that West Berlin was on East German territory or within its borders.
FRED CARR, the enigmatic money manager who built the tiny Enterprise Fund into a giant of three-quarter-billion dollars, has opened shop in Century City, Los Angeles, at 1801 Avenue of the Stars.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 (AP) Shaker Heights policemen removed a large box of explosives, a carbine and several boxes of ammunition tonight from the suburban home of a 21-year-old man believed to have bombed the Shaker Heights Municipal Building Monday night, the police chief said.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 Governor Rockefeller's new $7.3-billion budget drew criticism today from Mayor Lindsay and Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

ATLANTA, Feb. 4 The Atlanta Hawks, goaded by Lou Hudson and elusive Walt Hazzard, savored sweet revenge tonight by handing the New York Knickerbockers their worst defeat of the National Basketball Association season, 111-96, before 6,551 delighted fans at Alexander Memorial Coliseum.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP) Bill Sullivan, president of the Boston Patriots, said today the club generally was discouraging applications for transfer of the pro football franchise until all efforts to remain in Boston were exhausted.
ALBANY, Feb. 4 The Legislature was urged by the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime today to consider the legaliza tion of numbers gambling as a method of undercutting organized crime.
The impact of Treasury Secretary David M. Kennedy's words lingered on yesterday, pushing bond prices higher and reducing interest rates.
The appointment of two priests in the New York Archdiocese as Auxiliary Bishops to Cardinal Cooke was announced yesterday by Archbishop Luigi Raimondi, the apostolic delegate to the United States.

LAT SEN, Laos, Feb. 2 About 7,000 people live here and perhaps 10,000 more in refugee centers elsewhere on the Plaine des Jarres. But by the end of next week the area will probably be empty except for Government soldiers girding for an expected Communist offensive and for people who, rather than face one more uprooting, will go into hiding and wait for the battle to pass.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4 Benny Carter, the alto saxophonist, band leader and arranger who was a major influence in jazz in the 1930's, made one of his rare appearances last night in the East since he settled in Los Angeles 25 years ago.

The National Alliance of Businessmen has named Gerard M. Peterson as executive vice president of operations, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Peterson is an assistant secretary of the group insurance division of Aetna Life and Casualty.
Miss Alice Elstein, a senior at Russell Sage College, plans to be married in June to Joseph Y. Rudnick, a student in his third year at Albany Medical College.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) Two national peace groups are making plans for 70 days of fasting in Washington to protest the war in Vietnam.

LONDON, Feb. 4 President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic said tonight that he was ready to ask the Soviet Union for more arms if the United States supplied more Phantom and Skyhawk jets to Israel.

RICHMOND, Feb. 4 On Jan. 17, a 45-year-old lawyer from Big Stone Gap in the hill country of western Virginia stood beneath the elegant Ionic portico of the Virginia State Capitol a building that once housed the government of the Confederacy and quoted Abraham Lincoln on the subject of racial understanding.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Senator Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, defended the Administration's Vietnam policy today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, asserting that President Nixon's program of troop withdrawal was "irreversible."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans and his chief textile official both predicted today "meaningful restraints" on imports of textiles this year if not by a voluntary international agreement, then by action of the Congress.

Mrs. Richard M. Nixon was installed as honorary president of the Girl Scouts yesterday, following a tradition for First Ladies since Mrs. Woodrow Wilson became honorary president of the organization in 1917.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had won a series of stop-gap commitments from the Penn Central to alleviate the "deplorable conditions" on the Hudson and Harlem commuter divisions within "weeks or months."
CINCINNATI, Feb. 4 (UPI) The Seattle Supersonics scored 10 straight points in the fourth quarter tonight en route to a 121-115 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 Arthur Ashe had a desperate fight tonight to avoid elimination in the $60,000 International Tennis Players Association indoor open tournament.

MANILA, Feb. 4 "The more demonstrations there are against corrupt officials, the better are my chances for reforming the government," President Ferdinand E. Marcos said in an interview here today. "But violence must stop."

BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, Feb. 5 (UPI) The United States Embassy said today that a B-52 bomber en route to a Vietnam mission dropped its 30-ton bomb load on a sparsely populated region of Thailand by accident Monday. Two women were reported wounded.
A gift of $136-million worth of stock in Avon Products, Inc., was given late last year to fund a new private foundation by W. Van Alan Clark, the retired chairman of the company, and his wife.
Francis I. duPont Co., a major brokerage house and one of the largest remaining partnerships on Wall Street, disclosed yesterday that it incurred a loss of $7.7-million in 1969.

The Penn Central Company yesterday reported that its consolidated earnings on a preliminary basis for 1969 dropped to $4,388,000, or 18 cents a share. This contrasted with restated 1968 earnings of $86,961,000, or $3.77 a share.

ARDSLEY, N. Y., Feb. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah V. Dillon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Dudley Dillon, to Rohert Holley Jr., son of Mrs. Holley of Cherry Hill, N. J., and the late Mr. Holley.
ON the verge of 40, few blue-eyed blondes wear such an air of eager expectancy. Unless, like Midge Turk and Dacia Van Antwerp, they spent most of their adult years in a convent.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 4 Secretary General Thant's representative in Nigeria, Brigadier Said Uddin Khan of Pakistan, reported today that by last Saturday law and order were "almost back to normal" in the former Biafran enclave and that "the relief picture is improving every day."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) Government licensing of reporters was suggested today by a member of the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Manuufacturers' inventories rose sharply in relation to sales in December, the Commerce Department reported today.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 Schools in this resort community were peacefully desegregated today, but an organized boycott cut white attendance sharply at several schools affected by a busing plan ordered by a Federal judge.

KINGSTON, R.I., Feb. 4 A 15-hour delay did not bother the St. John's basketball team as it finished the job it started last night by routing Rhode Island, 85-67, this afternoon.
The appointments of two American scholars who will serve as George Eastman Visiting Professors at Oxford University will be announced today.
The formation of a five-center network to counsel families and treat patients with genetic disorders was announced yesterday by the National Foundation for Genetics and Neuromuscular Diseases.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (UPI) Stan Mikita scored a goal and had four assists tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to an 8-4 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The supplemental, or unscheduled "charter," airlines made their last stand today against reduced group fares to Europe on the major scheduled carriers.

Between his American concert debut in 1963 at Carnegie Hall and his one-man show, called simply "Charles Aznavour," which began a three-week run at the Music Box Theater last night, the French singer-composer has grown stronger as a performer.

MANY of the leading bridge clubs in the met ropolitan area offer teaching programs as well as games. One of the most ambitious in this direction is the Gotham Club, 27 West 72d Street, which now offers instruction by Irving Kass, Dr. William Lipton and George Kennedy, all prominent New York experts.

Paul P. Rao Jr. , a former New York City Tax Commissioner, announced yesterday that he would challenge Representative Edward I. Koch for renomination as the Democratic candidate in the 17th Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended a 1968 registration statement of Laser Nucleonics, Inc., covering the proposed public offering of 250,000 shares of common stock after the S.E.C. found it contained untrue and misleading statements.
United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr. picked two former members of his predecessor's staff yesterday for the first two appointments he has made since taking office last month.

Manhattan defeated Fordham in swimming, 55-49, at the Rose Hill pool last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The Investment Company Institute decided to stop fighting legislation that would force many mutual funds to reduce their charges to investors only after it was told that the White House would refuse to help kill the bill, it has been learned.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today to require Crowell Collier Macmillan, Inc., to divest itself of C. G. Conn, Ltd., and Uniforms by Ostwald, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 After a scheduled two hours of debate tomorrow, the House of Representatives will vote on a bill authorizing increased cutting of timber in the national forests.
ELATH, Israel The road south from this port city, an apparent road to nowhere, has been carrying a lot of traffic these days.
The General Electric Company and its two biggest electrical unions signed formal agreements yesterday, ending strikes that began last Oct. 27.

Viviane Bertolami, violinist, and Norine Harris, pianist, who have been performing together for five years and who have appeared previously in New York, came to the New York Cultural Center last night to play Beethoven's "Kreutzer" Sonata, Stravinsky's Suite Italienne (a chamber-music version of the ballet "Pulcinella") and Enesco's Sonata No. 3 in A minor.

Less than 20 years ago, there was only one major indoor track meet on most weekends meet or stayed home. Now, there are more meets on some weekends than there used to be in a month.
Sir Noel Coward, as he has been known since becoming a Knight on Jan. 1, arrives at Kennedy International Airport at 8:45 tonight.
Louise Bogan, one of the most distinguished lyric poets in the English language, died yesterday at her home at 709 West 169th Street. She was 72 years old.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Feb. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Frederick van Beuren Joy have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Halsted Greacen Joy, to Paul Kevin King of Boston. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. King of Arlington, Mass.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 A melee broke out at the Chicago conspiracy trial today, with Federal marshals and the defendants scuffling and shoving in the well of the court.

At a time when the cost of living runs high, one price that older persons must pay is moving down. The Equitable Life Assurance Society has just announced a 2 to 2 per cent cut in the cost of a life or refund immediate annuity. This comes at a time when a number of older persons have been discouraged by the action of their stocks or mutual fund shares.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 4 President Nixon sent a message to the Inter-American Economic Conference here today saying that he had asked Congress for substantial new funds to help finance Latin-American development.

Bernard Cornfeld, who heads a $2.5-billion overseas mutual fund complex, charged yesterday that the securities industry in this country has come under a "powerful and possibly disastrous attack" that could cripple its effectiveness and cause severe damage to the economy in general.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago suggested today that the nation's growing housing shortage might be eased by utilizing air space over rivers, highways, railroads and other urban areas.

Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark expressed sharp disagreement yesterday with a Justice Department contention that Government subpoenas for reporters' notes, unedited films and other records of the news media represented no departure from past policy.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 The Hillel Foundation at the University of Pennsylvania has voted to establish a draft sanctuary in its campus building here beginning tomorrow.
Bill Russell was named yesterday as the basketball player of the decade in a special Associated Press poll of sports writers and broadcasters.

ON the face of it, La Mama on Broadway might sound as unlikely as Fillmore East at the Metropolitan Opera. However, at times even the strangest things happen, and last night Ellen Stewart La Mama herself walked onto the stage of the ANTA Theater and welcomed everyone, as is her custom, to her theater "dedicated to the playwright and all aspects of the theater."

Three oil companies announced increases in 1969 profits yesterday. The Atlantic Richfield Company and the Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation also reported gains in fourth-quarter profits, while Pennzoil United, Inc., announced a decline in its earnings for the quarter.

NORTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 4 "We ask that you reply to these charges within a period of a week," the speaker said after listing a series of sweeping complaints against the president of Southeastern Massachusetts University here. A rally of students and professors cheered wildly.

PTTTSBURGH, Feb. 4 Dr. Francis Cowles Frary, who founded the research staff of the Aluminum Company of America, died today at the Presbyterian Home for the Aged in Oakmont, a Pittsburgh suburb. He was 85 years old.

Olympics. President Nixon issued a proclamation extending the warm welcome of the United States to all authorized Olympic delegations and requesting them to come to the United States to take part in the 1976 Olympic Games it they are held at Los Angeles and Denver.

A strike against the Long Island Rail Road has been authorized by 98 per cent of the members of Lodge 886 of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen of America in a mail ballot, Anthony F. D'Avanzo, the unit's general chairman, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 President Nixon asked the Soviet Union today for discussions on a limitation of arms shipments to the Middle East as part of a three-point proposal for alleviating tensions in the region, United States officials said.

With three local teams scheduled to play, there will be quite a few familiar faces on the court for Madison Square Garden's sixth college doubleheader of the season tonight. But notably among the missing is Spencer Haywood.

The economic toll of the tugboat strike here mounted yesterday as the United States Lines, a large containership operator, found it necessary to shift ship terminals at extra cost as a safety measure.

The Vietnam hearings of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee are taking place in the wake of an on-the-spot staff study that emphasizes many previously expressed doubts about President Nixon's policy of Vietnamization.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 4 Trouble is simmering again in Northern Ireland less than six months after sectarian riots engulfed the province last August.
FREEPORT, L.I., Feb. 4 Mr. and Mrs. Martin Gach have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Aline Hariette Gach, to Michael Leslie Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Kaufman of East Meadow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The Justice Department disclosed today that it would not insist on obtaining all of the material that it had demanded from newsmen in a recent series of subpoenas.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 4 Miss Susan Kennedy Rice and Jacques Gael Cressaty were married here this afternoon in the Resurrection Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Cathedral by the Right Rev. Joseph M. Harte, Bishop of Arizona.

Lured less by the legend of the statesman than by their affection for the private man, about 400 of the late Adlai Stevenson's friends gathered at the Plaza last night for a nostalgic reunion celebrating the 70th birthday of the man from Illinois.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 4 Fred Fellman, chairman of the Republican party in the Town of Babylon, was arraigned today on charges of having stolen funds from the town Republican organization and from two real estate companies by falsifying business records.
DETROIT, Feb. 4 (UPI) Hugh J. Ferry, former president and board chairman of the defunct Packard Motor Company, and a civic leader here for many years, died yesterday. He was 85 years old.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. For those who must learn economics the easy way from a book the switching hour approaches.

WARSAW, Feb. 4 (Reuters) West German and Polish representatives met for 65 minutes today as a prelude for formal discussions tomorrow aimed at healing acrimony that has existed between the two countries since World War II.

Arthur Godfrey, the radio and television personality, said yesterday he would refuse to do commercials for Axion the way he has been doing them because he has found that the detergent pollutes streams and lakes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 4 (UPI) The New York Nets outscored the Indiana Pacers, the Eastern Division leaders, by 16-8 in the final seven minutes tonight and gained a 102-92 American Basketball Association victory.
Congressional Democrats will present their own State of the Union Message to the nation Sunday afternoon in a telecast to be carried by the three major networks.

AFTER a trial period for the regulations that be came effective just over a year ago, and an exchange of views by three organizations one Eastern, two on the Pacific Coast a number of recommendations applying to knotty problems in obedience competition have been.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, denounced today the Administration's proposed expansion of the Safeguard missile defense system, calling it a step that could escalate the atomic arms race and divert resources from domestic needs.

Frank W. Rounds Jr., whose 18 months as an attache of the United States Embassy in Moscow was the basis for the book, "A Window on Red Square," died in Moscow Monday on a business visit. He was 55 years old.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Feb. 4 (UPI) Pete Maravich, sinking 53 per cent of his shots, scored 52 points tonight in leading Louisiana Sate to a 97-75 basketball rout of Florida.
NEWARK, Feb. 4 Theodore W. Kheel, the lawyer and labor mediator, and his associate, Lewis Kaden, will enter the Newark teachers strike tomorrow in an effort to end the three-day-old walkout.

Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh directed yesterday that a woman who touched off an outburst resulting in violence at the bomb-conspiracy trial of 13 Black Panthers on Tuesday be brought in to face punishment for contempt of court.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 4 An eight-week wildcat strike at the state-owned iron mines north of the Arctic Circle ended today. About 4,800 workers at Kiruna, Svappavaara and Malmberget accepted their strike committee's recommendations and returned to work although they had not won any of their demands for a substantial pay raise, lower pension age and improvements in working conditions.

The Allegheny Power System, Inc., announced yesterday 1969 preliminary net income of $39.3-million, or $1.90 a share. This was 13.6 per cent higher than the yearearlier level. Earnings in 1968 were equal to $1.79 a share on net income of $34.6-million.

New Yorkers and their automobiles skidded, railroad switches froze and the Sanitation Department worked overtime yesterday in the icy aftermath of the gusty, sleety, snowy storm that hit the city late Tuesday night.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 4 Bruce Devlin, the slim Australian, practiced putting for five hours on one green yesterday. Today the ex-plumber was in a five-way tie for the lead with a five-under-par 67 in the $125,000 Bob Hope Golf Classic.

Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh directed yesterday that a woman who touched off an outburst resulting in violence at the bomb-conspiracy trial of 13 Black Panthers on Tuesday be brought in to face punishment for contempt of court.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 4 An eight-week wildcat strike at the state-owned iron mines north of the Arctic Circle ended today. About 4,800 workers at Kiruna, Svappavaara and Malmberget accepted their strike committee's recommendations and returned to work although they had not won any of their demands for a substantial pay raise, lower pension age and improvements in working conditions.

The Allegheny Power System, Inc., announced yesterday 1969 preliminary net income of $39.3-million, or $1.90 a share. This was 13.6 per cent higher than the yearearlier level. Earnings in 1968 were equal to $1.79 a share on net income of $34.6-million.

New Yorkers and their automobiles skidded, railroad switches froze and the Sanitation Department worked overtime yesterday in the icy aftermath of the gusty, sleety, snowy storm that hit the city late Tuesday night.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 4 Bruce Devlin, the slim Australian, practiced putting for five hours on one green yesterday. Today the ex-plumber was in a five-way tie for the lead with a five-under-par 67 in the $125,000 Bob Hope Golf Classic.

NEWARK, Feb. 4 Municipal Judge Anthony Giuliano, who was under suspension from the bench here following his indictment last December on charges of income tax evasion, conspiracy and extortion, died early this morning of a heart attack at his home, 364 Roseville Avenue. He was 72 years old.

Frightening the wits out of the Red Wings' goalie, and in general barreling past anyone in an enemy uniform, the Rangers continued their dominance of the Detroit club with a 5-1 victory last night that could have served as a how-to lesson.

The American Electric Power Company announced yesterday that it has "significantly increased" its earlier commitments for the purchase of large turbine-generators from Brown, Boveri Company, Ltd., of Baden, Switzerland.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Savings Bond redemptions exceeded sales by $122-million last month, the 14th straight month of net decline, The Treasury Department said today.

MIAMI, Feb. 4 For the first five furlongs of the $32,350 Bahamas Stakes at Hialeah today, John Rotz felt he had the race won with Silent Screen. But when he turned for home, he said to himself, "I'm beat." He was wrong. Silent Screen, without being hit with the whip, ran down George Lewis in the last two strides to win by a head.
PRAGUE, Feb. 4 (Reuters) The Czechoslovak Communist party newspaper today defended the denial of facilities to two Western newsmen, but said, "We have no intention of dropping the Iron Curtain."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 While the advertising people meeting here were hearing what government was doing or planning to do to them, they took some time out to find out what advertising was doing for local communities.

ATHENS, Feb. 4--A special military tribunal in Salonika today sentenced four Greeks to life imprisonment for planning bomb explosions to protest the military-backed regime and United States installations in Greece.

During a brief, hurried trip to New York, Walter Felsenstein, Intendant (managing director) of the Komische Oper in East Berlin, has completed arrangements for a production of "Fiddler on the Roof" in his East German theater this year.
An apparent miscalculation on the part of a bank caused the interest rate of Federal funds to spurt to a record 12 per cent late yesterday afternoon.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 4 In another stormy episode punctuating the Israeli debate of "who is a Jew," an Opposition member of the Knesset, or parliament, was lifted out of his seat today by ushers and carried out of the chamber in Jerusalem. The ejected Deputy was Uri Avneri, leader of the tiny Haolam Hazeh party.

A.R. Gale has been elected senior vice president and a member of the board and of the executive committee of American Export Industries, Inc. Ralph R. Weiser has been named president of National Equipment Rental, Ltd., a subsidiary of A.E.I.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia In the cold empty store that is the office of the Committee to Aid American War Objectors, half a dozen youths sat on chairs and stools, their hands thrust into their pockets or between their thighs for warmth.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 31 A new air of self-confidence is evident in Croatia and Slovenia, Yugoslavia's well-off western republics, and nobody here seems afraid any more of being labeled a chauvinist.
LONDON, Feb. 4 The Minister of Defense, Denis Healey, is treating with "concern and urgency" accusations that British troops massacred 25 alleged terrorists in Malaya in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The Senate began work today on the largest Federal education aid measure in Congressional history, a $35-billion four-year package with heavy emphasis on special schooling for slum children.

At the age of 89 Bertrand Russell Nobel Laureate, mathematician, philosopher and, least of all, a hereditary earl was arrested for a breach of peace while taking part in a demonstration against nuclear warfare. When the magistrate asked him to pledge his future good behavior, he replied, "No, I won't," and went to jail for a week.
BONN, Feb. 4 Another Government-vs.-press feud has erupted in West Germany and it promises to be the stormiest since 1962 when federal authorities arrested four editors of Der Spiegel magazine.

The Jacques Cousteau special, "Return of the Sea Elephants," Sunday night on the American Broadcasting Company's television network will be part of the return to corporate advertising of the giant du Pont organization.
Prices remained firm yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. Australian issues continued to be in demand. Their performance was the outstanding feature of the day's trading.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Feb. 5 A Government safety expert said today that the rupture of auto gasoline tanks after a chain-reaction collision on the New Jersey Turnpkke Nov. 29 was a major cause of a holocaust after the crash that burned five motorists to death.

Two small children were killed and a third critically injured early this morning after a small fire broke out in the bedroom of their second-story apartment at 633 Tinton Avenue in the southeast Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Jan. 31 was above the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period was down.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 In offering today to "negotiate" with the news media for a "compromise" about how much unpublished information on the Black Panthers they would be forced to surrender to the courts, Attorney General John N. Mitchell offered an unusual confession of error and expression...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Arrangements were made today to test members of Congress and about 14,000 Capitol employes for tuberculosis.

It is no surprise that Peru's Supreme Court has thrown out the claim of two organizations of journalists that the infamous "Statute of Freedom of the Press" is unconstitutional. The generals who rule Peru had taken the prior precaution of purging the court and appointing new judges more to the military's taste.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 5 Dr. and Mrs. Everett Young have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Allyson Young, to David S. Schwartz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanford Schwartz of Greenvale. A wedding in June is planned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Bess Myerson Grant, commissioner of consumer affairs for New York City, condemned today the Nixon Administration's proposed legal remedies for unfair merchandising as a "consumer fraud."

NEWARK, Feb. 5 Negotiations in the four-day-old Newark teachers' strike were suspended tonight following the arrest of three officers of the Newark Teachers Union on charges of violating an antistrike court order.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Just before the House of Representatives convened today, the Democratic leadership postponed calling up a bill to authorize increased logging in the national forests. The postponement, informed members said, was because the votes for passage were lacking.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The Federal Government announced today it would continue the policy of keeping cancerous chickens from reaching American dinner tables.
The pride of Britain's passenger fleet, the Queen Elizabeth 2, crushed through thick Hudson River ice to a safe docking yesterday almost as if she had never known the nudge of a tugboat.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 The Justice Department requested authorization today to exhume the body of slain Black Panther leader, Fred Hampton, to perform another autopsy.
Miss Joan Kelley Lutz and Richard Lee Winegar have made plans to be married next autumn in Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that the Justice Department was taking steps to assure that no subpoenas would be issued to members of the news media without an attempt first to reach agreement on the scope of the subpoenas.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 5 Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said today that he would meet with Arthur T. Roth, a member of the NassauSuffolk Regional Planning Board, to discuss disclosures about Mr. Roth's real estate holdings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 American and British space experts believe that the Soviet Union has built and successfully tested a satellite capable of intercepting and destroying other orbiting spacecraft.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 5 The mystery of the disappearance of Lucien Fontaine from Roosevelt Raceway was solved today. The 30-year-old FrenchCanadian reinsman who, despite only 77 driving assignments, has brought home 14 winners, had not been seen in action here since he went, as slumping baseball players phrase it, 0-for-5 last Friday night.
The concert series "Music From Marlboro" usually means that accomplished and devoted instrumentalists are going to play chamber music as if they were born doing it together.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The voice of the Old South reverberated through the Senate today, demanding that the new standards of racial balance be applied to Northern school systems or abandoned altogether.

Ralph Nader, the Washington lawyer who has built a reputation as a champion of consumers, charged yesterday that Robert M. Morgenthau had been replaced as United States Attorney in New York to protect "criminal behavior from prosecution."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Several years ago, a California judge told a gathering of Boy Scout leaders that no Scout had ever been tried in his court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Donald F. Turner, who was head of the Justice Department's antitrust division during the Johnson Administration, said today that he saw no justification for filing antitrust suits against conglomerate mergers on the ground that the mergers would increase the prospects for illegal reciprocal dealings. This is one of the main bases for several of the suits that have been filed by the Nixon Administration.

The new consumer-consciousness of the Public Service Commission is admirably reflected in its rejection of fare increases sought by the New Haven division of the Penn Central Railroad and its insistence that the road make far-reaching improvements in both service and equipment.
LONDON, Feb. 5 At least four national newspapers in Britain "do not cover their direct costs," according to an official report published today.
The processing of prisoners or courtroom appearances was delayed as much as four hours yesterday when correction officers instituted a slowdown "by strictly sticking to departmental rules."
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 5 Any discussions of an open Davis Cup must include all parties, including the professional promoters, Edward A. Turville, the new United States Cup captain, said today.

After three weeks of rehearsal, Jules Feiffer's "The White House Murder Case" faced the public for the first time last night, at a preview at Circle in the Square. Among the more curious members of the audience was Mr. Feiffer himself, seeing his play for the first time.

GEORGE BALANCHINE gently coaxed a tired ballerina out of the wings onto centerstage during a rehearsal for the premiere of his ballet "Who Cares?" offered last night as he marked nearly half a century as a choreographer.
Every February, the Giants bring their prominent new players to town so New York can get a good look at them. Sometimes it works the other way around, too.

The Rev. Richard J. Neuhaus, 33-year-old pastor of the Lutheran Church of St. John the Evangelist in Brooklyn, announced yesterday that he was challenging Representative John J. Rooney for renomination as the Democratic candidate in New York's 14th Congressional District.

The South's desegregation crisis deepened yesterday. Racial tensions closed a Louisiana school and Mississippi's Governor, in apparent defiance of the Federal courts, asked his Legislature to re-establish the principle of freedom of choice for students.

The New York State Public Service Commission refused yesterday to allow the Penn Central to revise the fares paid by the 14,000 commuters who travel between New York City and other points in the state on the line's New Haven Division.
Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx charged yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its chairman were endangering the safety of Bronx residents.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 5 The Cincinnati City Council and negotiators for 1,485 striking members of the union of nonuniformed municipal employes agreed today on the terms of a settlement to end a 31-day strike.

Richie Garner, a sophomore with little playing time, turned around a first-half, ball-control game and led Manhattan College to a 68-60 victory over New York University last night in the second game of a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.

Marty Liquori is a 20-yearold Villanova junior from Cedar Grove, N.J., and he is probably America's best active miler. Tonight, he will run in the 51st annual Knights of Columbus indoor track meet at Madison Square Garden, but not the mile.
BOSTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Bobby Orr neared still another record tonight while scoring twice to pace the Bruins to a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

Aside from such long-established bands as Duke Ellington's, Count Basie's and Woody Herman's, big jazz bands today are apt to be made of well known musicians who get together to play primarily for kicks Clark Terry's band, for instance, the Thad Jones-Mel Lewis group or Duke Pearson's band.
TWO weeks ago, Leonard Bernstein, conductor emeritus of the New York Philharmonic, slipped into the Hunter Mountain Ski Bowl with his son Alexander for a day's sport and left almost unnoticed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 A new computerized study by the Indpendent Petroleum Association of America concluded today that a drop of only 25 cents a barrel in the price of crude oil as a result of a new oil-import policy would all but eliminate oil exploration and drilling by the independent by 1975.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 Two of the state's major business organizations the Empire State Chamber of Commerce and the Commerce and Industry Association of New York criticized the size of Governor Rockefeller's new $7.3-billion budget today.

THE VALLEY, Anguilla, Feb. 5 (Reuters) About 1,000 Anguillans surrounded the island's administration building today armed with sticks, stones, pieces of pipe and clubs to prevent a regional judge from holding court.

The city has made only sparse use of the emergency measures authorized by Mayor Lindsay two weeks ago to combat the widespread failure of heating systems in apartments here, according to statistics obtained yesterday from the Housing and Development Administration.
Cornelius Vermeule, curator of classical arts at the Boston Museum, said yesterday:
Barton Kreuzer, executive vice president, RCA Consumer Electronics, has been elected to the additional post of president, RCA Sales Corporation.

ATHENS, Feb. 5 A top Greek expert on prehistoric antiquity branded as a forgery today the 137-piece gold treasure, said to be 4,000 years old, that was put on display yesterday at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.
MASERU, Lesotho, Feb. 5 (AP) The Prime Minister, Chief Leabua Jonathan today banned five opposition publications.

University Settlement has arranged a champagne buffet in Philharmonic Hall's grand promenade terrace to follow the concert by Claudio Arrau at the hall the afternoon of Feb. 15. The event's proceeds will aid the 84-year-old settlement house on the Lower East Side at 184 Eldridge Street.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 Defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial fired a barrage of abuse at Judge Julius J. Hoffman today.

The General Electric Corporation, which is just emerging from a long strike, announced yesterday that it was increasing prices of all General Electric and Hotpoint major appliances, including room air-conditioners, effective today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) State Department officials said today that about 150 Americans, nearly all airmen, are missing or have been captured in Laos.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 President Nixon is studying a new, far-reaching proposal for settling labor disputes that threaten the nation's welfare, Government sources said tonight.

WHITINSVILLE, Mass., Feb. 5 (AP) J. Hugh Bolton, a World War I flying ace and former president of Whitin Machine Works here, died in San Francisco yesterday after a brief illness, his family reported. He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, said today a panel he heads planned a broad investigation of organized crime this year and would hire extra investigators to set up a special "organized crime unit."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (AP) A 4 -year-old, $110,000 battery suit filed by the former Los Angeles Dodgers' catcher, John Roseboro, against the San Francisco Giants' pitcher, Juan Marichal, was settled today for a reported $7,500.
The Avco Corporation reported yesterday that earnings declined in both the fourth fiscal quarter and the fiscal year, ended last Nov. 30.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The armed forces that protect the United States have apparently lost a couple of flags.
ROME, Ga., Feb. 5 (AP) Rudy York, former star slugger for the Detroit Tigers, died here today of lung cancer. He was 56 years old.

THE late Robert E. Sherwood, the playwright, once described Burr Tilstrom's show, "Kukla, Fran and Ollie," as an electronic fairy tale. It would be difficult to think of a more apt description as Ollie, the magnificent dragon with the center molar, gentle Kukla and Fran Allison returned last night to Channel 13 for a five-part series.
PARIS, Feb. 5 North Vietnam hinted today that it might not be willing to meet with the United States privately so long as the American delegation was headed by Philip C. Habib as acting chief.
TORONTO, Feb. 5 Martin McGrady is so tired of winning that he wouldn't mind losing, but he didn't mind winning the feature race tonight in the Toronto Telegram-Maple Leaf indoor track meet.
Accelerating mass-transit troubles in the city, the suburbs and upstate have turned out to be the first potentially critical issue of the 1970 race for Governor.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 The normally chaotic streets of Saigon fell silent tonight, the shops and restaurants closed and most Vietnamese went home to bid a rueful good-by to the Year of the Rooster and an anxious welcome to the Year of the Dog.
Dr. Matthew Besdine, president of the State Dental Society in 1961, who practiced In Brooklyn for 42 years, died Wednesday at his home, 1182 Dean Street, Brooklyn. He was 64 years old.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 When President Nixon sits down tomorrow with four Republican Governors to discuss water pollution in the Great Lakes states he will find that the machinery for cleaning up Lake Michigan is already turning.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 As an audience of upstate farmers jeered, urban representatives warned the Assembly Conservation Committee today of a "substantial water deficit in the immediate future" for New York City.

Trans World Airlines and Paramount Pictures teamed up yesterday to sponsor a press lunch with a cast of tens for a big, big, big announcement about something really new. The air was electric with excitement when the word came that, for the first time ever, there would be a bona fide world premiere of a major movie 30,000 feet up. The film will be "The Adventurers" and the theater will be a new 747 jet.

The Faculty Senate of City College urged the school's acting president yesterday to reverse himself and reappoint a sociology teacher who supported a student occupation of campus buildings last spring.
GIMBELS has discovered California and, starting Monday, it will celebrate that fact throughout the store for two weeks. Besides the numerous exhibits end activities, there are fashions...
The stock market staged another retreat yesterday, but a rally in the final hour trimmed its losses.

AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 5 Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis signed legislation today that is designed to protect Maine's rockbound coast from potential ravaging by the exploitation of petroleum facilities. Both branches of the Legislature, in bipartisan action without debate yesterday, enacted two key measures that were hailed by conservationists as landmarks in environmental integrity. The legislative package was believed to be the first of its kind approved by any state.
TEL AVIV, Friday, Feb. 6 An Israeli Navy vessel described as an auxiliary craft was sunk early this morning in the harbor of Elath, apparently by enemy sabotage. Another was damaged.
A new contract covering 9,000 workers at six department stores of the R.H. Macy Company will provide an immediate pay increase of $10 a week and $6 more a week on Feb. 1, 1971.

Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., a diversified entertainment and communications company, announced yesterday the election of Paul Hallingby Jr., general partner of White, Weld Co., and Stanley Schneider, president of the company's Columbia Pictures division, as members of the board of directors.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 5 Rinks representing the New York Caledonian Curling Club, the Plainfield (N.J.) C.C. and the Ardsley (N.Y.) C.C. won opening matches tonight in the 15th annual Cuthbertson bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

The promoters of a rock cruise to Bermuda, which was scuttled by the Greek Line and the Bermudian Government, will reply with a rock and light concert and news conference tonight on the campus of George Washington University in the capital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today that President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam was persecuting an Opposition leader for exposing the President's "political bag man" with the National Assembly.

PARIS, Feb. 5 (Reuters) A Boeing 747 jumbo jet of Pan American World Airways landed here for the first time today, and forced the ground controller to go up to the second floor of the Orly Airport building to guide the plane in.

NEWARK, Feb. 5 (AP) John P. Caufield, dismissed as Newark Fire Director last week when he refused to support Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio for a third term, announced today that he was a candidate for Mayor.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP) Mayor Kevin H. White said today he would have within 48 hours a "last-ditch" proposal to keep the Patriots in Boston. White Stadium, a high school field, was ruled out as a home for the pro football team after the Patriots' president, William H. Sullivan Jr., met with the mayor at City Hall.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) The San Francisco Warriors, paced by Joe Ellis and Jerry Lucas, took over fourth place in the National Basketball Association's Western Division tonight with a 127-105 victory over the Chicago Bulls.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 5 (AP) Capt. James A. Lovell Jr. of the Navy said today that the Apollo 13 space flight in April would be his last.

TULSA, Okla., Feb. 5 Tim Wood, the world and national men's champion, gained first place today during the compulsory figures of the senior men's event of the United States figure skating championships.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Following is the text of a letter sent today by United States Circuit Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the Senate Judiciary Committee responding to questions raised in the committee's hearings on his nomination to the Supreme Court:

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Feb. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Frank Henry Woods have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Amy Woods, to Nelson Gore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Gore of New York. The wedding will take place in June in New York.

An information manual for teachers in a Board of Education manpower-training program was described as discriminating against Puerto Ricans yesterday by Robert C. (Sonny) Carson, head of Independent Brooklyn CORE, at a hearing held by the State Division of Human Rights.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Following is the text of a statement today by Attorney General John N. Mitchell about subpoenas issued to members of the press:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The Transportation Department announced today that the Dunlop Tire and Rubber Corporation had refused to recall and replace without charge 90,000 tires that had failed Federal safety tests.
World sugar prices rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) Former United States Representative Ben F. Jensen, a Republican from Iowa, who served in the House for 26 years, died of cancer today in George Washington University Hospital at the age of 77. He had been in the hospital since Jan. 19.
BUFFALO, Feb. 5 (UPI) David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, called on business today to become more deeply involved in solving the problems of the nation's cities.
MIAMI, Feb. 5 (AP) The Pin Oak Stable's Hey Good Lookin, charged from last place and swept to a 1 -length victory in the feature at Hialeah Park before a crowd of 14,219 today.
An electronic device that instantly corrects color variations on processed film or videotape before the film or tape is broadcast was demonstrated yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 Henry Ford 2d asked the major oil companies to consider producing lead-free gasoline nationally and said his company's new car engines could be modified immediately to run on the less polluting fuel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 America's museums are "drowning" in their own success, overwhelmed by the millions streaming to see their exhibitions, the Congress was told today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 5 (UPI) Zoran Gluscevic, a writer sentenced last year to six months in jail for writing an article that "insulted" the Soviet Union, will not be imprisoned, a court ruled today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (AP) Vice President Agnew said today that he had found during his 11-country tour that Asian leaders shared concerns about "a new isolationism on the part of the American public" and about "potentially aggressive intentions of Communist China."
YOU might think that Chrysler's dismal results in the fourth quarter would cool Wall Street ardor for the stock of the No. 3 auto maker.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 4 Eight creditor nations, including the United States, are working toward what a senior State Department official called a "revolutionary" agreement to relieve Indonesia of the burden of foreign debt accumulated during the chaotic regime of former President Sukarno.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 According to American intelligence reports, the Soviet Union is altering some of the more than 100 MIG-21 jets it has furnished the United Arab Republic to enable them to carry bombs.
SOME are enthralled by the milkmaid syndrome. You know, Marie Antoinette playing farm girl at Le Petite Trianon before the revolution.
BRISBANE, Australia, Feb. 5 The American touring team scored a victory in its opening match here last night, defeating a strong Queensland group by 46 international match points.
GENEVA, Feb. 5 The Swiss Government braved strong opposition from the country's powerful industrial and business associations by announcing today an export-deposit plan for fighting inflation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The Catholic University of America has taken a major new step away from Vatican control with an overhaul of its bylaws and statutes.
The New York Yankees announced yesterday that they had signed John Ellis and Ron Klimkowski, two of the young players they hope will lead the team upward from fifth place in the American League.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Two soldiers who have made public statements supporting the war in Vietnam have drawn Congressional criticism for doing so with the apparent approval of superiors in the Pentagon.

Ten Councilmen took legal action yesterday in an attempt to force the city to make public a controversial million-dollar Rand Corporation housing study that is reportedly highly critical of several city housing laws, notably those dealing with rent control.

THE PRESIDENT Activities. President Nixon attended the annual Presidential prayer breakfast at the Washington Hilton Hotel. He received the annual report from the Boy Scouts of America. Mr. Nixon left on a two-day trip to Indianapolis and Chicago.

Investors Diversified Services, Inc., underwriter for the largest mutual-fund complex in the country, reported yesterday that last year's unaudited net operating income dropped to $23.37-million from 1968's $26,007,000.
The president of the New York State Council on Drug Addiction predicted yesterday that "within a couple of years every high school and every college in the country will be inundated by heroin."

BONN, Feb. 5 The Government spokesman, Conrad Ahlers, whose criticism of the Springer newspapers has prompted an uproar in the West German press, disarmed 200 newsmen today with sweet talk about their profession and nostalgic recollections of his own days as a journalist.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, is leading a drive to block the nomination of the White House choice for Director of Selective Service, Charles J. DiBona.

While Lima's La Prensa was resisting military control with typical courage, the editor of its equally distinguished counterpart of the same name in Argentina was winning new international recognition. Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz was awarded the Golden Pen of Freedom by the International Federation of Newspaper Editors and Publishers.

David M. Collins, a retired Naval commander and a former stockbroker, died Wednesday in a Palm Beach, Fla., hospital after a brief illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 162 Dolphin Road, Palm Beach.

Twelve of 86 beagles that were trained to smoke developed lung cancer, two scientists reported yesterday. They said it was the first time malignant tumors had been produced in large animals by exposing the animals to cigarette smoke.
Bewitched, bothered and bewildered probably best describes management's attitude today as it strives to maintain profits while inflation climbs and the economy declines.
FORT COLLINS, Colo., Feb. 5 (AP) Demonstrating students scuffled with campus police tonight at half-time of the Brigham Young-Colorado State University basketball game, won by Colorado State, 94-71.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its second consecutive losing performance yesterday in the lightest trading in more than two months.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Feb. 5 (UPI) The Honduran Defense Ministry said that Government forces fought Salvadoran troops tonight about 10 miles inside Honduras, it said four Salvadoran soldiers had been killed.
The Rev. Billy Graham is coming here for a crusade in Shea Stadium this June, only a year after his last appearance in the city.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.

YOU have to be extraordinarily confident either in yourself or in your critics to call a ballet "Who Cares?" for the answer could come back all too slickly and dangerously. But last night at our New York State Theater our New York State Balanchine did just that.
IT took considerable chasing but Jim Kanicki of the Cleveland Browns finally caught up with Fran Tarkenton of the Giants and spilled him for a loss.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5 The Democratic party, which needs money by the barrelful, managed to raise only a few spoonfuls tonight.
The Long Island Lighting Company said yesterday that its earnings in 1969 increased for the 17th consecutive year.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 Mrs. Ann Van Gerbig, widow of Howell Van Gerbig, was married here this afternoon to Morton Downey, the tenor and Coca-Cola executive.
The following reports were provided by the operators of the ski areas now open. Messages were filed at times indicated in parentheses:

Yields on top-quality tax-exempt state bonds moved down sharply yesterday as Connecticut sold $75-million of tirpleA securities to raise funds for schools, housing for the elderly and other facilities.

The Federal Reserve, which many observers believe should now be starting to lean toward a somewhat less restrictive credit policy, seemed to be bending over backwards in the latest statement period to avoid giving that impression.

Several major retail chains announced yesterday higher sales in January over the yearago month. Earlier reports in the month listed substantial gains by Sears, Roebuck, Montgomery Ward, J.C. Penney Company, S.S. Kresge and F. W. Woolworth.

The 1,013 members of the Long Island Rail Road unit of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen plan to strike next Tuesday to back up their demands for wage parity with their counterparts in the New York City subway system.

ELLIOTT CARTER was supposed to have a new work ready for the 125th Anniversary Year of the New York Philharmonic, two seasons back. But he never did get it in on time, and it was not until last night that Leonard Bernstein conducted the world premiere of Mr. Carter's Concerto for Orchestra.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 5 (U.P.I.) Longshoremen, after narrowly rejecting a third contract offer that would have given them the highest hourly wage rate for dockers in North America, went on strike again today and tied up British Columbia's six ports.

Scarpia, police chief of Rome, is a character on whom the rebellious young of today would quickly lay the epithet "pig." But he is more complex than that, a baron who is aware of having an aristocratic veneer as well as sadistic leanings. Giangiacomo Guelfi, the Italian baritone who made his Metropolitan Opera debut last night, underlined almost unrelievedly the role's brutality.

ROME A unique Italian contribution to modern political life is the art of governing without apparent government and this republic has managed to violate all normal credos except that efficient self-rule is not a contemporary Mediterranean phenomenon.

OCHO RIOS, Jamaica Shortly after dawn, a dawn that brought a warm wind from the Caribbean, Geoffrey, the beach boy and fishing guide at the Plantation Inn, and I set forth in an outboard powered skiff for some light-tackle fishing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The three members of the new White House Council on Environmental Quality indicated grave reservations today about proceeding with the development of the supersonic transport because of the environmental problems involved.

HOPKINTON, N.H., Feb. 5 (AP) The Business Research Institute, a research firm that analyzes marketing information for corporations, predicted today that the nation's total business volume in 1970 would fall short of 1969.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The wife of one of three men indicted in connection with the slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski was arrested in Cleveland today under a new Federal indictment accusing all four persons of conspiring to kill the rebel mine union leader, the Justice Department announced here today.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Feb. 5 Miss Judith A. Rubinstein and Jeffrey Martin Green,will be married March 29.
Two special agents of the Internal Revenue Service were arrested yesterday the fifth and sixth former or present tax agents to be arrested on bribery charges in the last three weeks.
The New York Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution will hold it 35th annual Colonial Ball at the Plaza Feb. 20 to herald the observance two days later of the birth of George Washington.

ARLINGTON, Va., Feb. 5 (AP) A murder charge against Debra Mattingly, 14 years old, who was accused with two other young persons of killing her stepfather, was dropped today by William J. Hassan, prosecutor of Arlington County.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Judge G. Harrold Carswell denied today that he had been discourteous or hostile to civil rights lawyers who appeared before him in court.
The Board of Education said last evening that it would appeal a State Supreme Court ruling that voided the new decentralized school district lines in Manhattan.

Anthony M. Scotto, vice president of the International Longshoremen's Association and a political power here, refused yesterday on the ground of possible self-incrimination to tell the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime whether he was a member of the Mafia.

PLANDOME, L.I., Feb. 5 Henry L. Duncombe Jr., director of economic studies for the General Motors Corporation, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Nancy Duncombe, to Edward J. Eder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Eder of Old Brookville. The wedding is planned for May 2 in the Congregational Church of Manhasset.

A little over a year ago the New York Urban Coalition and the National Alliance of Businessmen formed Coalition JOBS to fuse their efforts in behalf of the hard-core unemployed in this city. As a result of that effort 9,000 people previously without work or hope are now employed in jobs that hold some promise of advancement. Two-thirds of these jobs are in white-collar fields.
Riders of the subway, city buses and commuter rail lines should find a little excessive the enthusiasm members of the United States Senate expressed in passing the mass transit bill.
Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, president of the American Medical Association in 1936-37, died Wednesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 157 East 57th Street.
FRANKFURT, Ky., Feb. 5 (AP) The General Assembly took time out today from lawmaking to pay tribute to Earle Combs, Kentucky's contribution to the Baseball Hall of Fame.
Lester Samuel Morse, cofounder and board chairman of the Morse Shoe Company in Canton, Mass., died of a heart attack Wednesday in Good Samaritan Hospital, Palm Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old.

The International Utilities Corporation announced yesterday that, subject to the completion of formal agreements, it proposed to sell all of its holdings in Brascan, Ltd., for about $37-million in cash in Canadian funds.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 5 The six member nations of the European Economic Community, or Common Market, agreed today on a procedure for absorbing new members such as Britain, Denmark, Norway and Ireland, whose applications will be discussed later this year.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 5 -Larry Ziegler avoided the swimming pools and out-ofbounds stakes today and took the lead in the $125,000 Bob Hope Golf Classic with a 36hole aggregate of 132.
TRENTON, Feb. 5 Gov. William T. Cahill warned insurance companies today not to try to blackmail the state of New Jersey into granting higher automobile policy rates by holding back coverage.

No. 7106 is an average, middle-aged subway car. For the last few years it has been logging 250 miles a day on the Lexington Avenue IRT line, but now it sits on struts at the subway repair yard at 207th Street, as stationary as a cemetery slab.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 With 16 of the world's topranked professionals battling head to head today for major shares in the $60,000 International Tennis Players' Association indoor open, it was no surprise that the losers' list read like a who's who: Arthur Ashe, Manuel Santana, Tom Okker, Fred Stolle, Stan Smith, Roy Emerson, Roger Taylor and Jim Osborne.
ROME, Feb. 5 The Italian Socialist party gave lukewarm and ambiguous endorsement tonight to efforts to re-establish a center-left coalition government after six months of minority rule.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 5 (Reuters) Tanzania took another major step today in her blueprint for socialism with an announcement that the Government would take over the entire wholesaling system.

An unexpected rash of broken rails, the extremely cold weather this winter and the aging of rolling stock were cited by Penn Central officials yesterday as major reasons for the recent deterioration of service on the line's Hudson and Harlem Divisions.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 5 (AP) The Rutgers basketball team broke a 29-29 tie late in the first half with 11 straight points and went on to a 98-77 victory over Boston University tonight.

TUNIS Calm and satisfaction have returned to the oases in Tunisia's southern desert and to the farms and truck gardens of the center and north after a period of agitation and resentment. But that period has left enough traces to raise questions as to the Tunisians' ability to maintain the stability that has distinguished them in the Arab world.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 (AP) American fighter-bombers attacked enemy missile and gun positions in North Vietnam on Monday for the second time in a week after unarmed reconnaissance jets came under intense antiaircraft fire, the United States command disclosed today.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 5 President Nixon brought his Urban Affairs Council here today for a symbolic meeting outlining Administration thinking on a national policy for attacking the crisis of the cities.
Mrs. Maryann Weissman, whose remarks last Tuesday at the trial of 13 Black Panthers set off a demonstration that resulted in violence, was sent to jail for 30 days yesterday.

Hans Werner Henze, one of today's most successful opera composers, wrote his first stage piece in 1948 when he was only 22. It was "Das Wundertheater," or "The Miracle Theater," and was devised as an "opera for actors."
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 5 Foreign sheep breeders today paid a total of nearly $134,000 in United States money for 48 Australian stud Merino rams at the Sydney Sheep Show.

HONG KONG, Feb. 5 Communist China has announced a moderate policy for agriculture that appears to signify another gain for the pragmatists in Peking's persisting struggle between radicals and moderates.
The American experience in Vietnam has brought forth a new form of isolationism, according to the Louis Harris Survey.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were mixed yesterday. There was no definite trend, although a firmer tone was noted toward the end of the day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The Government today charged 14 real estate companies in Memphis and Atlanta with practicing blockbusting in previously all-white neighborhoods.
ATHENS, Feb. 6 Several foreign correspondents were taken to a detention camp today to be shown that Mikis Theodorakis, the Greek composer, was alive and well.

In the last few years a glimmer of hope has flashed across the television screen. That hope has taken the form of challenges by citizen, church and business groups to replace the franchises held by federally licensed stations that have failed in their obligation to present public service programs.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) A Federal judge authorized today the exhumation of the body of Fred Hampton, a Black Panther party chief, for examination in connection with a grand jury inquiry into his slaying.

BARTLESVILLE, Okla., Feb. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Armand F. Macmanus have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maureen Macmanus of Larchmont, N.Y., to Marc Pierre Desautels of Geneva. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Georges Desautels of Woodside, Calif.

The chief operator at an uptown branch of the New York Telephone Company, troubled by recent complaints and jokes about telephone service, on her own initiative invited unhappy customers to visit her operators yesterday for a first-hand report.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The American Bankers Association announced its opposition today not only to the version of the one-bank holding company bill that passed the House of Representatives, but also to any further action on such legislation until a basic study is made of the nation's entire financial system.
ATLANTA, Feb. 6 (AP) Walt Bellamy teamed with Lou Hudson tonight to pace the Atlanta Hawks to a 104-93 victory over the Chicago Bulls in a National Basketball Association contest.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 6 (AP) Mrs. Walter Winchell wife of Walter Winchell, the retired columnist, died yesterday in a Phoenix hospital. She was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Two of nine defendants were found guilty today of willfully destroying Dow Chemical Company property in an antiwar demonstration. They were convicted after they pleaded no contest to one charge against them.

Mayor Lindsay moved yesterday to take away some of the payment powers of the Human Resources Administration, the target of Federal criticism of fiscal mismanagement. Several indictments and convictions for mishandling of funds have been obtained against employe of the superagency.
A Bronx man and his common-law wife were charged with criminal negligence yesterday in connection with a fire in which two of their children were killed and a third was injured.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that the First National City Bank and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., had violated Federal securities laws by operating an unregistered investment company.
