DETROIT, Feb. 6 (AP) Shutdowns at 14 of the Big Three auto makers' assembly plants across the country idled more than 50,000 workers and slowed auto production this week.
For refusing to answer questions when granted immunity from prosecution for the answers, an alleged member of a gambling ring was jailed for 90 days yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 7 (AP) The allies resumed offensive operations throughout South Vietnam last night at the end of their 24-hour cease-fire, which, they said, had been marked by numerous enemy violations.

WASHINGTON, Feb.6. Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma resigned unexpectedly today as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, asserting that he wanted to free himself from the "restraints" of the job.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 6 Another war seemed imminent in American tennis today when the United States Lawn Tennis Association and the two professional organizations rejected contracts for the 1970 season.
It was a sunny day, but the temperature was a raw 10 degrees, and the man named George who was sitting on the steps of the Bouwerie Lane Theatre had no coat.

Charles A. Racht, regional manager of the six Florida offices of Shearson, Hammill Co., Inc., brokers and investment bankers, died Thursday after a short illness in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived. He was 41 years old.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced the appointment of Aramis Gomez as a member of the New York Housing Authority. Mr. Gomez will replace Roger W. Flood, who will retire from the three-member authority on March 16.
PARIS, Feb. 6 Three young revolutionaries in army unit form were sentenced to prison today for distributing leaflets that allegedly incited other conscripts to insubordination.

Hardly a week goes by that someone high in the Administration fails to pay his respects to the environment, which for political purposes is beginning to take on the combined attributes of flag and motherhood. The trouble with this admission of pure air and water into the pantheon of national symbols is that it becomes harder and harder for the public to tell whether the environment is being saved or only revered.

Homebound service out of Brooklyn on the Long Island Rail Road was briefly disrupted last night when the line defied a union threat and used supervisors to man a train whose crewmen had been abused by riders Thursday.
Dr. Bruno Bettelheim asserted yesterday that teachers could not do much about the spread of narcotics addiction in schools.
Arnold Palmer, whose boyish charm and faculty for miraculous comebacks sent professional golf into a multimillion-dollar spiral, was chosen athlete of the decade yesterday.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 6 Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey F. Kritzler of Ridgewood and High Falls, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Zoe Ann Kritzler, to Stephen Jordan Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Jordan Potter of White Plains.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 (AP) The United States command announced today that the person who placed four agents in the Saigon press corps had been reprimanded and transferred to a new assignment.

SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 6 Palmer Scott, founder of the Palmer Scott Company, Inc., boat builders, died Wednesday in Grenada, the West Lndies, where he was vacationing. He was 72 years old and lived on Jordan Road here.
The new-issue market slipped into the doldrums this week. Fewer companies made initial public offerings of their stock, prices declined and trading activity remained light.

NEWARK, Feb. 6 Anthony Imperiale, a City Councilman who is running for Mayor, today warned a Puerto Rican group known as the Young Lords that there would "not be any old lords" if they violated a police order to leave a school they had helped keep open during a teachers' strike.

FORT DAVIS, Tex., Feb. 6 (AP) An employe of the McDonald Observatory, described as drunk by the sheriff and as mentally depressed by his superiors, fired seven shots last midnight at a delicate $1-million telescope mirror.

In preparation for its 1970 gala, the Million Dollar Extravaganza, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on May 4, the benefit committee for the Waldemar Medical Research Foundation will participate in a Million Dollar Viaggetto (a little voyage) to foundation headquarters in Woodbury, L.I., on Tuesday.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 6 The Ardsley (N.Y.) Curling Club No. 2 rink, skipped by William Nolan, defeated the New York Caledonian Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Vernon Hambly, the 1968 winner, 13-6, tonight in the second round of the 15th annual Cuthbertson bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

The American Civil Liberties Union has proposed to the Federal Government the release from the Army of all men inducted under Selective Service delinquency regulations that were subseqently held invalid by the Supreme Court.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 Mrs. Tyler Young has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sarah Tyler Young, to Flying Officer Joseph Alan Wilkinson of the Royal Air Force.

DOVER, Del., Feb. 6 Charles L. Terry Jr., Governor of Delaware from 1965 to 1969, and former Chief Justice of the Delaware Supreme Court, died here today, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 69.
Natale Evola, a former convict with financial interests in several garment and trucking companies, was described at a public hearing yesterday as a Mafia "strong man" in the garment center.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 6 Yugoslavia and the European Economic Community today concluded a three-year nonpreferential, nondiscriminatory trade agreement, the Common Market's first commercial treaty with an Eastern European country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 A -House subcommittee heard again today that Federal grants to symphony orchestras and dance companies in ever-deeper financial trouble were not enough. A recital of achievements in film provided the only cheerful note.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (UPI) The National Hockey League cracked down on teams whose players leave their benches to join in fights, slapping three separate teams with $1,000 fines each and levying a total of $4,300 in fines to 39 players from four clubs.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 6 Belgium ended 1969 with an estimated 6 per cent increase of her gross national product, her industrial potential nearly engaged to capacity and price increases below those of her partners in the European Common Market.

Caught, they say, in a cost squeeze, American truckers are gearing up for another attempt to push through Congress legislation that would permit wider, longer and heavier trucks on the nation's interstate highways. Advances narrowly topped declines on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the list moved ahead in quiet trading.

THE incredible virtuosity of Peter Ustinov lent heart break, humor and hope to Rod Serling's inspired original drama entitled "A Storm in Summer," seen last night on the Hallmark Hall of Fame over the National Broadcasting Company network.

THE search for fine Tudor furniture is on for astute collectors just learning to appreciate its quality.
LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Feb. 6 (AP) Armed police clashed with Roman Catholic civil rights demonstrators tonight after a mob hurled rocks at British soldiers.

BOSTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) City and state officials, in an 11thhour effort to keep the Boston Patriots football team here, outlined a plan today to build a $16-million football stadium with funds guaranteed by horseracing revenue.

Richard N. Hughes, vice president of WPIX-TV, Channel 11, defended the public and community service records of his station in a speech to the City Club of New York yesterday. WPIX broadcast license is currently being challenged.

Marty Liquori is rapidly becoming the darling of the Madison Square Garden track gallery because (1) he wins and (2) he makes his races exciting. Last night, switching from the familiar mile to the relatively unfamiliar 1,000-yard run, he won an exciting race.

MOST families faced with the conditions that prevail in New York City schools have done one of three things: moved to the suburbs, turned to private or parochial resources or tried to cope as best they could with existing conditions.

The three United States Attorneys for the Eastern and Southern Districts of New York and for New Jersey met yesterday and discussed how to coordinate their fight against organized crime in the metropolitan area.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 6 Mickey Mantle's runaway victory in yesterday's pro-am didn't carry over into the opening round of the $30,000 American Airlines Astrojet Classic today, but he treated fans to one of the tournament's most spectacular shots.

Democratic supporters of Arthur J. Goldberg for the party's nomination for Governor have intensified their efforts to persuade him to run.
Antonio (Tony Ducks) Corallo, convicted last December of conspiracy to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus, was sentenced to a four and a half year prison term yesterday.

A strike against two northern New Jersey bus lines and a third serving upstate New York communities ended its sixth day yesterday with no signs of a quick settlement. Forty thousand commuters have had to find other means of transportation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to withdraw its order permitting elections this year for the Indiana legislature to be conducted without redistricting.
NEWARK, Feb. 6 (AP) Ellis F. White, the president of Essex County Community College, announced his resignation from that post today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The slowdown of the national economy pushed unemployment significantly higher in January to 3.9 per cent of the labor force, the Labor Department reported today.

A group or men who were "insiders" of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company almost six years ago were ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Dudley B. Bonsal to repay to the company their profits made in trading in its stock at that time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 A major post office project originally planned for New York City was shifted today to Jersey City.

WASHINGTON Senator George S. McGovern, the South Dakota Democrat and his wife, Eleanor, bought their $115,000 home fully furnished last June, and, since then, Mrs. McGovern has been rearranging the furniture. But no matter how she does it, the pieces always seem to end up just as they were in June.

TULSA, Feb. 6 Skating with the confidence of a world champion, Tim Wood of Colorado Springs, Colo., successfully defended his National men's figure skating championship tonight at the Tulsa Assembly Center.

Cambridge, Mass., Feb. 6 (AP) John Kolier came off the bench in the second half tonight, hit on six straight fieldgoal attempts and led Penn to an 86-77 basketball victory over Harvard. It was the Quakers' seventh triumph in Ivy League play in which they are unbeaten.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 6 Harry Bernstein contemplated a forkful of turkey chow mein, paused a moment before putting it in his mouth, and said, "You couldn't duplicate this meal anywhere outside for less than $2."

The Federal Government by offering the highest interest rates in more than a century persuaded public holders of 85 per cent of $5.57-billion of maturing bonds to exchange them for new notes yielding 8 per cent or more.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 6 Larry Ziegler, Who jumped from the ranks of the rabbits last year when he won the Michigan Golf Classic, remained the pacesetter in the $125,000 Bob Hope Golf Classic today. No longer forced to seek a qualifying spot each week as he is now a tournament winner, the 30-year-old St. Louis professional completed his three best rounds on the tour with a 54-hole aggregate of 200.

Tito Gobbi, the Italian baritone, will appear with the Metropolitan Opera for the first time this season on Feb. 28 as Scarpia in Puccini's "Tosca." Dorothy Kirsten will sing the title role; Richard Tucker will portray Cavaradossi.
Seven high school students and another teen-ager were arrested yesterday outside a Bronx high school on charges of possessing heroin.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 Two defendants showed up at the Chicago conspiracy trial this morning wearing black judicial robes, but soon afterward Judge Julius J. Hoffman ruled that they and the five other men at the defense table were just defendants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 President Nixon called today for an end to "sterile discussions" between Republicans and Democrats "as to who really deserves the credit for discovering the issue of dealing with pollution."

MIAMI, Feb. 6 (AP) Barbara Hunter's Pattee Canyon, making her first start since October, closed with a rush to win the sixth race at Hialeah Park today. She raced the 5 furlongs on the grass in 1:03, only two-fifths of a second slower than the track record.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 New York City welfare officials, complaining that relief recipients are forced to pay high rents for the dregs of the city's shrinking housing supply, plan to ask the Legislature for permission to finance cooperative housing.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb 6 The National Basketball Association voted today to expand to 18 teams for next season with the addition of four new franchises.

Miss Gillian Feeley and Alan Martin Harnik, graduate students in anthropology at New York University, were married yesterday in the office of Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman, a chaplain at Columbia University.

LONDON, Feb. 6 When twenty London policemen broke up a showing of Andy Warhol's "Flesh," and seized the film, it was only the latest in a series of repressive incidents in this supposedly permissive society. The police have confiscated John Lennon's erotic lithographs from an art gallery, harried respectable printers and arrested underground newspaper editors, all in the name of public decency.

The Board of Education said yesterday that nominating petitions of candidates seeking election to local school boards in Manhattan, as well as in other boroughs, would be accepted starting Monday despite present uncertainty over the eventual school district boundaries in Manhattan.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6 The State Urban Development Corporation plans to redevelop an 11-acre downtown residential neighborhood here in a project that will include 1,000 apartments for people of low and middle income.
SUEZ, United Arab Republic, Feb. 6 The voice of the imam appealing from the mosque to the survivors of Suez for fortitude and sacrifice echoed figuratively through the empty streets of the city.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 6 A vivid example of how much Oscar Robertson means to the Cincinnati Royals was presented tonight at Cincinnati Gardens, where the New York Knickerbockers took advantage of the Big O's absence to run up a 135-92 victory over the Royals.

THE lead of a singleton against a slam contract in a suit is a double-edged venture. The slight chance that the lead may produce an immediate ruff for the defense must be offset against the possibility that a queen or a jack in the hand of the other defender will be trapped.

Johnson offered today his version of the events two years ago that led to an end of the American troop build-up in Vietnam, a partial halt in the bombing of North Vietnam and his decision not to run for re-election.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Senator Roman L. Hruska of Nebraska said today that a civil rights lobbyist had given a misleading impression that Judge G. Harrold Carswell showed racial bias in his Federal District Court decisions.

NEWARK, Feb. 6 Two years ago, a Governor's commission studying the 1967 riots in New Jersey concluded that the Newark public school system was in "an advanced state of decay" and recommended that the state operate the system during the "educational crisis."
LENINGRAD, Feb. 6 (AP) Gabriele Seyfert, the skating star from East Germany, won her third European figure-skating championship tonight.

President Nixon has promised to "take a new and searching look at American education," but his 1971 budget offers only slender clues to the meaning of that pledge. The one certainty is that whatever new action is to be proposed will have to be carried out without additional funds. Education is confronted with a stand-pat budget.

THE PRESIDENT Activities, President Nixon visited the Hanover sewage treatment plant near Chicago. Later in the morning the President met in Chicago with four Middle Western Governors on pollution problems. He returned to Washington in the late afternoon.

MOSCOW. Feb. 6 The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia called on all peaceloving countries today to take "the most urgent measures" to end what it called Israel's "military escalation" against the United Arab Republic and other Arab states.
BONN, Feb. 6 A conscientious civil servant has discovered that the federal Government's belief in and affection for expertise is costing West German taxpayers well over a million dollars a year.
DENVER, Feb. 6 Multiple explosions destroyed 24 empty school buses and damaged 15 more last night when at least 12 dynamite bombs went off under their gas tanks.

Some critics of the city subway system, testifying yesterday at a legislative hearing on its efficiency, called for the dismissal of all of the members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the system. Others were willing to settle for the resignation of its chairman, Dr. William J. Ronan.
Mayor John V. Lindsay yesterday helped welcome the Chinese Lunar New Year 4668, the Year of the Dog as firecrackers crackled and lion dancers pranced in Chinatown.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Federal aid to school districts serving children living in public housing units came one step closer today when the Senate voted 43 to 32 to retain this new program in the $35-billion, four-year aid-to-education bill now being debated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Approval was granted today to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to operate the airfield at Stewart Air Force Base in Newburgh, N.Y.

The widow of Jack F.A. Flynn, national sales manager of television station WPIX, received a $615,000 settlement yesterday for the death of her husband in the crash of an American Airlines jet at Cincinnati on Nov. 8, 1965.
He seldom speaks, and then only in Spanish, but Luis Sarria doesn't have to He communicates in other ways.
WASHINGTON, Feb.6 Informed sources in the State Department said today that the Nigerian effort to relieve malnutrition in the former enclave of Biafra had reached a critical turning point.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 6 (AP) Two students wanted to go to Cuba and hijacked a jet plane today to take them there. A few hours later one of them was killed by police bullets, and four persons who had taken part in a police plan to stop them were wounded.
GARDINER, Me., Feb. 6 Miss Susan Dana and David I. Kertzer will be married May 30 in Augusta.
Federal Judge Sylvester Ryan has concluded that the printing press division of R. Hoe Co. should be sold or leased immediately without awaiting a plan of reorganization for the company.

You call it churning, but your broker says he is merely taking advantage of shifting investment opportunities. You haven't proved your case when you show that you have lost money as a result of rapid-fire trading. Nobody's perfect, your broker will say.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 A spokesman for the State Department said today that the first 3,000 of 18,000 Laotian refugees on the Plaine des Jarres were evacuated by American aircraft yesterday.
Gastona Marie Rossilli, who was a fashion-behavioral consultant to department stores and the Fashion Institute, died Thursday in her home at 45 Christopher Street after an illness of several months.

Mississippi's largest school district, in Jackson, the state capital, peacefully integrated its 55 schools yesterday while Gov. John Bell Williams and three other Southern Governors laid plans for a strategy session aimed to stem federally ordered desegregation.

The Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church of America, the largest of three Russian Orthodox groups in the United States, announced yesterday that Russian church officials in Moscow had agreed to acknowledge its independence.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 6 Miss Susanne Rheault, whose father, Col. Robert B. Rheault, retired in October as the commander of Special Forces (Green Berets) in Vietnam, plans to be married in June to John Anderson Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Brown of Wayne, Pa., and Bay Head, N.J.

CRANSTON, R.I., Feb. 6(AP) Louis J. Taglianetti, said by the police to be an underworld figure, and a woman companion were found shot to death tonight at the bottom of a flight of steps leading to a Broad Street apartment house.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Chief Justice of the United States, Warren E. Burger urged the states today to develop some simple method for hearing "promptly, fully and fairly" the grievances of prisoners.
Because of renewed demand for soybean meal by poultry and livestock producers, futures prices of that commodity closed strong yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The International Brotherhood of Teamsters is attempting to organize some 5,000 stockbrokers in the Chicago area.
A possible conflict-of-interest case involving a former deputy commissioner of the old Department of Licenses as referred by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

It is conventional wisdom about the Middle East that (1) the super-powers share an interest in peace, but cannot "control" the states with which they are closely associated; (2) the absence of peace is the equal responsibility of Israel and its Arab neighbors; and (3) the United States has been "pro-Israeli," at the expense of broader national interests.

The Interstate Department Stores, Inc., reported yesterday that five-week sales ended Feb. 1 rose 18.8 per cent to $42,415,500 from the yearearlier $35,708,600. The figures do not include supermarket sales.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Flynn of Sands Point, L.I., and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Gray Flynn, to Capt. Stephen Lawrence Gordon, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Gordon of Tenafly, N.J.

Assemblyman Stanley Steingut, the minority leader, announced his sponsorship yesterday of a bill to enable the city to take over apartments that are being held vacant by landlords who hope to convert them to offices.

Dean Morton I. Teicher of the Wurzweiler School of Social Work at Yeshiva University and Mrs. Teicher of New York, formerly of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Margaret Teicher, to Alvin James Goldman. Mr. Goldman is the son of Mrs. Bernard E. Rand of Shaker...

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 6 Seeded players swept their first-round matches today in the Eastern indoor tennis championships sponsored by the Mecca Tennis Club of New York City. Play was conducted at the Eastern Clay Indoor Tennis Club.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 6 Walter M. Shohl, a former judge of the Ohio Court of Appeals, died here last night at his home at the Queen City Club. His age was 84.

Revenues and earnings of the Halliburton Company set records in the fourth quarter and all 1969, L.B. Meaders, president, reported yesterday from Dallas. Revenues exceeded $1billion for the first time.
The General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday "significant gains" in sales of electricity and revenues for 1969 but "a modest decline" in earnings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today to overturn a Federal judge's ruling that a District of Columbia law was unconstitutional because it permits abortions only when the mother's life or health is in danger.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The Nixon Administration has decided to sell Israel new jet aircraft and other war material she requested in the fall, high official quarters said today.

Bernard Cornfeld, a former Philadelphia social worker who now heads the Geneva-based Investors Overseas Services Corporation, has purchased for $500,000 an 18th century, 80room Swiss castle that the United States had owned for seven years.
Taxpayers were urged by the Internal Revenue Service yesterday to file their tax returns as soon as possible to avoid delays of refunds.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 (AP) The Liberian flag freighter Antonios Demades was reported sinking today 780 miles east of Japan as a Coast Guard cutter sped to the rescue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The families of more than 12,000 servicemen are on the nation's welfare rolls and receive monthly welfare checks, food stamps, surplus food or other forms of assistance, the Defense Department reported today.

The sudden deaths of four Negro Army recruits during basic training at Fort Bliss, in El Paso, has prompted an Army doctor to urge that all Negro military recruits be screened for an inherited blood condition known as sickle cell trait.

After two decades of inaction, based on sophistry and outright hypocrisy, there are signs that the United States may at last be moving to ratify the International Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 6 (UPI) Norm Ferguson's two goals within one minute in the first period gave the Oakland Seals a 2-1 triumph over the St. Louis Blues tonight.
DETROIT, Feb. 6 The General Motors Corporation today reported gains in its minority group hiring, even among the salaried ranks, although the number of salaried black workers was still low.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, warned state and local governments today not to put off the "necessary" step of removing legal ceilings on bond interest rates in the hope that market interest rates would decline.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 7 Tran Ngoc Chau, an Opposition deputy accused by President Nguyen Van Thieu of Communist affiliations, says he feels he has been betrayed by the America mission here despite a long and close working relationship.

GREAT MEADOWS, N.J., Feb. 6 The Rev. Charles Francis Nugent, who retired last year after 16 years, as rector of the Episcopal Church of the Nativity, at Ocean Avenue and Farragut Road in Brooklyn, died yesterday in Warren Hospital, Philipsburg. He was 66 years old and lived here.

LONDON, Feb. 6 Peter Shaffer is one of the small band of British playwrights who believe that the entertainment play is a form robust enough to carry weightier issues. This certainly brought him popular success with "The Royal Hunt of the Sun." And perhaps it will do so again with his new play, "The Battle of Shrivings," at the Lyric Theater.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 Israeli jets attacked and sank a 700-ton Egyptian minelayer with a crew of 80 in the Gulf of Suez this evening, the Israelis reported. The attack apparently was in retaliation for the sinking of an Israeli coastal vessel in Elath harbor before dawn.
An unemployed cook with a coast-to-coast record of arrests jumped in the wrong car the other night after allegedly robbing a cab driver.
Warsaw, Feb. 6 (AP) Polish and West German representatives ended two days of talks today and agreed to meet again next month.
CAIRO, Feb. 6 Warfare between the United Arab Republic and Israel flared over a wide front today, with reports of ships being sunk, aircraft shot down and targets under heavy fire on both sides.

Mayor Lindsay cautioned business executives here yesterday that their federally supported program of hiring the hard-core unemployed needed to emphasize keeping the men employed and upgrading their skills.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 George F. Kennan, former Ambassador to Moscow, warned today that the United States could be jeopardizing talks with the Soviet Union on strategic arms control by "plunging ahead" with large new weapons, such as a missile defense system.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 6 A new inter-American negotiating unit was created here today in which the United States can be called to account for restricting the entry of Latin American goods into its market.
The National Steel Corporation announced yesterday it was following the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in introducing a guaranteed-price policy.

YOU might have imagined which is a critic's sly way of saying "I myself imagined" that Woody Allen's "Play It Again, Sam" was a vehicle with only a single trip ticket. Mr. Allen wrote about Mr. Allen for Mr. Allen. So how can the non-real Woody Allen stand up?
The Continental Corporation, which owns 34 per cent of the outstanding shares of Diners Club, Inc., announced yesterday it planned to acquire the rest through a tender offer at $15 a share.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Both the United Mine Workers of America and the Federal Government came under renewed, angry criticism today for what was described as prolonged, joint toleration of corruption, fear and violence among the nation's 200,000 coal miners.
A Bronx landlord and a former tenant in his building were indicted yesterday for the murder of three boys, two of whom they were said to have hired to start a fire in the structure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, introduced today a bill to outlaw eight long-lived insecticides, including one pest killer that has been called deadlier than DDT.
Julius Bendheim, former head of several real estate companies here, died of a stroke in his home at 911 Park Avenue on Thursday after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

ROME, Feb. 6 The audience is the instrument of a group of young American composers who have been honing their collective, electronic techniques here for three threadbare years and are now headed, somewhat nervously, for a New York debut and an American tour.

As everyone west of NeverNever Land expected, the New York Knickserbockers defeated the Cincinnati Royals last night in their National Basketball Association game before a capacity crowd of 19,500 at Madison Square Garden. The score was 121-114.
WASHINGTON The Congressional doves were aflutter last week. Their long muted cries were heard again in the land as they challenged the Nixon policy in Vietnam.
HAYNESVILLE, La., Feb. 7 (UPI) The Claiborne Parish Sheriff's office said today that the body of the Black Panther leader, Fred Hampton, was exhumed yesterday for a third autopsy.
INZELL, West Germany, Feb. 7 (AP) Erhard Keller of West Germany led the field in an international speed-skating meet today. Japanese skaters occupied the next three places.

MIAMI, Feb. 7 Trainer Frank I. Wright was standing by the clubhouse rail at Hialeah the other morning, shading his eyes from the sun and worriedly observing the antics of a filly named Embecias who was galloping into the clubhouse turn.

At dawn of March 10, 1948, Czechoslovakia's immensely popular Foreign Minister, Jan Masaryk, a democratic idealist, fell to his death from the bathroom window of his apartment at the Czernin Palace in Prague.

CRANFORD, N.J., Feb. 7 The engagement of Miss Laurie Arlene Kammler to David Russell McShane has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward August Kammler Jr. of Cranford and Wolfeboro, N.H., parents of the bride-to-be. Mr. McShane is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Russell McShane of Montclair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The gypsy moth, once confined to the Hudson River region, is now infiltrating public and privately owned forests as far south as Virginia and threatening future supplies of wood products.

Leeds Moberley, a newspaperman for more than 40 years and a former president of the New York Newspaper Guild, died yesterday in Flushing General Hospital of emphysema and cardiac arrest. He was 64 years old and lived at 144-11 75th Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

Westminster's entry will be passed upon by 53 judges, who will come from 17 states, the Virgin Islands, Australia, Canada and England. The slate always is arranged so that the dog that gets the best-in-show award will have been judged by three separate arbiters one in the breed, one in the variety group competition and the third in the final.

WILTON, Conn., Feb. 7 The engagement of Miss Nancy Marie Gallant, a junior at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Michael Gerald Connors, a junior at Fairfield University, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Gallant, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Connors.

SURFERS PARADISE, Australia, Feb. 7 (AP) Frank Matich of Australia, driving a McLaren MIOA Chevrolet, smashed the lap record by nearly two seconds today as he set the fastest qualifying time for the Rothman's 100-mile race.

LENINGRAD, Feb. 7 (AP) Ludmila Pahhomova and Aleksandr Gorshkov, Moscow students, became the first Russians ever to win the dancing title of the European figure skating championships, Tass reported today.

SERGEI DENHAM, who died Jan. 30, at 73, pro- vided a small but nonetheless significant footnote to the history of American dance. Born in Moscow, he settled in the United States after the revolution, and worked both here and in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The two senior surviving American participants in the Yalta conference, reminiscing a quarter of a century after that historic effort to shape the postwar world, see it as a landmark in United States diplomacy despite the criticisms it later drew.

Long Island Rail Road trains will continue to run, including the embattled 7:07 P.M., Brooklyn-to-Far Rockaway local, if police protection is provided for railroad employes, the head of the trainmen's union announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The State Department denied today that the Nixon Administration had already decided to meet Israel's request to purchase more jet aircraft.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 7 (AP) O. Pappa took the lead at the start and defeated a field of eight other older handicap horses in the $15,000 King Cotton Handicap at Oaklawn Park Saturday.

WASHINGTON In sending his precariously balanced $200.8-billion budget to Congress last week, President Nixon dipped his toe into waters largely avoided by his predecessors. He gently suggested that Congress might want to think about improving its own way of handling the budget an issue that has reached such seriousness that some observers have concluded that a rational fiscal policy is all but impossible in the United States.
On the yellow-and-black showcard, Joe Frazier's name is on top in red letters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Mrs. Lelia Gordon Noyes, widow of Newbold Noyes, an associate editor of The Washington Star, was married here today to the Rev. Dr. Albert Hawley Lucas, retired dean of the Episcopal Divinity School in Philadelphia.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 7 Severe winter weather for the past two months has had one beneficial effect on a project undertaken here by the Research Center of the Bureau of Mines.
A 22-year-old Army lieutenant is to go on trial tomorrow in South Vietnam charged with the "premeditated murder" of a suspected Vietcong agent last September, according to his lawyer in New York.
FILLMORE, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP) Plans for an $89-million water project have been suspended by the Department of the Interior to head off a threat to the nearly extinct California condor.

Andy Yuen of the Southern California Striders upset Al Hall, the National champion and Olympic team member, in the 35-pound weight throw yesterday as the 51st annual Knights of Columbus meet was completed with two field events.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Formation of a nationwide, nonpartisan coalition "to wipe out rural shacks and replace them with decent homes" was announced today.

"THE Last Sweet Days of Isaac" is my favorite rock musical thus far for three reasons: (a) The songs end when they are over; (b) While a boy and girl are doing all that talking about coming alive, they are alive; and (c) Language at last is beginning to rise to the beat.
Frank Leahy, whose wonlost record as a coach was exceeded only by his tutor, Knute Rockne, was named yesterday to the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.

It is the story of the destruction of a wealthy family presided over by patriarchal Hermann Weil, and particularly it is the story of Elli, his teen-age granddaughter, who survived.

THE comparison to a James Bond exploit was inevitable, altlhough airlifting a stolen 7-ton radar station would have been rejected by Ian Fleming, Bond's creator, as too fanciful, too improbable even for his implausible hero. Yet to the world's astonishment, Zahal, the Israeli Defense Forces, in December stole and then airlifted to Israel a 7-ton Russian-built radar station, together with its crew.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 7 Bernie Wells, 16-year-old Brattleboro (Vt.) Union School athlete, won the Donald B. Stewart Trophy in ski jumping today with a 163-foot jump on the 50-meter hill.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 7 Like a baby trying to run before he has learned to walk, tennis has stumbled to new chaotic depths.
WEST CHESTER, Pa., Feb. 7 St. John's University's swimming team, undefeated in its first nine meets, suffered its first loss, 60-53, today to West Chester State Teachers.
SEATTLE, Feb. 7 A Soviet employe of the United Nations was arrested today and charged with espionage in trying to obtain secret information about the missile defense of the Pacific Northwest.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 7 Miss Lucinda Braddock Watson, third of the five daughters of Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, and Mrs. Watson, was married here this afternoon to Sherman Alan Kew.

E.L. O'Neill, formerly senior vice president, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Emerson Electric Company, St. Louis. W.L. Davis, formerly president, has been elected vice chairman of the board and chief administrative officer, and W.R. Persons has been re-elected chairman of the board and chief executive officer. All three are Emerson directors.

COPENHAGEN. ON July 1, Denmark became the first Western nation to remove legal prohibitions against the production and sale of hard-core pornography to adults that is, any one at least 16 years old. In October, the leaders of the already flourishing pornography industry, like their counterparts in pleasure-boating, electronics or home-furnishings, hired a public-relations man and put on a trade show to display their wares.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 7 The University of Pennsylvania lived up to its national ranking as the Quakers romped to a 96-68 Ivy League basketball victory over Dartmouth before a crowd of 2,000 tonight in Alumni Gym.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 7 Miss Jean Elizabeth Smith, a learning-resources specialist for the Harvard Graduate Lesley College, will be married this spring to Stanley Shepard, who is enrolled in a doctoral program at the Harvard School of Education.

ALBANY, Ga., Feb. 7 Miss Mary Elizabeth Lashley and E. Lawrence Barcella Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Barcella of Bethesda, Md., will be married here March 21. The future bridegroom's father is manager of public relations for General Motors in Washington.
C.W. Post College broke a pair of meet records yesterday in the Collegiate Track Conference's 14th annual relay carnival at Queens College.

President Nixon's nomination of Federal District Judge G. Harold Carswell of Florida to the Supreme Court was stalled in the Senate Judiciary Committee last week as opponents used parliamentary ploys to delay a committee vote. As a result, it now appears that the full Senate may have to wait until the beginning of March to vote on the Carswell appointment.

MANILA, Feb. 7 President Ferdinand E. Marcos today accepted the resignation of Brig. Gen. Vicente Raval, chief of the Philippine Constabulary, who had been accused of permitting police brutality during a riot at the presidential palace here last week at which five students were killed.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) Najeeb E. Halaby, president of Pan American World Airways, predicts that Pan Am and other carriers will be in the space transportation business in the nineteen-eighties.

"ON one thing there was general agreement," said Louis Jouvet about his historic production in 1947 of Moliere's "Dom Juan," "that reading of the play gave no indication of what came out in performance."
ANNVILLE, Pa., Feb. 7 New York University's undefeated wrestling team trounced Dickinson and Lebanon Valley, the host school, in a triangular meet today.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 7 (UPI) After more than a year of discord, the presidents of Puerto Rico's two legislative houses have found something they can agree upon: cockroaches.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 7 The Government reported this week that 12 of the nationalist guerrillas who invaded Rhodesia from Zambia early last month had been killed, one of them while trying to escape.

TAKAYAMA, Japan Old Japan, which in Tokyo and other industrialized cities seems buried under clouds of smog, screeches of brakes and the glittering neon of go-go nightclubs, is alive and well here in this small town in the foothills of the Japanese Alps on Honshu Island. Somehow, Takayama has retained the style and flavor of the past in its daily life and, most especially, in centuries-old festivals, which the townspeople reenact every spring and fall.
The 230-lb, 24-year old financial tycoon shifts his bulk in the chair as the market ends its day-long gyrations with a whimper.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 (AP) Dave Bing scored 32 points and Otto Moore had a career high of 27 to lead the Detroit Pistons to a 113-109 victory over the Seattle Sonics in the National Basketball Association tonight.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 7 (AP) Scoring as many points in the first half as their opponents did in the entire game today, South Carolina routed Clemson 99-52. It was the Gamecocks' 16th consecutive basketball victory.
In Enugu, Port Harcourt, Umuahia and the other battered towns of the former Biafra, the slow healing of the physical scars of war has started.

International Ways of meeting increased Israeli assaults are expected to be discussed at the strategy conference of leaders of five Arab countries that opened yesterday in Cairo as much as ways of coordinating tactics of attack. Taking part are representatives of the United Arab Republic, Jordan, Syria, Iraq and the Sudan. Libya decided not to attend, apparently because of her sensitive arms negotiations with France. SAN CIPIRELLO, Sicily, Feb. 7 (Reuters) The Communist Mayor and the Republican Deputy Mayor of this village near Palermo have formed a nonpolitical alliance they were married, this week.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 7 Manhattan College won the one-mile and two-mile relays tonight, the last two events of the program, and defeated Navy and Penn State in a triangular track meet at the Naval Academy.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 The men considered the two best tennis players in the world, seeded No. 1 and 2 in the tournament, both Australian and left-handed, will meet tomorrow for the $10,000 first prize in the International Tennis Players Association indoor open.

Mrs. Charlotte Borg Erickson of Chicago and Honolulu, widow of L. Hyland Erickson, was married here yesterday to Howard Lowell Hartman of New York and Hartford. Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr. performed the ceremony at the River Club.
Columbia's basketball team, winner of 14 of its first 17 games, takes its second trip into New England next weekend, playing at Dartmouth Friday and at Harvard Saturday.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 7 Coumbia needed a good defense to handle a sometimes difficult Yale team and that was just what the Lions worked on as they trounced the Eli, 96-69, before 2,200 persons in Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) Federal and state indemnities paid to farmers under cooperative hog cholera control programs last year nearly tripled from that of 1968 because of the most outbreaks of the disease since the eradication campain began eight years ago.

MADISON, N.J., Feb. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Fred M. Kirby 2d have made known the engagement of their daugher, Miss Alice Sutherland Kirby, to George A. Horton 3d of Morristown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horton 2d of San Mateo, Calif.

A black-and-silver Afghan from Tulsa, Okla., Ch. Shangrila's Pharahna Phaedra, bred, owned and handled by Dr. Gerda Maria Kennedy, was named best of breed in a field of 205 yesterday at the 31st National Specialty Show of the Afghan Hound Club of America at the Statler-Hilton. It was the largest gathering of Afghans to compete in the United States.

Forty thousand daily riders of Inter-City Transportation Company buses, running between northern New Jersey and New York City, face fare increases generally of 10 per cent about April 1, a court-appointed trustee said yesterday.

DENVER, Feb. 7 (AP) Nelson Burton Jr. of St. Louis defeated three straight opponents today to take first-place money of $6,000 in the $45,000 Denver open bowling tournament.

THE Theater Guild has been bitten by the movie bug again. Last year, its Theater Guild Films made it big with "Slaves" somewhat bigger at the box office than with the critics. Now they've decided to take a second cinematic step this time joining producer Sam Jaffe to film a biography of the black abolitionist Frederick Douglass.

THERE is clear evidence of urban disaster on this page today. The process of abandonment of sound housing in the midst of a housing shortage is epidemic. At least 100,000 apartments have already been lost. Another half-million are now threatened l,350,000 people who will have to find new places to live in a city where there are no new places to live.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 A study group of the National Institute of Dental Research is working toward the goal of virtually eliminating tooth decay in the United States.

ONE of the New York City Opera's leading sopranos, Patricia Brooks, has been mar- ried for 16 years to Theodore Mann, a well-known theatrical producer and director.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 The protracted battle over constitutionality of prayer and Bible readings in public school classrooms has been taken to the Federal Court of Appeals here by both sides.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Arthur F. Burns, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, declined today to give any clue as to when and by how much the Federal Reserve would relax its extremely restrictive monetary policy. But he pledged to "do everything in my power to help this country prevent a recession."

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 7 Miss Janet Holmes and Gustave Adolph Heckscher 3d were married here this afternoon in the chapel of St. Luke's Episcopal Cathedral by Canon Thomas Smith.

Its six teeming blocks are littered with some of the world's most expendable objects: old shoes and antiques, statuary and used eyeglasses, illuminated manuscripts and worn-out tires. What lures the shopper native and tourist alike is the chance of a special bargain.

An accused bank robber, injured in a fall and abandoned by eight other prisoners in an escape from the Federal House of Detention here, was seized in a parked truck yesterday a half block from the prison on the western edge of Greenwich Village.

Reserved seats for the second edition of the Olympic invitation track meet at Madison Square Garden Feb. 20 are now on sale at the Garden box office and at the office of the New York Olympic Committee, Suite 1818, Hotel Warwick, 65 West 54th Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The nation's scheduled airlines carried 10.6 per cent more air cargo on domestic routes in 1969 than in 1968 for a new record, the Air Transport Association reports.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 8 (UPI)--Jean-Noel Augert of France won the slalom title today at the world Alpine ski championships after withstanding determined challenges from Patrick Russel, a teammate, and Billy Kidd of the United States.
NEWTON, N. J., Feb. 8 (AP) --The New Jersey Herald, which now is published on Thursday and Sunday, will become a daily in March.

TULSA, Okla., Feb. 8--With the world champion, Tim Wood of Colorado Springs, heading it, a well-balanced United States figure skating team will compete in the world championships in Ljubljana, Yugoslavia, March 2 through 8.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he probably would not vote to confirm the nomination of Judge G. Harrold Carswell to the United States Supreme Court, The Associated Press reported.

MASERU, Lesotho, Feb. 8 (Reuters)--The opposition Congress party, which claimed victory in Lesotho's abortive general election last month, accused Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan today of plotting to insure the victory of his party.
MOSCOW, Feb. 8--Yuri Simonov, 28 years old, has been named chief conductor of the Bolshoi Theater Orchestra. He will be the youngest chief conductor the Bolshoi has ever had.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 8 (UPI)--Australian entertainers who were performing for United States Marines when a grenade explosion in an enlisted men's club killed a marine and wounded 62 others said today that they had seen grenades lobbed from each side of the club.
An aggressive local merchant advertises refrigerators with "the longest prices in town." But a customer who bought one returns soon afterward and irately demands a...
VIENNA, Feb. 8--Soviet pressure on Rumania is mounting again after a few months' lull, in the view of analysts of Eastern European affairs.
A California physician said yesterday that the concept of health care as the treatment of separate diseases was outdated and that the total environment was "the most important determinant" of health.

The new chairman of the state Public Service Commission suggested yesterday that telephone users could "contribute to improved service" by avoiding or shortening calls during peak hours--about noon and 6 P.M.
Alton Henry Bradby, one of nine inmates who escaped from the Federal House of Detention here Friday night, returned to the prison and surrendered yesterday, reportedly at the urging of his family.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

Only one in every 10,000 drinkers has ever drunk Glenfiddich Scotch, according to William Lyons, executive vice president of Nadler Larimer. That can mean problems for the ad agency planning a testimonial campaign.

MIAMI, Feb. 8 (AP)--Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, conceded today that President Nixon "is making political points" with his Vietnam policy, but the Minnesota Democrat said the Administration needed to establish a timetable for troop withdrawal.
TOKYO, Feb. 8 (AP)--Shozo Saijo of Japan retained his World Boxing Association featherweight boxing title tonight by pounding out a 15round unanimous decision over Godfrey Stevens of Chile.

MONTREAL, Feb. 5--The English-speaking inhabitants of Montreal, roughly one-third of the 2.2 million people in the metropolitan area, are disturbed and divided by Quebec's latest move to strengthen the role of French as the province's principal language.

Governor Rockefeller justly chided President Nixon the other day on the disparity between the extravagance of the President's rhetoric in support of pollution control and the limited dimensions of his program for cleaning up the nation's water.

Four seasons after her Metropolitan Opera debut, Felicia Weathers came forward yesterday afternoon to proclaim that she is not only an opera star but also a singer. Her first recital here, at Alice Tully Hall, certified her credentials as a superior musician with a promising sense of what it means to address an audience in the special tone of the lieder artist.

STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 8--The towns and cities of Europe will double in population in the next 15 years, creating vast environmental problems, according to a report from the Council of Europe made available here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- Charging the Israelis with "arrogance of power," President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic has conceded that Israel now has air supremacy in the Middle East, primarily because of an abundance of highly trained pilots.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- Widespread faults and abuses in Medicare and Medicaid, with costs mounting almost beyond control, are shown in the most extensive analysis of the two health programs yet undertaken.
A Manhattan Assemblyman has proposed legislation to create a statewide public corporation to acquire and operate deteriorating or abandoned apartment houses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today that a less restrictive monetary policy at the Federal Reserve Board was needed "reasonably soon" to spur the economy in the second half of 1970.
DETROIT, Feb. 8 (UPI)-- Jean Guy Gendron scored two goals today to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a nationally televised National Hockey League game.
PORT ALLEGANY, Pa., Feb. 8--Miss Nancy Patricia Herger and A. Wilbur Duryee Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Duryee of New York and Pawling, N.Y., plan to be married on July 11.

THE WOMAN in front of the television camera is usually famous, often glamorous--and almost always well-dressed. She ought to be. Dress designers court her to wear their clothes on camera, hoping for a credit at the end of the show. They also bestow upon her that hallowed honor to which so many women aspire--wholesale buying privileges.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 8 --Australia defeated the unofficial United States team here today in the first of two "test matches". The Australians drew away in the closing stages of a wellfought match to win by 36 international match points.
Play begins tonight in twotennis tournaments featuring world-ranked stars.
A proposal that could alter the basic form of public television, and perhaps ultimately, its content, has been sent to the public and private sponsors of "Sesame Street."

Racial polarization, disruptions and growing racial tensions that sometimes explode into violence are plaguing school administrators in virtually every part of the country where schools have substantial Negro enrollments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The National Planning Association has joined the ranks of those who believe the United States may need large Federal Government budget surpluses in the new decade--not for the famillar anti-inflation economic reasons, but to fill a gap in the nation's savings.

HARTFORD, Feb. 8 (UPI)-- The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company said this weekend they had dropped their court appeals challenging Connecticut's rejection of their merger plan.

SDE BOKER, Israel, Feb. 8 (UPI)--President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic must be replaced if there is to be peace in the Middle East, David Ben-Gurion said today. Israel's first Premier added that Mr. Nasser's "position is becoming more and more critical."

STRASBOURG, France Feb. 8--The Bootes of Stoke-onTrent had no family motto, and so years ago young Robert Edward Boote, a strong willed and original Englishman, simply adopted one that he liked. It happened to be a slogan from an advertisement for British Ford cars:...
HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 8 --Pete Fishbach gained the semifinals of the Eastern men's indoor tennis championship tonight, but it's fortunate he won't have to play again until next Saturday.
Reorganization of the city's relief administration has eliminated about 2,200 caseworker jobs, Commissioner Jack R. Goldberg said yesterday.

TRENTON, Feb. 8--William Avella, 18-year-old son of Col. Joseph T. Avella, head of New Jersey's Selective Service System, was one of 18 young persons arrested in a narcotics raid made over the weekend by the Trenton police.
CADILLAC, Mich., Feb. 8-- Clarence Hill of Ishpeming, Mich., won the veterans' class competition easily today in the Briar Hill Ski Club 50-meter ski-jumping contest.

WALTER GOLDWATER, the bibliographer and proprietor of the University Place Bookshop, is the new president of the Marshall Chess Club. He is also the guiding spirit of the annual Goldwater-Marshall invitation tournament. His canny ability in over-the-board competition is welt known among metropolitan chess buffs.

If nothing else, Ken Rosemond, Georgia's basketball coach, is making life a little tougher for the 68-year-old Adolph Rupp, the baron of Blue Grass country, now in his 40th coaching season at Kentucky.
NANTUCKET, Mass., Feb. 8 --John F. Kelly, a former reporter for The New York Herald Tribune and The Hartford Courant, died of cancer at the Cottage Hospital here Thursday. His age was 69.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 8 (UPI) --A special meeting of Davis Cup nations will be held in London March 23 to consider South Africa's suspension for racial discrimination.

A long-range project to publish modern English translations of neglected but important French novels for the general reader has been undertaken by Prof. Henri Peyre, Sterling Professor of French at Yale.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 8--Israeli jets attacked what were described as military targets around Cairo today and reportedly downed two MIG-21's that were part of the first Egyptian aerial challenge to the raids in the Nile Delta.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 8 (Reuters)--The Spanish bullfighter Manuel Benitez, known as El Cordobes, was gored in the throat here yesterday but was reported out of danger today.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone-- When anyone speaks of a House of Morgan here, they are referring not to a bank but to a chain of pharmacies founded by Ernest Dunstan Morgan.

Ch. Special Edition made the headlines again yesterday when the Lakeland terrier was named the best of breed at the specialty of the United States Lakeland Terrier Club in the 102d Engineers Battalion Armory. The show was one of 13 specialties under the aegis of the Associated Terrier Clubs.

Liston M. Oak, a leader in the politics of the American left and a former managing editor of The New Leader, died Friday in Tel Aviv, while on a visit. He was 74 years old and lived in Long Valley, N.J.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 8--The Soviet mission to the United Nations was reported today to have arranged legal representation for Alexsandr V. Tikhomirov, a Russian translator for the United Nations, who was arrested in Seattle yesterday on charges of espionage.

The trustees of Columbia University announced yesterday that they have abolished the requirement that alumni trustees must have graduated from the university at least 10 years before their appointment to the board, thus making possible the selection of younger trustees.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 8--Sveinung Evensen, an 18year-old Ramapo (N.J.) high school senior, won the New York State junior cross-country ski championship today at the Anthony Wayne course.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 8-- The Most Rev. Luis Aponte Martinez, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of San Juan, said yesterday that his conditional approval of a Governmentsponsored birth control program "could and should have far reaching effects" in controlling the island's rapidly growing population.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 8-- Unionized teachers voted overwhelmingly today to strike Jersey City's four public high schools and 32 elementary schools tomorow in a contract dispute over wages.

Dogs that looked extra special were being walked along the streets of New York in the midtown area yesterday, particularly where the leading hotels were and most particularly near Madison Square Garden. The reason for this, as always at this time, was the Westminister Kennel Club Show. It will begin for the 94th consecutive year this morning in the Garden and will last through tomorrow evening.

Edward Davison, poet, teacher and lecturer, who retired two years ago as dean of the School of General Studies of Hunter College, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 435 East 57th Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) --The Internal Revenue Service said today that many taxpayers were confusing itemized deductions or personal exemptions with adjustments, thus delaying the payment of refunds.

Mr. and Mrs. Emmons Bryant of New York and Foxboro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Bryant, to Lieut. Neil Warren Hiller, U.S.M.C.R. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Charles Hiller of Milwaukee.

Miss Deborah Jane Deixel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vardon E. Deixel of Woodmere, L.I., was married at the St. Regis-Sheraton here yesterday afternoon to William Allan Mitchell Blumberg, a physicist at the Lawrence Radiation Laboratory in Livermore, Calif. The ceremony was performed by Cantor David Benedict.
More than $1-billion--double the original estimate--is expected to be needed by 1976 for a building program for the City University's senior colleges and graduate institutions.
The Prokofiev Quartet made its local debut at Vanderbilt Hall of New York University yesterday afternoon, and in some ways, the event was not routine.
Racial fears and resentment are steadily eroding relations between white teachers and administrators and black students in many, possibly most, high schools here.

For anyone interestd in the jazz styles of the thirties and forties, the Sunday jazz sessions at Uncle John's Strawhat, 316 West 49th Street, have become a living panorama of jazz history. In the month or two since these weekly performances were started by Jack Bradley, they, have featured such jazzmen as Julian Dash, Ray Nance, Roy Eldridge, Zoot Sims, Budd Johnson, Vic Dickenson and Jimmy Rushing.

CAIRO, Feb. 8--Israeli fighter-bombers striking at targets near the industrial city of Helwan wounded 12 civilian employes of the el Nasr automobile works, Egypt's Ministry of the Interior reported today.
BONN, Feb. 8 (AP)--The Foreign Ministry's state secretary, Georg Ferdinand Duckwitz, returned today from Warsaw where he held two days of talks with top officials of Poland.
The money and capital markets have just scored their most impressive advance since October, and they don't face a particularly burdensome volume of new securities for sale this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The Democratic leadership in Congress responded to President Nixon's State of the Union Message today with a nationally televised State of the Nation program that resembled Mr. Nixon's own 1968 campaign broadcasts.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP)--Jo Jo White, a rookie, sparked a Boston outburst at the outset of the third period today and the Celtics fashioned their third straight National Basketball Association victory, beating the Cincinnati Royals, 130-117.
OTTAWA, Feb. 7--The stranded Liberian oil tanker Arrow broke in two today off the coast of Nova Scotia as tugs hauled on her stern.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 8--The six governments of the European Economic Community have just tied up the loose ends of what is regarded as one of their most significant agreements since the 1957 Treaty of Rome establishing the Common Market.
The American Railway Car Institute and the Association of American Railroads reported over the weekend that orders and deliveries of new and rebuilt cars showed substantial increases last year.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (UPI)--Cale Yarborough, whose right shoulder was broken in a racing wreck two months ago, raced along the Daytona Speedway at a record 194.015 miles an hour today to gain the pole position for the $198,500 Daytona 500 stock car race on Feb. 22.
Acting on orders from President Nixon, Coast Guard tugboats began pushing sludgeladen barges away from the New Jersey coast yesterday in an effort to avert a possible health crisis.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 8--Mr. and Mrs. Abram S. Rosen of Maplewood have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margery Ellen Rosen, to Dr. Stewart M. Chodosch, the son of Mrs. David Chodosch of the Bronx and the late Mr. Chodosch.

The Dance Theater Workshop is a quietly persistent cultural force that during its four years of existence in a loft studio on West 20th Street has consistently presented new choreography. This past weekend, it opened its 15th studio series with four new works.

LONDON--One of the attractions of Britain for Americans these days is the simple feeling that it is safe. A person can walk through a park or down the street at night, without giving a thought to the possibility of robbery or assault. By American standards the level of crime in general is low.
Happiness crept quietly on little cat feet into Cunningham Walsh over the weekend and brought with it an estimated $3-million in billings.
FREDERICTON, New Brunswick--This province, which was prosperous and bustling 100 years ago but now earns only 70 per cent of the Canadian average, is engaged in economic reconstruction.

SANDERSVILLE, Ga., Feb. 8 (UPI)--The state police, fear ing a violent confrontation, halted 500 marching Negroes today and refused to let them into a high school gymnasium to hear a speech by Gov. Lester G. Maddox, who chastised whites for not fighting integration earlier.
Formation of an investment company to promote profitable agricultural enterprises in Latin America and turn them over to local ownership was announced yesterday by 12 prominent corporations.
PANAMA CITY, Feb. 8 (UPI) --Herb Hooper, a 30-year-old pro from Richmond, who shot an eagle on the 12th hole, carded a three-under-par 69 today and won the 15th annual Panama open.

MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I., Feb. 8--Fiddler's Blues, an aged brown mare owned by Jay Bolton of Huntington and handled by Sue Ford, captured all three classes to pile up 15 points and win the regular working hunter championship today at the Middle Island horse show.
The oldest church cemetery in the city, where Peter Stuyvesant, hundreds of his descendants and other historic figures are buried, is being converted into a community playground.

BUFFALO, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Clark Graebner downed Bob Lutz, 6-4, 3-6, 9-7, in the final of the Buffalo Tennis and Squash Club invitation indoor tournament today. Graebner has now won the tourney four years in a row.

Feb. 6, 1970 Following is a weekly listing of the net asset value of closed-end investment fund shares as reported by the companies through the Association of Closed-End Investment Companies at the close of business Friday.

BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (Reuters)--Western central bankers left an uneventful meeting of the Bank for International Settlements here today conscious that Washington-- not Basel--now holds the key to world monetary and economic developments.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--Two officials of the Lindsay administration today criticized as "backward" and "anticonsumer" a bill reintroduced in the Assembly that would supersede New York City's law requiring prepackaged meats to be sold in containers that are transparent on all sides.

The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest food chain, realized a 10 per cent increase in earnings last year on sales gain of 10 per cent, both setting new levels, Jacob E. Davis, chairman and president, reported over the weekend.
Four benefits have been scheduled for the opening of the 10-day National Antiques Show at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 20.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 8 (AP) --Ron Santo of the Chicago Cubs and George Andrie of the Dallas Cowboys won the $30,000 American Airlines Astrojet golf tournament today at the Goodyear Golf and Country Club course.
TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 8 (Reuters)--Iran announced today an increase of almost 50 per cent in her annual defense budget.

There must have been some quiet jubilation in the White House and the State Department the other day when Peking sent word it wants this year's second formal ChineseAmerican meeting held next Feb. 20, only one month after the initial get-together. Having gambled last year that the Chinese Communists might be favorably impressed by a unilateral American easing of trade restrictions, the Nixon Administration can be pleased that its wager is producing some dividends.

The Los Angeles Kings didn't even come close at the final buzzer last night as the Rangers closed in on one of the National Hockey League's oldest records with a 5-1 victory. The New Yorkers have gone 215 games without being shut out--the troublesome Kings last did it, in November 1968-- and are two short of the record shared by the New Yorkers of 1940, 1941 and 1942.
PARIS, Feb. 8--The French Communist party removed an ideological thorn in its side today by dropping Roger Garaudy, one of its principal intellectuals, from the Central Committee and the Politburo.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 8-- Homer P. Cochran, who retired last year as a senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York died today of a heart attack at his home, 961 Oakwood Place. He was 63 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8--The Rocket is back on top.
Prompted by "increasing complaints about poor workmanship, padded bills and defective parts used in auto repair work," the City Council will consider legislation to require licenses for mechanics.

RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 8 (AP) --Secretary of State William P. Rogers met today with the Moroccan Foreign Minister, Abdelhadi Boutalch, for what he described as a very friendly talk shout the Moroccan economy, North African affairs and the forthcoming appointment of a new United States ambassador to Morocco.
The cost to American business for control of pollution rose sharply last year and is expected to go on increasing, according to a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board.
The New York City Board of Education voted 3 to 2 yesterday to oppose a controversial bill that would repeal the State Constitution's ban on financial aid to schools with religious affiliation.

Most members of the International Association of Machinists striking 34 General Electric Company plants since Oct. 26 have apparentlyaccepted a new contract and are preparing to return to work, the Associated Press reported last night.

Minor revisions have been made in the movie industry's rating system, which was begun just over a year ago because of public resentment against excessive violence and sex scenes. The classifications set up by the Motion Picture Association of America have served to guide parents and, in the case of some films, to categorically bar admission to minors.

Irving Wiggs, who resigned last May as vice president and general manager of Gimbels, New York, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Parkview-Gem, Inc., a large discount-store chain based in Kansas City.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 8-- Paul Agnew Synnott, a former member of the advertising staff of Time magazine, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 611 Westover Road.

Miss Christina Ekengren O'Dunne, daughter of Mrs. Eugene O'Dunne Jr. of Washington and the late Mr. O'Dunne, was married on Jan. 25 to George Garrett Byers Griffin at the United States Embassy residence of Ambassador Carol Laise Bunker in Katmandu, Nepal.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 8--Eight months ago Dana Douglass, a blond, 17-year-old senior at Ridgewood (N.J.) High School, lost three horses in a fire at Holiday Farms, River Vale, N.J. First In, her top show mount, was among the three and Miss Douglass thought a good replacement would be hard to find.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 8--The New York Nets stormed back from an 11-point half-time deficit to beat the Carolina Cougars, 95-88, today in an American Basketball Association game at Island Garden.

There used to be a time not too many years ago when some insurance companies avoided you like the plague if you had a history of heart disease, diabetes, tuberculosis, cancer, epilepsy, hemophilia and a wide variety of other ailments.
State Senator Roy M. Goodman charged yesterday that heroin addicts, pushers, marijuana smokers and prostitutes were among the girls now housed in a city-run shelter in the East Village.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., Feb. 8 (AP)--Hundreds of birds have died in recent days on South Beach, where an unexplained oil slick washed ashore on the ocean side of Martha's Vineyard Island off Cape Cod.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP)--Bob Love scored 18 of his 36 points in the final quarter today, leading the Chicago Bulls to a 117107 National Basketball Association victory over Atlanta. The triumph came after the Hawks, led by Lou Hudson, took a 142-137 overtime verdict in a game that had to be resumed with one second remaining in regulation time.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., Feb. 8--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Montgomery of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Anastasia Montgomery, to William Harrison Heep, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Heep Jr. of Bronxville. A June wedding is planned.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)--Don Marcotte, a rookie wing, scored three goals and John McKenzie two tonight in a 7-1 romp by the Boston Bruins over the St. Louis Blues.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 8-- The Bayview Curling Club of Toronto, skipped by Kenneth Cooper, won the New York Caledonia medal today by defeating the Montreal Caledonian Curling Club, skipped by Jack Hobbs, 10--9, in the finals of the 15th annual Cuthbertson bonspiel at the St. Andrew's Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- Opponents of G. Harrold Carswell's Supreme Court nomination are using the current delay in his Senate confirmation proceedings to dig exhaustively into his background for any ammunition that might block his confirmation.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb., 8 --George C. Wallace urged Southern governors today to defy Federal Court integration orders and promised to seek the Presidency again in 1972 "if Nixon doesn't do something about the mess our schools are in."
EAGLE RIVER, Wis.--Twilight shadows were darkening around the Chanticleer Inn and the clean, feathery north woods snow thickened the heavy silence.

The Administration's $71.8-billion defense budget, viewed as a percentage of total Federal spending, promises to be the lowest in twenty years. It is $5.2 billion lower than defense expenditures during the current fiscal year. Yet it is headed into heavy weather in a Congress that is increasingly critical of military programs.

Joseph Brainin, journalist and writer, who retired three years ago as executive vice president of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science of Rehovot, Israel, died of a heart attack here Saturday night. He was 74 years old and lived at 172 West 79th Street.
George W. Rabinoff, a social work executive and educator, died Saturday at the New York Infirmary. He was 77 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Street.

A group from Hunter College, using paint and balloons costing $44.25 and bubbling enthusiasm, which costs nothing, accomplished a lightning redecoration of the Lexington Avenue subway station at 68th Street yesterday morning.
The city sent a plumber and two helpers yesterday to restore heat and water to a Bronx apartment house while a Commissioner and four assistants watched.

BY most rules of thumb-- at least of most thumbs --"Exchange," which opened last night at the brand-new Mercer-O'Casey Theater, is not theater. Indeed this diverting enough evening calls itself a musical entertainment, and it is an entertainment closer rather to cabaret than theater.

PARIS, Feb. 8--Une de Mai hates Vincennes. Today, shee had to face the roller-coaster course again for the third time in three weeks. She got through her ordeal as painlessly as possible by trotting a wise waiting race and winning in smooth style.

Thomas R. Dunk Jr., a retired cattle breeder from Jacksonville, Fla., won the Dachshund Club of America's 75th annual specialty last night at the Royal Manhattan Hotel. It was the third time one of his dogs had taken the top prize.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 8 --President Nison's negotiators have averted an unpleasant confrontation with Latin-American officials over inter-American trade and aid cooperation but only by making promises that depend on future action by the United States Congress.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8--The steel market is showing resistance to a downturn.

A group from Hunter College, using paint and balloons costing $44.25 and bubbling enthusiasm, which costs nothing, accomplished a lightning redecoration of the Lexington Avenue subway station at 68th Street yesterday morning.
The city sent a plumber and two helpers yesterday to restore heat and water to a Bronx apartment house while a Commissioner and four assistants watched.

BY most rules of thumb-- at least of most thumbs --"Exchange," which opened last night at the brand-new Mercer-O'Casey Theater, is not theater. Indeed this diverting enough evening calls itself a musical entertainment, and it is an entertainment closer rather to cabaret than theater.

Gene Michael and Stan Bahnsen were added yesterday to the list of New York Yankees who have signed their 1970 contracts. The most striking feature of this development was the fat raise Michael earned by becoming the regular shortstop late last May.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 9 Windward Passage has accomplished what she was built to do-finish ahead of Ondine in an ocean race.
GENEVA, Feb. 9 A consignment of radar parts being sent to Israel by air freight was seized at the Zurich Airport Friday by customs officials, the Swiss Government announced today.

The General Electric Company's 48-story headquarters here was evacuated yesterday because of a bomb threat. The threat came as Federal and local authorities investigated two bombings at G.E. facilities in the city.
Caird Leslie, a former ballet dancer and teacher, was found dead in his home at 129 West 56th Street on Sunday, apparently after having taken an overdose of sleeping pills. He was 70 years old.

GEORGE SZELL, looking trim and fit, and his Cleveland Orchestra, sounding trim and fit, occupied Carnegie Hall last night for a program consisting substantially of Gustav Mahler's "Das Lied von der Erde." There have been times in the past when that hour-long work was judged long enough to occupy a program by itself. Mr. Szell, however, prefaced the Mahler with Schubert's "Unfinished" Symphony and an intermission. That drew the evening out to normal concert length.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Agnes de Mille, the choreographer, pleaded with Congress today for more than a "pittance" for the arts and said the nation could make no better investment than in its gifted citizens.
Interest rates yesterday took another good-sized step downhill, away from the peaks they reached in December and January.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 9 The Appellate Division has ordered a Yonkers landlord to void the current waiting list and to report all vacancies in a building where a Negro prospective tenant was denied an apartment more than two years ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 President Nixon will get 250 new books for the permanent White House home library tomorrow, a gift from the American Booksellers Association.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 9 A Freeport advertising representative filed a notice of claim today against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Long Island Rail Road, seeking $50,000 for bringing on "commuter neurosis" and $373.15 for breach of contract.
Fears of voter resentment in the wake of a record number of state tax increases last year are causing most state governments to hold the line this year on new levies.
ROME, Feb. 9 The Vatican has asked Roman Catholic priests to reaffirm their vows of celibacy and obedience annually and publicly.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 9 An Egyptian pilot shot down an Israeli jet over the northern part of the Suez Canal area today, an Israeli military spokesman here reported.
