STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 9 Representatives of 24 European nations met in conference here today in an anxious search for ways to shore up the quality of their environment.
The most enthusiastic group at the opening day of the Westminster dog show yesterday was a delegation of 93 Britons almost all of whom had shown at Cruft's on Friday or Saturday.

BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 9 Retired Capt. Vincent J. Doyle of the Bayonne Police Department, who was instrumental in setting up the first two-way police radio system in the country in 1933 in this city, died Saturday at his home here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 9 David A. Morse, who announced his resignation as head of the International Labor Organization today, was born on Washington Avenue in the Bronx, but he is obviously not ready to retire to placid inactivity in any parochial neighborhood.

The $426-million request in President Nixon's budget for the Maritime Administration in the coming fiscal year contains the largest regular appropriation request for shipbuilding subsidies since World War II.
Liza Minnelli, glowing with bright-eyed youth and vitality, is working very hard at the Empire Room in the Waldorf-Astoria and she has to.

"No city can afford to throw away housing units at a rate of 33,000 annually and survive." That grim truth is set forth by Dr. Frank S. Kristof, perhaps the bestinformed of all experts on New York City housing, in a study for the Institute of Public Administration.
The Department of Journalism at New York University will offer an "internship for minority journalism students" this summer at the university's Washington Square campus.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The Justice Department charged 11 companies today with polluting waterways in the Chicago area.
Difficulty in effecting collections on export orders has forced a leading manufacturer of textile machinery to seek reorganization under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. Feb. 9 (AP) Classes at two schools here were canceled today and teachers manned picket lines as a dispute over discipline and teacher and pupil safety continued.
Mayor Lindsay called on town governments yesterday to join the big cities in formulating "new statewide strategies" for broadening state and local aid.
Mayor Lindsay came out yesterday in opposition to repeal of the so-called Blaine amendment, which prohibits state aid to schools with religious affiliations.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he did not know whether his three teen-aged daughters had ever smoked marijuana, but added, "I shouldn't be the least surprised if they have."
Miss Erica Marie Rizzo, a senior at Manhattanville College, plans to be married in June to Second Lieut. Thomas Kenney, who is serving with the Marines in Quantico, Va.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Frank C. Graham Jr. had been re-elected to a second one-year term as chairman of the exchange's board of governors. Mr. Graham is a partner of Purcell, Graham Co.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 9 Disappointment was ex- pressed here today by C.J. Haggerty, president of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., over Mr. Shultz's announcement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 Representative George E. Brown Jr. of Los Angeles, now in his fourth term in the House of Representatives, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination to oppose Senator George Murphy's bid for a second term.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn denied yesterday an application for a temporary injunction against New York City's local school board elections scheduled for March 19.

Thomas P.F. Hoving has told the board of directors of the National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting that he will resign as chairman in a month. He is expected, however, to remain a committee member.
CHICAGO, Feb.9 Testimony was formally completed today in the Chicago conspiracy trial and the marathon case moved rapidly toward an end.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (UPI) Norman Booth, sailing Southern Cross II, used his knowledge of local conditions today to win the Craven Filter invitation race for 5.5-Meter yachts off Palm Beach.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Labor Secretary George P. Shultz announced today that the Philadelphia Plan would be extended to 18 other cities unless they devised their own plans for ending job discrimination in the construction industry.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9 (UPI) A United States Navy river patrol boat strayed into Cambodian waters last week and was seized by Cambodian forces, the United States headquarters reported today. The vessel and its five-man crew are being held.
The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday it had reduced prices on some grades of highdensity polyethylene by about 6 per cent "in recognition of current market conditions."

KNOWING what he was in for, Wayne Maki ac- cepted an invitation to mayhem in Boston Sunday night. Maki, of the St. Louis Blues, was making his first appearance against the Bruins since that night last September when he gave Ted Green a fractured skull in an exhibition

The Parvin-Dohrmann Company, owner of three Las Vegas gambling casinos, disclosed yesterday that it was reorganizing its management in a settlement with several regulatory bodies that had raised questions about the concern.
Miss Susan Jean Bates, whose father and grandfather were members of Congress, plans to be married this summer to Andrew Ronald Grainger, a law student at the University of Michigan.
Japanese steel producers reported here yesterday that their shipments to the United States last year had exceeded the voluntary quota negotiated with the State Department by only 2 per cent.

The Dow Chemical Company a major diversified chemical producer, achieved record sales and earnings in 1969 and in the fourth quarter, Carl A. Gerstacker, chairman, reported yesterday from Midland, Mich., headquarters.

The state agency that operates the Long Island Rail Road has adopted new procedures for testing new commuter cars, which have been plagued by mechanical problems since they were introduced on the line a little over a year ago.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of Norman A. Levy to succeed Benjamin G. Browdy as president of the City Tax Commission, effective March 1.

IT'S just a voice in the wilderness, but at least one investor was so unhappy about the move to short-circuit First National City Bank's program to serve substantial investors that he called this newspaper.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (Reuters) President Nixon today nominated Stuart W. Rockwell, a career diplomat, to be the new United States Ambassador to Morocco.

The Weather Bureau has announced that it is now issuing daily forecasts covering regional weather conditions for five-day periods. Such "extended" forecasts previously were issued only three times a week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service confirmed today that its agents wanted to raid a Black Panther headquarters in Seattle last month but changed its plans at the request of the city's police.
Marion A. Dean, headmistress and trustee of the Barnard School for Girls, died Sunday of a heart attack at her home, 116 Pinehurst Avenue. Her age was 73.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 9 Harvard University announced today that it had signed what it believes to be the first construction contract in the United States that obligates a builder to hire a specific minimum number of minority workers.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 9 (UPI) Alabama fought off a late surge by Georgia tonight and knocked the Bulldogs out of a first-place tie with Kentucky in the Southeastern Conference with a 94-86 upset victory.

Roswell L. Gilpatric, a former Deputy Secretary of Defense, requested last night that four letters written to him by Mrs. Aristotle Onassis the widow of President Kennedy, be withdrawn from sale at an auction here next month because they had been stolen from his New York law office.

HAWTHORNE, N.J., Feb. 9 The four top-ranked tennis players in the United States and four foreign stars, each the champion of his country, began a two-day round-robin tournament tonight at the Hawthorne Center of National Indoor Tennis for $7,500 in prize money.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) President Nixon received today a report from a task force on oil imports, which is reported to include a proposal to substitute tariffs for quotas on oil imports.

TUNIS, Feb. 9 Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Moroccan officials expressed mutual concern today over reports that Egyptian influence was growing in the new military Government of Libya, informed sources said.

THE actor Alan Bergmann, playing a journalist named George S. Benoy, begins "The Jumping Fool" by addressing the audience in a chatty, confessional manner, promising delights of murder, melodrama and humor.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Mrs. Martin Luther King accused President Nixon today of slowing the civil rights movement and said Black Panthers awaiting trial were being unjustly treated.

There was a pleasant sort of competition at the 94th Westminster Kennel Club dog show in Madison Square Garden last night when a new wire fox terrier, Holmwire Tudor Reliant, arrived unheralded from Denver to become the first to qualify for best in show.
The voice wasn't as enthusiastic as it once was, but it sounded as positive as ever.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 9 Dr. Arthur H. Steinhaus, author and visiting professor of physiology at the University of Michigan since 1966, died yesterday. He was 72 years old.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 The Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature announced today a program to combat drug addiction, which they described as "the 1970 bubonic plague."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The leading officials of the Nixon Administration are confident that the military situation in South Vietnam is now good enough to permit the uninterrupted withdrawal of most United States ground combat forces over the next 18 months.

TRENTON, Feb. 9 Gov. William T. Cahill signed tonight a measure increasing New Jersey's state sales tax from 3 to 5 per- cent. He gave his approval shortly after final action on the legislation by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The State Department rejected today a Soviet claim of diplomatic immunity for a Soviet employe of the United Nations Secretariat arrested in Seattle on Saturday and charged with conspiracy to commit espionage.
The city lost its suit yesterday to rescind an average 10 per cent rent increase that went into effect Oct. 1 for 7,716 tenants of Stuyvesant Town.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 9 Berkeley police officials are pushing for a helicopter patrol to fight rising crime. They are being derided by protesters as potential "whirly pigs" and "chopper-coppers."
ALBANY, Feb. 9 (UPI) Legislation to protect reporters from being cited for contempt if they refuse to reveal sources of information was introduced in the Legislature today.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 9 The commanding general of Fort Benning and two of the high officers of this infantry training center denied emphatically today that President Nixon and the Pentagon had influenced the decision to bring First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. to general court-martial for the alleged massacre at Mylai in South Vietnam.
The Western Union Corporation and its subsidiaries re ported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net in- [ come for 1969.

Walter Robinson plays in the backcourt for Elizabeth-Forward High School, a town 15 miles south of Pittsburgh. It's not a very good basketball team. It has won only three of 17 games in Section IV of the Western Pennsylvania Interscholastic Athletic League.
CONCORD, Mass., Feb. 9 A. Page Browne, who retired in 1957 as senior vice president and director of Sheraton Hotels, died here yesterday. His age was 77.
Richard Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier" had its third performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera last night and it went even better than it had before.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Following are excerpts from a speech today by Senator Abraham A. Ribi- coff, Democrat of Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Hundreds of black students at racially mixed Western High School emphasized their demand for a week-long boycott today by ripping doors off hinges, setting a small fire, flooding a bathroom and taking over the school's public address system.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 9 (UPI) The Libyan Government has empowered a public custodian to administer the funds and properties of Jews who left the country to live abroad indefinitely, it was announced today.

The Cheetah Charter Bus Service Company, Inc., a fledgling enterprise with headquarters at 40 West 135th Street in Harlem, announced yesterday that it had moved a step closer to the day it could start doing business.

Vice President Agnew, Gov. Ronald Reagan, Mayor Sam Yorty and S.I. Hayakawa share a striking trait. Heard one on top of another all four in three days, during a recent California excursion each demonstrated the kind of simple plausibility that in these baffling days Americans seem most to desire from their politicians.
MEDFORD, L.I., Feb. 9 The Rev. Christopher B. Donohue, pastor of St. Sylvester Roman Catholic Church since 1963, died yesterday of a heart attack in the rectory. He was 61 years old.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 9 (AP) Vice President Spiro Agnew believes the $200 Doug Sanders won in the Bob Hope Desert golf classic will just pay Sanders's doctor bill.
About 15 minutes before the Vanderbilt women's invitation tennis tournament was to begin last night, a young woman urgently approached a workman and said:

Another Justice Department subpoena for confidential journalistic files became known yesterday. In this, the Antitrust Division has sought materials dealing with a Fortune magazine interview with James J. Ling, head of a conglomerate whose sales exceed $3-billion a year.
A switch in linemates didn't bother Phil Esposito one bit last week.
ATHENS, Feb. 9 Prof. Themistocles Tsatsos, a former cabinet minister and an expert on constitutional law, died here today after a brief illness. He was 63 years old.

The president of Hadassah called on American Jewish leaders last night to cooperate in an effort to acquaint Jewish college youth with the "pernicious". Arab propaganda directed against Israel "and the entire Jewish people."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The General Accounting Office has found that the Army, Navy and Air Force have been making many more of their officers eligible to go to graduate school at the taxpayers' expense than they ought to and that the services are making relatively little use of the officers when they return from school.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9 Nearly every day, fresh red and white flowers are heaped up before a swastika at the German Cemetery in Buenos Aires.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 9 Arthur T. Roth, chairman of the Franklin National Bank, denied any wrongdoing in the acquisition of land near the proposed site for a jetport and a transportation hub in Suffolk County and said he would not resign as a member of the Nassau-Suffolk Regional Planning Board.

Mayor Lindsay's decision to go ahead with plans for a new House of Detention for men in Manhattan was criticized by the City Planning Commission yesterday as the wrong approach to solving overcrowding in city jails.
LONDON, Feb. 9 The London Stock Exchange opened today in temporary quarters, an awkward tri-level trading floor that will accommodate the $72billion business until late in 1972.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 9 (AP) John Ferguson of the Montreal Canadiens was in satisfactory condition in a Minneapolis hospital today with a possible cheekbone fracture. Ferguson was injured in a game with the North Stars Saturday night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Treasury bill rates declined dramatically at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported today.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 9 Lester Stoefen, former United States and Wimbledon tennis champion, died of a rare liver ailment in his home yesterday. He was 58 years old.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 A resolution that would reduce the voting age in the state to 18 in three steps was introduced in the Assembly today with strong Republican backing.

The hearing on Carmine G. De Sapio's motion for a new trial on charges that he was part of a conspiracy to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus continued yesterday, without reaching a conclusion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The Democratic Policy Council, the party's official voice on policy matters, called today for "a firm and unequivocal commitment" to withdraw all American military forces from Vietnam on a definite timetable.

Two of three owners of a Bronx apartment house that has been without water for two weeks and without heat since Christmas were killed in a holdup, in November, 1967. The third their brother was described yesterday by an aide to Mayor Lindsay as having "gone completely to pieces" since the holdup.

PARIS, Feb. 9 The Roman Catholic hierarchy of France proclaimed its fraternal communion with Pope Paul VI last Thursday in his disagreement with the Dutch bishops over the celibacy of the priesthood. Yet discussions with church- men here have turned up some remarkable Gallic nuances.

The thud of Israeli bombs on the outskirts of Cairo, where the leaders of five "front-line" Arab nations met over the weekend, underscored the folly of the policy of militant confrontation with Israel that the meeting vaingloriously reaffirmed. By rejecting President Nixon's plea for a renewed cease-fire, the Arab leaders merely invite further humiliating punishment and make more difficult the prospect of ever regaining their lost territories.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9 (AP) Long Island University handed St. Peter's College its third straight basketball loss tonight, 66-59.

Progress was made yesterday as the Amateur Athletic Union sought to avert a boycott of its national indoor track and field championships by the nation's two strongest clubs. The meet will be held Feb. 27 at Madison Square Garden.

DANVERS, Mass., Feb. 9 James Thomas Chirurg, a former advertising agency executive, died at Hunt Memorial Hospital here today. He had suffered a heart attack in December. He was 63 years old and lived here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Carpeting that meets a pending Federal standard under the Flammable Fabrics Act was singled out at a Senate hearing today as a major hazard in a nursing home fire in which 21 elderly patients died.

Mrs. Beulah Sanders, chairman of the Citywide Coordinating Committee of Welfare Groups, outlined plans yesterday for Guaranteed Income Week that begins today in Buffalo and ends with a convergence of "several thousand" welfare recipients next Tuesday in Albany.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo. (UPI) Bess Wallace Truman will mark her 85th birthday Friday, devoting most of that day, like all others, to her husband.
ALMERIA, Spain Edwin Sherin, who staged the Broadway hit "The Great White Hope," is getting his first taste here of directing a film. "Valdez Is Coming."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The stories that President Nixon became interested in new uniforms for the White House Police only after his recent European trip are pure nonsense, inspired no doubt by the Democratic National Committee.

Reflecting increased prices, record production and sales to meet the strong demand for copper and other nonferrous metals, the Anaconda Company lifted its earnings last year by 11.5 per cent from 1968, C. Jay Parkinson, chairman, reported yesterday. Fourth-quarter earnings, however, declined.

Plans and rosters for the Major League East-West AllStar Classic, an exhibition game to be played in Los Angeles on Saturday afternoon, March 28, were announced yesterday by Bowie Kuhn, Commissioner of Baseball.

The New York Stock Exchange is expected to vote Thursday on final approval of rules changes that would permit public ownership of member firms. The exchange also may disclose a new commission-rate structure.

"I think our generation is privileged and cursed," said Elie Wiesel, the author. "We are privileged to be a witness to be able to say 'I was there, I saw it; I was at Sinai; I was in Jerusalem when it was liberated.'

CANBERRA, Australia The touring American team comprising Robert Jordan, Arthur Robinson, Bill Root, Dorothy Hayden and this writer had to fight hard for victory in a match in Australia's capital city last week. The team built up an early lead but the local team played with great steadiness and the final margin of victory in a watch of 32 deals was 14 international match points.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 9 Mr. and Mrs. John Woodard Roberts have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Roberts, to Tobias Victor Welo, a senior associate of the consulting concern of Cresap, McCormick Paget, Inc., of New York.
DALLAS, Feb. 9 A strong call was issued here today for retailers of men's apparel to hire and promote noncollege graduates for managerial and executive positions.

HELEN of Troy wasn't immediately discernible, but a whole mass of gods, goddesses, centaurs and temples were. They were cavorting or standing stationary and adorning the multitudinous evening dresses James Galanos designed for modern women to wear this spring and summer. The prints were credited to Tzaims Luksus.

A woman researcher for Newsweek magazine was summoned to the bench yesterday at the pretrial hearing here for 13 Black Panthers to face a contempt-of-court charge for having joined in spectator applause of defendants who denounced the court.
An irate woman subway rider recently filed with Controller Abraham D. Beame a 66-cent "invoice" for extra expenses incurred because of a disruption in subway service. Her terms: "Net cash at once."
The city's cemetery workers are finding that the hardships of a four-week old strike have not changed their style of life to any great extent.

MIAMI, Feb. 9 (AP) Sandy Hawley, whose chances of winning the Hialeah riding title were jolted earlier in the day when he received a five-day suspension, rode the favorite, Red Beret, to victory in the sixth race today before a crowd of 17,729.

TO an ailing Frank Leahy in a Chicago hospital it had to be a more revivify- ing than a transfusion. The one-time football coaching marvel at Notre Dame had just been notified that he had been elected to the collegiate Hall of Fame. No one ever doubted that he rated the distinction. The mystery has always been why it took so long.
NEWARK, Feb. 9 Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) De Cavalcante, reputed boss of a Mafia family, has engaged a new lawyer for his extortion trial.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 The Government argued today that the Sierra Club, a 70,000 member conservation organization, had no standing to object to the proposed Walt Disney Resort at Mineral King Valley in the High Sierra.
JAY STEFFY may well be the first interior designer who had to shovel himself out of a decorating mistake a dirt floor that turned unexpectedly to mud.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9 A teachers' strike in Jersey City led today to the closing of all 34 schools here, while a stalemate continued on the eighth day of a teachers' stoppage in Newark.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The United States and the Government of Laos have agreed that Laotian forces in the Plaine des Jarres will not try to hold the plain against attacking North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao forces but will fight a delaying action and fall back in an orderly fashion.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9 (UPI) Al Hirt, the jazz trumpeter, said today that a cut from a piece of concrete that struck him in the mouth during a Mardi Gras parade last night might endanger his career.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., Feb. 9 Mr. and Mrs. David A. Brody have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Sheryl Brody, to Gary Jon Marker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor E. Marker of Pottstown, Pa. An August wedding is planned.
Andy Granatelli is going racing on the international grand prix circuit, a whole new world for the former mechanic who learned his trade as an urchin on the streets of Chicago.
The United States economy has entered a recession, possibly one of some severity, a panel of bank investment specialists warned more than 2,000 of their colleagues here yesterday.

Art for subway's sake has appeared on the walls of the Lexington Avenue's 68th Street stop. The pretty orange leaves and flowers, footprints walking on the ceilings and rhythmic daubs and exclamation points on the beams were painted by students celebrating Hunter College's centennial. They were not a show of appreciation for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's artistry in extracting another dime from the straphangers.
American doctors have discovered a virus so virulent that they have stopped their research into its mysteries.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 9 Thousands demonstrated noisily and a handful violently at the Knesset today while the Israeli legislature debated a bill defining who is a Jew.
Wheat futures rose sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday and influenced firmer prices for other grains in the closing minutes of the session.
Miss Betsy Ann Blaisdell and Andrew John McGinley, co-workers at the International Business Machines Corporation in Kingston, N.Y., plan to be married in April.
WASHINGTON On the third floor of a bleak, factorylike building in Suitland, Md., in a room cluttered with recording devices and facsimile machines, sits a table with two red telephones.

Bronx Republicans nominated an opponent of Mayor Lindsay last night to run for an Assembly seat left vacant by the recent appointment of Benjamin Altman to a city post, but the vote was promptly challenged as "invalid and illegal" by a leader of the pro-Lindsay forces.
American Airlines has named Peter Radulovic Jr. to succeed Robert L. Frederick in Honolulu as vice president for the Pacific.

Prices closed generally higher on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. The firm tone reflected the Friday rally on Wall Street and reports that President Nixon's economic advisers saw no sign of an American recession.

The White Motor Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed to buy the assets of Alco Engine, Inc., and Alco Products Service, Inc., from Studebaker-Worthington, Inc., for stock valued at more than $15-million.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange managed to finish in the plus column yesterday although selling pressure in the last hour of trading reduced earlier gains.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 9 (AP) Before a crowd of 8,952, Navy Coach, ridden by Rudy Rincon, took command at the top of the stretch and registered a sixlength victory today in the Greenbelt Purse at Bowie Race Course.
Last year was one of the worst ever experienced by the Chicago North Western Railway, the operating subsidiary of Northwest Industries, Inc., the holding company headed by Ben W. Heineman.
A 664-foot oil tanker ran aground on a small island in the East River last night while negotiating the tricky currents of the Hell Gate.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 10 (Reuters) A United States Army helicopter crashed here today, killing the 12 men aboard. All aboard were Americans, military sources said.

WEST POINT, N.Y. The United States Military Academy, which was pouring thousands of gallons of raw sewage into the Hudson River each day only 14 years ago, is waiting for funds to build a treatment plant designed to meet Federal and state pollution standards.

HONG KONG, Feb. 9 In an effort to rekindle the patriotism and revolutionary fervor that existed among the Chinese in the war against Japan, Communist cultural authorities have revived popular songs of that period with new words more suited to present times.

OCHO RIOS, Jamaica Austen J. Thomas, a native Jamaican who lives at Greenglades, Stony Hill, outside Kingston, has been a sport fisherman all his life, but in recent years his energies have been devoted to increasing the harvest of food fish in underdeveloped countries.
Al Matson, captain of St. John's University's baseball team, has signed a contract with the Philadelphia Phillies and will leave for spring training on March 19.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 President Nixon moved today to equip the White House staff for the first time with its own experts on the multiplying issues of communications policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff called on his fellow Northern liberals today to drop their "monumental hypocrisy" on the segregation issue and concede that their school systems were just as unbalanced racially as those in the South.

New York City's 91 highschool student newspapers are in serious financial trouble and some of their faculty advisers predict that within a year many will be out of business unless outside assistance is forthcoming.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 Something has gone wrong. New York is supposed to be the theater capital of the world, and yet when Britain's National Theater makes its debut in the United States it bypasses New York and goes straight to Los Angeles.

"The high responsibility of bench and bar," Senator Jacob K. Javits said last night in a speech at The Association of the Bar of the City of New York, is "to hold fast to the Bill of Rights when the strong winds of public opinion may cause even the Congress to sway."

OTTAWA, Feb. 9 A twoday national conference to persuade Canadian business leaders to restrain price rises this year, even if it means lower profits, opened today with an appeal for sacrifice by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.
Miss Barbara Patterson Nevling, a graduate student at the University of Pennsylvania, plans to be married in June to Michael Howard Porter, a doctoral candidate at Cornell who teaches at Rutgers.
Glamour and pollution-control issues ranked among the better gainers yesterday as the stock market got a lift from statements made by Arthur F. Burns, new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Frank E. Taylor, for five years the editor in chief and general manager of the tradebook division of the McGraw Hill Book Company, is leaving to open his own publishing company.
LENINGRAD, Feb. 9 (Reuters) A Norwegian student today was sentenced to a year in a labor camp for distributing leaflets outside a Leningrad store protesting the detention of Soviet dissidents.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 9 Superior Court Judge Joseph H. Stamler ordered the Netcong school board today to cease immediately the daily classroom reading of prayers from The Congressional Record.

Four major landlord organizations offered a plan yesterday to replace the city's 27year-old rent-control law with a measure that would allow substantial rent increases in the 1.3 million controlled apartments here, but would force owners to put some of the added revenue into building improvements.

CAIRO, Feb. 9 The five Arab "confrontation countries" vowed today to fight on for the recovery of lands captured by Israel, thus implicitly rejecting endeavors by major powers to restore the 1967 cease-fire be- tween the United Arab Republic and Israel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) A major antiwar group announced today a three months' campaign of rallies, picketing and demonstrations against civil rights repression, the draft and war spending.
CAIRO, Feb. 9 (Reuters) Following is an unofficial translation of the text of the communique issued after the conference of Arab "confrontation countries":

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 9 (UPI) Karl Schranz won the first of two heats in the giant slalom at the world Alpine ski championships today. Billy Kidd of the United States, favored for the combined title, severely damaged his chances by finishing 30th.
Economy-minded advertisers are constantly eying television commercial production costs and trying to figure out ways to cut them.

Though the unemployment figures are somewhat unreliable on a month-to-month basis, it now seems clear that President Nixon's prescribed "slowing pains" are starting to affect the labor market. The seasonably adjusted unemployment rate climbed from 3.4 per cent in November and December to 3.9 per cent in January and will probably go higher.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) A Jumbo 747 jet engine overheated about 1,000 miles out over the Atlantic today, forcing the Pan American World Airways plane to return to London's Heathrow Airport.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 9 The Egyptian delegate, Mohammed Hassan el-Zayyat, today declared that he could not bring himself to believe that the United States would decide to sell a large number of jet fighter-bombers and fighters to Israel.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Rosenthal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Rosenthal, to Dr. Phillip Kummel Keats, a surgical interne at the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 (AP) Charles M. Manson's trial in the killings of actress Sharon Tate and six other persons was set today for March 30. The same trial date was set for two female co-defendants.

AUBURN, Mass., Feb. 9 (AP) About 25 maintenance men from the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority used large vacuum cleaners and "mud suckers" today to clean up $40,000 in dimes that spilled onto three-quarters of a mile of the Massachusetts Turnpike.

The director of the Puerto Rican-Hispanic Affairs Division of the City Commission on Human Rights resigned unexpectedly yesterday after charging that the commission discriminated against Puerto Ricans in its hiring practices.

H. Wendel Burch, director of international services for United Press International since 1959, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 61 years old and lived at 111-16 75th Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.
"Colette," a play about the French novelist, will be presented off Broadway in April.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Legislation aimed at giving the public more information about attempted corporate take-overs was introduced today by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey. Senator Williams was the author of the original corporate takeover Bill enacted in 1968. His new bill will broaden and extend it to additional situations.
Thomas A. Melfe has been promoted to senior vice president of the United States Trust Company of New York. He formerly was assistant division head of the trust administration division.

The despicable terrorist attack in Munich on passengers of the Israeli airline discredits the Arab cause, just as did earlier attacks in other European cities. This latest crime against innocent international air travelers deserves universal condemnation, especially by responsible Arab leaders.

The bishops of the Eastern Orthodox faith in the Americas met in special session yesterday in an attempt to head off a split between the Russian and Greek churches here over an effort to form an independent Orthodox church of America.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 10 Gov. Albert P. Brewer formally announced today that he would run for a full term as Governor and would stress that the job was "full-time."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Senator Jacob K. Javits, just returned from Japan, urged today the appointment of a "special Presidential task force" to make a finding on precisely what segment of the textile and apparel industries are being injured by rising imports.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Feb. 10 Joseph E. Williams, a former vice president in the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Sunday after a long illness at his home at 1055 Woodland Avenue here. He was 67 years old.

The discovery of the virus of Lassa Fever, which killed three of the first five Americans infected by it, is a sobering event. It is a reminder that even today's advanced medical science does not know all the virulent organisms nature has in its biological warfare arsenal. The list of such organisms can never be complete, if only because viruses are constantly mutating, and a mutant virus can pose dangers its parent stock did not.

AT 5 o'clock yesterday morning Joe Frazier was sleeping the sleep of the just when Yank Durham, his trainer-adviser, entered the room of their midtown hotel while rain lashed a message on the window. Gravel-voiced Yank delivered the message.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A spokesman for the State Department said today that the United States would begin negotiations with Spain on a new agreement on military bases and assistance in the near future.
The Gulf Oil Company announced yesterday plans for an approximate 40 per cent cutback in capital spending from $1.5-billion in 1969 to $900million in 1970.
Four letters written by Mrs. Aristotle Onassis both as Mrs. Onassis and as Mrs. John F. Kennedy were turned over to the District Attorney's complaint bureau yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) A House subcommittee reported that the Vietnam pacification program substantially increased security in the South Vietnam countryside last year but did not seriously counter Vietcong political activity.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 Franchises, or something very like them, seem to be the new pattern of the West Coast theater. In San Francisco I noticed that "Dames at Sea," "Hair" and "Oh! Calcutta!" were all there in local production on extended run, and a new staging of "Jacques Brel" is about to open.
The Presbytery of New York City voted last night to establish an experimental law office to serve as a "watchdog," going beyond the traditional role of ombudsman to that of investigator.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 10 (AP) Karl Schranz rose to the top of the World Cup standing for the first time this season today by speeding to victory in the giant slalom of the world Alpine ski championships.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 10 Picture the New York Jets holding an election to determine their starting line-up.
Mrs. Louise Clews Timpson, the former Duchess of Argyll, died yesterday in her sleep at home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. She was 65 years old.
"You'd think they were giving away paintings," a woman visitor to the Museum of Modern Art commented, surveying the crowded lobby on the museum's first "free Monday."
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Feb. 10 Mrs. Adrianne Benson Gold of 219 Lelac Avenue, wife of Abner Gold, editor of The Springfield Leader, died today at Overlook Hospital, Summit. She was 42 years old.

The pattern of disruption, threats and sporadic violence in the courtroom that has marked the Chicago conspiracy trial and is now being acted out in the case of the Black Panthers here constitutes a direct attack on the administration of justice.
PARIS, Feb. 10 An agreement for the sale of 30 Mirage fighter planes to Spain was signed here today after several months of negotiation.

EAST HILLS, L.I., Feb. 10 Loss of a painting by Sir Winston Churchill, which had been lent to an art dealer here by the former British Prime Minister's daughter, Lady Audley, has been reported to the police.
A bomb scare at the Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn forced the evacuation of 1,500 students who were attending evening classes there last night.
At 9:05, the other morning, No. 45,777 at the New Jersey State Prison Farm at Rahway became Richard Mayor again.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Following is the text of the message on the environment that President Nixon sent to Congress today:

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Feb. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Edward Crawford Hills of Shaker Heights and Delray Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Crawford Hills, to Richard William York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard York of Cleveland.

For some 20 years Newell Jenkins has been pursuing with dedication the music of Giovanni Battista Sammartini, a prolific and influential Italian composer of the 18th century. This year his thematic catalogue of the composer's works is being published by the American Musicological Society and Harvard University.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 10 (UPI) Miss Edda Koll, the legal secretary who refused to have her ticket punched on the New Haven division of the Penn Central to protest poor service, today demanded and won a jury trial in Rye City Court.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 10 Notre Dame rolled to a 20point half-time lead, staved off a determined second-half effort by St. John's and then rallied to rout the Redmen, in basketball, 90-76, before 10,347 at the Athletic and Convocation Center tonight.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 11 The American tour of Australia began eight days ago with a social game in Brisbane. Robert Jordan and Arthur Robinson of Philadelphia were in fine form, winning a section of a team event in spite of a 19-month rest from the game and the fact that all the visitors had had 27 hours on a plane from New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) A Federal judge sentenced four persons to prison today for defrauding the Defense Department of more than $4-million in excess profits on contracts for missile launchers.
OTTAWA, Feb. 10 A national conference of Canadian business leaders adopted today an unprecedented but highly qualified statement on price restraint.

UNTIL the final act, when fate begins to undermine the worldly role of Alphonsus of Liguori, the 18th century Catholic saint who founded the Congregation of the Most Holy Redeemer, a new play titled "Five Star Saint" makes an arresting evening of theater.
DALLAS, Feb. 10 Mrs. Baker Taylor has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alison Blair Taylor, to Robert S. Fastov, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fastov of Rockville Centre, L.I.

BAGELS and biscuits, brioches and bauernbrot are among 113 different varieties of breads, from nine Old-World-Style bakers, at Bloomingdale's Bread Basket, which opens today in the delicacies department.
OWERRI, Nigeria, Feb. 10 (AP) Markets are opening again and workmen are repairing roads and buildings in the area that was Biafra. Life is trickling back to normal, but serious problems remain.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 10 The man who signed murder charges against First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that he had led "a sort of rebellion" among the young law officers of this post early last September when it appeared to them that the Nixon Administration and Pentagon officials might be trying to cover up the alleged Sogmy massacre.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 10 The 91st Congress was criticized today as antilabor by the executive council of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, Feb, 10 The Soviet Union proposed fourpower talks today on the future status of West Berlin, diplomatic sources said, but with conditions that appeared unacceptable to the Western powers.
Although not without a few ups and downs, Yuval Waldman's Carnegie Recital Hall concert last night revealed a young violinist of unquestioned technical expertise and sound musical instincts.

OF course, my chief claim to fame is being the father of George," Francis Taylor Pearsons Plimpton, the distinguished lawyer and diplomat, remarked yesterday in chatting about his 44 years at the bar. The president of the Association of the Bar of the City of...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Robert M. Morgenthau, former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, today attacked the Nixon Administration's withdrawal of support for a bill designed to curb millions in tax evasion and wholesale violation of stock and bond trading laws through secret Swiss bank accounts.

ROME The crucial question in Italy's latest political crisis the 31st since World War II is whether the Communists can be excluded from government by another center-left coalition or whether extreme left factions among the Christian Democrats and Socialists would prefer to make a deal letting the Communists in.
The president-elect of the Medical Society of the State of New York yesterday criticized the report of the Senate Finance Committee detailing doctors' abuse of Medicaid and Medicare fees.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 (Reuters) A military court has ordered two members of the lower house to face questioning on alleged pro-Communist activities.

Vienna, Feb. 10 (Reuters) Banking spokesmen said a new East-West trade-financing bank, Aussenhandelsbank, would start operations next month with a share capital of 75 million schillings (2.925-million).
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 America will become "an industrial complex without a soul" unless Congress encourages the arts, the lasting evidences of our civilization, Isaac Stern warned today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Mortgage prices rose substantially at this week's auction of the Federal National Mortgage Association, it disclosed today.

MIAMI, Feb. 10 Trainer Elliott Burch said today that if Arts and Letters worked in satisfactory fashion this weekend he would start the Ribot colt in the $100,000-added Widener at Hialeah a week from Saturday.

Operations of the Goodyear Rubber Company in 1969 resulted in record full-year and fourth-quarter results with sales exceeding $3-billion for the first time, the company's report from Akron, Ohio, disclosed yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 10 Harold Engstrom, an industrial engineer and consultant, died at New Rochelle Hospital today of a heart attack. He had been ill with diabetes for several years. He was 71 years old, and lived at 105 Iden Avenue, Pelham Manor.

Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh issued a stern warning to spectators, defense lawyers and defendants yesterday against future disruptions of the pretrial hearings of 13 Black Panthers in the Criminal part of State Supreme Court at 100 Centre Street.

The American Broadcasting Company, after almost a week's delay, explained yesterday why it had censored the remarks of Judy Collins, the folly singer about the Chicago conspiracy trial presided over by Judge Julius J. Hoffman.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 10 The military history of the last 25 years seems to suggest that even small nations, well-trained in the black arts and dirty tricks of subversive or guerrilla warfare, can challenge and even defeat large nations if they have will-power, firepower and geography on their side.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 10 Pakistan has quietly moved an infantry regiment into Jordan, high officials close to King Hus- sein's palace in Amman said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Soviet Union has started to deploy its principal longrange missile in complexes that previously consisted only of medium-range missiles pointed at Western Europe, according to well placed United States Government sources.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Congressional Democrats put forward today their first alternative to President Nixon's controversial welfare reform program, an ambitious income maintenance plan that could cost the government $20-billion a year.

The plan to build a new stadium in Boston primarily for the use of the pro football team there, the Patriots, has hit a snag. Construction of the 55,000-seat stadium was to be financed by a $16-million bond issue guaranteed by 12 extra days of flat racing at the Suffolk Downs track, run by Bill Veeck.
HONOLULU, Feb. 10 The Hawaii Senate voted 17 to 7 tonight to repeal a 100-yearold law against abortion.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that despite the rapidly growing narcotics problem and mounting pressures for government action on all levels, the city could not substantially expand its programs against drug abuse because of lack of funds.

When Anna Katherine Nicholas of White Plains, wearing an ice-blue, kneelength, beaded evening gown, dramatically pointed to the best in show last night, it was only the third time in the 94 years of Westminster that a woman ever had judged the final.

Virginia Wade of England defeated Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., 4-6, 6-1, 8-6, and Rosemary Casals of San Francisco downed Peaches Bartkowitz of Hamtramck, Mich., 8-6, 6-1, in the quarterfinals of the $5,000 women's international tennis tournament at the Vanderbilt Athletic Club last night.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 (UPI) Lew Alcindor scored 36 points tonight to lead Milwaukee to a 139-131 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game.

HAWTHORNE, N.J., Feb. 10 With everything to his liking the slow surface, the fast scoring and the $2,500 first prize Manuel Santana of Spain defeated Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., 6-5, 6-2, tonight in the final of the Schaefer-Jaycee Classic at the Hawthorne National Indoor Tennis Center.
MABEN, Miss., Feb. 10 (AP) A combined elementary and high school was destroyed by fire today, hours before it was to reopen under court-ordered faculty desegregation.

Cazzie Russell will replace the injured Bill Bradley in the starting line-up tonight when the New York Knicks oppose the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden. Bradley, troubled with a left ankle sprain sustained against the Celtics on Jan. 27, has missed the last two days of practice at Lost Battalion Hall in Elmhurst, Queens.

Henry Kamm and Walter Rugaber, members of the news staff of The New York Times, were among the winners of George Polk Memorial Awards for "outstanding achievement" in journalism in 1969, it was announced yesterday by Long Island University, sponsor of the annual awards.
Thirteen civil rights and community service organizations announced yesterday that they would conduct a special drive to assure that all black perons are counted in the 1970 census.
LONDON, Feb. 10 A 22year-old Asian woman from Kenya who has been flying back and forth between Nairobi and London for a week was finally allowed to enter Britain temporarily today.
A mother and four of her six children were found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning in their apartment in downtown Brooklyn yesterday afternoon by the woman's estranged husband.

The New York Stock Exchange, in a reply to the antitrust division of the Justice Department, said yesterday that proposed rules changes permitting public ownership of exchange members are immune from the antitrust laws.
The New York Stock Exchange has under consideration rule changes that, in effect, would facilitate the absorption of its specialist units by large investment houses.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Everett Loftus Hollis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Jennings Hollis, to Hugh Joseph Turner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Turner of Peabody, Mass.
Continuing its 1970 pattern of not able to advance for more than two days in a row, the stock market took another tumble yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, the man who coined the term "Vietnamization," arrived here tonight to review the progress of that program during the last year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Following are excerpts from a statement today by the Democratic Policy Council:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A spokesman for the Senate Finance Committee said today that a clerical error was responsible for its reporting that an individual doctor received more than $1.4-million in Medicaid funds.
The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in revenues and sales and net income for the fourth quarter and for all 1969.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10 In one corner of the American ambassador's palatial residence, wearing gray business suits and weighing heavily in the affairs of Nevada and United States-Soviet relations, respectively, were the Lieutenant Governor of Nevada, Ed Fike, and the Ambassador, Jacob Beam.
OTTAWA, Feb. 10 The United States, Canada and Britain will undertake a broad program involving exchange of information on drugs, food additives and pesticides, it was announced here today.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York provided some valuable insight yesterday into the debate in the Federal Open Market Committee, which is under heavy pressure from the Administration to ease its credit policies soon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The House voted today to permit the National Park Service to spend an additional $38.3million for land for the Point Reyes National Seashore in California. The amount represents an increase in land values over the last eight years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 10 Dr. John Bamber Hickam of Indianapolis, chairman of the department of medicine at the Indiana University School of Medicine, died yesterday at St. Luke's Presbyterian Hospital at Chicago after a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 55 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The United States and the Soviet Union reached agreement today on an enlarged cultural exchange program for this year and next, increasing the numbers of students and artistic groups to be exchanged and initiating joint studies of environment problems.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Tactics employed by some leaders of the insurance industry in fighting regulatory legislation that Congress is considering were questioned and defended today at a Senate hearing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The General Accounting Office charged today in a report to Congress that the Pentagon had often gone ahead with new weapons development without reasonable expectation of success.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (AP) Vice President Agnew told Missouri Republicans tonight that policies voiced by Senator J.W. Fulbright amounted to a "blueprint for defeat in Vietnam and retreat from the world."

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) American League club owners met this afternoon and tonight without decision on the troubled Seattle franchise, then adjourned their meeting until 10:30 A.M. tomorrow (New York time).
The London Stock Exchange maintained a moderate upturn yesterday but showed some easing of prices toward the close.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Investors, Diversified Services, Inc., denounced today sight unseen the proposed new schedule of sales commissions and the proposed new rules for public ownership of brokerage firms that the New York Stock Exchange is about to make public.
NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 10 Mrs. Eugenie McMahon Burr, long a teacher, died this morning after a short illness. She was 65 years old and lived at 24 Olmstead Place.

TULSA, Feb. 10 (UPI) The Telex Corporation denied today that it intends to change its accounting from the financing to operating method or that it has been under any pressure from any source to do so.
TEL AVIV, Feb. 10 By a substantial majority, the Knesset tonight passed the first reading of the highly controversial bill accepting the rabbinical definition of "Jew" in civil legislaiton.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 10 John Potter's 57-foot cutter, Equation, proved more than equal to such famed sailing yachts as Windward Passage and Ondine today by emerging as the over-all winner of the 370-mile St. Petersburg to Fort Lauderdal race.

George N. Spitz, a former consultant to the Joint Legislative Committee on the Election Law, has a sound idea for cutting down the cost and confusion of electoral campaigns. Mr. Spitz, who has been active in numerous reform efforts, proposes that his fellow Democrats in Manhattan's 26th Senatorial District cooperate in underwriting the publication of a voters directory for the approaching primary.

More than 200 teachers, administrators and teachers aides at Public Schools 20 and 150 on Fox Street in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx asked Mayor Lindsay yesterday to declare the neighborhood a "disaster area."

WESTBURY, L.I, Feb. 10 Del Insko moved into tonight's harness racing card at Roosevelt Raceway needing five winners to raise his career total to 2,500, a plateau reached only by four modern drivers Billy Haughton, Stanley Dancer, Joe O'Brien and Bob Farrington.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 10 A judge of the New South Wales Equity Court today accused principals of an American company of blatant perjury, misuse of legal process and deliberate misrepresentation of information it had obtained from the Australian Deputy Prime Minister, John McEwen.

Special to The New York Times PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 10 A new Firebird auto model, aimed at the youth market or, more realistically, those with an urge for high styling and horsepower, was unveiled today by the Pontiac division of General Motors.
Two women and a man who were walking on the sidewalk at 59th Street and Third Avenue were killed yesterday by a limousine that jumped the curb and plowed into the window of a restaurant.
Tickets for the 33d annual National Invitation Tournament are now on sale at the Madison Square Garden box office.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 10 Thirtyfour Arabs and an Israeli soldier were injured by a grenade explosion today near the entrance to the civil administration building in Khan Yunis in the Israeli-occupied/Gaza Strip, an Israeli Army report said.
John Rendel, who plans to retire from The New York Times at the end of the year, received three honors yesterday for long and meritorious dog-show reporting.
THOTNOT, South Vietnam, Feb. 8 When an American visitor turned up in this Mekong Delta district yesterday, the total American presence doubled by virtue of his arrival.

The Celanese Corporation announced yesterday that its Netherlands subsidiary, CelEuro, N.V., had bought all the common stock of the Columbia Cellulose Company Ltd., owned by Svenska Cellulos Aktiebolaget of Stockholm in a transaction valued at more than $20-million.

Some of the best brains in publishing and advertising have contributed to the creation of Essence, a magazine for Negro women due for publication April 28. A dummy of it was unveiled yesterday and a handsome piece of work it is.

The national coordinating body for the United Fund and Community Chest drives urged its member groups in 2,260 communities yesterday to concentrate more of their efforts and money on problems such as poverty and drug addiction.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 The Senate, by an overwhelming majority, took a first step today toward repealing the strict language of the State Constitution that prohibits direct or indirect state financial aid to schools with religious affiliations.

John Sedlack became the fourth player in Queens College history to exceed 1,000 points as he pumped in 22 last night to lead the Knights to a 91-66 Knickerbocker Basketball Conference victory over Lehman College at the loser's Bronx gym. Sedlack brought his threeyear total to 1,002 points.
The Court this morning tempered justice with mercy. The Court, however, has a tremendous responsibility, a responsibility to administer this trial.

OTTAWA, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press) Resources Minister John J. Greene conceded today that the federal Government was powerless to enforce any ban on phosphates in laundry detergents or a progressive reduction in their use.
POTSDAM, N.Y., Feb. 10 (UPI) Dr. H. Austin Peck, 48 years old, president of the State University College here, hanged himself today from a basement beam in his home. He was found dead by his wife.

Mayor Lindsay's plans to set up a third Deputy Mayor's office that would cost more than $500,000 a year were blocked yesterday in the City Council and criticized afterward by Sanford D. Garelik, the Council President.

THOMASTON, Conn., Feb. 10 Karl W. Hallden, an industrialist and philanthropist, who made many contributions to Trinity College in Hartford, his alma mater, died yesterday at the Morton F. Plant hospital in Clearwater, Fla. He was 85 years old and maintained homes in Florida and here.
Inwood, the remote northernmost tip of Manhattan Island with a name few New Yorkers recognize and with quiet streets and parks that even fewer know, has suddenly found its voice.
ENDICOTT, N.Y., Feb. 10 Miss Maureen Elizabeth Hanafin and Charles Shipley Hall will be married in May.

TUNIS, Feb. 10 The Premier of Tunisia, Bahi Ladgham, said today after a conference with Secretary of State William P. Rogers that further United States sales of jet aircraft to Israel would be a "kind of provocation" that would "add insult to injury" to the Arab countries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 The Department of Justice has indefinitely delayed its attempts to require Earl Caldwell, a New York Times correspondent, to appear before a brand jury investigating the Black Panthers, Mr. Caldwell's attorney said today.

The impact of the 10-day-old tug strike on Westchester County eased yesterday when the Coast Guard agreed to provide tugs to tow sludge barges from its sewage-treatment plant in Yonkers out to sea for dumping. This averted "a serious crisis," according to Edward J. Delehanty, the county's Public Works Commissioner.
The 10th annual Blue Hill Troupe dance, to benefit the children of Friendly Homes, Inc., a residence in the Bronx for disturbed children, will be held Friday in the ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel.
Perhaps if President Nixon had promised the country less in the way of environmental reform, his message to Congress on the subject would seem more farreaching than it does.
UCHINOURA, Japan, Wednesday, Feb. 11 (Reuters) Japan put an artificial satellite into orbit today in its fifth attempt.
GENEVA, Feb. 10 Otto R. Mayer, former chancellor of the International Olympic Committee, died today in Lausanne. He was 69 years old.
DALLAS, Feb. 10 Merchants attending the annual convention here of the Menswear Retailers of America are playing a numbers game.

LAST season was the worst ever for Cale Yar borough. The hefty 195pound stock-car driver from Timmonsville, S.C., had a series of accidents in which, with ghastly consistency, he led races and then lost them by hitting the wall.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 10 Dr. Samuel H. Warshawsky, a dentist here for 40 years, died yesterday at Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune. He was 69 years old.

Thirteen city air-pollution inspectors about 15 per cent of the 83-man inspection force were suspended yesterday and six businessmen were arrested on charges of having bribed inspectors to overlook violations. Warrants were issued for the arrest of two more businessmen.

NEWARK, Feb. 10 Mario T. Gallo, one of the 15 men indicted last December here by a Federal grand jury investigating organized crime, was killed early today in an automobile crash in nearby West Orange.

The New York Stock Exchange is considering the establishment of a fund on which Federal agents could draw for undercover operations aimed at tracing stolen securities, Attorney General John N. Mitchell disclosed here last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Retail sales continued slow in January, with a one per cent drop from December, the Commerce Department reported today.
The City Planning Commission was criticized yesterday for proposing to spend more money than the city would have available to spend on construction over the next five years.
The rally in the bond market went into its seventh day yesterday and then faltered.

Carmine G. De Sapio, once a powerful figure in state and national Democratic politics, was sentenced yesterday to two years in prison and fined $4,500 for his part in a conspiracy to bribe former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus and obtain kickbacks on Consolidated Edison Company contracts.

Strong support has developed in Albany for revising the state unemployment insurance system to provide extra benefits for jobless workers with families. Such a revision would breach the strict tie to prior wages that has governed unemployment payments for more than three decades, but it would reduce the danger that jobless fathers would have to turn to public welfare to supplement their job-insurance checks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The following are the Federal standards that have been in effect and future standards that have now been set for auto exhausts. They do not pertain to trucks and buses. The figures are expressed in grams per mile of running time per vehicle.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10 At 11:30 this morning two young men plunged through the door of the Cabaret Toulouse onto the crowded sidewalk of Bourbon Street, fighting wildly.
In the last five days, Joe Frazier has sparred 20 busy, sometimes brutal rounds. In the same span, Jimmy Ellis has sparred two casual rounds.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 10 Army limited the Coast Guard to seven field goals and forced 46 turnovers, as it piled up an 85-34 basketball victory today. It was the cadet's 14th against five losses.

Newly knighted by his Queen and toasted by his countrymen on his 70th birthday, Sir Noel Coward has arrived in New York festooned with honors, not the least of which is that his 40-yearold comedy, "Private Lives," is one of the season's certifiable Broadway hits.
TWO things upset Main Rousseau Bocher, the last of the big-time couturiers: when a woman asks the price of a dress or whether he makes it in, say, a size 12.

OAK PARK, Mich., Feb. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bluestein have made known the engagement of Mrs. Bluestein's daughter, Miss Anita Carol Ackerman, to Dr. Stephen Frank Winer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Winer of Huntington Woods.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 10 Aleksandr V. Tikhomirov, The Russian translator arrested Saturday in Seattle on espionage charges, seems to have been attracting the attention of the New York City police for years by ignoring traffic regulations.
LONDON, Feb. 10 Entering the Common Market could raise Britain's food prices as much as 25 per cent and put a substantial new burden on the balance of payments, the Government said today.

The York division of the Borg-Warner Corporation said yesterday it would increase prices by about 5 per cent on air-conditioning and refrigeration products and on machinery used to make such products.

Possibly Richard Stoker's "Adlerian" Quartet has some therapeutic values apparent to specialists, but otherwise it is hard to find the relationship between Mr. Stoker's music and his avowed subject matter.

BONN, Feb. 10 Three Arabs armed with grenades, in an apparent attempt on the life of the son of Defense Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel, killed an Israeli airline passenger and wounded 23 persons in attacks yesterday on a bus and a lounge at the Munich airport.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 The seven defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial came here in August, 1968, to develop a National Liberation Front and start the revolution, the Government contended today in its final arguments.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 10 (UPI) All-America Rick Mount scored 41 points tonight to establish a Purdue career scoring mark and lead the Boilermakers to a 98-80 Big Ten basketball victory over Indiana.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Democratic Policy Council urged the Senate today to reject the nomination of G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court and opposed expansion of the Safeguard antiballistic missile system.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 President Nixon asked Congress today for a variety of tools some old, some new and some experimental to help clean the air and purify the nation's polluted waters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 President Nixon's environmental message ordered today stricter automobile exhaust standards that experts said posed two major questions: Who is to enforce auto pollution limits, and how are they to be applied to used cars.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the nation's largest brokerage house, announced yesterday that its profit in 1969 plunged nearly 41 per cent because of rising costs and shrinking volume.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 10 The Indian Supreme Court struck down Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Bank Nationalization Act today, ruling that the takeover of the 14 biggest private banks last July was "hostile discrimination" since other Indian banks and foreign banks were excluded.

A century-old weather record for a Feb. 10 was swept away yesterday by a rainstorm that drenched the metropolitan area, flooding streets and highways, disrupting road, air and rail traffic and causing some streams and rivers to overflow their banks.

HIGHLAND PARK, N.J., Feb. 10 The engagement of Miss Betty Zimmerberg, a junior at Radcliffe College, to Robert Bruce Sonenthal, a senior at Harvard, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Hyman J. Zimmerberg. The prospective bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Paul Sonenthal of Jackson Heights, Queens.
DETROIT, Feb. 10 A Dow Chemical Company spokesman at the company headquarters in Midland, Mich., said today that the assertions by a group of Colorado scientists were "just not credible."
ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Feb. 10 (AP) Eight boats qualified today for the first Sunfish world championships, bringing the fleet to 60 representing 11 nations.

JERICHO, L.I., Feb. 10 Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. Sironen of Jericho and Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothea May Sironen, to Alberto Valenti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matteo Valenti of Trapani, Italy.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 No share sales have been made by the Enterprise Fund or Harbor Fund in the last 10 days following the filing of a suit by the Securities Exchange Commission against the mutual funds' investment adviser and underwriter, the Shareholders Management Company.

A trim red fawn boxer with white markings on chest, face and feet and, in the words of the judge, "elegance personified," attained the peak of American dogdom by becoming best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club competition in Madison Square Garden last night.
YOUR name is Cincinnati Milling Company and you are beginning to diversify out of this rather prosaic but profitable business. How do you dramatize the fact?
BOURG-ST.-MAURICE, France, Feb. 10 An avalanche of snow thundered down on the fashionable Alpine resort of Val d'Isere today, killing at least 39 young skiers.
To anyone old enough to have experienced the great Depression, a rise in the unemployment rate like the halfpoint jump last month conjures up memory of breadlines,
Protestant and Roman Catholic Christians will begin observance of their most sacred season today with Ash Wednesday services marking the opening of Lent.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 New York City housing code inspectors are caught in a bureaucratic tangle that cuts working time in half and creates a serious lag in inspection of boilers, plumbing and elevators, according to state auditors.
Howard J. Samuels, a candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, announced yesterday that 18 upstate county leaders had endorsed his candidacy.

The designation of Edward P. Frasher as general manager for commuter services was announced yesterday by the Penn Central Company. He will have jurisdiction over the company's three commuter lines the New Haven and the Hudson and Harlem divisions.
City Councilman Theodore S. Weiss assailed yesterday a landlord association's plan to raise rents in the city's rentcontrolled apartments by an average of 25 per cent.
Gareth Martinis, son of Criminal Court Judge Joseph A. Martinis, was given a 90day jail sentence yesterday after pleading guilty to charges of drunken driving and driving without a license.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 A group of Colorado scientists contends, on the basis of its investigations in the Denver area, that one of the nation's key atomic bomb manufacturing plants has been releasing dangerously radioactive plutonium into the air, water and soil.

Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, held a news conference in a Long Island City poultry terminal yesterday to announce a "new" department regulation that, in fact, has been department procedure for many years.

The reason Jim Signorile of New York University was not smiling after last night's 89-72 victory over Lehigh before 600 fans in Alumni Gymnasium had nothing to do with the fact that he was not the game's leading scorer nor the leading rebounder.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today adopted a bill to repeat Article XI, Section 3, of the State Constitution, prohibiting state aid to religious affiliated schools and substitute the less restrictive language of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution:

LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) Joe Bugner, Britain's young heavyweight prospect, stopped Roberto Davila, a Peruvian living in New York, at the end of the third round of their scheduled 10-round feature bout at Albert Hall Stadium tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe has asked the Governors of New York and Connecticut and officials of the Penn Central and its unions to join in talks to speed the release of funds for improving the railroad's commuter service.
Future prices of frozen orange juice concentrate fell rather sharply yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Eleanor H. Le Maire, a nationally known business-interior designer, died of cancer Monday at her East Side apartment. Her age was 72.
Prices mostly declined on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in the lightest trading in more than three months.

AUSTRIAN blondes, South American brunettes, black women from Africa and tea-colored ones from Asia are all sisters under the skin. Let them loose among a lot of cosmetics and makeup experts and they're interested in the same fine points of beauty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Seven of the nine members of an antiwar group that destroyed files and equipment at the offices of the Dow Chemical Company last March were found guilty today on two charges of malicious destruction of property and one of unlawful entry.
An off-duty policeman moonlighting as a taxi driver shot and critically wounded a young man who allegedly tried to rob him last night.

Will Jason, a song composer who had written for motion pictures, died of cancer yesterday at the Mexican-American Hospital in Guadalajara, Mexico, where he had been living for the last 10 years. He was 59 years old.

FORT LEE, N.J., Feb. 10 Allen H. Spinner, a professor in the department of economics of engineering and management science at Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, died, apparently of a heart attack, at an Edison hospital Saturday. He was 48 years old and lived here at 2400 Hudson Terrace.
A conference on collective bargaining in education was told yesterday that some of the nation's school boards played "a very vicious game of racial polarization" to weaken teachers' unions.

THAT venerable institution, "This Was Burlesque," came back to New York last night at the Hudson West Cabaret Theater. Ann Corio's memory book of burlesque, originally opened off Broadway in 1962, moved to Broadway in 1965 and several months later began what appears to be an endless road tour of America.

GROTON, Conn., Feb. 11 (UPI) Two professors and the dean of the College of Engineering at Virginia Polytechnic Institute were among five persons aboard a plane believed to have crashed in Long Island Sound.
