JERSEY CITY, Feb. 11 Jersey City officials cut off virtually all future funds for the city's 34 strikebound public schools today in a drastic move to force the state to finance public education here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) The International Monetary Fund said today its governors had approved a plan to increase the quotas of most member nations, bringing them more into line with their current economic strength.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 11 (Reuters) Newspapers here reported today that the Israeli Cabinet had overwhelmingly rejected proposals by Foreign Minister Abba Eban for a new political initiative by Israel to restore the cease-fire with the United Arab Republic.
A fire caused heavy damage early this morning to the twostory building occupied by the Flatbush Yeshiva in Brooklyn.
Cocoa futures prices rose sharply yesterday in active trading on the New York Cocoa Exchange following the announcement on Tuesday that the original margin requirement for trading was being lowered.

Last year, Congress enacted the Tax Reform Act of 1969, the most massive overhaul of the tax law in the nation's history. The following article is the first of a series that periodically will examine the implications for personal money management of the changes that were adopted.

PAULINE KAEL is my favorite movie critic, which doesn't mean she is necessarily "reliable" or "trustworthy." Absolute trustworthiness presupposes a static intelligence, a kind of analytical gearbox or dogma mill for grinding fine whatever cinematic grain drops into it.

The request by Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, for a special task force to assess damage caused by textile and apparel imports ignores the interests of hundred of thousands of apparel and textile workers, it was charged yesterday in a joint statement by the presidents of four unions.
MOSCOW, Feb. 11 "Watch Your Faces" a theatrical mixture of poetry by Andrei Voznesensky, imaginative pantomime, topical humor and a relatively mild social message, opened here last night.
BONN, Feb. 11 The police today identified three young Arab suspects in the grenade attacks on Israeli passengers at the Munich airport yesterday, in which one was killed.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., achieved a 24 per cent increase in earnings last year on a 17 per cent gain in revenues, which topped $1-billion for the first time, William S. Paley, chairman, and Frank Stanton, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 An unorthodox Ash Wednesday service in a downtown church today marked the beginning of a 75-day protest against the the Vietnam war. The action begun today, the beginning of Lent, will continue through Passover.
OCHO RIOS, Jamaica Jamaica's off shore sport fishing is excellent, and charter boat rates are comparable to those along Florida's coast.
NANTERRE, France, Feb. 3 "Al Fatah will win!" shouted leftist protesters who surged through the law school here. Their campus foes had already slathered its walls with the slogan "Israel Will Live."

BONN, Feb. 11 Well-placed Western sources said today that a Soviet proposal for talks on West Berlin called for negotiations at the ambassadorial level starting in the second half of the month in the city's old Allied Control Council building.
LONDON, Feb. 11 Prince Charles, summoned to Parliament by his mother "for arduous and urgent affairs," took his seat in the House of Lords today.
It is possible to put on a chamber concert that is entertaining and yet musically beyond reproach. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center did just that last night in Alice Tully Hall.
The New York Board of Rabbis yesterday elected Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein, the spiritual leader of Temple Emanu-El in Lynbrook, L.I., as the board's president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 When a President sets out to identify his Administration with new initiatives in an area of national concern, such as poverty or the environment, his message to Congress is essentially a political document.

CAIRO, Feb. 11 Cairo's military spokesman reported that an Egyptian infantry company carried out another major assault across the Suez Canal early today, occupying an Israeli fortified position and later ambushing an armored column.
Some defeats over an 82game National Basketball Association schedule hurt more than others and last night's 125-118 setback by the Boston Celtics was in that category for the New York Knickerbockers.

A NORWEGIAN elkhound and a Pekingese were the dogs that pressed the best-in-show boxer most closely in the final analysis of the Westminster Kennel Club show competition in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, Anna Katherine Nicholas, the judge, said yesterday.
WEEB EWBANK put it all into perspective. "Now don't sign anybody until our doctor examines him," the Jets' coach said. "We've learned. We're still paying people who never played for us."
HONOLULU, Feb. 11 (AP) A bill repealing the state's abortion laws was referred today to a Senate-House conference committee.

CHEOREO, South Vietnam, Feb. 8 In an uprising four years ago the mountain tribesmen of Phubon Province in the Central Highlands came close to capturing this dusty capital from the South Vietnamese government.
The World Bank announced yesterday that it has arranged to borrow the equivalent of $100-million from Japan at an annual interest rate of 7.14 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Senate liberals, shaken by the new alliance between Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff and Southern opponents of school desegregation, moved today to counter the Connecticut Democrat's contention that the North was guilty of "monumental hypocrisy."

ALBANY, Feb. 11 The Assembly postponed action today on a controversial bill to repeal the state's constitutional ban on financial aid to parochial schools as the bill's sponsor offered an amendment that would permit taxpayers' suits "to restrain unconstitutional expenditures."

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 The defense in the Chicago conspiracy trial contended today that the Government "concocted" its case against the seven defendants to justify the police violence against demonstrators during the Democratic National convention here in 1968.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 One of the small dramas of American politics in 1970 is being played out in a Paris office.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Feb. 11 A county grand jury in this mined-out hard coal region has indicted two coal companies and their top officers in connection with a two-year-old mine cave-in that caused an estimated $2-million in damage to surface structures.

ROME, Feb. 11 Pope Paul VI, noting the 41st anniversary today of the signing of the Lateran Treaty and the Concordat between Italy and the Holy See, said the Vatican accepted the need for a jointly negotiated revision of some parts of the 1929 agreement.

DIANA LYNN HALL opens today in her first "ci vilian" part, and she's letting her hair grow for the role. The former actress (she's not sure whether she gave up the theater or the theater gave her up) is director of Go, a travel agency, operated by Diners Fugazy Travel. Go is the newest inhabitant of Bonwit Teller's sixth floor.

STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 11 Swedish officials, having already taken strict measures against air pollution, are thinking of banning private cars from sizable downtown areas in Stockholm and other cities.
MOSCOW, Feb. 11 The Soviet Union almost effortlessly scored a 9-2 victory over the United States tonight in a boxing match that often resembled an exercise in peaceful coexistence.
Clement S. Crystal, president of Clement S. Crystal, Inc., construction contractors, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 190 East 72d Street in New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Commerce Department was accused today of conducting an "industry-biased" study to determine whether unit pricing the posting of the price per pound, ounce or other appropriate unit for food and other consumer items was necessary and feasible.
City Council President Sanford D. Garelik, in a display of political independence, voted against one Lindsay administration proposal yesterday and sharply questioned another.

PARIS, Feb. 11 Xuan Thuy, chief of the North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace talks, confirmed tonight that there would be no secret talks as long as the United States maintained Philip C. Habib as acting head of its delegation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 American laboratories will be asked to make a big effort this year to grow large amounts of viruses in the hope of clinching the rapidly accumulating evidence that some human cancers are caused by viruses.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced the appointment of seven judges to the city's Criminal Court and an interim appointment to fill a vacancy on the Civil Court.

Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy sat quietly in an overcrowded room yesterday as Mayor Lindsay, New York's two United States Senators and other speakers praised a $10.1-million Federal grant to develop the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) The Ford Motor Company will end its direct sponsorship of stock car racing teams within the next 30 days, it was learned from a reliable source today.

BURLINGTON, N.C., Feb. 11 Mr. and Mrs. George Attonore Long of Burlington have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Julia Margaret Long, to James Kenneth Tighe, son of Mr. George Augustus Tighe of Bronxville, N.Y., and Mrs. Andrew Mitchell of Princeton, N.J. The couple plan to be married here April 11 in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Comforter.

The three commercial television networks have curbed their immediate interest in using a domestic satellite system to relay their programs across the country. They have engaged Page Communications Engineers, Inc., of Washington, to study all possible methods of interconnecting their affiliated stations, whether by ground or microwave facilities.
The Rudy Perez Dance Theater is an offbeat locale of muted emotion and wry juxtaposition of movement. It mingles calm climaxes with frenzied trivia to produce low-key but powerful theatrical effects.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 11 A small Israeli Army force was reported to have penetrated into Jordanian territory today, on the eastern side of the Dead Sea, raiding an Arab guerrilla encampment. The raiding party reported killing two men, capturing another and returning with weapons said to have been used in raids against Israel.
BONN, Feb. 11 Erich Heckel, one of the first German expressionists, died after a long illness Jan. 27 at a hospital in Radolfzell, Lake Constance. He was 86 years old.
SAN DIEGO, Feb. 11 (AP) Walt Hazzard led Atlanta through a National Basketball Association record-shattering 54-point third quarter tonight and the Hawks overwhelmed the San Diego Rockets, 155-131.
For the first time since the Police Department modernized its crime analysis system four years ago, the annual number of major crimes reported in the city has dropped.

State Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino complained in an angry letter to Mayor Lindsay yesterday that the Bronx County Courthouse was "a fire hazard by reason of exposed electrical wiring," was "in a filthy and shameful condition" and was leading "to the destruction of the public's confidence and respect for our judicial system."

RENATA TEBALDI may have recorded the role of Minnie in Puccini's "Fanciulla del West," but she had never sung it in New York. Last night at the Metropolitan Opera she took care of that omission. At the end of the first act she received a good hand. At the end of the second, the audience would not let her go. New York had found a new Girl of the Golden West to love.
OTTAWA, Feb. 11 A southeasterly gale drove oil from the broken Liberian tanker Arrow toward the rocky Nova Scotia shore today.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 11 Dr. Helen Kim, the president emeritus of Ewha Women's University and a pioneer in Korean women's education, died last night of cerebral hemorrhage at her home here. She was 86 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Judge G. Harrold Carswell's nomination to the Supreme Court won its first support today from a nationally known Negro leader when it was disclosed that Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, who was freed from Federal prison last month by President Nixon, had urged that the nomination be confirmed.

A group of Liberal party officials led by the minority leader in the City Council charged yesterday that the party had begun a "disgraceful purge" of officers who disagreed with the policies of Alex Rose, the party's dominant figure.
Rumors of an imminent cut in interest rates enabled the American Stock Exchange to post a gain yesterday as a late rally wiped out most of the earlier losses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 He seems surprisingly tall when seen silhouetted at night down an abandoned Washington street. Perhaps it is the stovepipe hat. He never walks the night streets without it. Once, he says, he took his nocturnal walk wearing a porkpie hat, but felt like an anachronism.

The national observance today of Abraham Lincoln's birth one hundred and sixty-one years ago comes at a time when the moral centerpiece of his Presidency the emancipation of the black man is being disputed in its most important meaning; education of youth as the way to achieve full equality of opportunity and citizenship in the United States, North and South.

THE Dallas Aces, the 1970 North American bridge team, arrived back on their home grounds last night to continue their touring rivalry with Omar Sharif's Bridge Circus. A private practice session was held last night and the Aces impressed their nonplaying captain, Oswald Jacoby.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) The Safeguard antiballistic missile radars emit such powerful radiation that they could cripple the long-range missiles they are supposed to protect. The radiation could also endanger the health of the launching crews, according to the Army.

YALE defeated Stanford in an outdoor swimming meet at Palo Alto last Saturday following pre-meet stories in California papers voicing hope for chilly weather that might handicap the "delicate Yalees."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 11 (UPI) The Ranco, Inc., management slate of directors won by a narrow margin in last week's elections, the company announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Plans are being drafted for a global network of stations equipped to monitor changes in the earth's environment threatening the life forms that in habit it. The project, in which scientists from the Soviet Union and the United States are playing leading roles, would identify subtle but potentially disastrous alterations caused by pollution, power plant radiation, chemicals and other factors.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 11 (AP) Anneroesli Zryd, a 20year-old salesgirl who was an 11th-hour addition to the Swiss team, surprised the world's best skiers today by winning the women's downhill of the world Alpine ski championships.
Office and clerical employes of the Lithographers and Photoengravers International Union have been on strike since Monday in a dispute over severance pay.
MIAMI, Feb. 11 (AP) J.B. Moseley's Drumtop and Hobeau Farm's Harem Lady closed fast to win the divisions of the $20,000-added Columbiana Handicap at Hialeah today before a crowd of 19,028.

TRAPPE, Md., Feb. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Russell A. Young, formerly of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Ferguson Young, to Hall Fletcher Swanson of Darien, Conn., son of Mrs. Eleanor F. Swanson of Darien and Dr. Irving A. Swanson, a New York dentist.
MASERU, Lesotho, Feb. 8 "To rent," says an advertise ment in The Rand Daily Mail of Johannesburg, "mountain cottage in Lesotho, Splendid scenery and superb trout fishing."
BOSTON, Feb. 11 Eight busloads of young men and women, carrying sleeping bags knapsacks and provisions, left Boston this afternoon on an expedition to harvest sugar in Cuba.

Dependability and predictability were the chief characteristics of the New York Philharmonic concert last night at Philharmonic Hall with Leonard Bernstein conducting his last concert of the season with the orchestra.

Management. President Nixon signed an Executive order establishing the President's Advisory Council on Management Improvement. The council will be chaired by Bernard A. Schriever, the former Air Force missile director.

Liggett Myers, Inc., the cigarette and food manufacturer and liquor distributor, announced yesterday it had turned down a formal proposal to be acquired by Heublein, Inc., a major producer of wines, vodka and mixed cocktails.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 11 (AP) The Milwaukee Bucks took a 102-90 lead early in the final period and then withstood a furious Phoenix rally to down the Suns, 127-120, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 Intensive lobbying for a compromise in New York State's Boat Sewage-Control Law has been turned back, and the long-delayed measure is set to go into effect March 1.
Charles E. Powers, resident counsel and secretary of the Automobile Club of New York until his retirement Jan. 1, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a short illness. He was 65 years old.

DENVER, Feb. 11 The Colorado Department of Public Health is looking into the report by a group of scientists that the Rocky Flats atom bomb manufacturing plant has been releasing highly poisonous plutonium into the environment.
New York Maritime College will begin a 10-week lecture series on sailing techniques on Tuesday, Rear Admiral Edward J. O'Donell, the president, announced yesterday.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 11 The Labor Department said today that it hoped to have the Outreach program for recruiting Negro youths for apprenticeship in construction unions in 80 cities by July 1. The program is run by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations but is subsidized by the Government.
Ed Conlin, Fordham's basketball coach, believes the only way Calvin Murphy of Niagara can be stopped is with a fish net and a tranquilizer gun.
A 47-year-old cab driver who was beaten and robbed early yesterday on the West Side, died of head injuries a few hours later in Roosevelt Hospital.

DETROIT, Feb. 11 The job of cleaning up the automobile engine by 1975 to meet President Nixon's proposed requirements could raise the price of a new car by 10 per cent, one of the auto industry's leading pollution experts said today.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange slipped yesterday in reaction to Tuesday's decline on Wall Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (AP) The helicopters roared into the Special Forces camp in the jungles 45 miles northeast of Saigon and the colonels and majors descended, looking for souvenirs for their game rooms back home.

TRENTON, Feb. 11 Angelo (Gyp) De Carlo, a reputed top Mafia figure in New Jersey, was told today in State Superior Court that he would be jailed tomorrow unless he testified "fully and responsively" before an extraordinary closed holiday session of the State Commission of Investigation.
United Artists Theaters, which runs a chain of 117 film houses in the metropolitan area, is planning to open several new ones here shortly.

PLYMOUTH UNION, Vt., Feb. 11 A middle-aged, rotund skier from Cleveland walked into Bob Rondeau's office at Round Top Mountain late this afternoon. It was beginning to snow after a 36-hour rainfall had deluged most of Vermont.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 11 A military judge ruled today that the Army had jurisdiction to try First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. on charges of killing 102 Vietnamese civilians at My lai 4, in the Songmy village complex, in 1968.
Msgr. John Joseph Patrick Fleming, president of Cathedral College of the Immaculate Conception in Douglaston, Queens, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at the college. He was 57 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Nixon Administration's most recent choice for Selective Service Director has withdrawn himself from consideration in the face of a threat from a senior member of the Senate Armed Services Committee to block the nomination.

The Indian Supreme Court's rejection of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Bank Nationalization Act is not likely to erase the dramatic political advantage Mrs. Gandhi scored when she first proposed nationalization last July, nor to halt the modest swing to the left that that action represented.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Frederic M. Stewart have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Stewart, to Army Lieut. Chris Harlow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas C. Harlow of Sunnyside, Queens. A June wedding is planned.

Mrs. Jacqueline Grennan Wexler, appealing for new patterns of government in the cities and on the campuses, was invested yesterday as the ninth president of Hunter College.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 11 Prince Butler, a harness horse, is batting 1,000. The 4-year-old hasn't been playing baseball during the current meeting at Roosevelt Raceway, but he has been pacing his way into the hearts (and fattening the wallets) of those fans who have been backing him.

MANILA, Feb. 11 A huge anti-Government rally scheduled for tomorrow was called off tonight following a meeting at the Presidential palace between President Ferdinand E. Marcos and militant labor and student leaders.

Friends of Duke Ellington, alumni of his orchestra, his proteges, members of the Duke Ellington Society of dedicated fans, and supporters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will gather for a musical tribute the evening of Feb. 23 at Madison Square Garden.

CAIRO, Feb. 11 Arab pressure on United States oil interests intensified today following a declaration by five Arab "confrontation" countries that the exploitation of Arab "resources and wealth" by benefactors of Israel must be "liquidated."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 United States fighterbombers attacked enemy gun positions inside Cambodia today after an American light observation helicopter was struck by ground fire from Cambodia and exploded in the air, United States spokesmen said.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 11 The National Environmental Policy Act recently signed by President Nixon was cited today in a suit that seeks to block construction of a $200million West German chemical complex in coastal Beaufort County.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 11 Secretary of State William P. Rogers conferred with President Tito of Yugoslavia here today on the Middle East crisis. In a statement Mr. Rogers also outlined a four-point policy on Africa that the Nixon Administration intends to follow.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 11 (AP) After threatening to boycott the qualification round for the special slalom at the world Alpine ski championships, the top men skiers have found a new way to protect their interests they have formed a union.

BOWIE, Md., Feb. 11 (AP) Eldon Nelson a jockey, and John Tammaro, a trainer, joined forces today to capture three of the first seven races, including a one, two finish in the featured Eddie Gallaher Purse at Bowie race course.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11 President Nixon has registered steady popularity gains in successive measurements since mid-December, according to the Gallup Poll. Sixty-six per cent of those interviewed in the latest survey said they approved the way Mr. Nixon was discharging his duties.

Energy Research, Inc., has announced that it has operated for 1,000 consecutive hours a fossil-fuel heated thermionic diode at 70 watts. This is considered a major breakthrough in power-generating technology.
The Cerro Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to appoint C. Gordon Murphy, a 45-year-old vice president of Litton Industries, Inc., as president and chief executive officer of Cerro.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Vice President Agnew, who was installed in a White House office with considerable fanfare little more than a year ago; is quietly vacating the premises.

OTTAWA, Feb. 11 The Government submitted to Parliament today spending estimates for 1970-71 that showed a 7.4 per cent rise to a record level of $12.9-billion. Much of the increase resulted from expenditures required by law.

Approximately 9,000 rushhour commuters on the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the Penn Central's line serving Jersey shore points were delayed or diverted last night when a mishap dislocated the railroad lift bridge over the Raritan River at Perth Amboy, N.J.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 11 The Berkeley City Council's public hearing on a proposal to buy two Police Department helicopters broke up in shouts of anger, stench-bomb fumes and fluttering paper airplanes last night.

Airline and Soviet security guards scuffled with reporters and photographers last night at Kennedy International Airport when Aleksandr V. Tikhomirov, who has been charged by the United States with espionage returned here from Seattle.

CAIRO, Feb. 11 In expectation of attacks on Cairo, the Ministry of the Interior has ordered tightening of defense measures. The capital's car owners were given 24 hours to paint their headlights blue or face fines.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11 Al Fath, the principal Paleastinian commando organization, declared tonight that it would resist with force any attempt by the Jordanian Government to enforce the internal-security regulations issued yesterday.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 11 The Oakland Athletics' owner, Charles O. Finley, has sent out 300,000 valentines to high school students, each good for free admission to a game on one of nine designated days next season.

A defective chimney, known for nearly a year to city housing inspectors, was tentatively blamed yesterday for the death on Tuesday by asphyxiation of a 31-year-old mother and four of her six children in their Brooklyn apartment.

A brokerage house is attempting to invade a restricted area of pension-fund management by requesting the internal Revenue Service to permit it to sponsor prototype pension plans.

DALLAS, Feb. 11 "My problems are nearer those of the little guy than those of the big stores and my major goal this year is to help give small retailers some of the advantages that big companies have had for a long time."

Substantial charges for future losses on contracts reduced last year's earnings of the United Aircraft Corporation to $50,909,496, or $4.21 a common share, from the record of $61,393,951, or $5.10 a share, earned in 1968 after similar special charges, according to a report issued yesterday from the company's East Hartford, Conn., headquarters.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 11 (AP) A personal letter from President Richard Nixon was presented tonight to Fabio Conci, the president of the Italian Winter Sport Federation, congratulating him for the organization of the Val Gardena World Alpine championships.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 The Los Angeles school system was ordered today to present a plan by June 1 for the integration of the district's 555 schools.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 11 (AP) Kenneth Wedra, hired killer of Dorothy DeTore, was sentenced to a maximum of 25 years to life in Westchester County Court today.

Dr. Alexander F. Balmain, a former assistant professor of history and sociology at Fordham University, died Saturday at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at the Sands Point (L.I.) Nursing home.

NEW HAVEN Once a year, as delicately as death's rattle, Yale students rate their courses and professors. A computer puts out the results, members of The Yale Daily News add their personal memorials, and the printed necrology is for sale at $1.95 as the Yale Course Critique.
Harry C. Gillespie, treasurer and director of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, has been elected corporate vice president.

BankAmericard, one of the nation's two principal credit card systems, reported yesterday that total billings last year soared to slightly more than $2-billion from $814-million in 1968, an increase of 146 per cent. Master Charge is the other principal system.

Gen. Jose V. Zuniga, former chief of the Honduran Army, died of pneumonia at Flushing Hospital in Queens Saturday, while visiting relatives here. He was 85 years old.

Protestants and Roman Catholics in the metropolitan area opened the solemn season of Lent yesterday at Ash Wednesday services devoted to penance prayer and redication to the service of God and their fellow men.

Mrs. Patricia Shephard Norris, former wife of the Chicago grain millionaire Bruce A. Norris, and Herbert Parsons Patterson, the 44year-old president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, plan to be married here on April 30.

Henry Saltzman, a former education aide to Mayor Lindsay, was appointed acting president of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn yesterday. He will fill the vacancy created by the death on Jan. 19 of James B. Donovan, the college's president.
