Governor Rockefeller rejected the city's plans for the Richmond Parkway yesterday and recommended that Mayor Lindsay accept an alternate route along the western edge of the Greenbelt in central Staten Island.
The Metropolitan Museum's second major exhibition of its centennial year opens to the public today with holiday hours of from 1 to 5 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The war in Vietnam has claimed more than 12,000 deaths among draftees, most of them in the army, the Pentagon said today.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders said today that they had agreed on a $30.7-million emergency loan package to improve mainteance on New York City's subway system and metropolitan area commuter railroad lines.
MONTREAL, Feb. 11 (UPI) Mike Walton scored his second goal of the game with only 43 seconds remaining tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-3 tie with the Montreal Canadiens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 A. majority of the House members from New York and New Jersey proposed legislation today to revoke the authority of the Army Corps of Engineers to permit the dumping of sewage sludge near the entrance to New York Harbor.
Utilities continued to expand at an unabated rate with a variety of new programs and projects announced yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 11 (AP) Railroad union leaders, in a pessimistic mood, resumed efforts today to settle a labor dispute that could produce another threat of a nationwide rail shutdown.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 The Rangers kept waiting for all of the Rolling Stones to swoop down on a power-play tonight, or perhaps for the electricity to fail completely.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The member of the Federal Reserve Board who has been running the program of control over bank lending to foreigners proposed today a major change in the program.
Nigeria's Ambassador to the United States, Joseph Iyalla, said yesterday that his country needs and welcomes American business participation in the difficult task of postwar reconstruction.
Spurred probably by the proliferating independent media-buying services, Grey Advertising has created a special unit that will do all its broadcast spot buying.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 The economy is unlikely to avoid a recession in 1970, a vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis said today.
PARIS, Feb. 11 (Reuters) January French foreign trade showed a deficit of 960-million francs, the Finance Ministry said.
ATLANTA, Feb. 11 The Nixon Administration will not oppose two Stennis amendments to the four-year, $35billion education bill, the chairman of the Georgia Republican party said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 President Nixon announced today that he would nominate Malcolm R. Wilkey, a former Assistant Attorney General in the Eisenhower Administration, to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12 Yale's track team won eight of 13 events today to defeat Dartmouth in a dual meet, 60-49.
The General Motors Acceptance Corporation announced yesterday that consolidated net income last year amounted to $47.16-million, up 4 per cent from 1968's $45.33million.

Dr. Harold S. Roberts, director and founder of the University of Hawaii's Industrial Relations Center in Honolulu, died there Feb. 5 of a heart attack. He was 58 years old. Dr. Roberts had lived in Hawaii since 1947.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Revised figures today put the

MERIDIAN, Miss., Feb. 12 A man convicted in the slaying of three civil rights workers in 1964 and his brother have been identified here by police sources as the paid informers who helped the police to spring a bizarre trap in the attempted bombing of a Jewish businessman's home here in 1968.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (UPI) Chet Walker, Bob Love and Shaler Halimon sparked a 67point final half for the Chicago Bulls tonight to provide a 122121 victory over the Phoenix Suns in a National Basketball Association game. The Suns led, 58-55, at the half.
TORONTO, Feb. 12 The stern section of the broken Liberian tanker Arrow, holding a million gallons of heavy fuel oil, sank in 100 feet of water off Nova Scotia today.
BONN, Feb. 12 Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany today invited Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany to confer this month in East Berlin on a treaty between the two German states.

PARIS With every battlefield success of Israel's redoubtable little military forces, new political problems emerge among the Arabs. The big question is whether these problems do not in fact make even more remote than ever Israel's hope for eventual settlement.

MILDENHALL Air Force Base, England, Feb. 12 (Reuters)--An American Air Force jet transport reported to have been leaking poisonous fumes from a rocket on board was cleared as safe by United States authorities tonight.

Steve Adams of St. Joseph's Regional High School of Ramsey, N.J., shattered Gary Gubner's 10-year-old meet record by nearly four feet yesterday in winning the open shot-put event at the 2lst annual New York University interscholastic track meet at Alumni Gymnasium in the Bronx.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 12 A labor group warned here today that mergers and the continuing increase in conglomerates posed a serious threat for American consumers and workers.
Gordon M. Fair, an expert in sanitary, engineering and former dean of engineering at Harvard University, died Wednesday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 75 years old.

An account of alleged intrigue within the Mafia to depose Carlo Gambino as boss of one of the most powerful organized crime "families" in the country unfolded yesterday at a public hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 City officials obtained a court order today in an effort to end a health emergency caused by a 10-day slowdown in garbage collections.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The United Mine Workers of America accused the news media today of conducting a "journalistic lynching bee" of its top leaders.
More than 125 upperclassmen from such colleges as Princeton, Yale, Harvard and Union Theological Seminary have signed up to take the examination to become New York City policemen.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 12 Fifteen years ago the newly formed American Motors Corporation, a fragile consolidation of the Nash and Hudson Companies, led its giant competitors with the first compact car in the United States, the Rambler. It turned the company around. Today, American Motors unveiled the Gremlin, the first sub-compact, designed to meet the challenge of imported cars.
DETROIT, Feb. 12 (UPI) Pete Stemkowski scored twice tonight as the Detroit Red Wings handed the St. Louis Blues their sixth straight loss, 5-2, in a National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) The Defense Department denied today that the powerful radars needed for the Safeguard antiballistic missile system would interfere with the Minuteman missiles it is designed to protect.

Pollution-control stocks, currently the favorite group in Wall Street, provided some support yesterday to a mixed market. Popular averages showed minor drops, while advances outpaced declines on the New York Stock Exchange by 653 to 612.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 13 (AP) North Vietnamese troops in concealed positions ambushed a United States Marine patrol in the Queson Valley south of Danang yesterday, and 13 of the Americans were killed in the battle. Twelve other marines were wounded.
Peter F. Tufo, at 31 an "oldtimer" in the Lindsay administration, has resigned as head of the city's Washington office to resume private law practice.

PARIS, Feb. 12 A coordinated United States-Soviet study of satellite communications was proposed here today by Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman of the board of the RCA Corporation, as a step toward ending nationalism in communications.
Miss Patricia Ann Moser, a junior at Carnegie Mellon University, plans to be married to Karl Geoffrey Spitzer, a student at Boston University School of Law.

MANILA, Feb. 12 An estimated 20,000 students and workers held an orderly demonstration in downtown Plaza Miranda this evening and listened to speakers who denounced "growing fascism and imperialism in the coun- try."
JERUSALEM, Feb. 12 Israeli jets raided deep in Egyptian territory today, hitting what were described as a radar station, an army camp, an air force depot and other military installations.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 The defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial were compared today to an illustrious line of "outside agitators."
Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, appealed yesterday to the Nixon Administration to provide Israel with "sufficient military and economic strength to deter Arab aggression."
Miss Frances Lea Parker, a stewardess for Continental Airlines, plans to be married in Houston on Feb. 28 to James M. Brooks Jr., an art student at the Fine Arts Museum there.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 12 Richard Waters, a staff statistician working behind the scenes in the wildly booming Sydney Stock Exchange, gauges the day's trend of the world's busiest share market by a faster method than scanning the figures that flow into his department.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 12 In a series of attacks against more than a dozen Laotian Government positions yesterday and early today, North Vietnamese troops launched what military observers here interpreted as their long-expected counteroffensive to retake the Plaine des Jarres.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 Professional track and field, which has had more false starts in the last 16 months than a nervous sprinter, is quietly moving into the blocks again for one last run to fame or financial doom.
Striking tugboat workers agreed yesterday to provide tows to governmental agencies for disposal of sludge at sea.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 12 (Reuters) Ted Turner, an American yachtsman, stepped off a jet from the United States today, raced to Sydney's Palm Beach by taxi and sailed his sloop Nemesis to victory in the third race of the Scandinavian Gold Cup 5.5-Meter Class series. Nemesis was timed in 3 hours 20 minutes 32 seconds.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 12 A suit charging that the Mount vernon Board of Education spent $200,000 unnecessarily on a school renovation project was brought yesterday in State Supreme Court here.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 12 Harried Long Island Rail Road commuters, according to a study, blame the rail line for fatigue, conscious anger, anxiety, headaches, palpitations, indigestion, abdominal cramps, muscle pain and even sexual problems.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 12 In Room 24 of the Hotel Laurin at Selva, one of the three little valley villages that are host to the world Alpine ski championships, lives an odd couple: Billy Kidd, the 26-year-old medalwinning United States skier, and Tage Pedersen, the 42year-old director of the Aspen Health Center in Colorado.

COPENHAGEN, Feb. 12 (AP) Don Fullmer of West Jordan; Utah, fought a 10-round draw tonight with Tom Bogs, the European middleweightchampion from Denmark, in an unpopular decision before 7,000 outraged spectators who thought the American had won.
Miss Antonia, Tackaberry Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Daniel Thompson of New York and Lloyd Neck, L.I., was married in a civil ceremony in London last Friday to Anthony James West.
Out of the deep, dark, secret (but creative) recesses that link American Telephone and Telegraph with Cunningham Walsh has come the Abominable Yellow Phoneman.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 12 Gretel II, Australia's potential challenger this year for the America's Cup, was launched by crane today into Sydney Harbor to the comments of yachting experts such as` "not radical but interesting," "a weirdie but she should fly," and "probably the most unusual 12-Meter yacht ever built."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 12 Pakistan is providing "military-training assistance" to Jordan but the number of her personnel there, as reported in The New York Times, is "highly exaggerated," a Foreign Office spokesman said today in Islamabad.

Stan Smith, who capped a brilliant 1969 showing with two singles victories and a share of the doubles triumph in Davis Cup challenge round play, was listed No. 1 nationally yesterday in the United States Lawn Tennis Association's final rankings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) A Congressional joint panel on the economy proposed today the abolishment of the Highway Trust Fund, which has been used to finance the vast interstate network of roads.

Pablo Casals, the 93-yearold cellist, will conduct 100 cellists in his own composition, "La Sardana," in a special benefit concert, "Salud Casals," to be given by the American Symphony Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall on April 15.

SAN JUAN, P.R. Feb. 12 (UPI) An underground Puerto Rican revolutionary movement that favors independence and calls itself Mira said today that it had carried out 19 terrorist acts since last December, including seven in New York City.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 Deep Yankee and Smokey Rainbow, a pair of 4-year-old horses, won a division apiece in the Independence pace series as the 1970 spring harness racing season opened tonight at Liberty Bell Park.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Feb. 12 (Reuters) Four avalanches struck in the French Alps near here today, killing an infant and once again isolating Val d'Isere.

A national committee of architects, judges and lawyers is studying the possibility of redesigning courtrooms so that defendants who might disrupt trials could be kept behind soundproof plastic shields except when testifying.

BONN, Feb. 12 The three Arabs who hurled grenades at the passengers of an Israeli airliner at the Munich airport Tuesday killing one of them and injuring 11 originally planned to hijack the jet, the Bavarian Interior Minister, Bruno Merk, disclosed today.
Potato futures rose sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in heavy volume.
"Could a combination of stochastic choice rules with heuristic, multivalent, decisiontaking procedures contribute an apparent musical coherence to a chain of changes of state in a structured system?"

Northwest Industries, Inc., the holding company that owns the Chicago North Western Railway and the Lone Star Steel Company as well as several other major corporate entities, reported yesterday its net income last year plunged to $16,818,000, from $36,803,000, in 1968. Last year's earnings actually fell $1,718,000 short of the $18,536,000 the company paid holders of its preferred stock. In 1968 earnings were equal to $2.64 a share on the common stock.

Stocks on the American Stock Exchange moved aimlessly yesterday as measured by its index, which was unchanged at 25.63. Trading moved at a slower pace than the previous day, apparently due to the holiday, 3,555,785 shares compared with 4,242,005 on Wednesday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 12 The Australian national team inflicted a second defeat on the American touring team here last night. Tim Seres and Dick Cummings, who played a key role in the earlier Australian victory in Sydney, teamed with an outstanding husband-andwife partnership, Jim and Norma Borin of Melbourne, to win the 48-deal match by 20 international points.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 12 The engagement of Miss Jane Foy to Joseph W. Karaman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Karaman, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. Foy of Kendridge Farm. Plans have been made for an August wedding.
With the commercial banks closed in New York City and other money centers, the credit markets yesterday were almost at a standstill.
Representative Edward I. Koch charged yestreday that the Waterfront Commission failed to use its licensing power to keep organized crime off the waterfront of New York Harbor.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 12 A tentative date in mid-May for the court-martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with the murder of 102 Vietnamese civilians, was set today by Lieut. Col. Reid W. Kennedy, military judge.

A move to encourage legal research on the constitutional implications of the Federal Government's policy of subpoenaing reporters and their notes was announced yesterday by Sidney Zion, president of Scanlan's Literary House, at a news conference at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West 44th Street.
STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 12 Representatives of 24 European countries called today for the safeguarding of unspoiled coastal areas and a variety of other conservationist measures.

A pricing policy on steel, generally described by producers as a guarantee of stability, was assured of acceptance throughout the industry yesterday when the United States Steel Corporation said it would match what other big companies had announced.
PARIS, Feb. 12 The four delegations to the Paris peace talks found nothing new to say to one another today and made the 54th plenary session one of the shortest on record.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 12 The Hat Corporation of America, one of the nation's largest hat producers, has notified its employes' union that its plant here will close down March 31, Paul Autuore, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers, said today.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 12 Just when it seemed that "Frosty," the 36-foot-high snowman in the middle of Darmouth's campus, was in danger of shrinking out of sight, along came a deep freeze last night to stop "his" cold sweat.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Feb. 12 (AP) Three teams rallied in the last end today and a fourth team Westchester of New York won handily in gaining the semifinals of the United States women's curling championships at The Country Club.

Calvin Murphy helped bring out the largest crowd (12,321) of the regular Madison Square Garden college basketball season last night and after a major scare gave the Niagara rooters something to cheer about.

Joe Savage is currently the country's top schoolboy indoor miler. Ditto for the half-mile. Ditto for the 1,000. Many people believe he would be the fastest in the 600, too, but he hasn't run it as yet.

LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 (UPI) Army unit publications in South Vietnam have received an official "suggestion" that they stop emphasizing "hard combat news" and replace it with "reports of the progress of our efforts in the fields of Vietnamization, pacification and civil action."
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday criticized a Negro neurosurgeon who endorsed the nomination of G. Harrold Carswell to the Supreme Court.

CALL it the Mao, call it the Nehru, or call it the Feruch, which is what Gilbert Feruch, the Paris tailor who made it fashionable, likes to call it. Whatever its name, the high-collared tunic has been mortally wounded in the United States by its mass acceptance. But in Europe, says Mr. Feruch, it has become a classic costume.
Thousands of cab drivers here will ask passengers to sign petitions calling upon the Legislature to reinstate the death penalty for murder in the state.
A Federal judge said yesterday, that a six-year-old criminal tax case would be dismissed because the Government had failed to prosecute it expeditiously.
E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, announced yesterday a series of changes in its top management that included several surprises.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The United States strongly condemned Israel's bombing of an Egyptian scrap-metal plant today and pressed for Big Four efforts to re-establish
Jack Tinker Partners, eager to find its way up the comeback trail, has just named Ken Duskin, a creative partner. He joins Marcella Free, whose appointment was recently announced.

Continuing her private blitzkrieg through women's tennis, Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia won the women's invitation tournament at the Vanderbilt Club last night by overcoming Virginia Wade of England. 6-3, 6-3.

FRANCIS Poulenc's "Le Bal Masque" was given by Gerard Souzay and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at the Wednesday evening concert in Tully Hall. Last night it was repeated, giving another segment of the New York audience a chance to hear a seldomplayed work of the 1930's. Otherwise the program was changed to include Hindemith's Viola Sonata (Op. 11, No. 4), Faure's "La Bonne Chanson" and the Six Bagatelles (Op. 126) of Beethoven.
APPLIED OCEANICS, Ltd., of Bath, Me., has devel- oped a wire lobster pot it believes may replace the traditional wooden unit.
In the narrow beige-tiled hallway of the Madison Square Garden boxing department, the old men in their black overcoats shuffle impatiently.
Herbert L. Weiderman, a retired insurance executive, died yesterday at the Tuxedo Park (N. Y.) Hospital. He was 60 years old.

THERE is one thing extraordinary about "I Dreamt I Dwelt in Bloomingdale's," the rock musical that opened last night at the Provincetown Playhouse. None of the actors sing any of the songs. An onstage rock combo called the Wet Clam does all the playing and singing.

The Israeli bombing of an industrial plant near Cairo, with heavy loss of civilian lives, was an inexcusable perversion of Israel's indisputable right to respond to President Nasser's "war of attrition." Certainly the slaughter of scores of Egyptians was not justified by Tuesday's bloody attack on El Al airline passengers at Munich, despicable as was that guerrilla assault.

ROSLYN, L.I., Feb. 12 Mr. and Mrs. Frank Thomas Lombardo have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Bernadette Lombardo to Alfred Pearce Ilch, son of Mrs. Alfred P. Ilch and the late Mr. Ilch of Rumson, N.J.A spring wedding is planned.

A poll by Louis Harris published yesterday in the New York Post finds that, "for the first time in the modern political era, the Democratic party has lost its position as the majority political party."

Mortimer M. Caplin, the bankruptcy trustee for Webb Knapp, Inc., in a report filed with the Federal district court here, said he had found that after nearly five years of trusteeship "there still remains a severe deficiency in stockholders' equity" of that once farflung realty empire headed by William Zeckendorf Sr.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 12 An African leader told Secretary of State William P. Rogers today that the United States should show the "same energy" in opposing suppression of blacks in southern Africa by minority white governments as it had shown in fighting fascism in World War II.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 12 The Executive Commission of the European Common Market has decided to defend itself against criticisms that its trade policies are harming trade in the non-Communist world.
GROTON, Conn., Feb. 12 (UPI) A search for a missing Pilgrim Airlines plane with five men aboard was called off at sunset today.

HARRISON, N.Y. Some people use art as decoration; they demand that a picture be a certain size to fill a certain spot or they shop for a painting whose colors will go with the living room walls. (Serious art lovers, naturally, take a dim view of this.)
Assemblyman Franz S. Leichter, a West Side Democrat, introduced a bill yesterday that would make it possible for registered addicts to receive doses of heroin and other hard drugs in state clinics.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 12 (AP) Billy Kidd, America's skiing ace, who has a sore back, moved into the favorite's role for the combined title at the world Alpine ski championships today when Dumeng Giovanoli of Switzerland and Franz Vogler of West Germany were injured during practice runs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The Army has charged Capt. Thomas K. Willingham, a 25year-old infantry officer, with the unpremeditated murder of Vietnamese civilians in the village of Songmy on March 16, 1968.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Feb. 12 (AP) First degree murder charges were filed today against Mrs. Annette Gilly, 29 years old, in the slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter, Washington County officials said.

MIAMI, Feb. 12 (AP) The Mill River Stable's Spiral Staircase scored an upset victory in the $10,000 Roman Soldier Purse race at Hialeah today, winning by three lengths from Perfect Tan. Hunter's Dance, a 113-1 shot, was only a nose behind Perfect Tan.

The anguished roars from the subway tunnels have finally become loud enough to be heard in Albany. With the statewide election coming on faster than the Sea Beach express, Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leaders have come up with a modest bundle of cash to make life a little less intolerable for subway riders as well as commuters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Gov. Raymond P. Shafer of Pennsylvania spent most of 1969 trying to persuade his state legislature to increase taxes.
Eileen Farrell, soprano, gave her first New York recital in five years at Philharmonic Hall last night, and she was her usual super-radiant self.
OAKLAND, Feb. 12 "Practice?" asked the pretty girl from United Air Lines. "What do you guys need practice for?"
Stocks advanced slightly in cautious trading on the London stock exchange as traders watched the action on exchanges in New York.
For Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams, his job has a twofold purpose: to build stable neighborhoods in slums and to insert himself as the conduit between all Bronx communities and City Hall.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12 (AP) The first child born to Mrs. Robert B. Meyner, wife of the former Governor of New Jersey, was dead at birth, Princeton Hospital reported today.
A Transit Authority spokesman said yesterday that a conductor who accidentally opened the wrong doors of an elevated IND line "F" train to a 40-foot drop had been warned and "told to be careful."

CRAWFORDVILLE, Fla., Feb. 12 Judge G. Harrold Carswell, nominated by President Nixon to the Supreme Court, owned and sold real estate in 1966 with a covenant restricting the use of the land to "members of the Caucasian race."

Terraced steps replace the steep old entrance stairway. The wooden vestibule known as "the doghouse" has given way to polished brass doors and a curtain of air. The grimy limestone interior has been freshened back to whiteness. And the statues and shops that cluttered the vast floor have been superseded by flower-filled planters.
WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 12 Del Insko, a 5-foot-2-inch, 120-pound bundle of energy, arrived tonight at a harnessracing plateau previously reached by only four other modern-day drivers.

Four letters written by Mrs. Aristotle Onassis to Roswell L. Gilpatric were "found in a wastepaper basket," according to information received by Charles Hamilton, the autograph dealer who accepted the correspondence for auction.

A call by a group that identifies itself as the Transit Crisis Coalition, which urges restoration of the 20-cent transit fare, for a protest demonstration at the headquarters of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority attracted five person yesterday.
GENEVA, Feb. 12 Swiss bankers have been sending so many francs abroad to earn a better return than can be gained at home that the Swiss currency is now in short supply.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Federal Communications commissioner Nicholas Johnson said tonight that the nation's news media had an "absolute right" to refuse the demands by Government prosecutors for reporters' notes and unused television film.
EL KHANKA, United Arab Republic, Feb. 12 Israeli fighter-bombers attacked a scrapmetal processing plant in this Cairo suburb this morning, killing dozens of civilian workers and wounding many more.

THE tinsel-bright ball sitting on top of the chromed cylinder looks like an outsize Christmas tree ornament. The glittering bauble, a 5-inch diameter sphere, may well be the first lamp bulb that is as decorative unlighted as when it is turned on.
VIENNA, Feb. 12 Rumania stressed today her "constructive" posture in the search for a settlement in the Middle East, offering increased cooperation with all parties involved.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 The Government newspaper Izvestia made it clear today that the Soviet Union was dissatisfied with President Nixon's reply to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin's proposals for reducing tension in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 More than one-fourth of the $800-million appropriated by Congress this year for waste treatment plants will not go for new projects. The money will be used to reimburse the states that have prefinanced the Federal share of projects that are already completed or started.

A confidential draft of the Rand Corporation's study on housing decay concludes that a relaxation of the city's rent control law must be linked to a $130-million-a-year city program of rent subsidies to needy families.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 A leading member of Congress on trade matters threw cold water today on a major program of both the Johnson and Nixon Administrations the idea of special tariff preferences for nonfarm goods from the lessdeveloped countries.

THERE was a summer vacation when David Durk, now a sergeant on the New York City police force, was still at Amherst College, and turned down a chance to be an interne at the United Nations and joined the team- sters instead to take a job working in a freezer from...
Carol Channing, the huskyvoiced, blond comedienne who has been a domestic entertainment phenomenon for more than 20 years, is finally going to make her foreign stage debut.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Feb. 7, registered a rise in volume over the corresponding week of last year. Intercity Truck Tonnage in the same period was down.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The nation's top weather administrator told a symposium of meteorologists and weather specialists this morning that the national weather forecasting effort was not meeting the needs of the American people.
Although they lost the Super Bowl game to the Kansas City Chiefs, the Minnesota Vikings did well by their bank accounts near the end of the last National Football League season.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Feb. 12 The engagement of Miss Florence Roome Meyer to Kent Landon Brittan has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Van Nostrand Meyer of Locust Valley. Mr. Brittan is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Goodhue Brittan of Vail, Colo.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 12 President Nixon believes that the North and South should be treated equally on school desegregation, the White House said here today.
NAURU, Feb. 12 The world's smallest republic has started the world's smallest international airline, Air Nauru, according to an announcement by the government of this Pacific island.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The Pentagon is studying a proposal to provide enough modern sensing devices so that South Vietnam could seal its entire 900-mile border against sizable enemy infiltration.
TOKYO, Feb. 12 As Japan's first space satellite, a 50-pounder, circled the earth today, scientists and policymakers wrestled with problems of where and how to direct such ventures in the future.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 11 Bill Ahlhauser, Belinda Behne, Jim Boulet and 32 other Milwaukee teen-agers among them some of the brightest and most successful students in the city's most highly regarded public and private schools believe that much of their high school experience has been a waste of time.
Lope de Vega's rarely performed historical drama, "Fuente Ovejuna" ("The Sheep Well"), seems a strange vehicle at first glance to introduce a university theatrical troupe to a larger public.

The president of Irish International Airlines was in New York yesterday and issued a statement in which he told of his "disappointment" that Pan American World Airways "should belabor the old horse of its efforts to get into Dublin, Ireland."
LAUSKA, Zambia, Feb. 12 President Kenneth D. Kaunda today banned the oppositioin African National Congress in the Livingston district on Zambia's border with Rhodesia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 If the business community wants to see a value-added tax enacted, it will have to help sell the idea to the American people, a high Treasury official told an audience of corporation chiefs today.

TRENTON, Feb. 12 Angelo (Gyp) Da Carlo, a reputed Mafioso who was portrayed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last year as a methodical gangland executioner, burst into tears today under questioning by the State Commission of Investigation.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 12 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi decided tonight to renationalize the nation's 14 leading banks, brushing aside left-wing advice that she take over all of India's foreign and domestic banks, informed sources said.
The New York Public Library again faces a financial crisis, with the prospect of a $4.3-million deficit. Two issues vital to the city's cultural and educational environment are at stake.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 In a rare expression of concern about the dangers of monopoly in local media, the Federal Communications Commission today held up for hearings the license renewal of KFBC-TV in Cheyenne, Wyo.

The National Union Electric Corporation is considering phasing out operations of its Emerson television and radio division in Jersey City, C. Russell Feldmann, chairman, said at a news confercence here yesterday.

Not much can be done to make the title character in Wagner's "Der Fliegende Hollander" come to life. He is intended, or course, as a faceless, mythic fellow, and even in his big chance to snap out of it and act like a human being, in the scene at Daland's house, he stands around striking lovelorn poses for half an hour and then leaves without so much as kissing the angelic Senta.

Continuing its opposition to the proposed Storm King Mountain storage hydroelectric plant, the city will ask the Federal Power Commission today to reverse a decision granting a construction license to Consolidated Edison Company.

Federal and city narcotics agents arrested three men in Manhattan and Queens last night and confiscated quantities of pure heroin and cocaine, which the police said were worth more than $9-million on the illegal market.

CAIRO, Feb. 12 The war has not changed Cairo much on the surface. Some but not all the vast windows at the airport are taped, just in case. Some but not all lights are dimmed at night; but the life of the city goes on about as before, slow and indifferent as the Nile.

The former Stewart Air Force Base, near Newburgh, N.Y., in Orange County, was formally turned over to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday for use, starting March 1, as an airport for corporate and other general-aviation planes.

SAINT JOHN, New Brunswick, Feb 12 (UPI) More than 200 enthusiastic young people from the United States, just returned from Cuban sugar fields, today met 500 recruits preparing to take their place. The returning group sang, slapped backs and described their trip as an "incredible experience."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) The military draft will probably call lottery numbers no higher than 90 in March, an informed source said today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 12 (AP)--An Iowa Air National Guard pilot has been dropped from the ranks because of his bushy moustache. The Guard said today, "Nonconformists just don't work in the military."
A new crop of potholes is making driving often bumpy, sometimes hazardous and occasionally even impossible on streets, roads and highways in the metropolitan area.

A CUT version of "Red, White and Maddox," the satire on the career of Gov. Lester Maddox of Georgia, which had a brief Broadway run after an original presentation in Atlanta, was offered last night by station WNEW-TV, Channel 5. The show's compression to electronic proportions was not very helpful, and the best joke of the night had nothing to do with the original.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 The American Motors Corporation took the automobile industry spotlight today not only by showing its new small car to the news media but also by running up the largest gain in early-February car sales.

MONTEREY, Calif., Feb. 12 Miss Pamela Marie Hull, a graduate of Catholic University of America and Gerard A. Dupuis, who received a degree from the Columbus School of Law of Catholic University, will be married April 4 in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.
GENEVA, Feb. 12 The European Economic Community told its trading partners today it intended to abide by the "letter and spirit" of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Except for the opening moments of the game, Georgetown University never trailed tonight and registered a 94-72 basketball triumph over New York University at McDonough Gym.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 12 The United States today called for big-power discussions on limiting arms shipments to the Middle East and declared that the Big Four should make a joint appeal for an immediate restoration of the cease-fire between Israel and Arab countries.
NOT long ago Burnham Co., a medium-sized brok erage house noted for the quality of its research, started a mutual fund for its custom- ers.

BALLET is a hard taskmaster. In drama you see a play, offer your opinion and fly away. In ballet a critic has to live with his earlier thoughts. Any man who has ever been in love will know the perils of such a course.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The United States Ambassador to France, Sargent Shriver, is flying from Paris to Bucharest tomorrow on a private visit, State Department officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) The president of El Al, the Israeli air line, suggested capital punishment today for persons hijacking or attacking passenger planes.

DALLAS, Feb. 12 More than 250 policemen arrested 351 Negro students at Bishop College during the night, ending a six-day sit-in by the students, who were protesting conditions at the predominantly Negro school.
GENEVA, Feb. 12 The Swiss Government announced today that it had requested recall of two diplomats from the Soviet embassy in Berne because they had been found to be spies.
The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to authorize the presentation of a new commission rate schedule to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 12 (AP) Preliminary data for the fourth quarter of 1969 confirm their prediction of a further slowdown in the American economy, University of Michigan-economists said today.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 12 (UPI) Lee W. Stanley, who created the comic panel "The Old Home Town," died yesterday at his home here. He was 84 years old.
The following reports were Provided by the operators of the ski areas now open. Messages were filed at times indicated in parentheses:
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 12 A new Brazilian morality law was decreed yesterday for periodicals and books.

ROME, Jan. 12 The caretaker Premier, Mariano Rumor, who has headed Italy's last two Governments, agreed tonight to try to form a third and to reconstruct the four-party center-left coalition that has dominated Italian politics since 1963.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 Vice President Agnew criticized tonight colleges and universities that are now admitting minority groups on the basis of quotas rather than aptitude for learning.

Democrats yesterday heaped criticism on details of Governor Rockefeller's proposed $30.7-million mass-transit loan. But many conceded that it was a step in the right direction and predicted that the proposal would easily pass the Legislature, probably next week.
NORTH SALEM, N.Y., Feb. 12 Miss Susan Ann Bondy and David Gordon Willoughby, an account executive with the Young Rubicam advertising agency in New York, plan to be married here in May.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 12 Madison policemen used tear gas to disperse bands of antiwar demonstrators on the University of Wisconsin campus this afternoon.
Miss Mary Jane McKee, a senior at Sweet Briar College, plans to be married in June to Norman Spencer Carmichael, a graduate of the University of Virginia.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 12 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird conferred today with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam and affirmed Presdent Nixon's decision to continue the withdrawal of American troops.
The Rev. Richard F. Doherty, assistant pastor at St. Vincent de Paul Church at 123 West 23d Street, died Wednesday. He was 61 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 When Peter F. Tufo went before the New York City Board of Estimate in the fall of 1968 to request a few hundred extra dollars to move the city's office in Washington to slightly larger quarters, an aide to Mario A. Procacino, who was then Controller, grumbled ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Senator Edmund S. Muskie, dissatisfied with the lack of political attention he has been attracting, plans to use his re-election campaign in Maine this year as a national platform.
The city's debt costs will increase by more than $125-million to $850-million during the coming fiscal year, according to a report issued yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame.

Representative James H. Scheuer, whose district in the Bronx was virtually eliminated by this year's reapportionment, announced yesterday that he would seek election from a neighboring district to the north now represented by a fellow Democrat, Jacob H. Gilbert.

THE PRESIDENT Activities. President Nixon was at his Key Biscayne, Fla., home where he worked with White House staff members on his foreign policy message, which will be delivered to Congress next Wednesday.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 12 Thirteen persons were arrested here today on charges of violating a court order barring a teachers' walkout.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 12 (UPI) Gov. John Bell Williams vetoed more than $5-million in Federal grants for Head Start programs today on the grounds that they were primarily operated for black children and consequently discriminated against whites.

"The Return or the Smothers Brothers" on National Broadcasting Company television at 10 P.M. Monday, will be dedicated to Constitutional rights, on which the brothers stand and on which the network will not even cautiously tread.

The producer of an instrument that can translate video signals from outer space into permanent pictures at the rate of six a second surrendered the equipment yesterday after the Federal Government went to court to win its release.

James J. Feron, president of S.J. Feron, Inc., a tennis and squash racquet shop at 55 E. 44th Street, died yesterday at University Hospital after suffering a brain hemorrhage Sunday. He was 66 years old.

As expected, President Saragat has asked Mariano Rumor to reconstruct a four-party center-left Govern ment in Italy to replace Mr. Rumor's minority Christian Democratic Cabinet. The hope must be that the two Socialist parties are now ready to halt their feuding and collaborate with Christian Democrats and Republicans to end months of dangerous drift.
The Singer Company attained record sales and earnings for the 11th successive year in 1969, with the fourth-quarter also contributing record results.
CAPETOWN, Feb. 12 The brother of King Moshoeshoe II of Lesotho, himself under house arrest since Chief Leabua Jonathan, the Prime Minister, suspended the Constitution 13 days ago, has been arrested.
City Council President Sanford D. Garelik, who opposed two Lindsay administration proposals earlier this week in a display of political independence, was in a conciliatory mood yesterday.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 12 King Hussein and the Palestinian commandos reached agreement here tonight on measures to end the crisis over new security steps taken by the Jordanian Government.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 12 (AP) Bob Murphy posted a sixunder-par 66 today and tied Lee Trevino for the first-round lead in the $100,000 Tucson open golf tournament.

The Seattle Pilots, using $650,000 supplied by their 11 partners in the American League, will continue to play baseball in Seattle in 1970, but after that the future location of the franchise may be Milwaukee or Dallas-Fort Worth.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 (UPI) Dave Wohl scored 5 consecutive points in the closing minutes tonight to send once-defeated Pennsylvania to a 70-62 Ivy League basketball victory over Yale at the Palestra.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 13 (Agence France-Presse) The North Vietnamese Government has published a resolution concerning the opening of a "productive labor movement," designed to put into effect the economic plan for 1970.
WISE, Va., Feb. 13 (UPI) Oliver W. Powers, father of the former U-2 pilot Francis Gary Powers, died at a hospital here yesterday of an undetermined cause. He was 65 years old.

The Lindsay administration's belated move to help the children who are being treated for drug addiction in the Bronx Odyssey House program ought to be but the first step in a long march forward. The old antagonism between officials of municipal and of private addiction treatment facilities has to be replaced by a new spirit of cooperation. The drug problem is large enough to require a concentrated attack from many sides by many people.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP) Expressions of confidence emanated today from the camps of the champion, Jose (Mantequilla) Napoles, and Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez as they went through final preparations for their 15-round fight for the world welterweight championship tomorrow night.

Four of every 10 New York Stock Exchange member firms doing a public business lost money on security commission income (including net margin interest income) in the first half of 1969. Their cumulative loss amounted to $58-million. Losses ranged up to $5.7-million, with 13 firms losing over $1-million and 51 losing over $250,000.

The modus operandi, armaments and descriptions of two men who used explosives to divert the police while robbing a Danbury, Conn., bank yesterday were strikingly similar to those of two men who held up a bank in Union, Mo., exactly three months ago.

The Capital Cities Broadcasting Corporation reached an agreement yesterday to acquire radio and television stations in Philadelphia, New Haven and Fresno, Calif., from Triangle Publications, Inc., in addition to the syndication division of Triangle.

LONDON, Feb. 13 In Nairobi one recent evening a young lawyer spoke of his feelings toward England. In most respects he was himself the characteristic product of an elitist English education: a First at Oxford, a prestigious fellowship, a brilliant passage through the bar examinations. But his parents were Indian, and he was born in Kenya.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company plans to seek a review of a recent Federal court ruling that it failed to use "due diligence" in connection with a 1964 news release concerning a rich mineral find in Timmins, Ontario.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 13 (UPI) John Lotz, a pro from Hayward, Calif., shot an eightunder-par 64 in the second round of the $100,000 Tucson open today and took a onestroke lead at the halfway mark.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 13 The European Common Market and Israel reached agreement today on a five-year preferential trade treaty that pledges substantial tariff reductions on exchanges of industrial and farm products.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Feb. 13 (AP) Chuck Millican of Plymouth, Mass., took the lead today in the first world championship sunfish regatta by winning the opening sixmile race and finishing fourth in the second.
STRASBOURG, France, Feb. 13 The science of ecology the study of the natural environment received encouragement in Europe yesterday.
With lights and off-duty signs blazing, a mile-long procession of 300 cabs rolled from Times Square to a Brooklyn funeral home yesterday in tribute to a cab driver slain in a holdup.
Mrs. Dena Eckstein Cadden Postley of 69 Dogwood Lane, Stamford, Conn., widow of Walter Postley, a typographer, died here yesterday. She was 82 years old.

ENGLISH lusterware is attracting a new genera tion of collectors who appreciate the qualities of l9thcentury pottery. When it was first popular in the 1920's, common English luster was considered an 18th-century product. It was admired as rural ware and used with country furniture.

A MOTHER image doesn't necessarily mean Mrs. Whistler or Sophie Portnoy. She can be Joanne Tiefer, 22 years old, who has long dark hair, wears a size five in a mini or a maxi and who answers when 11-month-old Melissa calls, "Mama."

DETROIT, Feb. 13 Frank Angelo, managing editor of The Detroit Free Press, who is president of Sigma Delta Chi, said tonight that the criticism of the national journalism society was "unwarranted" because the organization "has been fighting for freedom of information for several decades."

TWO new novels with authentic Seventh Avenue backgrounds will soon have the fashion industry in a state of gossipy ferment. By coincidence, both have heroes named Phil who wrestle with the problem, to be or not to be a homosexual.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13 More than 350 delegates of the Sports Car Club of America, representing a nationwide membership of 18,500, opened the club's 26th annual convention today with attention divided between motor sports and club politics.
KEY BISCAYNE Fla., Feb. 13 The weekend White House shrugged off today reports of the Carswell land sale.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 (UPI) Federal officials, who predicted "several dozen" more arrests when they began gambling raids Jan. 1 are instead dropping charges against some men previously arrested.
OAKLAND, Feb. 13 The Rangers tied their own league record by scoring for the 117th consecutive game tonight, but they didn't feel like celebrating.

ROME, Feb. 13 (Reuters) Two young Italians sentenced this week to a year in a labor camp for a protest demonstration in a Moscow department store will be released, diplomatic sources said here tonight.

THOIBINH, South Vietnam, Feb. 9 At the end of a wobbly board out over the canal bank, a wrinkled woman squatted and washed her family's breakfast dishes in the brown water as sampans loaded with baskets of green vegetables, rice and people in conical straw hats passed by.

MIAMI, Feb. 13 (UPI) Sandra Haynie, who bounced back from a severe knee injury and got rid of her crutches only a few weeks ago, fired a fourunder-par 68 today to grab the first-round lead in the $40,000 Burdine's women's invitation golf tournament.

Mayor Lindsay agreed yesterday to cut back funds for a major new office to be headed by Deputy Mayor-designate Robert M. Morgenthau, and the Board of Estimate then approved the figure by a vote of 18 to 4.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Industrial production declined in January for the sixth consecutive month, further confirming the slowdown in the economy, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Plans for a new film unit on its 55th Street premises have been announced by the City Center of Music and Drama. The project, expected to take shape in late fall as City Center Cinema, will transform a large basement hall directly beneath the Center auditorium into one or several movie theaters next to a new film museum.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 Israel reported today that her antiaircraft fire brought down an Egyptian fighter-bomber in the Suez Canal sector. The downed craft was described by an army spokesman as a Sukhoi-7, a Soviet-built jet that has proved particularly suitable for the low-flying hit-and-run missions that the Egyptians appear to have adopted.
International air cargo losses, of which 80 per cent were attributed to theft, have almost tripled during the last two years, according to the American Institute of Marine Underwriters.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13 Princeton combined a tight defense with a methodical offense tonight to crush Brown, 73-40, in an Ivy League game.

To the most cruel of his soprano heroines, Turandot, Puccini gave the cruelest music, but when it is superbly sung it creates one of the most exciting vocal effects in opera. Last night at the Metropolitan, "Turandot" was given its first performance of the season, and Birgit Nilsson was on hand to sing the title role assurance that it would be superbly sung.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 (UPI) Tom Gola announced his resignation as head basketball coach at La Salle College today after completing a twoyear rebuilding program.
ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 13 The American tour ing team wound up its Australian visit by winning its final match here tonight.
CAPETOWN, Feb. 13 (AP) South Africa has been selling two-thirds of her newly mined gold abroad on the free market in recent months. Finance Minister Nicolaas Diederiche told the Parliament today.
The Federal Reserve System held close to its policy of firm monetary restraint during the last two weeks, banking figures published yesterday showed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 13 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the withdrawal of American troops from Vietnam would continue despite the stalemate in the Paris negotiations and the persistence of a substantial enemy threat on the battlefield.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Feb. 13 (UPI) Ingrid Lafforgue of France withstood a strong finishing run by Barbara Cochran of Richmond, Vt., and captured the women's slalom title at the world Alpine ski championships today.
SANDERSVILLE, Ga., Feb. 10 A wisp of gray in his short black goatee is the only outward sign that Richard Turner has lived with the threat of death.

CAIRO, Feb. 13 Hundreds of thousands of Egyptians cheered President Gamal Abdel Nasser wildly in the streets of Cairo today and cried for revenge against Israel for the air attack on an industrial plant that killed scores of civilian workers yesterday.
A WORLDWIDE shortage of herring has resulted in some shortages of processed herring products at the retail level and a 10 to 20 per cent increase in prices during the past six months.

The chairman and the former chairman of the state's Joint Legislative Committee on Higher Education said yesterday that Vice President Agnew had mistakenly equated "open admissions" with ethnic quotas in his criticism Thursday night of college and university admissions practices.

TOKYO, Feb. 13 It will be possible to mix an inexpensive martini in Japan starting tomorrow. The Government decided today to remove quantitative restrictions from nine categories of imports including vermouth.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 (AP) The Cincinnati Royals broke loose with torrid thirdperiod shooting, and defeated the San Francisco Warriors, 128-110, tonight.
A 24-year-old Brooklyn man was charged with arson last night in connection with a fire at the Mary Queen of Heaven Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn Friday evening.

John R. Hardin, retired senior partner in the Newark law firm of Pitney Hardin Kipp, died yesterday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at Timberstone, Old Gladstone Road, Chester, N.J.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 13 Secretary General Thant today ordered Lieut. Gen. Odd Bull, commander of the United Nations observation team in the Middle East, to return to New York this weekend for urgent consultation. The order followed the Israeli bombing attack that killed at least 70 civilians in a Cairo suburb yesterday.
AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 13 Only 300 to 500 Pakistani soldiers, assigned to an antiaircraft detail, are stationed in Jordan, according to highly placed Jordanian sources and Western diplomats.
ROCKVILLE, Md., Feb. 12 Miss Marian Elaine Glick's engagement to Andrew David Zeitlin has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Glick of Rockville.

DRESDEN, East Germany, Feb. 13 "That terrible night" just 25 years ago, when Dresden was devastated in one of the most controversial chapters of World War II, still sears the memories of those who survive.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 12 Mr. and Mrs. John Hamilton Howard have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rowan Belknap Howard, to Jeffrey Clement Morse, son of Dr. and Mrs. Willard Jackson Morse of East Braintree, Vt. The wedding is planned for May.
Lawrence Meyer Fletcher, a Broadway, movie and television actor, died Wednesday in Bridgeport Hospital, Bridgeport, Conn. He was 70 years old and lived at 31 Smedley Road, Fairfield, Conn.

LONDON, Feb. 13 Davison, Newman Co., tea merchants of Creechurch Lane, are praparing packets of Ceylon, India and Darjeeling for export to the United States in the expectation of better acceptance than was received in Boston in 1773.
"A total of 228,175 arrests were recorded here during 1969, an increase of 21.6 per cent over the 187,613 arrests in 1968, the Police Department reported yesterday.
PRAGUE, Feb. 13 While the Communist party has been talking about discipline, the people have been interested in manners.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (UPI) Terry Dischinger, Jimmy Walker and Dave Bing combined for 73 points tonight in leading the Detroit Pistons to a 132-120 victory over the Phoenix Suns in a National Basketball Association game.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 13 Outscored this morning by Middlebury in an action-filled slalom event, Dartmouth stormed back in cross-country this afternoon to gain the team lead as the Big Green's 60th annual Winter Carnival got under way.

The Metropolitan Opera will introduce a new production of Bellini's "Norma" on March 3, during the 10th week of its season, in a performance sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild for the benefit of the company's production fund. Joan Sutherland will sing the title role, and Marilyn Horne will make her Metropolitan debut in the part of Adalgisa.

GLEN ROCK, N.J., Feb. 13 The engagement of Miss Stephanie Marie Moore, a junior at Syracuse University, to Charles Thorndike Ladd, a doctoral candidate at Syracuse, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William A. Moore, parents of the prospective bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Blaney Ladd of North Scituate, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Judge Carswell's nomination will be considered again, in a routine manner, by the American Bar Association committee that last month declared him qualified to sit on the high court.

MANILA, Feb. 13--The Opposition Liberal party has demanded that President Ferdinand E. Marcos explain to the public exactly what he agreed to during his meeting Wednesday evening with militant labor and student leaders.

NEWARK, Feb. 13 Hours before he died in an automobile crash early Tuesday morning, a man under indictment in the Federal investigation of organized crime in New Jersey had submitted to an extensive interview by United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 13 This city filed suit in Superior Court here today in an attempt to force the state to pay for "the support and maintenance of a thorough and efficient system of public schools."
Paul Siebel, a folk singer with a country and Western bias, is playing through tomorrow at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

NEWARK, Feb. 13 Twentythree persons were arrested here today during a march and demonstration in downtown Newark and outside of City Hall in support of the twoweek-old strike by the Newark Teachers Union.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 Martin McGrady ran down Lee Evans in the stretch and won a thrilling race to the finish tonight en route to an indoor record in the 600-yard run at the 11th annual Los Angeles Times indoor games.

Justice Daniel E. Fitzpatrick of the State Supreme Court, and Mrs. Fitzpatrick of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann Fitzpatrick, to Joseph John Asselta of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Asselta of Garden City, L.I. The wedding will be in June.
GENEVA, Feb. 13 World Jewish leaders and officials of the World Council of Churches announced today plans to hold, for the first time, consultations on a regular basis.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 13 The continuing increase in foreign imports was criticized as dangerous to the United States economy and unfair to this nation's workers by a major labor group meeting here today.

ROME, Feb. 13 (Reuters) The Premier-designate, Mariano Rumor, began efforts today to form Italy's 31st government in 25 years against a background symptomatic of his country's woes 90,000 public transportation workers staged a crippling one-day strike.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) The Government has refused to allow a small church in New Mexico to use a forbidden drug on grounds that it might open the door to establishment of drug-oriented religious sects.
Tom Seaver's salary for pitching for the New York Mets in 1970 will be $80,000, more than double the amount he received while winning 25 games and leading the Mets to their pennant in 1969.
Profit taking hit the pits at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Grain and soybean futures prices, with the exception of soybean oil, dropped after days of upward movement.

Merck Co. posted the highest sales and earnings in its history in all 1969 and in the fourth quarter with profits for the year exceeding $100-million for the first time, Henry R. Gadsden, president, reported yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I. Feb. 13 The majority of horseplayers are a superstitious lot. Most gamblers who follow the horses will not walk beneath a ladder, permit a black cat to cross their paths and they take special pains not to shatter a mirror.

My colleagues eye me with increasing contempt, and my family views me with growing suspicion. How much self-respect can I salvage if the Justice Department continues to ignore me and fails to subpoena my files and my notebooks?

David Oistrakh, the Soviet violinist, has covered quite a bit of musical ground in the various concert appearances he has made here within the past few weeks, and he came up with two works that qualify as novelties for inclusion in the recital he gave at Philharmonic Hall last night.

Two suspected bank robbers and an alleged truck hijacker who escaped with six other prisoners from the Federal House of Detention here on Feb. 6 were captured early yesterday in Brooklyn by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

A STARTLING expanse of sky not just a patch work affair filling in the gaps between skyscraper tops viewed at the risk of a crick in the neck is one of the attractions that is drawing brownstone buyers to Carroll Gardens in South Brooklyn. Many of the area's four- and five-story early Victorian brownstones are set back behind 25-foot-deep front yards, giving the sky room to make its presence felt.
ROCHESTER, Feb. 13 (AP) Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the nuclear physicist, has resigned from the University of Rochester Faculty Senate in a dispute with the administration, it was learned today.
The New York Stock Exchange asked the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to approve a substantial increase in the commission rates paid by small investors to buy and sell stock.
With per capita cigarette consumption at the lowest point in a decade, the battle against cigarette smoking seems to be gaining momentum and taking off in a new direction.
TRENTON, Feb. 13 Dr. Robert Heussler resigned as president of Trenton State College today as striking students demonstrated outside his office.

ATLANTA, Feb. 13 (AP) The Hong Kong flu is back. National health officials say its occurrence has been reported in 45 states, but they predict that it will not be so severe as last year's epidemic that killed thousands.
Newspaper unions here are stressing demands for sizable wade increases in negotiations that are currently under way with the city's four major, general-interest newspapers.

Some "off-field activities" in 1967 of Denny McLain, the American League's outstanding pitcher for the last two seasons, are under investigation by the office of the commissioner of baseball, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.
Investor enthusiasm for new stock issues remained at a low ebb this week as 10 companies, accocding to one compilation, offered shares to the public for the first time.

The Treasury Department, in an experiment designed to improve its cash management, announced plans yesterday to sell $1.75-billion of bills that will mature in an unusually short time. In addition, the Treasury disclosed that it would raise additional money by increasing the size of its regular weekly and monthly sales of bills.

After more than 10 years of planning, changes and heated controversy, the Board of Estimate yesterday unanimously voted final approval of the Cooper Square Development Plan to revitalize six large parcels near the Bowery south of Cooper Square.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The long-term success of the pacification program may be in doubt, the latest reports from South Vietnam indicate, because of an inability to destroy the underground Vietcong "shadow government" and of a resurgence of terrorism against village officials.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13 (UPI) A high West German official conferred with the Soviet Premier, Aleksei N. Kosygin, for an hour and a half today and indicated after the meeting that the two countries were ready to negotiate a treaty to renounce the use of force.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 13 (AP) Georgia Tech took advantage of a cold spell by fifthranked North Carolina State tonight and handed the Wolfpack an 89-77 basketball defeat.

KEARNY, N.J., Feb. 13 (AP) Two boys were shot, one fatally, in Arlington Cemetery here today during what Deputy Police Chief Henry Bloomer said was an apparent attempt by them to take the car of an off-duty Jersey City policeman.
BONN, Feb. 13 A senior United States diplomat, J. Robert Schaetzel, has accused members of the Common Market of ignoring vital American economic interests.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 13 Mayor and Mrs. Matthew G. Carter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bettye Frances Carter, to Robert Turner Freeman 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Freeman Jr. of Washington.
Among the unknown factors in Monday night's heavyweight title showdown is how Jimmy Ellis's nose will react.
American Telephone turned in a star performance yesterday as the stock market drifted down a bit in the absence of any teeth-rattling news.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 13 (Reuters) Two more American helicopters have been shot down in Vietnam, injuring seven Americans and 16 South Vietnamese, a United States spokesman said today.

THE collage paintings of Romare Bearden, with their fragmented images of Negro life locked into an elegant cubist design, are fairly well known on the New York art scene. The sculptures of Barbara Chase Riboud, including her four abstract "Monuments to Malcolm X," are new to New York.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Saturday, Feb. 14 (Reuters) Prof. Christiaan N. Barnard, South Africa's heart transplant pioneer, married 19-year-old Barbara Zoellner, a Johannesburg socialite, early today.
Mina Lewiton, an author and the wife of Howard Simon, died Wednesday in her home at Lilac Hill, Stanfordville, N.Y. She was 65 years old.

The London Stock Exchange closed easier in quiet trading yesterday. A mood of caution prevailed as traders awaited the release on Monday of Britain's January trade figures. The possibility of a strike at British Ford, coupled with the decline in Thursday's New York markets, was also considered a factor.

A 10-member citizens committee to mobilize public support for legal off-track betting was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay, Controller Abraham D. Beame and City Council President Sanford D. Garelik.

"Steven Boyd," a Negro who with his wife runs the "Chicken Soul restaurant at 1325 Nevins Street in Brooklyn," met face to face yesterday with two young white business school students who expressed an interest in helping him make a "go of it."

A group of about 70 black journalists announced yesterday that they would resist any attempt by the Government to force them to appear before any investigation or law enforcement agency with unpublished or unbroadcast material they had gathered.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 13 Al Fatah, the major Palestinian guerrilla group, said tonight over the Cairo radio that the commando movement had emerged victorious in its confrontation with the Jordanian Government.

The Nixon Administration is seeking to continue the long movement toward a freer trade policy that has been going on in this country since President Roosevelt's Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act of 1934. The last major accomplishment in this direction was the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, which led to the Kennedy Round of tariff cuts.
WHEN he is asked about himself, the burly Mayor of Jersey City is fond of quoting the motto of the Fighting 69th Regiment: "Gentle when stroked, fierce when provoked."

WOULD a broker churn the stocks of a little old lady? Never. Especially not those of a housekeeper who came to this country from England, earned $125 a month most of her life and was fortunate enough late in life to marry her employer and inherit half a million dollars as his widow.
The police said yesterday that they had broken up a teenaged gang of self-styled "cat burglars" that was responsible for burglarizing 100 stores in the last year in the Flushing section of Queens.

A lawyer who had offered to auction off four "Dear Ros" letters that Mrs. Aristotle Onassis wrote to Roswell Gilpatric from whom they were allegedly stolen contended yesterday that he had been "duped" by someone who wanted them made public to embarrass the principals.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 The General Motors Corporation is redesigning its car engines to operate on unleaded gasoline of lower octane ratings than those of most present fuels.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Feb. 13 Richard W. Hayes, vice president for marketing of Devro Ltd., a division of Johnson Johnson, since 1964, died today at his home here at 414 Lawrence Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 57.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The attorney for Capt. Thomas K. Willingham, the ranking Army figure to be charged with crimes in the Vietnamese village of Songmy, said today that his client was accused of killing "20 Vietnamese civilians."

Luigi Quintiliano, who retired as manager of Local 38 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, died Thursday here after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 341 West 24th Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) The tiny, single engine airplane that Col. Charles A. Lindbergh flew to Japan in 1931 will leave Washington tomorrow for a second trip to Japan.
Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell said yesterday that a large-scale seizure of heroin and cocaine on Thursday night would cause a temporary "panic" among city narcotics addicts.

Without the benefit of tugboats, the world's longest and largest passenger liner, the superliner France, eased into her West Side berth before dawn yesterday in a delicate, closely timed maneuver, while most of her 1,152 passengers slept.

Traders on the American Stock Exchange tried hard yesterday, but they did not quite achieve an advance. Declines outnumbered advances by a narrow margin in quiet trading.

"Old Master Drawings From Chatsworth" is at the Morgan Library, at the corner of 36th Street and Madison Avenue, and "Leonard Baskin: The Graphic Work, 1950-1970" is at the FAR Gallery, 746 Madison Avenue at 64th Street.

MADRAS, Ore., Feb. 12 Mr. and Mrs. J.P. McBride have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ann McBride, to Michael L. Lehrman of Washington, president of Aircraft, Holdings, Inc. He is the son of Charles Lehrman of New York and the late Mrs. Edithe G. Lehrman.
BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 13 A reserve policeman was seriously injured early today when two bombs exploded in the Berkeley police parking lot.

MAYAGUEZ, P.R.-- Newly widened and improved roads have made a little-known mountain peak here in western Puerto Rico easily accessible to tourists and natives alike. From there on a clear day, one has spectacular views of three sides of the Puerto Rican coast.

GOLD SPRING, N.Y.--It is roughly four miles along the Appalachian Trail from the sturdy overnight log shelter at Indian Lake to the windy summit of Candlewood Hill. It took us more than four.

Witold Gombrowicz (1904-1969), the Polish novelist and playwright, was that melancholy phenomenon in literature, the minor writer on to a major vision. Gombrowicz conceived of an "interhuman sphere," which he also called "Form," that represented the collective shape he saw mankind assuming. "Being united," he wrote, "people impose on one another such or such a mode of being, talking, acting. . . . Every person deforms other persons while being simultaneously deformed by them."

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 15 Some of the 39 passengers of a hijacked South Korean airliner who were returned from North Korea yesterday after 65 days of captivity said today that most of the 12 passengers and crew members remaining in the North were being held there against their will. The retirement of Chet Huntley from the National Broadcasting Company's evening newscast was formally announced last night by his partner, David Brinkley.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 16 (AP) Roy Emerson of Australia and Clark Graebner of New York advanced with four other seeded players in the $50,000 national indoor open tennis championships today.

Indeed, at the end of "Rosshalde," the artist-protagonist...
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 16--Nathan M. Pusey, the president of Harvard University, announced today that he would retire next year, two years earlier than planned.

Jarring of Sweden, his special representative, will meet in Geneva Wednesday to assess their "roles in seeking to cope" with the "increasingly serious deterioration" of the Middle East situation, a United Nations spokesman today said.

A study on how best to promote the arts in Harlem has been authorized by the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration, according to August Heckscher, the administrator.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 16 (AP) Dan Issel scored 40 points tonight and led Kentucky to a 116-86 victory over Georgia that moved the Wildcats closer to the Southeastern Conference basketball championship.

MIAMI, Feb. 16 (UPI) John A. Morris's Missile Belle, the even-money favorite of 18,488 fans, galloped to an easy victory at Hialeah today in the first running of the $31,300 Indian Creek Stakes of 1-1/16 miles on grass.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 16 (AP) After nearly 50 years, Georgia has finally ratified the 19th Amendment to the United States Constitution, which gives women the right to vote.

ROME, Feb. 16 A Rome appeals court today granted a left-wing editor, Francesco Tolin, provisional liberty pending his appeal of his conviction on charges that he had used his weekly newspaper to incite striking workers to crime.

ONE way to attract attention is to puzzle people. Virtually everyone going by the shop at 694 Madison Avenue (62d Street) stops to look at the clothes and accessories in the window, then does a double take at the women having their hair done further back in the shop.

"Anne of the Thousand Days," "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid," "Midnight Cowboy," "Hello, Dolly!" and the French made "Z" were nominated yesterday for an Oscar as best picture of 1969.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) The United States Tax Court has ruled that former Illinois Gov. William G. Stratton failed to report $28,458 in taxable income for 1958.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 A special legislative commission today released the results of its seven-month study on the causes of campus protests with praise for "the sincerity and honesty" of most student activists and recommendations for educators, politicians and the students themselves.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 Mrs. Gwladys Hopkins Marvel, widow of Josiah Marvel, former Ambassador to Denmark, was married today to Dr. Frank Abercrombie Elliott. The bridegroom, a native of South Africa, is director of the neurological department at the Pennsylvania Hospital and professor of neurology at the University of Pennsylvania. The ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church here was performed by the Rev. Dr. Ernest A. Harding, the rector.

AUGUSTA, Ga. Feb. 16 (AP) Mrs. Diane Kennedy Pike, widow of the Right Rev. James A. Pike, resigned Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of California, says that she had had "messages" from her dead husband.

The Falstaff Brewing Corporation, St. Louis, will be moving its Falstaff beer out of the Chicago office of Foote, Cone Belding on May 31. The brand was backed by almost $8-million in measured media last year.
HERE'S a question: What kind of company can pay out more in dividends than it earns but neither flirt with bankruptcy nor alarm its shareholders?

OSAKA, Japan, Feb. 12 With characteristic energy, the Japanese are running well ahead of schedule on preparations for Expo '70 complete with characteristic traffic jams, crowds and other minor frustrations.

Monroe Mitchel, administrator of the A. Holly Patterson Home for the Aged and Infirm in Uniondale, L.I., has been selected as "Young Hospital Administrator of the Year" by the American College of Hospital Administrators.
The flow of rock toward the edges of the Pacific Ocean, which has become evident in recent years, has not been a uniform process but has varied both in speed and direction.

The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company and its subsidlaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1969. The annual report put operating revenues at $247,291,996 against $225,042,556 a year earlier.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 Two shows brought down the house at the aged Arena tonight, both put on by Philadelphians. Joe Frazier, the new undisputed heavyweight champion, scored first, but Cassius Clay, his predecessor, may have racked up as many points shortly afterward.

The pretrial hearing of motions brought by 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places was halted for a half hour yesterday as the defendants refused to leave their cells to return to the courtroom after the lunch recess.
Delta Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that it had asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to let it acquire Northeast Airlines, Inc., or the carrier's route from Miami to Los Angeles.

Trading in nickel futures opened yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange with two contracts of 2,000 pounds of electrolytic cathodes each being traded at $2.50 a pound for the June month. During the session the December, 1970, contract was traded at $2.35 a pound and that of April, 1970, for $2.40 a pound. There were 45 trades in all.
Eastman Dillon, Union Secutities Co., a leading investment banking and brokerage firm, announced yesterday that Willard S. Boothby had been named chief executive partner.

Dr. Morrison S. Levbarg, a pediatrician, and Mrs. Levbarg of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Diane Rebecca Levbarg, to John Hugh Robert Brook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leopold Brook of London. A July 1 wedding at the Plaza is planned.
ALBANY, Feb. 16 (UPI) Governor Rockefeller said today he would sign a bill legalizing pari-mutuel betting on quarterhorse racing if the Legislature acts favorably on it.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 16 Senator Edmund S. Muskie announced here today that he would seek re-election this year to a third term in the United States Senate, paving the way for a possible Presidential bid in 1972.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Treasury bill rates declined dramatically at today's auction to the lowest levels since last June, the Government reported late this afternoon.
LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Feb. 16 (UPI) Two United States soldiers went on trial today before separate courtsmartial on charges of killing 2 South Vietnamese.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 16 Baseball training, that distinctive American rite of spring enjoyed by the privileged few and absorbed vicariously by the envious many, begins officially for the New York Yankees tomorrow. But the Yankees who often don't get their names in the papers have been at work for some time already.

The Netherlands Chamber Choir sang a concert of sacred and secular music at Hunter College Playhouse last night, and for the most part the group showed the same reverential attitude toward both kinds of music.
