Three outlets of the National Educational Television network last night canceled a controversial program on United Stated military interventions, contending that it presented an oversimplified, misleading and unbalanced view.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 16 The United States touring team, including Robert Jordan, Arthur Robinson, Bill Root, Mrs. Dorothy Hayden and this writer, won one and lost one in two short matches here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Federal Aviation Administration officials and a group of dissident air traffic controllers spent several hours with a Federal mediator today in an effort to avoid a nationwide air traffic slowdown.

Steve Hamilton, the left-handed relief pitcher who is the senior member of the team at the age of 33, signed yesterday for his eighth season with the New York Yankees. Contract terms were not disclosed.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 Israel's Parliament was presented with a new budget today, calling for higher taxes, a slowdown in development projects and heavier expenditures for the country's military machine than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco urged today a Congressional investigation of the growing practice by banks in demanding a cut of the profits before making business loans.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 The Public Service Commission has decided to "consider" granting the New York Telephone Company an interim rate increase of 10.4 per cent, pending final determination of how much more money the utility needs to make a "reasonable" return on its investment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 The United States balance of international payments showed a record deficit in 1969 by one method of measurement and a record surplus by the other, the Commerce Department reported today. Both measures were distorted by special factors last year, particularly by the impact of the extremely restrive monetary policy in the United States.

GENEVA, Feb. 16 Gerard C. Smith, Director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said today that he hoped for early progress at the disarmament conference here on a ban on germ warfare.

CAIRO, Feb. 16 The gunfire, bomb blasts, passions and ferocity of war seemed far away today as the four million people of Cairo feasted, danced and sang under a warm sun. They gathered in parks or any other green area for family picnics, sailed along the Nile in highmasted feluccas and, in general, enjoyed themselves.

Robert G. Whytock, a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Sunday after a heart attack in his home at 97 Lortel Avenue, Castleton Corners, S.I. He was 60 years old.

Formal acknowledgment by representatives of industry that the consumer movement is here to stay and may be pinching some corporate pocketbooks was offered here yesterday as more than 125 top executives began a three-day meeting on "consumerism."

Draft. President Nixon appointed Col. Dee Ingold, 65, a native of Milwaukee, to serve as interim director of Selective Service. A White House spokesman said a new director would be named "in the near future" to replace Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, who left office today.

Morris B. Abram, president of Brandeis University, has decided to seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.

Robert A. Klath, F. Kent Mitchel, David K. Evans and James H. Whitcomb have been elected corporate vice presidents of the General Foods Corporation. Mr. Klath has also been promoted to controller of the corporation and remains director of corporate planning.

Dr. Peyton Rous, who 60 years ago demonstrated for the first time that animal cancer can be caused by a virus, died of cancer early yesterday at Memorial Hospital in New York. He was 90 years old.

TOKYO, Feb. 16 Communist China is sharply stepping up its orders of Japanese steel in 1970, industry sources here said today. It was noted that representatives of a number of Japanese steel companies were now in China negotiating additional sales to the Peking Government.

Waldie of California fully expects to be clobbered Wednesday morning when the House Democrats caucus and vote on his motion of no-confidence in Speaker John McCormack. To him this is just another indication of how far out of touch the House of Representatives is with the people it's supposed to represent.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Feb. 16--Charges under the Suppression of Communism Act against 22 black Africans were dropped today, but they were immediately rearrested under the Terrorism Act. Its provisions allow indefinite detention without trial.
UNTIL a few years ago, the first job for many a bright, ambitious law graduate was clear; a Wall Street firm, or clerkship to a judge, or perhaps a time as an assistant district attorney.
DENVER, Feb. 16 The Colorado Health Department is expanding its search for dangerous radiation levels in private homes, businesses and public buildings in the western part of the state.
Two major corporations with powerful marketing capability took steps yesterday to make new diversified stock or real estate investments available to investors, both large and small.

EL PASO, Tex., Feb. 16 (AP) The head of the American Society of Newspaper Editors told Texas publishers today that "an ugly mood" against news media was sweeping the country. He predicted it would get worse.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) President Nixon set up today what he called "an informal Cabinet-level working group" to see what the Federal Government could do to help school districts desegregate and still preserve the public education system.

NEWTON, Mass., Feb. 16 (AP) Pat McMahon, a Lowell schoolteacher from Ireland, set a course record today in winning Silver Lake Dodge's fourth annual Washington's Birthday road race from Hopkinton to Newton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Col. Dee Ingold, a long-time aide to Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, the draft director, was named acting director today. He said he would attempt no policy changes during what he expects to be a brief term in office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia upheld today the Federal Communications Commission's decision to renew the Mormon Church's broadcast licenses in Salt Lake City, despite charges of undue concentration of media control.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 16 Secretary General Thant, a Buddhist, sought the help of governments today in developing the birthplace of Buddha, in the foothills of the Himalayas, as a major religious shrine.

MOSCOW, Feb. 16 The Soviet Union asserted tonight that it would supply the Arab countries with "the necessary support" to bolster their defenses against what it termed Israel's criminal policy of aggression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Television coverage of disruptive college students is a major factor in keeping states from granting the vote to 18-yearolds, according to witnesses who appeared today before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee considering a constitutional amendment to lower the voting age nationally.
SCARSDALE, N.Y.--The other night, shortly before midnight, a nude young lady ran out of one of the brick and shingle houses on Theresa Lane, a quiet, crescent-shaped hill in the Greenburgh area here.
MADRID, Feb. 16 Spain has turned over to Morocco a prominent Moroccan Socialist who is under sentence of death in his own country.

Miss Lynne Stetson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Clark Stetson of Dallas, became the bride of Capt. David Vickers Forrest, U. S. A. F., a psychiatrist and the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melbourne A. Forrest of East Hills, N. Y., yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, (The Little Church Around the Corner.

Mortimer Howard, a vaudeville pianist and the "Uncle Morty" of "The Horn Hardart Children's Hour" on radio and television, died at Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn on Sunday after suffering a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived at 1395 East 19th Street in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Transportation Secretary John A Volpe, whose highway plans around the country have been opposed by people living in the path of proposed construction, said today that no new projects would be approved unless "adequate replacement housing" was provided first.
Zaven Demirdjian raised his arms above his head in a Job-like gesture. "As God is my judge," he declared in a quivering voice, "I never cursed! Never!"

The worst thing about the extremely severe contempt sentences imposed upon the Chicago Seven and their attorneys is that they serve just the purpose the defendants had in mind throughout of bringing into question the impartiality of the American judicial system.

Middle East experts for the major oil companies are convinced that the political situation in the Arab world is more critical than at any time since the 1967 war, but they are not panicking about the prospects for their industry in the area.

The drive toward lower interest rates remained intact yesterday, both in the corporate bond market where a new Bell System issue was given a lower-than-expected yield and in the money market where the Federal Reserve injected a substantial amount of credit.
Fola La Follette, a suffrage leader, actress and daughter of the late Senator Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin, died of pneumonia yesterday at a hospital in Arlington, Va. She was 87 years old.
Two Democrats, Emanuel R. Gold and Alan Hochberg, were elected to the State Assembly yesterday in special elections to fill vacant seats from heavily Democratic areas of Queens and the Bronx.
Jerry West of the Los Angeles Lakers led the National Basketball Association's scorers by a wide margin in the official statistics issued yesterday for games played through Sunday.
If all cello recitals could be as pleasing to look at and listen to as the one given by Zara Nelsova at Alice Tully Hall last night, the cello world would be the better for it.

Baker Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Donald A. McMahon as president, chief operating officer and a director. Mr. McMahon, who will be 39 years old this week, joined Baker from Litton Industries, where he was a vice president and president of the Monroe division. Baker is in the protection and security systems field.

AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 17--Evidence of strong market demand by all except one major purchaser led the Texas Railroad Commission today to continue Texas oil production for March at the 68 per cent which prevails in February.

Theodore C. Sorensen, former aide to Presidenet John F. Kennedy and to his brother, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, formally announced yesterday that he was running for the United States Senate from New York.

Smith of Lake Forest, Ill., board president of the Adlai Stevenson Institute for International Affairs in Chicago, plans to be married here June 13 to Stephan Miller Petty.

Officials from 40 American steel companies told the Commerce Department in Washington yesterday that the United States should restrict exports of iron and steel scrap because a shortage in this country has been driving prices to the highest levels in about 13 years.

Total school desegregation came with "grace and style" to a predominantly white school district in South Carolina yesterday, but whites abandoned classooms in two heavily black counties in Mississippi.

Officers of some of the countrrys leading organizations, meeting to extol the virtues of public service and patriotism, discovered yesterday that many of them shared a fear that their influence over American youth might be in decline.
A 78-year-old widow was found stabbed to death yesterday in Riverside Park, her handbag missing and the poodles that she walked daily in the park lingering nearby.
A new master plan for Columbia University's academic and housing needs will be officially submitted to the university's trustees within the next few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI)--Dr. James L. Goddard, former head of the Food and Drug Administration, proposed today that the Government tax drugs subject to abuse and use the proceeds to pay for treatment of addicts and a huge education program.

For Gail Fitzgerald, running has provided equal doses of frustration and success. Now she seems on the verge of such great success that she could become the world's fastest woman at 400 meters and 440 yards.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17--Swifter moves to develop economic ties with Communist China were stressed here today as part of a greatly changed role American business must play in the world trade of the nineteenseventies.

Pennsylvania's nine-station public television network will shut down in 10 days unless a $1.7-million appropriation, tied up for eight months in the State Senate, is approved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--The American Hospital Association's new president, Mark Berke, forecast today that the United States would have a national health insurance system in three to six years.

Richard L. Freundlich, 32 years old, has been elected president of Ship 'n Shore, Inc., the country's largest women's shirt producer, succeeding William Netzky, who remains a director. Mr. Freundlich was previously marketing and administrative director.

Arthur Ashe, the leading money-winner among independent professionals on the United States indoor tennis circuit, increased his earnings to $6,400 with victories in the singles and doubles finals at the Fidelity Bankers invitation tournament at Richmond last weekend.

The election of Richard D. DeLauer as executive vice president of TRW, Inc., Cleveland-based diversified company, was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors in Los Angeles. He will continue as vice president and general manager of TRW's Systems Group.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 17--The rich young New York Mets converged on their spring training headquarters today to open their title defense and to look for answers to the intriguing question: What can they do for an encore?
A very large enterprise reports a record operating deficit for 1969. By another set of figures, however, it is able to show a modest surplus of receipts over expenditures.

OTTAWA, Feb. 17 (AP)-- Judge Edward Carter reserved judgment today on an assault charge against Wayne Maki of the St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League. The judge said in Provincial Court he would make his decision within 10 days.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Feb. 17--To the New York Yankees, who begin spring training tomorrow with more than 30 pitchers and catchers in uniform, the New York Mets represent a model, an inspiration and a challenge.

TOKYO, Feb. 17 (AP)-- Japan's gold and foreigncurrency reserves reached a record of $3.61-billion at the end of January, the Finance Ministry said today.

The Amerada Hess Corporation reported yesterday a decline in earnings in 1969 to $84,655,776, or $2.38 a share from the year-earlier $90,588,213, or $2.40 a share. Fourthquarter earnings were also lower.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (Reuters) --The special West German envoy, Egon Bahr, said today, after his fifth meeting with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, that the meeting had been agreeable and that he would return to Moscow next week for more talks on a possible nonaggression pact.

NEWARK, Feb. 17 (UPI)--A lawyer for Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio filed motions in Federal Court yesterday asking for the dismissal of extortion and tax-evasion charges against him.

TOKYO, Feb. 17--Premier Eisaku Sato made clear today that his Government contemplated no major changes in relations with Communist China in the near future.

KATONAH, N.Y., Feb. 17 --Miss Brooke Somerville Babcock, whose grandfather, H. Howard Babcock of New York, is board chairman of the Madison Square Boys Club, plans to be married in May to William King Prather.
Dorothy Adams, executive vice president of Clyne Maxon, Inc., advertising agency, died of a heart attack Monday in her home at 25 Sutton Place. She was 62 years old.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 17-- Some 25,000 educators and school district officials meeting here seem agreed on one thing: Their school systems do not have enough money to meet rapidly expanding needs and costs.

ALBANY, Feb. 17--The Senate, in a vote that crossed party lines, approved and sent to the Assembly today a bill requested by Governor Rockefeller that would permit the state to lend $30.7-million for transit aid, more than $24.7million of it to improve maintenance on New York City's subway system and on commuter lines in the metropolitan area.

The American Stock Exchange turned in its fourth consecutive loss yesterday as declines outpaced advances by a good margin in fairly light trading.
A motion by a defendant in a bombing-conspiracy case to suppress a confession he made when he was arrested was denied in Federal Court yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 17--Minority Leader Stanley Steingut introduced in the Assembly today a tax-reform bill that would generate an estimated total of $330-million in additional state revenues by eliminating preferential treatment of capital gains, raising the corporate franchise tax and increasing the liability of top-bracket wage earners.

Smith, Barney Co., Inc., a leading investment concern, called yesterday for a moratorium on the implementation of the new commission rates proposed by the New York Stock Exchange.

The New York Knickerbockers gave their fans a treat last night at Madison Square Garden. With balanced scoring, in which no player hit 20 points, but four got 18 or more, they romped to a 114-93 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers before a capacity crowd of 19,500, the 21st of the season here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17--Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade have approved an increase in commission rates, the commodity exchange announced today. The increase averages 34 per cent for the board's traditional grain commodities.
