Aleksandr V. Tikhomirov, the Russian translator at the United Nations against whom the United States first brought, and then dropped, spy charges, flew home to Moscow yesterday, The Associated Press reported.
GENEVA, Feb. 17--The international trading community was urged today to gird its forces for a major assault on barriers to the free flow of goods across frontiers in 1971.

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 17-- Albert Milfred Gants, candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Representative from the 26th Congressional District, and Mrs. Gants have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Valerie Gants, to Joel Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Marcus of Hewlett, L.I. The wedding will take place here July 12.

The scrapping of the city's nine superagencies and the reshuffling of existing departments into four groups, each under the direction of a deputy mayor, has been recommended in a report to the Institute of Public Administration.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 17--A number of oil slicks that had threatened resort beaches along the Gulf of Mexico yesterday were broken up by rain and high winds today.

TRENTON, Feb. 17--Frank Sinatra testified for more than an hour here tonight before a hastily summoned, extraordinary closed session of the State Commission of Investigation, which asked him what he knew about organized crime and official corruption in New Jersey.

The still officially suppressed study by the Rand Corporation of housing decay in this city makes plainer than ever the need for modifying New York's 27-year-old rent control law. Apartments that would cost more than a billion dollars to replace are being abandoned each year while vacant rental housing sinks toward zero. An over-all deficit of $225 million annually in owners' income from rent-controlled apartments is a critical element in that drift toward housing disaster.
AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 17-- State Senator Ralph W. Hall headed for Washington today to see if the Supreme Court would lift the legal bar against his candidacy for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- Senate subcommittee hearings on a Constitutional amendment to lower the voting age to 18 recessed today with the subcommittee's chairman guardedly optimistic that an amendment would be reported to the Senate in the next few months.

LONDON, Feb. 17--The author and publishers of a book that alleged that the commander of a naval escort force abandoned a World War II convoy of freighters carrying supplies to the Soviet Union were ordered by the High Court today to pay him $96,000 in damages.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968, stringently criticized even before it has become fully operative, undergoes its first Congressional review beginning tomorrow.

The Gannett Company, Inc., which publishes 34 newspapers and operates eight broadcasting stations, announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Federated Publications, Inc., of Battle Creek, Mich., publisher of seven daily newspapers, for about $52-million in stock.

The Soviet promise of "necessary help" to the reeling Arab states is at the very least a futile gesture that will escalate the arms race in the Middle East and work to the disadvantage of the Arabs. It will render more difficult progress toward the peaceful settlement that the Russians say they prefer.
The Security National Bank, which has long been a power in banking on Long Island, announced yesterday a $58-million deal that could give it a long-sought entree into the New York City market.

Mrs. Sophie Blanche Rosner, retired high school teacher and wife of Henry J. Rosner, the city's Assistant Commissioner of Social Services, died yesterday at Beth Abraham Home in the Bronx after a long illness. She was 62 years old and lived at 12 East 86th Street.

BONN, Feb. 17--Karl Schiller, West German Minister of the Economy, said today that the European Common Market's proposed economic and monetary union should never be allowed to become an instrument for discrimination against outsiders.
ALBANY, Feb. 17--A State Department of Health scientist, apparently involved in private, unauthorized research with a radioactive isotope, has been permanently contaminated by the material.
Silver futures dropped yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange in moderate trading.

Textile sales in the next five years will grow from the present $21-billion a year at the mill level to $30-billion, John P. Figh, the Chase Manhattan Bank's technical director for textiles, predicted yesterday.
DETROIT, Feb. 17 (AP)--The whereabouts of Denny McLain remained a mystery today with speculation continuing on the role he might be playing in a Federal investigation of gambling centered on Detroit.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 17 (AP)-- Maj. Gen. George Morris Gelston, who as head of the Maryland National Guard and as Baltimore Police Commissioner was known for his calm handling of racial disorders, died today. He was 57 years old.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 17 --The executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. strongly supported today a program for national health insurance that would provide comprehensive care for all Americans.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 17--Israel carried her bombing raids to the outskirts of Cairo again today and warned the Egyptians that there would be no let-up in the air attacks until they agreed to abide by the cease-fire of 1967.

ATHENS, Feb. 17--An Athens criminal court opened and adjourned indefinitely today the murder trial of two Arabs who attacked an Israeli airliner at Athens airport almost 14 months ago, and Israel quickly protested the postponement.

THE stylish Jimmy Ellis gave something of a boxing lesson to an overly cau- tious Joe Frazier in the first round of their fight for the undisputed heavyweight championship of the world in Madison Square Garden the night before last. But once Frazier abandoned caution and began doing what came naturally, he brought an abrupt end to the lesson. He also brought an abrupt end to Ellis, a knockout victim after 12 minutes of fighting.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 17--Miss Margaret Nancy Jensen and Donley Hotchkiss Johnson, teachers at the Forman School here, plan to be married in August.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) --The strike-bound National Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today for permission to postpone the start of Miami-London service until next June 30.

TOKYO--Kabuki training and the Don Quixote spirit-- these are the elements youthful Somegoro Ichikawa hopes to integrate on March 2, when he makes his Broadway debut in the title role of "Man of La Mancha."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Feb. 17--Until recently a man calling himself a historian of science would have had about as much success as an astrologist in getting a job teaching at a university.
GREENSBORO, N.C., Feb. 17 (UPI)--The New York Nets, paced by Walt Simon's 22 points, defeated the Carolina Cougars, 108-103, tonight after trailing most of the American Basketball Association game.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 17-- North Vietnamese troops, despite what one diplomatic source here today called "the most intensive United States bombing in the history of the Laotian war," are reported to have driven Government troops from more than 20 positions in and around the Plaine des Jarres.
The Shell Chemical Company announced yesterday it would raise prices by about 6.5 per cent on more than 50 organic chemicals sold by its industrial chemicals division.

WHEN a young playwright with his first Broadway play appends a quotation from Sophocles to it, you may feel that he is revealing a confidence fringing on the hubristic. Robert Marasco, whose "Child's Play" opened to a hero's welcome at the Royale Theater last night, may be no Sophocles but he has written a wonderfully powerful melodrama that will thrill audiences for a long time to come.

TRACU, South Vietnam, Feb. 16--"Better Killing Through Electronics," said a sign someone had pasted up in the naval operations center of the small base near the Vamcodong River, 20 miles west of Saigon.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 17--Army's basketball team had to go into overtime tonight to subdue Seton Hall, 77-69, before 3,300 fans.

PARIS--It is arguable that President Georges Pompidou has a more "American" view of the development of capitalist society and of employerworker relationships than his predecessor. On the verge of his first official trip to the United States it is interesting to elaborate this point.
Mrs. Anne Duffy, an artist and widow of Edmund Duffy, Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist for The Baltimore Sun, died Sunday in San Juan, P.R. She was 70 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)--Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that the St. Lawrence Seaway has benefited the entire nation and should be paid for on that basis.

Directors of the Gibraltar Financial Corporation of California and the Wesco Financial Corporation have authorized merger discussions between the two companies whereby Gibraltar would acquire Wesco through an exchange of stock.

GENEVA, Feb. 17--The United States called on the Geneva disarmament conference today, at the opening of its new session, to negotiate a pact banning the "use, production and possession of biological methods of warfare."
Chief Justice Warren E. Burger last night urged American justice to change its emphasis from punishing wrongdoers to helping them.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17-- A wave of violence, including the second police station bombing within five days, struck cities around San Francisco Bay last night.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 17--Mr. and Mrs. Claudius DaSilva Fingar have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Batcheller Fingar, to Peter Farnsworth Morse, the son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Marston Morse of Princeton, N.J.

THE viewer who misses tonight's special, "Annie, the Women in the Life of a Man," will be a sorry set owner. The performance by Anne Bancroft, who has been chiefly noted for her dramatic roles, is truly a tour de force of such a multiplicity of charms, humor and talent that it is almost hard to believe. Rightfully, she should be the toast of the country by tomorrow morning.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17--Najeeb E. Halaby, president of Pan American World Airways, said here today that he believed it would take 10 years to provide Chicago with the airport facilities it needs to handle supersonic and jumbo planes plus conventional traffic.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17--As a controversial operation known as Phoenix moves into its third year and to center stage today at Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings in Washington, American officals here privately continue to call it one of the most important and least successful programs in South Vietnam.
A speed-up in trial of criminal cases was promised yesterday to combat an overcrowding "crisis" in the city's prisons.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18 (AP) Bill Melchionni scored 10 of his 13 points in an overtime period tonight as the New York Nets beat the Pittsburgh Pipers, 116-110, in an American Basketball Association game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Nixon set forth today the fundamentals of a foreign policy designed to achieve a "durable peace" in the seventies. The policy commits the United States to a major role in world affairs, sharply qualified, however, by the President's judgment that the United States should carry less of the burden and its allies more.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 18 Army investigators said this afternoon that they had been unable to establish a motive for the knifing deaths yesterday of an Army doctor's wife and their two small daughters on the base at Fort Bragg.

Although not many of its members would like to admit it, the New York advertising industry can learn something from the Chicago crowd. And one thing is how to train minority-group members for professional agency jobs.

STRBSKE PLESBO, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 18 (AP) The Soviet Union collected its fourth gold medal today when a 27-year-old Moscow schoolteacher won the women's 10kilometer cross-country ski race in the Nordic world skiing championships. Forty-four women from 14 nations competed.

Dr. Alan R. Solomon, chairman of the department of art at the University of California at Irvine, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack in his home at 470 West End Avenue, where he had been confined for several months. He was 49 years old.

Old King Cotton sits on his throne, armed with a whip and fanned by female slaves. Watched by militant Southern leaders, both Napoleon and Britannia deposit their crowns at his feet. A tall figure crowned with horns sits on a shield, a symbol of the Ku Klux Klan.
CAIRO, Feb. 18 The United Arab Republic has undertaken a worldwide diplomatic campaign accusing the United States of responsibility for Israeli air attacks against civilian targets in this country.

MANILA, Thursday, Feb. 19 Rampaging youths shouting "Down with imperialists!" assaulted the United States Embassy last night with stones and flaming objects and then spread out to the well-to-do Ermita district, smashing windows, burning cars and mauling people who got in their way.

BONN, Feb. 18 Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany notified Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany today that he was prepared to meet him for talks in East Berlin any day between March 9 and March 22.
The Explorers Club dinner on Feb. 27 at the WaldorfAstoria will salute Alaska.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 18 Only two Americans were able to advance to the quarterfinals of the $50,000 national indoor open tennis championships today. They were Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and Jim Osborne of Honolulu, and they play each other tomorrow.

OLIVER MESSIAEN is a composer more talked about than played. This Frenchman is something of a legend; a mystic, a teacher who numbers among his pupils Pierre Boulez and Karlheinz Stockhausen, an avantgardist who was experimenting with post-Webern music and totally organized music as early as 1948, an eccentric, a composer who is eternally animated by a sort of pantheism that encompasses Christianity, bird calls and the universe itself.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The continuing build-up of Soviet missiles is causing grave concern within the Nixon Administration oven the prospects for halting the arms race, the President said today in his foreign-policy message to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 For a nation weary of war and other foreign burdens, in a world that seems less menacing if not yet safe, President Nixon has proclaimed a policy to protect what he deems vital at a price that he deems bearable. By thus scaling down the nation's ambitions to match its ...
President Nixon's 43,000-word "state of the world" message is a unique and useful if banal and wordy compendium of the Administration's foreign policies and procedures.

VIETNAM The President listed signs of progress; success in the pacification program, greater enemy difficulties in recruitment and supply, a drop in Vietcong control over the rural population. But he also said "Vietnamization is still a developing process, and enemy intentions on the battlefield are unclear." He said that the "key to peace" lay in whether Hanoi wished to negotiate in good faith.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Nixon announced today the choice of Edward B. Miller, a 47-year-old management lawyer from Chicago, for the post of chairman of the National Labor Relations Board.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 The East Germans tonight confirmed the receipt of Chancellor Brandt's offer of talks with Premier Stoph next month, but charged Bonn with seeking to "avoid the basic question of securing peace."
The State Urban Development Corporation, acting through a new subsidiary corporation, will undertake a countywide housing and development program in Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Arthur F. Burns, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that if the economy followed the path currently foreseen both by himself and by Administration economists, then monetary policy could be progressively loosened during the course of this year.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 The State Senate unanimously adopted a resolution today calling for a legislative inquiry into possible "dereliction of duty" by the police in allegedly failing to thwart narcotics peddlers in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
St. Bonaventure's thirdranked basketball team breezed to its 18th victory of the season last night in the 69th Regiment Armory, routing St. Francis, 87-57.
TOKYO, Feb. 18 (Reuters) Japanese shipbuilders today decided to reinforce 69 Japanese vessels that are similar in structure to the 62,147-ton ore carrier that sank off Japan Feb. 9.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 Hopes of American business for an early end of Government restrictions on direct foreign investments were dampened today by Budget Director Robert P. Mayo.

After almost 10 years as an outspoken critic of the "inadequate" housing programs that have accompanied big cities on their "road of decline," S. William Green was sworn in yesterday as administrator of the Northeastern region of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.

A formidable contributor to the effort to provide protein for the world's hungry has emerged as a result of an agreement between two large companies one American and the other Swedish to form a new corporation, the NabiscoAstra Nutrition Development Corporation, with headquarters here.
RABAT, Morocco, Feb. 18 King Hassan II of Morocco virtually confirmed today that a new plot to overthrow the Moroccan Government had been discovered recently in Madrid.

PARIS, Feb. 17 Norwegians complain that their snow is fouled by air swirling up from the English Midlands. Swedes grumble that their "acid" rain has been polluted by winds from the Ruhr Valley in West Germany. The Dutch are upset by the wastes pumped into the lower reaches of the Rhine from factories in Germany and Switzerland.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 18 (UPI) A group of Connecticut commuters to New York City want to block a fare increase scheduled to take effect on March 1. They also want cleaner cars on the old New Haven Railroad, they said in a statement issued today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The quickest way to empty a crowd from the Orange Bowl, said a pudgy, bespectacled man seated there one day last fall, would be for the public address system to announce: "Telephone call for Mr. Kissinger."

The Rangers were so intent on preventing the Flyers from jumping out to their accustomed early lead last night that they pressed too much and the Philadelphians scored on the first two shots of the game.
Every shareholder, and especially the 780,000 shareholders of Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, should find this formula a handy one to have. It's the easy way to figure the value of rights.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 18 The 17-year-old daughter of a Stamford policeman was found stabbed to death this morning in a stairwell near her family's apartment.

Samuel Frank, a member of the American Stock Exchange and its predecessor, the Curb Exchange, since 1911, died Tuesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived at 4 South Pinehurst Avenue.
If a mysterious atmosphere of evil broods over all the action in Robert Marasco's first drama, "Child's Play," it is not mysterious to the author.
IT IS one of those unexpected and oblique references you hear over din ner when a certain topic is mentioned, and in this case it was Chinese cooking.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Nixon's message on the state of the world was generally received favorably today by Senate leaders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Senate of the United States has now cravenly abandoned the policy of racial integration sixteen years after it was born in a Supreme Court decision, ninety-four years after the Civil War "Reconstruction" ended in a similar sell-out, and less than a week after President Nixon, on Lincoln's Birthday, gave the signal of surrender.

The Roman Catholic priest who was ejected from the City Council chamber two days ago for disrupting the meeting, said he would try today to present his demands at a closed executive session of the Council's Housing Committee.
Suggestions calculated to increase attendance at Aqueduct and Belmont Park are contained in the annual report of the New York State Racing Commission.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Feb. 18 Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Peterson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Andrea Elizabeth Peterson, to Hugh James Freund, son of Mrs. Mortimer Berkowitz Jr. of New York and Remsenburg, and S.,E. Freund of St. Louis.

The alleged sale of air-conditioned 1969 and 1970 Chevrolets for $150 each resulted yesterday in a total of 11 arrests in connection with an investigation of the theft of automobiles from a car-rental concern.

One of President Nixon's objectives in his "state of the world" message was to persuade Americans that he has streamlined the machinery and tidied up the processes for the making and carrying out of United States foreign policy. This accounts for his claim to have re-established and "revitalized" the National Security Council and his elaborate description of how, ideally, the N.S.C. system will function.
HONG KONG, Feb. 18 Communist China accused Japan today of developing missiles for use with nuclear warheads.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and the Nalco Chemical Company announced yesterday they were matching the price increase for antiknock compounds initiated Tuesday by the Ethyl Corporation.

The First Boston Corporation, the country's largest publicly owned investment house, announced yesterday that its earnings last year fell sharply to $4,117,765, or $2.53 a share, from 1968's $7,714,255, or $4.72 a share.
Witnesses at a pornography hearing yesterday denounced the extensive distribution of immoral movies, the public display of obscene publications and the unsolicited mailing of offensive material.

With soybean futures again attracting the bulk of the interest, trading was mixed and active in all major pits of the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as prices rose. Several hit new highs for the season.
Negotiations to avert a threatened strike at nine city museums, libraries and zoos will be held today at the office of Herbert H. Haber, City Labor Relations Director, 250 Broadway.
HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 18 (AP) Alfred Newman, a piano prodigy who became one of Hollywood's most widely known composer-conductors and the winner of eight Academy Awards, died yesterday. He was 68 years old.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) Members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today reacted with hope and a touch of skepticism to testimony that pacification was succeeding in South Vietnam.
BIRMINGHAM, England, Feb. 18 About 4,800 teachers began an indefinite strike at 460 city schools today in support of national wage demands by the National Union of Teachers.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18 Quiet, dark-haired Susan Schultz was on the edge of tears as she slipped through a group of young people and sat in front of the microphones under the bright television lights.

AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 18 In a protest against five central Massachusetts colleges, nearly 200 black students occupied four buildings at Amherst College for more than 14 hours today. They evacuated the building at 3:30 this afternoon, saying they had changed their strategy.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 18 Israel disclosed tentative plans today to improve the lot of Arab refugees dislocated and caught within her jurisdiction by the 1967 war.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 18 Mr. and Mrs. William James Barritt Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Jean Barritt, to James Dudley Clendinen, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Clendinen.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 18 (UPI) The remnants of a vast oil slick that could not be brought under control as it slid across Tampa Bay appeared trapped today, and experts began assessing the damage to fish, birds, beaches and boats.
DETROIT, Feb. 18 A new tractor aimed at poor farmers was unveiled today by the Ford Motor Company.
THE chess buff banks generally on Mikhail Tal, middle-game virtuoso, to find a sacrificial coup for a winning clincher. Two recent examples here are from the 1969 Soviet championship.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 18 Arthur T. Roth, chairman of the Franklin National Bank, resigned today as a member of the Nassau-Suffolk Regional Planning Board in the face of conflict-of-interest charges arising from land speculation in Suffolk County.
RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 18 (UPI) Racially troubled Rahway High School will remain closed until next Tuesday, to give parents, teachers and students time to work out programs to ease the tense atmosphere.
MEMPHIS, Feb. 18 (UPI) Joe Caldwell pumped in 41 points tonight to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 139-125 overtime victory over the Cincinnati Royals in national basketball association action.
Eight former college football stars have been elected to the National Football Foundation's Hall of Fame. They will be formally inducted, Dec. 8, at the awards dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 18 It was the first day of spring training today and a warm sun came out right on schedule, and the World Series was still 7 months away, but Steve Hamilton, the senior New York Yankee, already had one notable victory to his credit.
Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., the giant conglomerate, is moving into red ink for the first time since it amassed a group of diversified companies over the last several years.

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 18 (UPI) A one-man grand jury investigating alleged corruption among government officials in the handling of an urban renewal project indicted today Mayor Donald R. Cronin, a city commissioner and a businessman on charges of attempting to solicit a bribe from a construction company.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 18 The Norfolk, Conn., Curling Club rink, skipped by Mrs. Merwin Ellert, won its first two matches decisively today for a plus-15 score and a 1-point lead in the Ardsley Curling Club women's invitation bonspiel at Ardsley Country Club.

A former assistant vice president and manager of the Plainview branch of the Long Island National Bank was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of having embezzled "in excess of $1,000."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Miss Mary Patricia O'Brien, a master's degree candidate in cardiovascular nursing, and Richard J. Roth, the co-founder of the Edmund Burke School here, plan to be married in April.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Under the shadow of a March 1 deadline, a Senate Judiciary subcommittee began hearings today on voting rights legislation and immediately became entangled in arguments over states' rights and traditional Senate rights.
A group of Mexican children hospitalized at an early age with severe malnutrition has scored lower on intelligence tests in later life than did their siblings who had not suffered from the disorders.
GENEVA, Feb. 18 Secretary General Thant of the United Nations today urged the United States and the Soviet Union to declare a moratorium on the testing and deploying of stratedic nuclear weapons.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 New York has a number of symbols: There's a flower (the rose), a tree (the sugar maple), a gem (the garnet), and a motto ("Excelsior" or ever upward).

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18 The Israeli representative at the United Nations charged today that the Secretariat acting for Secretary General Thant, had suppressed an appeal by Israel on behalf of Soviet Jews. He said that Mr. Thant's action resulted directly from strong pressure from Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet representative.

Stockholders of the Greyhound Corporation approved yesterday a previously proposed plan to purchase substantially all of the common stock and 4 per cent convertible debentures of Armour Co. owned by General Host Corporation.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 18 An explosion shook a Belfast courtroom today while five Protestants were being tried on charges of conspiring to blow up a water pipeline in Northern Ireland last winter. Damage was slight and no one was injured.

GATLINBURG, Tenn., Feb. 18 Searchers today found the body of a 16-year-old Explorer Scout, Geoff Hague of Morristown, Tenn., at the base of a cliff near the Tennessee-North Carolina line in Great Smoky Mountains National Park.
Kalph Abraham has nothing against shooting a basketball. The only thing is, he usually has to grab a rebound before he can shoot.

Mrs. Carolyn Storrs Spofford, wife of Charles M. Spofford, a partner in the law firm of Davis, Polk Wardwell and vice chairman of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, died Tuesday at her home, 120 East 78th Street. Her age was 62.
ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP) A Federal Court of Appeals has ordered a Florida county to implement a neighborhood pupil assignment plan that would leave intact three allNegro schools.
A tapestry by Sylvia Carewe was stolen last night from an exhibition at the Campus Center of Fordham University in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) Following are the roll-call votes, involving the education bill, by which the Senate today rejected an amendment by Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, to ease a national policy on school desegregation and then approved an amendment by John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, to require enforcement of school desegregation equally throughout the nation:
EVERY once in a while a member of the Wall Street community wants to let his hair down but will do so only if he is assured that he can have his say without being identified.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 18 Dr. George A. Manfredonia, former director of radiology and president of the medical board at Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn, died Monday in Hempstead General Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 381 Stewart Avenue.

TRENTON, Feb. 18 A high official of the State Commission of Investigation asserted today that Frank Sinatra was compelled to testify here last night primarily because the commission was determined to show that it commanded the power to compel virtually anyone it wanted to appear before it.
Two men were shot and killed and another was wounded in his left leg in a midtown building late last night by a fourth man with whom they had argued earier at a nearby bar. Their assailant escaped.

Robert Russell and Ludmila Ulehla, the two composers whose works made up a program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, are alike in that both as their music demonstrates are experienced hands and aware of the subtleties of their craft.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 18(AP) The Boston Celtics defeated the Phoenix Suns, 116-113, as Bailey Howell sank two free throws with 35 seconds left in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
Robert S. Bird, who had been a prize-winning reporter on The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Times, died last night at Bellevue Hospital after having suffered a heart attack on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 A foreign policy-making apparatus that previously had been largely hidden from public view was revealed today by President Nixon in his message to Congress on the state of the world.

Robert M. Morgenthau was sworn in yesterday as the city's third Deputy Mayor, and he took the occasion to twit the Nixon Administration for having forced him to resign as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. After Mayor Lindsay had administered the oath in the Blue Room of City Hall, Mr. Morgenthau said:

Red Skelton, the comedian and pantomimist, who on Jan. 29 appeared at the White House to inaugurate a series of evenings of entertainment at the Executive Mansion, is being dropped next season from the regular schedule of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Following, as made public by the White House, is the text of President Nixon's first annual foreign-affairs message to Congress, which was submitted today under the title "United States Foreign Policy for the 1970's: A New Strategy for Peace":
The 20-year-old son of Jesse Gray, Harlem rent strike leader, and another man were charged in Criminal Court with possession of 22 ounces of cocaine.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Feb. 18 (UPI) District Court Judge James A. Boyle filed today his inquest report and a transcript of the testimony in the death of Mary Jo Kopechne in Senator Edward M. Kennedy's car. The documents were not made public.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 All seven defendants in the Chicago conspiracy trial were acquitted today of plotting to incite a riot here during the 1968 Democratic National Convention, but five of them were convicted of seeking to promote a riot through individual acts.
WESTFIELD, N.J., Feb. 18 Two youths were held in $2,500 bail each today in connection with a two-alarm fire that extensively damaged the Masonic Temple at 311 Temple Place here yesterday.

The Olympia Press was enjoined by State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer yesterday from selling a paperback novel called "The Original Seven" because its title and cover closely resembled Irving Wallace's best seller, "The Seven Minutes."
The New York Board of Rabbis yesterday called on Governor Rockefeller to declare an emergency in the gravediggers strike as mediation efforts continued in attempts to settle the 38-day-old walkout.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Justice Department and LingTemco-Vought, Inc., one of the nation's largest conglomerate corporations, are attempting to negotiate a settlement of the Government's antitrust case against L-T-V's acquisition of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.
Blue-chip issues and the long-depressed oil group moved strongly in the forefront of a broad market advance yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 A House of Representatives member from New York who is organizing a Congressional boycott of the appearance of President Pompidou of France before Congress next Wednesday said today that more than one-fourth of house members would stay away from the session.

DUBLIN Ten years ago the National Gallery of Ireland was a more or less moribund Victorian institution with just a trickle of visitors to view its rich art treasures. Today this premier gallery has become a hub of cultural life and is now visited by thousands including many parties of American and British tourists.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 18 The Federal grand jury investigating the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski summoned three high officials of the United Mine Workers of America today, including the first member of the union's headquarters in Washington to be called here in the three-week investigation.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 18 Wilfred Burchett, a leftist Australian newsman known for his reports from the Communist side in Korea and Vietnam, was prevented today from coming to Australia to attend a memorial service for his brother.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Nixon was told by antipoverty researchers today that an experimental program of income subsidy among the working poor had provided evidence that his controversial welfare reform plan would work.
GENEVA "Do the major powers want to carry on on the basis of worldwide free trade, or is the world going to be carved up into regional groupings based on discriminatory preferential arrangements?"

THE Omar Sharif Bridge Circus, which has been touring North America for the last month, has been strengthened by the arrival from Italy of Pietro Forquet of Naples, one of the world's greatest players. He has resumed his celebrated partnership with Benito Garozzo of Rome. Their teammates are Sharif, Leon Yallouze and Claude Delmouly of Paris, and Giorgio Belladonna of Rome.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 18 Dr. Lee A. DuBridge, President Nixon's science adviser, said today that it would take 10 years to free the nation's highways of pollution-producing automobiles.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. Feb. 18 (UPI) Sixth-ranked Jacksonville University shook off a fullcourt press by 11th-ranked Florida State and posted an 8581 victory tonight before the beggest college basketball crowd in Florida history.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 17 The Rev. Bernard J. Ristuccia, chairman of the department of religious studies at Niagara University, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack at Mount St. Mary's Hospital in nearby Lewiston. He was 53 years old.
GENEVA, Feb. 18 The United States announced today its support of proposals designed to start a major international attack on barriers to world trade in 1971.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Is it advancing age, the habit of eating peanut butter on bananas just at bedtime, or perhaps only February? Whatever the cause, an entirely different class of people has been turning up lately there at the very foot of the day, in that disembodied moment between the last yawn and the first snore.

VISITORS to Florida's Everglades National Park who want something more than the usual water and land tours now have a fully charted and marked 99-mile wilderness waterway from Flamingo to Everglades City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 For three long days last week, six men and a woman sat in the sun outside or around a dining room table inside Villa 15 at the Key Biscayne Hotel in Florida, a short drive from President Nixon's house, debating the structure of sentences and paragraphs.
BONN, Feb. 18 Three armed Arabs suspected of trying to hijack an Israeli airliner were arrested last night at the Munich airport.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 (AP) Francis O. Boylon, president and chief executive officer of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, died yesterday, ap parently of a heart attack, at Boca Raton, Fla. He was 58 years old.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 18 (Reuters) S.Y. Agnon, co-winner of the 1966 Nobel prize for Literature, was buried today in the old cemetery on the Mount of Olives.
A woman who said she survived a massacre in the area of Songmy in South Vietnam said yesterday that American troops had entered her hamlet and had begun shooting children.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 (UPI) Lew Alcindor scored 12 of his 26 points in the second quarter tonight and led the Milwaukee Bucks to a 109-102 National Basketball Association victory over the San Francisco Warriors.

Two young singers associated in different ways with the Metropolitan Opera gave a joint concert at the New York Cultural Center last night and showed enough talent to suggest that the Met is doing something right. They were Frederica von Stade, a mezzosoprano, who is already singing small roles with the company, and George Allan Reid, who has worked with the Metropolitan Opera Studio.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The three Federal bank regulatory agencies ruled today that banks may not offer new savers premiums worth more than $5 at wholesale. For deposits of more than $5,000, the value of the premium can rise to $10.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 The Public Service Commission said today that it had rejected a proposed 13 per cent increase on the Consolidated Edison Company's steam rates and ordered an investigation to determine whether any of the $6.4-million in additional revenue the company asked for "is justified."

It is the singular and fundamental finding of New York State's Insurance Department that present automobile insurance policies are, for those obligated to rely on them, unsafe at any speed. The department has just released a carefully prepared report that recommends scrapping the present method of compensating traffic victims. This recommendation deserves sympathetic attention and action.

The New York Civil Liberties Union charged yesterday that policemen here "are showing a wholesale disregard for regulations" in arresting persons or issuing summonses for distributing political leaflets on the sidewalk.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 (UPI) Earl Monroe and Kevin Loughery combined for 47 points as the Baltimore Bullets defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 117-103, for the third straight time tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
TORONTO, Feb. 18 (UPI) The Toronto Maple Leafs rallied twice tonight to beat the Montreal Canadiens, 5-3, in a National Hockey League game.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 (AP) Informed sources reported today that B-52 bombing raids in South Vietnam had been halted for 36 hours while the planes, the biggest bombers the United States has, went into action for the first time against North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao troops threatening the Plaine des Jarres in Laos.
DETROIT, Feb. 18 (AP) Denny McLain spent 45 minutes today testifying before a Federal grand jury investigating interstate gambling, Federal officials said.

Mr. Rovensky had a long and successful career as a banker before he became chairman of the executive committee of American Car and Foundry in 1943. He reorganized the management and diversified the products of the concern, and became its chairman in 1951.

Jack R. Goldberg, the city's Commissioner of Social Services, declared yesterday that "most" mothers on welfare, as well as his department, believe that "employment where feasible should be encouraged."

Walter J. Minton, President of G.P. Putnam's Sons, the publishers, and Miss Marion Whitehorn were married here last Sunday. State Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey performed the private ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18 Six of 10 adults living in the nation's metropolitan centers would move to less urbanized areas if they could live anywhere they wished, the Gallup Poll reported today. The four of 10 remaining like it where they are, according to the poll.
Paced by the Krause brothers, Walter and Wayne, New York University's undefeated fencing team beat Columbia, 15-12, last night before a standing-room crowd of 200 at the Washington Square gym.
The American Stock Exchange posted its first advance in five sessions yesterday. Most issues closed higher in active trading.

Coatless workmen whistled. Small children, unswaddled from leggings and mittens, babbled with joy. Overcoat buttons were undone and mufflers pocketed. Hummocks of begrimed snow dwindled into oily puddles. In Central Park, a young man and a young girl walked hand in hand across the deserted Mall.

PROFESSIONAL ski racing, long a red-ink item in the snow-sport's ledgers, may soon be writing in blue. The American Broadcasting Company said yesterday it would tape two profesional events this winter. The pictures subsequently will be televised across the United States ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration took its first step into third-generation space vehicles today by asking the aerospace industry to submit designs of engines for an orbital ferry.
The driver of a Brooklyn gypsy cab was shot yesterday morning as he struggled with a holdup man.
LONDON, Feb. 19 David Percival's "Girlfriend," at the Apollo Theater, is the latest of a long line of plays designed to keep the West End public painlessly abreast with modern youth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) Following is a transcript of remarks made by President Nixon to news correspondents on Monday during a briefing on his foreign-policy message. The briefing was conducted on the understanding that its contents would not be disclosed until today, when the message was sent to Congress.

The cancellation Monday night by six public television stations of an hour-long documentary critical of American foreign policy was assailed yesterday by an association of public television producers and by James Day, president of National Educational Television.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 18 Prime Minister John Gorton announced in Canberra today that Australia would sign the treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons, but would not ratify it until her reservations were resolved.

MIAMI, Feb. 18 Phil Johnson a trainer, made an error of judgment today and couldn't have been more delighted. While he expected Naskra to perform creditably in today's $33,350 Everglades Stakes at Hialeah, he warned that the colt was not at his best.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 18 Judge J. Smith Henley ruled in Federal District Court today that the conditions in the Arkansas Penitentiary were unconstitutional and that the two state prison farms would have to be closed unless the conditions improved.

Austin Carr, one of the most discussed collegiate basketball stars, moves into Madison Square Garden tonight as a vital cog on the Notre Dame team that faces New York University in the second game of a double-header.
Arthur Godfrey has begun making television commercials for Axion that frankly admit the detergent is a water pollutant, his office said last night.
BOSTON, Feb. 18 Residents of Randolph, a community of Boston, were asked to stop smoking today and to donate the money they would have spent for cigarettes and tobacco to a scholarship fund.

WASHINTGON, Feb. 18 (UPI) President Nixon's proposed welfare breakthroughs minimum annual incomes for working families showed new strength in Congress today. Sources expected approval soon by the House Ways and Means Committee.
Arturo Alessandri Rodriguez, former dean of faculty of law of the University of Chile, died here Friday of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

The hazards of fortune on Broadway are such that within four days an unheralded and unsung play opens and proves to be a winner, while a musical in preparation for several years ends its run after four "public" performannces and 28 previews with a loss of $400,000.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 18 Oliver Smith scored 22 points and picked off 10 rebounds as Fairleigh-Dickinson defeated C.W. Post, 65-58, tonight. It was Fairleigh's 11th victory against nine defeats. Post is 10-11.
AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 18 Until recently, James Street had never seen Chicago or Washington or those "tall buildings" that Texans identify with Times Square.
NEWARK, Feb. 18 In what was apparently a show of strength and a test of a court order, David Selden, national president of the American Federation of Teachers, was arrested and jailed here today.
FLINT, Mich., Feb. 19 The jury hearing the Algiers Motel conspiracy trial will begin deliberating next week after a surprisingly brief offer of evidence today by the defense.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Nixon cautioned the Soviet Union today against any attempts to manipulate Middle Eastern tensions for its own great-power interests.
The verdict in the Chicago conspiracy trial brought a range of contrasting reactions from individuals and organizations yesterday.
WASHINGTON Mrs. Erma Striner has a pleasant apartment with comfortable places to sit and pretty things to see. She thinks that people who live in public housing projects should have the same.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler, one of Wall Street's leading institutional brokerage houses, charged yesterday that the new commission schedule proposed by the New York Stock Exchange was "grossly inequitable."

It did not look like the setting for a murder. Not at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. In cheery sunshine, strollers and dog-walkers left footprints in the still-white snow. Children laughed and shrilled in the playgrounds while their mothers chatted serenely. Sneakered men clambered aboard their craft in the boat basin.
MICHAEL LAX'S first encounter with glassmaking may have been by accident, but his present involvement is definitely by design.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges, for years one of the most powerful opponents of abortion reform, indicated today that his stand was easing and that he might support some form of liberalization.

Former Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that he was beginning a statewide series of speeches to warn Democrats that "the Limousine liberals... the left-lefts, leftovers and left-outs," were destroying the party's chances to win this year's gubernatorial election.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 State Department officials said that tonight's attack on the United States Embassy in Manila was the work of a handful of militant students and had not damaged United States relations with the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The National Transportation Safety Board recommended today that all ocean and coastal fishing vessels carry inflatable life rafts sufficient to accommodate all hands and that all life preservers be equipped with waterproof flashlights.

THE series of three New England shows that al ways follows Westminster will end with competition in Providence on Saturday and New Haven on Sunday. The Hartford event that began the series was held last Saturday. All three are in the 1,250dog range.

After weeks of saying that St. John's would win its third straight Metropolitan Intercollegiate title, and two days of counting up real and imaginary points, Steve Bartold, the Redmen's coach, had to sweat out the final event on the program last night at the 102d Engineers Armory before his prediction would come true.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 18 President Tito of Yugoslavia criticized developed nations today for the terms on which they grant bilateral loans to developing countries "under unfavorable conditions, high interest rates and short terms for repayment."
PARIS, Feb. 18 (Reuters) A Paris court ruled today that five members of the staff of Le Figaro had a right to share in the running of the morning newspaper.

A 16-year-old football player at James Monroe High School in the Bronx died Tuesday night of an overdose of heroin and yesterday another 16-yearold died in the Bronx, apparently also the victim of a narcotics overdose.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 18 Organized labor, stressing the importance of the 1970 off-year elections, is planning its most extensive and thorough drive to register members as voters and get them to the polls.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 The Soviet Union disclosed today that it had withdrawn from the European Community of Writers, an organization promoting an exchange of East-West ideas, because of the group's criticism of the expulsion of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn from the Soviet writers union.

VERONA, N.J., Feb. 18 Robert A. Cooke, who retired in 1966 after 30 years as traffic manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 71 years old and lived at 20 Westover Road.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 (UPI) Temple led by Tom Wieczerak's 19 points, defeated Long Island University, 80-55, tonight in a college basketball game.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 18 Premier Gaston Eyskens told Parliament today how he intended to remodel the Belgian state, founded in 1830 after the Belgians separated from the Netherlands.
Edward J. O'Malley Jr., an internationally known usedbook dealer, died of a heart attack last Friday at his home, 615 West 186th Street. He was 65 years old.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company registered its record $1.57-billion 30-year debenture offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. In the process it also filled in most of the unanswered questions about the record-breaking offering to the world's largest stockholder family, which now totals some 3.1 million persons.
MIAMI, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Miami Dolphins dismissed their head coach, George Wilson, today and named Don Shula of the Baltimore Colts to replace him.
Hunter College's assembly hall was filled to capacity last night to hear several speakers denounce the verdicts at the trial of the Chicago 7 and condemn the charges here against 13 Black Panthers.
YUMA, Ariz., Feb. 18 Al Ferrara is probably the only 13-year-old kid from Brooklyn who performed at Carnegie Hall and then went on to become a major league baseball player.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 18 Joe Savage of Roselle (N.J.) Catholic High School sought a national schoolboy mile record today on Lawrenceville School's 10-lap board track but had to settle for the fastest indoor mile by an Eastern runner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The Justice Department's antitrust chief told Congress today that the rate of corporate mergers had slackened in the last year. He said any attempt to legislate tough new restrictions should be delayed until the trend and its causes became clearer.
The current decline in interest rates gained force yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended Kennedy, Cabot Co. of Beverly Hills, Calif., and two individuals for violating antifraud rules.
On Trans World Airlines Flight 1 next Wednesday passengers aboard the Boeing 747 will be watching Robert Redford glide over the ski slopes in "Downhill Racer."

ALBANY, Feb. 18 The Assembly today approved a $30.7million mass-transit loan bill, all but $6-million of which will go to improve maintenance on New York City's subway system and metropolitan area commuter railroad lines.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 18 North Vietnamese supported by tanks mounted their fourth major attack against the airfield in the Plaine des Jarres last night.

"IT is hard to convey such experiences," writes Robert Coles, "such a world, to those who don't see it and feel it and smell it and hear it. It is even harder to describe that world as it is met and apprehended and suffered by hundreds of thousands of parents and children."
Christmas Club A Corporation, no longer content with helping banks help you to be a Santa's helper, is going into the advertising business.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (Reuters) William M. Kunstler, one of the defense lawyers in the Chicago conspiracy trial, called for mass street demonstrations against the American legal system when he addressed a protest rally tonight.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 The State Court of Appeals ruled today that the right of free speech did not permit the use of the American flag in "dishonorable" ways as a form of protest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 With an inconclusive challenge to the House leadership, Democratic liberals opened today a long-range campaign to reform the institutions of the House, including the seniority system.
Short-interest positions on the New York Stock Exchange on Feb. 13 were slightly below the month-earlier figure, the exchange reported yesterday.

JULES FEIFFER is a very funny, very savage man. A comedian with a conscience is always a dangerous fellow to have around. In "The White House Murder Case," which opened last night at the Circle in the Square and which I saw at a preview, Mr. Feiffer takes a man-sized swipe at our modern society.

St. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 18 It was like Alice Through the Looking Glass. On the same field where Marvelous Mary Throneberry and Roadblock Jones had stumbled in dim years past, the affluent young Mets of 1970 opened their spring training season today in sunshine and jubilant commotion.
The public accounting profession proposed yesterday that stiff new rules be adopted to prevent corporations from changing their accounting methods to improve their earnings results.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Feb. 18--Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today at a conference of United States Ambassadors to African countries that the United States would identify itself with the "unfinished business" of winning political freedom for black populations living under minority white rule in southern Africa.

IN the lives of certain Americans there comes a mo ment when the man who has been patiently conning them pulls off his dark glasses, his hat, his hairpiece, or whatever his impenetable disguise of the day, and asks, "Do you know who I am?" And the answer, incredulous at first, and then in a torrent of amazed belief: "Why... you're...ALLEN FUNT!"

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18 As Harvard University moves into what its retiring president, Nathan M. Pusey, calls a "fresh chapter" in its history, the campus has begun to speculate on what kind of a man should be sought to lead it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Intensive studies conducted recently by the Administration in South Vietnam and private reports from the area have led President Nixon to see "tangible progress" in the "Vietnamization" of the war and success "to date" in the pacification of the Vietnam countryside.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange retreated from the outset yesterday as buyers held back following the decline on Wall Street Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Senate voted today to cut off Federal aid to school districts that fail to desegregate, even though their racial imbalance is a product of residential patterns and not illegal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18-- Two weeks ago Leon F. Panetta, director of the Office of Civil Rights for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, was reasonably satisfied with the course that the Administration was taking in school desegregation.

ATHENS, Feb. 18 A statement by Tass, the Soviet press agency, accusing the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of seeking to bring Cyprus under its control was seen by Western diplomats in Athens today as an effort by Moscow to stir anti-NATO feeling in Turkey.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 President Nixon urged the Senate today to ratify the 1949 United Nations agreement outlawing genocide.
Prices moved narrowly yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. At the outset, stocks edged ahead but, by the close, these early gains were cut back or reversed.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday after selling pressure erased most of the gains achieved earlier in the day.

A recommendation was made last night that all first grades in the Roman Catholic elementary schools of the Diocese of Brooklyn be dropped in September and that the second grades be abolished next year unless state aid is provided.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 George W. Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, termed "absolutely ridiculous" today the concept that housing construction and improved maintenance could be achieved under New York City's rent control law.

A selective List of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where indicated.

PARIS, Friday, Feb. 19 An international aid official, saying that lack of jobs was the most severe problem facing the developing countries, asserted today that companies investing in those countries should forgo much of their labor-saving machinery and take advantage of cheap labor.

On a knoll overlooking a sandy strip of a tiny island in Jamaica Bay is a baited trap. It has been placed there by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Its purpose is to catch a dog that has been thriving without human help for many months, perhaps as long as two years.
SYRACUSE, Feb. 19 (AP) Archie Clark scored 28 points tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 133-114 victory over the Detroit Pistons in a National Basketball Association game.
ATLANTA, Feb. 19 (AP) Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves signed a two-year contract today for a reported $125,000 a year.
MANILA, Feb. 19 The United States Ambassador in Manila, in an unusually sharp diplomatic note today, protested over the mob assault on the American Embassy last night.

George Maldonado began his program in Carnegie Recital Hall last night with Schumann's "Dichterliebe" cycle and ended it with Vaughan Williams's seven "Songs of Travel." These proved to be the most congenial vehicles for the baritone, who gave his first recital here a little more than a year ago.

HONG KONG, Friday, Feb. 20 (AP) The Hanoi radio said today that President Nixon's foreign-policy statement showed that his Administration wanted to win the war in Vietnam through force rather than negotiation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Critics of G. Harrold Carswell's nomination to the Supreme Court said today that grass roots opposition to the nomination was rising and that they planned to mobilize it to bring pressure on uncommitted Senators to vote against confirmation.
MIAMI, Feb. (AP) Exhausted but smiling, 33 Cuban refugees stepped ashore here today following 18 days of near starvation on a desert island where they lived off crayfish and crabs.
PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 19 (AP) General Motors announced today the recall of 4,269 school buses and 21,681 trucks because of a possible brake defect.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb, 19 A mistrial was declared in a murder trial today following the arrest of a Queens man on a charge of offering to fix the jury for $6,000.

Denny McLain, the pitcher who won 31 games for the Detroit Tigers in 1968, was suspended indefinitely yesterday by Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, because of "1967 bookmaking activities and his associations at that time."

Notre Dame and Manhattan, headed for postseason tournament bids, ran into a flock of big scares last night before they finally subdued their opponents in a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.

ONTARIO, N.Y. Feb. 19 The Westinghouse Electric Corporation expects its nuclear power business to operate at a profit this year. John W. Simpson, president of Power Systems, told 110 utility analysts here today.

Mrs. Doris M. Brixey and Arthur Wallace Pope, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gioia M. Pope, to Carey Buckingham Swope Jr., son of Mr. and and Mrs. Swope of Baltimore and Juniper Point, West Boothbay Harbor, Me.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UPI) Jim Pappin scored the winning goal for the Black Hawks with less than nine minutes to play tonight as Chicago scored a 3-2 victory over Minnesota, extending the North Stars nonwinning streak to 17 games.

WASHINGTON, Feb.19 Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, who was a leading critic of the Johnson Administration's policy on Vietnam, turned his attention to the Nixon Administration today, accusing it of misleading the nation "over the issues at stake" in the war.
THE subjec is discussed as casually today as a visit to the dentist Everyone either knows or has heard of an adolescent who is undergoing psychiatric treatment.
WOODS HOLE, Mass. "Any race that does not adapt, will have to disappear," says Albert Szent-Gyorgyi, the biologist. "The dinosaurs disappeared, and man may have to disappear too."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 More than one-fourth of the airports in the country used by the airlines have no fire-fighting equipment, the Air Line Pilots Association reported today.
CAIRO, Feb. 19 Egyptians found nothing to praise and much to object to today in President Nixon's comments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The sale of the first Federally guaranteed securities issued by private enterprise to provide funds for housing construction was announced today by Secretary of Housing George Romney.
The Federal Reserve System gave no sign of easing its policy of strict monetary restraint during the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.
Willie (The Actor) Sutton, who, gained national notoriety as a bank robber and escape artist, applied for welfare assistance yesterday in Brooklyn.
The following reports were provided by the operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at times indicated in parentheses:

At one time or other in his serendipitous careers, Mr. Flanders was the editor of a technical magazine, a pig farmer, a wartime production administrator, a lecturer, a banker, a machinists' apprentice, a draftsman, the trustee of two universities, and, at the age of 67, a freshman Senator.
The Department of Social Services yesterday announced a massive program to assure that all of the city's poor will be counted in the 1970 Federal census.

The city's Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that it was deferring enforcement of a regulation that would require retail food merchants here to show the price per unit for some items.
For the first time this year, riders on the Penn Central's New Haven and Harlem Divisions have a written apology for a severe delay.

SMOKE RISE, N.J., Feb. 19 The engagement of Miss Lindsay Brooke Davis to David Nelson Deinzer has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Davis Jr., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon W. Deinzer.
A charge that two-thirds of Puerto Rican college students are dropping out because of the "insensitivity" of colleges to their needs was made yesterday by Louis Nieves, executive director of Aspira.
IT is easy to understand that the little guy is upset over the New York Stock Exchange's plan to raise commission rates substantially on smaller trades those of 300 shares or less.

After jouncing and bouncing in his car on a trip through the city's pitted, potholed streets, Transportation Administrator Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff ordered yesterday a ban on all street-opening permits.
PORT ST. JOE, Fla., Feb. 19 (UPI) The state authorities said today that the captain of a United Fruit Company freighter had been arrested for releasing oil into St. Joseph's Bay.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 Organized labor's top leaders emphasized today that workers must seek substantial wage gains this year to offset price increases and to achieve improvement in buying power.
BROCKTON, Mass., Feb. 19 (AP) Rita Warren of Brockton was convicted in District Court today on three charges in connection with her fight to restore prayer in Brockton public schools.

President Nixon took a step toward removing an ugly blot from this country's international posture yesterday when he urged the Senate to ratify a United Nations genocide convention that has been pending for nearly 21 years.

Miss Harriet Hauberg Sweeney, whose father, the late Edward Cleaveland Sweeney, was president of the Explorers Club, plans to be married early in September to Photographer Technician 2d Cl. Peter Carl Droste, who is serving with Navy intelligence in Japan.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 19 Objections voiced by the Soviet delegate, Yakov A. Malik, are understood to have prevented an appeal by the Big Four today for restoration of a cease-fire in the Middle East.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 Directors of the North American Rockwell Corporation today elected Willard F. Rockwell Jr., chairman, as chief executive officer and Robert Anderson, executive vice president, as president and chief operating officer.
The Board of Education decided yesterday that all future school construction and modernization contracts after May 1 would require on-the-job training programs for blacks and Puerto Ricans.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Feb. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Jamieson have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Betsy Jamieson, to Thomas Watkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Watkins of Montclair. A June wedding is planned.

WESTBURY, L.I., Feb. 19 Joe MacDonald, in his own, quiet way one of the more talented reinsmen on harness racing's big wheel, drove Valley Girl, to victory in tonight's main event at Roosevelt Raceway. It was the Nova Scotiaborn horseman's only driving assignment on the nine-race card and gave him 10 winners in 50 starts at the current winter meeting.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 The verdict in the Chicago conspiracy trial was described today as a hard-fought compromise, with three of the women jurors holding out for acquittal of all seven defendants until a crucial conference in the Palmer House Hotel late Tuesday night.

The city asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to reconsider a recent decision approving a "restructuring" of commuter fares on the New Haven Division of the Penn Central. The city contended the the restructuring was unfair to riders and had been rejected by the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The United States Civil Rights Commission recommended today that Federal installations be withheld or even removed from areas lacking low-cost nondiscriminatory housing for their employes.
JERUSALEM "We are the People of the Book, and so help me we are going to live up to our name," Mayor Teddy Kollek said the other day.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 19 A Green Beret team commander said today that he and Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald of Patchogue, L.I., discussed the ritualistic murders of the actress, Sharon Tate and three of her friends only a couple of days before the doctor's family was found dead at Fort Bragg.

OSAKA, Japan, Feb. 12 The young man stood lounging against the window of the Miami Coffee Shop, three levels beneath the surface of the main street, his hands deep into his tight trousers, his heavily pomaded black hair fringing a face that would be pale and pasty for a Caucasian.

HONG KONG, Feb. 19 (Reuters) The Soviet Union warned China today against new "adventurist" moves. On the eve of United States-Chinese talks in Warsaw, the Moscow radio said in a Chinese-language broadcast that Peking's trade shift from Communist countries to the West had caused damage to China's economy.

One of the most valuable of this country's postwar ventures in intellectual and cultural exchange has been cut back savagely in the last two years. It is the Fulbright scholarship program, named for the Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee who conceived it in 1946.

SINCE ski thieves seem to have replaced leg frac tures and long lift lines as a major topic of conversation around snow running centers, Harry Vallin, the owner of the Scandinavian Ski Shops, was sought out yesterday in the hope that he could offer some suggestions about coping with the problem. Vallin, who operates stores in midtown Manhattan, Garden City and Scarsdale, could help.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Periodic charges that certain news reports have been "staged" by broadcasting networks and stations are under quiet and extended study by a Congressional subcommittee.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 19 Mayor Julius M. Wilensky said today that he had told the police to "pull out all the stops" in their search for the killer of the 17-year-old daughter of a local policeman.
LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 19 (UPI) Detroit Tiger manager Mayo Smith, said today the suspension of Denny McLain came as a "shock" to him.

Dr. Phillip Shaw, professor of English at Brooklyn College and a specialist in reading and learning skills, died yesterday in Adelphi Hospital, after an illness of several weeks. He was 60 years old and lived at 3824 Farragut Road, Brooklyn.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 19 (UPI) Rod Funseth endured cold weather and gusty winds today to card a three-under-par 67 and take a three-stroke lead after the first round of the $100,000 San Antonio open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 A report that criticizes cuts in Federal research funds and warns that they are hampering the productivity of American scientists was released without comment today by the White House.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 Talmadge (Tab) Prince of Dublin, Ga., a race driver who observed his 32d birthday on Monday, was killed in a threecar crash this afternoon at Daytona International Speedway.

NEWARK, Feb. 19 Tensions rose sharply in the city's school dispute today as 46 more striking teachers on picket lines were arrested and parent groups heatedly demanded an end to the walkout in an emotional two-hour meeting with Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio.
The 10-cent increase in city subway and bus fares and rising food prices pushed the Consumer Price Index higher by 0.7 per cent last month in the New York area.
Feb. 19 Daniel C.C. Gilbert, an architect who practiced in New York and the Tarrytowns for more than 30 years, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital. He was 56 years old.

THOSE who equate the crafts of Norway with the rest of contemporary Scandinavia may be in for one or two surprises at the exhibition of Norwegian handicrafts that opened yesterday at the American Federation of Arts gallery.
PARIS, Feb. 19 A Communist and a Gaullist asserted their patriotism the other night before several million Frenchman, but neither would accept the other's claim to it.

Two groups of economists issued forecasts yesterday suggesting that the Council of Economic Advisers may have been too optimistic in predicting a flat half. Both were optimistic, however, in forecasting a lessening of inflationary pressures.

RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 19 A round of conferences involving high school teachers, students and parents is seeking a formula to end racial conflict in this municipality's 1,600-student high school, so the school can reopen next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today the thrust of President Nixon's welfare reforms to provide a minimum annual income for working families.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 19 President Nixon's report to Congress on foreign policy has been read with deep satisfaction in Israel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Feb. 14 were both above the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

At least eight business trade associations, representing a broad cross-section of American business, have set or recently completed plans to leave New York for Washington because of a desire to be closer to the Government and because of the high cost of operating here.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 19 Tom Seaver combed his hair, put on a striped shirt, sat on a wooden stool in the locker room and tackled the question of the moment: What will keep the New York Mets from growing fat and complacent so soon after reaching the top?

LEADING from strength, the New York City Opera opened its spring (spring?) season last night at the State Theater with its big hit of a few months ago. That was, of course, Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" with Beverly Sills in the title role. This is the "Lucia" cleanly and logically staged by Tito Capobianco, with attractive sets by Marsha Louise Eck, and with several major cuts opened, including the Wolfscrag scene between Edgardo and Enrico.

STRBSKE PLESO, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 19 (AP) The Soviet Union's cross-country skiers won the men's 40-kilometer relay today before 10,000 spectators in an exciting race that gave the Soviet its fith gold medal of the world Nordic skiing championships. Only seconds separated the first three teams.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 19 The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, today called the current enemy offensive in Laos "the most important" yet.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 19 A Tennessee official of the United Mine Workers of America told newsmen today that the Federal grand jury investigating the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski was "trying to pin" the slaying on the union and "is on the wrong track."

Forty-one young men and women were arraigned on narcotics charges yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. The figure set a record for the number of narcotics suspects arraigned there in one day.

In approving Judge G. Harrold Carswell by a vote of 13 to 4, the Senate Judiciary Committee has expressed an opinion so overtly political as to make it a useless guide for Senate action on his nomination to the Supreme Court. Distinguished legal scholars who testified before the committee felt that their views fell on minds so determined to consent that they were closed to advice.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Feb. 19 (UPI) A court clerk from Boston, traveling under state police escort, took custody today of the judge's report and the secret transcript of the testimony on Mary Jo Kopechne's death in Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy's car last July.
BOSTON, Feb. 19 (AP) Two students who took part in a two-day occupation of Boston University's administration building last December have been expelled, the university announced today.
Citizens for Clean Air, Inc. will benefit from a supper party at L'Etoile restaurant, 1 East 59th Street, next Thursday.

Leon Frechtel, a prosecutor at the Nuremberg War Crimes Trials who left Government service to become an apparel manufacturer, died at his home yesterday after a heart attack. He was 57 years old and lived at 1080 Fifth Avenue.
A coalition of 40 organizations urged the Board of Education yesterday to suspend the community school-board elections scheduled to be held throughout the city on March 19.
